Surprisingly, the <i>tanna</i> reverts back to his earlier claim: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> the case that capital punishments may be administered <b>even on Shabbat?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> by way of a verbal analogy: <b>“You shall kindle no fire throughout your habitations</b> on Shabbat day” (Exodus 35:3) <b>and below it says,</b> at the end of the chapter dealing with murderers: <b>“And these things shall be for you a statute of judgment to you throughout your generations in all your habitations”</b> (Numbers 35:29).
<b>Just as</b> the term <b>“habitations” stated below,</b> in Numbers, means <b>in the court,</b> where judgment is performed, <b>so too,</b> the term <b>“habitations” stated here</b> means <b>in the court,</b> i.e., in the place where judges preside. <b>And the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“You shall kindle no</b> fire.” Since one of the court-imposed death penalties is burning, which is performed by kindling fire, then evidently, court-imposed death penalties do not override Shabbat.
With the above conclusion in mind, the Gemara comments: <b>What, is it not</b> the case that the opinion of the school of Rabbi Yishmael is in accordance with that of <b>Rabbi Natan, who said</b> that the prohibition against kindling fire <b>was</b> singled <b>out to divide,</b> and therefore lighting a fire is punishable by <i>karet</i> and stoning? <b>And</b> if so, <b>the reason</b> why capital punishments are not administered on Shabbat is <b>that the Merciful One writes: “You shall kindle no</b> fire,” from which it may be inferred that <b>if it were not so,</b> then court-imposed capital punishment <b>would override</b> Shabbat. In other words, the positive mitzva of legal execution would override the prohibition against lighting a fire on Shabbat, which incurs <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> there is no proof from here, as it can be claimed that the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> from the school of Rabbi Yishmael is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that kindling fire is an ordinary prohibition. The Gemara retorts: <b>And let it even be</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. You</b> can <b>say that</b> when <b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> that <b>kindling was</b> singled <b>out as a prohibition,</b> he was referring to <b>kindling alone,</b> i.e., that lighting a regular fire is only a regular prohibition.
Conversely, the <b>kindling by the court</b> for the execution of burning <b>is</b> actually the <b>cooking of</b> a leaden <b>wick.</b> Since execution by burning involves melting, or cooking, a piece of lead, called a wick, and pouring it into the mouth of the convict, it therefore constitutes the prohibited labor of cooking, which is a different prohibition than kindling fire.
<b>And Rav Sheshet said</b> in this regard: <b>What</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> between <b>cooking a wick,</b> which is performed for court-imposed capital punishments, and <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> between the <b>cooking of herbs</b> used to dye curtains for the Tabernacle, from whose work the list of prohibited labors on Shabbat is derived? Since the court-imposed death penalty involves the prohibited labor of cooking, which according to all opinions incurs <i>karet</i>, this apparently indicates that without the special verse that renders this prohibited, one would have said that a positive mitzva overrides a prohibition for which one is liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara rejects this argument as well. <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: This <i>tanna</i></b> does <b>not</b> raise the possibility that a court-administered death penalty might override Shabbat <b>because a positive mitzva comes and overrides a prohibition. Rather,</b> he entertains this option <b>because he learns this by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, <b>and this is what</b> he <b>is saying: How do I establish</b> the verse <b>“Every one who profanes it shall surely be put to death”</b> (Exodus 31:14)? This applies <b>to other</b> prohibited <b>labors, except for court-imposed capital punishment. However,</b> it could be said that <b>court-imposed capital punishment overrides Shabbat, by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference:

Daf 7a

<b>If</b> the Temple <b>service,</b> which includes the sacrifice of offerings, <b>is</b> so <b>severe that it overrides Shabbat,</b> as offerings were brought on Shabbat, and yet the <i>halakha</i> of <b>murder overrides it,</b> i.e., the obligation to execute a sentenced convict overrides the Temple service, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to one sentenced to death: <b>“You shall take him from My altar, that he may die”</b> (Exodus 21:14), then in the case of <b>Shabbat, which is overridden by</b> the Temple <b>service, is it not right that</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>murder should</b> likewise override it?
§ The Gemara analyzes a puzzling statement in the above <i>baraita</i>. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the claim: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> the case that capital punishments may be administered even on Shabbat, <b>which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>stated</b> in an unexplained reversion to his previous suggestion? The Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> he <b>is saying:</b> The <i>a fortiori</i> reasoning can be refuted, as the obligation <b>to bury a corpse with no one</b> available <b>to bury it [<i>met mitzva</i>] can prove</b> otherwise, <b>as</b> the obligation to bury a <i>met mitzva</i> <b>overrides</b> the Temple <b>service, and</b> yet <b>it does not override Shabbat.</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>then</b> retracted his statement and <b>said</b> that one can claim that <b>the burial of a <i>met mitzva</i> overrides Shabbat by</b> means of the same <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> the Temple <b>service overrides Shabbat,</b> and <b>the burial of a <i>met mitzva</i> overrides</b> it.
The Gemara pauses in the middle of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference to explain this last point. This is derived <b>from</b> the superfluous phrase <b>“or for his sister”</b> in the verse “He shall not make himself ritually impure for his father, or for his mother, for his brother, or for his sister, when they die” (Numbers 6:7), which is referring to a nazirite. This verse teaches that even a nazirite on his way to sacrifice the Paschal lamb must render himself ritually impure to bury a <i>met mitzva</i>. The Gemara resumes the <i>a fortiori</i> inference: If so, as <b>Shabbat is overridden by</b> the Temple <b>service, is it not right that the burial of a <i>met mitzva</i> should override it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall kindle no</b> fire throughout your habitations on Shabbat day” (Exodus 35:3).
This concludes Rav Shimi bar Ashi’s interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>, that the <i>tanna</i> suggested that a court-administered death penalty might override Shabbat not because of the principle that a positive mitzva overrides a prohibition, but due to a potential <i>a fortiori</i> inference. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to that which entered his mind at the outset, that</b> the assumption of the <i>tanna</i> was indeed based on the principle that <b>a positive mitzva comes and overrides a prohibition, what</b> is the meaning of the clause: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> the case that capital punishments may be administered even on Shabbat, <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>said?</b> How should the <i>baraita</i> be explained according to the initial interpretation?
The Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying:</b> It would have been possible to say the following: <b>How do I establish</b> the verse <b>“Every one who profanes it shall surely be put to death”</b> (Exodus 31:14)? This applies <b>to other</b> prohibited <b>labors, except for court-imposed capital punishment. However, court-imposed capital punishment overrides Shabbat, as a positive mitzva comes and overrides a prohibition.</b>
The <i>tanna</i> <b>then</b> retracted his statement and <b>said:</b> You can <b>say that we stated</b> the principle <b>that a positive mitzva comes and overrides a prohibition,</b> yet this is true for a regular <b>prohibition alone.</b> However, <b>did you hear that it overrides a prohibition that includes <i>karet</i>?</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>then said,</b> hinting at a counter-claim: <b>Is that not to say,</b> with regard to the principle that <b>a positive mitzva overrides a prohibition,</b> that <b>the prohibition is more stringent than</b> the positive mitzva? After all, the court punishes one who violates a prohibition with lashes, which is not the case for a failure to uphold a positive mitzva. <b>And</b> yet by Torah law <b>the positive mitzva comes and overrides it.</b>
If so, <b>what difference</b> is it <b>to me</b> if it is a case of <b>a minor stringency and what difference</b> is it <b>to me</b> if it is <b>a major stringency?</b> Once the Torah has stated that a positive mitzva supersedes a prohibition, there should be no difference between a relatively stringent prohibition and a lenient one. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not kindle.”</b> In sum, the Gemara has not found a clear proof for the opinion that a positive mitzva supersedes a prohibition that incurs <i>karet</i>.
Consequently, the Gemara suggests a different interpretation. The superfluous phrase “with her” indeed teaches that the obligation of levirate marriage does not override the prohibition with regard to women with whom relations are forbidden. However, this derivation is required not because one might have thought that a positive mitzva supersedes a prohibition that incurs <i>karet</i>. <b>Rather,</b> this phrase <b>is necessary</b> because it could <b>enter your mind to say: Let this</b> case of <b>a brother’s wife,</b> to whom the mitzva of levirate marriage applies, <b>be</b> treated in accordance with a well-established hermeneutical principle: <b>A matter that was included in a generalization, but emerged to teach, emerged to teach not just about itself but to teach about the entire generalization.</b>
The Gemara explains the application of this principle to the current case. Since the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife is included in the general prohibition with regard to women with whom relations are forbidden, it can be claimed that the <i>halakha</i> of levirate marriage renders not only a brother’s childless wife permitted, but in this case it renders permitted all women with whom relations are usually forbidden. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that clarifies this hermeneutical principle: <b>A matter that was included in a generalization, but emerged</b> to teach, emerged to teach not just about itself but to teach about the entire generalization. <b>How so?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> provides an example of this principle by citing a verse: <b>“But the soul that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace-offerings</b> that belong to the Lord, <b>with his ritual impurity upon him,</b> that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20). <b>But aren’t peace-</b>offerings <b>included in</b> the general category <b>of</b> all <b>consecrated offerings? And why were they</b> explicitly <b>singled out</b> from of the rest in the above verse? <b>To draw an analogy between them and to say to you: Just as peace-</b>offerings <b>are unique</b> in that they are <b>consecrated for the altar, so too,</b> this <i>halakha</i> that one who eats of them is liable to receive <i>karet</i> applies to <b>all</b> food that is <b>consecrated for the altar,</b> which <b>excludes</b> objects that are <b>consecrated for the Temple maintenance.</b>
The above <i>baraita</i> provided an example of the principle that an item singled out from a general category teaches a <i>halakha</i> with regard to the entire category. <b>Here too,</b> one can argue: <b>This</b> case of <b>a brother’s wife was included in</b> the general category of <b>all</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden, and why was she singled out? To compare to her and say to you: Just as</b> a childless <b>brother’s wife is permitted, so too, all</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden are likewise permitted.</b>
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Is</b> it <b>comparable? There,</b> in the case cited as an example of this hermeneutical principle, <b>the generalization,</b> i.e., all offerings, are included <b>in the prohibition</b> against eating offerings while ritually impure, <b>and the detailed</b> case of peace-offerings is also included <b>in the prohibition.</b> Consequently, it can be said that the specific case was singled out to teach about the entire category. By contrast, <b>here,</b> in the case of levirate marriage with forbidden relatives, <b>the generalization</b> is included <b>in the prohibition</b> against engaging in forbidden relations, <b>and</b> yet <b>the detailed case is permitted.</b> Therefore, it cannot be said that the detail has been singled out so as to clarify some aspect of the general category; rather, its <i>halakha</i> differs from the rest.
Instead, this case <b>is comparable only to</b> those that fit a different hermeneutical principle, concerning <b>a matter that was included in a generalization but emerged to discuss a new matter.</b> If a novel aspect or special ruling is taught with regard to a specific case within a broader general category, <b>then you cannot return it to its generalization</b> even for other matters, to the extent that this case has been entirely removed from the general category <b>until the Torah explicitly returns it</b> to its generalization. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a matter that was included in a generalization but emerged to discuss a new matter, you may not return it to its generalization until the Torah explicitly returns it</b> to its generalization.
<b>How so?</b> The <i>baraita</i> provides an example of this principle. With regard to the guilt-offering of a leper, the verse states: <b>“And he shall slaughter the sheep in the place where they slaughter the sin-offering and the burnt-offering, in the place of the Sanctuary; for as the sin-offering is the priest’s, so is the guilt-offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:13). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “As the sin-offering</b>…<b>so is the guilt-offering,”</b> since apparently this comparison does not teach anything new because the <i>halakhot</i> of guilt-offerings are already stated elsewhere (Leviticus 7:1–10), then <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “As the sin-offering</b>…<b>so is the guilt-offering”?</b>
<b>Since the guilt-offering of a leper was specified</b> from the general category of all guilt-offerings <b>to discuss a new matter,</b> i.e., that the blood is placed on <b>the thumb</b> of the right hand <b>and the big toe of the right foot</b> of the leper, one <b>might</b> have thought that this guilt-offering <b>does not require placement of the blood and sacrificial parts on the altar,</b> as for this guilt-offering the placement of blood on the leper is sufficient.

Daf 7b

Therefore, <b>the verse states: “As the sin-offering</b>…<b>so is the guilt-offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:13), to teach that <b>just as the sin-offering requires placement of the blood and sacrificial parts on the altar, so too, the</b> leper’s <b>guilt-offering requires placement of the blood and sacrificial parts on the altar.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And had the verse not</b> explicitly <b>restored this</b> case of guilt-offering to its generalization, <b>I would say: With regard to that which was excluded</b> from the generalization as a novel ruling in this case, it was <b>excluded, and with regard to that</b> case <b>which was not excluded,</b> it was <b>not excluded, and</b> therefore the <i>halakha</i> would have been different in the various cases. <b>Here, too, I would say: A brother’s wife who was permitted</b> is <b>permitted,</b> whereas the <b>other</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden</b> were <b>not</b> permitted at all. Consequently, there is no proof from here that one might have thought that women with whom relations are forbidden are in fact permitted in levirate marriage.
§ <b>Rather,</b> the suggestion that other women with whom relations are usually forbidden might be permitted for levirate marriage was based on a different argument: It might <b>enter your mind to say: Let</b> this claim <b>be derived by</b> the hermeneutical principle of: <b>What do we find</b> with regard to, which is a principle of inductive reasoning involving a comparison between cases that include similar details. In other words, the <i>halakha</i> of all other women with whom relations are forbidden can be derived <b>from</b> that of <b>a brother’s wife: Just as a brother’s wife enters levirate marriage, so too, a wife’s sister should enter into levirate marriage.</b>
The Gemara wonders about this: <b>Is it comparable?</b> How can one case be derived from the other? <b>There,</b> in the case of a brother’s wife, only <b>one prohibition</b> has been permitted, the prohibition with regard to a brother’s wife, whereas <b>here,</b> we are dealing with <b>two prohibitions,</b> both a brother’s wife and a wife’s sister. The Gemara answers: It is nevertheless necessary to refute this suggestion, <b>lest you say: Since it is permitted, it is permitted.</b> In other words, as the Torah permitted a brother’s wife in levirate marriage despite the fact that she is ordinarily forbidden, she remains permitted even if the additional prohibition with regard to a wife’s sister applies to her.
<b>And from where do you say that we state</b> this reasoning of: <b>Since it is permitted, it is permitted? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a leper whose eighth</b> day, on which he becomes ritually pure from his leprosy and brings his last offerings to the Temple, <b>occurs on the eve of Passover, and he experienced a seminal emission on that</b> eighth <b>day and</b> then <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath, <b>the Sages said: Although any other</b> individual <b>who immersed himself that day</b> for purification from his ritual impurity <b>may not enter</b> the Temple before sunset, <b>this</b> leper, who saw an emission of semen and immersed, <b>may enter</b> the Temple.
The <i>baraita</i> explains the reason for this exception. It is <b>better that a positive mitzva that includes <i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., bringing the Paschal lamb at the right time, <b>comes and overrides a positive mitzva that does not include <i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., not entering the Temple in a state of ritual impurity. If the leper does not become purified of his leprosy he may not sacrifice the Paschal lamb. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: By Torah law there is not even</b> the overriding of <b>a positive mitzva in this</b> case of one who immersed himself during the day entering the Temple.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains his claim: <b>As it is stated: “And Jehoshaphat stood in the congregation of Judah</b> and Jerusalem, in the House of the Lord, <b>before the new courtyard”</b> (II Chronicles 20:5). <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>“the new courtyard”? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is referring to the place <b>where they issued new matters and said</b> that <b>one who immersed himself that day may not enter the camp of the Levites,</b> which in Jerusalem is the Temple Mount, despite the fact that by Torah law no such prohibition applies.
<b>And</b> with regard to this <i>halakha</i> itself, that a leper who experienced a seminal emission may nevertheless sacrifice offerings in the Temple, <b>Ulla said: What is the reason</b> that this is permitted to him? <b>Since it is permitted for his leprosy,</b> i.e., the Torah allowed him to enter the Temple Mount while still a leper to achieve full ritual purification, which requires that he sacrifice offerings, <b>it is permitted with regard to his seminal emission</b> as well. This shows that the <i>tanna</i> accepts the principle that as one prohibition is permitted, two prohibitions are likewise permitted. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Is</b> this assumption <b>comparable to</b> the case of <b>Ulla?</b>

Daf 8a

This works out <b>well when the deceased</b> brother had first <b>married</b> one of the sisters, who was thereby rendered prohibited to the <i>yavam</i> as his brother’s wife, <b>and</b> only <b>afterward</b> had <b>the living</b> brother <b>married</b> her sister, which renders his brother’s wife forbidden to him on another count, this time as his wife’s sister. <b>As</b> in that case one can say that <b>since</b> the first <b>prohibition</b> with regard to <b>a brother’s wife was</b> subsequently nullified and thereby <b>permitted</b> by the mitzva of levirate marriage, <b>the prohibition</b> with regard to <b>a wife’s sister was also</b> nullified and thereby <b>permitted.</b>
<b>However,</b> if the reverse occurred, and first the <b>living</b> brother had <b>married</b> his wife <b>and</b> only <b>afterward the deceased</b> brother had <b>married</b> her sister, in this case <b>the prohibition</b> with regard to <b>a wife’s sister precedes</b> the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife, i.e., she was initially forbidden to him as his wife’s sister. Consequently, even when the second prohibition lapses upon the death of his childless brother, the first prohibition should remain intact.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>even</b> in a case where <b>the deceased</b> brother had <b>married</b> first, <b>it</b> works out <b>well</b> only <b>when the deceased</b> brother had <b>married</b> the woman <b>and</b> then <b>died, and</b> only <b>afterward the surviving</b> brother <b>married</b> that brother’s wife’s sister. The reason is <b>that</b> in this case, the sister of the wife of the deceased brother <b>was fit for him in between,</b> i.e., during the period from when the deceased brother died until he married that brother’s wife’s sister. Therefore, it can be claimed that the second prohibition should not apply. <b>However,</b> if <b>the deceased</b> brother <b>married</b> first, <b>and did not die</b> yet, <b>and afterward,</b> during the deceased brother’s lifetime, <b>the living</b> brother <b>married</b> the deceased brother’s sister, <b>she was not fit for him at all,</b> as there was no period of time during which she was permitted to him.
The Gemara provides proof for this claim: <b>Doesn’t Ulla agree that if</b> a leper <b>experienced a seminal emission on the night of the eighth,</b> not on the eighth day but on the previous night, <b>that he may not insert his hands</b> and feet <b>to the thumb and big toe</b> to receive the blood and oil for his purification? The reason is <b>that</b> in this case he is ritually impure due to the emission and <b>he</b> had <b>not</b> yet <b>emerged</b> from the impurity of leprosy <b>at a time that is fitting to bring an offering,</b> as he cannot sacrifice his offerings until the daylight hours of the eighth day. Since there was not a single moment when he was permitted to enter the Temple in his state of ritual impurity, in this case one cannot apply the principle: Since it is permitted, it is permitted.
§ <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests that the phrase <b>“with her,”</b> which teaches the prohibition with regard to a wife’s sister in levirate marriage, <b>is necessary</b> for a case <b>where the deceased</b> brother had first <b>married and</b> then <b>died, and</b> only <b>afterward the living</b> brother <b>married</b> the sister of the deceased brother’s wife, in which case his brother’s wife was permitted to him for a period of time. Accordingly, one might have applied the principle: Since it is permitted, it is permitted. For this reason it was necessary to write “with her,” to teach that this second woman is nevertheless forbidden as his wife’s sister.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the suggestion that other women with whom relations are forbidden are permitted in levirate marriage <b>is derived from the juxtaposition of Rabbi Yona. As Rabbi Yona said, and some say</b> this was stated by <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: The verse states: “For whoever shall do any of these abominations,</b> the souls that do them <b>shall be cut off</b> from among their people” (Leviticus 18:29). In this verse <b>all of</b> the women <b>with whom relations are forbidden are juxtaposed with</b> the case of <b>a brother’s wife.</b> Consequently, one might say that <b>just as a brother’s wife is permitted</b> in levirate marriage, <b>so too, all</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden are likewise permitted.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “With her,”</b> which excludes the prohibition with regard to a wife’s sister.
Against this proof, <b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Since</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>all</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden can be juxtaposed with</b> the case of <b>a brother’s wife</b> and thereby rendered permitted in levirate marriage, <b>and</b> these cases <b>can</b> equally <b>be juxtaposed with</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a wife’s sister,</b> which would mean that they are forbidden, <b>what did you see that you juxtaposed them with a wife’s sister? Juxtapose them</b> instead <b>with a brother’s wife.</b> If so, the opposite could be derived from the phrase “with her,” i.e., not that all women with whom relations are forbidden are prohibited like a wife’s sister, but that all these women are permitted in levirate marriage, even a wife’s sister.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that if one must decide between two possible ways of understanding juxtaposed cases, one of which leads <b>to a lenient</b> ruling <b>and</b> the other to <b>a stringent</b> ruling, <b>we juxtapose to</b> reach <b>the stringent ruling,</b> not the leniency. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Here,</b> there are <b>two prohibitions,</b> a brother’s wife and a wife’s sister, <b>and there,</b> in the case of all other women with whom relations are forbidden, there are also <b>two prohibitions. And one</b> may <b>derive</b> a case involving <b>two</b> prohibitions <b>from</b> another case that involves <b>two</b> prohibitions. <b>However, here,</b> in the case of a regular levirate marriage that does not involve any other forbidden relation, there is only <b>one prohibition</b> proscribing a brother’s wife, <b>and one may not derive</b> a case involving <b>two</b> prohibitions <b>from</b> a case that involves only <b>one.</b>
§ <b>Rava said</b> that this entire <i>halakha</i> must be understood differently. With regard to <b>a forbidden relation</b> herself, it is <b>not necessary</b> for <b>a verse</b> to teach that she cannot enter into levirate marriage, <b>as a positive mitzva does not override a prohibition that includes <i>karet</i>.</b> Rather, <b>the verse</b> “with her” <b>is necessary to prohibit a rival wife,</b> as a rival wife is not prohibited to the <i>yavam</i> as a forbidden relation.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does the <i>tanna</i> in fact maintain with regard to <b>a forbidden relation</b> that it is <b>not necessary</b> for <b>a verse</b> to teach that she is prohibited in levirate marriage? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than that <b>this</b> woman is exempt from levirate marriage. From where is it inferred that the same applies to her rival wife? This shows that the case of a forbidden relation does require a special inference from a verse.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>due to her rival wife,</b> i.e., the <i>baraita</i> does not mean that the <i>halakha</i> of women with whom relations are forbidden is derived from this verse; rather, this case is mentioned only to introduce the case of a rival wife.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But it is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than that <b>these</b> sisters are exempt from levirate marriage, which again suggests that the derivation from the verse applies to all of them. This is similarly rejected: This is also stated <b>due to their rival wives.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different <i>baraita</i> that contradicts Rava’s statement: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that there is a different proof that a forbidden relation and her rival wife are prohibited in levirate marriage. The Torah says: “He will have intercourse with her and take her to him to be his wife and consummate the levirate marriage with her” (Deuteronomy 25:5). Since the verse does not say simply: <b>Have intercourse,</b> but: <b>“Have intercourse with her,”</b> this indicates that he takes this woman specifically, not a different woman who is forbidden. Furthermore, the verse does not simply state: <b>And consummate the levirate marriage,</b> but: <b>“And consummate the levirate marriage with her.”</b> These additions serve <b>to prohibit rival wives and</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden.</b>
This shows that even the prohibition with regard to women with whom relations are forbidden requires a special inference. The Gemara answers: Amend the language of the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say: To prohibit rival wives of</b> those <b>with whom relations are forbidden,</b> not the women themselves with whom relations are forbidden. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But he brought two</b> proofs from the <b>verse,</b> both “have intercourse with her” and “and consummate the levirate marriage with her.” <b>What, is it not</b> because <b>one</b> phrase is required for the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> a woman <b>with whom relations are forbidden and</b> the other <b>one for a rival wife?</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, this</b> source <b>and that</b> source <b>are</b> necessary <b>for a rival wife,</b> and both phrases are required, for the following reason. <b>One</b> of them comes <b>to prohibit a rival wife in a place where the mitzva</b> of levirate marriage is applicable, <b>and one</b> serves <b>to permit a rival wife in a place where the mitzva</b> is <b>not</b> applicable. If a woman is the rival wife of one of those relatives forbidden to a given man, he is permitted to marry her following the death of her husband, as the prohibition proscribing rival wives of women with whom relations are forbidden pertains only to cases where the <i>halakhot</i> of levirate marriage are applicable, i.e., in the case of a brother’s wife.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is derived from the fact that the verse does not merely state: <b>And consummate the levirate marriage,</b> but instead emphasizes: <b>“And consummate the levirate marriage with her.”</b> This comes to teach: <b>It is in a place where levirate marriage</b> applies <b>that a rival wife is prohibited;</b> however, <b>in a place where the levirate marriage</b> is <b>not</b> applicable, <b>a rival wife is permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precisely</b> formulated in accordance with the opinion of Rava, <b>as it teaches: Fifteen women exempt their rival wives, whereas</b> the phrase: <b>Are exempt and exempt</b> others, <b>is not taught.</b> This indicates that the exemption of these women who are themselves forbidden relations does not necessitate any special inference, as this is not a novel <i>halakha</i>, and therefore the mishna does not even state this point explicitly. The novelty is that they exempt their rival wives. The Gemara summarizes: <b>Conclude from this</b> that Rava’s opinion is correct.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if so, <b>what is different</b> about <b>a forbidden relation that</b> a special <b>verse is not necessary</b> to exclude it? The reason must be <b>that a positive mitzva does not override a prohibition that entails <i>karet</i>.</b> If so, <b>a rival wife</b> should <b>also not require an</b> additional <b>verse, due to</b> the fact that <b>a positive mitzva does not override a prohibition that entails <i>karet</i>.</b> The phrase “to be a rival to her” (Leviticus 18:18) teaches that the rival wife of a wife’s sister is prohibited like the wife’s sister herself.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Beivai Mar, said to Ravina</b> that <b>this is what we say in the name of Rava:</b> With regard to <b>a rival wife too, a verse is not necessary,</b> as is the case with a forbidden relation herself, since the prohibition in her case as well incurs <i>karet</i>, and therefore one would not think that the positive mitzva of levirate marriage overrides that prohibition. <b>The verse is necessary</b>

Daf 8b

<b>to permit a rival wife in a place where the mitzva</b> of levirate marriage is <b>not</b> applicable. <b>What is the reason,</b> i.e., how is this inferred? <b>The verse states: “With her.”</b> In other words, <b>it is in a place</b> where the obligation “her brother-in-law will have intercourse <b>with her” is</b> applicable <b>that</b> a rival wife is <b>prohibited,</b> whereas <b>in a place</b> where the obligation “Her brother-in-law will have intercourse <b>with her” is not</b> applicable, a rival wife is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said to Rava:</b> If the phrase “with her” is referring only to a case where levirate marriage is applicable, one can <b>say</b> that <b>a forbidden relative herself should be permitted in a place</b> where the <b>mitzva</b> of levirate marriage is <b>not</b> applicable. According to this interpretation, the prohibitions with regard to all those with whom relations are forbidden are in effect only when levirate marriage applies. Rava answered: <b>And is it not an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? If these relatives are <b>prohibited in a place</b> where there is <b>a mitzva,</b> could they be <b>permitted in a place</b> where there is <b>no mitzva?</b>
Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to</b> Rava: That is no proof, as the case of <b>a rival wife</b> herself <b>can prove</b> that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is incorrect, <b>as in a place</b> where there is <b>a mitzva she is prohibited and in a place</b> where there is <b>no mitzva she is permitted.</b> Rava <b>said to</b> Rami bar Ḥami: <b>With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall not take a woman to her sister…<b>in her lifetime”</b> (Leviticus 18:18). This indicates that <b>all</b> cases in which it <b>is in the lifetime</b> of her sister she is forbidden, even when no mitzva applies.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> phrase <b>“in her lifetime” is necessary,</b> as indicated by the plain meaning of the phrase, <b>to exclude the time after death,</b> i.e., to teach that a wife’s sister is forbidden only while the wife is still alive, whereas after her death the sister is permitted. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> that a woman is permitted after her sister’s death <b>is derived from</b> “and you shall not take <b>a woman to her sister”</b> (Leviticus 18:18), as when one of them is dead it is no longer considered “a woman to her sister.”
The Gemara further asks: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from “a woman to her sister,” I would say</b> that even <b>if she were divorced,</b> her sister <b>is permitted.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In her lifetime,”</b> which indicates that the prohibition is in effect in <b>all</b> cases <b>that</b> are <b>in her lifetime. This</b> teaches <b>that although she is divorced,</b> her sister is <b>not</b> permitted.
§ <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests a different interpretation. <b>Rav Huna bar Taḥlifa said in the name of Rava: Two verses are written,</b> i.e., two separate issues are mentioned in the same verse. <b>It is written: “And you shall not take a woman to her sister, to be a rival [<i>litzror</i>],”</b> which indicates that two rival wives are prohibited. <b>And it is written: “To uncover her nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 18:18), in the singular, <b>which means one</b> and not both of them. <b>How is it</b> possible to reconcile this apparent contradiction? <b>In a place</b> where there is <b>a mitzva</b> of levirate marriage, <b>both</b> the forbidden relation and her rival wife <b>are prohibited. In a place</b> where there is <b>no mitzva</b> of levirate marriage, the forbidden relation <b>is prohibited but her rival wife is permitted.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>I</b> can <b>reverse this</b> and suggest the opposite. <b>In a place</b> where there is <b>a mitzva,</b> the forbidden relation <b>is prohibited and her rival wife is permitted, and in a place</b> where there is <b>no mitzva, both of them are prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let</b> the verse <b>not say “with her,”</b> at all, as this superfluous phrase teaches that the prohibition with regard to a rival wife applies only when there is a mitzva of “her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her.”
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: From where</b> is it derived <b>that this</b> superfluous phrase <b>“with her,”</b> comes <b>to prohibit,</b> i.e., although there is an obligation that “her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her,” a wife’s sister remains prohibited? <b>Perhaps</b> it serves <b>to permit, and this is what the Merciful One is saying: “You shall not take a woman to her sister, to be a rival”</b> (Leviticus 18:18), i.e., <b>neither her nor her rival wife.</b> When is this the case? It is <b>in a place where</b> the obligation of “her brother-in-law will have intercourse <b>with her”</b> does <b>not</b> apply. <b>However, in a place where “with her” does apply</b> and there is an obligation of levirate marriage, <b>both of them are permitted.</b>
Rav Kahana replied to Rav Ashi: <b>If</b> the above statement is <b>so,</b> and <b>“to uncover her nakedness”</b> is referring <b>to one</b> woman, under <b>what circumstances</b> can <b>you find</b> this case? When is only one of them prohibited? <b>If</b> it is <b>in a place</b> where there is <b>a mitzva, they are both permitted; if</b> it is <b>in a place</b> where there is <b>no mitzva, they are both forbidden.</b> Therefore, the earlier line of reasoning must be accepted: A rival wife is forbidden only in a case where the mitzva of levirate marriage is in effect.
§ While clarifying the exposition of the phrase “with her,” an alternative interpretation attributed to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was mentioned. The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The verse does not say <b>have intercourse,</b> but <b>“have intercourse with her.”</b> And it does not say <b>and consummate the levirate marriage,</b> but <b>“and consummate the levirate marriage with her.”</b> These phrases serve <b>to prohibit rival wives and</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Are rival wives written here?</b> In other words, what is the connection between the verse and the topic of rival wives, an issue that is not even mentioned in the verse? <b>And furthermore:</b> The prohibition with regard to <b>rival wives is derived</b> from the phrase <b>“To be a rival wife [<i>litzror</i>],”</b> not from this source.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>derives</b> a different <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the phrase <b>“to be a rival wife,” in accordance with that</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon.</b> In Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, the exemption of two sisters from levirate marriage applies not only when the <i>yavam</i> is married to one of the sisters, but also if two sisters who come before him for levirate marriage were previously married to two of his brothers. In that case, the levirate bond itself is sufficient for them to be considered rival wives of one another.
And with regard to the previous question: <b>Are rival wives written here?</b> The answer is that <b>this is what he is saying: If so,</b> that the verse does not come to exempt rival wives, <b>let the verse state</b> only: <b>Have intercourse. What is</b> the meaning of <b>“have intercourse with her”?</b> It serves to limit the case to one woman and not two, in the following manner: <b>Anywhere that there are two</b> possibilities of <b>having intercourse,</b> i.e., there is a choice between marrying one of two women in levirate marriage, in such a way <b>that if he wants he may marry this one, and if he wants he may marry that one,</b> then each one is <b>permitted. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> have a choice and is obligated to marry one of them, e.g., if the other is a forbidden relation to him, <b>they are both prohibited,</b> including the rival wife.
When the verse states: <b>“And consummate the levirate marriage with her,”</b> it comes to teach the following. <b>It is in a place</b> where <b>levirate marriage</b> is applicable <b>that a rival wife is prohibited,</b> whereas <b>in a place</b> where <b>levirate marriage</b> is <b>not</b> applicable, <b>a rival wife is permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the Rabbis,</b> who do not interpret the verse in this manner, <b>what do they do with this</b> emphasis on <b>“have intercourse with her”?</b> How do they interpret it?
The Gemara responds: <b>They need this for that which Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina</b> said, <b>as Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: “And have intercourse with her”</b> means marriage, i.e., she is fully his wife from that moment onward. This <b>teaches that he divorces her with a bill of divorce</b> after levirate marriage, and she can no longer be released by <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>and he</b> may subsequently <b>remarry her</b> if he so wishes. And the verse <b>“and consummate the levirate marriage with her,”</b> this means <b>against her will.</b> Although betrothal in general does not take effect without the woman’s consent, levirate marriage can be effected against her will.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi derive these widely accepted <i>halakhot</i>? The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> cited by <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina,</b> that a woman taken in levirate marriage has the status of a regular wife who may be divorced and remarried, <b>is derived from</b> the verse “and take her to him <b>to be his wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), which means that she will be his wife for all purposes, like any other wife. And the <i>halakha</i> that levirate marriage can be effected <b>against her will is derived from “her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her,”</b> which indicates that it can be achieved without her consent.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>do with this</b> superfluous phrase, <b>“with her”?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>He needs it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a different matter. The Sages said: <b>The court is obligated</b> to bring a bull as a sin-offering for an unwittingly committed communal sin on account of an erroneous <i>halakha</i> they taught <b>only for a matter whose intentional</b> transgression incurs <b><i>karet</i> and whose unwitting</b> violation necessitates the sacrifice of <b>a sin-offering. And similarly, the anointed</b> High Priest, who also brings a bull for an unwittingly committed sin, is obligated to do so only if his mistake involved a matter whose intentional transgression incurs <i>karet</i> and whose unwitting transgression necessitates the sacrifice of a sin-offering.

Daf 9a

<b>And</b> a community brings a bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>for idolatrous worship only</b> if the act of idolatry involved <b>a matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering. And we also learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>any mitzva in the Torah for whose intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> if a private <b>individual</b> sinned unwittingly, he <b>brings a ewe or a she-goat.</b> If it was <b>a <i>Nasi</i>, he brings a goat</b> for a sin of this kind, and if the sinner was <b>an anointed</b> High Priest <b>or the court, they bring a bull.</b>
<b>And</b> if they unwittingly sinned in a matter <b>involving idolatrous worship,</b> a private <b>individual, a <i>Nasi</i>, and an anointed</b> High Priest <b>bring a she-goat,</b> whereas <b>a community brings a bull and a goat,</b> the <b>bull as a burnt-offering and</b> the <b>goat as a sin-offering.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that one must bring a sin-offering for this transgression, derived?
The Gemara answers: <b>As the Sages taught</b> with regard to an unwitting communal sin offering: <b>“And the sin by which they have sinned is known”</b> (Leviticus 4:14). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: It is stated here,</b> with regard to a sin-offering: <b>“By which [<i>aleha</i>],” and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the prohibition with regard to a wife’s sister: <b>“Unto [<i>aleha</i>].”</b> This teaches by verbal analogy: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of a wife’s sister, it is <b>a matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering, so too here,</b> the offering is brought for <b>a matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that the offering brought by the community is a sin-offering; <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>an anointed</b> High Priest also brings a sin-offering for this transgression? <b>As it is written</b> with regard <b>to an anointed</b> High Priest: “If the anointed priest shall sin <b>so as to bring guilt on the people”</b> (Leviticus 4:3), which indicates that <b>an anointed</b> High Priest brings an offering <b>like the community.</b>
From where is it derived that a private <b>individual and a <i>Nasi</i></b> bring sin-offerings only for a severe transgression of this kind? <b>This is derived</b> by verbal analogy between the words <b>“mitzvot”</b> and <b>“mitzvot”</b> that are stated three times, with regard to the community’s sin-offering, a private individual’s sin-offering, and the sin-offering of a <i>Nasi</i>: “Any of the mitzvot of the Lord that He has commanded not to be done” (Leviticus 4:2, 13, 22).
<b>And</b> it was stated above that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>idolatrous worship only</b> if it involved <b>a matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>a community</b> that was guilty <b>of idolatrous worship is derived</b> by a verbal analogy between the phrases <b>“from the eyes”</b> and <b>“from the eyes.”</b> With regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, the verse states: “From the eyes of the assembly” (Leviticus 4:13), while concerning an unwitting sin of idol worship, it says: “From the eyes of the congregation” (Numbers 15:24). This verbal analogy teaches that a congregation brings a sin-offering for idolatrous worship only if it involved a transgression that incurs <i>karet</i> when performed intentionally.
The cases of a private <b>individual, a <i>Nasi</i>, and an anointed</b> High Priest are derived <b>from</b> a verse that deals with an unwitting sin of idolatry: <b>“And if one person</b> sin” (Numbers 15:27). <b>All</b> of these, a private <b>individual, a <i>Nasi</i>, and an anointed</b> High Priest, <b>are included</b> in this verse. In this case the principle: The letter <b><i>vav</i> adds to the previous matter,</b> applies. When a phrase begins with the conjunction <i>vav</i>, meaning: And, it is a continuation of the previous matter rather than a new topic. Based on this principle, these two <i>halakhot</i> are connected with one another.
<b>And</b> therefore <b>let the lower,</b> i.e., the second, subject, a private individual, <b>be derived from the upper</b> issue, the community. Just as a community brings this offering only for a transgression whose intentional violation incurs <i>karet</i>, the same is true of a private individual. The verbal analogy stated in this <i>baraita</i> is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s inference from the phrase “with her.”
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the Rabbis,</b> who interpret “with her” with regard to rival wives, <b>from where do they derive this conclusion</b> that one is liable to bring the offering for idolatrous worship only for a transgression whose intentional violation incurs <i>karet</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>They derive it from that which Rabbi Yehoshua</b> ben Levi <b>read out to his son</b> to teach him the verses that summarize the case of unwitting idol worship: <b>“You shall have one law [<i>Torah</i>] for him that does unwittingly. But the soul that does with a high hand,</b> whether he be home born or a stranger, he blasphemes the Lord; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people” (Numbers 15:29–30).
In this manner, <b>the entire Torah is juxtaposed with idolatrous worship. Just as</b> in the case of <b>idolatrous worship</b> there is no obligation to bring an offering unless it is <b>a matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as indicated by the verse: “That soul shall be cut off from among his people,” <b>so too,</b> the same applies to <b>any matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>We found</b> a source for a private <b>individual, a <i>Nasi</i>, and an anointed</b> High Priest, <b>whether</b> with regard <b>to idolatrous worship or</b> with regard <b>to</b> the <b>other mitzvot. From where</b> is it derived that <b>a community</b> is liable only for an unwitting transgression <b>of idolatrous worship</b> of this kind? <b>The verse states: “And if one person</b> sin” <b>(</b>Numbers 15:27). Once again, the letter <i>vav</i> teaches that these two cases are connected, <b>and let the upper,</b> the first, issue of a community, <b>be derived from the lower</b> case, that of a private individual.
<b>However, from where do we</b> derive that <b>a community</b> brings an offering <b>for other mitzvot</b> only if the intentional violation of the prohibition incurs <i>karet</i>? The Gemara responds: <b>He derives</b> it from the aforementioned verbal analogy between <b>“from the eyes”</b> and <b>“from the eyes.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>do with this</b> verse: <b>“One law”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Since we find that the Torah differentiates between</b> private <b>individuals</b> who sinned <b>and the many</b> who sinned in idol worship.
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: Private <b>individuals</b> who worshipped idols are sentenced <b>to stoning,</b> and <b>therefore their money is spared</b> from destruction. Although the sinner is put to death, his possessions are not destroyed. By contrast, the <b>many</b> are condemned to the lighter death penalty of decapitation <b>by sword,</b> the punishment for those who worshipped idols in an idolatrous city, and <b>therefore their money is forfeited,</b> as by Torah law all possessions belonging to the residents of an idolatrous city must be burned.
Due to this difference, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>we</b> should likewise <b>differentiate between their offerings,</b> i.e., if an individual and a community unwittingly practiced idolatrous worship, different offerings are brought in the two cases. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “One law for you.”</b> The word: “you” is in the plural, which indicates that an individual and a community that worshipped idols are subject to the same <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Ḥilkiya from</b> the city of <b>Hagronya strongly objects to this: The reason</b> for this ruling is <b>that the Merciful One</b> specifically <b>writes: “One law for you,”</b> from which it may be inferred that <b>if that were not so, I would say</b> that <b>we</b> should <b>differentiate</b> between the offerings of an individual and a community. If so, it is appropriate to ask: <b>What</b> offering <b>would they bring</b> if we were to differentiate? You cannot say <b>they would bring a bull,</b> as <b>it is a community</b> that sinned unwittingly <b>in</b> transgressing <b>other mitzvot who bring</b> a bull, and as this case is written separately, clearly its <i>halakha</i> is different.
Likewise, you cannot say that they should bring <b>a ewe,</b> as <b>it is an individual</b> who sinned <b>in</b> transgressing <b>the other mitzvot who brings</b> a ewe. Nor can you say that they bring a <b>goat,</b> as <b>it is a <i>Nasi</i></b> who sinned <b>in</b> transgressing <b>the other mitzvot who brings</b> a goat. And you cannot say that they would bring <b>a bull as a burnt-offering and a goat as a sin-offering,</b> as <b>it is the community,</b> i.e., the majority of Jews, who sinned <b>in</b> performing <b>idolatrous worship who bring</b> these. <b>Rather, what</b> might they bring? If one were to suggest <b>a she-goat,</b> that would not be appropriate, because <b>this is the offering</b> of a private <b>individual as well,</b> since an individual brings a ewe or a she-goat as a sin-offering. Apparently there is no need for a special inference in this case, as there are no other possibilities.
The Gemara answers: It <b>is necessary</b> for a verse to teach that there is no difference between the offerings of an individual and a community, as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since a community</b> that sinned <b>by</b> the erroneous <b>instruction</b> of the court that it is permitted to practice idolatry <b>brings a bull as a burnt-offering and a goat as a sin-offering,</b> then, when a community sins of its own accord <b>they too</b> should <b>bring</b> these animals, but <b>the opposite,</b> i.e., a bull as a sin-offering and a goat as a burnt-offering.
<b>Alternatively,</b> it could be argued: Theoretically a community <b>must</b> bring a different form of atonement from that of an individual, yet <b>they have no remedy,</b> as the Torah did not specify which offering is brought for a sin of the many. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> by means of the phrase “one law for you” that there is indeed an offering for the many who practiced idol worship.
§ After discussing different interpretations of the relevant verses, the Gemara addresses the details of the <i>halakhot</i> of the mishna. It first considers the numbers that comprise the structure of the mishna as a whole. The Sage <b>Levi said to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>Why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> the cases of <b>fifteen women? Let him teach</b> the cases of <b>sixteen</b> women, including the case of a rival wife of a forbidden relation. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him:</b> Judging by his question, <b>it seems to me that</b> this Sage <b>has no brain in his head.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi proceeded to explain the question and the answer himself: <b>What is your thinking?</b> Is it that the <i>tanna</i> should have included the case of <b>his mother</b> who had been <b>raped by his father?</b> In the opinion of the Rabbis, a woman raped by one’s father is permitted in marriage to another of his sons. Consequently, it is possible that she might give birth to a son and later marry one of the other sons of the rapist. If her husband subsequently died childless, this woman would come before the brother of the deceased for levirate marriage, who is in this case her son. If so, there are in fact sixteen women with whom relations are forbidden.
However, continued Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, this is incorrect, as the case of <b>his mother raped by his father is</b> a matter of <b>dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, a woman raped by one’s father could never come before him for levirate marriage, as it is prohibited for her to marry his brothers. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> of this mishna <b>does not deal with disputed</b> cases. The mishna enumerates only those cases that are accepted by all opinions, not those that are a matter of dispute.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does the <i>tanna</i> really <b>not</b> mention disputed cases? <b>But</b> there are the cases of <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> of the Sages, <b>and a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity.</b> In other words, the <i>tanna</i> does refer to the cases of a woman who one is prohibited to marry by decree of the Sages, e.g., a distant secondary forbidden relation, and one who is prohibited due to a regular prohibition that preserves the sanctity of the Jewish people or the priesthood.
These are cases concerning <b>which Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis disagree</b> whether these women are entirely exempt from both levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i> like a forbidden relation, or whether the mitzva of levirate marriage does in fact apply but since the <i>yavam</i> may not marry her in practice, she must be released by <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>And</b> yet these disputed cases <b>are taught</b> in the mishna.
The Gemara responds: When <b>we say</b> that only accepted <i>halakhot</i> are included in the mishna, we are referring only to <b>our</b> present <b>chapter,</b> whereas the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis is stated in the second chapter. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> in this chapter it is stated that <b>Beit Shammai permit rival wives to the brothers,</b> as they hold that there is no prohibition against rival wives of those with whom relations are forbidden, <b>and Beit Hillel prohibit</b> this. Evidently, the first chapter does deal with disputed cases.
The Gemara answers: When <b>Beit Shammai</b> express an opinion <b>where Beit Hillel</b> disagree, their opinion is considered as if it were <b>not</b> in the <b>mishna,</b> i.e., it is completely disregarded, as it is commonly accepted that the opinion of Beit Shammai is rejected and not ruled as <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, this cannot be considered a true dispute. The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>But</b> there is the case of <b>a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist,</b> i.e., the <i>yavam</i> was not alive at the time of his brother’s death.

Daf 9b

This is a case concerning <b>which Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis disagree, and</b> yet it <b>is taught.</b> If this <i>halakha</i> is taught, evidently this mishna does deal with matters subject to dispute. The Gemara answers <b>that</b> Rabbi Shimon does not disagree with the Rabbis concerning all cases of a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. If this <i>yavam</i> was <b>born</b> after his brother’s death, he concedes that the obligation of levirate marriage does not apply to the newborn <i>yavam</i>. Rather, the <i>yevama</i> is prohibited to him as his brother’s wife.
Furthermore, in a case where he was born <b>and at the end,</b> i.e., afterward, a second older brother <b>entered into levirate marriage</b> with the <i>yevama</i> and subsequently died as well, and the same woman again came before that same younger brother, <b>Rabbi Shimon did not disagree</b> with the opinion of the Rabbis here either, as he admits that this woman is permanently forbidden to him because when he was born she was classified as the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.
In fact, Rabbi Shimon disagreed only with regard to a different case, when there were two brothers, one of whom died, and the second took the <i>yevama</i> in levirate marriage. If a third brother was subsequently born and afterward the second brother died, Rabbi Shimon maintains that the youngest brother may enter into levirate marriage with this woman because she was never forbidden to him, as what occurred prior to his birth is of no relevance. Since even in Rabbi Shimon’s opinion it is possible to find a case in which the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist is forbidden to him, it can be claimed that the mishna is taught in accordance with all opinions.<br>The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Oshaya say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon disagreed even with regard to the first</b> case? In other words, Rabbi Shimon disagreed not only in the case of a woman who entered into levirate marriage before the young brother was born, but even if the young brother was born before the initial levirate marriage took place.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: This statement of <b>Rabbi Oshaya was conclusively refuted.</b> Consequently, it remains possible to say that the mishna does not deal with disputes.<br>The Gemara raises a difficulty from another angle. The third chapter discusses a case involving four brothers, two of whom passed away after they were married to two sisters. As a result, the two sisters simultaneously came before the surviving brothers for levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Sages ruled that in this case the brothers may not enter into levirate marriage with the sisters, as it is as though the two sisters came before each brother individually, and due to the levirate bond each sister was, in a sense, considered married to each brother to a certain extent. <br>Consequently, for each brother the other sister is viewed as his wife’s sister, as it were, and is forbidden to him. Since this occurs to both sisters simultaneously, it is prohibited for both of them to enter into levirate marriage. However, the Sages further said that if one of these sisters was a forbidden relation to one of the surviving brothers, e.g., if he had married her daughter or some other relative, the second sister, to whom he is not a close relative, is permitted to him. If the same applies to the other brother and the second sister, the two brothers could perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the two sisters or even enter into levirate marriage with them.
With this in mind, the Gemara states its objection: <b>And didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav said, and likewise Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard <b>to all of those</b> fifteen women enumerated in the mishna, it is possible to find a scenario in which <b>I</b> would <b>call them: The</b> woman <b>who is forbidden to this</b> brother <b>is permitted to that</b> brother, <b>and the one who is forbidden to this</b> brother <b>is permitted to that</b> brother. <b>And</b> consequently, <b>her sister who is her sister-in-law performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> This complex situation can be demonstrated with regard to each of the women enumerated in the mishna, e.g., if one sister is the mother-in-law of one brother, and the second sister is the mother-in-law of the second brother, and so on.
<b>And Rav Yehuda explains</b> that this is not true of all of the women listed in the mishna. Only <b>from</b> the case of <b>his mother-in-law and onward,</b> until the end of the list, is it possible for one sister to be a forbidden relation to one brother and the other sister not to be forbidden at all. <b>However, in the first six cases, no,</b> this option does not apply. <b>What is the reason</b> for this?
<b>Since,</b> for example, in the case of <b>one’s daughter,</b> although it is possible that one of the sisters is the daughter of one of the brothers, her mother is prohibited to all of the brothers as their brother’s wife, and therefore she could not possibly have a daughter from another brother. This case is possible only if one brother raped a woman who subsequently gave birth to his daughter. Since the prohibition with regard to a brother’s wife applies only in the case of marriage, this same woman is not forbidden to a different brother. If another brother came and raped her as well and she gave birth to his daughter too, and these two daughters later married two other brothers, each of these sisters who are sisters-in-law is forbidden to one of the brothers but permitted to the other.
Accordingly, <b>in</b> the case of <b>rape you</b> can <b>find</b> this scenario, but <b>in</b> the case of <b>marriage you cannot find</b> it. However, the mishna cannot be interpreted as referring to a case of this kind, as <b>it deals with marriage</b> and <b>it does not deal with rape.</b>
<b>And Abaye explains</b> differently, as he would include in this scenario <b>even his daughter from the woman he raped.</b> Why would he include this case? <b>Since you can find</b> this possibility, <b>if you wish it can be by rape, and if you wish it can be by marriage,</b> i.e., regardless of the details, this situation can occur. <b>However,</b> the last case, that of <b>a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist,</b> he would <b>not</b> include. <b>What is the reason</b> for this?
<b>Since it is</b> only <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon that you find this</b> potential scenario, as he permits a <i>yevama</i> to her <i>yavam</i> in a case where he was born after she first entered levirate marriage, it is therefore possible that one sister might be forbidden to one brother if he was born before his brother took her in levirate marriage. Likewise, another sister might be forbidden to another brother for the same reason, although the first woman would be permitted to him, as in his lifetime she was never the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> however, <b>you cannot find this</b> scenario, and the mishna <b>does not deal with disputes</b> but only with those cases that are accepted by all opinions.
<b>But Rav Safra explains</b> that the possibility of one brother permitted only to one woman and another brother likewise permitted only to one woman exists <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist, and you</b> can <b>find this</b> scenario <b>in</b> a case involving <b>six brothers, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon.</b>

Daf 10a

<b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember how this might occur is as follows: <b>Died, was born, entered into levirate marriage, died, was born, entered into levirate marriage.</b> In other words, there were several brothers, and one, Reuven, <b>died,</b> before another, Yissakhar, <b>was born, and</b> another brother, Shimon, <b>entered into levirate marriage</b> with the deceased’s wife, and there was another brother, Levi, who <b>died</b> as well, and yet another brother, Zevulun, <b>was born, and</b> a sixth brother, Yehuda, <b>entered into levirate marriage</b> with the deceased’s wife. In this case, if Shimon and Yehuda were to die childless, their wives would come before the surviving brothers, Yissakhar and Zevulun, for levirate marriage. To one of them, Yissakhar, the wife of the first brother, Reuven, is prohibited, and for the other brother, Zevulun, the wife of the second brother, Levi, is likewise prohibited. <br>This is an example of the type of case analyzed in the third chapter, in which the ruling is that the woman who is forbidden to this brother is permitted to that one, and she who is forbidden to this one is permitted to that one. In any case, Rabbi Ḥiyya incorporates the opinion of Rabbi Shimon into this principle, as he maintains that this scenario can apply to each case stated in the mishna. If so, the mishna evidently does deal with disputed legal rulings. How, then, can Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi claim that the cases of the mishna are unanimous?
§ <b>Rather, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not hold</b> in accordance with <b>these general statements</b> applied by Rabbi Ḥiyya, and therefore he maintains that no issue subject to dispute was taught in the mishna. <b>Rav Adda Karḥina,</b> who was sitting <b>before Rav Kahana, said in the name of Rava: Actually,</b> one can explain that <b>Rabbi does hold</b> in accordance with <b>these general statements</b> laid out by Rabbi Ḥiyya. <b>And this is what</b> he <b>said</b> to Levi: In the case of <b>his mother</b> who had been <b>raped by his father, you find this</b> case <b>with</b> only <b>one</b> of the women; however, <b>you cannot find it with two.</b> In other words, the terms mentioned by Rabbi Ḥiyya above: She who is forbidden to this one is permitted to that one, and: A sister who is a sister-in-law performs either <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage, apply only partly to this complex case.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>If Ya’akov,</b> the father, <b>raped two sisters</b> who gave birth to two sons, and he had two other sons who married these raped sisters and died, in this scenario <b>you find</b> a case of <b>her sister who is her sister-in-law,</b> as there is a <i>yevama</i> who comes before one of the brothers who is a forbidden relative and also a sister and a sister-in-law of another <i>yevama</i>. However, <b>you cannot find</b> the principle of: <b>She who is forbidden to this one is permitted to that one.</b> Although it is possible that one’s brother’s wife who is one’s mother might come before one for levirate marriage, just as he is forbidden to his mother, he is likewise forbidden to his mother’s sister.
<b>And if</b> the father <b>raped two unrelated women,</b> who gave birth to two sons and then married two other sons of the same father who subsequently died, <b>you find</b> the case of: <b>She who is forbidden to this one is permitted to that one,</b> as each of the two raped women comes before one of the brothers for levirate marriage while she is forbidden to the other as his mother. However, <b>you do not find</b> a situation of: <b>Her sister who is her sister-in-law.</b> Therefore, the case of one’s mother who was raped by one’s father cannot be included in the list of the mishna, as the characteristics stated by Rabbi Ḥiyya do not apply to this case.
§ <b>Rav Ashi stated</b> a different explanation: <b>Actually, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not hold</b> in accordance with <b>these general statements</b> of Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>and</b> the mishna <b>does deal with</b> <i>halakhot</i> that are in <b>dispute.</b> According to his opinion, <b>what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>It seems to me that he has no brain in his head, that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to</b> Levi?
According to Rav Ashi, <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said</b> to Levi: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>you were not precise</b> in your interpretation of <b>the mishna? As the mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who prohibited</b> the case <b>of a woman</b> who was <b>raped by one’s father.</b> Accordingly, the rulings of the mishna cannot be attributed to any opinion that is not in line with that of Rabbi Yehuda. What is the proof that this mishna is indeed in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda?
<b>As it teaches</b> in the next mishna: <b>Six</b> women <b>with whom relations are forbidden are more severe than these</b> enumerated in the previous mishna, <b>because they</b> may <b>marry</b> only <b>others</b> and can never be married to any of the brothers, and therefore <b>their rival wives are permitted.</b> These women include: <b>His mother, his father’s wife, and his father’s sister.</b> Rav Ashi infers: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>His mother? If we say</b> that this mother is <b>married to his father,</b> then <b>this is the same</b> case as: <b>His father’s wife,</b> which would mean that the mishna lists only five cases, not six.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>a woman raped by his father? And it is taught</b> in the mishna that the <i>halakhot</i> of levirate marriage do not apply to them <b>because they may marry</b> only <b>others,</b> which indicates: <b>Others, yes; the brothers, no.</b> Since each of the brothers are sons of the same father, each one is prohibited from marrying the mother of one of the other brothers, as although she is not his mother, she is nevertheless a woman raped by his father, whom one may not marry. <b>Who did you hear who holds</b> in accordance with <b>this conclusion</b> that a woman raped by one’s father is prohibited to all his sons? It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda who prohibits a woman raped by his father. Due to that</b> reason the case of a woman raped by one’s father <b>was not taught</b> in the first mishna.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda you</b> can <b>find this</b> possibility that a woman raped by a father comes before the son for levirate marriage. <b>What if one</b> of the brothers <b>transgressed and married</b> a woman raped by his father? Even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that this is a violation of a regular prohibition that does not incur <i>karet</i>, and therefore the marriage is valid. Consequently, if this brother died childless, this woman would come before her son for levirate marriage. The Gemara rejects this proof: The <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> cases of <b>what if,</b> i.e., the mishna does not cite an example that could result only from a transgression.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: Even without</b> a hypothetical: <b>What if, you</b> can <b>find</b> an example of a woman raped by a father who is not forbidden to the son in marriage. How so? <b>Ya’akov,</b> the father, <b>raped his daughter-in-law, from whom he fathered a son. And</b> the son, <b>Reuven,</b> the husband of the daughter-in-law, <b>died childless. And</b> as Ya’akov had two sons, the deceased Reuven and a son by Reuven’s wife whom Ya’akov had raped, Reuven’s wife <b>would</b> then <b>come before her son</b> for levirate marriage. <b>And since she is forbidden, her rival wife is also forbidden.</b> Consequently, a case of this kind is possible without the levirate marriage resulting from an illicit marriage.
Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: The mishna <b>deals with</b> cases of <b>legitimate brothers,</b> whereas <b>it does not deal with cases of illegitimate brothers.</b> The offspring of a man who rapes his daughter-in-law is a <i>mamzer</i>, and cases of this kind are not discussed in the mishna. The Gemara comments: <b>Nevertheless,</b> despite Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s criticism, <b>Levi established this</b> additional possibility of a woman raped by one’s father <b>in his <i>mishnayot</i>.</b>
<b>As Levi taught</b> in his <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the case of <b>his mother, at times she exempts her rival wife, and at</b> other <b>times she does not exempt her rival wife</b>. <b>How so?</b> If <b>his mother was married to his father and</b> after his father’s death she illicitly <b>married</b> her son’s <b>paternal brother, who</b> then <b>died, this is</b> a case of: <b>His mother who does not exempt her rival wife.</b> The reason is that her marriage to his brother does not take effect at all, as it was forbidden on pain of <i>karet</i>. Since this marriage never occurred, only the other wife, the so-called rival wife, is considered a wife of the brother, and she may enter into levirate marriage.

Daf 10b

If, however, <b>his mother was a woman</b> who was <b>raped by his father and</b> subsequently <b>married his paternal brother, and</b> the brother <b>died, this is</b> a case of <b>his mother who exempts her rival wife.</b> According to the opinion of the Rabbis this marriage is permitted, and even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda the marriage is valid despite the transgression. Consequently, both the mother and her rival wife come before the son for levirate marriage. Since the mother is a forbidden relation to him, her rival wife is exempt as well.
<b>And although the Sages taught in the mishna: Fifteen</b> women, <b>we must add a sixteenth</b> case, <b>for example,</b> the situation described above. <b>Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: According to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, who said</b> that the mishna <b>teaches even</b> cases of: <b>What if,</b> which involve a transgression, <b>let</b> the mishna also <b>teach</b> the case of <b>one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i> and went back and betrothed her, and</b> then <b>died childless.</b> His betrothal is a transgression, as after <i>ḥalitza</i> the <i>yevama</i> is permanently forbidden to him. <b>As,</b> in this case, <b>since she is forbidden</b> to all the brothers, due to the <i>ḥalitza</i> performed by the deceased <i>yavam</i>, <b>her rival wife is also forbidden.</b> This is an additional case of a woman who exempts her rival wife.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Reish Lakish: This example is not cited <b>because</b> the case <b>does not</b> include the possibility <b>of a rival wife of a rival wife.</b> All of the other cases listed in the mishna involve both rival wives and rival wives of rival wives. Here, however, this is impossible, as the same prohibition applies equally to all of the brothers, and therefore none of them may marry her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>say</b> a different answer <b>to</b> Reish Lakish, as he could simply have pointed out that marriage to a woman who had performed <i>ḥalitza</i> is not a violation that incurs <i>karet</i>, neither for the one who performed the <i>ḥalitza</i> nor for his brothers if they marry her after he dies. Rather, <b>it is</b> an act for which they are <b>liable for</b> violating a regular <b>prohibition, and those liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition are</b> obligated <b>in <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage.</b> In these cases the mitzva of levirate marriage still applies, and although the woman should be released by <i>ḥalitza</i>, she is not entirely exempt from levirate marriage, and therefore her rival wife is not exempt either.
The Gemara responds that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>is speaking in accordance with the statement of</b> Reish Lakish, as follows: According <b>to my</b> opinion your question is groundless, as <b>they are liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition, and those liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition are</b> obligated <b>in <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage. However,</b> according <b>to your</b> opinion, <b>those</b> brothers who marry a <i>yevama</i> who had performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>are liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> and therefore you must resolve the difficulty by saying that the mishna did not teach this case <b>because</b> it <b>does not</b> include the possibility <b>of a rival wife of a rival wife.</b>
The Gemara discusses the dispute alluded to in the previous paragraph. <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i> and went back and betrothed her, Reish Lakish said:</b> The brother who earlier performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>is not liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> returning to <b>the <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>].</b> She is no longer forbidden as a brother’s wife, although she is forbidden by a regular prohibition.
