However,</b> with regard to <b>two courts</b> located <b>in two</b> different <b>cities, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>Rava said to him: But</b> the dispute between <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel is considered like</b> a case of <b>two courts in one city,</b> as these two schools of thought were found everywhere, not in any specific place. <b>Rather, Rava said: When we say</b> that the prohibition: <b>“You shall not cut yourselves”</b> applies, we are referring to a case <b>where</b> there is <b>a court in one city, a section</b> of which <b>rules in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai and</b> another <b>section rules in accordance with the statement of Beit Hillel. However,</b> with regard to <b>two courts</b> located <b>in one city, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
§ The Gemara cites other relevant sources. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: In the locale of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> where his ruling was followed, <b>they would cut down trees</b> on Shabbat <b>to prepare charcoal</b> from them <b>to fashion iron</b> tools with which to circumcise a child <b>on Shabbat.</b> In Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, not only does the mitzva of circumcision override Shabbat, but also any action required for the preparation of the tools necessary for the circumcision likewise overrides Shabbat. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili they would eat poultry meat in milk,</b> as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili held that the prohibition of meat in milk does not include poultry.
The Gemara infers: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Eliezer, yes,</b> they would act in this manner, whereas <b>in the locale of Rabbi Akiva,</b> for instance, <b>no,</b> they would not do so, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>a principle was stated by Rabbi Akiva: Any prohibited labor that can be performed on Shabbat eve does not override Shabbat</b> even if it involves a mitzva. A mitzva whose proper time is on Shabbat overrides Shabbat only if its performance was impossible earlier, e.g., the act of circumcision itself, which cannot be performed earlier.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is this refutation?</b> As stated above, <b>it is different</b> when dealing <b>with numerous places,</b> and the <i>baraita</i> explicitly states that this practice was followed in Rabbi Eliezer’s locale. Consequently, there is no violation of the prohibition against splitting into factions. The Gemara asks: <b>He who asked it, why did he ask it,</b> i.e., what is the basis for the question in the first place? It is obvious that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a specific place.
The Gemara answers: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>due to the severity of Shabbat, it,</b> i.e., the world, <b>is considered like a single locale.</b> In other words, one might have thought that the permission to tolerate diverse customs in different places applies only to other prohibitions, whereas the prohibition of Shabbat is so severe that it is unacceptable to allow different customs, as this might lead people to disrespect Shabbat. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even in the case of Shabbat there can be different customs in various locales.
§ The Gemara cites another relevant case involving Shabbat: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that Rabbi Abbahu, when he happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, would move</b> an oil <b>lamp [<i>sheraga</i>]</b> after the flame that had been lit for that Shabbat had burned out, as Rabbi Yehoshua accepted the ruling that it is permitted to carry items of this sort that had been set aside. <b>But when he happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who prohibited carrying items of this kind that had been set aside on Shabbat, <b>he would not move</b> an oil <b>lamp.</b> This indicates that divergent customs are followed in different places.
Again, the Gemara asks: <b>And what is this difficulty? Didn’t we say</b> that <b>it is different</b> when dealing <b>with numerous places?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>this is what we are saying:</b> With regard to <b>Rabbi Abbahu</b> himself, <b>how could he act in this manner here and how could he act in that manner there?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Abbahu holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> that it is permitted to carry this item. <b>And when he happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yoḥanan he would not carry it, in deference to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> so as not to act contrary to his ruling in the place where he was the authority. The Gemara asks: <b>But there was a servant</b> accompanying Rabbi Abbahu who would see him carrying these types of articles that had been set aside. Wasn’t Rabbi Abbahu concerned that the servant might carry them in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s locale? The Gemara explains <b>that he would inform the servant</b> and explain to him the reason for his change in behavior.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the question of whether Beit Shammai followed their own rulings. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in the mishna: <b>Although</b> Beit Hillel <b>prohibit and</b> Beit Shammai <b>permit,</b> and these disqualify the women and those deem them fit, <b>Beit Shammai did not refrain from marrying women from Beit Hillel, nor did Beit Hillel</b> refrain from marrying women <b>from Beit Shammai. Granted, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did not act</b> in accordance with their opinion, it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>they did not</b> have to <b>refrain</b> from marrying women from Beit Hillel. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>they did act</b> in accordance with their opinion, <b>why didn’t they refrain</b> from marrying one another?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Granted, Beit Shammai did not refrain</b> from marrying into <b>Beit Hillel,</b> as even if Beit Shammai maintain in a certain case that a rival wife required levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>, if she went ahead and married another man their <b>children are</b> born to a union whose partners are <b>liable by</b> a regular <b>prohibition:</b> “The wife of the dead man shall not be married outside” (Deuteronomy 25:5). Since this transgression does not entail <i>karet</i>, the children of this relationship are not <i>mamzerim</i>.
<b>However, why did Beit Hillel not refrain</b> from marrying into <b>Beit Shammai?</b> In the opinion of Beit Hillel the <b>children</b> of these rival wives who entered into levirate marriage are born of a union whose partners are <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as the prohibition of a brother’s wife was never nullified in this case, which means that the children <b>are <i>mamzerim</i>.</b> If so, how could Beit Hillel allow these marriages?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>Beit Hillel maintain that</b> the child of a union whose partners are <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> is not a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> as a <i>mamzer</i> is only one whose parents violated a prohibition that entails the death penalty, <b>didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: Although Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagreed</b> with regard <b>to rival wives, they concede that a <i>mamzer</i> is only from</b> a union <b>whose prohibition</b> is <b>a prohibition of forbidden relations punishable by <i>karet</i>?</b> Consequently, the children of rival wives are <i>mamzerim</i> according to Beit Hillel. <b>Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from</b> here that Beit Shammai <b>did not act</b> in accordance with their own opinion?
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>No; actually,</b> Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinion. As for the problem with these marriages, the answer is <b>that they would inform</b> Beit Hillel <b>and</b> Beit Hillel would <b>withdraw</b> from the match. When those who acted in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel would come to marry women from those who followed the rulings of Beit Shammai, they would be notified that certain children were born of rival wives and that those people were considered <i>mamzerim</i> in the opinion of Beit Hillel, who therefore declared them forbidden in marriage.
The Gemara comments: <b>And so too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the case, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> With regard to <b>all of the</b> disputes concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual purity and impurity, where those,</b> Beit Hillel, rule an article <b>ritually pure and these,</b> Beit Shammai, rule it <b>ritually impure, they did not refrain from handling ritually pure</b> objects <b>each with the other.</b>

Daf 14b

<b>Granted, if you say that they notified them,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>they did not</b> need to <b>refrain</b> from using their objects. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>they did not notify them, granted,</b> it is logical that <b>Beit Shammai did not refrain from</b> handling items belonging to <b>Beit Hillel, as ritually impure</b> objects <b>for Beit Hillel are ritually pure for Beit Shammai,</b> and therefore no special care is necessary.
<b>However, why didn’t Beit Hillel refrain from</b> touching articles that belonged to <b>Beit Shammai?</b> After all, <b>ritually pure</b> objects <b>for Beit Shammai are ritually impure for Beit Hillel. Rather, is it not</b> the case that Beit Shammai <b>notified</b> Beit Hillel that these items were ritually pure only in their own opinion, and Beit Hillel separated themselves from them? The Gemara summarizes the discussion: <b>Conclude from</b> here that this is the correct interpretation.
The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> way <b>is this</b> case <b>stronger than that</b> case? In other words, why is the statement with regard to ritual purity and impurity more conclusive than the one that deals with marriage? Since the practice of notification was not explicitly stated in the case of ritual purity but was merely inferred logically, the same reasoning applies equally to the case of marriage. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that since it is so unusual, a marriage to <b>a rival wife</b> generates <b>publicity</b> and is so widely known that no special notification is required, therefore, the Gemara <b>teaches us</b> that even in this case notification is required.
§ Since the statement of Rabbi Elazar was mentioned, the Gemara turns to discuss <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Elazar said: Although Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagreed</b> with regard <b>to rival wives, they concede that a <i>mamzer</i> is only from</b> a union <b>whose prohibition</b> is <b>a prohibition of forbidden relations punishable by <i>karet</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who concedes</b> to whom? <b>If we say</b> that <b>Beit Shammai</b> concede <b>to Beit Hillel,</b> this is <b>obvious,</b> since if they acted in accordance with their own opinion that rival wives who married others without <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>are liable</b> only <b>for</b> violating a regular <b>prohibition,</b> their <b>children are</b> therefore <b>fit</b> and are not <i>mamzerim</i> at all.
<b>Rather,</b> one could say that <b>Beit Hillel</b> concede <b>to Beit Shammai.</b> But in that case <b>she herself,</b> the rival wife of a forbidden relative who married one of the <i>yevamin</i>, <b>is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i></b> in the opinion of Beit Hillel, and the child is a <i>mamzer</i>, whereas Rabbi Elazar’s statement indicates that they concede with regard to a different case.
The Gemara explains: <b>Actually, Beit Shammai</b> concede <b>to Beit Hillel,</b> and this is not a novelty with regard to their basic dispute. Instead, the statement comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva, who said:</b> The offspring <b>from</b> forbidden relations for which one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>teaches us</b> that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree that the offspring <b>from</b> forbidden relations for which one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition is not a <i>mamzer</i>;</b> rather, one is a <i>mamzer</i> only if he is born of a union punishable by <i>karet</i>.
§ The Gemara returns to the initial question of whether or not Beit Shammai acted in accordance with their own opinion. The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: Although Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagreed</b> with regard <b>to</b> several cases, nevertheless, they did not refrain from marrying women from each other’s communities. The cases with regard to which they disagreed include <b>rival wives, and sisters,</b> i.e., if two sisters had been married to two brothers and simultaneously became obligated in levirate marriage, Beit Hillel prohibit both in levirate marriage, and if they violated the prohibition and married regardless, they require a divorce. By contrast, Beit Shammai permit them to remain married.
Furthermore, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagreed with regard <b>to an outdated bill of divorce</b> that had been written but not delivered. Beit Shammai maintain that if the husband and wife continued to live together after the writing of the bill of divorce, the same bill of divorce can still be used later, whereas Beit Hillel dispute this. <b>And</b> they likewise <b>disagreed</b> with regard <b>to an uncertain married woman,</b> i.e., whether a minor who was actually married, and not merely betrothed, may perform refusal. <b>And</b> they also <b>disagreed</b> with regard <b>to one who divorces his wife and</b> later <b>she lodged</b> together <b>with him at an inn,</b> as to whether or not this is sufficient grounds for assuming that they remarried.
Additionally, they disagreed with regard to the issue of betrothal <b>by money and with</b> the equivalent <b>value of money,</b> and <b>by a <i>peruta</i> or with</b> the equivalent <b>value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> According to Beit Shammai, the minimal amount of money effective for betrothal is a dinar or the equivalent of a dinar, whereas Beit Hillel maintain that even the less valuable <i>peruta</i> or its equivalent is sufficient.
Despite the fact that these <i>halakhot</i> entail important ramifications depending on whether or not these women were married or fit for marriage, or whether their offspring are fit for marriage, <b>Beit Shammai did not refrain from marrying women from Beit Hillel, nor did Beit Hillel</b> refrain from marrying women <b>from Beit Shammai.</b> This serves <b>to teach you that</b> they <b>practiced affection and camaraderie between them, to fulfill that which is stated: “Love truth and peace”</b> (Zechariah 8:19). <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They did refrain in the certain</b> cases, <b>but they did not refrain in the uncertain</b> cases. In other words, Beit Hillel were not worried that any ordinary woman from Beit Shammai might be one of those of uncertain status.
The Gemara infers from the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinion, it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>they refrained</b> in the certain cases. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>they did not act</b> in accordance with their opinion, <b>why did they refrain</b> from marriage? The Gemara replies: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way, that Beit Shammai acted in accordance with their opinion? <b>Even if they acted</b> in accordance with their opinion, <b>granted</b> that <b>Beit Hillel refrained from</b> marrying into <b>Beit Shammai,</b> as <b>those</b> rival wives who entered into levirate marriage <b>are liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> and</b> their children <b>are <i>mamzerim</i> according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b>
<b>However, why did Beit Shammai refrain from</b> marrying the offspring of rival wives of <b>Beit Hillel?</b> The parents are <b>liable for</b> violating a regular <b>prohibition, and</b> therefore their children <b>are fit.</b> The Gemara answers <b>as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> with regard to a different matter: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>was necessary</b> not for the children of the rival wife, but <b>only for the rival wife herself. Here too, it was necessary only for the rival wife herself.</b> The <i>halakha</i> was not taught with regard to the children of the rival wives; rather, it is referring only to the rival wives.
The Gemara asks further: <b>And in what</b> way are uncertain cases <b>different from the certain</b> cases, such as forbidden rival wives? If you say <b>that</b> certain cases are undoubtedly <b>prohibited</b> in the opinion of Beit Hillel, the cases involving <b>uncertain</b> circumstances, e.g., one who divorced his wife and then stayed with her in the same inn, <b>are also prohibited.</b> Even if Beit Hillel render these cases prohibited only due to some uncertainty, the ruling is the same.
The Gemara answers: <b>Do not say: In the uncertain</b> cases, i.e., that the <i>halakha</i> involved doubtful circumstances. <b>Rather, say: From the unspecified</b> case. In other words, barring clear knowledge of an uncertain betrothal within a specific family, they would take women from that family in marriage. The reason is <b>that</b> Beit Shammai <b>would notify</b> Beit Hillel of the prohibition according to their opinion, <b>and</b> they would <b>refrain</b> from the marriage. If there was no notification, this was a clear sign that no doubt was involved in this case at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what</b> does <b>this</b> come to <b>teach us?</b> Is it <b>that</b> they had <b>relations of affection and camaraderie between them,</b> i.e., that each trusted that the other side would never cause them to err with regard to something they held to be prohibited? <b>This is</b> the same as the <b>first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>. What is Rabbi Shimon adding by his statement? The Gemara answers: This comes to <b>teach us that the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> This is not a dispute between two Sages. Rather, Rabbi Shimon’s opinion elucidates the earlier statement.
§ The Gemara offers an alternative resolution: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: How should</b> one act with regard to <b>this <i>halakha</i></b> of rival wives? In what form should it <b>become widespread among the Jewish people?</b> If <b>we act in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai</b> and permit a rival wife in levirate marriage, <b>the offspring</b> will be <b>a <i>mamzer</i> according to the statement of Beit Hillel.</b> If <b>we act in accordance with the statement of Beit Hillel</b> and grant full exemption to the rival wives, <b>the offspring will</b> be of <b>flawed</b> lineage <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> as he is the child of a woman prohibited in marriage by a regular prohibition. Although he is not a <i>mamzer</i>, his lineage is nevertheless defective. Instead, <b>let us enact</b> a general decree <b>for rival wives</b>

Daf 15a

that they <b>should perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and not enter into levirate marriage.</b> If they act in this manner, they will be permitted to marry others and the problem will be solved according to all opinions. <b>They were unable to finalize the matter</b> according to the proposition raised by Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri <b>before times of trouble</b> arrived. Due to the outbreak of war they were unable to gather together to vote and establish an accepted halakhic ruling.
Sometime later, when they returned to discuss the issue, <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said to</b> the other Sages: <b>What shall we do with those earlier rival wives from now</b> onward? Since in the meantime some rival wives had entered into levirate marriage, if we issue a collective ruling that rival wives may not do so, their children will be declared <i>mamzerim</i>. Therefore, it is better not to establish this <i>halakha</i> at all.
The Gemara analyzes this episode in relation to the matter at hand. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their own opinion, <b>this is</b> the meaning of <b>what</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>said: What shall we do?</b> Since these rival wives had already entered into levirate marriage, it was impossible to change the status of their children retroactively. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>they did not act</b> in accordance with their opinion, <b>what is</b> the meaning of: <b>What shall we do?</b> If Beit Shammai did not act upon their ruling, they never actually permitted a <i>yavam</i> to take a rival wife in levirate marriage.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This amendment was <b>necessary,</b> not for the benefit of the children of rival wives, as Beit Shammai never in fact acted on their ruling; <b>rather,</b> it was necessary <b>only for the rival wife herself.</b> If these rival wives married others, in the opinion of Beit Shammai their marriages were flawed, as they did not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. And as for the question: <b>What shall we do, this is what</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>those rival wives</b> who were entirely exempt according <b>to Beit Hillel, what</b> should <b>we do with them</b> according <b>to Beit Shammai,</b> as these rival wives had already married others without performing <i>ḥalitza</i>?
The Gemara elaborates: If you say <b>let them perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, they will be repulsive to their husbands,</b> as it will seem to the husband that the woman he has been living with for some time suddenly requires a permit for marriage. <b>And if you would say, let them be repulsive</b> to their husbands, as that is not our concern, this is not the case, as the Torah says: <b>“Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace”</b> (Proverbs 3:17).
§ The Gemara suggests further: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another source, <b>as Rabbi Tarfon said: I yearn</b> for the following scenario: <b>When shall my daughter’s rival wife come before me and I will marry her?</b> In other words, in this hypothetical case I would act in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai and take her in levirate marriage. This statement indicates that those who held by the traditions of Beit Shammai did indeed act upon their opinion. The Gemara amends this statement. <b>Say: And I will marry her off,</b> i.e., I shall act in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel and marry her off to others.
The Gemara asks: <b>But he said: I yearn,</b> and if he meant that he would follow the ruling of Beit Hillel, which is the common practice, what is the novelty of Rabbi Tarfon’s statement? The Gemara responds: Rabbi Tarfon comes <b>to exclude</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> who maintains that all rival wives perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. Rabbi Tarfon yearned for an opportunity to demonstrate that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear an incident involving Rabban Gamliel’s daughter, who was married to Abba, his brother, and</b> Abba <b>died childless, and Rabban Gamliel entered into levirate marriage with her rival wife.</b> This is apparently conclusive proof that the rival wife of a daughter may enter into levirate marriage. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand it</b> that way? Was <b>Rabban Gamliel among the disciples of Beit Shammai?</b> In fact, Rabban Gamliel, who was a descendant of Hillel himself, certainly followed the opinion of Beit Hillel.
<b>Rather,</b> the case of <b>Rabban Gamliel’s daughter is different, as she was a sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>aylonit</i>],</b> and therefore the prohibition against marrying her rival wife does not apply, as explicitly stated in the mishna. The Gemara asks: But <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the same <i>baraita</i>: <b>Others say</b> that <b>Rabban Gamliel’s daughter was an <i>aylonit</i>,</b> it can be derived <b>by inference that the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>she was not an <i>aylonit</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: The dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i> was not about whether or not she was an <i>aylonit</i>, as she certainly was. Rather, the practical difference <b>between them</b> is whether <b>he knew</b> that <b>she</b> was an <i>aylonit</i> at the time of marriage and decided to marry her regardless. Some maintain in general that if the husband was aware of her condition prior to marriage, her rival wife is forbidden, <b>but</b> if <b>he did not know about her</b> status, the rival wife is permitted.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that the practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns a different case, that of one who <b>married and ultimately divorced.</b> This is referring to an issue discussed above of whether a woman is considered the rival wife of a forbidden relation simply by virtue of her marriage to the specific man or whether she must be married to him at the time when the mitzva of levirate obligation takes effect, i.e., at the time of the brother’s death.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that the practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns a case where <b>there is a condition in sexual relations.</b> In other words, the first <i>tanna</i> holds that Rabban Gamliel’s daughter was married only conditionally, and since the condition was never fulfilled the marriage was nullified. Consequently, Rabban Gamliel could marry the other wife regardless of his daughter’s status as an <i>aylonit</i>, as she was never married to his brother at all. However, according to the other <i>tanna</i>, even if the marriage was dependent upon a condition that was not fulfilled, because the man engaged in sexual relations with her the act of intercourse itself serves to nullify the condition. Accordingly, he maintains that the only reason Rabban Gamliel could enter into levirate marriage with his daughter’s rival wife was not because of the condition, but due to the fact that his daughter was an <i>aylonit</i>. Whichever explanation is accepted, this case provides no proof with regard to the issue of whether or not Beit Shammai acted in accordance with their ruling.
§ <b>Rav Mesharshiyya raised an objection</b> against those who claim that Beit Shammai did not act in accordance with their opinion. It is taught in a mishna: There was <b>an incident involving Rabbi Akiva, who collected an <i>etrog</i> on the first of</b> the month of <b>Shevat and performed with it two tenths.</b> In other words, he separated two tithes from the fruit, as though it belonged to two different tithing years. He removed both the second tithe and the poor man’s tithe at the same time, two tithes that should not be separated in the same year.
The mishna explains: <b>One</b> tithe he removed <b>in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai,</b> who hold that the new year for trees occurs on the first of Shevat, which means that the <i>etrog</i> required tithing according to the regulations of the upcoming year. <b>And one</b> tithe was <b>in accordance with the statement of Beit Hillel,</b> who hold the new year for trees is on the fifteenth of Shevat, and therefore the <i>etrog</i> required tithing in accordance with the previous year. The Gemara infers: <b>Conclude from here</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinion, as Rabbi Akiva took care to act in accordance with the ruling of Beit Shammai.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva was uncertain as to his tradition, and he did not know if Beit Hillel said</b> that the New Year for trees occurs <b>on the first of Shevat or if they said</b> it is <b>on the fifteenth of Shevat.</b> He did not act in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai at all; rather, he sought to act in accordance with the ruling of Beit Hillel but was uncertain about their opinion on this matter.
§ <b>Mar Zutra raised an objection</b> to this issue from a different source: There was <b>an incident in which the daughter-in-law of Shammai the Elder gave birth</b> to a son. In Shammai’s opinion this newborn baby is immediately obligated in the mitzva to sit in a <i>sukka</i>, <b>and he</b> therefore <b>removed the mortar [<i>ma’aziva</i>]</b> covering the ceiling <b>and he placed</b> <i>sukka</i> <b>covering over the bed for the minor. Conclude from here</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinions. The Gemara answers: There is no proof from <b>there,</b> as anyone <b>watching</b> would <b>say</b> that <b>he did it</b> merely <b>to increase</b> the <b>air.</b> Since people would not necessarily think that he removed the mortar as a ruling of <i>halakha</i>, this behavior is not considered the formation of a faction.
<b>Mar Zutra raised</b> a further <b>objection:</b> There was <b>an incident involving the Yehu water trough in Jerusalem, which had a hole</b> that connected it <b>to a ritual bath, and all the ritual purifications in Jerusalem were performed in it,</b> i.e., people immersed their utensils in this trough. <b>And Beit Shammai sent</b> messengers <b>and they widened</b> the opening in the water trough, as in the opinion of Beit Shammai the hole was not large enough for the trough to be considered connected to the adjacent ritual bath <b>as Beit Shammai say:</b> The two areas are not connected <b>unless the majority of it is opened.</b> In other words, they require the major portion of the barrier between the ritual bath and the nearby trough to be open.
<b>And we learned</b> in a mishna: Beit Hillel hold that <b>a joining of ritual baths</b> is effective if the hole has the <b>width of the tube</b> used to pour water in and out <b>of a wineskin, and in its</b> open <b>space</b> there is enough room for <b>about two fingers that can return to their place.</b> In other words, if it is possible to insert into the hole two fingers that can move around on all sides, the cavity is sufficiently large to be considered a connection. According to Beit Shammai, however, the hole must open up the majority of the barrier between the two areas. If so, <b>conclude from this</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinions. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>There,</b>

Daf 15b

anyone <b>watching</b> would <b>say</b> that <b>he did</b> it <b>to increase the water</b> flow, and he did not intend to change the <i>halakha</i>. Rather, they would think that he widened the water trough only because there was not enough water flow.
§ The Gemara cites another relevant source. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok said: When I studied Torah with Rabbi Yoḥanan the Ḥorani,</b> who was a disciple of Beit Shammai, <b>I saw that he would eat dry bread in salt in years of drought. I went and informed</b> my <b>father</b> of his meager meal, and <b>he said to me: Take olives</b> for <b>him, and I took</b> for <b>him</b> some olives. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>saw that they were moist</b> with the liquid that oozes from olives, which renders them susceptible to ritual impurity. Concerned that they had already become ritually impure, <b>he said to me: I do not eat olives.</b> He spoke politely and stated that he did not eat olives because he did not wish to embarrass his benefactor by disclosing that he feared they had become ritually impure.
Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok continued his account. <b>I went and informed</b> my <b>father. He said to me: Go and say to him</b> that the <b>barrel</b> containing the olives <b>was perforated, but it was clogged by sediments</b> in the oil and therefore some moisture remained inside. However, due to the presence of the hole, the olives were not rendered susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>And we learned</b> this in a mishna: With regard to <b>a barrel of preserved olives, Beit Shammai say it does not need to be perforated,</b> as the juice issuing from the olives does not render them susceptible to ritual impurity.
<b>And Beit Hillel say</b> that <b>it does need to be perforated,</b> as they maintain that the juice of olives is considered oil and it therefore renders the olives susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>And</b> Beit Hillel <b>concede that if</b> the barrel <b>was perforated and</b> subsequently <b>clogged by sediments it is ritually pure,</b> despite the moisture on the olives. Since liquids render food susceptible to ritual impurity only if they were placed on them intentionally, the hole in the barrel clearly shows that one did not intend for the juice to be there. By boring a hole in the barrel he has rendered it obvious that he did not desire the presence of the olive juices, and therefore it does not matter that the hole became blocked.
The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And although</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan the Ḥorani <b>was a disciple of Shammai, he always acted only in accordance with the statements of Beit Hillel.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>acted</b> in accordance with their opinions, <b>this is</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan the Ḥorani’s <b>greatness,</b> i.e., he is praised for acting in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel. <b>However, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did not act</b> in accordance with their own rulings, <b>what is the greatness</b> and uniqueness <b>of</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan the Ḥorani? From here it can be inferred that Beit Shammai generally did act in accordance with their opinions.
§ The Gemara adds: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof. <b>They asked Rabbi Yehoshua: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>rival wife of a daughter? He said to them:</b> It is a matter of <b>dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel.</b> They continued to ask him: <b>And in accordance with whose statement is the <i>halakha</i>? He said to them: Why are you inserting my head between two great mountains,</b> i.e., <b>between two great disputing</b> opinions, <b>between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel? I fear lest</b> these two mountains <b>break my skull.</b>
<b>However, I shall testify to you about two great families that were in Jerusalem, the Beit Tzevo’im family</b> who came <b>from</b> the town of <b>Ben Akhmai, and the Beit Kofai family from</b> the town of <b>Ben Mekoshesh: They were the descendants of rival wives</b> who married others, in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel, <b>and from them</b> came <b>High Priests who served on the altar.</b> Accordingly, I can testify that this was the accepted halakhic practice throughout the generations.
The Gemara infers from this statement: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Beit Shammai <b>acted</b> in accordance with their opinions, <b>this is why</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said: I fear,</b> since a conclusive halakhic ruling would mean that certain children are <i>mamzerim</i>, and the descendants of that family might take vengeance upon him. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>they did not act</b> in accordance with their opinions, <b>why did he say: I fear?</b> The Gemara retorts: <b>And even</b> if Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their rulings, <b>what is</b> the reason that he said: <b>I fear?</b>
<b>Didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua say</b> that in his opinion <b>a <i>mamzer</i> is only</b> someone born <b>from</b> a union <b>of those liable to</b> receive <b>the court-imposed capital punishments,</b> not from those liable to receive <i>karet</i>. If so, in the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, the children of rival wives who entered into levirate marriage would not be <i>mamzerim</i> at all, and therefore he had no reason to fear reprisals. The Gemara answers: <b>Even if</b> this is the case, nevertheless, he had something to fear, as, although the child of a rival wife would <b>not be a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> he would <b>nevertheless be</b> of <b>flawed</b> lineage and disqualified from the priesthood.
The Gemara adds that this can be derived <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a widow: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a widow, whose prohibition does not apply to all,</b> as she is forbidden in marriage only to a High Priest and not to any other man, <b>and</b> yet the lineage of <b>her son is flawed,</b> as he is disqualified from the priesthood, the son of <b>this</b> rival wife should certainly be disqualified from the priesthood, as <b>her prohibition applies equally to all,</b> even regular Israelites.
§ Incidentally, the Gemara notes a problem with the above discussion: <b>They asked</b> Rabbi Yehoshua about <b>rival wives, and he answered them</b> about <b>the children of rival wives.</b> He did not refer to the rival wives themselves. The Gemara explains: <b>They asked him</b> questions on <b>two</b> matters: First, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>rival wives? And if you say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>rival wives</b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel</b> and they are exempt, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to Beit Shammai</b> in the case of <b>the children of rival wives</b> who, following <b>Beit Hillel,</b> married others without <i>ḥalitza</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference</b> does this question make? Since Rabbi Yehoshua maintains that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the ruling of Beit Hillel, why even discuss Beit Shammai’s opinion on this matter? The Gemara explains: His answer enables one <b>to resolve</b> a different issue, the case of a <b>child of one who remarries his divorcée according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b> Is the child of a divorcée who remarried her previous husband after she had been married to another man fit or disqualified from the priesthood?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Do we say</b> the following <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> with regard to <b>a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest, whose prohibition does not apply to all,</b> as she is prohibited in marriage only to a High Priest, <b>and</b> yet the lineage of <b>her son is flawed</b> as he is disqualified from the priesthood, so too, in the case of <b>this</b> rival wife, <b>whose prohibition applies equally to all</b> men, <b>is it not right that her son</b> should be of <b>flawed</b> lineage?
<b>Or perhaps</b> this comparison <b>can be refuted: What</b> about the fact <b>that a widow</b> is different, <b>as she herself is disqualified</b> from marrying a priest, i.e., if a High Priest has intercourse with her she is disqualified from marrying any member of the entire priesthood, including common priests, whereas a remarried divorcée herself is not disqualified from marrying into the priesthood? <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: I fear</b> that if I issue a decisive ruling concerning <b>rival wives</b> this might lead to a conflict,

Daf 16a

whereas with regard to the <b>children of rival wives, I testify to you</b> that they are not disqualified, since, as stated, their descendants served as High Priests.
§ The Gemara states: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another source that indicates Beit Shammai did act upon their opinions: <b>In the time of Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas, the rival wife of a daughter was permitted to the brothers. Conclude from this</b> that Beit Shammai <b>did act</b> in accordance with their opinions. The Gemara summarizes these proofs: Indeed, <b>conclude from</b> these sources that Beit Shammai did put their rulings into practice.
§ Since the last source is only part of a larger incident, the Gemara cites <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. In the time of Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas</b> the Sages <b>permitted the rival wife of a daughter to the brothers.</b> In other words, it became known that Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas deemed permitted a daughter’s rival wife. <b>And this matter was difficult</b> in the eyes of <b>the Rabbis because he was a great Sage</b> and his decision in favor of Beit Shammai carried great weight. They could not approach him immediately, as he was very old <b>and his eyes had dimmed</b> so much that he was incapable <b>of coming to the study hall.</b>
They <b>said: And who will go and notify him</b> that this matter requires clarification? <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: I will go.</b> They asked: <b>And who</b> shall go <b>after him?</b> They selected <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya,</b> who was one of the great Sages of the generation, notwithstanding his youth. They further inquired: <b>And who after him? Rabbi Akiva. They went and stood at the entrance of</b> Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas’s <b>house. His maidservant entered</b> and <b>said to him: Rabbi, the Sages of Israel have come to you. He said to her: Let them enter, and they entered.</b>
Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas <b>grabbed Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> with whom he was already acquainted, <b>and sat him on a bed of gold,</b> as Rabbi Dosa was extremely wealthy. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: Rabbi, call your other disciple</b> so <b>that he may sit.</b> He asked him to call the other Sage as well, as it is a mark of respect when speaking to a great scholar to call every other Sage his disciple. <b>He said to him: Who is it?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua replied: <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b> Rabbi Dosa <b>said: And does our colleague Azarya have a son?</b> Due to his old age and prolonged absence from the study hall he had not heard of him.
Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas <b>recited this verse about</b> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya: <b>“I have been young, and now am old; yet I have not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread”</b> (Psalms 37:25). He interpreted this verse to mean that the son of a Torah scholar also becomes a Torah scholar. <b>He grabbed him and sat him on a bed of gold.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: Rabbi, call your other disciple</b> so <b>that he may sit. He said to him: Who is that?</b> He said to him: <b>Akiva ben Yosef.</b> Rabbi Dosa <b>said to him: You are Akiva ben Yosef, whose name has spread from one end of the world to the other?</b> Even Rabbi Dosa had heard of Rabbi Akiva’s reputation as a great man. <b>Sit, my son, sit. May the likes of you multiply in Israel.</b>
Out of courtesy, they did not wish to broach the subject immediately. Rather, <b>they began to encircle him with</b> deliberations on different <b><i>halakhot</i>, until they came to</b> the case of the <b>rival wife of a daughter. They said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>rival wife of a daughter? He said</b> that it is a matter of <b>dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel.</b> They asked him: <b>According to whose statement is the <i>halakha</i>? He said to them: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel. They said to him: But didn’t they say in your name that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai?</b>
<b>He said to them: Did you hear</b> that <b>Dosa</b> ben Harkinas issued this ruling, <b>or did you hear</b> that it was stated by <b>ben Harkinas? They said to him: On your life, Rabbi, we heard simply</b> ben Harkinas. <b>He said to them:</b> If so, it is no wonder, as <b>I have a younger brother who is the firstborn of the Satan,</b> i.e., he is extremely sharp and as brazen as a demon. <b>And his name is Yonatan, and he is among the disciples of Shammai.</b> It is he who issued this ruling.
Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas added: <b>And beware that he not batter you with <i>halakhot</i></b> in this matter, <b>as he has with him three hundred proofs with regard to</b> the <b>rival wife of a daughter that she is permitted. However,</b> you need not worry about the issue itself, as <b>I call as witnesses before me the heavens and the earth that on this</b> very <b>mortar,</b> which was preserved in my house due to its historical importance, <b>Haggai the prophet sat, and</b> I have a tradition that <b>he said three matters</b> of <i>halakha</i>: First, that the <b>rival wife of a daughter is forbidden.</b>
Second, that the halakhic rulings for the territories of <b>Ammon and Moab</b> in Transjordan, although similar to those of Eretz Yisrael, are not exactly the same, as their residents <b>tithe the poor man’s tithe in the Sabbatical Year.</b> The total abandonment of fields in the seventh year does not apply in Ammon and Moab, as they are not part of Eretz Yisrael. Instead, in those areas one must bring the poor man’s tithe to the paupers of Eretz Yisrael, as there are no tithes in Eretz Yisrael in the Sabbatical Year. Lastly, Haggai testified: <b>And one accepts converts from the Karduyin and the Tarmodim,</b> without concern that there might be Jews mingled among them, which could render them <i>mamzerim</i> and prohibited from entering the community.
The Sage <b>taught: When they entered, they</b> all <b>entered through one entrance. When they left, they left through three entrances,</b> in an effort to try to find Rabbi Dosa’s brother. <b>Rabbi Akiva encountered him.</b> Yonatan ben Harkinas <b>raised against him</b> all of his <b>objections</b> to the opinion of Beit Hillel, <b>and he withstood him,</b> i.e., Rabbi Akiva was able to respond to all of them.
Yonatan ben Harkinas grew angry and <b>said to him: You are Akiva ben Yosef, whose name has spread from one end of the world to the other? Be happy that you have merited a</b> great <b>name, and</b> yet <b>you have not yet reached</b> the level <b>of cattle herders.</b> Cattle herders were generally simple individuals who were not familiar even with ordinary matters, and certainly not with <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Akiva said to him</b> with characteristic modesty: <b>And</b> I have not <b>even</b> reached the level <b>of shepherds,</b> who are considered even worse than cattle herders, as they are unfit for giving testimony.
§ Since the <i>halakhot</i> of the prophet Haggai were mentioned, the Gemara discusses them here. Haggai said that <b>Ammon and Moab tithe the poor man’s tithe in the Sabbatical Year, as the Master said: Many cities were conquered by those who returned from Egypt, and were not conquered by those who returned from Babylonia</b> after the destruction of the First Temple. <b>And the initial consecration</b> of Eretz Yisrael, by those who returned from Egypt, <b>sanctified it for its time and did not sanctify it forever,</b> as the future sanctification of Eretz Yisrael depended on the renewed conquest of the land by the Jewish people.
<b>And</b> those who returned from Babylonia <b>left those</b> places aside and did not consider them part of Eretz Yisrael even after Jewish settlement was renewed there. They would plow and harvest in these places in the Sabbatical Year and tithe the poor man’s tithe <b>so that the poor</b> of Eretz Yisrael who did not have sufficient income from the previous years <b>could rely upon them.</b> Consequently, <b>in the Sabbatical Year</b> the poor received help from this tithe.
§ Haggai also declared: <b>And one accepts converts from the Karduyim and the Tarmodim.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rami bar Yeḥezkel teach</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One does not accept converts from the Karduyim? Rav Ashi said: Kartuyim,</b> not Karduyim, <b>was stated</b> by Rami bar Yeḥezkel. <b>As people say</b> in common discourse: <b>The Kartuyim are unfit.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> a slightly different version of this discussion. <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught: One does not accept converts from the Kartuyim. What, is it not</b> the case that <b>Kartuyim is</b> the same as <b>Karduyim?</b> If so there is a contradiction between the <i>baraita</i> of Rami bar Yeḥezkel and the statement of Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas. <b>Rav Ashi said: No; the Kartuyim are</b> one <b>discrete</b> category <b>and the Karduyim are</b> another <b>discrete</b> category, <b>as people say: Kartuyim are unfit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and the Elders both say: One does not accept converts from the Tarmodim.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that one does not accept converts from the Tarmodim due to a concern that Jews may have intermingled with them? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>All</b> clothing with <b>stains</b> of blood that might be from a menstruating woman and <b>that come from the</b> city on the border of Eretz Yisrael called <b>Rekem are ritually pure,</b> as it can be assumed that they belong to gentiles, and the blood of a menstruating gentile woman is not ritually impure.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> it <b>ritually impure because those</b> residents of that place <b>are converts and are in error.</b> In other words, some of the inhabitants of Rekem assimilated and no longer observe the <i>halakhot</i> of the Torah, and therefore one must be wary lest the stains are in fact from a Jewish menstruating woman. Stains that came <b>from among the gentiles,</b> however, <b>are ritually pure. And we discussed</b> the following problem:

Daf 16b

The <i>tanna</i> <b>concluded and taught:</b> All stains from <b>among the gentiles</b> are pure, from which it may be inferred: <b>And even from Tarmod.</b> This indicates that in all places inhabited by gentiles there is no need to be concerned about stains. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That is to say, one accepts converts from Tarmod</b> without concern that they might be Jewish, albeit <i>mamzerim</i>. This contradicts the previous opinion attributed to Rabbi Yoḥanan that converts from the Tarmodim are not accepted.
<b>And if you would say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan specifically emphasized: <b>That</b> is to say, i.e., he meant that this conclusion may be logically inferred from the mishna, <b>and</b> yet <b>he</b> himself <b>does not hold</b> by <b>this</b> opinion, <b>but didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan state</b> a principle that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>an unattributed mishna,</b> as is the case here? The Gemara answers: <b>They are <i>amora’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Some Sages said in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s name that the Tarmodim are unfit, while others maintain that they are fit.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that the Sages do <b>not</b> accept converts <b>from Tarmod? Rabbi Yoḥanan and the Elders disagree</b> about <b>this</b> matter. Although they concur that converts from Tarmod are not accepted, they disagree with regard to the reason. <b>One</b> of them <b>said</b> that it is <b>due to the servants of</b> King <b>Solomon.</b> Solomon built a city in Tarmod (see I Kings 9:18), and his gentile servants, taking advantage of their status and power, married Jewish women unlawfully. Therefore, it is possible that the inhabitants of Tarmod and their descendants are <i>mamzerim</i>. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said</b> that it is <b>due to the daughters of Jerusalem,</b> who were taken captive and raped and gave birth to children among the gentiles.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> that it is <b>due to the servants of Solomon,</b> this is logical, as <b>he holds</b> that in the case of <b>a gentile or a slave who had intercourse with a Jewish woman, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Accordingly, as the servants of Solomon were slaves and they engaged in intercourse with Jewish women, their children are considered <i>mamzerim</i>. <b>However, according to the one who said</b> that it is <b>due to the daughters of Jerusalem, what is</b> the reason that the concern applied specifically to Tarmod and no other cities? <b>Rav Yosef and the Rabbis disagree</b> with regard to <b>this</b> question, <b>and both</b> stated their opinions <b>in the name of Rabba bar bar Ḥana.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>One</b> of them <b>said</b> that <b>twelve thousand men and six thousand archers</b> came from Tarmod, <b>and</b> the other <b>one said</b> that there were <b>twelve thousand men, of whom six thousand</b> were <b>archers. When the gentiles entered the Sanctuary</b> during the conquest of Jerusalem, they <b>all turned to</b> plunder the <b>silver and the gold</b> they saw there, <b>but</b> the warriors of Tarmod <b>turned to the daughters of Jerusalem, as it is stated: “They have ravished the women in Zion, the maidens in the cities of Judah”</b> (Lamentations 5:11). According to the opinion that children born of relations between gentiles and Jewish women are <i>mamzerim</i>, all the children born to these women are <i>mamzerim</i>.
§ In relation to a verse cited earlier, <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: This verse was stated by the ministering angel</b> appointed over <b>the world: “I have been young, and now am old;</b> yet I have not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread” (Psalms 37:25). <b>Who said this? If we say</b> that it was <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, is there old age before Him?</b> Could God possibly say: “I have been young, and now am old”? <b>And rather,</b> one could say that <b>David</b> himself <b>said it,</b> from his own experience; but <b>was he indeed so old?</b> After all, David died at the age of seventy. <b>Rather, conclude from this</b> that <b>the ministering angel</b> appointed over <b>the world said it,</b> as he can speak both of youth and old age, and it is he who reported his observations from around the world.
<b>And Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani</b> further <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “The adversary has spread out his hand upon all her treasures;</b> for she has seen that the heathens have entered into her Temple, concerning which You commanded that they should not enter into Your congregation” (Lamentations 1:10)? <b>This</b> is referring to <b>Ammon and Moab.</b> How so? <b>When the gentiles entered the Sanctuary, all turned to</b> plunder <b>the silver and the gold, and</b> the soldiers from Ammon and Moab <b>turned to the scrolls of Torah</b> to destroy them. <b>They said:</b> Is <b>this</b> the scroll <b>in which it is written: “An Ammonite and a Moabite shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:4)? <b>Let it be burnt by fire.</b>
With regard to the Ammonites, the Gemara cites another verse: <b>“The Lord has commanded against Jacob that they who are round about him should be his adversaries”</b> (Lamentations 1:17). <b>Rav said: For an example</b> of this, there is the city <b>Homanya</b> in relation <b>to</b> the city <b>Pum Nahara,</b> as the descendants of the Ammonites live in Homanya, and they harass the Jews of Pum Nahara.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said:</b> With regard to <b>a gentile who betrothed</b> a Jewish woman <b>nowadays, we are concerned that the betrothal</b> might be valid, despite the fact that a betrothal of a gentile is meaningless, <b>lest he be from the ten tribes</b> of Israel who intermingled with the gentiles. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But</b> there is an important principle in <i>halakha</i> that <b>any</b> item <b>separated,</b> i.e., not fixed in its place, is presumed to have been <b>separated from the majority.</b> In this case, it can be assumed that any individual singled out from the gentiles belongs to the majority of gentiles and has no Jewish roots at all.
The Gemara responds: Rav Yehuda means that there is a concern only with regard to those who came from <b>the permanent</b> dwelling <b>places</b> of the ten tribes. <b>As Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said</b> that the verse states about those exiled from Samaria: <b>“And he put them in Halah, and in Habor, on the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes”</b> (I Kings 18:11). Rabbi Abba bar Kahana proceeded to identify these places. <b>Halah; this is</b> the place called <b>Ḥalzon. And Habor;</b>

Daf 17a

<b>this is Ḥadyab. The river of Gozan; this is Ginzak. And the cities of the Medes; this is Ḥamadan and its surroundings. And some say: This is Nihar and its surroundings.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Which are its surroundings? Shmuel said: Kerakh, Mushkhei, Ḥidkei, and Domakya</b> are the surroundings of Ḥamadan. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And all of them are for disqualification.</b> In other words, if someone from one of these places wishes to convert, there is concern that he might be a descendant of a Jew and therefore a <i>mamzer</i>. Consequently, they all are disqualified.
Rav Yehuda continued his recounting: <b>When I said this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that there is a concern about the betrothal of gentiles nowadays, <b>before Shmuel, he said to me:</b> One need not worry about this, as <b>your son from a Jewish woman is called your son,</b> i.e., he inherits his lineage from you, <b>and your son from a gentile woman is not called your son,</b> but <b>rather her son.</b> Consequently, all children born to Jews from gentile women are not considered Jews, as their lineage is determined by their gentile mothers.
The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t there</b> Jewish <b>girls</b> who were captured by gentiles, whose children are considered to be Jews? <b>And Ravina said: Learn from this</b> that <b>the son of your daughter from a gentile is called your son.</b> If so, the descendants of Jewish women captured by gentiles would indeed be Jews. The Gemara answers: This is no concern, as it <b>is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that the girls</b> from the ten tribes <b>of that generation became barren</b> and did not give birth to any offspring, whereas some of the exiled men of the ten tribes married gentile women. Consequently, all of the children born there were gentiles.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rav Yehuda actually related the following: <b>When I said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Shmuel, he said to me: They did not move from there,</b> the place where they deliberated on this matter, <b>until they rendered</b> all of <b>them,</b> including those who intermingled with the ten tribes in different locations, <b>full-fledged gentiles.</b> Consequently, there is no concern that their betrothals might be of any effect, <b>as it is stated: “They have dealt treacherously against the Lord, for they have begotten strange children”</b> (Hosea 5:7).
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yosef sat behind Rav Kahana, and Rav Kahana sat before Rav Yehuda, and he sat and he said</b> this tradition: <b>In the future, the Jews will establish a Festival day when Tarmod is destroyed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But it has</b> already <b>been destroyed.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> place that was destroyed <b>was Tamud,</b> not Tarmod. <b>Rav Ashi said: Tarmod is</b> the same as <b>Tamud.</b> However, the city <b>is doubled.</b> In other words, when it <b>is destroyed from this side it is settled on that side, and</b> when it <b>is destroyed from that side it is settled on this side.</b> Consequently, it has not yet been entirely destroyed.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Hamnuna sat before Ulla and was engaged in</b> the study of <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> Ulla <b>said</b> about him: <b>What a man; what a man.</b> In other words: What a great man this Rav Hamnuna is. <b>If only Harpanya were not his city,</b> as the inhabitants of that place are all of flawed lineage, which indicates that the lineage of Rav Hamnuna is likewise impaired. Rav Hamnuna <b>was ashamed.</b> Ulla <b>said to him: Where do you give the money for</b> payment of the <b>poll</b> tax? <b>He said to him:</b> I pay it <b>to</b> the city of <b>Pum Nahara,</b> as my city is subject to taxation by that city. <b>He said to him: If so, you are from Pum Nahara,</b> not Harpanya, and your lineage is evidently not flawed.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the name <b>Harpanya? Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It means <b>the mountain to which all turn [<i>har shehakol ponin bo</i>].</b> In other words, it is the destination for all those who could not find wives anywhere else, as most of its population is of flawed lineage. <b>It is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: All those who do not know their family or tribe turn there. Rava said: This</b> type of flaw is appalling and <b>is deeper than the netherworld, as is stated: “Shall I ransom them from the power of the netherworld? Shall I redeem them from death?”</b> (Hosea 13:14). This verse indicates that it is possible to be ransomed and released from the netherworld, <b>whereas their disqualification cannot be rectified.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Those</b> who are <b>disqualified from Harpanya</b> are unfit <b>due to the disqualification</b> of the inhabitants <b>of</b> nearby <b>Meishon,</b> who were unfit and intermarried with the residents of Harpanya. <b>Those disqualified from Meishon</b> are unfit <b>due to those disqualified from Tarmod, and those disqualified from Tarmod</b> are disqualified <b>due to the servants of Solomon.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And this</b> explains the folk saying <b>that people say</b> in this regard: <b>A large ephah and a small ephah,</b> which are both inaccurate utensils that may not be used for measuring, <b>roll onward to the netherworld, and from the netherworld to Tarmod, and from Tarmod to Meishon, and from Meishon to Harpanya.</b> The same idea expressed by the Sages with regard to the disqualification of lineage was also incorporated into a well-known adage among commoners.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Each of the women enumerated in the first chapter causes exemption from levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i> for her rival wives. This is due to the close family relationship she has with her brother-in-law, making her forbidden to him. The single exception is the case explained in this mishna. <b>What</b> is the case of <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist?</b> For example: If there were <b>two brothers, and one of them died</b> childless, <b>and</b> subsequently <b>a brother of theirs was born, after which the second brother,</b> the elder, <b>took his</b> deceased <b>brother’s wife in levirate marriage, and</b> then <b>died</b> as well. Consequently, two women require levirate marriage: The widow of the first brother who had been taken in levirate marriage by the second brother, and the widow of the second brother, the first widow’s rival wife. <b>The first</b> widow, who had been the wife of the first brother to die, <b>goes out</b> without any obligation to be taken in levirate marriage by the youngest brother who was born later, <b>since</b> she is <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.</b> The first deceased brother never lived at the same time as the newly born brother. <b>The second</b> widow, who had been married to the second brother, is exempt <b>due to her rival wife.</b>
The mishna discusses an additional situation: If the second brother had <b>performed</b> only <b>levirate betrothal with her,</b> meaning that he had not yet consummated the marriage, <b>and</b> then <b>died,</b> both the wife betrothed by a levirate betrothal to the second brother and the wife of the second brother fall before the youngest brother born after the death of the first brother. In that case, the first wife certainly goes out and is exempt from both <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage, since she is to him the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. <b>The second,</b> however, was never effectively the rival wife of the first brother’s wife, as the first brother’s wife had only been betrothed by levirate betrothal and was not fully married to the second brother. Therefore, <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Naḥman said: He who taught</b> the version of the mishna which reads: <b>The first</b> widow goes out, <b>is not mistaken</b> in his version, and <b>he who taught</b> a variant version of the mishna which reads: <b>The second</b> widow goes out, <b>is not mistaken</b> either, since it is possible to understand the mishna both ways. Both versions of the text can refer to the same woman, i.e., the wife of the first brother, by different titles. The Gemara explains that <b>he who taught:</b>

Daf 17b

<b>The first, is not mistaken,</b> as <b>what is</b> the meaning of <b>first?</b> It means <b>the first to fall</b> before her <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage. <b>And he who taught</b> referring to her as <b>the second is not mistaken</b> either, as <b>what is</b> the meaning of <b>second?</b> It means <b>the second to enter marriage.</b> Since the second deceased brother was already married to one woman, this <i>yevama</i> whom he took in levirate marriage was his second wife. The Gemara wonders: Is this the necessary order of events? <b>Are we not</b> also <b>dealing with</b> a scenario <b>in which</b> the second brother <b>took</b> the wife of the first brother <b>in levirate marriage and then later took</b> another wife? Would such a situation not merit the same ruling? <b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of calling the wife of the first brother <b>the second?</b> It means <b>she who had been married for a second time.</b> She had already been married twice, whereas the wife of the second brother had been married only once.
§ The Gemara turns from a review of the language used in the mishna to a discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> of a wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist. <b>Where is it written</b> that the mitzva of levirate marriage does not apply in the case of <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist? Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: The verse states “If brothers dwell together</b> and one of them dies” (Deuteronomy 25:5), meaning <b>that they had a common dwelling</b> together <b>in the world.</b> This <b>excludes the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.</b> Furthermore, it is derived: <b>“Together”</b> means that they were <b>united</b> together <b>in an inheritance;</b> i.e., they are united in that they inherit together. In other words, since property is inherited by sons from their father, it can be inferred that the verse is speaking specifically of brothers from the same father. This <b>excludes his maternal</b> half <b>brother,</b> with whom he is not united by inheritance, since only brothers who share the same father inherit from each other.
<b>Rabba said: One learns</b> the ruling that levirate marriage applies only to <b>brothers from the</b> same <b>father</b> by the verbal analogy between the term <b>brotherhood</b> used in the context of levirate marriage and the term <b>brotherhood from the children of Jacob. Just as there,</b> with regard to the children of Jacob, they are all brothers <b>from the father and not from the mother,</b> since they were from four different mothers, <b>so too, here,</b> in the case of levirate marriage, it is referring specifically to brothers <b>from the father and not from the mother.</b>
The Gemara raises an objection: Why should we learn from the children of Jacob? <b>Let it derive</b> the meaning of the term <b>brotherhood</b> by verbal analogy to the term <b>brotherhood from</b> the verses discussing <b>those with whom relations are forbidden.</b> In the <i>halakhot</i> of forbidden relations, both paternal and maternal half brothers are considered brothers, and are thereby subject to such prohibitions as those against relations with a brother’s wife. The Gemara answers: The first analogy is preferable, as <b>we infer “brothers” from “brothers.”</b> The word “brothers” is stated both with regard to the children of Jacob and with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of levirate marriage, <b>whereas</b> with regard to forbidden relations it says “your brother,” and <b>one cannot make an inference to “brothers” from “your brother.”</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>What difference does it make</b> if there is a minor difference between the words being compared? <b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> a verbal analogy with regard to leprosy of houses between the verse <b>“and the priest shall return [<i>veshav</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:39) and the verse <b>“and the priest shall come [<i>uva</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:44), from which it is derived that <b>this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>returning,</b> i.e., it is after seven days, and <b>this is</b> the same <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>coming,</b> that it is after seven days. Consequently, a less pronounced difference of one letter between the Hebrew words for “brothers” and “your brother” should certainly not prevent the teaching of a verbal analogy. The Gemara responds: <b>This applies when nothing</b> else <b>was</b> more <b>similar, but where there is something similar we infer from that which is more similar.</b> In such situations, it is preferable to learn from the word that bears greater similarity.
The Gemara objects on another count: <b>Let</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>derive</b> the meaning of the term <b>brotherhood</b> from the term <b>brotherhood from Lot, as it is written</b> that Abraham said to Lot: <b>“For we are brothers”</b> (Genesis 13:8). From here one could conclude that the word brothers means relatives and not necessarily brothers. The Gemara rejects this: <b>It is</b> more <b>reasonable to derive from the children of Jacob, due to</b> the fact that the word “brothers” <b>is free</b> in its context and is therefore available to be used in a verbal analogy: <b>Since it could have written: We your servants are twelve children of our father,</b> but instead it <b>writes:</b> “Twelve <b>brothers,</b> the children of one man” (Genesis 42:13), <b>learn from here</b> that this comes <b>to render</b> the word “brothers” <b>free</b> so that it may be allocated to another matter, i.e., the definition of brothers.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> although Rav Yehuda and Rabba learned the same ruling from two different passages, according to both <b>it was necessary to write “brothers” and it was necessary to write “together”</b> in the verses discussing levirate marriage, <b>as, if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“brothers,” I would say that one should infer</b> the meaning of the term <b>“brothers”</b> from the term <b>“brothers” from Lot. And if you would say it is not free</b> there in the same way that the word “brothers” is free in the passage concerning the children of Jacob, this is <b>not so;</b> in fact, <b>it is free.</b> With regard to Lot <b>it could have written: Friends,</b> as they were not actual brothers but relatives, <b>and</b> yet <b>“brothers” is written.</b> One might <b>learn from</b> here <b>that this is free</b> to be allocated elsewhere and teach that such relatives are called brothers even for levirate marriage. Therefore, <b>the Torah wrote “together”</b> to teach that this applies specifically to <b>those</b> brothers who are <b>united in an inheritance.</b>
<b>And if the Merciful One had written “together”</b> alone and not added “brothers,” <b>I would say that</b> they must <b>have</b> both <b>the same father and mother together,</b> and that otherwise the mitzva of levirate marriage would not apply. Therefore, “brothers” is written to compare this to the children of Jacob, who were brothers from the same father but not the same mother. It is for this reason, then, that <b>it</b> is <b>necessary</b> to write both.
The Gemara asks about the last supposition: <b>But from where would it be derived</b> that perhaps levirate marriage would apply only if they are full brothers, sharing both a father and mother? Why should one assume that maternal brotherhood is also of import here? Doesn’t <b>the Merciful One make levirate marriage dependent upon inheritance?</b> The Torah states that the <i>yavam</i> who performs the levirate marriage will establish the name of his deceased brother, meaning that he inherits from him, <b>and inheritance</b> comes <b>from the father and not from the mother.</b> Nevertheless, this <b>was necessary,</b> as <b>it could enter your mind to say that since this</b> <i>halakha</i> of levirate marriage <b>is a novelty</b> in <b>that</b> a woman who was a <b>forbidden relation to him</b> as a brother’s wife <b>is</b> now <b>rendered permitted, say</b> that this permissibility will be limited <b>only to</b> cases of brothers <b>with the same father and same mother together.</b> It is due to this possibility that the verbal analogy to the brothers who were the children of Jacob is <b>necessary.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>a widow</b> whose husband had died childless and who is <b>waiting for her <i>yavam</i></b> to perform levirate marriage or set her free with <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>who</b> then <b>died</b> before her <i>yavam</i> could take her in levirate marriage, the <i>yavam</i> <b>is permitted to</b> marry <b>her mother.</b> The levirate obligation does not create a familial relation between them. <b>Apparently,</b> Rav Huna says that Rav <b>holds</b> that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond [<i>zikka</i>] is not substantial.</b> In other words, the bond formed between the <i>yevama</i> and her <i>yavam</i> requiring levirate marriage does not create a halakhic connection between the two. The Gemara asks: <b>Then let him say</b> explicitly: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of he who says</b> that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial,</b> as this issue is in fact a matter of dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>. Why did he not simply conclude that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> who held that the levirate bond is not substantial?
The Gemara answers: <b>If he had said that, I would say: This</b> statement that the levirate bond is not substantial <b>applies</b> only in reference <b>to two</b> brothers, each of whom has the possibility to take her in levirate marriage. In such cases the levirate bond between either one of the brothers and the <i>yevama</i> is not absolute, as it is always possible for the other brother to marry her instead. <b>But in</b> cases of <b>one</b> brother, then since the obligation to the <i>yevama</i> is exclusively his, I would say that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Then let him say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial, even in</b> the case of <b>one</b> brother. The Gemara answers: <b>If he had said that, I would say: Even</b> if his <i>yevama</i> were <b>alive</b> and required levirate marriage with him, he would be allowed to take her mother in marriage. Therefore, <b>this comes to teach us</b> that <b>after death, yes, he is</b> permitted to marry her mother; but <b>while</b> she is <b>alive,</b> he is <b>not.</b> Why not? This is <b>because it is prohibited to nullify the mitzva of levirate marriage.</b> Were he to marry her mother, he would no longer be able to take the daughter in levirate marriage because his wife’s daughter is forbidden to him. As a result of his marriage, he would cancel the mitzva of levirate marriage so that it could no longer apply to him.
The Gemara raises an objection to the statement of Rav Huna: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna (49a): If <b>his <i>yevama</i> dies, he is permitted to</b> marry <b>her sister.</b> A precise reading of this phrase leads to the implication that with regard to <b>her sister, yes,</b> it is permitted, as even if it had been his wife who had died he would be permitted to marry her sister. But with regard to <b>her mother, no,</b> it is not permitted.
The Gemara rejects this: No evidence can be derived from here, as it is possible to say that <b>the same is true even for her mother,</b> that she too is permitted. <b>But since it taught in the first clause</b> of this mishna: If <b>his wife dies he is permitted to take her sister,</b> and there the language is precise and implies: <b>Her sister, yes, but her mother, no, as she is forbidden by Torah</b> law because it is prohibited for a man to marry both a woman and her daughter even after one of them dies, therefore he used the same language when <b>he taught the latter clause</b> of the same mishna that <b>he is permitted to</b> take <b>her sister.</b> However, in the latter clause it is not an exact reading, and in actuality one is allowed to marry any of her relatives. This completes the Gemara’s explanation of Rav Huna’s opinion.
<b>And Rav Yehuda said:</b> In the case of <b>a widow who dies</b> while <b>waiting for her brother-in-law</b> to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage, <b>he is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>her mother.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently</b> Rav Yehuda <b>holds</b> that <b>the levirate bond is substantial;</b> this would mean that the attachment between the <i>yevama</i> and the <i>yavam</i> is like that of marriage and that the <i>yavam</i> is therefore prohibited from marrying her relatives. <b>But</b> it must be asked: Why does Rav Yehuda say it in such a way? <b>Let</b> him <b>say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of the one who says that the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If he would have said that, I would say that</b> with regard to the levirate bond, <b>this applies in</b> the case of <b>one</b> brother, <b>but</b> if there were <b>two</b> brothers then <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>But when</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree,</b> they <b>disagree in</b> a case of <b>two</b> brothers, so how could one think that Rav Yehuda is speaking only in the case of a single brother? <b>Rather,</b> one must say: <b>If he were to say that</b> the conclusive halakhic ruling is that the bond is substantial,

Daf 18a

<b>I would say</b> that the levirate bond applies as long as the <i>yevama</i> requiring levirate marriage <b>is alive but</b> that <b>after</b> her <b>death the bond was terminated.</b> In other words, after the <i>yevama</i> died any relationship between the two dissolved. <b>This comes to teach us that the bond is not terminated without cause</b> but instead requires an actual act, such as <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage. Until one of these acts is performed, the bond remains in place. <b>Let us say that it supports</b> Rav Yehuda’s opinion from that which was taught: If <b>his <i>yevama</i> dies, he is permitted to</b> marry <b>her sister.</b> From here the Gemara deduces: <b>Her sister, yes; her mother, no,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rav Yehuda.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>The same is true, that even her mother</b> is permitted. <b>And</b> this language was used only <b>since he taught in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>his wife dies he is permitted to take her sister; specifically her sister but not her mother, as she is forbidden by Torah</b> law. Therefore, <b>he also taught in the latter clause</b> that <b>he is permitted to</b> marry <b>her sister.</b>
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya raised an objection</b> to this from the mishna: If <b>he performed levirate betrothal with her and</b> then <b>died, the second</b> woman <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> This implies that <b>the reason is</b> specifically <b>that he performed levirate betrothal with her. Had</b> the brother <b>not performed levirate betrothal with her, the second</b> woman <b>would also</b> be permitted to <b>enter into levirate marriage. And if you say that the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial,</b> then she would be considered <b>a rival wife of the wife of a brother with whom</b> the third brother <b>did not coexist by that bond.</b> Since the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist is prohibited from entering into levirate marriage, her rival wife would likewise be forbidden from doing so.
