<b>Rabba said:</b> This should not be read precisely, as <b>the same is true even if</b> the second brother <b>did not perform levirate betrothal; the second</b> woman <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not enter into levirate marriage,</b> as the levirate bond renders her a rival wife of the wife of a brother with whom the third brother did not coexist.
<b>And</b> the reason <b>that</b> it <b>teaches</b> the case of <b>levirate betrothal</b> specifically was <b>in order to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who said:</b> The legal status of <b>levirate betrothal</b> with a <i>yevama</i> eligible for levirate marriage <b>is</b> that of <b>a full-fledged acquisition,</b> and it is legally binding to the same degree as an actual betrothal. Therefore, even <i>ḥalitza</i> would be unnecessary, similar to the case of a rival wife of a forbidden relation. This is what <b>it comes to teach us:</b> Even if he performed levirate betrothal she is not truly considered the rival wife of a forbidden relation; the prohibition concerning her is by rabbinic law, and she is therefore required to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> this from that which was taught: In the case of <b>two brothers who coexisted, and one died childless and the second arose to perform levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> but did not manage to perform levirate betrothal before</b> a third <b>brother was born, and</b> then the second brother, who also had a wife, <b>died,</b> whereby both women would fall before the newly born brother for levirate marriage, then <b>the first goes out</b> and is not obligated in levirate marriage <b>because</b> she is <b>the wife of his brother with whom he did not coexist, and the second</b> woman, who was the wife of the second brother, <b>either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage. But if you say that the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial,</b> then the wife of the second brother <b>would be rendered a rival wife of the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist</b> by that <b>bond.</b>
The Gemara rejects that: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: The</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rabbi Meir hold that the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial?</b> After all, unattributed <i>mishnayot</i> are in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, and <b>didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (26a): In the case of <b>four brothers, two of whom are married to two sisters,</b> if <b>those married to the sisters died,</b> whereby both sisters fall before the surviving brothers for levirate marriage, <b>then those</b> two sisters <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> It would seem that the reason for this is that each of the sisters has a levirate bond to both remaining brothers.
<b>And if it enters your mind to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir held that the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial,</b> didn’t <b>these</b> two sisters <b>come from two</b> different <b>houses,</b> as each was married to a different brother? If so, <b>one</b> brother <b>should take one in levirate marriage and the other should take one in levirate marriage.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> in Rabbi Meir’s opinion <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial.</b> The mishna states that they perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and do not enter into levirate marriage <b>because he held that it is prohibited to nullify the mitzva of levirate marriage.</b> That is to say, it is prohibited to act in such a way that the mitzva of levirate marriage becomes obviated. Under these circumstances there is concern that <b>perhaps as one</b> brother <b>performs levirate marriage</b> to one of the sisters <b>the other</b> brother <b>dies</b> before he manages to perform levirate marriage to the other. If that were to happen, <b>you</b> would thereby <b>nullify the mitzva of levirate marriage</b> since the sister that would now fall before the remaining brother would be his wife’s sister and therefore prohibited from entering into levirate marriage with him.
The Gemara objects: <b>But if the</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial,</b> then <b>let</b> the mitzva of levirate marriage <b>be nullified.</b> That is, if the levirate bond does not carry any real obligation, then the mitzva itself never truly came into effect. <b>As Rabban Gamliel said: The</b> levirate <b>bond is not substantial, and it is permitted to nullify the mitzva of levirate marriage.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (109a): That mishna discusses a case of two brothers who were married to two sisters. One sister is an adult and therefore her marriage was fully effectual, and one sister is still a minor, and she was orphaned from her father, and her marriage was valid only by rabbinic ordinance. If the brother who was married to the elder sister died, then that sister falls for levirate marriage before the brother married to the minor. Under these circumstances, the Sages suggested directing the minor to refuse her marriage to her husband so that he would be able to take his brother’s wife in levirate marriage. If the minor does not do so, he would be unable to take her sister in marriage, as she would be the sister of his minor wife and thereby fully exempt from the levirate obligation. <b>Rabban Gamliel said: If</b> the minor <b>refused</b> in the meantime of her own accord, <b>then she refused, but if she did not refuse, let her wait until she reaches</b> the age of <b>maturity, and</b> then <b>that other</b> adult sister <b>will be exempt</b> from performing <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage <b>due to</b> the fact that she is his <b>wife’s sister.</b> Here it is apparent that Rabban Gamliel is not concerned about nullifying the mitzva of levirate marriage from one of them.
Rabba <b>said to</b> Abaye: Do you wish to <b>raise a contradiction between</b> the words of <b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Meir?</b> This would imply that the contradiction needs to be resolved, but statements from two different <i>tanna’im</i> do not need to agree or to be resolved. Abaye responded: <b>No,</b> in fact <b>this is what we meant to say:</b> How could one possibly say that <b>Rabbi Meir is concerned</b> lest there be nullification of the mitzva of levirate marriage <b>even when it is uncertain</b> because perhaps the first brother will not die, whereas <b>Rabban Gamliel is not concerned</b> that the mitzva be nullified <b>even when it is certain?</b> It is surprising that there should be such a great difference between the tannaitic opinions. Rabba answered: <b>Perhaps the one who is not concerned</b> about nullification of the mitzva of levirate marriage <b>is not concerned even if</b> nullification is <b>certain, and the one who is concerned is concerned even if</b> nullification <b>is uncertain.</b>
With regard to the actual dispute between Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda, <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: This</b> <i>halakha</i> stated <b>by Rav Yehuda,</b> that even if a woman waiting for levirate marriage dies her mother is still forbidden to the <i>yavam</i>, <b>is</b> from his teacher <b>Shmuel</b> and not from Rav, who was also one of his teachers. Evidence for this can be found in <b>that</b> which <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (41a):

Daf 18b

In the case of <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i></b> to take her in levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, if <b>his brother betrothed her sister they said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira: They say to</b> the brother who betrothed her: <b>Wait</b> and do not marry your betrothed <b>until your brother performs</b> the required <b>action,</b> either <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage. This is because until that time the levirate bond is still applicable and the woman betrothed to you is forbidden to you as the sister of a woman bonded to you. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.</b> From here one may infer that Shmuel holds that the levirate bond is substantial.
Rav Yosef <b>said to him: And if</b> it were the opinion <b>of Rav, what</b> problem would there be? Abaye <b>said to him: It</b> is <b>difficult</b> because there would be a contradiction between the opinion <b>of Rav</b> and another statement <b>of Rav,</b> since Rav Huna cited Rav, and the conclusion from his statements was that the levirate bond is not substantial. He said to him: Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda each cited Rav. <b>Perhaps they are <i>amora’im</i> and</b> disagree <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> i.e., with regard to his opinion? The Gemara answers: <b>Since that which was stated in the name of Shmuel was explicit, while that</b> said <b>in the name of Rav</b> must be explained <b>as an amoraic</b> dispute, <b>we will not leave</b> that statement said <b>explicitly in the name of Shmuel and explain it as an amoraic</b> dispute <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana said: I reported this discussion before Rav Zevid of Neharde’a. He said: That is how you teach this,</b> without knowing for certain that Rav Yehuda was stating the <i>halakha</i> in the name of Shmuel. <b>We learn</b> it <b>explicitly: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In the case of <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> who died</b> before he could perform <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage, <b>he is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>her mother. Apparently</b> Shmuel <b>holds</b> that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial. And Shmuel</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel</b> also <b>said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.</b>
The Gemara comments: Both statements by Shmuel on the subject <b>are necessary</b> and there was no redundancy here, <b>as, if he were to teach us</b> only the principle that <b>the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial, I would say</b> that <b>this applies</b> only <b>to</b> the case of <b>one</b> <i>yavam</i> <b>but not to</b> a case of <b>two</b> <i>yevamin</i>, where the levirate bond is not as strong. <b>This comes to teach us</b> that even in the case of two <i>yevamin</i> there is a bond, and that is the conclusive <i>halakha</i> put forth by Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira. <b>And if he were to teach us</b> only that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, I would say that this applies</b> only in the case <b>where</b> the woman awaiting levirate marriage <b>is living, but after her death the</b> levirate <b>bond is terminated</b> and he is permitted to marry her relatives. <b>This comes to teach us that the</b> levirate <b>bond is not terminated without cause</b> but rather it is necessary to perform some act in order to exempt her from it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there were <b>two brothers, and one died, and the second entered into levirate marriage with his brother’s wife</b> while he was already married to another woman, <b>and subsequently</b> a third <b>brother was born to them, and</b> the second brother then <b>died,</b> whereby both of his wives happened before the third brother for levirate marriage, then <b>the first woman,</b> who was the wife of the first brother, <b>is exempt due to</b> the fact that she is <b>the wife of a brother with whom</b> the third brother <b>did not coexist, and the second</b> woman, who was the first wife of the second brother, is exempt <b>due to her rival wife.</b> If the second brother had <b>performed</b> only <b>levirate betrothal with her and</b> then <b>died</b> before fully marrying her, <b>the second</b> woman <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage,</b> as the levirate betrothal is not considered a sufficiently valid marriage so as to render her the rival wife of a relation forbidden to the third brother.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> with regard to the first clause of the mishna: The third brother either <b>enters into levirate marriage with whichever one he wishes, or he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with whichever one he wishes.</b> Since he was born after his second brother had already entered into levirate marriage with the first brother’s widow, she is considered the wife of a brother with whom he did coexist, not the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. Therefore, he may enter into levirate marriage with her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Oshaya said: Rabbi Shimon’s opinion differed even on the first</b> mishna. That is, Rabbi Shimon disagreed not only in the case stated explicitly in this mishna, in which the newly born brother came into the world after the widow of his first brother had already married his second brother, but he also disagreed in the case of the first mishna in the chapter, where the third brother was born prior to his second brother entering into levirate marriage with the widow. <b>From where</b> is this derived? Rav Oshaya came to this conclusion <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches a superfluous mishna.</b>
How so? <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is it teaching the section of the first clause,</b> i.e., the previous mishna? <b>If we say</b> it is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who prohibit marriage to the wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist in all cases, then let us look at the second mishna. <b>Now</b> that even in the case where the second brother <b>entered into levirate marriage and afterward</b> the third brother <b>was born,</b> such that <b>when he found her,</b> i.e., when he was born, she had a <b>permitted</b> status, as she was already married to the second brother, she was never in his lifetime the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist but was in fact for him the wife of a living brother. Nevertheless, even under such circumstances, <b>the Rabbis prohibit</b> him from entering into levirate marriage with her. <b>Is</b> it <b>necessary,</b> then, to teach the case presented in the first mishna of a third brother who was <b>born and subsequently</b> the second brother <b>entered into levirate marriage</b> with the wife of the first brother? According to the opinion of the Rabbis, this first mishna is redundant. <b>Rather, is it not</b> that it <b>was necessary</b> to state this first mishna <b>for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b>
If so, this is how it must be understood: <b>The first</b> mishna <b>was taught in order to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> which allows even the case specified in the first mishna, <b>and the latter clause,</b> i.e., the present mishna, <b>was taught to convey the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that even if the third brother was born after levirate marriage to the second brother she remains forbidden to the third brother. <b>And by right it</b> should have explained <b>that Rabbi Shimon disagrees</b> even <b>in the first</b> mishna, <b>but</b> the author of the mishna <b>waited until the Rabbis finished their words, and then he went back</b> and wrote that Rabbi Shimon <b>disagreed with them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, how can you find</b> this case of <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist?</b> The Gemara answers: It is in the case of <b>a single brother who died and</b> subsequently another <b>brother was born to him.</b> Here, the widow would be the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist, and she would not be required to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> or enter into levirate marriage with him. <b>Alternatively,</b> it can be found in the case of <b>two</b> brothers, one of whom died, <b>and</b> the remaining brother <b>did not take</b> the deceased brother’s wife <b>in levirate marriage, and did not die,</b> and in the meantime a third brother was born. She still has the levirate bond due to the deceased brother, who was a brother with whom the newly born brother did not coexist.
The Gemara proceeds to clarify Rabbi Shimon’s position: <b>Granted,</b> in the case when the second brother first <b>performed levirate marriage</b> and <b>subsequently</b> the third brother <b>was born,</b> it is possible to explain <b>that when</b> the third brother <b>found her,</b> i.e., when he was born, <b>he found her in a permitted</b> state because when he was born she was already the wife of a living brother with whom he coexisted. <b>But</b> if <b>he was born and subsequently</b> the second brother <b>performed levirate marriage, what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Shimon renders her permitted? The Gemara answers: One must say that Rabbi Shimon <b>holds that the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial,</b> and that the bond itself created a tie of kinship. Moreover, a woman with a levirate <b>bond is considered like a married woman.</b> Since there is a bond between the <i>yevama</i> and the living brother it is as though she were already married to him. Accordingly, she is, for the new brother, like the wife of his brother with whom he coexisted.
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this: Now</b> that in the case of a levirate <b>bond and a levirate betrothal</b> together <b>Rabbi Shimon is uncertain as to whether she is similar to a married woman or an unmarried woman, is it necessary</b> to say that by levirate <b>bond alone</b> she is not like a married woman? If so, how can the Gemara assume that for Rabbi Shimon, the levirate bond alone gives her the status of a married woman?
<b>What</b> is the proof that this is Rabbi Shimon’s opinion? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (31b): In the case of <b>three brothers</b> who were <b>married to three unrelated women, and one of</b> the brothers <b>died, and the second</b> brother <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> with the widow <b>and</b> subsequently <b>died, then these</b> women, both the first wife of the second brother and the betrothed widow of the first brother, <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage</b> with the third brother.
What is the reason that the wife of the first brother is not eligible for levirate marriage? <b>As it is stated: “And one of them dies…her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her</b> and will take her to him to be his wife and consummate the levirate marriage” (Deuteronomy 25:5). From here it is derived: <b>She who is subject to</b> a levirate <b>bond with a single <i>yavam</i></b> enters levirate marriage <b>and not she who is subject to</b> a levirate <b>bond with two <i>yevamin</i>.</b> This woman requires levirate marriage due to the death of the first brother, and also, due to the subsequent levirate betrothal, requires levirate marriage following the death of the second brother.
However, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Let him enter into levirate marriage</b> with <b>whichever he wishes and perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the second.</b> Rabbi Shimon does not accept the homiletical interpretation forbidding a woman who is subject to two levirate bonds. The Gemara explains his opinion: Rabbi Shimon does <b>not</b> allow him to <b>take both in levirate marriage.</b> Why not? <b>Perhaps the</b> levirate <b>bond is substantial,</b> and combined with the levirate bond to the second brother the woman might be considered to be already married to the second brother, <b>and</b> then <b>these</b> two women <b>would be two <i>yevamot</i> who come</b>

Daf 19a

<b>from a single household,</b> i.e., husband, and everyone agrees that only one wife from each household may be taken in levirate marriage, as the verse states: “To build his brother’s house,” which is interpreted to mean that the remaining brother may perform levirate marriage with only one wife of his late brother and not with two. To <b>take one in levirate marriage and exempt the other</b> without any procedure, he may <b>not</b> do, <b>as perhaps</b> the levirate <b>bond is not substantial</b> enough to make the first brother’s widow <b>like a married woman</b> to the second brother. In that case this woman whose husband died first remains the wife of the first brother, and the second woman is the wife of the second brother. Then there would be two separate levirate obligations, and one could not exempt the other; <b>they would be two <i>yevamot</i> who come from two households.</b> Therefore, <b>apparently</b> even when levirate betrothal was performed Rabbi Shimon <b>is uncertain</b> whether or not the levirate bond is substantial.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>indeed, one</b> of them <b>may be taken in levirate marriage and</b> thereby <b>exempt the other,</b> and <b>this was prohibited</b> only <b>by rabbinic law,</b> this would be a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the concern <b>lest those</b> who were not aware of the details mistakenly <b>say</b> that in general if <b>two <i>yevamot</i> come from two households</b> then <b>one is taken in levirate marriage and the other is exempt without anything.</b> One might have thought that the reason Rabbi Shimon required the other woman to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> is to avoid the possibility of such a mistake.
<b>But</b> this cannot be, <b>as Rabbi Shimon’s reason</b> is mentioned explicitly in the <i>baraita</i>, and there he does not state that this is a decree of the Sages. Rather, his reason <b>is due to</b> the question with regard to the strength of levirate betrothal, specifically whether the status of marriage is achieved by <b>levirate betrothal or not</b> achieved by <b>levirate betrothal. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon said to the Rabbis</b> in explanation of his opinion that one of the women could enter into levirate marriage: <b>If the levirate betrothal of the second</b> brother <b>is indeed levirate betrothal and</b> is considered as a fully valid marriage, then the third brother <b>is engaging in relations with the wife of the second</b> brother when he takes her in levirate marriage. That is, if the levirate betrothal by the second brother has the same status as full marriage, then she becomes the wife of this second brother, and all previous connections are no longer relevant.
<b>But if the levirate betrothal of the second</b> brother <b>is not levirate betrothal,</b> i.e., it does not have the full status <b>of</b> marriage, then there was never in fact any connection between the two. If she is then taken by the third brother in levirate marriage, <b>he would be engaging in relations with the wife of the first</b> brother. From here one can conclude that the basis for Rabbi Shimon’s uncertainty is related to the questions concerning the strength of the levirate betrothal.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> From here you cannot prove what Rabbi Shimon’s opinion was. <b>Is there no difference to you between</b> a levirate <b>bond to a single <i>yavam</i> and a bond to two <i>yevamim</i>? Perhaps when Rabbi Shimon said</b> that a levirate <b>bond</b> is substantial enough to render her <b>like a married woman,</b> this applies only <b>when</b> there is <b>a single <i>yavam</i>.</b> If these were the circumstances of the case discussed, that when one brother died there remained only one <i>yavam</i>, then because the obligation of levirate marriage would apply only to him, she would be considered his wife. <b>But</b> perhaps he held that if there were <b>two <i>yevamin</i>,</b> then <b>no,</b> she would not be considered a married woman, as here the bond would apply to both at once. Accordingly, Rabbi Shimon’s uncertainty is with regard to the case of a levirate bond with two <i>yevamin</i>.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Does Rabbi Shimon differentiate</b> between the case of one <i>yavam</i> and the case of two <i>yevamin</i> in the matter of a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist? <b>But it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist: <b>Rabbi Shimon stated a principle: Whenever the birth</b> of the third brother <b>precedes the</b> levirate <b>marriage</b> of the second brother, if this second brother dies and the <i>yevama</i> falls before the third brother, <b>she does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b> In such circumstances she is the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. But if <b>the</b> levirate <b>marriage preceded his birth, she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b>
<b>What, is it not</b> referring to the case of <b>a single <i>yavam</i>, and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>She does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b> Even if there is only a single <i>yavam</i> this is not considered full marriage, and she remains forbidden as the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. Consequently, she who is subject to a levirate bond is not like a married woman. The Gemara answers: <b>No.</b> it refers to a case of <b>two <i>yevamin</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But what,</b> then, is the ruling for <b>a single <i>yavam</i>? So too,</b> one should say <b>she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage,</b> as the woman who requires levirate marriage is like the wife of the second brother for all purposes. <b>If so, rather than teaching</b> the case when <b>the marriage</b> of the second brother <b>precedes the birth</b> of the third brother, that if this second brother dies and she falls before the third brother, <b>she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage, let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within</b> the situation <b>itself</b> and say: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? When</b> there are <b>two <i>yevamin</i>. But</b> if there is <b>one <i>yavam</i>, she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: No, <b>the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is in reference to two <i>yevamin</i></b> and differentiates between various cases involving two <i>yevamin</i>, namely, the case where the birth of the third brother preceded the marriage of the second brother and the case where the marriage of the second brother preceded the birth of the third brother. The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what is the principle</b> in this matter? If Rabbi Shimon is speaking of two <i>yevamin</i> and not a single <i>yavam</i>, then it makes no sense to speak of a principle, as the <i>halakha</i> is different in the case of a single <i>yavam</i>.
<b>Moreover, Rav Oshaya raised an objection</b> from that which was taught in a mishna (28b): If there were <b>three brothers, two of whom were married to two sisters, or to a woman and her daughter, or a woman and her daughter’s daughter, or a woman and her son’s daughter,</b> who are, in each case, two women who may not be married to the same person simultaneously, and subsequently these brothers who were married to relatives died, <b>then those</b> two women <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> Since they both have a levirate bond to the third brother at the same time and he is prohibited from marrying both, they cause one another to be unable to perform levirate marriage. <b>And Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> them even from <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>And if it enters your mind that Rabbi Shimon held that</b> a levirate <b>bond is substantial</b> enough to make her <b>like a married woman,</b> then <b>let</b> the third brother <b>consummate the levirate marriage to the</b> widow of the <b>first</b> husband to die, since as soon as her husband dies she has a levirate bond with the other brothers and should be considered to be like his wife, <b>and let the other be exempt</b> as a result, as her levirate bond began only with the death of the second husband.
<b>Rav Amram said: What</b> is <b>really</b> the meaning of the word <b>exempt</b> used by Rabbi Shimon? Only <b>the second is exempt.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>But it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon exempts both.</b> From here it is clear that in his opinion a woman subject to a levirate bond does not have the same status as a married woman.
<b>Rava said:</b> In the case mentioned in that <i>baraita</i>, there were three brothers, two of whom died. Each of the deceased brothers had four wives who were related to the wives of the other brother as described in the mishna. One wife of the first brother was the sister of a wife of the second brother. Another wife was the mother of a wife of the second brother. Another was the daughter of the daughter of a wife of the second brother. And another was the daughter of the son of a wife of the second brother. When these brothers died, all eight women happened before the remaining brother for levirate marriage. When Rabbi Shimon deemed both of them exempt, he was referring to <b>the second from this pair and the second from that pair.</b> That is, since one of them was bound to the third brother her relative became exempt as a forbidden relative, and the other of the pair was her rival wife in each of the cases.
The Gemara comments: <b>Rava was mistaken about</b> there being <b>four pairs.</b> He mistakenly understood that the mishna spoke of two brothers who married four pairs of relatives. Why does the Gemara assume that he was mistaken? <b>One</b> piece of evidence <b>is that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the case using the expression: <b>Or, or.</b> The mishna teaches: Or to a woman and her daughter, or to a woman and her daughter’s daughter, or a woman and her son’s daughter, meaning that not all of the pairs happened before a single <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage. <b>And further,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have said: Rabbi Shimon exempts all four of them,</b> i.e., the four women married to the second brother.
<b>And further, it is taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon exempts both of them from</b> both <b><i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage, as it is stated: “And you shall not take a woman to her sister, to be a rival to her”</b> (Leviticus 18:18). From here it is derived that <b>when</b> two sisters are about to <b>become rival wives one to the other,</b> that is, at the moment they fall before one brother for levirate marriage, <b>you do not have</b> the option of <b>taking even one of them.</b> In other words, levirate marriage to either of them is not permitted, and therefore both are exempt and not only the second. Thus Rava’s explanation is rejected.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said</b> an alternative answer to the Gemara’s challenge: <b>If</b> these <i>yevamot</i> <b>happened</b> before him for levirate marriage <b>one after the other, indeed it is so</b> that the first woman bound is like a married woman, and she exempts the second, who is her close relative. However, <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case when both brothers died at once and so both women <b>happened</b> before him <b>at once. And Rabbi Shimon holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said: It is possible to be precise.</b> He held, contrary to the opinion of the Rabbis, that it was possible to be exact about measurements of time. Therefore, it is possible for two things to truly occur at once, and it is possible that both brothers died simultaneously.
Until this point the Gemara dealt with Rav Oshaya’s opinion stating that according to Rabbi Shimon’s statement, even in the case of one who was born before his brother’s levirate marriage the ruling of a wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist would not apply. However, <b>Rav Pappa said: Rabbi Shimon disagreed</b> in the case where the second brother <b>performed levirate marriage and after that</b> the third brother <b>was born;</b> however, <b>where</b> the third brother <b>was born</b> after the death of the first brother <b>and after that</b> the second brother <b>performed levirate marriage</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>did not disagree.</b> He agreed that in this case she would be forbidden to the newly born brother as the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.
As for the question that Rav Oshaya raised with regard to the apparent redundancy of the similar rulings in both the first mishna of the chapter and the mishna on 18b, it can be explained that <b>both were necessary for</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> who prohibited marriage to the wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist in every case. The difficulty raised concerning the apparent redundancy of the first mishna, given the greater scope of the opinion revealed in the second mishna, can be explained by saying that the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the mishna employing the style: <b>Not</b> only <b>this</b> but <b>also that.</b> That is, the mishna follows the stylistic principle of first teaching the obvious case and continues by saying that this principle applies not only in the obvious case but even in the less obvious case. If so, there is no need to assume that there is an additional dispute with Rabbi Shimon.
The Gemara continues: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa, and this is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Oshaya:</b> If there were <b>two coexisting brothers, and one died childless, and the second was about to perform levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> but did not manage to perform levirate betrothal before his brother was born, and</b> then the second brother <b>died,</b> then <b>the first</b> woman <b>goes out</b> and is free to remarry without <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>she was the wife of a brother with whom</b> the third brother <b>did not coexist, and the second either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> She was never the rival wife of the widow of the first brother.
If the second brother <b>performed levirate betrothal with her and afterward his brother was born, or if his brother was born and then he performed the levirate betrothal, and then he died, the first goes out</b> and is free to remarry <b>as the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist, and the second,</b> the wife of the second brother, <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> This is because, due to the levirate betrothal, she is considered by the Rabbis to be the rival wife of a wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.

Daf 19b

<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Intercourse or <i>ḥalitza</i> with one of them,</b> i.e., the wife of the second brother, <b>exempts her rival wife</b>, but if <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the one <b>who received the levirate betrothal, then</b> her <b>rival wife</b>, i.e., the wife of the second brother, <b>is not</b> thereby <b>exempt,</b> since possibly levirate betrothal does not have the same strength as marriage. If the second brother <b>married</b> his deceased brother’s wife <b>and</b> then <b>died</b> himself, <b>and afterward a brother was born, or if a brother was born and then he married her and died,</b> the two wives <b>are both exempt from <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage.</b> In this case, one was the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist and the other her rival wife.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If he <b>married</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> then <b>a brother was born, and then he died, both</b> the wife of the first deceased brother and the original wife of the <i>yavam</i> <b>are exempt from <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Shimon says: Since</b> the third brother <b>came and found her in a permitted state, and she was never for a moment prohibited to him,</b> as when he was born she was already the wife of the second brother, who was still alive, <b>he</b> therefore <b>takes whichever he wishes in levirate marriage, or performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with whichever he wishes.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>The section of the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, which refers to the case of a brother born after the levirate marriage, <b>according to whom is it taught? If we say it is taught for</b> the purpose of clarifying the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it does not make sense, <b>since it makes no difference to Rabbi Meir whether the levirate marriage preceded the birth or the birth preceded the levirate marriage.</b> In his opinion under both circumstances she is the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. And if this were in fact taught for the purpose of clarifying his opinion <b>it should have combined</b> the cases <b>and taught them</b> together.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that the latter segment was meant to clarify the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> since the different parts of the <i>baraita</i> enumerate different possibilities? <b>And</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>disagrees in</b> the case when the brother first <b>performed levirate marriage and afterward</b> his brother <b>was born,</b> but he <b>does not disagree in</b> the case where the younger brother <b>was born and afterward</b> the second brother performed <b>levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara summarizes: <b>Conclude from this</b> that Rabbi Shimon disagrees only here, as Rav Pappa explained.
§ The Gemara proceeds to discuss the <i>baraita</i> itself. <b>The Master said: The second was about to perform levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i>, but did not manage to perform levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> before his brother was born, and</b> then the second brother <b>died. The first</b> woman <b>goes out</b> and is free to remarry without <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>she was the wife of a brother with whom</b> the third brother <b>did not coexist, and the second</b> woman <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>Was about to, and what is</b> the meaning of: <b>Did not manage</b> to perform levirate betrothal? The important issue is not his intention but his actions. <b>If he did it, he did it; and if he did not do it, he did not do it.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the correct interpretation is: <b>Was about to</b> means that he was about to perform levirate betrothal <b>with her consent. Did not manage</b> means that he did not manage to perform it <b>with her consent, but instead</b> did it <b>against her will.</b> Consequently, it is understood that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who performs levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> without her consent, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He acquired</b> her and the betrothal is fully valid, like a consensual levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i>; <b>and the Rabbis say: He did not acquire</b> her.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion? <b>He learned</b> this <b>from</b> the case of a <i>yavam</i> engaging in <b>intercourse with a <i>yevama</i>. Just as</b> even <b>non-consensual intercourse with the <i>yevama</i></b> renders her his wife, as the matter does not require her consent, <b>so too, betrothal of a <i>yevama</i></b> can be <b>non-consensual.</b> But <b>the Rabbis learned from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>betrothal in general; just as betrothal in general requires consent</b> by the woman, <b>so too, betrothal of a <i>yevama</i></b> for purposes of levirate marriage <b>requires consent.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis <b>disagree? One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that halakhic <b>matters concerning <i>yevamot</i> must be inferred from matters concerning <i>yevamot</i></b> and not from other areas of <i>halakha</i>. <b>And one Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that halakhic <b>matters concerning</b> levirate <b>betrothal must be inferred from matters concerning betrothal.</b>
The Gemara clarifies another segment of the <i>baraita</i>. It is taught: If the second brother <b>performed levirate betrothal with her, and afterward his brother was born, or if his brother was born and then he performed levirate betrothal and died, the first</b> woman <b>goes out</b> and is free to remarry <b>because</b> she is <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist, and the second,</b> the wife of the second brother, <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> but does not enter into levirate marriage. Rabbi Shimon says: Intercourse or <i>ḥalitza</i> with one of them exempts her rival wife.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>To which</b> case is <b>Rabbi Shimon referring? If we say</b> that he is referring to the case when <b>his brother was born and then he performed levirate betrothal with her, didn’t you</b> already <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon did not dispute</b> the case where the brother <b>was born and then ultimately he performed a levirate marriage,</b> and she would be forbidden as the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist. <b>Rather,</b> one must say that Rabbi Shimon disputed the case where <b>he performed levirate betrothal with her and afterward his brother was born.</b>
Later in the <i>baraita</i> it is taught: If the third brother <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the wife of the first brother, <b>to whom</b> the second brother <b>performed levirate betrothal, her rival wife is not exempt.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because the rival wife</b>, the widow of the second brother, has a <b>definite</b> legal status that requires an act to free her to remarry, as she is the wife of a brother with whom he did coexist, <b>whereas</b> the widow of the first brother <b>with whom</b> the second brother <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> had only <b>an uncertain</b> legal status, as it is not clear if she is to be considered truly the wife of the second brother by means of the levirate betrothal or not. <b>And</b> the principle is that <b>an uncertainty does not override a certainty.</b> Therefore, even if the third brother performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, since the status of the first woman’s obligation is uncertain, the status of the <i>ḥalitza</i> itself is uncertain, as it is possible that she did not require <i>ḥalitza</i> at all. Consequently, this <i>ḥalitza</i> is not sufficient to exempt her rival wife. This teaches that he must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage with the woman who is definitely obligated, and then the other will be exempt.
<b>Rav Menashe bar Zevid sat before Rav Huna. He sat and said: What is the reason that Rabbi Shimon</b> allows the third brother to marry the wife of his brother with whom he did not coexist where she was taken in levirate marriage prior to his birth? The Gemara also wonders: <b>What is Rabbi Shimon’s reason? The reason</b> is <b>as he stated</b> in that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>Since</b> the third brother <b>came and found her in a permitted state, and she was never for a moment prohibited to him</b> he may perform levirate marriage with her.
<b>Rather,</b> the question was as follows: Rabbi Shimon gave such a persuasive explanation of his opinion that it raises the question: <b>What is the reason for the Rabbis’</b> opinion? The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states:</b> “Her brother-in-law will…<b>take her to him to be his wife and consummate the levirate marriage [<i>veyibbema</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5). This means that <b>the first levirate bond is still upon her.</b> Even after she is taken as a wife by the second brother, her earlier status as wife of her late first husband is still in effect. The Gemara challenges this: <b>But</b> what about <b>that which we learn</b> in a mishna (38a): If <b>he took</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>in marriage</b> as his wife, <b>then her</b> legal status is <b>that of his wife in every sense; and Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said:</b> This <b>teaches</b>

Daf 20a

<b>that he must divorce</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>with a bill of divorce</b> and she does not also require <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>And he may remarry her,</b> if he wishes, after the divorce; as the <i>halakha</i> is not ruled in accordance with the opinion that after he performs the mitzva she is once more forbidden to him as his brother’s wife. Why? <b>There, too, let</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>say</b> that the verse states: <b>“And consummate the levirate marriage [<i>veyibbema</i>],”</b> as explained above, meaning that <b>the first levirate bond is still upon her and she should</b> also <b>require <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as the verse states: “And take her to him to be his wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5) to teach that <b>once he has taken her,</b> her legal status is <b>that of his wife in every sense.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>If so, here too,</b> in the case of a brother born after the levirate marriage, according to the opinion of the Rabbis this same principle should apply. The Gemara answers that <b>The Merciful One states: “And consummate the levirate marriage [<i>veyibbema</i>],”</b> that is, even after the marriage she is still considered to be the wife of the deceased brother [<i>yevama</i>] with respect to any brothers who are born later.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see</b> to distinguish in this way and say that once she is married the levirate obligation is totally abrogated with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>, but that she remains prohibited as the wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist with respect to any brothers born in the future? The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> to say: <b>Toss that which is permitted on that which is permitted, and toss that which is prohibited on that which is prohibited.</b> In other words, in cases where the woman becomes permitted to her <i>yavam</i> through levirate marriage, it stands to reason that this permitted state is absolute, but with regard to the prohibition against taking the wife of a brother with whom one did not coexist, it stands to reason that the verse comes to teach that she retains her prohibited status with respect to any brothers born in the future.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But according to Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that <b>since he came and found her in a permitted state</b> a brother born subsequently may perform levirate marriage <b>since she was never for a single moment prohibited to him; however, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> consider the case of <b>one’s maternal</b> half <b>sister,</b> who <b>married his paternal</b> half <b>brother;</b> their marriage was fully permissible since the husband and wife were in no way related to each other. <b>And then his brother was born and</b> the married brother <b>died;</b> in that case, <b>let</b> the sister <b>enter into levirate marriage</b> with her newly born half brother for the same reason, i.e., <b>since he came and found her in a permitted state,</b> as when he was born she was already his brother’s wife.
The Gemara challenges this suggestion: How can you say that? What happened to <b>the prohibition against</b> marrying <b>his sister, to where did it go?</b> This widow is the maternal sister of the newly born brother and is therefore forbidden to him. The Gemara objects: If so, <b>here too,</b> one could have said: What happened to <b>the prohibition</b> against marrying the wife of <b>a brother with whom one did not coexist, to where did it go?</b> In this case as well, the prohibition against marrying the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist already applied from the first brother, so why does Rabbi Shimon see this as abrogated by marriage? The Gemara answers that the comparison is unsound. <b>This prohibition</b> against marrying one’s sister <b>has no</b> case where it is <b>permitted</b> and so in this case is also not canceled, whereas <b>that prohibition</b> against marrying a brother’s wife <b>has</b> a case where it is <b>permitted,</b> when the mitzva of levirate marriage applies to a second brother and is therefore removed completely before the third brother is born.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The Sages <b>stated a principle about a <i>yevama</i>: Whoever is</b> forbidden <b>by a prohibition of forbidden relations</b> to her <i>yavam</i> <b>neither performs <i>ḥalitza</i> nor enters into levirate marriage</b> and is completely exempt. If she is forbidden by <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> or by <b>a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity,</b> as will be explained later, then since in these cases the obligation of levirate marriage is not fundamentally nullified <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> in order to become free of the levirate bond, <b>and</b> due to her prohibition <b>she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
The Sages stated another principle: If two sisters who had been married to two brothers who subsequently died happened before the third brother for levirate marriage, and one of those sisters is a close relation to this third brother and is therefore forbidden to him, she is exempt from levirate marriage. But the other, <b>her sister who is her <i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., her sister-in-law, <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> In this case, they are not ruled to be two sisters who happened before him simultaneously for levirate marriage, since one of them is prohibited to him as a forbidden relation, and therefore she never actually happened before him at all.
The mishna explains: <b>A prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> is referring to <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationships,</b> which are prohibited <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Sages prohibited marriage to certain women who were not forbidden by the Torah but were nevertheless deemed forbidden incestuous relations. <b>A prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> is referring to marriage of <b>a widow to a High Priest, a divorcée or a woman who has performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>] to a common priest, a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>]</b> or a <b>Gibeonite woman to an Israelite, and</b> also <b>an Israelite woman to a Gibeonite or</b> to <b>a son born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzer</i>].</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: This <b>principle</b> stated in the mishna about <i>yevamot</i>, <b>what</b> other cases does it <b>add?</b> Since the entire list of cases involving a forbidden relation was already detailed in the first chapter, what is this mishna adding? <b>Rafram bar Pappa said: It comes to include the</b> case of a <b>rival wife of a sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>aylonit</i>],</b> who is incapable of bearing children. Not only does an <i>aylonit</i> herself not enter into levirate marriage, since she is unable to give birth, but her rival wife is exempt as well. <b>And</b> this is <b>like</b> the principle <b>of Rav Asi,</b> who said that the rival wife of an <i>aylonit</i> is forbidden because the <i>aylonit</i> herself remains prohibited to the <i>yavam</i> as the wife of his brother, as she was never rendered permitted by the obligation of levirate marriage. Therefore, her rival wife is the rival wife of someone prohibited as a forbidden relation.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rafram bar Pappa’s statement was made in a different context. It was taught in the mishna: <b>Whoever is forbidden</b> to her <i>yavam</i> <b>by a prohibition of forbidden relations</b> is completely exempt, which implies that <b>it is</b> specifically in such a case <b>that her rival wife is forbidden. But</b> any case when one wife <b>is not forbidden by a prohibition of forbidden relations</b> but is instead forbidden for some other reason, then <b>her rival wife is not forbidden.</b> This case comes <b>to exclude what? Rafram said: It excludes the rival wife of an <i>aylonit</i>,</b> who requires levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i> because the <i>aylonit</i> is not prohibited as a forbidden relation. <b>And</b> this statement is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Asi.</b>
The mishna states: <b>Her sister who is her <i>yevama</i></b> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage. The Gemara clarifies this: <b>Whose sister? If we say</b> it is the sister of one <b>who is</b> forbidden due to <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva, since by Torah</b> law <b>she is cast before him</b> for levirate marriage, then this would in fact simply be a case of two sisters who fell simultaneously before him, both requiring levirate marriage, since according to Torah law there is no prohibition against entering into levirate marriage with such a woman. If so, it turns out that <b>he encounters the sister of the woman with whom he has</b> a levirate <b>bond; but</b> that case has already been taught. <b>Rather,</b> it must refer to <b>the sister of</b> a woman who is forbidden to him by a <b>prohibition of forbidden relations,</b> and since he may not enter into levirate marriage with a forbidden relation, her sister is not considered to be the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond. Therefore, the sister may be taken in levirate marriage.
The mishna states that <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> is referring to <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationships,</b> which are prohibited by rabbinic law. The Gemara asks: <b>Why is this called a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva? Abaye said:</b> This is because <b>it is a mitzva to listen to</b> and obey <b>the words of the Sages.</b>
The mishna states: <b>A prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> is referring to a marriage of <b>a widow to a High Priest,</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i> to a common priest.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why are these called a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity? As it is written</b> with regard to the priests: <b>“They shall be sacred to their God…</b>they shall not take a woman that is a harlot, or profaned; neither shall they take a woman divorced by her husband” (Leviticus 21:6–7).
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda switches</b> the terms: <b>A prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> is referring to <b>a widow to the High Priest,</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i> to a common priest. And why is this called a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva? As it is written</b> in summarization at the end of Leviticus: <b>“These are the <i>mitzvot</i></b> that the Lord commanded Moses for the children of Israel in Mount Sinai” (Leviticus 27:34).
<b>A prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> is referring to <b>secondary relationships</b> forbidden <b>by rabbinic law. And why is this called a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity? Abaye said: Whoever fulfills the words of the Sages is called sacred. Rava said to him:</b> The language you use is not precise, since if so, <b>whoever does not fulfill the words of the Sages is not called sacred,</b> which implies that <b>he is also not called wicked.</b> However, anyone who transgresses the words of the Sages is in fact referred to as wicked. <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the reason why this is called a prohibition stemming from sanctity is that the term sanctity indicates differentiation or separation, and there is a principle that <b>you must sanctify yourself</b> by refraining from that <b>which is permitted to you</b> by Torah law. The Sages decreed against secondary forbidden relations so that one would not eventually come to transgress Torah law.
The mishna states that the levirate bond of <b>a widow to a High Priest</b> requires her to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and she may not enter into levirate marriage. The Gemara comments: The <i>halakha</i> that a widow does not enter into levirate marriage with a High Priest is <b>taught categorically,</b> merely in a general manner. <b>It is no different</b> whether she is a widow <b>from marriage or</b> she is a widow <b>from betrothal</b> alone.
<b>Granted,</b> she certainly may not enter into levirate marriage if she is a widow <b>from marriage,</b> since she is forbidden to the High Priest by the <b>positive mitzva</b> stated in the verse: “And he shall take a wife in her virginity” (Leviticus 21:13), <b>and</b> by the <b>prohibition</b> stated in the verse: “A widow, or one divorced…these he shall not take” (Leviticus 21:14). <b>And a positive mitzva,</b> levirate marriage, <b>does not override</b> both <b>a prohibition,</b> not marrying a widow, <b>and a positive mitzva,</b> marrying a virgin, together. <b>However,</b> if she is a widow <b>from betrothal,</b> then <b>there is only a prohibition,</b> as she is still a virgin. In that case, why not say that <b>the positive mitzva</b> of levirate marriage should <b>come and override the prohibition</b> against marrying a widow from betrothal?
<b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> in response: <b>The verse states: “His <i>yevama</i> shall ascend to the gate</b> to the Elders and say: My brother-in-law refused to establish a name for his brother in Israel, he did not wish to consummate the levirate marriage” (Deuteronomy 25:7). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “His <i>yevama</i>,”</b> since it is clear to whom the verse refers and no new information is added by this word, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “His <i>yevama</i>”?</b> It comes to teach that <b>there is one <i>yevama</i> who ascends for <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not ascend for levirate marriage,</b> and her brother-in-law is not given a choice. <b>Who is this? This is</b> a woman with whom it is prohibited for her <i>yavam</i> to enter into levirate marriage, as he would be <b>liable</b> for the violation of <b>a prohibition,</b> and the positive mitzva of levirate marriage does not override the prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say</b> that this is referring to <b>those</b> women who are forbidden and would be <b>liable</b> to receive the penalty of <b><i>karet</i></b> as well, i.e., that these too may not enter into levirate marriage but nevertheless require <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “And if the man does not wish to take</b> his <i>yevama</i>” (Deuteronomy 25:7). This <b>implies</b> that if <b>he wishes, he takes her in levirate marriage;</b> it depends upon his wishes. However, <b>one who is eligible for levirate marriage is eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>. And</b> conversely, <b>one who is ineligible for levirate marriage is ineligible for <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and therefore does not require <i>ḥalitza</i> at all. Since those relations that carry a penalty of <i>karet</i> have no possibility of entering into levirate marriage, they do not require <i>ḥalitza</i> either.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, those</b> relations who are forbidden as he would be <b>liable</b> for the violation of <b>a</b> standard <b>prohibition</b> also should not require <i>ḥalitza</i>, as they may not enter into levirate marriage. The Gemara answers: <b>But the Merciful One included</b> one category of <i>yevama</i> who is eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i> alone and not levirate marriage through the term: <b>“His <i>yevama</i>.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> to conclude that the additional term is referring to relations who are forbidden and with whom he would be liable for the violation of a prohibition and not those who are liable to receive <i>karet</i>?

Daf 20b

The Gemara answers: That <b>stands to reason,</b> since <b>betrothal takes effect</b> with those women who are forbidden and with whom he would be <b>liable</b> for the violation of <b>a prohibition.</b> That is, if a man betroths a woman who is forbidden to him and with whom he would be liable for the violation of a prohibition, then although he violates a prohibition in doing so, the betrothal is valid and cannot be ended without a bill of divorce. Therefore, such a woman also requires <i>ḥalitza</i>. In contrast, <b>betrothal does not take effect</b> at all with <b>those</b> who are forbidden and would be <b>liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> and therefore in these cases the laws of levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i> do not apply at all.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> to the explanation of Rav: It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva and a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> that if <b>he engages in intercourse with</b> such a woman <b>or performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, her rival wife is exempt,</b> even though it was prohibited for him to have engaged in intercourse with her in the first place. <b>If it enters your mind</b> that women who are forbidden, as he would be <b>liable</b> for the violation of <b>a prohibition, require <i>ḥalitza</i> by Torah</b> law <b>but do not require levirate marriage,</b> then <b>when he engages in intercourse with</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>why is her rival wife exempt?</b> If there is no biblical mitzva to engage in intercourse with her, his action would carry no halakhic validity and the rival wife should not be exempt.
Rava <b>raised the objection and he resolved it:</b> The <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches it disjunctively;</b> it did not all deal with the same case. When the <i>baraita</i> says: <b>Engages in intercourse with her,</b> it is referring <b>to a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva.</b> If one engages in intercourse with a <i>yevama</i> prohibited to him by rabbinic law, since by Torah law levirate marriage with her is valid, then although his act involved the transgression of a rabbinic decree, he nevertheless fulfilled the Torah mitzva and the rival wife is thereby exempt. When the <i>baraita</i> says: <b>Performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her,</b> it <b>is referring to a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity,</b> and by Torah law there is no option of levirate marriage because of the prohibited relation; therefore, only <i>ḥalitza</i> exempts her rival wife.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Yevamot</i> 11:3): <b>A man with crushed testicles</b> or with other wounds to his genitals <b>or one whose penis has been severed, one who is a eunuch</b> caused <b>by man</b> and not from birth or by disease, or <b>an elderly man,</b> all of whom are incapable of fathering children, <b>one either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage. How so?</b> If any of these infertile men <b>died, and they had brothers and they</b> also <b>had wives,</b> and they then died childless, <b>and the brothers proceeded to perform levirate betrothal with their wives, or gave them a bill of divorce, or performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, whatever they did is done;</b> i.e., their act was effective. <b>And if</b> any one of the brothers <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with the widow of one of those infertile men, he thereby <b>acquired</b> the woman as a wife according to the laws of levirate marriage.
The inverse is also true: If <b>the brothers died</b> childless, <b>and</b> the infertile men <b>proceeded to perform levirate betrothal with their wives,</b> or <b>gave a bill of divorce, or performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, whatever they did is done</b> and took effect. <b>And if they engaged in intercourse</b> with their <i>yevama</i>, <b>they</b> thereby <b>acquired</b> the <i>yevama</i> as their wife. However, <b>it is forbidden to maintain them,</b> i.e., allow them to continue to live as husband and wife, <b>because it is stated: “One with crushed testicles</b> or whose penis has been severed shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:2); they are prohibited from entering the congregation, i.e., marrying a Jew. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that women who are forbidden, as he would be <b>liable</b> for the violation of <b>a prohibition, require <i>ḥalitza</i> by Torah</b> law <b>but do not require levirate marriage, then</b> one could ask: <b>if they engaged in intercourse why are they acquired</b> as wives even though there would be no mitzva of levirate marriage because the men are prohibited from marrying them?
<b>Rather,</b> Rav’s opinion is rejected, and <b>Rava said</b> an alternative explanation: The reason why a High Priest does not take <b>a widow from betrothal</b> in levirate marriage is because that relationship is <b>also</b> a violation of both <b>a positive mitzva and a prohibition</b> and therefore a different positive mitzva does not override it. How so? <b>As it is written: “They shall be sacred to their God”</b> (Leviticus 21:6), which teaches that there is a positive mitzva of sanctity associated with all prohibitions applying to priests. Therefore, any such prohibition contains both a positive and a negative mitzva.
The Gemara asks: This resolves the issue of priestly prohibitions, but <b>what is there to say</b> about <b>a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>] or a Gibeonite woman,</b> who are prohibited from entering the congregation due to considerations of sanctity? They too may not enter into levirate marriage despite the positive mitzva, which would ordinarily override a prohibition. The Gemara answers: <b>It is written</b> with regard to all of the mitzvot: <b>“Sanctify yourselves,</b> therefore, and be sacred” (Leviticus 11:44). This teaches that in addition to the prohibition, there is the positive mitzva of sanctity.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>If so,</b> then every single prohibition in <b>the entire Torah</b> contains both <b>a positive mitzva and a prohibition, as it is written: “Sanctify yourselves”</b> (Leviticus 11:44). <b>Rather,</b> this reasoning must be rejected, and <b>Rava stated</b> a different reason: While in essence the mitzva of levirate marriage does apply here, nevertheless, <b>a widow from betrothal</b> is prohibited from entering into levirate marriage with the High Priest <b>by</b> rabbinic <b>decree, due to</b> the case of <b>a widow from marriage.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is there to say</b> about the case of <b>a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman?</b> There appears to be no reason for a rabbinic decree in such cases. The Gemara answers: There, one must say that intercourse with a <i>mamzeret</i> even <b>when the mitzva</b> of levirate marriage <b>applies</b> was prohibited by rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> cases <b>when the mitzva</b> of levirate marriage <b>does not apply.</b> The decree was issued lest one come to think that since in the case of levirate marriage a <i>mamzeret</i> is permitted, even in cases when there is no levirate marriage a <i>mamzeret</i> is similarly permitted.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> and the levirate marriage is prohibited lest it become confused with another case, then <b>the wife of a paternal brother should not enter into levirate marriage;</b> i.e., by the same logic, although the Torah allowed it, the Sages should have established a <b>rabbinic decree</b> requiring that she perform <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>due to</b> the case of <b>the wife of a maternal brother,</b> who always remains prohibited as a brother’s wife. The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One made levirate marriage dependent upon inheritance,</b> and it <b>is well known</b> by everyone that only patrilineal relatives inherit, so there is no likelihood of confusion.
The Gemara objects further: Then <b>a childless woman should not enter into levirate marriage</b> even though the mitzva applies to her; there should be a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the case of <b>a woman who has children.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One made levirate marriage dependent upon children;</b> it <b>is well known</b> by everyone that the entire purpose of levirate marriage is to establish one’s brother’s name and that levirate marriage applies only when there are no children. Here, too, there is no likelihood of error.
The Gemara challenges further: <b>The wife of a brother with whom one did coexist should not enter into levirate marriage;</b> there should be a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the case of <b>the wife of a brother with whom he did not coexist.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The Merciful One made levirate marriage dependent upon</b> a common <b>dwelling</b> together and coexistence of brothers, and this <b>is well known</b> by everyone since the matter is explicit in the Torah.
The Gemara continues to object: <b>No woman should enter into levirate marriage;</b> there should be a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the case of <b>an <i>aylonit</i>.</b> Since an <i>aylonit</i> may not enter into levirate marriage, all other women should be prohibited by rabbinic decree from doing so to avoid confusion. The Gemara answers: The case of an <i>aylonit</i> is <b>not commonplace,</b> and the Sages did not institute rabbinic decrees on matters that are not common. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>neither a <i>mamzeret</i> nor a Gibeonite woman is commonplace either.</b> Therefore, since the likelihood of taking a <i>mamzeret</i> in levirate marriage is so small, there is no danger that one might think it is permitted to marry a <i>mamzeret</i> even where the mitzva does not apply.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that it is necessary to reject the previous suggestion and to offer a different reason: <b>The first</b> act of <b>intercourse</b> is prohibited by rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the likelihood of <b>a second</b> act of <b>intercourse.</b> Although intercourse the first time with the <i>yevama</i> is the fulfillment of a positive mitzva, which does override the prohibition, once the mitzva is fulfilled with that act there is no longer any positive mitzva involved. Afterward, this <i>yevama</i> becomes prohibited because there is no longer a positive mitzva to override the prohibition. Therefore, due to the possibility that one might engage in intercourse a second time with this woman, the Sages decreed that even the first act is prohibited.
The Gemara comments: <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> one of those <i>yevamin</i> who may not marry their <i>yevama</i> due to a prohibition <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her, <b>he acquired</b> her <b>with the first</b> act of <b>intercourse; however, it is prohibited to retain</b> her <b>for a second act of intercourse.</b>
The Gemara continues with a retraction from Rava: <b>Rava then said, and some say</b> it was actually <b>Rav Ashi</b> who said: <b>That which I said,</b> that the reason for the rabbinic decree was to prevent a second act of intercourse, <b>is not correct,</b> as there is a simpler explanation. <b>As Reish Lakish said</b> about the same matter: <b>In every place that you find a positive mitzva and a prohibition</b> applying to the same matter, <b>if you can fulfill both of them</b> together, <b>this is best,</b> and the positive mitzva does not override the prohibition. <b>And if</b> there is <b>not</b> any possibility of fulfilling both, then <b>let the positive mitzva come and override the prohibition. Here, too,</b> in the case of levirate marriage, <b>it is possible, by way of <i>ḥalitza</i>, to fulfill the positive mitzva and</b> not to transgress <b>the prohibition</b> prohibiting marriage to these women.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this last statement by Rava from that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And if</b> one of those <i>yevamin</i> <b>engaged in intercourse, he acquired</b> her as a wife. This shows that although it is possible to perform the mitzva by way of <i>ḥalitza</i>, if he nevertheless performs levirate marriage then the positive mitzva overrides the prohibition and the <i>yevama</i> is thereby acquired as his wife. The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and Rava’s last explanation is rejected. The previous explanation is the correct one: The prohibition is due to rabbinic decree.
§ On the same subject, <b>it was stated</b> with regard to the case of <b>a High Priest who engaged in intercourse with a widow</b> who was his <i>yevama</i> requiring levirate marriage that the <i>amora’im</i> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar</b> disputed the matter. <b>One said</b> that intercourse <b>does not exempt her rival wife</b> who had also been married to the High Priest’s brother, since the act was prohibited, <b>and one said</b> that it does <b>exempt her rival wife</b>, because although intercourse was forbidden, it is nevertheless a valid enactment of levirate marriage, and so her rival wife is thereby exempt.

Daf 21a

As for <b>a widow from marriage, everyone agrees that this does not exempt</b> the rival wife, <b>as a positive mitzva does not override a prohibition and a positive mitzva</b> together. <b>When they disagree,</b> it <b>is in</b> the case of <b>a widow from betrothal. The one who said that it exempts</b> the rival wife holds that <b>the positive mitzva</b> of levirate marriage <b>comes and overrides</b> the <b>prohibition</b> against a High Priest marrying a widow. <b>And the one who said that it does not exempt</b> the rival wife held that <b>a positive mitzva does not come and override a prohibition, since it is possible</b> to perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i>.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion that the rival wife would not be exempt, from the previously cited <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> one of those <i>yevamin</i> <b>engaged in intercourse, he acquired</b> her as a wife. This shows that the act of levirate marriage is valid, even when prohibited. If so, in the case of the High Priest and a widow as well, her rival wife should be exempt. <b>This is a conclusive refutation,</b> and that opinion is rejected.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say that</b> this is <b>also a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> and therefore reject his principle? The Gemara answers: <b>Reish Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: When I say</b> that in every place that you find a positive mitzva and a prohibition applying to the same matter, if you can fulfill both of them together without transgressing the prohibition, this is best, and the positive mitzva does not override the prohibition, this is applicable only <b>when the mitzva is fulfilled</b> properly; <b>but here, <i>ḥalitza</i> in place of levirate marriage is not</b> considered a proper fulfillment of the <b>mitzva.</b>
§ <b>Rava said: Where</b> is the prohibition against <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationships hinted at in the Torah? As it is stated</b> at the end of the portion discussing forbidden incestuous relations: <b>“For all these abominations have the men of the land done”</b> (Leviticus 18:27). <b>“These”</b> must be understood to mean <b>the harsh ones,</b> i.e., the severe transgressions. This proves <b>by inference that there are</b> also lesser transgressions that are, as it were, <b>soft ones. And what are those</b> soft ones? They are <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationships.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> may it <b>be inferred</b> that the word <b>“these” [<i>ha’el</i>] is an expression</b> meaning <b>harsh? As it is written: “And the mighty [<i>eilei</i>] of the land he took away”</b> (Ezekiel 17:13). The similarity of these words implies that “these” also has connotations of mighty or harsh.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that this statement <b>contradicts</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Levi? As Rabbi Levi said: The harshness of the punishment for</b> using dishonest <b>measures is more than the punishment for</b> transgressing the prohibition of <b>forbidden relationships, as</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> forbidden relations, it <b>is stated</b> only: <b>“These [<i>el</i>],” whereas</b> with regard to <b>that,</b> dishonest measures, it <b>is stated: “These [<i>eleh</i>]”</b> with an additional letter <i>heh</i> as a suffix: “For all that do these [<i>eleh</i>] things, even all that do unrighteously, are an abomination unto the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 25:16). This implies that the word <i>eleh</i> indicates harshness and not the word <i>el</i>. The Gemara answers: This does not contradict his opinion. The word <b><i>el</i></b> has the connotation of <b>harsh, but <i>eleh</i></b> has the connotation of even <b>harsher than <i>el</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to forbidden relationships</b> the word <b><i>eleh</i> is also written:</b> “For whosoever shall do any of these [<i>eleh</i>] abominations, even the souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people” (Leviticus 18:29). If so, why is the punishment for using dishonest measures considered harsher? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> expression meaning these [<i>eleh</i>] in the context of forbidden relations does not emphasize their severity; rather, it comes <b>to exclude</b> one who uses deception in <b>measures from</b> the penalty of <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather,</b> in <b>what</b> way is deception in measurements more <b>severe</b> than forbidden relations? The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> who engage in forbidden relations have the <b>possibility of repentance.</b> If one engaged in relations with a forbidden relative he can rectify the sin through repentance. In the case of <b>those</b> who deceive the public with dishonest measures, <b>it is not possible to repent</b> fully because, having deceived the general public, they have no way of returning the money. Whereas generally a thief can return stolen property to its rightful owner, one who used dishonest measures with multiple customers has no way to track them all down in order to return the money.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that the prohibition of secondary forbidden relationships is learned <b>from here:</b> As it says with regard to King Solomon: <b>“He weighed [<i>izzen</i>] and sought out, and set in order many proverbs”</b> (Ecclesiastes 12:9), <b>and Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Before Solomon came, the Torah was like a basket [<i>kefifa</i>] without handles [<i>oznayim</i>], until Solomon came and made handles for it.</b> By means of his explanation and proverbs he enabled each person to understand and take hold of the Torah, fulfill its mitzvot, and distance himself from transgressions.
<b>Rabbi Oshaya said</b> that the prohibition of secondary forbidden relationships is learned <b>from here: “Avoid it, pass not by it; turn from it, and pass on”</b> (Proverbs 4:15). One must distance oneself from any prohibited act and not pass near a place of forbidden objects or situations.
<b>Rav Ashi said a parable: To what is this matter,</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Oshaya, comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to a man guarding an orchard;</b> if he <b>guards it from the outside, all of it is guarded.</b> But if <b>he guards it from the inside,</b> only <b>that which is in front of him</b> that he can see <b>is guarded,</b> while <b>that which is behind him is unguarded.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And this</b> parable <b>of Rav Ashi is a mistake [<i>beduta</i>]</b> and is not accurate. <b>There,</b> in his metaphor, <b>that which is in front of him at least is guarded; here,</b> in the case of forbidden relationships, <b>were it not for</b> the rabbinic decree against <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationships one would</b> eventually <b>encounter</b> and transgress <b>the</b> biblically <b>forbidden relationship itself.</b> Guarding from the outside is not only preferable, it is essential.
