<b>If you wish, say</b> a different answer for Rav’s explanation: <b>Those <i>baraitot</i></b> that require the wife and the suspected adulterer to divorce even without witnesses to the adultery are taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a case where a husband saw <b>a peddler leaving</b> the house, <b>and</b> when he entered he found his <b>wife retying her smock [<i>sinar</i>],</b> i.e., putting her clothes back on, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Since this is a distasteful matter</b> because it looks as though she committed adultery with the peddler, <b>she</b> must be <b>divorced</b> by her husband. Alternatively, if the husband entered after the peddler had left and found <b>saliva above the netting of the bed,</b> implying that someone had lain on the bed and spit upward, although no actual act was witnessed, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Since this is a distasteful matter, she</b> must be <b>divorced.</b>

Daf 25a

The same applies if the husband found <b>the shoes reversed under the bed,</b> so that the toe of the shoe faced the bed; this is a sign that a stranger came in and placed them like that. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Since this is a distasteful matter, she</b> must be <b>divorced.</b> The Gemara questions this: <b>Shoes turned around? Let him see whose they are</b> and clarify who the stranger was and then find out what he was doing there. <b>Rather,</b> the case was that he found the <b>place of the shoes,</b> i.e., shoe prints, <b>reversed under the bed</b> and cannot recognize whose shoe prints they are. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Since this is a distasteful matter, she</b> must be <b>divorced.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav,</b> that they must divorce only if there were witnesses, <b>and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, that they must divorce if there is a matter that is distasteful. The Gemara challenges this: One <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>difficult,</b> as it contradicts <b>the</b> other <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: This contradiction is <b>not difficult. This one</b> relates to a case <b>where the rumor ceases</b> and the woman is sent away only if there are witnesses, but <b>that one</b> relates to a case <b>where the rumor does not cease,</b> in which case he divorces her even if there are no witnesses. The Gemara elucidates the cases: In cases of <b>a rumor that does not cease,</b> even if <b>there are no witnesses</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and he divorces her. If <b>the rumor ceases and there are witnesses,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> and he divorces her because there are witnesses.
The Gemara clarifies this: <b>At what point</b> is it considered to be <b>a persistent rumor? Abaye said:</b> My <b>mother told me: A rumor in the city</b> lasts <b>a day and a half.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>We said</b> that this is the length of time <b>only</b> if the rumor <b>did not cease in the meantime. But</b> if the rumor <b>did cease in the meantime,</b> even it was later renewed, <b>this is</b> considered a rumor that <b>has ceased</b> and is disregarded. <b>And we said</b> that a rumor that ceased is not considered persistent <b>only</b> if the reason it <b>ceased</b> was <b>not due to fear</b> of the individual about whom it is said. <b>But if it ceased due to fear, it is</b> only <b>due to fear</b> and is still considered a persistent rumor. <b>And we said</b> that a persistent rumor has validity <b>only</b> if the subject of the rumor <b>does not have any</b> known <b>enemies, but</b> if <b>he has enemies</b> it may be assumed that <b>it is the enemies who put out the rumor</b> about him.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Gittin</i> 45b): A man <b>who divorces his wife due to</b> her <b>bad reputation may not take</b> her <b>back</b> again, even if it turns out that the rumor was untrue. Likewise, if he divorced his wife <b>due to a vow</b> of hers that is unbearable to him <b>he may not take</b> her <b>back</b> even if she is released from that vow. <b>Rabba bar</b> Rav <b>Huna sent</b> a question <b>to Rabba bar Rav Naḥman: Our teacher, instruct us.</b> If one of those men listed in that mishna divorced his wife due to her bad reputation or vow and it was therefore prohibited for him to take her back, yet he nevertheless <b>remarried</b> her, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Must</b> he <b>divorce</b> her?
Rabba bar Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: We</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna (24b): With regard to <b>one who is suspected of</b> committing adultery with <b>a married woman, and he,</b> her husband, <b>divorced her, even if he</b> subsequently <b>remarried</b> her <b>he must divorce</b> her. Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to him: Is this comparable</b> to the case I asked about? <b>There,</b> in the mishna, it says: <b>They,</b> the court, <b>remove her</b> from him, <b>whereas here</b> (<i>Gittin</i> 45b), the mishna states: <b>He divorced her</b> of his own accord. Perhaps if the court requires them to divorce, the <i>halakha</i> is different. The Gemara explains: <b>And Rabba bar Rav Naḥman,</b> who held that the two <i>mishnayot</i> were comparable, had a text of <b>the mishna</b> that <b>also</b> read: <b>He divorced her,</b> instead of: They remove her.
Rabba bar Rav Huna asks: <b>Still, is this comparable? Here,</b> the question was raised in a case where <b>the</b> first <b>husband</b> remarried her, which will not strengthen the rumors of her bad reputation, <b>but there,</b> the mishna refers to <b>the man</b> with whom she committed <b>adultery</b> remarrying her, which strengthens those rumors. <b>He said to him: They are certainly comparable to each other: Here,</b> in the mishna discussing one who is suspected of committing adultery, <b>the Sages said that he may not marry</b> her <b>and if he did marry</b> her <b>he must divorce</b> her. <b>So too, the Sages said</b> in the case of one who divorced his wife due to her reputation or vow <b>that he may not take</b> her <b>back, and if he does remarry</b> her <b>he must divorce</b> her.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>That is not so,</b> as <b>there,</b> when the man suspected of committing adultery marries the woman, <b>he thereby strengthens the rumor</b> of adultery. For this reason he must divorce her. <b>Here, we say that he,</b> the husband, <b>established</b> the facts of <b>the rumor</b> and found that it <b>was not so</b> and the rumor was baseless. Therefore, there is no need for him to divorce her if he remarries her. Rabba bar Rav Huna’s question remains unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> An agent <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas and said: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence,</b> as required in order to establish the bill of divorce as valid, <b>may not marry</b> the <b>wife,</b> i.e., the divorcée. Since the validity of the bill of divorce is based upon his testimony, marrying the divorcée creates the impression that he had an ulterior motive for his testimony. Similarly, a witness who testified that a certain man <b>died,</b> or testified: <b>I killed him,</b> or: <b>We killed him, may not marry</b> that man’s <b>wife. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he testified: <b>I killed him, his wife may not be married</b> at all based on that evidence, as his testimony is unreliable, but if he said: <b>We killed him, his wife may be married</b> to anyone other than those witnesses.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies: <b>The reason that</b> the agent may not marry the divorcée applies specifically in a case where he brings the bill of divorce <b>from a country overseas, as</b> in this case <b>we,</b> the court, <b>rely upon his</b> testimony to validate the bill of divorce. <b>But</b> an agent who brings a bill of divorce <b>from Eretz Yisrael</b> need not make any verbal declaration, and <b>since we,</b> the court, <b>do not rely upon his</b> testimony but upon the written bill of divorce alone, <b>he may marry his wife,</b> i.e., the divorcée, since it does not arouse suspicion.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But</b> also in the case of a witness who said that the husband <b>died, we,</b> the court, <b>do not rely</b> solely <b>upon</b> his testimony. <b>As the Master said: A woman is exacting</b> in her investigation of the truth of the testimony that her husband died before she <b>marries</b> again, and it is primarily on that basis that she is permitted to remarry. <b>Yet it is taught that he</b> still <b>may not marry his wife.</b>
The Gemara answers: The two cases are not comparable, as <b>there,</b> in the case when a witness testifies that the husband has died, <b>there is not anything written</b> as proof, and therefore he may not marry the widow. However, <b>here,</b> in a case where an agent brings a bill of divorce from Eretz Yisrael, <b>there is</b> a <b>written</b> document that is valid without any testimony. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (117a): <b>What is the difference between a bill of divorce and death?</b> Why does the court rely upon those men who are not trusted as witnesses to the death of a husband if they act as agents to bring a bill of divorce, even from overseas, such that they must give testimony that it was written and signed in their presence? The difference is <b>that</b> with regard to a bill of divorce <b>the writing proves</b> their testimony.
The mishna stated that if the witness said with regard to the husband that <b>he died,</b> or: <b>I killed him,</b> or: <b>We killed him,</b> then <b>he may not marry</b> the <b>wife</b> of the deceased. The Gemara infers that <b>he,</b> the witness <b>himself, may not marry</b> the <b>wife; this</b> implies that <b>to another she may be married</b> on the basis of his testimony.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>Didn’t Rav Yosef say:</b> With regard to one who testified that <b>so-and-so sodomized me against my will,</b> then <b>he</b> who testified to being the victim of the sexual assault <b>and another</b> bystander witness can <b>combine</b> as a pair of witnesses in order <b>to put</b> the assailant <b>to death</b> for homosexual intercourse. But if he testified: I was <b>willingly</b> sodomized by so-and-so, then <b>he is wicked</b> by his own admission, since he willingly transgressed. <b>And the Torah said: “Put not your hand with the wicked to be a corrupt witness”</b> (Exodus 23:1). If one renders himself unfit as a witness by admitting to murder, how can his testimony be accepted to permit the wife to remarry?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>testimony</b> that <b>a woman’s</b> husband died <b>is different, as the Sages ruled leniently</b> in such matters and perhaps accepted testimony of a wicked witness in such cases, <b>didn’t Rav Menashe say:</b>

Daf 25b

Although one who is considered <b>a robber according to the words</b> of the Sages is unfit for other forms of testimony, <b>he is fit</b> as a witness <b>for testimony</b> that <b>a woman’s</b> husband died. <b>A robber according to Torah law is unfit</b> as a witness even <b>for testimony</b> that <b>a woman’s</b> husband has died. <b>Should we say that</b> what <b>Rav Menashe said</b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b> Rabbi Yehuda said in the mishna that one who is considered absolutely wicked because he admitted that he is a murderer is unfit for testifying to the death of a husband, but one who was merely present among a gang of murderers is not.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rav Menashe</b> could have <b>said to you: I am speaking even according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Although the Rabbis did not allow one who was wicked by Torah law to testify for a woman, a witness who admitted: I killed him, is nevertheless believed. <b>And the rationale of the Rabbis here is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, as Rava</b> disputed Rav Yosef’s opinion and <b>said:</b> Even if one said that he was willingly sodomized by this man, he is not believed concerning his own actions, because <b>a person is his own relative.</b> Consequently, he may not testify about himself, just as the testimony of any relative is disqualified. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>a person does not make himself wicked.</b> His testimony with regard to his own actions is inadmissible because he is his own relative, but his testimony is accepted both to put a sodomizer to death or to render it permitted for a woman to remarry by saying that he killed her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> according to this explanation that the opinion <b>that Rav Yosef spoke is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rav Yosef</b> could have <b>said to you: I am speaking even according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as</b> in my opinion, <b>testimony</b> enabling <b>a woman</b> to remarry <b>is different in that the Rabbis ruled more leniently</b> and they even accept testimony from a completely wicked individual. However, <b>Rav Menashe, who</b> renders unfit one who is wicked by Torah law from testimony enabling a woman to remarry, <b>spoke in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who differentiates even in such testimony between one who is considered wicked according to Torah law and one who is considered wicked by rabbinic law.
In the mishna it is taught that the court accepts testimony from one who said: <b>I killed him,</b> or: <b>We killed him,</b> while Rabbi Yehuda differentiates between one who said: I killed him, whose testimony is not accepted, and one who said: We killed him, whose testimony is accepted and the woman <b>may be married</b> to others. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different between: I killed him, and: We killed him?</b> Isn’t he a murderer by his own admission as well when he testifies: We killed him? <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> Do not understand that by saying: We killed him, he included himself among the murderers. Rather, it is referring to a case <b>where he said: I was with his murderers,</b> but he was not an active participant to the murder.
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that this is the basis for Rabbi Yehuda’s distinction: <b>They told Rabbi Yehuda:</b> There was <b>an incident involving an armed bandit [<i>listim</i>] who was taken out to be executed in</b> the <b>passage [<i>megizat</i>] of Cappadocia, and he said to</b> those present: <b>Go and tell the wife of Shimon the Priest</b> that <b>I killed her husband as I entered Lod. And some say</b> that he said: <b>As he entered Lod. And they married off his wife</b> on the basis of this testimony. This implies that the court accepts testimony from the murderer himself. Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to them:</b> You derive <b>proof from there?</b> The case was <b>that he said: I was with his murderers,</b> but not that he himself murdered the woman’s husband.
The Gemara challenges: How could Rabbi Yehuda understand the incident in such a way? <b>But it is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that the witness himself was <b>an armed bandit.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He was captured for</b> a charge of <b>armed banditry.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But it is taught that he was taken out to be executed,</b> implying that he was found guilty of murder. The Gemara answers: That was <b>a gentile court, and they execute without being precise.</b> One who is among a gang of bandits is executed by a gentile court regardless of whether or not he himself was a murderer. This <i>baraita</i> therefore provides evidence that Rabbi Yehuda admits the testimony of such a witness only if he says: I was with his murderers.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A <b>Sage who</b> refused to release a woman from a vow that <b>rendered the wife forbidden to her husband by</b> that <b>vow,</b> resulting in her being divorced from her husband, <b>may not marry her,</b> so as to avoid suspicion that he rendered her forbidden to her husband in order to marry her himself. However, a judge before whom a woman <b>performed refusal</b> when she was a minor, declaring that she did not desire the husband chosen for her by her family, <b>or before whom</b> she <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, may marry her because</b> he was only one member of <b>the court,</b> thereby alleviating suspicion.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught that a Sage who rendered a woman forbidden to her husband may not then marry her. The Gemara deduces from here: <b>This</b> implies that if <b>he</b> rendered <b>her permitted</b> to her husband and she was later widowed or divorced, then <b>he may marry her.</b> The Gemara clarifies this: <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that he was <b>a single</b> judge and not part of a court, <b>can a single</b> judge <b>dissolve</b> vows? <b>But didn’t Rav say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rav Amram said: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Dissolution of vows</b> requires a court of <b>three</b> judges?
<b>Rather,</b> could it be a case <b>of three</b> judges rather than one? In such a case, <b>would they be suspect</b> of distorting judgment? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If <b>she performed refusal or performed <i>ḥalitza</i> before him, he may marry her because he</b> functioned as a member of <b>a court</b> of three? This teaches that there is no suspicion of a judge in a court of three.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> you should explain that this case is <b>that of a single</b> judge, <b>and</b> it is <b>as Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Vows may be dissolved even <b>by a single expert,</b> and a three-member court is not always necessary. <b>Here too,</b> it is referring to <b>a single expert</b> refusing to nullify her vow.
It is taught in the mishna that if a woman <b>performed refusal or performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> before a judge, he may still marry her, as he was part of a court. The Gemara deduces from here: <b>The reason is</b> specifically that he functioned on <b>the court</b> as one of three judges. The Gemara deduces: <b>Then, if there were</b> only <b>two</b> judges, <b>he would not</b> be permitted to marry her.
If so, in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>witnesses signed on the</b> document of <b>sale of a field or on a woman’s bill of divorce, the Sages were not concerned about this matter</b> if one of the witnesses subsequently purchased the field or married the divorcée. Since there are two witnesses, there is no suspicion that they collaborated for the benefit of one of them. The Gemara answers: If there were two judges there would also be no concern; however, <b>this</b> mishna <b>itself</b> comes <b>to teach us</b> that a refusal must be performed before a full court, <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said that refusal may be performed before two. This teaches us</b> that <b>refusal</b> must be performed before <b>three</b> judges.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages with regard to one who was prohibited from marrying a certain woman: If he nevertheless <b>married</b> her despite the prohibition, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether <b>he must divorce</b> her? <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> If <b>he married</b> her, <b>he must divorce</b> her. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> If <b>he married</b> her, <b>he need not divorce</b> her. <b>Rav Zuti from the school of Rav Pappi taught</b> the Sages a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of the</b> one who <b>said that</b> if <b>he married</b> her, <b>he need not divorce</b> her.
<b>The Rabbis said to Rav Ashi:</b> With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that you said, that if he married her he need not divorce her, was it based upon <b>tradition or</b> is it your own <b>conclusion? He said to them: It is the mishna.</b> I reached this conclusion from the wording of the mishna, which taught that <b>one suspected</b> by others of engaging in sexual relations <b>with</b> a Canaanite <b>maidservant and she</b> was subsequently <b>set free, or with a gentile woman and she</b> subsequently <b>converted may not marry</b> that woman. <b>But if he did marry her, they,</b> the judges of the court, <b>do not remove</b> her from him. <b>Apparently,</b>

Daf 26a

<b>we do not remove her</b> from her husband owing to suspicion <b>due to rumor</b> alone. <b>Here too, we do not remove her</b> from her husband <b>due to a rumor.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And</b> for <b>all of these</b> who were involved in permitting the wife to remarry, i.e., the judge, the agent who brought a bill of divorce, and the one who testified for a woman that her husband died, if <b>they had wives</b> at the time of the ruling or the testimony <b>and</b> their wives <b>died</b> thereafter, then those women they had set free <b>are permitted to be married to them.</b> There is no concern that while their wives were still alive these individuals set their eyes upon another woman.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of these</b> women who were prohibited from marrying a certain man due to some suspicion, if <b>they were</b> subsequently <b>married to others and</b> then <b>were divorced or widowed</b> from the second husband, <b>they are permitted to be married to them,</b> i.e., to the judge, messenger, or witness who permitted her to remarry. <b>And all of these</b> women who were prohibited from marrying due to some suspicion <b>are permitted to the sons or to the brothers</b> of those who set them free.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught that if any of the men had wives who subsequently died, they may marry those women freed by them. The Gemara deduces from here: <b>If</b> the wives of those who rendered the woman permitted <b>died, yes,</b> they are permitted to marry the woman that they freed for marriage; but if the wives <b>were divorced, no,</b> it is prohibited. In such a case, marrying the woman that one had rendered permitted would raise suspicions that he had in fact planned to marry her all along.
<b>Rav Hillel said to Rav Ashi: Yet it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Even if they were divorced</b> from their first wives they are permitted to marry the women they freed. The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> mishna is referring to a case <b>when there was a quarrel</b> between the husband and the wife at the time that he freed the other woman, as then there is legitimate concern that he was already interested in her. <b>That</b> case of the <i>baraita</i> <b>was when there was no quarrel</b> between them at the time, and therefore the divorce clearly resulted from some other reason.
<b>And if you wish, say: Both this and that</b> were said in cases <b>when there was no quarrel</b> between the one who freed the woman and his first wife, and only later did they quarrel and divorce. <b>And this</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> case of the mishna <b>was when he started</b> the quarrel <b>himself,</b> as then there is legitimate concern that he had an interest in this other woman and therefore sought out a reason to divorce his wife. <b>And that</b> case of the <i>baraita</i> <b>was when</b> his wife <b>started</b> the quarrel, as then there would be no reason to suspect him of freeing the other woman in order to marry her.
The mishna stated: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of these</b> women, <b>if they were married</b> to others and then were divorced or widowed, it is permitted for them to marry those who caused them to be free to marry in the first place. <b>It enters our mind to say</b> that the case referred to here was one of <b>death after death,</b> i.e., the case of a woman whose first husband’s death had been substantiated by a single witness but whose second husband died as well, <b>and</b> also to the case of <b>divorce following</b> a bill of <b>divorce</b> that had been validated by a single witness.
Based on this, <b>should we say that the mishna,</b> which permits a woman to remarry even after her two previous husbands have died, <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>As, if it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>say: After two times</b> a woman has the <b>presumptive status</b> to cause death to her husbands, and such a woman is considered murderous. Therefore, she may not remarry. Since there is no mention of such concern in the mishna, it appears that the mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No</b> evidence can be derived from here, as the reference here may be to <b>death after divorce or divorce after death.</b> The mishna could be referring either to a woman who was at first divorced and then later widowed by her second husband’s death, or to a woman whose first husband died and who was subsequently divorced, but not to a case where she was widowed by the death of two husbands.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And all of these</b> women who were prohibited from marrying the man who freed them due to some suspicion <b>are permitted to the sons or to the brothers</b> of those who set them free. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which we learned</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (4:5) that <b>one suspected</b> of adultery <b>with</b> a specific <b>woman is prohibited</b> not only from marrying her, but also <b>from</b> marrying <b>her mother, and her daughter, and her sister.</b> Yet here we allow his sons and brothers to marry the woman despite the suspicion.
The Gemara answers: There is a distinction between the situations, for <b>it is common for women</b> to be <b>at</b> the house of other <b>women</b> and to stay overnight. Therefore, there is concern that a relative of the alleged adulterer’s wife, with whom he was suspected of misconduct, might frequent his house and he might be tempted to repeat his transgression. On the other hand, <b>it is not common for men</b> to be <b>at</b> the house of other <b>men,</b> so that even if she was married to his relative, the one suspected of misconduct would not generally sleep at the house of the husband.
<b>Alternatively,</b> a different argument could be made: <b>Women are not so strict with one another, as lying with them</b> and having sexual relations with them <b>does not render them mutually forbidden.</b> In other words, if a man commits adultery with his wife’s close relative, his wife does not become forbidden to him, so she may not pay attention to his behavior with the woman under suspicion. However, <b>men are strict with one another, as lying with them</b> and having sexual relations with the other man’s wife <b>does render them,</b> the husband and wife, <b>mutually forbidden.</b> In other words, if another man has relations with a married woman, she is forbidden to her husband, and so men pay close attention to what the others are doing.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, one’s father</b> should be permitted to marry a woman set free by his son <b>as well.</b> So why does the mishna say: Their sons or their brothers, and not: Their fathers? The Gemara answers: Certainly his father is allowed as well, but the mishna <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to mention the case of <b>his father</b> because he is most certainly permitted to marry a woman set free by his son, <b>as his son is embarrassed [<i>baziz</i>] before him</b> and so would not come to sleep with his father’s wife. <b>But I might say that</b> since <b>the father is not embarrassed before his son,</b> she <b>may not</b> be married to the son of one for whom there is suspicion. Therefore, <b>this comes to teach us</b> that there is no such concern.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>four brothers, two of whom were married to two sisters, and the ones married to the sisters died, then those</b> sisters must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> Since both sisters require levirate marriage with each of the surviving brothers, a levirate bond exists between each sister and the brothers. Each of them is considered the sister of a woman with whom each brother has a levirate bond and is therefore forbidden to him by rabbinic law. <b>And if they married</b> the sisters <b>before</b> consulting the court, <b>they should divorce</b> them, for the Sages decreed that in this situation they may not remain married. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that there is a dispute in this matter: <b>Beit Shammai say: He may maintain</b> her as his wife, <b>while Beit Hillel say: They</b> must <b>divorce</b> them.
If <b>one of</b> the sisters <b>was forbidden to one</b> of the brothers due to <b>a prohibition against forbidden relations</b> because she was a relative of his wife or a relative on his mother’s side, then <b>he is forbidden to</b> marry <b>her but permitted to</b> marry <b>her sister.</b> Because she is his close relative, she is exempt from levirate marriage with him, and therefore she is not bound to him with a levirate bond. Consequently, her sister is not considered the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond, and he is permitted to enter into levirate marriage with her. But <b>the second</b> brother, who is not a close relative of either sister, <b>is forbidden to</b> marry <b>both of them.</b> Indeed, for him each woman remains the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond.
If <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> or <b>a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> will be transgressed when one of the women marries one of the brothers, then her sister must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage,</b> as she is considered the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond. In this case, the sister who is forbidden to the brother due to a mitzva or due to sanctity is bound to the brother for the purpose of <i>ḥalitza</i>.
If <b>one of those</b> women <b>was forbidden to this</b> one brother due to <b>a prohibition against forbidden relations and the second</b> woman <b>was forbidden to that</b> second brother due to <b>a prohibition against forbidden relations,</b> then <b>she who is forbidden to this</b> brother <b>is permitted to that</b> brother, <b>and she who is forbidden to that</b> brother <b>is permitted to this</b> one.
<b>And this is</b> the case that was referred to when <b>they said: When her sister is</b> also <b>her <i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., in a case where two sisters are also <i>yevamot</i> and therefore happened for levirate marriage before two brothers, <b>she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> This must be referring to a case where each sister is forbidden to one of the brothers due to a prohibition concerning forbidden relatives. In this case, each sister has a levirate bond only with the one brother to whom she is permitted, and the prohibition against marrying the sister of a woman with whom one has a levirate bond does not apply. Therefore, each brother can either perform the act of <i>ḥalitza</i> or consummate the levirate marriage with the sister to whom he is not related.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara deduces from the <i>halakha</i> cited in the mishna: <b>Conclude from here</b> that the <b>levirate bond is substantial.</b> That is, the very obligation of levirate marriage creates a bond that is similar to marriage. <b>For if the levirate bond were not substantial,</b> why would these two women not enter into levirate marriage? <b>After all, these</b> two women <b>come from two households,</b> as each had a different husband, and they both require levirate marriage. <b>Let this</b> brother <b>consummate the levirate marriage with one</b> sister <b>and let that</b> brother <b>consummate the levirate marriage with</b> the <b>other</b> sister. The fact that the mishna requires <i>ḥalitza</i> in this situation indicates that the levirate bond is substantial and resembles marriage to the extent that each sister is forbidden to each brother due to the prohibition against marrying the sister of a woman to whom one has a levirate bond.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Actually, I</b> could <b>say to you</b> that according to this <i>tanna</i> <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> and yet they are prohibited from entering levirate marriage for a different reason. It is <b>because</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds that it is prohibited to negate the mitzva of levirate marriage.</b> It is prohibited to act in a way that would lead to a situation where the mitzva to perform levirate marriage is negated. How would this situation arise? <b>Perhaps before one</b> brother <b>consummates the levirate marriage, the other</b> brother <b>dies,</b> and only one brother remains. In that case, the second sister would also happen before him for levirate marriage, <b>and</b> by performing levirate marriage with one sister <b>he would</b> thereby <b>negate the mitzva of levirate marriage</b> with the other sister. When the remaining brother marries one of the sisters, the mitzva to enter into levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i> is automatically negated from the second sister, as she is then forbidden to him as his wife’s sister.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if this is the rationale behind the ruling in the mishna, then the same concern would exist if there were <b>three</b> brothers, <b>as well.</b> Why did the mishna specify four brothers? It could have cited the case of three brothers, two of whom were married to two sisters. In these circumstances, the concern for negating the mitzva of levirate marriage also exists.
The Gemara answers: Indeed, the ruling would be the same in that case. However, the mishna <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to specify that the women must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> in a case involving <b>three</b> brothers, <b>as certainly the mitzva of levirate marriage is negated</b> with one of the sisters when the <i>yavam</i> marries the other sister. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>four</b> brothers, where there is concern only over the possibility that one of the brothers might die, we might have said that <b>we are not concerned over</b> the possibility of <b>the death</b> of a brother and therefore allow the brothers to consummate the levirate marriage. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that even in the case where there is concern only for the negation of the mitzva, they must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and not consummate the levirate marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if we are concerned over the possibility that the remaining brother might die,

Daf 26b

then this should <b>also</b> be true in a case of <b>five</b> brothers, two of whom were married to two sisters and died, and their wives happened before the three remaining brothers for levirate marriage. The Gemara answers: <b>We are not concerned over</b> the possibility of <b>the death of two</b> brothers in such a short period of time.
§ <b>Rava bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In a case where <b>three sisters</b> who were married to three brothers became <b><i>yevamot</i></b> and <b>happened before two</b> remaining <b>brothers</b> who were their <b><i>yevamin</i></b> for levirate marriage, then <b>this</b> one brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with one</b> of the women, <b>and that</b> brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> another <b>one</b> of the women. <b>And the middle,</b> i.e., third, sister <b>requires <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of</b> the brothers.
<b>Rabba said to them: From</b> the fact <b>that you say</b> that <b>the middle one requires <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of</b> the brothers, it can be deduced that <b>you hold</b> that <b>the levirate bond is substantial</b> and creates a familial relationship, <b>and</b> similarly <b>this</b> <i>ḥalitza</i> performed by each of the brothers with the third sister <b>is invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> Since the third woman is the sister of a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, it is not possible to consummate the levirate marriage with her. Therefore, the <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with her is not entirely valid and does not release her from the levirate bond between her and the two brothers. <b>And</b> there is a principle that <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> must be repeated by all of the brothers;</b> each of them must perform an act of <i>ḥalitza</i> with this woman.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, the first</b> two women should <b>also</b> require <i>ḥalitza</i> from each of the brothers because each act of <i>ḥalitza</i> was invalid, as each woman has the status of the sister of a woman with whom the man has a levirate bond, and it is therefore prohibited for the men to consummate the levirate marriage with them.
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> the case is <b>that they,</b> i.e., the sisters, <b>happened</b> before the brothers <b>simultaneously, it is indeed so</b> that the two brothers would each be obligated to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with each of the three sisters. This <i>halakha</i> is <b>necessary only</b> in the case <b>where they happened</b> before the brothers, <b>one after the other.</b>
How so? <b>One</b> sister <b>happened</b> before the brothers for levirate marriage and then <b>Reuven,</b> one of the brothers, <b>performed</b> valid <b><i>ḥalitza</i> with her. Another</b> sister <b>happened</b> before the brothers for levirate marriage, and the brother <b>Shimon performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with her.</b> In this case, Shimon was allowed to consummate the levirate marriage with her if he so desired, as she had no family relationship to him at all. When Reuven performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first sister, he removed the levirate bond between her and the other brothers, such that Shimon has no relationship with the first sister at all and is free to marry the second sister. Therefore, when he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, the act was valid.
<b>Another</b> third sister then <b>happened</b> before the brothers for levirate marriage. When <b>this</b> first brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, he terminates his levirate bond, and</b> when <b>this</b> second brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, he terminates his levirate bond.</b> However, neither brother can, by performing <i>ḥalitza</i>, terminate the other brother’s levirate bond because each brother’s <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid, as each brother is unable to consummate the levirate marriage in this case. This is due to the woman’s status as the sister of a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: How can this statement be cited in the name of Rav? <b>But didn’t Rav say: The levirate bond is not substantial.</b> This <i>halakha</i>, however, was explained based on the assumption that the levirate bond is substantial. The Gemara answers: Indeed, according to Rav himself it is unnecessary to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with multiple brothers. He, however, <b>states</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of the one who says that the levirate bond is substantial,</b> despite the fact that he does not hold this himself.
<b>And</b> with regard to the above case <b>Shmuel said</b> a different halakhic ruling: It is sufficient if <b>one</b> brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with each</b> of the sisters. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But since we have heard that Shmuel said: We require a full-fledged <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> and invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> does not result in complete exemption, this ruling is difficult. It is not clear why the invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> in this case would be sufficient, <b>as Shmuel said:</b>

Daf 27a

In the case of three brothers, two of whom were married to several women, including two sisters, and the two married brothers later died, and their wives happened before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage, if the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the sisters</b> who were among the wives, <b>the rival wives are not</b> thereby <b>exempt.</b> One can deduce from here that since the <i>yavam</i> cannot consummate the levirate marriage with the sisters, as each is the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond, then the act of <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid, and invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> is ineffective in exempting their rival wives. It is concluded from here that even Shmuel requires valid <i>ḥalitza</i>, i.e., <i>ḥalitza</i> that occurs when there is a possibility of consummating the levirate marriage. According to this rationale, however, Shmuel’s ruling in the above case is difficult: With regard to the second sister, <b>when there exists</b> the possibility for <b>Shimon’s <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> i.e., the <i>ḥalitza</i> of the second brother who did not yet perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, to be <b>a valid <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> would it be allowed for <b>Reuven,</b> the brother who already did <i>ḥalitza</i> with one sister, <b>to perform invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> her?
The Gemara resolves this difficulty by reinterpreting Shmuel’s statement. <b>What</b> does it mean <b>that it says: One performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with each of them, that</b> Shmuel <b>stated?</b> Shmuel <b>says that with regard to the middle one,</b> i.e., the third sister, one of the two brothers performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t he say: Each of them,</b> indicating that one brother performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with all of the sisters? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the brother who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with one sister repeats the act with another, it turns out that <b>most</b> of the acts of <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>are</b> performed <b>with him, and this is called:</b> With <b>each of them. And if you wish, say</b> a different answer: <b>When Shmuel said we require a full-fledged <i>ḥalitza</i>, this applies only to exempt her rival wife</b> by means of that <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>But to exempt</b> the woman <b>herself,</b> even invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> would render her <b>exempt.</b> In the case above, since no rival wives are involved, it would be sufficient for one brother to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with each of the sisters.
§ Apropos of Shmuel’s statement, the Gemara examines <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Shmuel said:</b> In the case of three brothers, two of whom were married to several women, including two sisters, and the two married brothers later died, and their wives happened before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage, if the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the sisters, the rival wives are not</b> thereby <b>exempt.</b> But if he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with the rival wives, the sisters are exempt.</b> Similarly, if he gave a bill of divorce to one of these women, whereby he would no longer be permitted to consummate the levirate marriage with them due to a rabbinic decree, and he then <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the woman who received a bill of divorce, the rival wife is not</b> thereby <b>exempt.</b> Since he was unable to consummate the levirate marriage with her, the <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with her was invalid, and invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> does not exempt the rival wife. If he performed the act of <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with the rival wife,</b> then <b>the woman who received a bill of divorce is exempt.</b>
The ruling is similar with regard to the case where the <i>yavam</i> performed <i>ma’amar</i>, i.e., levirate betrothal, to one of the wives. If <b>he</b> then <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the woman <b>who received</b> his <b>levirate betrothal</b> then <b>the rival wife is not exempt.</b> Indeed, this <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid as well, for once the <i>yavam</i> performed levirate betrothal, this act can be rescinded only by means of a bill of divorce. Because the woman needs to receive a bill of divorce in addition to the <i>ḥalitza</i> in order to exempt her from her bond, the <i>ḥalitza</i> is considered invalid and is not sufficient to exempt the rival wife. But if the <i>yavam</i> performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with the rival wife,</b> then <b>she who received</b> his <b>levirate betrothal is exempt</b> from <i>ḥalitza</i> and requires only a bill of divorce.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in the two cases? Why, if he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with the sisters, are the rival wives not exempt?</b> This is because the sister <b>is</b> related <b>to him</b> as <b>the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond.</b> Since, under these circumstances he would not be permitted to consummate the levirate marriage with her, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is then considered invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>. However, if that is so, when <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the rival wives, the sisters should not be exempt either, as the</b> rival wives <b>are</b> related <b>to him as rival wives of the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond.</b> If the woman is forbidden to him due to a relationship created by the levirate bond, then her rival wife is forbidden to him in the same way, and her <i>ḥalitza</i> would be invalid as well. The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel holds</b> that <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> and therefore the levirate bond does not create a relationship between the <i>yavam</i> and the sisters such that the prohibition would be extended to the rival wives as well.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But didn’t Shmuel say</b> explicitly that <b>the levirate bond is substantial?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>He stated</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of those who say that the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> although he himself maintains the opposite.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is</b> indeed <b>so,</b> that he stated this ruling in accordance with the opinion that the levirate bond is not substantial, then when the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the sisters, why were</b> their <b>rival wives not exempt? Granted, Rachel’s rival wife,</b> i.e., the rival wife of the second sister, <b>would not be exempt, for once he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with Leah,</b> the first sister, <b>and then</b> later <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with Rachel,</b> it turns out that <b>Rachel’s <i>ḥalitza</i> was invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as he could not consummate the levirate marriage with Rachel because she is the sister of a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, and invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> does not exempt a rival wife. <b>However, the rival wife of Leah should be exempt</b> because if the levirate bond is not substantial, the <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first sister would have been completely valid.
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> does it mean <b>that it says: The rival wives are not exempt, that</b> Shmuel <b>stated?</b> It is referring only <b>to the rival wife of Rachel,</b> the second sister, who is not exempt. The Gemara challenges: <b>But he said rival wives</b> in the plural, seeming to refer to both rival wives? The Gemara answers: He spoke of <b>rival wives in general.</b> In other words, this is a general <i>halakha</i>, and for that reason it was stated in the plural. However, it does not mean that both the rival wife of the first sister and the rival wife of the second sister are not exempt.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>If that is so,</b> that when Shmuel chose to speak in the plural he was referring only to the rival wife of Rachel, there arises a difficulty with the second half of the statement: If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the rival wives, the sisters are exempt. But would Rachel</b> become <b>exempt</b> by <i>ḥalitza</i> performed <b>with her rival wife? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A man is forbidden to</b> marry <b>the rival wife of a close relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>?</b> Once the <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with one sister, Leah, then her sister’s rival wife, i.e., Rachel’s rival wife, would be considered the rival wife of the sister of a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>. Being as she is forbidden to him, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid and should not exempt Rachel.
The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel also</b> meant to distinguish between a case where <b>he began and</b> the case where <b>he did not begin.</b> This is how his statement should be understood: If <b>he began</b> by performing <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with</b> one of <b>the sisters, he may not finish by</b> performing a second act of <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with</b> any one of <b>the rival wives, as we learned</b> in a mishna (40b): <b>A man is forbidden</b> to marry <b>the rival wife of a close relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>.</b> Due to this prohibition, <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with the second rival wife is invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> and would not exempt the second sister. If, however, <b>he began with the rival wives</b> and performed the first <i>ḥalitza</i> with the rival wife of Leah, <b>he may finish with the sisters as well</b> and perform the second <i>ḥalitza</i> with Leah, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (40b): <b>A man is permitted to</b> marry <b>the close relative of the rival wife of his <i>ḥalutza</i>.</b> Therefore, if he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with Leah’s rival wife, then Rachel, who is the sister of the rival wife of his <i>ḥalutza</i>, is permitted to him. He can therefore perform a completely valid <i>ḥalitza</i> with her and thereby exempt her rival wife.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> Shmuel’s statement should be interpreted <b>as you</b> originally <b>said,</b> that Shmuel’s rationale for these <i>halakhot</i> accords with his opinion that the levirate bond is substantial. As for the objection that was raised as to why the sisters would be exempted by <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with the rival wives if these rival wives were considered the rival wife of the sister of a woman with whom the <i>yavam</i> had a levirate bond, this can be resolved as follows: This <b>is because the levirate bond is not</b> so <b>strong as to render the</b> status of <b>a rival wife like</b> an actual <b>forbidden relative.</b> The levirate bond is sufficient to prohibit levirate marriage with the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond, but not sufficient to prohibit their rival wives to the <i>yavam</i>.
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ashi:</b> If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the sisters, the rival wives are not exempt</b> from levirate marriage. From here one can deduce: <b>Consequently,</b> if he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with the rival wives, the sisters are exempt. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Is it not because</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>held</b> that <b>the levirate bond is substantial,</b> and therefore the rival wives were not rendered exempt by the <i>ḥalitza</i> of the sisters, <b>but</b> nevertheless <b>the levirate bond is not</b> so <b>strong as to render the rival wife equivalent to a forbidden relative?</b> Therefore, the prohibition with regard to the rival wives in this case is less severe than the prohibition concerning the sisters themselves, and when they perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, the <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid and the sisters are exempt.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel</b> rejected this explanation and <b>said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Beit Shammai permitted the rival wives to</b> marry <b>the brothers;</b> even if they are the rival wives of his actual relatives, they are permitted to enter into levirate marriage. In the case above, where they are merely rival wives of the sister with whom he has a levirate bond, all the more so they are permitted to enter into levirate marriage. The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> if this ruling is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai, who say that the rival wives are permitted, then the rival wife <b>should enter into levirate marriage as well.</b> Why does it speak here only of <i>ḥalitza</i> but not of the possibility of entering levirate marriage?
The Gemara answers: The ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, who said: Come and let us establish</b> a ruling <b>that the rival wives must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage,</b> thereby circumventing the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. Although Beit Shammai permitted the rival wives to perform levirate betrothal, they should perform <i>ḥalitza</i> instead in order to conform to Beit Hillel’s opinion as well. The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t the Master say</b> that <b>they did not succeed in finalizing the matter</b> and establishing Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri’s amendment <b>before the times of trouble came</b> in the form of the anti-Jewish decrees, and so this ruling was never actually established? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: After his</b> time, other Sages <b>returned</b> to this issue and <b>established</b> this amendment in accordance with his opinion.
§ Apropos of the statement of Shmuel with regard to a woman who received a bill of divorce and a woman who received levirate betrothal, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages:

Daf 27b

If two women happened before a single <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage, and one is <b>a woman who received a bill of divorce and</b> the other is <b>a woman who received levirate betrothal, which has precedence</b> for <i>ḥalitza</i>? <b>Is the woman who received a bill of divorce preferred because he began the</b> process of <b><i>ḥalitza</i> with her,</b> as presenting a bill of divorce represents the first step separating the woman from him? <b>Or perhaps the woman who received levirate betrothal is preferred, because she is closest to</b> being able to enter into permitted <b>sexual intercourse.</b> The act of levirate betrothal is generally done just prior to levirate marriage and is equivalent to the act of betrothal in non-levirate contexts. As a result, levirate betrothal strengthens the connection between the woman and the <i>yavam</i>. For this reason, it may be preferable to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the woman who received levirate betrothal.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> The Sages disputed the ruling with regard to a <i>yavam</i> who performed levirate betrothal with one sister-in-law and then performed it with her rival wife as well, or conversely, gave both women a bill of divorce. In such cases, would the second levirate betrothal or bill of divorce be effective? It was taught: <b>And Rabban Gamliel concedes that a bill of divorce is effective after levirate betrothal.</b> Therefore, the bill of divorce that the <i>yavam</i> gave to one <i>yevama</i> after having performed levirate betrothal with the other <i>yevama</i> is effective to some degree. Similarly, Rabban Gamliel concedes that <b>levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>after a bill of divorce is effective.</b>
<b>If the bill of divorce is preferred</b> to levirate betrothal, then <b>levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>afterward should not be effective.</b> The opposite would hold true as well: <b>And if levirate betrothal is preferred,</b> then <b>a bill of divorce</b> given <b>afterward should not be effective. Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> this statement <b>that the two are equivalent to each other?</b> The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <b>conclude from</b> this statement that they are equivalent. Therefore, neither the woman who received a bill of divorce nor the woman who received levirate betrothal has precedence for <i>ḥalitza</i>.
§ <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In a case of <b>two sisters</b> who became <b><i>yevamot</i>,</b> i.e., the two sisters were married to two brothers who died, <b>who happened before one <i>yavam</i></b> for levirate marriage, if <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first</b> sister, then <b>she is permitted</b> to marry any man. If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the second</b> sister, then <b>she is permitted</b> to do so as well.
If <b>the first</b> sister <b>died</b> before the <i>yavam</i> was able to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, then he <b>is permitted to</b> take <b>the second</b> sister in levirate marriage, for even if he had actually been married to the first sister, one is permitted to marry the sister of his wife after his wife dies. <b>And needless to say,</b> if <b>the second</b> sister <b>died, then he is permitted to</b> take <b>the first</b> sister in levirate marriage <b>because she would be</b> considered <b>a <i>yevama</i> who was permitted</b> at the time that she happened before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage; <b>and</b> then later <b>forbidden</b> as the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond when the second sister happened before him for levirate marriage; <b>and subsequently became permitted</b> by the death of the second sister. Therefore, <b>she can return</b> completely <b>to her original permitted status.</b>
<b>However, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If <b>the second</b> sister <b>dies, he is permitted to</b> take <b>the first. But if the first</b> sister <b>dies, he is prohibited from</b> taking <b>the second</b> sister. <b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? The reason is <b>that any <i>yevama</i> to whom the verse “her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5) <b>cannot be applied at the time that she happens</b> before him for levirate marriage because she was forbidden to him at that moment, <b>is then</b> forever considered to be <b>like the wife of a brother who has children, and she is forbidden</b> to him. Because the second sister was forbidden to the <i>yavam</i> at the time that she happened before him for levirate marriage, being the sister of a woman with whom he had a levirate bond, she can never again be permitted to him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rav not accept that reason? Didn’t Rav</b> himself <b>say</b> the exact same words: <b>Any woman to whom the verse “her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her” cannot be applied at the time that she happens</b> before him for levirate marriage <b>is then</b> considered to be <b>like the wife of a brother who has children, and she is forbidden</b> to him? The Gemara answers: <b>This applies only when</b> the prohibition <b>that stands before her</b> and prevents the levirate marriage <b>is the prohibition against marrying the sister of one’s wife, which is prohibited by Torah</b> law. Therefore, if the woman who happens before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage is his wife’s sister, he is prohibited from performing levirate marriage even if his wife dies afterward. <b>But here</b> the prohibition to marry the sister stems from a relationship created by <b>a levirate bond.</b> This prohibition is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, and therefore the bond does not render her forbidden to him forever.
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the mishna: In the case of <b>four brothers, two of whom were married to two sisters, and those married to the sisters died, then those</b> sisters <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage. And why</b> does the mishna require <i>ḥalitza</i>? <b>Let one of</b> the brothers <b>rise and perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the second</b> sister, i.e., the sister whose husband died later. As a result, <b>the first would be like a <i>yevama</i> who was permitted</b> at the time of her husband’s death but later became <b>forbidden</b> due to the bond that was created with her sister, <b>and</b> she then <b>subsequently became permitted</b> by means of <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with her sister, <b>insofar as the other</b> brother, i.e., he who did not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>is concerned.</b> Therefore, <b>she should return to her original permitted status.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: I do not know who taught: Sisters.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was in doubt as to the correct version of this mishna, as he could not find any reasonable explanation of this mishna according to any known opinion. The Gemara asks: Why did Rabbi Yoḥanan respond in such an extreme manner. <b>Let him say to him,</b> to Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, an alternate solution: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the ruling that the sisters <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, which</b> the mishna <b>teaches?</b> The meaning is that <b>one</b> sister <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: Such a solution is untenable, as the mishna <b>teaches</b> the ruling using the words: <b>Perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> in the plural.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>say to him: What is</b> the meaning of the ruling to <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>? They perform <i>ḥalitza</i> in general.</b> Accordingly, the mishna teaches that in such cases the second woman performs <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara responds: The mishna <b>teaches: Then those</b> women perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. The emphasis on the word: Those, indicates that it is specifically those two women who both perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara asks further: <b>And let him say</b> that the mishna is referring only to the specific case <b>where</b> <i>the yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first</b> sister <b>first.</b> As a result, there was no longer any possibility of rendering the second sister permitted, as Rabbi Yoḥanan permitted levirate marriage only in the case where <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed with the second sister first. The Gemara answers: This cannot be suggested either, for the phrase: <b>Perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b>

Daf 28a

implies that the mishna <b>teaches</b> a case in which <i>ḥalitza</i> is performed <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> This indicates that this is the first course of action and the only way to resolve the situation. The Gemara asks further: And <b>let him say to him</b> the following: The mishna prohibits levirate marriage <i>ab initio</i> in this case, due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest he proceed and perform the <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first</b> sister <b>first,</b> whereby it would be prohibited to consummate the levirate marriage with the second. Perhaps for this reason the Sages decreed that it is prohibited to consummate the levirate marriage even if <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed with the second sister. The Gemara answers: <b>It teaches: They may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> This indicates that <b>the <i>halakha</i> of levirate marriage does not apply here at all.</b> Accordingly, even after the fact, if he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the second sister, the <i>halakha</i> of levirate marriage would not apply to the first sister.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him say to him</b> a different reason for the ruling of the mishna: It is due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> the second brother <b>die, and it is prohibited to negate the mitzva of levirate marriage.</b> Perhaps for this reason it would be forbidden to consummate the levirate marriage in the case where two sisters happened before him for levirate marriage, and not due to the prohibition proscribing the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan was not concerned over</b> the possibility of the <b>death</b> of a brother, and in his opinion there is no need to make a decree to address such cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>say to him</b> that this mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who said: Once</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>stood before him at one time as forbidden,</b> even if it was not at the time that she happened before him, <b>she remains forbidden to him forever.</b> Perhaps the mishna could be explained according to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> is cited explicitly <b>in the latter clause</b> of the mishna, it can be deduced that <b>the first clause is not</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> Therefore, this ruling cannot be attributed to Rabbi Elazar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him say to him</b> that here the reference is to a situation <b>where</b> the two brothers died at once, and consequently both of the women <b>happened before</b> the <i>yevamin</i> for levirate marriage <b>at the same time. And</b> this mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says: It is possible to be precise.</b> It is possible to determine that two events occurred at exactly the same moment, both sisters were forbidden at the time that they happened before the brothers-in-law. The Gemara answers: <b>The <i>tanna</i> did not teach an unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b> Any time the mishna is cited in accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion, it is always attributed to him explicitly.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him say to him</b> a different explanation for the ruling: This mishna is indeed addressing a case where the brothers died one after the other, yet <b>we do not know which</b> sister <b>happened</b> before the <i>yevamin</i> for levirate marriage <b>first.</b> In that case, it would be impossible to determine which sister would be permitted.
The Gemara answers: <b>If so, that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> in the latter clause: <b>And if they married</b> their wives <b>before</b> consulting the court <b>they should divorce them,</b> is difficult. Why must they divorce their wives in this situation? <b>Granted,</b> the brother who took <b>the first</b> sister in levirate marriage must divorce her, as <b>we say to him: Who permitted her to you?</b> Indeed, she was forbidden as the sister of a woman with whom he had a levirate bond, and so he must divorce her. <b>However,</b> the brother who took <b>the second</b> sister <b>could say: My fellow</b> brother <b>consummated the levirate marriage with the second</b> sister, but <b>I am consummating the levirate marriage with the first</b> sister. It is possible that after the other brother consummated the levirate marriage with the second sister, the first sister would then be permitted to him after the fact, and he is not required to divorce her unless it is certain that he violated a prohibition.
The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan meant when he <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina: <b>I do not know who taught: Sisters,</b> for according to these considerations he cannot properly resolve the ruling of this mishna.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>one of</b> the sisters <b>was forbidden to one</b> of the brothers due to a <b>prohibition against forbidden relatives</b> because she was a relative of his wife or a relative from his mother’s side, then <b>he is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>her but permitted to</b> marry <b>her sister.</b> But <b>the second</b> brother, who is not a close relative of either sister, <b>is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>both of them. It enters your mind</b> to say <b>that</b> a forbidden woman, such as <b>his mother-in-law, happened</b> before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage <b>first.</b>
Accordingly, the Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> would both women be forbidden to the second brother? <b>Let the son-in-law rise and consummate the levirate marriage with</b> the sister <b>who is not his mother-in-law first. Consequently, with regard to the other</b> brother, <b>his mother-in-law would be</b> considered <b>a <i>yevama</i> who was permitted</b> to perform levirate marriage at the time that she happened before him, <b>and then forbidden</b> when her sister happened before him for levirate marriage as well, <b>and then subsequently became permitted</b> when his brother consummated the levirate marriage with her sister. If so, the mother-in-law <b>should return to her original permitted status</b> and may enter into levirate marriage with him.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>who was not his mother-in-law happened</b> before the brothers for levirate marriage <b>first,</b> in which case she was permitted to both of them. When her sister, i.e., the mother-in-law, happened before them for levirate marriage as well, both women were rendered forbidden to the second brother, as each one is the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond. Because the mother-in-law was forbidden from the time that she happened before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage, she can never be permitted to him.
§ With regard to the case of two brothers who married their wives before consulting the court, the mishna states that the women should be divorced. <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> disagrees and <b>says</b> that this is a matter of dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, as <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> They may maintain them as their wives, and Beit Hillel say: They should divorce them. An expanded version of this discussion <b>is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (5:1): <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>Beit Shammai say: They may maintain them</b> as their wives, <b>and Beit Hillel say: They should divorce them. Rabbi Shimon says: They may maintain them</b> as their wives. <b>Abba Shaul</b> disagrees with Rabbi Eliezer and <b>says: This was a matter of leniency for Beit Hillel.</b> They were the ones who put forth a lenient ruling, <b>as Beit Shammai say: They should divorce them, and Beit Hillel say: They may maintain</b> them as their wives.
The Gemara asks about this <i>baraita</i>: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> This matter is a dispute between Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai, with different versions of their opinions, and therefore Rabbi Shimon should not have formulated the <i>halakha</i> in this manner. Indeed, <b>if</b> he holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> then <b>that is</b> the same as the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> He would thereby conclude that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai, as per Rabbi Eliezer’s version. If so, he should have formulated his opinion in that way. <b>If,</b> however, he holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> then <b>that is</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>This is what he is saying:</b> Rabbi Shimon actually maintains a third opinion: <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not dispute this matter;</b> both agreed that the marriages may be maintained.
§ The mishna stated: If <b>one of</b> the sisters <b>was</b> forbidden to one of the brothers due to a prohibition against forbidden relations, then he is prohibited from marrying her but permitted to marry her sister. The Gemara asks: <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> this <b>on one occasion: When her sister,</b> who is a forbidden relative to the <i>yavam</i>, <b>is her <i>yevama</i></b> as well, <b>she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b>
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> that this be said here as well, <b>for if it taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>there</b> in its more general formulation (<i>Yevamot</i> 20a), then I might have said: The <i>yavam</i> is permitted to marry the sister <b>because there is no</b> reason <b>to issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree due to a second</b> brother. There, there is only one <i>yavam</i>, to whom one sister is permitted and the other is forbidden. <b>Here, however,</b> in the case of two brothers, <b>where there is</b> reason <b>to issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree due to the second</b> brother, lest he consummate the levirate marriage as well, <b>I would say</b> that we do <b>not</b> allow even the first brother to perform levirate marriage, and both sisters-in-law should be forbidden to both brothers.
<b>And if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>here,</b> it would have been possible to say that the permissibility of levirate marriage here is <b>because there is</b> a second brother who <b>indicates,</b> by refraining from performing levirate marriage, that the sister of a woman bound by a levirate bond is forbidden. <b>However, there,</b> where there <b>is not a second</b> brother, <b>I would say no,</b> this <i>halakha</i> would not apply, due to a concern that people might wrongly conclude that the sister of a woman bound by a levirate bond is permitted. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> in both places.
It was taught in the mishna: If one of the sisters was forbidden to one of the brothers due to <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> or due to a prohibition stemming from sanctity, then her sister must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage. The Gemara wonders: <b>We</b> already <b>learned this as well:</b>

Daf 28b

If <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> or <b>a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> will be transgressed through the levirate marriage, then the woman must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara answers: There is a novelty here: <b>There,</b> where the <i>halakha</i> is reviewed in general terms, it speaks of <b>a prohibition due to a mitzva alone.</b> One woman happened before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage and it is only as a result of this prohibition that she is prevented from entering levirate marriage. <b>Here,</b> there is <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva and,</b> in addition, <b>her sister</b> happened before the <i>yevamin</i> for levirate marriage together with her.
<b>It might enter your mind to say: Let the prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva stand in</b> the same <b>place,</b> i.e., level of severity, <b>as the prohibition against forbidden relatives.</b> Consequently, the woman who is forbidden to the <i>yavam</i> is considered a forbidden relative and her sister is permitted to him. Despite the fact that the prohibition resulting from a mitzva is not as severe, here it is given equal status, <b>and</b> we might say: <b>Let</b> her sister <b>enter into levirate marriage.</b> Therefore, <b>this comes to teach us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why in fact <b>does</b> her sister not <b>enter into levirate marriage?</b> The Gemara answers: Her sister is forbidden to him <b>because by Torah</b> law the prohibited woman <b>is</b> still <b>set before</b> <i>the yavam</i> for levirate marriage. Were he to take the sister in levirate marriage <b>he would</b> essentially <b>be encountering the sister of the woman with whom he has</b> a levirate bond. <b>It might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>due to the mitzva</b> of levirate marriage, <b>the Sages did as they did</b> and nullified their decree prohibiting the sister of a woman with whom the <i>yavam</i> has a levirate bond from entering levirate marriage, when the original sister is forbidden only as the result of a mitzva. Therefore, it <b>teaches us</b> that they did not cancel their decree in this situation.
It was taught in the mishna: If <b>one of those</b> women was forbidden to this one brother due to a prohibition against forbidden relatives and the second was forbidden to that second brother due to a prohibition against forbidden relatives, then she who is forbidden to this brother is permitted to that brother, and she who is forbidden to that brother is permitted to this one. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>as well, for this is</b> identical to <b>that</b> which was taught earlier, when the mishna stated that if one of the sisters was forbidden to one of the brothers due to a prohibition against forbidden relatives, then he is forbidden to marry her but permitted to marry her sister. However, the second brother, who is not a close relative of either sister, is prohibited from marrying both of them. Once the mishna taught that the <i>yavam</i> is permitted to marry the woman to whom he is not related, <b>what is the</b> difference <b>to me</b> if there is <b>one</b> brother <b>or two</b> brothers? If this happened to both brothers, clearly both should be allowed.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to state this, <b>for if it taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>there,</b> in the case where only one brother is permitted, one might have said: <b>This is because there is a second</b> brother <b>who indicates</b> that the sister of a woman bound by a levirate bond is forbidden to him by refraining from levirate marriage with her. <b>However, here,</b> where there <b>is not a second</b> brother <b>who indicates</b> this, as both brothers are performing levirate marriage, then <b>I would say no;</b> this <i>halakha</i> would not apply, due to the concern that people might wrongly conclude that the sister of a woman with whom the <i>yavam</i> has a levirate bond is permitted even in cases where the other woman is not a forbidden relative.
<b>And</b> the opposite could also be said: <b>If it taught us</b> the ruling only <b>here,</b> in the case of two brothers, one might have said: <b>On the contrary, they both indicate</b> the nature of <b>each other’s</b> status. Each of the brothers married a specific sister-in-law, i.e., the woman who was not his close relative, indicating he does not have a levirate bond with the other sister. <b>But in the other</b> case, where one brother is allowed to consummate the levirate marriage and the second brother is forbidden to both sisters, I might say that <b>no,</b> we would not allow marriage to the first brother either. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state the <i>halakha</i> in both instances.
It was taught in the mishna: <b>And this is</b> the case that was referred to when <b>they said:</b> When her sister is also her <i>yevama</i>, she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage. The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> the expression: <b>This is,</b> come to <b>exclude?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It excludes</b> the case where there is <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva for this</b> one <b>and a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva for that</b> one. Although each woman is forbidden to a different brother due to a prohibition resulting from a mitzva, they may not both enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need this as well? This is</b> identical to <b>that</b> which was taught previously, that if one of the sisters was forbidden to the <i>yavam</i> due to a prohibition resulting from a mitzva, then he is not permitted to consummate the levirate marriage with either of them. <b>What</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if she happened before <b>one</b> brother <b>or two?</b>
