<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who has <b>a double levirate relationship</b> is exempt from levirate marriage is <b>by Torah</b> law, as indicated by the proof offered in the mishna, <b>she should not require <i>ḥalitza</i> as well,</b> but be completely exempt. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>by rabbinic</b> law. The restriction on levirate marriage in this case is not by Torah law, as by Torah law the brother is allowed to consummate the levirate marriage with both of these women since each was the wife of a different brother. The requirement for <i>ḥalitza</i> in this case was instituted as a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>two <i>yevamot</i> who come from a single household can enter into levirate marriage.</b> Since the second brother had performed levirate betrothal, people might come to think that both were actually married to him. If the third brother consummates the levirate marriage with both women, it would lead people to think that it is permitted to take two of a brother’s wives in levirate marriage, when in fact the Torah allows the <i>yavam</i> to marry only a single wife of the deceased.
The Gemara asks: <b>So let him consummate the levirate marriage with one</b> woman <b>and perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the other <b>one,</b> and this would eliminate our concern. The Gemara responds: We do not do this due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest they say:</b> When there are two women from <b>a single household, part of it</b> must <b>be built</b>

Daf 32a

<b>and part of it</b> must <b>be released by <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> That is, if two women were married to a single man, one of these women must enter into levirate marriage and the other must perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara wonders: <b>So let them say</b> it. Why would it be problematic if people thought that? Even were they to act upon this mistaken assumption it would cause no harm, as there is no transgression involved in performing <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>If he were to consummate the levirate marriage</b> with one and then later <b>proceed to perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the other, then <b>indeed</b> there would be no reason for concern.
<b>Rather,</b> the requirement to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with both women is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that was instituted <b>lest he first perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of his brother’s wives <b>and subsequently consummate the levirate marriage</b> with the other. Under such circumstances, he would in fact be violating a prohibition. Once he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first woman <b>he is subject to</b> the prohibition indicated by the verse “So shall it be done to the man <b>who does not build</b> his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9). In this verse <b>the Merciful One states</b> that <b>once he did not build</b> his brother’s house but rather opted to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with one of his brother’s wives, <b>he may not proceed to build</b> it by consummating the levirate marriage with a different wife.
<b>Rava said:</b> If the brother who performed levirate betrothal in the case described in the mishna subsequently <b>gave a bill of divorce</b> to that wife in order to nullify <b>his levirate betrothal</b> before he died, <b>her rival wife is rendered permitted</b> to the third brother. The third brother is allowed to consummate the levirate marriage with the wife of the second brother because this wife is no longer considered to be the rival wife of a woman with a double levirate relationship. The bill of divorce serves to nullify the act of levirate betrothal completely. <b>However,</b> the woman with whom the brother performed levirate betrothal and then received the bill of divorce <b>is forbidden</b> to the third brother. Why is this? <b>She might be confused with</b> a woman <b>who receives a bill of divorce.</b> In general cases where levirate betrothal was not performed, if a man gives a <i>yevama</i> a bill of divorce, he is no longer allowed to consummate the levirate marriage with her. If it were permitted to consummate the levirate marriage in this case, people might mistakenly do so in other cases of divorce as well.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> an alternative formulation of Rava’s statement. <b>Rava said:</b> If the second brother <b>gave a bill of divorce</b> to the wife of the first deceased brother in order to nullify <b>his levirate betrothal</b> to her, then <b>even she</b> herself <b>is permitted</b> to enter into levirate marriage with the third brother. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>That which he performed with her, he removed.</b> The levirate betrothal was completely nullified by the bill of divorce, and it is as though he had done nothing at all. Therefore, as far as the third brother is concerned, she remains with her original, single levirate bond, as though her status had never been changed by the second brother.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case where <b>two brothers were married to two sisters, and one of</b> the brothers <b>died,</b> the widow at this point would be exempt from levirate marriage as the sister of his wife. <b>And afterward the wife of the second</b> brother <b>died.</b> Although the <i>yevama</i> is no longer the sister of his wife, <b>this</b> woman <b>is nevertheless forbidden to him forever, since she had</b> already <b>been forbidden to him at one time.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious? Now, just as there,</b> in the earlier <i>mishnayot</i>, where there was a third brother and so the woman <b>was not disassociated from this household completely,</b> as the levirate obligation existed between her and the third brother to whom she was permitted, <b>you said</b> that <b>she may not</b> enter into levirate marriage because she was forbidden at one time, <b>here,</b> in the case of only two brothers, <b>where she is disassociated from this household completely,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> clear that it should be prohibited for her to enter into levirate marriage? The Gemara answers: <b>The <i>tanna</i> taught this</b> mishna <b>at first,</b> at which time <b>he saw it</b> fitting to rule that <b>those</b> other cases are <b>permitted, and</b> therefore he <b>permitted them. And then he</b> subsequently <b>saw it</b> fitting to rule that <b>they are forbidden. And since</b> that case was novel, <b>it was beloved to him, he taught it earlier.</b> But despite the fact that this mishna was no longer necessary, <b>the mishna does not move from its place.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>he engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with this woman who was forbidden to him, <b>he is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for</b> violating the prohibition against marrying <b>a brother’s wife,</b> because she was never rendered permitted by the levirate mitzva, <b>and</b> he is liable to receive punishment <b>for</b> violating the prohibition against marrying <b>a wife’s sister;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Shimon says: He is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>only for</b> violating the prohibition proscribing <b>a brother’s wife.</b> Rabbi Shimon holds that one prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition is already in place, and since she was already forbidden as his brother’s wife, the additional prohibition cannot take effect. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: He is liable only due to</b> the prohibition against marrying <b>a wife’s sister?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where the living</b> brother <b>married</b> his wife first <b>and afterward the</b> brother who is now <b>deceased</b> married her sister. In that case, the first prohibition to take effect on the <i>yevama</i> was that of a wife’s sister, and only later, when she was married to his now-deceased brother, did the additional prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife take effect. <b>There,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where the</b> brother who is now <b>deceased married</b> his wife first, whereby she became forbidden to the brother as a brother’s wife, <b>and afterward the living</b> brother <b>married</b> her sister, rendering her forbidden as his wife’s sister as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> in a case <b>where the deceased</b> brother <b>married</b> one of the sisters first, in which case she was forbidden to his brother as a brother’s wife, <b>and afterward the living</b> brother <b>married</b> her sister, the only prohibition in place is that of a brother’s wife. Therefore, <b>since the prohibition</b> with regard to <b>a wife’s sister never took effect,</b> then after her husband died <b>she should</b> now <b>enter into levirate marriage.</b> As the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife is canceled in the face of the levirate mitzva, she should indeed enter into levirate marriage.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The prohibition</b> with regard to <b>a wife’s sister remains suspended. If the prohibition</b> proscribing <b>a brother’s wife is terminated, the prohibition</b> proscribing <b>a wife’s sister comes and takes effect. Therefore,</b> it is clear that the prohibition proscribing a wife’s sister <b>is not</b> completely <b>terminated.</b> Accordingly, when a man dies and the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife is overridden by the levirate mitzva, the prohibition proscribing a wife’s sister takes effect and she is forbidden to him due to that. The moment the first prohibition ceases to exist, the second immediately takes effect.
The <i>baraita</i> indicates that Rabbi Yosei holds that if the brother consummated the levirate marriage with this woman he violated two prohibitions. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yosei hold</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who committed a transgression deserving of two death penalties is sentenced to the harsher</b> of the two deaths? One would be guilty of such a transgression if he engaged in intercourse with a forbidden relative who was also a married woman, as he would incur one death penalty due to her being a forbidden relative and one death penalty due to her being a married woman. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: He is sentenced according to the first relationship that applied to him</b> with regard to this woman.
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what case did Rabbi Yosei say that he is sentenced according to the first relationship that applied to him?</b> If this woman was <b>his mother-in-law</b> who was widowed or divorced, and therefore forbidden to him only due to her status as his mother-in-law, and later she married <b>and became</b> forbidden as <b>a married woman</b> and he engaged in sexual relations with her, then <b>he is sentenced for</b> violating the prohibition proscribing <b>his mother-in-law,</b> since this was the first prohibition to apply. Alternatively, if she was <b>a married woman</b> and then he married her daughter so that she then <b>became his mother-in-law,</b> and then had sexual relations with her, <b>he is sentenced for</b> violating the prohibition proscribing <b>a married woman.</b>

Daf 32b

<b>Rabbi Abbahu said: Rabbi Yosei concedes</b> that a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition already exists <b>when it is an expanded prohibition.</b> An expanded prohibition is a prohibition that has a greater scope than the original prohibition, either because it applies with greater severity or because it applies to additional individuals. Rabbi Yosei holds that if the second prohibition incorporates additional individuals into the list of those for whom the original item is prohibited, then it takes effect in addition to the previous prohibition that had a more limited range.
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well</b> in cases <b>where the living</b> brother <b>married</b> his wife first, and her sister became forbidden to him as a wife’s sister, <b>and then afterward the</b> brother who was subsequently <b>deceased married</b> his wife’s sister. In that case it is possible to say: <b>Since a prohibition was added for</b> all <b>the brothers, a prohibition was added for</b> the living brother as well, and he is liable due to both prohibitions, as this prohibition is more wide-ranging than the previous one. In other words, at first this sister was permitted to the other brothers, and when the second brother married her she was rendered a brother’s wife and so she was additionally forbidden to the other brothers.
<b>However, where</b> the <b>deceased</b> brother <b>married</b> first and <b>afterward</b> the <b>living</b> brother <b>married</b> her sister, <b>in what way is there a prohibition that adds?</b> No additional individuals were incorporated into the prohibition as a result of the marriage of the living brother with the sister, since the prohibition here proscribing a wife’s sister applies to him alone.
<b>And if you would say: Since</b> he himself now married a sister <b>he became prohibited to all of the other sisters,</b> as opposed to the prior state of affairs where only his brother was married to one of the sisters and all of the other sisters were permitted to him, and therefore an additional prohibition now applies to him, this is difficult. In this case the new prohibition is not considered an expanded prohibition, but rather <b>it is</b> considered <b>a more inclusive prohibition.</b> It is more inclusive and more comprehensive in that it adds additional aspects to the prohibition for the same individual. This is not called an expanded prohibition, as it does not add prohibitions to additional individuals.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that when Rabbi Yosei stated in the <i>baraita</i> that the man is liable due to both prohibitions, for a brother’s wife and for a wife’s sister, he meant to say: <b>I ascribe to him</b> liability <b>as though he transgressed twice,</b> since indeed he violated two prohibitions, <b>yet he is liable</b> to receive punishment in human courts <b>on only one</b> count. <b>And likewise, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I ascribe to him</b> liability <b>as though he transgressed twice, yet he is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>on only one</b> count. The Gemara asks: <b>What difference does it make</b> if we consider it as though he transgressed twice? The Gemara answers: It affects the decision whether or not <b>to bury him among the completely wicked.</b> Just as a righteous individual is not buried among the wicked, so too, a wicked individual is not buried among those more wicked than himself. He who violated this prohibition is considered as though he committed two transgressions and not one, and so he would be buried accordingly.
§ The Gemara comments that the issue of a prohibition taking effect where another prohibition already exists is taught <b>in the dispute</b> found in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>where it was stated:</b> With regard to <b>a non-priest who served</b> in some capacity in one of the Temple services, such as the burning of a burnt-offering on the altar <b>on Shabbat, Rabbi Ḥiyya says: He is liable</b> to receive punishment on <b>two</b> counts, both because he was a non-priest serving in the Temple and because he desecrated Shabbat. <b>Bar Kappara says: He is liable</b> on <b>only one</b> count. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>two</b> counts. <b>Bar Kappara jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>one</b> count.
Since the matter could not be decided by tradition, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya began to deliberate</b> and analyze the question logically. Prohibited labor on <b>Shabbat was prohibited to all. When</b> prohibited labor <b>was permitted in the Temple</b> for the purposes of the Temple service, <b>it was permitted</b> only <b>for priests.</b> This indicates that <b>it was permitted for priests and not for non-priests.</b> Therefore, when a non-priest serves in the Temple on Shabbat, <b>there is</b> a transgression <b>here due to</b> his serving as <b>a non-priest and there is</b> a transgression <b>here due to</b> his desecrating <b>Shabbat. Bar Kappara began to deliberate</b> in a different manner: <b>Shabbat was prohibited to all. When it was permitted it was permitted in the Temple,</b> so that if it was permitted for one to serve in the Temple, it was permitted for him to serve on Shabbat. Therefore, <b>there is</b> a transgression <b>here only</b> for his serving as <b>a non-priest,</b> since if this man were a priest his service would have been permitted. Therefore, he is not liable to receive punishment for desecrating Shabbat.
They disagreed over a similar issue as well, the case of a priest <b>with a blemish who served</b> in the Temple by sacrificing a public offering, which overrides ritual impurity, <b>while</b> he was <b>ritually impure. Rabbi Ḥiyya says: He is liable on two</b> counts, both for serving with a blemish and for being ritually impure. <b>Bar Kappara says: He is liable on only one</b> count, for serving with a blemish. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>two</b> counts. <b>Bar Kappara jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>one</b> count.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya began to deliberate. Ritual impurity was prohibited to all,</b> as it was prohibited for all individuals who are ritually impure to enter into the Temple. <b>When it was permitted in the Temple</b> in circumstances where the entire public was impure, <b>it was permitted for unblemished priests.</b> Therefore, <b>it was permitted</b> only <b>for unblemished priests and not for</b> priests <b>with blemishes.</b> Consequently, if that priest with a blemish served while impure, <b>there is</b> a transgression <b>here due to</b> his status as <b>a blemished</b> priest <b>and there is</b> a transgression <b>here due to ritual impurity. Bar Kappara began to deliberate</b> in a different manner: <b>Ritual impurity was prohibited to all. When it was permitted in the Temple, it was permitted</b> for all. Therefore, the only problem was that this priest was blemished, and so <b>there is</b> a transgression <b>here only due to</b> his status as <b>a blemished</b> priest.
They disagreed over a similar issue as well. This dispute is with regard to <b>a non-priest who ate a</b> bird sin-offering that was killed by <b>pinching</b> the back of its neck. It is permitted for priests to consume such an offering, but it is prohibited to consume any other bird killed in such a manner, since it was not ritually slaughtered. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says: He is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>on two</b> counts, both for being a non-priest who ate a priestly offering and for eating something that was not properly slaughtered. <b>Bar Kappara says: He is liable on only one</b> count. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>two</b> counts. <b>Bar Kappara jumped up and swore:</b> I swear <b>by the Temple service</b> that <b>this I heard from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: He is liable on <b>one</b> count.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya began to deliberate. An unslaughtered animal carcass was prohibited to all. When it was permitted in the Temple, it was permitted to priests</b> alone. Since <b>it was permitted to priests and not to non-priests, there is</b> a transgression <b>here due to</b> his <b>status as a non-priest</b> who ate of the sin-offering <b>and there is a</b> transgression <b>here due to</b> eating an animal killed by <b>pinching. Bar Kappara began to deliberate: An unslaughtered animal carcass was prohibited to all. When it was permitted in the Temple, it was permitted</b> to all. Therefore <b>there is</b> a transgression <b>here only for being a non-priest,</b> since if he were a priest there would be no prohibition at all.

Daf 33a

The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara suggests that they disagree with regard to the issue of <b>a more inclusive prohibition, and</b> this dispute pertains to the status of a more inclusive prohibition specifically <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Ḥiyya holds that Rabbi Yosei</b> is of the opinion that <b>in</b> the case of <b>a more inclusive prohibition, one is liable on two</b> counts. <b>Bar Kappara holds</b> that Rabbi Yosei is of the opinion that <b>one is liable only on one</b> count.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what more inclusive prohibition is there here</b> in these cases? <b>Granted,</b> in the case of <b>a non-priest</b> who served in the Temple on Shabbat, <b>initially he was permitted to perform labor</b> every day <b>and was prohibited from</b> engaging in <b>the</b> Temple <b>service.</b> When <b>Shabbat came, since he is</b> now <b>prohibited from</b> engaging in <b>prohibited labor</b> in all contexts due to Shabbat, <b>he is also prohibited from</b> engaging in labors related to the Temple <b>service</b> due to Shabbat. Indeed, the additional prohibition of Shabbat was added to the previously existing prohibition against performing service in the Temple. This is a more inclusive prohibition since it also includes prohibited labor outside of the Temple.
The same is true with regard to <b>a blemished priest</b> who served in the Temple while ritually impure: <b>Initially,</b> prior to his becoming ritually impure, <b>he was allowed to eat</b> from the consecrated animals <b>but was prohibited from</b> performing <b>the</b> Temple <b>service,</b> like all blemished priests. When <b>he was rendered ritually impure, since he is</b> now <b>prohibited from eating</b> of the consecrated items, <b>he is also prohibited from</b> performing the Temple <b>service</b> due to that same ritual impurity. There is, then, a more inclusive prohibition here. <b>However,</b> with regard to the case of a bird that was killed by <b>pinching, you find</b> that the prohibition against the eating of consecrated items by a non-priest and the prohibition against eating an unslaughtered animal carcass take effect <b>simultaneously. You do not,</b> however, <b>find a more inclusive prohibition</b> here as there was no original prohibition that took effect beforehand. Instead, this is a case of two prohibitions that take effect simultaneously.
<b>Rather,</b> the previous explanation is rejected and the Gemara suggests instead that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> an additional <b>prohibition</b> that takes effect <b>simultaneously, and</b> this dispute pertains to the status of these prohibitions specifically <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Ḥiyya holds that Rabbi Yosei</b> is of the opinion that <b>one is liable on two</b> counts in cases of <b>prohibitions</b> that take effect <b>simultaneously. And bar Kappara holds</b> that Rabbi Yosei is of the opinion that <b>one is liable only on a single</b> count.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>But here,</b> in the first two instances, <b>what</b> case of <b>simultaneous prohibitions is there here?</b> In the two previous cases the prohibitions took effect one after the other, and not simultaneously. The Gemara answers that these cases can also be interpreted as occurring simultaneously as follows: With regard to <b>the non-priest who served on Shabbat, this would be in a case where</b> a minor <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> signaling adulthood <b>on Shabbat.</b> Before that point he was considered a minor and therefore not liable for his actions. Therefore, <b>this is</b> a case where the prohibition against serving as <b>a non-priest and</b> the prohibition against violating <b>Shabbat</b> took effect <b>together.</b>
With regard to the case of <b>one who was blemished,</b> this can be explained <b>as well:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> a minor <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs and was</b> immediately <b>rendered ritually impure. This is</b> a case where the prohibition with regard to <b>a blemished</b> priest <b>and</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>ritual impurity</b> took effect <b>together. Alternatively,</b> it could be a case <b>where he cut</b> off <b>his finger with a ritually impure knife.</b> Here, the cut and removal of his finger rendered him simultaneously blemished and ritually impure.
Following this clarification of the dispute, the matter is now considered from a different angle: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> the dispute between his version of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s ruling and that of bar Kappara can be explained as follows: <b>When Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya, he taught him <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> and Rabbi Yosei holds that there are cases where two prohibitions can both take effect. And <b>when</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught bar Kappara,</b> he did so <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> who holds that a new prohibition can never take effect where another prohibition already exists. Therefore, Rabbi Ḥiyya could understand why bar Kappara insisted on his opinion. Rabbi Ḥiyya thought that bar Kappara was in fact relating an accurate statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, as Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was relating to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Ḥiyya assumed that bar Kappara did not understand that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement was not in accordance with Rabbi Yosei’s opinion. <b>According to bar Kappara, however, was Rabbi Ḥiyya then telling a falsehood?</b> How would bar Kappara relate to Rabbi Ḥiyya’s oath? Did he think that Rabbi Ḥiyya would swear that he heard words from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi that were never said?
<b>Rather,</b> this must be explained differently: Rabbi Ḥiyya and bar Kappara <b>disagree</b> with regard to cases where two <b>prohibitions</b> take effect <b>simultaneously, and</b> this dispute pertains to the status of these prohibition specifically <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> It could be suggested that when the two prohibitions take effect simultaneously, Rabbi Shimon would concede that they both take effect. However, this explanation raises a difficulty as well: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> it is clear why <b>he was swearing.</b> He did so in order <b>to exclude</b> the understanding of <b>Rabbi Shimon’s</b> opinion that was based on <b>his presumed</b> opinion. As it was known that Rabbi Shimon holds that a new prohibition cannot take effect where another prohibition exists; this is the default understanding of his opinion. Therefore, it was incumbent upon Rabbi Ḥiyya to take an oath in order to emphasize that despite Rabbi Shimon’s general opinion, in cases where the prohibitions take effect simultaneously, he would concede that both prohibitions can take effect. <b>However, according to bar Kappara, why was it necessary to swear?</b> It would have sufficed for him simply to make his statement, as it concurs with the default understanding of Rabbi Shimon’s opinion. The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
One can raise a difficulty with this explanation from a different angle as well: <b>Granted, according to bar Kappara, when Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught him,</b> he taught him <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that two prohibitions cannot take effect even in cases when they occur simultaneously, and <b>when he taught</b> the ruling <b>to Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> it was <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Accordingly, Rabbi Ḥiyya did in fact swear that he heard that one is liable only on one count, but he wrongly understood that this was Rabbi Shimon’s opinion. <b>However, according to Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> who holds that Rabbi Shimon concedes that in cases where the prohibitions take effect simultaneously one is liable for both, was <b>bar Kappara lying?</b> His statement would accord neither with Rabbi Shimon nor with Rabbi Yosei.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that this is what transpired: <b>When Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught him,</b> bar Kappara, <b>he taught him two</b> cases involving <b>exemptions,</b> i.e., the cases of a non-priest who served in the Temple on Shabbat and that of the blemished priest who served while ritually impure. Both of these are cases of more inclusive prohibitions, and he was informing bar Kappara that Rabbi Shimon holds them liable on only one count, because Rabbi Shimon holds that a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition already exists only if the prohibitions take effect simultaneously, but not in cases of more inclusive prohibitions.

Daf 33b

<b>And he taught him</b> the ruling with regard to <b>a more inclusive prohibition,</b> that in such cases there is an exemption, <b>and</b> this ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. And bar Kappara</b> then <b>saw</b> the case of <b>a non-priest who ate</b> a bird killed by <b>pinching, and since it was similar</b> to the previous cases, <b>he mixed them together.</b> Then, sometime later, it seemed to him as though he had in truth heard all of these cases together from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>but</b> when <b>he examined this</b> last case, <b>he found</b> that it could exist <b>only</b> if the events occurred <b>simultaneously.</b>
<b>And he concluded</b> that <b>since</b> the case of a non-priest eating a bird killed by pinching can occur only in a scenario where the prohibitions take effect <b>simultaneously,</b> the other cases are instances of <b>simultaneous</b> prohibitions <b>as well. And</b> similarly, <b>since</b> he was taught <b>to exempt</b> one individual from a second prohibition in <b>those cases, these cases</b> were taught <b>to exempt</b> one individual from a second prohibition <b>as well.</b> Therefore, according to Rabbi Ḥiyya, bar Kappara did not knowingly speak falsely. Rather, he heard certain matters from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and then mistakenly merged with them other matters. As a result, he confused the issue.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of bar Kappara from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a non-priest who served on Shabbat and</b> the case of <b>a blemished priest who served while ritually impure, there is</b> liability <b>here, due to</b> the prohibition against serving as <b>a non-priest; and due to</b> the prohibition against desecrating <b>Shabbat; and due to</b> the prohibition against serving as <b>a blemished priest; and due to</b> the prohibition against serving after contracting <b>ritual impurity.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Shimon says: There is</b> liability <b>here only due to</b> the prohibition against serving as <b>a non-priest and due to</b> the prohibition against serving as <b>a blemished priest.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And yet</b> the case of a non-priest who ate a bird killed by <b>pinching was left out</b> and not mentioned among the cases subject to this dispute.
The Gemara asks: <b>According to whom was this left out?</b> That is, according to the opinion of which <i>tanna</i> would this question arise? <b>If we say</b> that this was left out <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> it is difficult. <b>Now</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> holds, even <b>in</b> cases of <b>a more inclusive prohibition, that one is liable on two</b> counts, as was stated with regard to a non-priest who served on Shabbat, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that in the case <b>where the</b> additional <b>prohibition</b> takes effect <b>simultaneously</b> one would be liable on two counts? <b>Rather, is it not according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> that this case was left out, as Rabbi Shimon would concede that in this case one is liable on two counts? Therefore, Rabbi Shimon <b>exempts</b> one from liability for the second prohibition in cases of <b>more inclusive prohibitions, but in</b> cases of <b>simultaneous prohibitions</b> he would <b>deem</b> one <b>liable</b> on two counts. The Gemara summarizes: <b>The refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of bar Kappara is</b> indeed <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and his statements are rejected.
The Gemara raises a question with regard to one of the laws mentioned above. The <i>baraita</i> mentioned the case of <b>a non-priest who served on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>In what</b> form of service did he perform in the Temple? <b>If</b> this is referring to a case where a non-priest performed <b>the slaughtering</b> of the sacrificial animal, there would be no prohibition, as the <b>slaughtering by a non-priest is valid. And if</b> it is referring to <b>receiving</b> the blood <b>and carrying</b> the blood to the altar, while this is a case where he would be liable as a non-priest performing the service of a priest, insofar as Shabbat is concerned <b>this is a case only of moving,</b> and it does not entail a violation of any prohibited labor.
<b>If</b> he served <b>by burning</b> the sacrificial portions on the altar, then this discussion follows the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, <b>but didn’t Rabbi Yosei say</b> that the prohibition against <b>kindling on Shabbat was</b> singled <b>out</b> to teach that one who lights a fire on Shabbat merely violates <b>a prohibition?</b> This is as opposed to the other prohibited labors, which incur death penalties when violated willfully and entail the bringing of a sin-offering when violated unintentionally. Why, then, would Rabbi Yosei deem one liable for two sin-offerings?
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov said:</b> The service referred to <b>in</b> this case is <b>the slaughtering of the High Priest’s bull</b> on Yom Kippur, <b>and this is in accordance with the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>the slaughtering of the High Priest’s bull is disqualified</b> if performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> for this service is designated specifically for the High Priest alone. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that this is referring to the slaughtering of the High Priest’s bull, then <b>why specifically</b> state <b>a non-priest? The same would hold true even</b> for <b>a common priest as well.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This is referring to one who is as a non-priest in relation to</b> the High Priest and not to an actual non-priest. The Hebrew word <i>zar</i> literally means foreigner, and this type of service is considered foreign to a common priest as well as a non-priest.
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this:</b> The previous rejection that was based on the idea that the act of burning was not a full-fledged prohibited labor is in fact groundless. <b>Is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaching</b> how many <b>sin-offerings</b> would be incurred, <b>or is he teaching</b> how many <b>negative mitzvot</b> are being violated? <b>Rather, he merely</b> enumerates <b>the prohibitions</b> violated by a certain action, without detailing their severities, and therefore the desecration of Shabbat involved in the Temple service can be any Shabbat violation. The Gemara asks: <b>What practical difference does it make</b> how many prohibitions are involved? The Gemara answers: It affects the decision whether or not <b>to bury him among the completely wicked.</b> If he violated two prohibitions, he is considered wicked on two counts and consequently must be buried accordingly.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>two</b> men <b>who betrothed two women, and at the time that they entered the wedding canopy,</b> after the betrothal, the men <b>switched this</b> wife <b>with that</b> wife <b>and that</b> one <b>with this</b> one, <b>then these</b> two men <b>are liable for</b> engaging in forbidden sexual relations with <b>a married woman,</b> since each of them had intercourse with his fellow’s wife. The act of betrothal is sufficient to prohibit a woman to all other men as a married woman. Therefore, when the women were switched, both men transgressed this violation. <b>And if they were brothers,</b> then they are also liable <b>for</b> forbidden sexual relations with <b>a brother’s wife. And if</b> these women <b>were sisters,</b> then they are liable <b>for</b> taking <b>a wife and her sister</b> as well. <b>And if they were menstruating women,</b> they would be liable <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>a menstruating woman</b> as well.
<b>And</b> following these forbidden sexual relations, <b>we separate</b> these women from their husbands <b>for three months, lest they were impregnated</b> by that forbidden act of intercourse. Doing so makes it possible to distinguish a child born of these relations, so that he could be rendered a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>And if they were female minors and unable to bear children, then we immediately return them</b> to their original husbands. <b>And if they were daughters of priests, they are</b> thereby <b>disqualified from eating of <i>teruma</i>.</b> By engaging in illicit sexual acts, they were rendered forbidden to priests and disqualified from eating <i>teruma</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> In the mishna it states: <b>They switched</b> this one with that one. <b>Are we dealing with</b> such <b>wicked individuals</b> that they would intentionally switch their wives? <b>And furthermore,</b> consider <b>that which Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> on this subject: <b>There are sixteen sin-offerings here,</b> four sin-offerings for each of the men and four for each of the women. Yet, <b>if</b> they had acted <b>intentionally would there be an offering?</b> Sacrifices are brought only for unintentional acts. <b>Rav Yehuda said: Teach</b> instead <b>they were switched,</b> which indicates that the switching was not done intentionally; rather, the women were accidentally mixed up.
The Gemara comments: <b>This, too, stands to reason from the fact that the latter clause teaches: If they were female minors and unable to bear children, then we immediately return them. And if</b> this had been done <b>intentionally, would it be permitted</b> to return a woman who had engaged in illicit sexual acts to her husband? The Gemara comments: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult</b> and does not disprove the notion that the act was intentional. Even if the act was intentional, these women would be permitted to return to their husbands. This is because the <b>seduction of a minor girl is</b> considered <b>rape, and</b> after <b>rape</b> a woman <b>is permitted</b> to return <b>to an Israelite</b> husband.
<b>However,</b> this can be derived from a different point <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches: We separate</b> these women from their husbands <b>for three months,</b> as <b>perhaps they</b> became <b>pregnant.</b> From here it can be deduced: <b>Were</b> it to become clear after three months that <b>they are not pregnant, they are permitted</b> to return to their husbands. <b>And if</b> they had acted <b>intentionally, would this be permitted? Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from here</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where <b>they were switched</b> inadvertently? The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <b>conclude from here</b> that this is the case.

Daf 34a

The Gemara asks: According to Rabbi Ḥiyya, who teaches that this case incurs sixteen sin-offerings, <b>who is this <i>tanna</i> who holds</b> that a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition already exists for <b>a more inclusive prohibition, an expanded prohibition, and a simultaneous prohibition?</b> If these men are brothers, the moment that one betrothed a woman, that woman was immediately rendered forbidden to the second brother both as a married woman and as his brother’s wife. When the second brother betrothed her sister, this added the prohibition pertaining to his wife’s sister. This is a more inclusive prohibition because, as a result of this betrothal, the second brother is prohibited from engaging in sexual intercourse not only with his wife’s sister, who is his brother’s wife, but also with all of her other sisters. When this woman becomes a menstruating woman, she is forbidden to her husband as well, which is an expanded prohibition. Consequently, the mishna includes examples of all three types of prohibitions and asserts that they all take effect in this case. Therefore, the Gemara wonders which <i>tanna</i> holds that in each of these cases the prohibition takes effect even where another prohibition exists.
<b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: This is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There is</b> one who performs a single act of <b>eating</b> an olive-bulk of food, <b>and he is liable to bring four sin-offerings and one guilt-offering.</b>
How so? This <i>halakha</i> applies to one who is <b>ritually impure who ate</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> that was <b><i>notar</i> from a consecrated offering,</b> i.e., it remained after the time when it was permitted to eat it, and this occurred <b>on Yom Kippur.</b> One who did this is liable to bring one sin offering for eating consecrated food while impure, one for eating forbidden fat, one for eating <i>notar</i>, and one for eating on Yom Kippur. He is also liable to bring a guilt-offering for misuse of consecrated items. In this case, it was prohibited to eat the fat from the moment the animal was born. When the animal was consecrated, the prohibition against deriving benefit from it took effect on the entire animal, rendering this an expanded prohibition. When the priest became ritually impure and thereby prohibited from partaking of all sanctified foods, a more inclusive prohibition took effect. The moment the fat was rendered <i>notar</i>, it became prohibited to offer it on the altar as well, so that that is another instance of an expanded prohibition. Lastly, on Yom Kippur, an additional, more inclusive prohibition took effect because on Yom Kippur it is prohibited to eat all food, even that which is not consecrated.
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> There is one more sin-offering for which he may be liable. <b>If it was Shabbat and he carried</b> this olive-bulk of food from one domain to another <b>in his mouth, he is liable</b> for carrying out on Shabbat. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Meir: Liability for the sin-offering that you added <b>is not</b> incurred <b>from</b> violation <b>of the</b> same <b>type</b> of prohibition. He is liable for carrying out the food, not for eating it. In this example, the prohibitions of Shabbat and Yom Kippur take effect at the same moment, and therefore this last case would be an instance of simultaneous prohibitions, and Rabbi Meir holds that they take effect as well. Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> demonstrates that Rabbi Meir holds that prohibitions take effect where other prohibitions already exist in all of these instances: More inclusive prohibitions, expanded prohibitions, and simultaneous prohibitions.
The Gemara continues to clarify the opinion of Rabbi Meir: <b>And in accordance with whose opinion is</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir? If</b> you say that <b>it is in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> this is difficult. <b>Didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>say that one who erred with regard to a mitzva is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, i.e., one who unwittingly performed a transgression while intending to perform a mitzva is exempt from punishment? In the case in the mishna as well, the men intended to perform the mitzva of marriage but unwittingly violated a transgression because the wives were switched. Therefore, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, they should be exempt from a sin-offering. <b>Rather,</b> this must be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that even if one mistakenly transgressed while attempting to perform a mitzva, he is still obligated to bring a sin-offering.
<b>If you wish,</b> resolve this differently and <b>say: Actually,</b> this can be explained even <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. When Rabbi Yehoshua says that one who erred with regard to a mitzva is exempt, this applies</b> only <b>to</b> the case of <b>babies</b> who were mixed up in such a way that on Shabbat the <i>mohel</i> mistakenly circumcised a baby whose time had not yet come for circumcision. Since the <i>mohel</i> did not fulfill the mitzva of circumcision, he should be liable for performing prohibited labor on Shabbat. However, Rabbi Yehoshua exempts him from a sin-offering <b>since</b> he is <b>pressed for time.</b> Because circumcision must be performed only on the day specified, he was rushed and anxious to perform the circumcision, and due to this sense of urgency he erred and thought that the proper time was on Shabbat. <b>In this</b> case in the mishna, <b>however,</b> where the mistake involved marriage, <b>since</b> the brothers were <b>not pressed for time</b> Rabbi Yehoshua does <b>not</b> deem the brothers exempt.
The Gemara objects: <b>And yet</b> in the case of eating <b><i>teruma</i>, where one is not pressed for time and</b> nevertheless Rabbi Yehoshua <b>exempts</b> him if the act involved a mitzva, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 72b): If a priest <b>was partaking of <i>teruma</i> and it became known that he was the son of a divorced woman or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> and thereby disqualified from the priesthood and prohibited from eating <i>teruma</i>, <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to pay <b>the</b> value of the <b>principal and</b> an additional <b>fifth,</b> like any non-priest who unwittingly ate <i>teruma</i>. However, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him because at the time of consumption he intended to perform a mitzva, for he thought that he was a priest eating of the <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>But wasn’t it stated with regard to</b> that mishna: <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: Here we are dealing with</b> leavened <b><i>teruma</i></b> that was being eaten by the priest <b>on the eve of Passover, for he is pressed for time.</b> In this case, he would rush to eat it so that it would not have to be burned.
The Gemara offers a different attribution of the mishna: <b>And if you wish, say</b> a different explanation: The mishna is not according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who deems one liable in cases of more inclusive prohibitions and expanded prohibitions. Rather, the mishna is referring only to cases <b>of simultaneous prohibitions, and in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> the prohibitions in the mishna, <b>you can find that they</b> take effect simultaneously in the case <b>where</b> the men <b>appointed</b> a single <b>agent</b> to betroth the women for them, <b>and</b> the women <b>appointed an agent</b> to accept the betrothals for them, <b>and</b> one <b>agent encounters</b> the other <b>agent.</b> In this scenario, all the men become betrothed to all the women the moment that the agents meet, and the prohibitions all take effect simultaneously. <b>However,</b> with regard to the prohibition pertaining to <b>menstruating women, how can you find</b> the case where both women become menstruating women at the exact time of betrothal?
<b>Rav Amram said that Rav said:</b> This is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the women <b>continuously discharge</b> menstrual blood <b>from within the thirteenth</b> year of the brothers <b>until after</b> they reached the age of <b>thirteen,</b> in order <b>to deem</b> the men <b>liable</b> for the prohibition pertaining to a menstruating woman. At the moment that the boys reached maturity and the betrothals went into effect, the sisters were forbidden as menstruating women. And the women were continuously discharging blood <b>from within the twelfth</b> year of the women <b>until after</b> the age of <b>twelve, in order to deem</b> the women <b>liable</b> for engaging in relations as a menstruating woman. Therefore, if this took place in such a way that on the exact day when the men reached maturity, i.e., their thirteenth birthday, the women reached maturity, i.e., their twelfth birthday, and at that moment they were menstruating, then all of the prohibitions would take effect simultaneously and they would be liable on all counts, according to Rabbi Shimon as well.
§ The mishna taught that <b>we separate</b> these women from their husbands for three months, as perhaps they became pregnant. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> it known that a virgin <b>woman does not become pregnant from her first sexual act? Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> This is referring to a situation <b>where they engaged in intercourse and then repeated</b> the act, so that it is possible that the women were impregnated during the second act of intercourse. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if this is so, how can one explain <b>that which Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: Here, then, are sixteen sin-offerings?</b> If there were indeed two acts of intercourse, then <b>there</b> should <b>be thirty-two</b> sin-offerings, since each prohibition was violated twice.
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning, that</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya’s enumeration of sin-offerings applies to all acts of intercourse, then <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who deems one liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every thrusting</b> movement during a single act of intercourse, there would <b>be many</b> prohibitions that were violated. This would greatly multiply the number of sin-offerings required. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that Rabbi Ḥiyya, with regard to Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, <b>is enumerating</b> only <b>the first thrusting</b> movement <b>in the intercourse. And so too,</b> with regard to the Rabbis’ opinion, <b>he is enumerating</b> only <b>the first act of intercourse.</b> If there were two acts of intercourse, however, the number of sin-offerings would be doubled.
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman:</b>

Daf 34b

<b>But didn’t Tamar become pregnant from the first act of intercourse,</b> despite the fact that she was a virgin at the time of her sexual act with Judah? Rav Naḥman <b>said: Tamar broke</b> her hymen <b>with her finger</b> prior to intercourse, and it is due to this that she became pregnant from the first act of intercourse, <b>as Rabbi Yitzḥak said: All of those</b> women <b>from the household of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>who break</b> their hymens <b>are named Tamar</b> by nickname. <b>And why are they named Tamar?</b> They are called this <b>on account of Tamar, who broke</b> her hymen <b>with her finger.</b> The Gemara wonders about the proof from Tamar itself: <b>But weren’t there Er and Onan,</b> her previous husbands, who presumably engaged in sexual intercourse with her? The Gemara responds: <b>Er and Onan engaged in sexual intercourse in an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse, and therefore she was still a virgin.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: After a woman gives birth, her husband <b>penetrates inside and spills</b> his semen <b>outside</b> for <b>the entire twenty-four months</b> during which the baby is breastfeeding, so that his wife not become pregnant, as that would terminate her milk production and the child might die. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. They said to him: These</b> acts <b>are nothing other</b> than acts <b>similar to those of Er and Onan,</b> which are prohibited. Regardless, it can be deduced from here that Er and Onan engaged in normative sexual intercourse with Tamar, only they did not fully complete the sexual act.
The Gemara answers: The <i>Tosefta</i> actually means that what they did was <b>similar to the act of Er and Onan</b> in some ways, but <b>not similar to the act of Er and Onan</b> in other ways. The Gemara elaborates: <b>It was similar to the act of Er and Onan</b> in that there was a spilling of semen, <b>as it is written: “And it came to pass when he had intercourse with his brother’s wife, that he spilled it on the ground”</b> (Genesis 38:9). Yet it was <b>not similar to the act of Er and Onan, as there</b> Er and Onan engaged in sexual intercourse in <b>an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse, <b>while here</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to sexual intercourse <b>in a typical manner.</b>
The Gemara continues to clarify what took place: <b>Granted, Onan</b> engaged in unnatural sexual intercourse with her, <b>as it is written with regard to his</b> act: <b>“That he spilled it on the ground”</b> (Genesis 38:9). <b>However, from where do we</b> derive that <b>Er</b> engaged in unnatural sexual intercourse with her? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: As it is written</b> with regard to Onan: <b>“And He slew him also”</b> (Genesis 38:10). This indicates that <b>he, too, died the same death</b> for performing the same transgression as his brother. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Onan</b> engaged in anal intercourse because he did not want Tamar to give birth <b>as</b> “he knew that <b>the seed would not be his”</b> (Genesis 38:9). <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>Er, what is the reason he acted</b> in <b>this</b> way? The Gemara responds: He did so in order <b>that she not become pregnant and become less beautiful</b> as a result of her pregnancy.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “And the woman, <b>with whom</b> a man shall lie giving seed, they shall both bathe themselves in water, and be unclean until the evening” (Leviticus 15:18). The extra term <b>“with whom”</b> comes <b>to exclude a bride</b> who does not become ritually impure; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: It excludes</b> the case of sexual intercourse performed <b>in an atypical manner. Hon, son of Rav Naḥman, said to Rav Naḥman: Shall we say that Rabbi Yehuda holds: The Torah spared a bride’s adornments,</b> including her make-up, and therefore exempted her from submersion in water, as that might cause them ruin? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> That is not the reason. Rather, <b>it is because a woman does not become pregnant from the first act of intercourse.</b> Therefore, that act of intercourse would not cause ritual impurity, as it is not considered intercourse that can result in the implanting of seed.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree? The Rabbis hold</b> that the phrase <b>“giving seed” excludes the initial stage of intercourse,</b> during which there is no emission of semen. And the extra phrase <b>“with whom” excludes intercourse that is performed in an atypical way. Rabbi Yehuda,</b> on the other hand, <b>holds that</b> the exclusion of both <b>atypical</b> sexual intercourse <b>and the initial stage of intercourse were derived from</b> the phrase <b>“giving seed,”</b> as neither of these are sexual acts that might bring about the birth of a seed, i.e., a child. The phrase <b>“with whom”</b> then <b>excludes a bride.</b>
On the topic of intercourse that cannot result in conception, the Gemara relates the following: <b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Any</b> woman who <b>waits after her husband</b> has died or divorced her for <b>ten years</b> without intercourse <b>and is then married can no longer bear children. Rav Naḥman said: They taught</b> this principle <b>only</b> with regard to cases <b>where she did not intend to get married</b> at a later time, <b>but</b> if <b>she intended to get married</b> at some point, <b>she can become pregnant</b> later on. <b>Rava said to</b> his wife, the <b>daughter of Rav Ḥisda: The Sages are gossiping about you.</b> From the time she was widowed from her first husband until the time that she was married to Rava, more than ten years passed, yet she bore him children. It seemed as though she had engaged in intercourse in the meantime. <b>She said to him: My mind was on you.</b> Indeed, it is told that already as a young girl she prophesized that she would marry Rava.
The Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> woman <b>who came before Rav Yosef said to him: My teacher, I waited after my husband’s</b> death for <b>ten years, and</b> nevertheless <b>I gave birth. He said to her: My daughter, do not cast aspersions on the statement of the Sages. She said to him</b> in confession: <b>I had sexual intercourse with a gentile</b> during those ten years.
§ <b>Shmuel said: And all of those</b> women who had sexual intercourse, and there is therefore a concern that they might be pregnant, <b>must wait three months</b> before marrying so as to differentiate between a child born from the previous intercourse and a child born from this marriage, <b>except for a female convert</b> who is a minor <b>and a female released slave who is a minor.</b> Although it is possible that they had sexual intercourse, they cannot become pregnant in any case. <b>However, a female Israelite who was a minor</b> and had intercourse <b>must wait three months</b> like all other women.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> situation is this statement referring? <b>If it is</b> referring to a minor who was released from her marriage <b>by refusal,</b> as a minor girl who was married to a man by her mother or brothers may refuse to remain married to her husband until reaching majority, <b>but didn’t Shmuel say that she is not required</b> to wait three months? <b>And if</b> it is referring to a woman who received <b>a bill of divorce</b> as a minor, <b>didn’t Shmuel</b> already <b>state</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>one time?</b> Why would he repeat this ruling, <b>as Shmuel said: A female minor who refused</b> her husband <b>need not wait three months</b> before her second marriage, but if <b>he gave her a bill of divorce, she must wait three months,</b> so as not to make a distinction between an adult divorcée and a minor divorcée. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that this is referring to a female minor who was involved in <b>licentious sexual intercourse.</b>

Daf 35a

<b>And,</b> although there is no possibility for her to become pregnant, <b>the Sages issued</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> requiring the three month waiting period <b>for a female minor due to</b> this requirement for <b>a female adult</b> who engaged in promiscuous sexual acts.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we issue a decree</b> with regard to <b>a female minor due to</b> the ruling for <b>a female adult? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>If they were female minors who could not bear children, we return them immediately</b> to their husbands? This indicates that there is no concern for pregnancy, and the Sages did not issue a decree in this case. <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said: This was a provisional edict</b> issued in exigent circumstances, and therefore one cannot extrapolate from the case in the mishna to other situations. The Gemara wonders: Can one assume <b>by inference that there was</b> such an occurrence? It would seem from the mishna that this was merely a possibility and not an actual occurrence, for if it actually happened it would have been appropriate for the mishna to relate the actual case. <b>Rather,</b> the ruling in the mishna is <b>like a provisional edict in that switching</b> of wives, such as described in the mishna, <b>is uncommon,</b> and in cases that are not common, the Sages do not issue a decree. Therefore, in the case of the mishna, the female minors were not required to wait.
<b>Some say another version</b> of what was taught: <b>Shmuel said: All</b> women <b>must wait three months, except for a female convert</b> who is an adult <b>and a freed maidservant who is an adult;</b> these women need not wait. <b>However, an Israelite female minor need not wait three months</b> in any case. The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what</b> situation is this statement referring? <b>If</b> it is referring to a female minor released from her marriage <b>by refusal,</b> it would be superfluous, <b>as didn’t Shmuel</b> already <b>state this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>one time?</b> If it is referring to a woman released <b>by a bill of divorce,</b> but <b>didn’t Shmuel say that</b> in that case <b>she is required</b> to wait, <b>as Shmuel said:</b> If <b>she refused him she need not wait three months,</b> but <b>if he gave her a bill of divorce, she must wait three months? Rather,</b> this is referring to cases of <b>promiscuous sexual intercourse, and</b> an occurrence of <b>promiscuous sexual intercourse with female minors is uncommon,</b> and the Sages did not issue rabbinic decrees in uncommon instances.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let</b> the Sages <b>issue a decree</b> requiring <b>a female convert and a released maidservant</b> to wait three months, <b>as</b> at the time that one was a gentile and the other a maidservant, <b>promiscuous sexual intercourse was common for them.</b> The Gemara responds: Shmuel <b>stated</b> his <i>halakhic</i> ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>the female convert; and the captured woman,</b> who is suspected of having been raped during her imprisonment; <b>and the maidservant, who were redeemed or who were converted or who were released, must wait three months</b> prior to marriage. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei allows</b> them <b>to be betrothed and married immediately. Rabba said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei? He holds that a woman who engages in promiscuous sexual intercourse uses</b> a contraceptive <b>resorbent</b> that she places at the opening of her womb <b>so as not to become impregnated.</b> Therefore, there is no concern that she might be pregnant.
<b>Abaye said to him: Granted, a female convert</b> does this. <b>Since she is determined to convert, she guards herself</b> so as not to be impregnated while still a gentile <b>in order to distinguish between children conceived in sanctity,</b> i.e., after her conversion, <b>and children conceived out of sanctity. A captured woman and a maidservant</b> would <b>also</b> be cautious because <b>they hear from their masters</b> that they are about to be redeemed or that they are about to be released, <b>and they guard themselves</b> so as not to be impregnated. <b>However,</b> with regard to a maidservant who <b>is released due to</b> damage caused her by her masters, i.e., loss of one of her extremities such as <b>a tooth or an eye, how can you find</b> a case where there is no concern for her becoming impregnated? Since she could not have known in advance that she would be released, she would have had no reason to be careful not to become pregnant.
<b>And if you would say</b> that in <b>any</b> case <b>where</b> the situation occurs <b>by itself,</b> as in the case where a woman was unaware of her pending release, <b>Rabbi Yosei concedes</b> that she must indeed wait, this is difficult. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A woman who was raped and a woman who was seduced must wait three months</b> as perhaps she became pregnant; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei permits her to be betrothed and to be married immediately.</b> Clearly, a woman who was raped could not have prepared herself ahead of time so as not to become pregnant.
<b>Rather, Abaye said: A woman who engages in promiscuous sexual intercourse turns over</b> following intercourse, trying to prevent the absorption of the semen, so as <b>not to become pregnant.</b> Maidservants act in a similar manner. The Gemara asks: If indeed she tries not to become pregnant, how then would <b>the other</b> opinion, that of Rabbi Yehuda, explain why she must wait three months? The Gemara responds: <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps she did not turn over well enough</b> and therefore became pregnant.
§ With regard to the case of two betrothed women who were switched at the time they entered the wedding canopy, the mishna states: <b>And if they were daughters of priests,</b> they are disqualified from partaking in <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara asks: Does this indicate that with regard to the <b>daughters of priests, yes,</b> they are disqualified from partaking in <i>teruma</i>, but with regard to <b>the daughter of an Israelite, no,</b> she would not be disqualified? It would seem that an Israelite woman married to a priest should most certainly be disqualified from eating of her husband’s <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: Rather, <b>say: If they were the wives of priests</b> then they are disqualified. The Gemara questions this formulation: Does this indicate that with regard to the <b>wives of priests, yes,</b> they are disqualified, but with regard to the <b>wives of Israelites, no,</b> they are not disqualified, and if their husbands died, they would be suitable for marriage to the priests?
The Gemara objects to this: <b>But didn’t Rav Amram say: Rav Sheshet said this matter to us, and he lit our eyes</b> by showing us that this ruling is indicated <b>from what was</b> stated in <b>the mishna</b> (<i>Yevamot</i> 53b). He said: <b>The wife of an Israelite who was raped, even though she is permitted to</b> return to <b>her husband, she is</b> nevertheless <b>disqualified from the priesthood.</b> If her husband later dies, she may not marry a priest, for although she is permitted to her husband the rape disqualified her for matters of priesthood.
<b>Rava</b> resolved this and <b>said: This is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying</b> in the mishna: <b>If they were daughters of priests</b> who <b>were married to an Israelite, they are disqualified from the <i>teruma</i> that is from the household of their fathers,</b> so that if their husbands die while they are childless, they may not go back to eat of the <i>teruma</i> in the house of their fathers. While other childless daughters of priests are again qualified to eat of the <i>teruma</i> the moment they leave their Israelite husbands, these women were disqualified by their act of forbidden sexual intercourse.

Daf 35b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When a man who has a brother dies childless, his widow [<i>yevama</i>] and one of his brothers [<i>yavam</i>] may perform a ritual through which she is freed of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>]. It is then considered, with regard to forbidden relationships, as though they had been married and divorced. Therefore, he is forbidden to her relatives, and she to his. However, with regard to <b>one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i> and</b> then <b>she is found</b> to have been <b>pregnant</b> at the time of the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>and she gave birth, in the event that the offspring is viable,</b> the deceased husband has been survived by offspring and so there was never any levirate bond; consequently, the <i>ḥalitza</i> that was performed was entirely unnecessary and a meaningless act. As such, <b>he</b> remains <b>permitted to her relatives and she</b> remains <b>permitted to his relatives.</b> Furthermore, since the <i>ḥalitza</i> was meaningless, she is not afforded the status of a <i>ḥalutza</i>, i.e., a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, a status akin to that of a divorcée. Therefore, the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>does not disqualify her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b>
If <b>the offspring is not viable,</b> then it emerges that the <i>ḥalitza</i> was indeed necessary. Therefore, <b>he is forbidden</b> to engage in relations <b>with her relatives and she is forbidden</b> to engage in relations <b>with his relatives,</b> as though they had been married and divorced, <b>and</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood,</b> as she is afforded the status of a <i>ḥalutza</i>.
With regard to <b>one who consummates</b> the levirate marriage with <b>his <i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., he had intercourse with her under the assumption that there is a levirate bond and so there is a mitzva to do so, <b>and</b> then <b>she is found to</b> have been <b>pregnant</b> at the time of the intercourse <b>and she gave birth, in the event that the offspring is viable</b> the deceased brother has been survived by offspring and it is evident that there was never any levirate bond. In that case, the relations they had, rather than being a mitzva, were a violation of the prohibition against engaging in relations with one’s brother’s wife. Therefore, the <i>yavam</i> <b>must send</b> her <b>out,</b> i.e., they must separate, as she is forbidden to him as his brother’s wife, <b>and</b> to atone for the forbidden relations that they had, <b>they are</b> each <b>obligated</b> to bring a sin-<b>offering,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> for all who inadvertently transgress a prohibition that, when performed intentionally, is punishable by <i>karet</i>.
<b>And if the offspring is not viable,</b> and therefore there was in fact a levirate bond, <b>he may maintain</b> her as his wife since his intercourse with her was a valid consummation of levirate marriage.
If they consummated the levirate marriage and seven months later she gave birth, there is <b>uncertainty whether</b> the child <b>is nine</b> months <b>old,</b> i.e., counting from conception, and is the offspring <b>of the first</b> husband, and as such there was no levirate bond, or <b>whether</b> the child is only <b>seven</b> months <b>old</b> and is the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband, i.e., the <i>yavam</i>, and not of the deceased, in which case there was a levirate bond. In that case, due to the possibility that she is forbidden to him as his brother’s wife, <b>he must send</b> her <b>out.</b> However, the lineage of <b>the child is unflawed,</b> since regardless of whether it was born of the first or second husband, there was no transgression involved in its conception. Furthermore, to atone for the possibility that they had forbidden relations <b>they are</b> both <b>obligated to bring a guilt-</b>offering for <b>uncertainty,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> for anyone who is uncertain whether they inadvertently transgressed a prohibition that would require one to bring a sin-offering.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> An amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to <b>one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with a pregnant woman and she</b> later <b>miscarried.</b> Since she miscarried, she was certainly bound to the <i>yavam</i> by a levirate bond and may not marry anyone else; rather, she is obligated to consummate the levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. The question is whether the <i>ḥalitza</i> that was performed while she was still pregnant is effective in releasing her from the levirate bond. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: She does not require</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers. Reish Lakish said: She requires</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>she does not require</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers</b> because he holds: <b><i>Ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman</b> who later miscarries <b>is considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> in order to release her from the levirate bond. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>intercourse with a pregnant woman</b> who later miscarries <b>is considered</b> a valid consummation of levirate marriage through <b>intercourse,</b> such that she and the <i>yavam</i> are considered to be married. <b>And Reish Lakish said she requires</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers</b> because he holds: <b><i>Ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, and intercourse with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> a valid consummation of levirate marriage through <b>intercourse.</b> Therefore, after she miscarries, another <i>ḥalitza</i> must be performed in order to release her from the levirate bond.
<b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? If you wish, say</b> that they disagree over the interpretation of <b>a verse. And if you wish, say</b> that they disagree on a point of <b>logical reasoning.</b>
<b>If you wish, say</b> that that they disagree over a point of <b>logical reasoning</b> in that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan holds: If Elijah</b> the prophet <b>were to come</b> at the moment of the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>and say that this</b> woman <b>who is pregnant will miscarry, is she not eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage,</b> even though she is currently pregnant, since her husband died and will not be survived by offspring? <b>Now, too,</b> even though when the <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage is performed it is not known whether or not she will miscarry, <b>the matter will be revealed retroactively,</b> i.e., if she ultimately miscarries then it is apparent the <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage was always necessary and is therefore valid.
<b>And Reish Lakish said: We do not say</b> that <b>the matter will be revealed retroactively</b> in order to validate the levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>. Since at the time of the levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i> it was still unknown whether she would miscarry, the act is considered premature and ineffective.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that they disagree over the interpretation of <b>a verse</b> in that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan holds: The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: “If brothers dwell together, and one of them dies, <b>and he has no child”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), i.e., the obligation to consummate a levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i> applies whenever a husband dies and is not survived by offspring. <b>And this</b> man, whose wife is currently pregnant, <b>does not have</b> any children who will survive him. Therefore, there is an obligation to consummate a levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and if done, they will be effective. <b>And Reish Lakish holds:</b> The phrase <b>“and he has no [<i>ein</i>] child”</b> is expounded by the Sages to teach that one should <b>inspect [<i>ayein</i>] him</b> carefully to determine if he is survived by offspring of any form, and currently he is in fact survived by the fetus. Therefore, there is currently no obligation to consummate a levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and consequently, even if done, they are ineffective.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> from the mishna: If <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed with a pregnant woman, and <b>the offspring is not viable,</b> then <b>he is forbidden to her relatives and she is forbidden to his relatives, and</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her from the priesthood.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan explains the challenge: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say</b> that <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman</b> who later miscarries <b>is considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, it is due to that</b> reason that the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her</b> from the priesthood. <b>However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>as you say that <i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, why</b> should the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualify her from the priesthood?</b> According to your opinion, shouldn’t the <i>ḥalitza</i> be entirely disregarded?
Reish Lakish <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: Indeed, by Torah law the <i>ḥalitza</i> is to be entirely disregarded. The mishna’s ruling that she is disqualified from the priesthood is <b>by rabbinic</b> decree <b>and is merely a stringency</b> lest people not realize that she was pregnant and think that a <i>ḥalutza</i> is permitted to marry a priest.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> an alternate version of the dispute: <b>Reish Lakish raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the mishna: If <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed with a pregnant woman and <b>the offspring is not viable,</b> then <b>he is forbidden to her relatives and she is forbidden to his relatives, and</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her from the priesthood.</b> Reish Lakish explains the challenge: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say that <i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, this is</b> consistent with <b>that which is taught</b> in the mishna: The <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her from the priesthood,</b> which should be understood <b>as</b> a rabbinic <b>stringency, and</b> it is understandable that the mishna <b>does not teach: She does not require</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers,</b> because according to my opinion, once she miscarries, she does indeed require another <i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers.
<b>However, according to your</b> opinion that <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with a pregnant woman is an effective <i>ḥalitza</i>, the mishna <b>should have</b> taught the full extent of her permissible status, i.e., that <b>she does not</b> even <b>require</b> another <b><i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers</b> after she miscarries because the original <i>ḥalitza</i> was effective. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>Yes, it is indeed so</b> that she does not require another <i>ḥalitza</i> from the brothers, <b>but since the first clause taught:</b> The <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>does not disqualify her</b> from the priesthood, therefore <b>the latter clause taught:</b> The <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>disqualifies her</b> from the priesthood, in order to directly contrast with the first clause rather than teach the greater novelty.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> from the mishna: If a <i>yavam</i> had intercourse with his <i>yevama</i>, who was pregnant, and <b>the offspring is not viable,</b> and therefore she was bound by a levirate bond, <b>he may maintain</b> her as his wife. Rabbi Yoḥanan explains the challenge: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say <i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman is considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, and</b> similarly, <b>intercourse with a pregnant woman is considered</b> a valid consummation of levirate marriage through <b>intercourse,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that the mishna <b>teaches: He may maintain</b> her as his wife, because the levirate marriage was indeed valid.
<b>However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>as you said</b> that <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> effective <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, and intercourse with a pregnant woman is not considered</b> a valid consummation of levirate marriage through <b>intercourse,</b> the mishna <b>should have</b> taught that <b>he should proceed to engage in intercourse</b> with her again in order to consummate the levirate marriage <b>and</b> only then <b>may he maintain</b> her as his wife. Reish Lakish responded: <b>What is</b> the intention of the mishna when it teaches: <b>He may maintain</b> her as his wife? Perforce it means that <b>he should proceed to engage in intercourse</b> again with her <b>and</b> then <b>he may maintain</b> her as his wife, <b>as</b> any other way <b>is insufficient</b> to release her from the levirate bond. Therefore, it is unnecessary for the mishna to teach this explicitly.
