<b>And</b> if <b>afterward the wife</b> of the second brother <b>died after him,</b> i.e., after her husband had already died, which restored the original situation in which the bachelor was bound by a levirate bond only to the widow of the first brother, then in such a case <b>that <i>yevama</i>,</b> the widow of the first brother, <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
Rav Hamnuna explains the challenge from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But why</b> may she not consummate the levirate marriage? <b>She should be like a <i>yevama</i> who was</b> initially <b>permitted</b> to her <i>yavam</i>, <b>and</b> then <b>became forbidden</b> to him, <b>and then reverted</b> to her original status <b>and was permitted, and so</b> in this case <b>she should</b> also <b>revert to her original permitted status</b> with regard to levirate marriage and be permitted to consummate a levirate marriage with him. The fact that the <i>baraita</i> rules that she is prohibited from consummating the marriage demonstrates that she does not revert to her original permitted status.
Rava <b>was silent,</b> as he had no immediate answer. <b>After</b> Rav Hamnuna <b>left</b> the study hall, Rava <b>said</b> to himself: <b>Why did you not say to him</b> that the <i>baraita</i> does not pose a challenge because <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who said</b> in a mishna (108b) with regard to the case of a man who divorced his wife, remarried her, and then died childless, that the <i>yevama</i> may not consummate levirate marriage with her <i>yavam</i> because <b>once</b> a <i>yevama</i> <b>has stood</b> before her <i>yavam</i> <b>in a forbidden state,</b> even <b>for a single moment, she</b> remains <b>forbidden to him forever,</b> and in that case, during the period she was divorced from her husband she was forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>? The Rabbis, however, disagree with his opinion, and the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with their opinion.
<b>He then said</b> to himself: It is not certain that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar because one could <b>say that Rabbi Elazar said</b> his opinion only <b>where she was not suitable</b> for the <i>yavam</i>, i.e., she was forbidden to him, already from <b>the time</b> of her <b>happening</b> before her <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage at the moment of her husband’s death. <b>However, where she was suitable</b> for her <i>yavam</i> <b>at the time of</b> her <b>happening</b> before him and became forbidden to him only at some later point, as in the case of a <i>yavam</i> who betrothed the sister of his <i>yevama</i>, <b>did he</b> actually <b>say</b> that if the reason for the prohibition is removed then she does not return to her permissible state? If the <i>baraita</i> does not represent the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, then it must be unanimously agreed upon, and therefore it indeed poses a challenge.
<b>He then said: Yes,</b> actually, Rabbi Elazar did state his opinion even in such a case, <b>and</b> so <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a <i>yavam</i> who betrothed the sister of his <i>yevama</i>, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If <b>his <i>yevama</i> dies, he is permitted to his wife.</b> If <b>his wife dies, that <i>yevama</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not enter into levirate marriage</b> with him. Therefore, the challenge from the <i>baraita</i> can be dismissed since it represents only Rabbi Elazar’s opinion.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>Shmuel and Rav Asi, who say</b> that she may not consummate the levirate marriage, hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that they hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> as perhaps <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Elazar</b> in the case of a man who divorced and remarried his wife and then died childless <b>only due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> in that case, <b>from</b> the time of her <b>happening</b> for levirate marriage <b>and onward she was not forbidden to them,</b> i.e., her <i>yevamin</i>. The fact that the prohibition between her and her <i>yevamin</i> ended before she ever happened before them for levirate marriage means it has no bearing on her current eligibility for levirate marriage. <b>However, here,</b> in the case where the <i>yavam</i> betrothed the sister of his <i>yevama</i>, since <b>she became forbidden</b> after she had already happened before him for levirate marriage, <b>even the Rabbis</b> would <b>agree</b> that she remains permanently ineligible to consummate levirate marriage with him.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A <i>yevama</i> may neither perform <i>ḥalitza</i> nor enter into levirate marriage until she has</b> waited <b>three months</b> from the time of her husband’s death. <b>And similarly, all other women may not be betrothed and may not marry until they have</b> waited <b>three months</b> since their previous marriage ended. This waiting period is necessary so that, should a woman give birth shortly after remarrying, it will be obvious who the father of the child is. This applies <b>both to virgins and non-virgins, both to divorcées and widows,</b> and <b>both to women</b> who were <b>married</b> to their previous husbands <b>and women</b> who were only <b>betrothed.</b> All of these women must wait three months before remarrying even though for some of them the reason for doing so does not apply.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The women</b> who were <b>married</b> to their previous husbands <b>may be betrothed, and the women</b> who were only <b>betrothed</b> to their previous husbands <b>may marry</b> without waiting three months. This is true <b>except for the betrothed women that are in</b> the area of <b>Judea, due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the groom <b>is familiar with her.</b> The custom in Judea was for the couple to be secluded together before the marriage so that they would become familiar with each other. This led to the possibility that they might cohabit even during their betrothal period. Rabbi Yehuda holds that one does not need to wait three months whenever the reason for doing so does not apply.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: All of the women may be betrothed</b> within three months even if they were previously married, <b>except for a widow,</b>

Daf 41b

<b>due to the mourning</b> period she must observe for her deceased husband.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions the mishna’s opening clause: <b>Granted, she should not enter into levirate marriage,</b> as she might already be pregnant, which would still not be noticeable during the first three months, and <b>perhaps the baby will be viable.</b> In that case it would emerge that she was never subject to the mitzva of levirate marriage, <b>and</b> therefore, if the <i>yavam</i> consummates a levirate marriage <b>he will have encountered the Torah prohibition against</b> engaging in relations with one’s <b>brother’s wife. However, why should she not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this mishna, which states that a pregnant woman should not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> that <b>a <i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>with a pregnant woman</b> who later miscarries <b>is considered</b> a valid <b><i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t they</b> already <b>conclusively refute</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan one time</b> previously from other sources? The Gemara rephrases the suggestion: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>from this</b> mishna <b>as well there is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara deflects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> it is possible that in the mishna <b>here, this is the reason</b> that she may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>Perhaps</b> the <b>offspring will be viable,</b> in which case although she performed the act of <i>ḥalitza</i>, it is entirely meaningless since it was completely unnecessary, and she would remain permitted to marry into the priesthood. However, this could lead to a problem: People might not realize that the <i>ḥalitza</i> she performed was meaningless, and they would think she is a <i>ḥalutza</i> who is prohibited from marrying a priest. <b>It would</b> therefore <b>emerge</b> that if you permit her to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> even though it is possible that she is pregnant, it could be that <b>you will</b> ultimately <b>require a public announcement</b> to be made <b>for her</b> to attest to the fact that the <i>ḥalitza</i> she performed was meaningless and she is in fact still permitted to marry <b>into the priesthood.</b>
The Gemara wonders why this poses a problem: <b>But</b> why not let her perform <i>ḥalitza</i> even though it is possible she is pregnant, and then, if it becomes necessary, <b>require</b> a public announcement to be made <b>for her?</b> The Gemara explains why one should avoid having to rely on a public announcement: <b>Perhaps there will be some</b> people <b>who are</b> present <b>at the <i>ḥalitza</i> but were not</b> present <b>at the public announcement, and</b> those people <b>will</b> incorrectly <b>disqualify her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> To avoid this situation, the mishna rules that she should wait three months before performing <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: This answer <b>works out well</b> with regard to <b>a widow</b> because as a widow she is currently still permitted to marry into the priesthood, but with regard to <b>a divorcée,</b> who is already prohibited from marrying into the priesthood, <b>what is there to say;</b> why shouldn’t she perform <i>ḥalitza</i> immediately? The Gemara provides an alternative reason to delay the <i>ḥalitza</i>: The reason is <b>because</b> by performing <i>ḥalitza</i> immediately <b>she will forfeit the sustenance payments</b> from her deceased husband’s estate, which she otherwise would have been entitled to for the first three months. Since she is not permitted to remarry during those three months, she will have no means of support. Therefore, she should wait until after three months have passed before performing <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: This answer <b>works out well</b> with regard to a <b>woman</b> who was <b>married</b> to her previous husband and who is therefore entitled to sustenance payments, but with regard to <b>a divorcée who</b> was only <b>betrothed</b> to her previous husband, <b>what is there to say?</b> She is neither entitled to receive sustenance payments nor is she permitted to marry into the priesthood. Why, then, shouldn’t she perform <i>ḥalitza</i> immediately?
The Gemara therefore provides an alternative reason to delay the <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> stated, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving a certain man who came before Rabbi Yosei.</b> The man <b>said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to performing <i>ḥalitza</i> within three</b> months of the husband’s death? <b>He said to him: She may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> He asked him: <b>Let her perform <i>ḥalitza</i>; what</b> would be the problem <b>with that?</b> Even if she is pregnant, no prohibition will have been transgressed.
To explain his ruling, Rabbi Yosei <b>recited this verse about him: “And if the man does not wish</b> to take his <i>yevama</i>” (Deuteronomy 25:7) in levirate marriage, then he must perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. By inference, the possibility of performing <i>ḥalitza</i> exists only in a case in which <b>if he wishes he may consummate the levirate marriage.</b> This teaches the principle that <b>one who is eligible for levirate marriage is eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> and one who is ineligible for levirate marriage is ineligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>. This includes even a woman who is temporarily prohibited from marrying, e.g., a woman in the first three months following a previous marriage.
<b>Rav Ḥinnana raised an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Those women</b> whose status as a <i>yevama</i> <b>is uncertain perform <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> According to this <i>baraita</i>, there are in fact cases in which a woman is eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i> but may not enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara clarifies the case: <b>What is</b> the case of <b>women</b> whose status as a <i>yevama</i> <b>is uncertain? If we say</b> it is referring to a woman whose <b>betrothal</b> to her previous husband <b>is uncertain,</b> then <b>why does she not enter into levirate marriage? Let her enter into levirate marriage, and</b> there is <b>no</b> problem <b>with that,</b> because if the betrothal was never valid, then she is permitted to the <i>yavam</i> as she is not his brother’s wife; and if it was valid, then she is now obligated to enter into levirate marriage with him.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case of <b>uncertainty</b> in <b>which</b> a man <b>betrothed one of two sisters and he does not know which</b> one <b>of them he betrothed?</b> If that man then died childless, the <i>yavam</i> may not consummate the levirate marriage with either sister because it is possible that he will do so with the sister who was not betrothed to his brother, who is therefore forbidden to him as the sister of a woman who is bound to him by a levirate bond. This is in fact the case of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> even though she is not permitted to enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of uncertainty, <b>if Elijah were to come and say that</b> the man <b>betrothed this one</b> of the sisters, then <b>she would be eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage.</b> It is clear, then, that fundamentally the sister who was betrothed is actually eligible for levirate marriage, and it is merely a lack of knowledge that prevents her from entering into it.
However, <b>here,</b> with regard to a woman during the first three months following her previous marriage, <b>if Elijah were to come and say that this</b> woman <b>is not pregnant, would one pay heed to him and would we allow</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>to consummate levirate marriage?</b> Certainly not, <b>as</b> is evident from the fact that <b>a minor girl, who cannot become pregnant, must</b> also <b>wait three months.</b> Evidently, the requirement to wait three months applies in all situations, even those in which the reason for the requirement is irrelevant. Therefore, by virtue of that decree the <i>yevama</i> is considered to be fundamentally ineligible for levirate marriage and similarly is ineligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>.
§ The Gemara mentioned that a <i>yevama</i> is supported from her deceased husband’s estate. It now proceeds to cite a <i>baraita</i> that teaches this <i>halakha</i>: <b>The Sages taught: A <i>yevama</i></b> during <b>the first three months</b> following her husband’s death <b>receives sustenance</b> payments <b>from the husband’s</b> estate. This is because her previous marriage to him is the cause of her current unmarried state, since is it due to that marriage that she must first wait three months before remarrying. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward, she does not receive sustenance</b> payments, <b>neither from the husband’s</b> estate <b>nor from the <i>yavam</i>,</b> as he has not yet consummated a levirate marriage with her.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If the <i>yavam</i> <b>was brought to judgment</b> and it was decided that he was obligated to either consummate the levirate marriage with her or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>and he ran away</b> to avoid doing so, <b>she receives sustenance</b> payments <b>from</b> the estate <b>of the <i>yavam</i>,</b> which is his penalty for neglecting his duty.
The Gemara asks: If <b>she happened before</b> her <b><i>yavam</i></b> who is <b>a minor</b> for levirate marriage, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>From the <i>yavam</i> she does not have</b> any right to sustenance payments because, as a minor, he is unable to consummate a levirate marriage, but as to payments <b>from</b> her <b>husband’s</b> estate, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Since his death placed her in a situation that forces her to remain in an unmarried state, does his estate have to take the responsibility of supporting her?
<b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to</b> this matter: <b>One said she does have</b> rights to sustenance payments, <b>and</b> the other <b>one said she does not have</b> any rights. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>she does not have</b> any rights to sustenance payments. This is because the husband is not considered to be responsible for her situation; rather, it is thought that <b>she was penalized by Heaven.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> In the case of <b>a <i>yevama</i> with whom the brothers</b> of her deceased husband <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> within three</b> months of her husband’s death, she still <b>needs to wait three months</b> before remarrying.

Daf 42a

If they performed the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>after three</b> months, <b>she does not need to wait three months</b> and may marry immediately.
The Gemara infers from the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>: It <b>must be</b> that <b>the three months that are stated</b> throughout the <i>baraita</i> are counted <b>from the time of the husband’s death and not from the time of the <i>ḥalitza</i> of the <i>yavam</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> the case of <b>a bill of divorce, where Rav said</b> that the three months are counted <b>from the time of the giving</b> of the bill of divorce, <b>and Shmuel said</b> that the count is <b>from the time of the writing</b> of the bill. If a couple is secluded together after the bill of divorce is written, the bill of divorce is invalid. Therefore, there is no concern that they were secluded from that time. This is why Shmuel holds that the three months are counted from the writing. Rav apparently assumes that even so, the count always begins from the formal end of the marriage and not from the point from which there was no possibility of her becoming pregnant. Why, then, does the <i>baraita</i> not rule also in the case when a woman happens for levirate marriage, that the count should begin from the point of <i>ḥalitza</i>, since the marriage is only fully severed at that point?
<b>Rava said:</b> With regard to a <i>yevama</i>, all agree that the count begins from the time of her husband’s death. This can be derived through an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as follows: If <b>a prohibition</b> that entails <b><i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., the prohibition against engaging in relations with one’s brother’s wife in the event she is pregnant and not subject to levirate marriage, <b>you have permitted</b> after three months from the husband’s death, then in the case of a standard <b>negative prohibition,</b> such as the prohibition against engaging in relations with a woman within three months of the death of her previous husband, is it <b>not all the more so</b> clear that she should be permitted to remarry after three months from her husband’s death? Therefore, even Rav agrees that in this case, the count begins from the husband’s death.
§ The mishna states: <b>And similarly, all other women may</b> not be betrothed or marry until they have waited three months. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, a <i>yevama</i></b> has to wait, <b>in accordance with</b> the reason <b>that we said,</b> that if she is pregnant with viable offspring, consummating the levirate marriage would violate the prohibition against engaging in relations with one’s brother’s wife. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>all other women, why</b> shouldn’t they remarry immediately even if they are pregnant?
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to Abraham: <b>“To be a God to you and your seed after you”</b> (Genesis 17:7), which indicates that the Divine Presence rests with someone only when his seed can be identified as being descended from him, i.e., there are no uncertainties with regard to their lineage. Therefore, to prevent any uncertainties concerning the lineage of her child, the woman must wait so that it will be possible <b>to distinguish between the seed of the first</b> husband <b>and the seed of the second</b> husband. After three months, if she has conceived from her previous husband, the pregnancy will already be noticeable.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Therefore,</b> on account of the requirement to wait three months, <b>a male convert and a female convert</b> who were originally married to each other and converted <b>need to wait three months</b> before they may remarry following their conversion. Rava asks: <b>Here,</b> in this case, <b>what</b> reason <b>is there to distinguish?</b> Even if they do not wait and she is found to be pregnant, it is clear who the child’s parents are.
The Gemara explains: <b>Here, too, there is</b> a need <b>to distinguish between seed that was sown in sanctity,</b> i.e., a child conceived by a Jewish parents, <b>and seed that was not sown in sanctity,</b> i.e., a child conceived by gentile parents.
<b>Rava stated</b> a different reason for the need to wait: It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> a child be born and be incorrectly identified as the son of his mother’s second husband when he is fact the son of her first husband. This could result in him <b>marrying his paternal sister,</b> unaware of the true relationship between them, <b>or consummating a levirate marriage with the wife of his maternal brother</b> under the misconception that his maternal brother was also his paternal brother. This would be prohibited because the prohibition to engage in relations with one’s brother’s wife is waived only in the case where there is a mitzva of levirate marriage, which applies only to paternal brothers.
<b>Or</b> in the event that his mother’s second husband died and he was assumed to be his only offspring, <b>he would cause his mother to go out</b> and be permitted <b>to the</b> general <b>public</b> because, under the misconception that he was the offspring of the deceased, he assumed that there was no mitzva of levirate marriage. <b>Or,</b> in the event that his maternal brother died childless and the brother’s widow became subject to levirate marriage, under the misconception that he was the paternal brother of the deceased he might perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and <b>permit</b> his supposed <b><i>yevama</i> to</b> marry a man from <b>the</b> general <b>public.</b> To avoid these problems, the Sages decreed that a woman must wait before remarrying.
<b>Rav Ḥananya raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In all of those</b> cases where the Sages prohibit a woman from marrying or consummating a levirate marriage, <b>I identify</b> that the prohibition is <b>due to an ordinance</b> instituted to prevent a violation of <b>forbidden relations, and here,</b> with regard to the prohibition against marrying within three months, it is <b>due to an ordinance for</b> the benefit of <b>the offspring.</b> Rav Ḥananya explains the challenge: <b>And if it is so</b> that Rava’s understanding of the prohibition against marrying within three months is correct, then <b>all of the</b> cases of forbidden marriages are <b>due to an ordinance</b> to prevent violation of <b>forbidden relations.</b> However, the <i>baraita</i> indicates otherwise.
The Gemara defends Rava’s opinion and explains that the <i>baraita</i> can be interpreted in a way that is consistent with his understanding: When the <i>baraita</i> says that <b>this</b> prohibition is <b>due to an ordinance for</b> the benefit of <b>the offspring,</b> it means <b>that</b> due to the prohibition the offspring <b>will not encounter</b> a prohibition of <b>forbidden relations.</b>
§ The Gemara analyzes the prohibition against marrying before three months have passed: <b>Granted, she should not wait</b> for only <b>two months and</b> then <b>marry, as this is</b> still a case that could give rise to <b>an uncertainty whether</b> the child born to her seven months after remarrying <b>is nine</b> months <b>old,</b> i.e., counting from conception, and it is the offspring <b>of the first</b> husband, or <b>whether</b> the child is only <b>seven</b> months <b>old</b> and is the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband.
<b>However, let her wait</b> only <b>one month and</b> then <b>marry, and</b> then, since it is presumed that a baby born during its eighth month since conception is not viable but a baby born during its seventh or nine month is viable, <b>if after seven</b> months since remarrying <b>she gives birth,</b> then the child <b>is</b> clearly <b>seven</b> months <b>old</b> and <b>is</b> the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband, <b>and if after eight</b> months since remarrying <b>she gives birth,</b> then <b>this</b> child <b>is</b> clearly <b>nine</b> months <b>old and is</b> the offspring <b>of the first</b> husband. Why, then, is there a need to wait three months?
The Gemara explains: <b>Even if she gave birth after eight</b> months since remarrying <b>one could say that</b> the child is the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband, as <b>perhaps she waited one month</b> after remarrying <b>and conceived</b> only then. As such, the baby would be only seven months old, and that would explain its viability.
The Gemara asks further: <b>But let her wait for two and a half months and</b> then <b>marry, as, if after seven</b> months since remarrying <b>she gives birth,</b> then <b>this</b> child <b>is</b> clearly <b>seven</b> months <b>old and is</b> the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband. <b>And if after six and a half</b> months since remarrying <b>she gives birth,</b> then <b>this</b> child <b>is</b> clearly <b>nine</b> months <b>old</b> and <b>is</b> the offspring <b>of the first</b> husband, because <b>if</b> one would suggest <b>it is</b> the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband, in that case it would be <b>six and a half</b> months <b>old,</b> at <b>which</b> age it <b>cannot survive.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>Even if after six and a half</b> months since remarrying <b>she gave birth, one could say that</b> the child is the offspring <b>of the latter</b> husband, <b>as Mar Zutra said: Even according to the one who says</b> that <b>a woman who gives birth after nine</b> months <b>does not give birth after an incomplete</b> number of months, i.e., she carries for a full nine months, nevertheless, <b>a woman who gives birth after seven months can give birth after an incomplete</b> number of months, and therefore it is possible that the baby was actually born after six and a half months.
This fact is derived from the verse concerning the birth of Samuel the prophet, <b>as it is stated: “And it came to pass, when the seasons of the days had come,</b> that Hannah conceived, and bore a son” (I Samuel 1:20). How much time is indicated by the phrase “the seasons of the days”? <b>The minimal sense of</b> the word <b>“seasons” is two,</b> and since each season of the year is three months, that indicates six months. <b>The minimal sense of</b> the word <b>“days” is two.</b> Accordingly, one may conclude that Samuel the prophet was born after six months and two days.
The Gemara suggests further: <b>But let her wait any</b> minimal <b>amount</b> of time, less than a month, <b>and</b> then <b>marry, and</b> then <b>when three months</b> after the end of her first marriage <b>are complete, examine her</b> body to see if she is noticeably pregnant. If she is, then perforce the baby is the offspring of her previous husband because a pregnancy is not noticeable until three months.
<b>Rav Safra said:</b> This solution is not possible because <b>one does not examine</b> the bodies of <b>married women so as not to shame them before their husbands.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>But let her be examined through the way she walks,</b> since after three months a pregnant woman walks differently than a woman who is not pregnant.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said: A woman</b> who conceived from her previous husband would <b>mask herself</b> by purposefully walking in a manner in which her pregnancy will not be discerned, so that her child will be identified as the son of her new husband <b>in order that her child will</b> ultimately <b>inherit her</b> new <b>husband’s property.</b> Therefore, it is impossible to rely upon a test of this kind. In summary, the Gemara has demonstrated that it would be ineffective to wait any less than three months.
§ The Gemara asks: In cases <b>where we are convinced that she is pregnant, let her marry</b> immediately, as the reason to wait three months does not apply. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>is it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A man may not marry a woman who is pregnant</b> with the child <b>of another</b> man, <b>nor a woman who is nursing</b> the child <b>of another</b> man; <b>and if he</b> transgressed and <b>married</b> her, he is penalized for violating the prohibition, and <b>he must divorce</b> her <b>and may never take</b> her <b>back?</b>
The Gemara explains: This prohibition is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> she become pregnant a second time and <b>her</b> original <b>fetus will be deformed</b> into the shape of <b>a sandal fish.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, even</b> if his wife is pregnant with <b>his own</b> child, the same concern applies.
The Gemara responds: She is permitted to engage in relations, both <b>if</b> one holds <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> that a young girl, for whom it is dangerous to become pregnant, is permitted to engage in relations <b>using a</b> contraceptive <b>resorbent</b> placed at the entrance to her womb, then also a woman pregnant with her husband’s child may engage in relations <b>using a resorbent, and</b> similarly <b>if</b> one holds <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> a young girl is permitted to engage in relations in her usual manner and <b>Heaven will have mercy</b> upon her and prevent any mishap, then in this case as well a pregnant woman should continue to engage in relations and <b>Heaven will have mercy</b> upon her.
The Gemara objects: But <b>here, too,</b> in the case of a woman who is pregnant with the child of another man, these solutions could be employed: Both <b>if</b> one holds <b>in accordance with the one who says</b> that a young girl may engage in relations <b>using a resorbent,</b> in this case as well she may do so <b>using a resorbent, and</b> similarly <b>if</b> one holds <b>in accordance with the one who says</b> that <b>Heaven will have mercy</b> upon her, in this case as well <b>Heaven will have mercy</b> upon her.
The Gemara suggests a different reason for the prohibition against marrying a woman who is pregnant with the child of another man: <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>due to the</b> damage that could be caused to the fetus by the <b>pressure</b> applied to it at the time of intercourse. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, even</b> if his wife his pregnant with <b>his own</b> child, the same concern applies. The Gemara explains: When it is <b>his own</b> child, <b>he has mercy upon it</b> and tries not to apply too much pressure. The Gemara asks: But <b>here, too,</b> when it is the child of another man, <b>he will have mercy upon it,</b> as certainly one is careful not to cause harm to any human life and will be careful not to press down too hard.
The Gemara suggests a different reason: <b>Rather,</b> the reason for the prohibition is that <b>a typical pregnant woman is poised to nurse</b> her child once it is born;

Daf 42b

therefore, one should be concerned that <b>perhaps she will become pregnant and her milk will dry up</b> during pregnancy, <b>and</b> the lack of milk will <b>kill</b> her newborn child. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, even</b> if his wife is pregnant with <b>his own</b> child, the same concern applies. The Gemara explains: For <b>his own</b> child, <b>she will feed [<i>memasmesa</i>] him with eggs and milk</b> as a substitute for the mother’s milk. The Gemara asks: Even if the child is not his, it is still the mother’s child, and for <b>her</b> child <b>she will also feed him with eggs and milk.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The husband will not give her</b> money to procure food for a child that is not his. The Gemara asks: <b>But she could sue</b> her first husband’s <b>heirs</b> to provide subsistence for the child. <b>Abaye said: A woman is embarrassed to come to court, and</b> therefore she will not obtain enough sustenance for him. Consequently, <b>she</b> effectively <b>kills her son</b> as a result.
§ The mishna states: The requirement to wait three months before remarrying applies <b>both to virgins and non-virgins,</b> both to divorcées and to widows, and both to women who were married to their previous husbands and to women who were only betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> women <b>are</b> referred to as <b>virgins and which are</b> referred to as those who were <b>betrothed?</b> Although the two terms appear to be synonymous, since a virgin will be subject to levirate marriage only if she was betrothed, they must certainly refer to two different categories of women. Similarly, <b>which</b> women <b>are</b> referred to as <b>non-virgins and which are</b> referred to as <b>married,</b> as a married woman is always considered to be a non-virgin?
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying:</b> The requirement to wait applies <b>to both virgins and non-virgins who were widowed or divorced, whether from betrothal or from marriage,</b> i.e., the mishna does not list different categories of women but instead establishes a general principle.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Elazar did not enter the study hall</b> one day. <b>He found Rabbi Asi</b> and <b>said to him: What was said by the Sages in the study hall</b> today? <b>He said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that a woman is permitted to be betrothed even before three months have passed, since the reason for waiting does not apply in that case.
Rabbi Elazar said: <b>From the fact</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan needed to state this, it would seem <b>that</b> there is <b>an individual</b> opinion that <b>disagrees with him,</b> even though no such opinion is mentioned in the mishna. Rabbi Asi answered: <b>Yes,</b> that is correct, <b>and so it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Yevamot</i> 6:6): With regard to a woman who is certainly not pregnant, for example, a woman who, at the time of her husband’s death, had not lived with her husband for some time because she always eagerly hurried, like <b>one pursued, to go to her father’s house, or because she had</b> been subject to <b>anger in her husband’s house, or because her husband had been incarcerated in prison, or because her husband was elderly or infirm, or because she was infirm.</b>
<b>Or</b> a woman who could not be pregnant <b>because she miscarried after her husband’s death, or because she was barren, or elderly, or a minor, or a sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>aylonit</i>], or</b> if for some other reason <b>she was unsuited to give birth;</b> even though the reason for the decree to wait three months does not apply to such a woman, nevertheless, <b>she must wait three months.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> such women <b>to be betrothed or to marry immediately.</b> It is apparent from the <i>baraita</i> that the question of whether a woman is required to wait the three months when the reason to do so does not apply is subject to a dispute.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: Rabbi Yoḥanan retracted</b> his statement that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Even <b>if he</b> wanted to <b>retract</b> his statement, would <b>he retract from the <i>baraita</i></b> that records the opinions of the Sages <b>of the vineyard</b> of Yavne? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, said: I heard from the mouth of the Sages in the vineyard of Yavne</b> that <b>all</b> those women enumerated in the <i>baraita</i> above <b>need to wait three months.</b> If the great Sages of Yavne held in accordance with the opinion Rabbi Yosei, then the <i>halakha</i> is certainly in accordance with his opinion.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zerika: When you come before Rabbi Abbahu, raise the</b> following <b>contradiction: Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei? Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is</b> always established <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>an unattributed mishna? And we learned</b> in the mishna an unattributed ruling: <b>All women may not marry and may not be betrothed until they have</b> waited <b>three months</b> since their previous marriage ended; this applies to <b>both virgins and non-virgins.</b>
When Rabbi Zerika went and asked, Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b> The one <b>who raised this contradiction to you is</b> clearly <b>not concerned for his flour;</b> this <b>is</b> a case of <b>an unattributed</b> ruling <b>followed by a dispute</b> on that ruling, and in such cases the <b><i>halakha</i> is not</b> necessarily <b>in accordance with the unattributed opinion. As Rav Pappa said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> who said the following principle: When the Mishna first records <b>a dispute, and afterward</b> it records only one side of that dispute as <b>an unattributed opinion,</b> then the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</b> However, when the Mishna first records <b>an unattributed opinion and afterward</b> records that the ruling is subject to <b>a dispute, the <i>halakha</i> is not</b> necessarily <b>in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</b> In each case, the later reference is considered to be a summary of the matter.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Abbahu would walk while leaning upon the shoulder of Rabbi Naḥum, his attendant,</b> and along the way Rabbi Naḥum would <b>walk and gather halakhic rulings from him.</b> Once, Rabbi Naḥum <b>asked him:</b> When the Mishna first records <b>a dispute, and afterward</b> it records only one side of that dispute as <b>an unattributed opinion, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</b> Rabbi Naḥum then asked: When the Mishna first records <b>an unattributed opinion and afterward</b> records that the ruling is subject to <b>a dispute, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is not</b> necessarily <b>in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</b>
Rabbi Naḥum asked: When a ruling is recorded in <b>the Mishna as unattributed and</b> it is subject to <b>a dispute in a <i>baraita</i>, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the <b>unattributed opinion</b> in the Mishna. Rabbi Naḥum then asked: When <b>the Mishna</b> records that a matter is subject to <b>a dispute, and</b> only one side is recorded as <b>an unattributed opinion in a <i>baraita</i>, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b>

Daf 43a

<b>If Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>had not taught</b> that ruling in the Mishna, <b>from where would Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> his disciple and redactor of the <i>baraitot</i>, <b>have</b> known <b>it?</b> Since the source of the unattributed ruling in the <i>baraita</i> is certainly the dispute recorded in the mishna, its lack of attribution in the <i>baraita</i> only reflects the fact that Rabbi Ḥiyya ruled in accordance with that opinion, but that cannot be used to indicate that it is the accepted <i>halakha</i>.
Rabbi Naḥum questioned the principle that the <i>halakha</i> is always in accordance with an unattributed ruling in a mishna and <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 13:8): <b>A comb</b> made <b>for</b> combing beaten <b>flax</b> in preparation for spinning, from <b>which its teeth were removed and</b> only <b>two</b> of its teeth <b>remained in it,</b> is still suitable for combing. It is therefore considered a utensil and will become <b>ritually impure</b> if it comes in contact with ritual impurity. However, if only <b>one</b> tooth remained, so that the comb was no longer suitable for combing, it is no longer considered a utensil and so will remain <b>ritually pure</b> even if it comes in contact with ritual impurity. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>any</b> of the teeth <b>that were individually removed on their own,</b> since they do serve a purpose, e.g., they may be embedded and used as hooks, they are considered utensils and can become <b>ritually impure.</b>
A comb made <b>for</b> combing <b>wool from which every other one of its teeth were removed,</b> so that no two consecutive teeth remained in place, is no longer suitable for combing and so will remain <b>ritually pure.</b> If <b>three</b> teeth <b>remained in it in a single place</b> so that it could still be used for combing, then it could become <b>ritually impure.</b> However, if <b>one of those</b> teeth <b>was the external</b> frame of the comb itself, then it could not function as a comb, and so it will remain <b>ritually pure.</b> If <b>two</b> of the teeth <b>were removed and made into</b> small <b>pincers,</b> then they could become <b>ritually impure.</b> Alternatively, if <b>one</b> of the teeth was removed, <b>and it was prepared</b> in a manner that made it suitable <b>for</b> use in cleaning <b>an oil lamp or for stretching</b> ropes, then it would be considered a utensil and could become <b>ritually impure.</b>
Rabbi Naḥum posed his question: <b>But we maintain that</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with that mishna.</b> This would seem to contradict the principle that the <i>halakha</i> is always in accordance with an unattributed opinion. Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to</b> Rabbi Naḥum that the principle applies to all cases <b>apart from this</b> mishna, <b>as</b> with regard to this particular mishna there are <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish who both say: This is not</b> an authoritative <b>mishna,</b> and so it cannot be relied upon for a halakhic ruling.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> to say that the mishna is not authoritative? <b>Rav Huna bar Manoaḥ said in the name of Rav Idi, son of Rav Ika:</b> It is <b>because the first clause</b> of that mishna <b>contradicts the latter clause, as it teaches:</b> A comb used <b>for wool from which every other one of its teeth were removed</b> is no longer considered a utensil, and so it will remain <b>ritually pure. This</b> implies that <b>were two</b> teeth <b>to remain in it in one place,</b> it could become <b>ritually impure. And then</b> the mishna <b>continues and teaches:</b> If <b>three</b> teeth <b>remained in it in a single place</b> it is still considered a utensil and so it could become <b>ritually impure.</b> This indicates that if there are <b>three, yes,</b> it could become ritually impure, but if there are <b>two, no,</b> it would not become ritually impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>But what</b> is the <b>difficulty? Perhaps this</b> ruling that if two teeth remain it is considered a utensil is referring to <b>the internal</b> teeth, found in the middle of the frame, while <b>that</b> ruling that it is not considered a utensil is referring to <b>the outer</b> teeth, which are adjacent to the frame of the comb, which makes them unsuitable for use.
<b>Rather,</b> the difficulty with the mishna is <b>from here, as it teaches: And any</b> of the teeth <b>that were individually removed on their own,</b> since they can serve a useful purpose they are considered utensils and can become <b>ritually impure. And</b> the implication is that this is true <b>even though</b> the tooth <b>was not prepared</b> for that purpose. But <b>say the latter clause</b> as follows: If <b>one</b> of the teeth was removed, <b>and it was prepared</b> in a manner that rendered it suitable <b>for</b> use in cleaning <b>an oil lamp or for stretching</b> ropes, then it would be considered a utensil and could become <b>ritually impure.</b> The implication is that if <b>it was prepared</b> for use, then <b>yes,</b> it would be considered a utensil, but if <b>it was not prepared</b> for use, then <b>no,</b> it would not be considered a utensil.
<b>Abaye said: But what</b> is the <b>difficulty? Perhaps this</b> ruling, that further preparation is not required before it is considered a utensil, is referring to a case where the teeth were removed <b>with their base,</b> which allows them to be used immediately for various functions, whereas <b>that</b> ruling, that it is considered a utensil only once it is prepared for use, is referring to a case where the teeth were removed <b>without their base</b> and therefore require further preparation before they can be used.
<b>Rav Pappa stated</b> an alternative resolution: <b>But what</b> is the <b>difficulty? Perhaps this</b> ruling that further preparation is not required is referring to a case where the teeth <b>were narrow,</b> whereas <b>that</b> ruling that it is considered a utensil only once it is prepared for use is referring to a case where the teeth <b>were thick.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason that the mishna is not accepted as authoritative is not due to some difficulty in the formulation of the mishna, but <b>because those who are exact</b> in their rendition of the tradition <b>conclude</b> this mishna with: <b>This is</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> In other words, this mishna is not unattributed but presents the minority opinion of a single Sage, and it is for this reason that it is not accepted as authoritative.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin sent</b> a message from Eretz Yisrael with regard to the <i>halakha</i> cited in the mishna: <b>One may betroth</b> a woman, but not marry her, <b>within three</b> months of her previous marriage; <b>and so one acts in practice.</b>
<b>And so Rabbi Elazar would teach us in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina the Great</b> that the three months are counted as follows: One counts <b>the majority of</b> the days of <b>the first</b> month, <b>and the majority of the third</b> month, <b>and the entire middle</b> month.
<b>Ameimar permitted one to betroth</b> a woman <b>on the ninetieth day</b> itself. <b>Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: Didn’t Rav and Shmuel both say</b> that <b>she needs to wait three</b> full <b>months, excluding the day on which</b> the husband <b>died and excluding the day on which she is betrothed?</b> It is apparent that it is still prohibited to betroth a woman on the ninetieth day itself. Ameimar said to him: <b>That</b> which you heard, that the days of the husband’s death and of the betrothal are not included, <b>was stated</b> only <b>with regard to a nursing woman, as</b> it was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said:</b> A nursing woman <b>needs to wait twenty-four months</b> before being betrothed, <b>excluding the day on which</b> the baby <b>was born and excluding the day on which she is betrothed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t</b> there an incident concerning <b>a certain</b> person <b>who prepared a betrothal feast on the ninetieth day</b> following the death of the woman’s first husband, <b>and Rava caused him to forfeit his feast</b> by prohibiting the betrothal on that day? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> feast <b>was</b> actually <b>a marriage feast,</b> but had it been a betrothal feast it would have been permitted.
The Gemara summarizes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is</b> that a nursing mother <b>needs to wait twenty-four months, excluding the day on which</b> the baby <b>was born and excluding the day on which she is betrothed. And</b> if she was widowed but was not nursing, then <b>she needs to wait</b> only <b>three months, excluding the day on which</b> her previous husband <b>died and excluding the day on which she is betrothed.</b>
§ The mishna states that Rabbi Yosei says: All women may be betrothed within three months <b>except for a widow,</b> due to the mourning period she must observe for her deceased husband. <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> questioned the mishna’s ruling and <b>said:</b> Based on an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, it should be permitted for a woman to be betrothed during the thirty-day mourning period for her husband: If during another period of mourning, which the Gemara will specify, <b>when it is prohibited to launder</b> clothes, <b>it is permitted to be betrothed,</b> then during the thirty-day mourning period for a husband, <b>when it is permitted to launder</b> clothes, <b>isn’t it logical that it</b> should also be <b>permitted to be betrothed?</b>
The Gemara explains the cases involved: <b>What is</b> the period of mourning to which Rav Ḥisda is referring? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ta’anit</i> 26b): During <b>the week in which the Ninth of Av occurs, it is prohibited to cut</b> hair <b>and to launder</b> clothes, <b>but on Thursday it is permitted in deference to Shabbat. And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Prior to this time the public reduce their activities,</b> refraining <b>from business transactions, from building and planting, and they may betroth</b> women <b>but may not marry</b> them, <b>and they may not make a betrothal feast.</b> The Gemara assumes that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the days immediately preceding the Ninth of Av. Accordingly, during the days prior to the Ninth of Av it is prohibited to launder clothes, but it is permitted to be betrothed. It was upon this period of time that Rav Ḥisda based his <i>a fortiori</i> inference.
To defend Rav Yosei’s ruling in the mishna, the Gemara explains: <b>When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught</b> with regard to the period <b>prior to</b> the period that is <b>prior</b> to the Ninth of Av, i.e., the days prior to the week in which the Ninth of Av occurs. It is only then that it is permitted to be betrothed, but during the week in which the Ninth of Av occurs it is prohibited. Therefore, the basis of Rav Ḥisda’s <i>a fortiori</i> inference is undermined.
<b>Rava said:</b> From the period <b>prior to</b> the period that is <b>prior</b> to the Ninth of Av, a challenge to Rabbi Yosei’s ruling can <b>also</b> be advanced based on an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as follows: If in a period of mourning <b>when it is prohibited to conduct business transactions, it is permitted to be betrothed,</b> then during the thirty-day mourning period for a husband, <b>when it is permitted to conduct business transactions, isn’t it logical that it</b> should also be <b>permitted to be betrothed?</b>
The Gemara accepts the conclusion of this <i>a fortiori</i> inference and therefore concludes: <b>Do not say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: All women may be betrothed</b> within three months; <b>rather,</b> emend his statement to <b>say: All women may be married</b> within three months except for a widow. However, even Rabbi Yosei agrees that it is permitted for a widow to be betrothed during this period.

Daf 43b

The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yosei not accept</b> that there is a decree to wait three months in order <b>to distinguish</b> between the seed of the first and second husbands? According to the Gemara’s emendation of his statement, it would appear there is no case in which Rabbi Yosei applies the decree.
The Gemara answers: Indeed, <b>he does not accept</b> the decree. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>actually, he does accept</b> the decree and applies it in the case of a married woman who was divorced. <b>And</b> with regard to the challenge to his opinion from the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, emend the mishna and <b>say: Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>all</b> women <b>who were</b> only <b>betrothed</b> to their previous husbands and then <b>divorced may be married</b> within three months, since the reason to wait does not apply in this case.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then <b>this</b> opinion of Rabbi Yosei <b>is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> What difference is there between them? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in the case of a woman who was <b>married</b> to her previous husband and seeks <b>to be betrothed. Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>it is permitted to betroth</b> a woman who was <b>married</b> to her previous husband without first waiting three months. <b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>it is prohibited to betroth</b> a woman who was <b>married</b> to her previous husband without first waiting three months.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yosei</b> really <b>hold</b> that <b>it is prohibited to betroth</b> a woman who was <b>married</b> to her previous husband without first waiting three months? <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>all women may be betrothed</b> without waiting <b>except for a widow, due to the mourning period</b> she must observe for her deceased husband; <b>and how long is her mourning period?</b> It is <b>thirty days. And none of them may be married until they have</b> waited <b>three months.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the question: <b>What difficulty does this</b> <i>baraita</i> pose? <b>If we say that</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>all women may be betrothed</b> without waiting, <b>is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>stronger than the mishna that was established</b> as teaching that women who were only <b>betrothed</b> to their previous husbands and then <b>divorced may be married</b> within three months? <b>Here, too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> could be established as teaching that <b>all</b> women who were only <b>betrothed</b> to their previous husbands and then <b>divorced may be married</b> within three months.
<b>Rather,</b> the difficulty arises <b>from the latter clause that teaches: And none of them may marry until they have</b> waited <b>three months.</b> This implies that Rabbi Yosei holds that it is specifically <b>marrying that</b> is <b>not</b> permitted, <b>but betrothing seems well</b> and is permitted. This challenges the Gemara’s original claim that Rabbi Yosei disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda on this point.
<b>Rava said: Resolve</b> the difficulty <b>and</b> emend Rabbi Yosei’s statement to <b>say this: Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>all</b> women who were only <b>betrothed</b> to their previous husbands and then <b>divorced may marry</b> within three months <b>except for a widow, due to the mourning period</b> she must observe for her deceased husband. <b>And how long is her mourning period?</b> It is <b>thirty days. And</b> women who were <b>married</b> to their previous husbands <b>may not be betrothed until they have</b> waited <b>three months.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does</b> a woman who became <b>a widow from betrothal have</b> to observe <b>a mourning period</b> for her husband? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ami teach</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one’s <b>wife</b> to whom he was <b>betrothed</b> died, <b>he does not observe</b> a period of <b>acute mourning</b> for her, <b>and</b> if he is a priest <b>he is not</b> permitted <b>to become ritually impure for her. And similarly,</b> if he dies, <b>she does not observe</b> a period of <b>acute mourning</b> for him and <b>she does not become ritually impure for him.</b> If <b>she dies, he does not inherit from her.</b> If <b>he dies, she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b> The <i>baraita</i> demonstrates that a widow is required to mourn her husband only if she was married to him and not merely betrothed. If so, clearly Rabbi Yosei’s ruling in the mishna is referring to married women. Accordingly, all of the Gemara’s emendations of Rabbi Yosei’s statement, in order to defend his statement from Rav Ḥisda’s <i>a fortiori</i> inference, are refuted.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that the question of whether it is permitted to betroth a woman during the period prior to the week of the Ninth of Av <b>is</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From the New Moon</b> of Av <b>and until the fast</b> on the ninth, <b>the public reduces its activities,</b> refraining <b>from business transactions, from building and planting, and from betrothing and marrying.</b> During <b>the week in which the Ninth of Av occurs, it is prohibited to cut</b> hair <b>and to launder</b> clothes, <b>and it is prohibited to be betrothed. And some say: It is prohibited for the entire month.</b> The Gemara’s challenge to Rabbi Yosei’s opinion that it is prohibited for a widow to be betrothed during her mourning period was based on an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that assumes that it is permitted to be betrothed during the mourning period preceding the week of the Ninth of Av. However, since this ruling is subject to a dispute, Rabbi Yosei could reject the <i>a fortiori</i> inference by stating that he holds in accordance with the opinion that it is in fact prohibited to be betrothed during that period.
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this: From where</b> is it known <b>that</b> when the <i>baraita</i> prohibits one <b>to be betrothed,</b> it is referring <b>to actually betrothing? Perhaps it is</b> only <b>to make a betrothal feast that is prohibited, but</b> merely <b>to be betrothed seems well</b> and is permitted.
The Gemara questions Rav Ashi’s objection: <b>If so,</b> then with regard to the prohibition <b>against marrying</b> as well one could make the same claim: With regard to the prohibition <b>to marry, too, it is only to make a marriage feast that is prohibited, but</b> merely <b>to marry seems well</b> and is permitted. The Gemara rejects its question: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? Granted,</b> from <b>a marriage,</b> even <b>without a feast, there is joy, but</b> from <b>a betrothal without a feast, is there</b> any <b>joy?</b> It is merely a legal ceremony.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi stated</b> a different resolution of Rav Yosei’s opinion: <b>New mourning,</b> i.e., the mourning for a relative who has just passed away, <b>is different from old mourning,</b> i.e., the mourning over historic events such as the destruction of the Temple, and it is appropriate to be more lenient in the latter. <b>And the mourning of the public is different from the</b> private <b>mourning of the individual,</b> and it is appropriate to be more stringent in the latter. As such, it is not possible to form an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from the <i>halakhot</i> of mourning for the Temple to those of a wife mourning for her husband.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <b>four brothers married to four women and</b> some of the brothers <b>died</b> childless, their wives thereby become <i>yevamot</i>. <b>If the eldest of</b> the brothers who survived <b>wished to consummate the levirate marriage with all of</b> his <i>yevamot</i>, <b>he has permission</b> to do so.
In the case of <b>one who was married to two women and died</b> childless, the <b>intercourse or <i>ḥalitza</i> of</b> either <b>one of</b> the wives with the <i>yavam</i> <b>releases her rival wife</b> from the levirate bond, and the rival wife need not enter into levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.

Daf 44a

If <b>one</b> of these women <b>was fit</b> to marry into the priesthood <b>and one was unfit,</b> then <b>if he performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, he should perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the unfit</b> woman rather than with the one who is fit for the priesthood, since doing so with the woman who is fit would needlessly disqualify her from marrying into the priesthood. <b>But if he consummates the levirate marriage, he may consummate the levirate marriage with</b> the one who is <b>fit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The simple reading of the mishna’s first clause implies that all four brothers died. The Gemara questions this: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> to say that all <b>four brothers</b> died? If they all died, then who remains to consummate the levirate marriage? <b>Rather,</b> emend the mishna and <b>say</b> instead: <b>Four</b> married men <b>of</b> a set of more than four <b>brothers</b> died.
The mishna continues: If the eldest of them wished to consummate the levirate marriage with all of his <i>yevamot</i>, <b>he has permission</b> to do so. The Gemara asks: <b>Do they</b> actually <b>leave him</b> to do so? <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And the Elders of his city shall call him”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:8), which indicates that <b>they,</b> the Elders, <b>and not their agent,</b> should call him. The verse continues: <b>“And they speak to him”;</b> this phrase <b>teaches that they offer him advice that is appropriate for him.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: Appropriate advice means <b>that if he was a young man and she an elderly woman</b> or if <b>he was an elderly man and she a young woman, they say to him: What do you</b> want <b>with a young woman</b> when you are elderly? Or: <b>What do you</b> want <b>with an elderly woman</b> when you are young? <b>Go after your own kind,</b> i.e., a woman of a similar age, <b>and do not place discord in your household</b> that could be caused by marrying a woman of a significantly different age. From the <i>baraita</i> it is apparent that if consummating the levirate marriage will ultimately lead to contention between the couple, it is preferable to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. Similarly, in the case of the mishna, marrying four women will likely lead to contention since it is difficult to support so many people, and poverty will lead to strife. Therefore, the <i>yavam</i> should not be allowed to consummate levirate marriages with all of them.
The Gemara qualifies the mishna’s case: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach that he has permission to consummate the levirate marriage with all of his <i>yevamot</i> in the case <b>where it is possible for him</b> to provide for all four women. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then the same should be true <b>even</b> if there are <b>many</b> more women <b>as well;</b> why does the mishna specifically discuss a case of four women? The Gemara explains: The mishna <b>teaches us good advice;</b> in a case of up to <b>four</b> women, <b>yes,</b> if he can provide for them then it is acceptable to marry all of them. But if there are any <b>more</b> than that, <b>no,</b> he should not, <b>in order that he will</b> be able to <b>meet the conjugal rights</b> of each woman at least once <b>in</b> each <b>month.</b> A Torah scholar is expected to provide conjugal relations once a week. If he marries no more than four women, then that will ensure that each of his wives will receive their conjugal rights at least once a month.
§ The mishna states: In the case of <b>one who was married</b> to two women and died childless, the intercourse or <i>ḥalitza</i> of either one of them with the <i>yavam</i> releases her rival wife from the levirate bond. The Gemara questions why the mishna considers only the possibility that he would do so with only one of the women: <b>But let him</b> instead <b>consummate levirate marriages with both of them. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The verse states</b> that a <i>yavam</i> who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> is referred to as: “The man <b>who does not build his brother’s house”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:9). The fact that the word “house” appears in the singular indicates that even had he instead chosen to consummate a levirate marriage, only <b>one house may he build,</b> by consummating a levirate marriage with one of his brother’s wives, <b>but he may not build two houses.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let him perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of them;</b> why does the mishna state that he does so with only one woman? <b>Mar Zutra bar Toviya said: The verse states</b> that following the <i>ḥalitza</i> the man is called: <b>“The house of him who had his shoe removed”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:10). The fact that the word “house” appears in the singular indicates that <b>he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> only <b>one house,</b> i.e., only one of his brother’s wives, <b>and he does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with two houses.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let him consummate the levirate marriage with one and perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the other.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “If</b> the man <b>does not wish</b> to take his <i>yevama</i>” (Deuteronomy 25:7), which implies that with regard to anyone who performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>were he to wish</b> to, <b>he could consummate the levirate marriage.</b> This teaches the principle that only <b>one who is eligible for levirate marriage is eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> but <b>one who is ineligible for levirate marriage is ineligible for <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> And since, in the case of the mishna, if the <i>yavam</i> consummated the levirate marriage with one of his brother’s wives he may not do so with the second, consequently he may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her either.
<b>And furthermore,</b> an additional reason that one may not do so is so <b>that</b> people <b>should not say</b> that the brother’s <b>house was partially built</b> through levirate marriage <b>and partially released through <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> even if <b>they will say</b> that, what of it? The Gemara explains: <b>If he</b> first <b>consummated the levirate marriage</b> with one wife <b>and subsequently performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the other, <b>indeed,</b> there is no reason not to do this. <b>However, perhaps he</b> might first <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one wife <b>and subsequently consummate levirate marriage</b> with the other, <b>and</b> by doing so <b>he is liable for</b> a violation of the prohibition <b>of: “He does not build</b> his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9). The verse indicates that one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> has not built his brother’s house and is therefore subsequently prohibited from attempting to do so by consummating a levirate marriage with either the <i>ḥalutza</i> or any of her rival wives.
The Gemara asks. <b>But</b> since the Torah’s description of levirate marriage mentions only a case in which the deceased brother had only one wife, <b>say: When there is only one</b> wife, <b>the mitzva of levirate marriage exists,</b> but <b>when there are two</b> wives, <b>the mitzva of levirate marriage does not exist.</b>
The Gemara suggests a proof: <b>If</b> that were <b>so, why do I</b> need the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a rival wife of a forbidden relation, which is forbidden by the Merciful One</b> in the Torah? <b>Now</b> that even in the case of <b>two</b> women in <b>general,</b> where neither woman is a forbidden relation, <b>you say</b> that <b>they are not eligible for <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage, is it necessary</b> to say <b>a rival wife of a forbidden relation</b> is also forbidden? The fact that the Torah does prohibit a rival wife of a forbidden relation indicates that the mitzva of levirate marriage does exist in a general case of two wives in which neither is a forbidden relation.
The Gemara objects: <b>Why not?</b> Even if one assumes that there is no mitzva of levirate marriage when the deceased brother had two wives, <b>it is</b> still <b>necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> concerning a rival wife of a forbidden relation because it could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that since there is no possibility of consummating the levirate marriage with her, <b>the forbidden relation stands outside</b> the calculation such that her presence is disregarded, <b>and her rival wife should enter into levirate marriage</b> as though she were the only wife. Therefore, the verse needs to <b>teach us that</b> the rival wife <b>is forbidden.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the repeated use of the phrase <b>“his <i>yevama</i>,” “his <i>yevama</i>”</b> in the verses concerning levirate marriage <b>amplifies</b> the mitzva of levirate marriage so that it applies even when the deceased brother had more than one wife.
§ The mishna states: If <b>one</b> of these wives of the deceased brother <b>was fit</b> for the priesthood and one was unfit, <i>ḥalitza</i> should not be performed with the fit woman since doing so would needlessly disqualify her from the priesthood. <b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>here,</b> through this mishna, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught</b> the principle that one should not perform an action that will needlessly disadvantage others, and so <b>a person should not spill out water</b> collected in <b>his pit</b> that he does not need <b>when others are in need of it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who remarries his divorcée</b> after she had been married to another man from whom she was then widowed or divorced, <b>or one who marries the woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>], or one who marries a relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>,</b> since all such marriages are forbidden he <b>must divorce</b> her, <b>and the offspring</b> born from such unions <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b> He holds that even the offspring from relations forbidden by a prohibition punishable by lashes is a <i>mamzer</i>.
<b>The Rabbis say: The offspring</b> in those cases <b>is not a <i>mamzer</i>, but they concede with regard to one who marries a relative of his divorcée,</b> a union forbidden by a prohibition entailing <i>karet</i>, <b>that the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> They hold that only the offspring from relations forbidden by a prohibition entailing <i>karet</i> is a <i>mamzer</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Akiva</b> actually <b>hold</b> that with regard to <b>one who marries a relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>? Didn’t Reish Lakish say</b> that through the mishna <b>here, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught</b> that <b>a sister of</b> one’s <b>divorcée</b> is forbidden <b>by Torah law</b> whereas <b>a sister of</b> one’s <b><i>ḥalutza</i></b> is forbidden <b>by rabbinic law?</b> If a relative of one’s <i>ḥalutza</i> is forbidden by rabbinic law, how can the offspring of that union be a <i>mamzer</i>? The Gemara concedes: Emend the mishna and <b>teach</b> instead: <b>A relative of his divorcée.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>So, too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the correct version of the mishna, as <b>the latter clause teaches: But they concede</b> in the case of <b>one who marries a relative of his divorcée that the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>. Granted, if you say</b> that Rabbi Akiva <b>was talking about that</b> case, <b>this is</b> consistent with <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches: They concede,</b> which implies that they agree to a case already mentioned. <b>However, if you say</b> that he <b>was not talking about that</b> case, <b>what</b> could the phrase: <b>They concede,</b> possibly be referring to?
The Gemara objects: <b>But perhaps this</b> phrase <b>teaches us that</b> the Rabbis concede <b>that</b> the offspring <b>from</b> forbidden relations for which one <b>is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> The Gemara rejects this option: <b>This is already taught later on</b> in a mishna (49a): <b>Which</b> offspring of forbidden relations has the status of <b>a <i>mamzer</i>?</b> It is the offspring of a union with <b>any next of kin that is subject to</b> a Torah prohibition that one <b>should not engage in sexual relations</b> with them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Shimon HaTimni says:</b> It is the offspring of a union with <b>any</b> forbidden relative <b>for which one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> at the hand of Heaven. And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his statement.</b> Since the mishna explicitly rules in accordance with Rabbi Shimon HaTimni, it would be unnecessary for the mishna here to teach that fact.
The Gemara persists: <b>But perhaps the <i>tanna</i> taught us as unattributed</b> a mishna that is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon HaTimni</b> to indicate that this is indeed the accepted <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>If so,</b> then <b>let him teach other</b> cases of forbidden relations <b>for which one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>; why do I</b> need the mishna to specifically consider the case of <b>a relative of</b> one’s <b>divorcée? Rather, conclude from this</b> that Rabbi Akiva indeed <b>was talking about that</b> case.
The Gemara persists: <b>But perhaps he was not actually talking about that</b> case, <b>but since</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>taught</b> the cases of <b>one who remarries his divorcée, or one who marries his <i>ḥalutza</i> or a relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>,</b> the mishna <b>also taught</b> in the name of the Rabbis the case of one who marries <b>a relative of his divorcée</b> because it is a similar case. The Gemara concedes that this would be an acceptable reading of the mishna.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna should not be emended, and with regard to the Gemara’s original question as to how Rabbi Akiva could claim that the offspring from one’s union with a relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i> is a <i>mamzer</i> if that union is forbidden only by rabbinic law, one must conclude that <b>a relative of one’s <i>ḥalutza</i></b> is forbidden by Torah law <b>according to Rabbi Akiva</b> and therefore the offspring <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>this is Rabbi Akiva’s reasoning: As the verse states: “The house of he who had his shoe removed”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:10). <b>The verse called</b> his relationship with the <i>ḥalutza</i> <b>his house,</b> indicating that the <i>ḥalutza</i> is considered as though she had been married to the <i>yavam</i>, and therefore her relative is forbidden to him by Torah law.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: All agree in</b> the case of <b>one who remarries his divorcée</b>

Daf 44b

<b>that the offspring,</b> even if not a <i>mamzer</i>, <b>has flawed</b> lineage and, if the offspring is a girl, is unfit <b>to</b> marry into the <b>priesthood.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>Who</b> is included by saying: <b>All agree?</b> It is <b>Shimon HaTimni, as although Shimon HaTimni said</b> that the offspring of relations <b>for which one is liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition is not a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> nevertheless, <b>granted</b> that Shimon HaTimni holds that <b>he is not a <i>mamzer</i>;</b> he would agree, <b>however,</b> that <b>he is</b> of <b>flawed</b> lineage.
This is derived <b>through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a widow,</b> as follows: <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>a widow</b> who is married <b>to a High Priest, where the prohibition</b> that pertains <b>to her is not equally applicable to all,</b> i.e., only a High Priest is prohibited from marrying a widow, and nevertheless <b>her child</b> from that union will <b>have flawed</b> lineage, then so too with regard to <b>this</b> divorcée, who married another man and is therefore prohibited from marrying her original husband, <b>where the prohibition</b> that pertains <b>to her is equally applicable to all</b> Jews, as the prohibition to remarry one’s divorcée after she was married to another man applies to all Jews, <b>isn’t it logical that her child</b> from that union will have <b>flawed</b> lineage?
The Gemara raises a number of objections: The logic of this <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted: What</b> is true with regard <b>to a widow, where</b> her union with a High Priest is what makes <b>her herself disqualified</b> from subsequently marrying any priest and, if she is the daughter of a priest, from eating <i>teruma</i>, is not true with regard to a remarried divorcée, where her remarriage to another man is permitted and is not the cause of any further disqualification. Therefore, one case cannot be deduced from the other.
<b>And furthermore, “She is an abomination”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:4) <b>is written</b> with regard to remarrying with one’s divorcée, and the emphasis on the word “she” teaches that only she is considered so, <b>but her children are not abominations</b> and they have unflawed lineage.
<b>And furthermore, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who remarries his divorcée, and one who marries his <i>ḥalutza</i>, and one who marries a relative of his <i>ḥalutza</i>, Rabbi Akiva says</b> that <b>one’s betrothal of such</b> women <b>is not</b> effective. <b>And</b> therefore, even if he attempts to do so, it is meaningless and <b>she does not require a bill of divorce from him</b> in order to separate from him. <b>And</b> if she has relations with him <b>she is</b> rendered <b>unfit and her child is unfit, and we force him to send</b> her <b>away. The Rabbis say</b> that <b>one’s betrothal of such</b> women <b>is</b> effective, <b>and</b> therefore if he betrothed her <b>she requires a bill of divorce from him, and</b> if she has relations with him <b>she</b> remains <b>fit and her child is fit.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: When the <i>baraita</i> states she and her child are rendered unfit, <b>to whom</b> are they unfit to be married? <b>Is it not to the priesthood? No,</b> it is <b>to the congregation</b> of Israel. <b>If so,</b> when the <i>baraita</i> states <b>she is fit, to whom</b> is she fit to be married? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>to the congregation</b> of Israel, <b>this is obvious;</b> could it be that <b>because she engaged in forbidden sexual relations that she is rendered unfit from</b> marrying into <b>the congregation</b> of Israel? Although by doing so she is rendered a <i>zona</i>, that can disqualify her only from marrying a priest. <b>Rather, is it not</b> that the intention is that she is fit <b>to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>And since</b> in reference <b>to her</b> the word fit in the <i>baraita</i> means fit <b>for the priesthood,</b> it follows that for <b>the child as well,</b> the word fit means fit <b>for the priesthood.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>Are these cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is,</b> and although the two cases are juxtaposed in the <i>baraita</i> they need not be relating to the same issue. Rather, when referring to the mother the <i>baraita</i> mentions fitness for the priesthood, and when referring to the child it mentions fitness for the congregation of Israel.
