The Gemara explains: <b>When that</b> clause <b>is taught, it is taught</b> only <b>with regard to the matter of immersion,</b> which is mentioned immediately beforehand, but not with regard to the need to accept the yoke of mitzvot that is mentioned prior to that.
§ Having cited it above, the Gemara focuses on the case of the beautiful female prisoner of war: <b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“And she shall shave her head and do her nails”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:12). The phrase “do her nails” is ambiguous. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> It means <b>she cuts</b> her nails. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> It means <b>she grows</b> them.
Each <i>tanna</i> explains the basis of his opinion: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> An act of <b>doing is stated with regard to the head,</b> that she should shave it, <b>and</b> an act of <b>doing is stated with regard to the nails; just as there,</b> with regard to the hair on her head, the Torah requires its <b>removal, so too, here,</b> with regard to her nails, the Torah requires their <b>removal. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> An act of <b>doing is stated with regard to the head,</b> that she should shave it, <b>and</b> an act of <b>doing is stated with regard to the nails; just as there,</b> with regard to the hair on her head, the Torah requires that she do something that makes her <b>repulsive, so too, here,</b> with regard to her nails, the Torah requires she do something that makes her <b>repulsive,</b> i.e., allowing them to grow.
<b>And a proof for the statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> may be adduced from the verse that states: <b>“And Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, came down to meet the king; and he had neither done his feet nor done his mustache”</b> (II Samuel 19:25). <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>doing</b> in that context? Clearly it means the <b>removal</b> of his toenails and his mustache.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And she shall bewail her father and her mother</b> a month of days and after that you may come to her” (Deuteronomy 21:13).

Daf 48b

<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: “Her father”</b> means <b>her actual father</b> and <b>“her mother”</b> means <b>her actual mother. Rabbi Akiva says: Her father and her mother; this</b> is referring to the <b>idolatrous deity</b> that she had worshiped but will no longer be able to worship, <b>and so it says: “They say to a tree: You are my father,</b> and to a stone: You have given birth to us” (Jeremiah 2:27).
The verses states: <b>“A month of days</b> and after that you may come to her” (Deuteronomy 21:13). This means <b>a thirty-day month. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> She must wait <b>ninety days.</b> This is derived as follows: The phrase <b>“a month”</b> connotes <b>thirty</b> days; the word <b>“days”</b> adds another <b>thirty</b> days; <b>and</b> the words <b>“after that”</b> indicate another period equal to one previously mentioned, i.e., a further <b>thirty</b> days.
<b>Ravina strongly objects to this:</b> If the words “after that” indicate another period equal to one previously mentioned, then one should <b>say:</b> The phrase <b>“a month”</b> connotes <b>thirty</b> days; the word <b>“days”</b> adds another <b>thirty</b> days; <b>and</b> then the words <b>“after that”</b> add another period which is <b>equal to</b> the total sum of all <b>those</b> days she has already waited, i.e., an additional sixty days. The Gemara concedes: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may maintain slaves that are not circumcised</b> under one’s control; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: One may not maintain</b> such slaves, even for a moment. <b>Rabbi Yishmael said to him: But it says</b> with regard to Shabbat: <b>“And the son of your maidservant will be refreshed”</b> (Exodus 23:12). The verse prohibits a Jewish master from allowing his slave to perform labor on Shabbat. The Gemara will explain that this is referring to an uncircumcised slave. It is therefore apparent that it is permitted to keep such a slave. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him: The verse speaks of one who purchases a slave at twilight</b> on the eve of Shabbat <b>and</b> therefore <b>does not have the opportunity to circumcise him</b> before the onset of Shabbat.
The Gemara notes: <b>In any event,</b> in the opinion <b>of everyone</b> the verse: <b>“And the son of your maidservant will be refreshed,” is written with regard to an uncircumcised slave. From where</b> is this <b>inferred? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And the son of your maidservant will be refreshed”; the verse speaks of an uncircumcised slave.</b> Do <b>you say</b> it speaks <b>of an uncircumcised slave, or</b> perhaps <b>it is</b> speaking <b>only of a circumcised slave? When it says</b> elsewhere: “And the seventh day is a Shabbat to the Lord your God, you shall not do any labor, you, and your son, and your daughter, and your slave, and your maidservant…<b>so that your slave and your maidservant may rest like you”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:13), <b>a circumcised slave is</b> already <b>mentioned; how,</b> then, <b>do I uphold</b> the verse <b>“And the son of your maidservant will be refreshed”?</b> It must refer <b>to an uncircumcised slave.</b>
The verse continues: <b>“And the stranger [<i>ger</i>]”</b> (Exodus 23:12). <b>This</b> is referring to <b>a gentile who observes certain mitzvot [<i>ger toshav</i>].</b> Do <b>you say</b> that <b>this is a <i>ger toshav</i>, or</b> perhaps <b>it is only a righteous convert [<i>ger tzedek</i>],</b> who is a Jew in every sense? <b>When it says</b> elsewhere: <b>“And your stranger [<i>ger</i>] that is within your gates”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:13), <b>a righteous convert is</b> already <b>mentioned. How,</b> then, <b>do I uphold</b> the verse <b>“And the stranger [<i>ger</i>]”?</b> It must be that <b>this is a <i>ger toshav</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> In the case of <b>one who purchases a slave from a gentile and</b> the slave <b>does not wish to be circumcised, he abides with him up to twelve months.</b> If, after this period, <b>he will</b> still <b>not be circumcised, he then sells him</b> on <b>to gentiles.</b>
<b>The Sages said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Rav Pappa</b> and asked: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It seems <b>that it is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as, if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, didn’t he say: One may not maintain</b> an uncircumcised slave even for a moment? Rav Pappa <b>said to them: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> since perhaps <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i> of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>applies</b> only <b>where</b> the slave <b>did not make his</b> refusal to be circumcised <b>explicit; however, where he did make his</b> refusal to be circumcised <b>explicit,</b> since <b>he has made it explicit,</b> it is prohibited to maintain him, as Rabbi Akiva rules.
<b>Rav Kahana said: I said</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Zevid from Neharde’a. He said to me: If so,</b> that Rabbi Akiva agrees that one may temporarily maintain a slave who has not explicitly refused to be circumcised, then <b>when Rabbi Akiva said to</b> Rabbi Yishmael that the verse with regard to an uncircumcised slave <b>is referring to one who purchases a slave at twilight</b> on the eve of Shabbat, <b>let him</b> instead <b>answer him</b> that the verse is referring to <b>this</b> case of a slave who has not explicitly refused to be circumcised. The Gemara explains: Rabbi Akiva <b>said</b> only <b>one out of two</b> possible <b>reasons</b> why it would be permitted to be in possession of such a slave.
<b>Ravin sent</b> a message citing a <i>halakha</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Ilai: And all of my teachers said to me in his name: What is</b> the case of <b>an uncircumcised slave whom it is permitted to maintain? This is one whose master purchased him on condition not to circumcise him. The Sages said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Rav Pappa</b> and asked: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It seems <b>that it is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as, if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, didn’t he say: One may not maintain</b> an uncircumcised slave even for a moment? Rav Pappa <b>said to them: You</b> can <b>even say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> since perhaps <b>that</b> ruling of Rabbi Akiva <b>applies</b> only <b>where</b> the master <b>did not make a condition with regard to</b> the slave that he would not be circumcised; <b>however, where he did make</b> such <b>a condition,</b> since <b>he made a condition,</b> even Rabbi Akiva would concede it is permitted to maintain him.
<b>Rav Kahana said: I said</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Zevid from Neharde’a and he said to me: If so,</b> that Rabbi Akiva agrees that one may maintain a slave who was purchased on condition that he would not be circumcised, then <b>when Rabbi Akiva said to</b> Rabbi Yishmael that the verse with regard to an uncircumcised slave <b>is referring to one who purchases a slave at twilight</b> on the eve of Shabbat <b>and</b> therefore <b>does not have the opportunity to circumcise him</b> before the onset of Shabbat, <b>let him</b> instead <b>answer him</b> that the verse is referring to <b>this</b> case of a slave who was purchased on condition that he would not be circumcised.
The Gemara responds: <b>But</b> even <b>according to your reasoning</b> that Rabbi Akiva disagrees, since you do agree with Rav Pappa’s resolution of Rabbi Akiva’s opinion with the <i>halakha</i> of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, <b>let</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>answer him</b> that the verse is referring to <b>that</b> case of a slave who has not explicitly refused to be circumcised. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Akiva <b>said</b> only <b>one out of two or three</b> possible <b>reasons</b> that it would be permitted to be in possession of such a slave.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi, and Rabbi Ami, and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa were sitting in the courtyard of Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa. They were sitting and saying: There was one city in Eretz Yisrael whose slaves did not wish to be circumcised.</b> Their masters <b>abided with them until twelve months</b> had passed <b>and then sold them to gentiles. In accordance with whose</b> opinion did they act?
<b>It is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who purchases a slave from a gentile and</b> the slave <b>does not wish to be circumcised,</b> the master <b>abides with him</b> for <b>up to twelve months.</b> If, after this period, the slave <b>will</b> still <b>not be circumcised,</b> the master <b>then sells him to gentiles. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may not allow him to remain in Eretz Yisrael due to the loss of ritually pure items</b> he could cause. As long as the slave remains uncircumcised, he is considered to be a gentile; therefore, by rabbinic decree, ritually pure items that he touches are considered to be impure. <b>And in a city that is near to the border he may not be allowed to remain at all, lest he hear some</b> secret <b>matter</b> concerning security <b>and go and say</b> it over <b>to his fellow gentile</b> in an enemy country. However, once he has been circumcised and accepted the yoke of mitzvot, this concern no longer exists.
§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Ḥananya, son of Rabban Gamliel, says: For what</b> reason <b>are converts at the present time tormented and hardships come upon them?</b> It is <b>because</b> when they were gentiles <b>they did not observe the seven Noahide mitzvot. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> They would not be punished for their deeds prior to their conversion because <b>a convert who</b> just <b>converted is like a child</b> just <b>born</b> in that he retains no connection to his past life. <b>Rather, for what</b> reason <b>are they tormented?</b> It is <b>because they are not</b> as <b>well-versed in the intricacies of the mitzvot as</b> a born <b>Jew,</b> and consequently they often inadvertently transgress mitzvot. <b>Abba Ḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Elazar:</b> It is <b>because they observe</b> mitzvot <b>not out of love</b> of God, <b>but only out of fear</b> of the punishments for failing to observe them.
<b>Others say:</b> It is <b>because they waited before entering under the wings of the Divine Presence,</b> i.e., they are punished for not converting sooner than they did. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Ḥanina</b> who said: <b>What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that one should convert at the earliest opportunity? Boaz said to Ruth: <b>“The Lord shall recompense your work, and your reward shall be complete from the Lord, the God of Israel,</b> under whose wings <b>you have come to take refuge”</b> (Ruth 2:12).

Daf 49a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Which</b> offspring of forbidden relations have the status of <b>a <i>mamzer</i>?</b> It is the offspring of a union with <b>any next of kin that is subject to</b> a Torah prohibition that <b>he should not engage in sexual relations</b> with them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Shimon HaTimni says:</b> It is the offspring of a union with <b>any</b> forbidden relation <b>for which one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> at the hand of Heaven. And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his statement. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is the offspring of a union with <b>any</b> forbidden relation <b>for which one is liable to</b> receive <b>court-</b>imposed <b>capital punishment.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai said: I found a scroll</b> recording people’s <b>lineages in Jerusalem, and it was written in it</b> that <b>so-and-so is a <i>mamzer</i> from</b> an adulterous union with <b>a married woman,</b> a sin punishable by court-imposed capital punishment. The only reason for the scroll to state the reason that this individual is a <i>mamzer</i> is in order <b>to support the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
The mishna delineates the circumstances in which it is prohibited to engage in relations with the sister of one’s wife and the sister of one’s <i>yevama</i>: If a man’s <b>wife died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> If <b>he divorced her and</b> then <b>she died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> If he divorced his wife and then <b>she was married to another and</b> then <b>died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> If <b>his <i>yevama</i> died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with her and</b> then <b>she died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> If after <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>she was married to another and</b> then <b>died, he is permitted to her sister.</b> The principle underlying all these cases is that the prohibition against engaging in relations with her sister only applies while the wife or <i>yevama</i> remain alive, irrespective of their current relationship to the man.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is Rabbi Akiva’s reasoning? As it is written: “A man shall not take his father’s wife, and he shall not uncover his father’s cloak”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:1). This teaches that a <b>cloak that his father saw,</b> i.e., a woman with whom his father engaged in sexual relations, the son <b>may not uncover.</b>
<b>And</b> in this interpretation of the verse, Rabbi Akiva <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said:</b> The verse states only that such relations are forbidden, but they would not render him liable to receive <i>karet</i>; perforce <b>the verse speaks of a woman raped by one’s father,</b> since <b>she is</b> one of the women with whom relations render one <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition.</b> The verse could not refer to one’s father’s wife since relations with her render one liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara completes its explanation of Rabbi Akiva’s opinion: <b>And in close proximity to that</b> verse is the verse: <b>“A <i>mamzer</i> shall not enter into the congregation of the Lord”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:3). <b>Apparently,</b> even <b>from these</b> forbidden relations, which render one liable for the violation of a prohibition, the offspring <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Rabbi Simai, who</b> holds that Rabbi Akiva <b>includes</b> as a <i>mamzer</i> the offspring of all <b>other</b> forbidden relations <b>for which one is liable</b> for violation of <b>a prohibition,</b> even those <b>that are not</b> with his <b>next of kin; and</b> also <b>according to Rabbi Yeshevav, who</b> holds that Rabbi Akiva <b>includes even</b> the offspring of relations <b>for which one is liable for</b> the violation of a <b>positive mitzva;</b> since according to them, Rabbi Akiva includes cases that are not similar to the case of a woman raped by his father, what is his source?
The Gemara answers: <b>They derive</b> it <b>from</b> the verse that states: <b>“And he shall not</b> uncover his father’s cloak” (Deuteronomy 23:1). The word “and” is superfluous and serves to include additional cases.
<b>And Shimon HaTimni holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say:</b> It is <b>with regard to the widow waiting for his father</b> to perform <b>levirate marriage that the verse is speaking,</b> and it indicates <b>that she is</b> one of the women with whom relations <b>render one liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And in close proximity to that</b> verse is the verse: <b>“A <i>mamzer</i> shall not enter</b> into the congregation of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:3). <b>Apparently,</b> only the offspring of a union <b>for which one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> derive his opinion? If the verses should be derived as Rabbi Akiva and Shimon HaTimni suggest, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> only: <b>“He shall not uncover</b> his father’s cloak.” It is unnecessary for the verse to mention the prohibition with regard to one’s father’s wife, as the fact that the offspring of that union is a <i>mamzer</i> would be known through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, since that prohibition is more stringent than the one derived from the verse: “And shall not uncover his father’s cloak.” <b>Why do I</b> need both the clause <b>“a man shall not take</b> his father’s wife” and the clause <b>“and shall not uncover</b> his father’s cloak”? <b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>this is what</b> the Torah <b>is saying:</b> Only the offspring of relations with the woman mentioned in the verse <b>after</b> the words <b>“a man shall not take” until</b> the words <b>“he shall not uncover,”</b> i.e., his father’s wife, <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>, but</b> the offspring of relations with the woman mentioned <b>beyond</b> that point, i.e., the woman referred to as “his father’s cloak,” <b>is not a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
§ <b>Abaye said: All</b> <i>tanna’im</i> in the mishna <b>agree with regard to one who engages in sexual relations with a menstruating woman,</b>

Daf 49b

<b>or with a <i>sota</i>, that the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
With regard to <b>a menstruating woman</b> the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i> <b>because</b> one’s <b>betrothal of her takes effect, as it is stated: “And her impurity shall be upon him”</b> (Leviticus 15:24). The phrase “shall be” alludes to the fact that a betrothal with her takes effect. The verse teaches that <b>even at the time of her</b> menstrual <b>impurity, betrothal with her takes effect.</b>
With regard to <b>a <i>sota</i>, too,</b> the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i> <b>because</b> one’s <b>betrothal of her takes effect.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>This</b> teaching of Abaye <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All agree with regard to one who engages in sexual relations with a menstruating woman, or with a <i>sota</i>, or with a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i></b> to perform levirate marriage, <b>that the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>And Abaye</b> did not mention the case of a <b>widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i></b> because <b>he is uncertain whether,</b> if someone other than the <i>yavam</i> betrothed her, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> that it does not take effect or <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> that it might take effect.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai said:</b> I found a scroll recording people’s lineages. The Gemara cites an expanded version of the contents of the scroll. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai said: I found a scroll</b> recording people’s <b>lineages, in Jerusalem, and it was written in it</b> that <b>so-and-so is a <i>mamzer</i> from</b> an adulterous union with <b>a married woman. And it was</b> also <b>written in it: The teachings of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov</b> measure only <b>a <i>kav</i> but are clean</b> and accurate, and so the <i>halakha</i> is decided in accordance with his opinions. <b>And it was written in it: Manasseh,</b> king of Israel, <b>killed Isaiah</b> the prophet.
The Gemara expands on the events surrounding Isaiah’s death: <b>Rava said:</b> Manasseh <b>judged him</b> as a false witness for issuing statements contradicting the Torah <b>and</b> only then <b>killed him.</b> Manasseh <b>said to</b> Isaiah: <b>Moses your master said</b> in the Torah: “And He said: You cannot see My face, <b>for man cannot see Me and live”</b> (Exodus 33:20), <b>and</b> yet <b>you said: “I saw the Lord sitting upon a high and lofty throne”</b> (Isaiah 6:1). <b>Moses your master said:</b> “For <b>which</b> great nation is there, that has God so near to it, <b>as the Lord our God is, whenever we call upon Him?”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:7), <b>and</b> yet <b>you said: “Seek the Lord while He may be found, call upon Him while He is near”</b> (Isaiah 55:6), which implies that God is not always near. <b>Moses your master said: “I will fulfill the number of your days”</b> (Exodus 23:26), which implies that each individual has a preordained allotted lifespan that he cannot outlive, <b>and</b> yet <b>you said</b> in a prophecy to King Hezekiah: <b>“And I will add to your days, fifteen years”</b> (II Kings 20:6).
<b>Isaiah said</b> to himself: <b>I know him,</b> i.e., Manasseh, <b>that he will not accept whatever</b> explanation <b>that I will say to him</b> to resolve my prophecies with the words of the Torah. <b>And</b> even <b>if I say it to him, I will make him into an intentional transgressor</b> since he will kill me anyway. Therefore, in order to escape, <b>he uttered a</b> divine <b>name</b> and <b>was swallowed within a cedar</b> tree. Manasseh’s servants <b>brought the cedar</b> tree <b>and sawed through it</b> in order to kill him. <b>When</b> the saw <b>reached to where his mouth was,</b> Isaiah <b>died.</b> He died specifically at this point <b>due to that which he said: “In the midst of a people of unclean lips, I dwell”</b> (Isaiah 6:5). He was punished for referring to the Jewish people in a derogatory manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>In any case,</b> as Manasseh pointed out, these <b>verses contradict each other;</b> how are these contradictions to be resolved?
The Gemara resolves the first contradiction: <b>“I saw the Lord”</b> is to be understood <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All of the prophets observed</b> their prophecies <b>through an obscure looking glass [<i>aspaklaria</i>],</b> i.e., their prophecies were given as metaphoric visions but were not a direct perception of the matter. However, <b>Moses our master observed</b> his prophecies <b>through a clear looking glass,</b> i.e., he gained a direct and accurate perception of the matter.
The Gemara resolves the second contradiction: Isaiah’s prophecy: <b>“Seek the Lord while He may be found,”</b> does not contradict the verse in the Torah that God is near to His nation “whenever we call upon Him,” because <b>this</b> prophecy of Isaiah was made <b>with regard to the individual</b> and <b>this</b> verse in the Torah is stated <b>with regard to a community,</b> as the prayer of the community is always accepted. The Gemara asks: <b>And when</b> is the time that God is to be found near <b>the individual? Rav Naḥman said Rabba bar Avuh said: These are the ten days between Rosh HaShana and Yom Kippur.</b>
The resolution of the third contradiction from the verse: <b>“I will fulfill the number of your days,” is</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“I will fulfill the number of your days”;</b>

Daf 50a

<b>these are</b> the <b>years of</b> the <b>generations,</b> i.e., the allotted lifespan that is preordained for each individual before birth. If <b>he is deserving,</b> God <b>completes his</b> allotted lifespan. If <b>he is not deserving,</b> God <b>reduces his</b> lifespan; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b> Rabbi Akiva assumes one cannot outlive one’s preordained allotted lifespan. <b>The Rabbis say:</b> If <b>he is deserving,</b> God <b>adds</b> years <b>to his</b> lifespan. If <b>he is not deserving,</b> God <b>reduces his</b> lifespan. According to the Rabbis, Isaiah’s prophecy is referring to one who deserved to have extra years added to his allotted lifespan, and the verse in the Torah is referring to one who deserved to merely complete his lifespan.
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Akiva:</b> How can you claim that one cannot outlive one’s allotted lifespan when <b>there is</b> a verse that <b>states</b> that Isaiah prophesied to Hezekiah as Hezekiah lay on his deathbed: <b>“And I will add unto your days fifteen years”?</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to them:</b> Those additional years that God <b>added to his</b> lifespan are <b>from his own</b> allotted lifespan. When Hezekiah sinned God decreed that his lifespan be shortened, but when he repented God allowed him to live out those years. <b>Know</b> that this is so, <b>as a prophet</b> during the reign of King Jeroboam <b>stood and prophesied: “Behold, a son shall be born unto the House of David, Josiah is his name”</b> (I Kings 13:2). Josiah was the grandson of Manasseh, Hezekiah’s son, and at the time Hezekiah lay on his deathbed, <b>Manasseh had not yet been born.</b> Evidently, Hezekiah’s preordained allotted lifespan had still not been completed.
<b>And</b> what would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to Rabbi Akiva’s proof? They could counter: <b>Is it written</b> that Josiah was to be born specifically <b>from</b> the descendants of <b>Hezekiah? It is written</b> only that he would be born <b>“unto the House of David,”</b> so <b>he could be born either from</b> the descendants of <b>Hezekiah or from a different person</b> of the House of David. Accordingly, no proof concerning Hezekiah’s allotted lifespan can be deduced from that verse.
§ The mishna details the prohibition with regard to one’s wife’s sister in various cases: If a man’s <b>wife died,</b> he is permitted to her sister; if <b>his <i>yevama</i> died,</b> he is permitted to her sister. <b>Rav Yosef said: Here Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught an unnecessary mishna,</b> since the prohibition with regard to one’s wife’s sister and the fact that the prohibition exists only in the lifetime of one’s wife is stated explicitly in the Torah, and there is no additional novelty in this mishna’s ruling.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabban Gamliel says: A bill of divorce [<i>get</i>] is not</b> effective when given <b>after a bill of divorce</b> was previously given to a <i>yevama</i>. Once a <i>yevama</i> receives a bill of divorce from a <i>yavam</i>, no bill of divorce given by that <i>yavam</i> to her rival wife or a bill of divorce given to her by a different <i>yavam</i> is of any effect. <b>And levirate betrothal is not</b> effective <b>after</b> a previous <b>levirate betrothal</b> was performed, <b>and intercourse</b> with a second <i>yevama</i> <b>is not</b> effective <b>after intercourse</b> with the first one, <b>and <i>ḥalitza</i> is not</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i></b> was previously performed. <b>But the Rabbis say: A bill of divorce is</b> effective when given <b>after a bill of divorce, and levirate betrothal is</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal, but nothing is</b> effective <b>after intercourse or after <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> If a <i>yavam</i> has relations with the <i>yevama</i> or performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, no other action performed afterward is effective, whether performed by that <i>yavam</i> toward a different <i>yevama</i> or by any <i>yavam</i> with the original <i>yevama</i>.
The mishna elaborates: <b>How</b> do these laws work in practice? If a <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i>, and he</b> later <b>gave her a bill of divorce, she</b> nevertheless <b>requires <i>ḥalitza</i> from him.</b> The bill of divorce does not fully exempt her from levirate marriage, as the levirate bond remains intact. If <b>he performed levirate betrothal and</b> then <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, she requires a bill of divorce from him</b> in order to cancel the levirate betrothal. If the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate betrothal and</b> then engaged in <b>intercourse</b> with the <i>yevama</i>, <b>this is</b> the way to perform levirate marriage <b>in accordance with its mitzva,</b> as the Sages instituted this as the proper procedure for a <i>yavam</i> to perform levirate marriage.
If the <i>yavam</i> <b>gave</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>a bill of divorce and</b> afterward <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> with her, <b>she requires</b> another <b>bill of divorce</b> to cancel the levirate betrothal, as well as <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> to nullify the levirate bond. If <b>he gave</b> her <b>a bill of divorce and</b> then <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her, <b>she requires a bill of divorce</b> to cancel the betrothal that took place via intercourse, <b>and <i>ḥalitza</i></b> to nullify the levirate bond; the intercourse did not affect the levirate bond because once he gave her a bill of divorce she was forbidden to him. If <b>he gave</b> her <b>a bill of divorce and performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as the levirate bond was completely nullified.
Similarly, if he <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with her <b>and</b> then either <b>performed levirate betrothal,</b> or <b>gave a bill of divorce, or engaged in intercourse</b> with her; <b>alternatively,</b> if he <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her <b>and</b> then either <b>performed levirate betrothal,</b> or <b>gave a bill of divorce, or performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> after they engaged in relations, <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i></b> or intercourse. Any action performed afterward is unrelated to the levirate bond.

Daf 50b

The above principles apply <b>both</b> in cases of <b>one <i>yevama</i> to one <i>yavam</i>, as well as</b> in cases of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> to one <i>yavam</i>. How so?</b> If <b>he performed levirate betrothal with this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>and levirate betrothal with that</b> one, i.e., her rival wife, <b>they require two bills of divorce,</b> each for her own levirate betrothal, <b>and <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of them, to release them both from the levirate bond. If he performed <b>levirate betrothal with this</b> one <b>and</b> gave <b>a bill of divorce to that</b> one, the first woman <b>requires a bill of divorce</b> to cancel the levirate betrothal, <b>and</b> one of them must receive <b><i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> If he performed <b>levirate betrothal with this</b> one <b>and engaged in intercourse with that</b> one, <b>they require two bills of divorce and</b> he must perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of them. If the <i>yavam</i> performed <b>levirate betrothal with this</b> one <b>and performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with that</b> one, <b>the first</b> woman <b>requires a bill of divorce.</b>
If the <i>yavam</i> gave <b>a bill of divorce to this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>and a bill of divorce to that</b> one, <b>they require <i>ḥalitza</i> from him.</b> If he gave <b>a bill of divorce to this</b> one <b>and engaged in intercourse with that</b> one, the latter <b>requires a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> If he gave <b>a bill of divorce to this</b> one <b>and</b> performed <b>levirate betrothal with that</b> one, the latter <b>requires a bill of divorce and</b> he must perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of them. If the <i>yavam</i> gave <b>a bill of divorce to this</b> woman <b>and performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with that</b> one, <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> and he cannot betroth the rival wife.
If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> then <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with a second <i>yevama</i>, <b>or he performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> then proceeded to either <b>perform levirate betrothal, give a bill of divorce, or engage in intercourse</b> with a second; <b>alternatively, he engaged in intercourse</b> with one <i>yevama</i> and <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with the second <i>yevama</i>, <b>or he engaged in intercourse</b> with one <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> proceeded to either <b>perform levirate betrothal, give a bill of divorce, or perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the second, <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i></b> or intercourse. These <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>both</b> in cases of <b>one <i>yavam</i> to two <i>yevamot</i>, as well as two <i>yevamin</i> to one <i>yevama</i>.</b>
If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> then proceeded to either <b>perform levirate betrothal, give a bill of divorce, or engage in intercourse</b> with a second <i>yevama</i>; <b>alternatively, he engaged in intercourse</b> with one <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> then proceeded to <b>perform levirate betrothal, or give a bill of divorce, or perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with a second <i>yevama</i>, <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>, whether</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> took place <b>at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end.</b> All of these <i>halakhot</i> accord with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, who maintains betrothal does not take effect on a woman who is forbidden due to the prohibition against betrothing a <i>yevama</i> after <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>But</b> with regard to <b>intercourse, when it is at the beginning,</b> i.e., the first act the <i>yavam</i> performed with his <i>yevama</i>, <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after it</b> and any subsequent action is void. However, if it was performed <b>in the middle, and</b> similarly if it was performed <b>at the end,</b> i.e., after some other action that impairs the validity of his intercourse, <b>something is</b> effective <b>after it. Rabbi Neḥemya says: Both</b> with regard to <b>intercourse and <i>ḥalitza</i>, whether</b> performed <b>at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end, nothing is</b> effective <b>after it.</b> If the <i>yavam</i> performed a valid action according to Torah law, any subsequent action is of no consequence according to <i>halakha</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Rabban Gamliel and the Rabbis <b>disagree only with regard to</b> the efficacy of <b>a bill of divorce</b> performed <b>after a bill of divorce and levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>after levirate betrothal, but one bill of divorce</b> given <b>to a</b> single <b><i>yevama</i>, or one levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>with a</b> single <b><i>yevama</i>, is effective.</b> The bill of divorce prevents him from performing levirate marriage, and the levirate betrothal requires a bill of divorce to cancel it, in addition to <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>What is the reason that the Sages said</b> that <b>a bill of divorce is effective for a <i>yevama</i>,</b> despite the fact that she is not his wife? This is <b>because it is effective in general</b> in cases of married women. <b>For if you say</b> that <b>it is not effective</b> in the case of a <i>yevama</i>, there are some who might mistakenly <b>say</b> the following: <b>A bill of divorce</b> is given to a woman in order <b>to remove her</b> from her husband, <b>and <i>ḥalitza</i></b> likewise serves <b>to remove her</b> from the <i>yavam</i>; <b>since a bill of divorce is ineffective</b> for this <i>yevama</i>, <b><i>ḥalitza</i> is also ineffective</b> and does not sever their relationship completely. <b>And</b> perhaps the <i>yavam</i> <b>will come to engage in intercourse after <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> which is forbidden by the Torah prohibition derived from the verse: “So shall it be done to the man who does not build his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9).
<b>And what is the reason the Sages said</b> that <b>levirate betrothal is effective for a <i>yevama</i>? Because it is effective in general,</b> as levirate betrothal is essentially an act of betrothal. <b>For if you say</b> that <b>it is not effective,</b> there are some who might mistakenly <b>say: Levirate betrothal serves to acquire</b> a woman <b>and intercourse</b> serves <b>to acquire</b> a woman in general, as women can be betrothed by intercourse; <b>since levirate betrothal is ineffective</b> in the case of a <i>yevama</i>, <b>intercourse is also ineffective,</b> i.e., it does not acquire a <i>yevama</i> completely. <b>And</b> he will therefore <b>come to engage in intercourse</b> with a rival wife <b>after intercourse</b> with the first <i>yevama</i>.
<b>And what is the reason the Sages</b> who disagree with Rabbi Neḥemya <b>said</b> that <b>invalid intercourse,</b> i.e., intercourse that follows any disqualifying action with the rival wife of a <i>yevama</i>, does not fully acquire the <i>yevama</i>, such that <b>something is</b> effective <b>after it?</b> In this case the invalid intercourse does not cancel the levirate bond, and therefore further action with the <i>yevama</i> is effective.
The Sages <b>say: If this is intercourse</b> performed <b>after a bill of divorce,</b> then it is considered invalid due to <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to <b>intercourse after a bill of divorce because</b> of its potential confusion with a case of <b>intercourse after <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Sages established that invalid intercourse of this kind should not cancel the levirate bond completely, for if it did, then people might come to engage in intercourse after <i>ḥalitza</i>, which would violate a Torah prohibition. <b>And if this is intercourse</b> performed <b>after levirate betrothal,</b> then it is considered invalid due to <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to <b>intercourse after levirate betrothal because</b> of its potential confusion with a case of <b>intercourse</b> with the second <i>yevama</i> <b>after intercourse</b> with the first. If intercourse after levirate betrothal is effective, people might come to engage in intercourse with a second <i>yevama</i> after intercourse with a first, and this is forbidden as the woman is considered his brother’s wife who is not eligible for levirate marriage.
<b>And what is the reason the Sages said</b> with regard to <b>this invalid <i>ḥalitza</i></b> that <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after it?</b> For they <b>say: What</b> is the reason that <b>we should issue a decree</b> in that case? <b>Should we issue a decree</b> with regard to <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>after a bill of divorce due to</b> a concern for <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>?</b> In this case there is no concern, as there is no prohibition involved in repeating <i>ḥalitza</i>. In <b>any</b> situation <b>like these, let her continue performing <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> for no harm is done if <i>ḥalitza</i> is performed unnecessarily.
Alternatively, <b>should we issue a decree</b> stating that other actions are effective after <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> is performed <b>after levirate betrothal due to</b> the concern for confusion with the case of <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> performed <b>after intercourse?</b> In this case there is a concern that people will assume that no bill of divorce is required after intercourse so long as the <i>yavam</i> performed <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara challenges this concern: <b>Is that to say</b> that in the case of <b><i>ḥalitza</i> after levirate betrothal she does not require a bill of divorce for his levirate betrothal,</b> such that one would conclude the same for <i>ḥalitza</i> after intercourse? In the case of <i>ḥalitza</i> after levirate betrothal, the woman requires a bill of divorce, and similarly in the case of <b><i>ḥalitza</i> after intercourse she likewise requires a bill of divorce for his intercourse.</b> Thus, the same action performed following <i>ḥalitza</i> after levirate betrothal is also performed following <i>ḥalitza</i> after intercourse, and therefore there is no need to issue a further decree.
§ <b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 51a

<b>What is the reason</b> for the ruling of <b>Rabban Gamliel</b> that a bill of divorce is not effective after a bill of divorce? It is <b>because he is uncertain</b> with regard to <b>a bill of divorce whether</b> it effectively <b>precludes</b> levirate marriage or <b>whether</b> it <b>does not preclude</b> levirate marriage. Similarly, he is uncertain with regard to <b>levirate betrothal, whether it</b> effectively <b>acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>or does not acquire</b> her at all. The Gemara clarifies: With regard to <b>a bill of divorce,</b> he is uncertain as to <b>whether it precludes</b> levirate marriage <b>or does not preclude</b> it. <b>If the first</b> bill of divorce <b>precludes</b> levirate marriage<b>, what did he do</b> by giving <b>the latter</b> bill of divorce, <b>as</b> it has no substance? Alternatively, <b>if the first</b> bill of divorce <b>does not preclude</b> levirate marriage, <b>neither does the latter preclude</b> levirate marriage.
Likewise, with regard to <b>levirate betrothal,</b> he is uncertain as to <b>whether it acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>or does not acquire</b> her. <b>If the first</b> levirate betrothal effectively <b>acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i>, <b>what does the last one accomplish? And if the first one does not acquire</b> her, <b>the last one also does not acquire</b> her. For this reason Rabban Gamliel maintains that a bill of divorce is not effective after a bill of divorce was given, and similarly levirate betrothal is not effective after levirate betrothal was performed.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> his opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And Rabban Gamliel concedes that a bill of divorce is</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal and levirate betrothal is</b> effective <b>after a bill of divorce.</b> If a <i>yavam</i> gave a bill of divorce to one <i>yevama</i> and then performed levirate betrothal with the other, or the reverse, both actions would be effective. <b>And</b> he also concedes that <b>a bill of divorce is</b> effective <b>after intercourse and levirate betrothal</b> such that if the <i>yavam</i> engaged in levirate betrothal with one <i>yevama</i>, engaged in intercourse with a second, and gave a bill of divorce to a third, the bill of divorce is effective and he is prohibited from marrying the relatives of the third <i>yevama</i>. <b>And</b> he concedes <b>that levirate betrothal is</b> effective <b>after intercourse and a bill of divorce,</b> such that if he gave a bill of divorce to one woman, engaged in intercourse with a second, and performed levirate betrothal with a third, the levirate betrothal is effective and the third woman requires a bill of divorce.
<b>And if Rabban Gamliel is uncertain</b> with regard to the efficacy of levirate betrothal or a bill of divorce, then the third action should never be effective. Either the initial levirate betrothal or bill of divorce was completely effective, in which case any subsequent action is not effective, or these actions are not effective at all and the intercourse that followed them <b>should be like intercourse</b> performed <b>at the beginning, and</b> it should serve to <b>acquire</b> the <i>yevama</i> completely, and any actions performed afterward with the rival wife should be of no account. <b>For we learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>intercourse, when it is at the beginning, nothing is</b> effective <b>after it.</b> Consequently, Rabban Gamliel’s ruling is difficult.
<b>Rather, Abaye said: Actually, it is obvious to Rabban Gamliel that a bill of divorce precludes</b> levirate marriage, <b>and that levirate betrothal acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i>. <b>Nevertheless, the Sages said</b> that with regard to <b>this <i>yevama</i>, in one respect a bill of divorce is effective for her, and in another respect levirate betrothal is effective for her,</b> but they are not effective in the same manner. Therefore, <b>a bill of divorce</b> given <b>after a bill of divorce does not preclude</b> levirate marriage, <b>as the first</b> bill of divorce <b>has</b> already <b>precluded</b> it <b>for him</b> as much as he can preclude it by means of a bill of divorce. <b>And levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>after levirate betrothal does not acquire</b> her<b>, as the first</b> levirate betrothal <b>has acquired</b> her <b>for him</b> as much as possible. However, with regard to <b>a bill of divorce after levirate betrothal, and levirate betrothal after a bill of divorce, this action precludes</b> levirate marriage <b>and that action acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i>. Since the acquisition of levirate betrothal and the nullification of a bill of divorce work in different ways, there can be both an acquisition and a nullification, and therefore one can be effective after the other.
<b>However, the Rabbis</b> maintain that <b>the Sages instituted for each and every one</b> of the brothers-in-law both the nullification of <b>a bill of divorce and</b> the acquisition of <b>levirate betrothal for a <i>yevama</i>,</b> and they decreed that these should be effective for each of the <i>yevamot</i>. Therefore the strength of the first bill of divorce or levirate betrothal is equal to that of the second one, and both are effective.
Abaye proceeds to explain the rest of Rabban Gamliel’s teaching in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And this invalid intercourse,</b> i.e., intercourse that was performed after a disqualifying action, such as levirate betrothal or a bill of divorce, <b>is superior to levirate betrothal and</b> also <b>inferior to levirate betrothal:</b> It is <b>preferable to levirate betrothal</b> in the following respect: <b>whereas levirate betrothal after levirate betrothal is not effective</b> at all, <b>intercourse after levirate betrothal is effective,</b> because intercourse acquires a <i>yevama</i> according to Torah law. <b>And</b> it is <b>inferior to levirate betrothal, for whereas levirate betrothal after a bill of divorce</b> according to Rabban Gamliel <b>acquires the entire remainder</b> of the woman left <b>by the bill of divorce,</b> such that any further levirate betrothal would be ineffective, <b>intercourse after a bill of divorce does not acquire the entire remainder</b> of the woman left <b>by the bill of divorce,</b> as it is not considered valid intercourse, and a subsequent levirate betrothal is effective.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How,</b> i.e., in what case, <b>did Rabban Gamliel say</b> that <b>a bill of divorce is not</b> effective <b>after a bill of divorce?</b> In the case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> who happened before one <i>yavam</i> and he gave a bill of divorce to this one and a bill of divorce to that one. Rabban Gamliel says: He performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first one and is forbidden to</b> marry <b>her relatives,</b> as she is his <i>ḥalutza</i>, <b>and he is permitted to</b> marry <b>the relatives of the second one.</b> Because the bill of divorce he gave the second woman is of no consequence at all, she is merely the rival wife of his <i>ḥalutza</i>, and he is therefore permitted to marry her relatives.
<b>But the Rabbis say:</b> If <b>he gave a bill of divorce to this one and a bill of divorce to that one, he is forbidden</b> to marry <b>the relatives of both of them, and</b> he must perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i> with one of them. And you</b> would <b>say the same with regard to two <i>yevamim</i> and one <i>yevama</i>.</b> If the two <i>yevamin</i> gave one <i>yevama</i> a bill of divorce, one after the other, Rabban Gamliel maintains that the bill of divorce of the second <i>yavam</i> is of no account, and he is therefore permitted to marry her relatives, whereas the Rabbis hold that it is effective in that it renders him forbidden to her relatives.
<b>How,</b> with regard to what circumstance, <b>did Rabban Gamliel say</b> that <b>there is no levirate betrothal after levirate betrothal?</b> In a case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> who happened before one <i>yavam</i>, and he performed levirate betrothal with this one and levirate betrothal with that one, Rabban Gamliel says: He gives a bill of divorce to the first one and performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her, and is forbidden to her relatives, but</b> he <b>is permitted to the relatives of</b> the <b>second one,</b> as the levirate betrothal performed with the rival wife is ineffective. <b>But the Rabbis say: He gives a bill of divorce to both of them,</b> as the levirate betrothal is effective for both women, <b>and he is forbidden to the relatives of both of them; and</b> as for <b><i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> he must perform it <b>with one of them. And you</b> would <b>say the same with regard to two <i>yevamim</i> and one <i>yevama</i>.</b> If the first <i>yavam</i> performed levirate betrothal with the <i>yevama</i>, and the second <i>yavam</i> consequently performed levirate betrothal with her, they are both required to give her a bill of divorce and both are forbidden to marry her relatives.
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>He gives a bill of divorce to this one and a bill of divorce to that one. Rabban Gamliel says: He performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first one and is forbidden to</b> marry <b>her relatives, and</b> he <b>is permitted to</b> marry <b>the relatives of the second one.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say that</b> this <b>is a conclusive refutation of</b> the statement of <b>Shmuel? For Shmuel said:</b> If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the woman who received a bill of divorce, the rival wife is not exempted</b> by this invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>. The <i>yavam</i> must therefore repeat the <i>ḥalitza</i> with the rival wife as well. This appears to contradict the <i>baraita</i>, where Rabban Gamliel rules that he has to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with only one of the <i>yevamot</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: When I said</b> my above teaching, it was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the one who said that the levirate bond is substantial,</b> and he must therefore perform a valid <i>ḥalitza</i> in order to cancel this bond. A <i>ḥalitza</i> performed with a woman who received a bill of divorce is not powerful enough to completely cancel the bond of the rival wife who did not performed <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>But Rabban Gamliel holds</b> that <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> and therefore any <i>ḥalitza</i> that releases one of the women also serves to release the other.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>from</b> the fact that <b>Rabban Gamliel holds</b> that <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b>

Daf 51b

it can be inferred that <b>the Rabbis hold that the levirate bond is substantial,</b> as it is assumed that they disagree with Rabban Gamliel in this regard as well. <b>And the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: And you</b> would <b>say the same with regard to two <i>yevamin</i> and one <i>yevama</i></b> such that if the two <i>yevamin</i> gave one <i>yevama</i> a bill of divorce, she is exempted by the <i>ḥalitza</i> of one of them. If so, <b>let us say that it is a conclusive refutation of</b> the statement that <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> said that <b>Rav said. For Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In cases of <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>is required to repeat</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with all the brothers.</b> If the <i>ḥalitza</i> was invalid for some reason, all the brothers must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the <i>yevama</i>, as her bond with them is not canceled by an invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: Both Rabban Gamliel and the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> whereas my statement is in accordance with the opinion that the levirate bond is substantial. <b>And here</b> the dispute does not concern the topic of the levirate bond at all, but rather it only involves the explicitly mentioned issue: They <b>disagree with regard to</b> the efficacy of <b>a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce and levirate betrothal after levirate betrothal.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he performed levirate betrothal with this one and levirate betrothal with that one, Rabban Gamliel says: He gives a bill of divorce to the first one and performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her and is forbidden to her relatives, but he is permitted to the relatives of the second one.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>Since Rabban Gamliel holds</b> that <b>levirate betrothal is not</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal,</b> and the second levirate betrothal is of no consequence, the <b>first</b> woman <b>should also be permitted to enter into levirate marriage.</b> Why must he perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her? The Gemara answers: It is prohibited due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest he perform levirate marriage with the second</b> woman. The Sages were concerned that in cases where the <i>yavam</i> performed levirate betrothal with both women, if he were permitted to consummate the levirate marriage with the first woman, he might do so with the second woman as well.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabban Gamliel, and Beit Shammai, and Rabbi Shimon, and ben Azzai, and Rabbi Neḥemya, they all hold</b> that <b>levirate betrothal acquires</b> the <i>yevama</i> as <b>a full-fledged acquisition,</b> like a regular betrothal. The source for <b>Rabban Gamliel’s</b> opinion is <b>that which we said</b> above, that levirate betrothal is not effective after levirate betrothal. Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that the second levirate betrothal is not effective because she was already fully acquired by the first one.
The source for the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: In the case of <b>three brothers, two</b> of whom <b>were married to two sisters, and one who was single,</b> the following occurred: <b>The husband of one of the sisters died</b> childless, leaving behind his wife, <b>and the single</b> brother <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> with this wife. <b>Afterward, the second brother died,</b> whereby the second brother’s wife, the sister of the betrothed, happened before him for levirate marriage as well. In this case, <b>Beit Shammai say: His wife remains with him,</b> i.e., the woman he betrothed is considered like his wife, and he is not required to divorce her. <b>And this other leaves</b> the <i>yavam</i> and is exempt from levirate marriage <b>due to</b> the fact that she is <b>the sister of a wife.</b> This indicates that Beit Shammai hold that the levirate betrothal performed with the first woman makes her fully betrothed, thereby nullifying the levirate bond with her sister.
The source for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> is based on the following case cited in a mishna (96b): In the case of a boy aged nine years and one day old who had relations with his <i>yevama</i>, and afterward his brother, who is also nine years and one day old, had relations with her, the second brother disqualifies her from performing levirate marriage with the first one. Rabbi Shimon says he does not disqualify her. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon said to the Rabbis: If the intercourse of</b> the <b>first</b> brother is considered effective <b>intercourse, the intercourse of</b> the <b>second</b> brother <b>is not</b> considered effective <b>intercourse</b> such that it would disqualify her from performing levirate marriage with the first brother, as the first brother has already acquired her through his intercourse. <b>If the intercourse of</b> the <b>first</b> brother <b>is not</b> considered effective <b>intercourse, the intercourse of</b> the <b>second</b> brother <b>is also not</b> effective <b>intercourse. And the Sages considered the intercourse of a nine-year-old</b> boy to be <b>like levirate betrothal, and Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the intercourse of the second boy <b>is not</b> considered <b>intercourse.</b> This proves that in his opinion the intercourse of a nine-year-old fully acquires the <i>yevama</i>, and similarly, so does levirate betrothal.
This source for <b>ben Azzai’s</b> opinion is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Azzai says: Levirate betrothal is</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal</b> in the case of <b>two <i>yevamin</i> and one <i>yevama</i>, but levirate betrothal is not</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal</b> in the case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> and one <i>yavam</i>.</b> Because the latter case involves only one <i>yavam</i>, his levirate betrothal fully acquires the <i>yevama</i>, and therefore the levirate betrothal he performs with the second woman is of no account, as he is already betrothed to the first <i>yevama</i>. The source for <b>Rabbi Neḥemya’s</b> opinion is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> With regard to <b>both intercourse and <i>ḥalitza</i>, whether at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end, nothing is</b> effective <b>after it. And the Sages considered invalid intercourse</b> to be <b>like levirate betrothal, and</b> Rabbi Neḥemya <b>teaches</b> that <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after it.</b> This indicates that he maintains that no form of acquisition is effective after levirate betrothal, as levirate betrothal completely acquires the <i>yevama</i>.
§ The mishna states: <b>How so?</b> If he <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> with his <i>yevama</i> and gave her a bill of divorce, <b>etc.</b>

Daf 52a

The Gemara is puzzled: Is <b>this case</b> upon which the mishna elaborates the case of <b>a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce</b> that is mentioned first in the mishna? The mishna first is referring to a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce, but when it comes to the specifics, it mentions a bill of divorce after levirate betrothal. <b>Rav Yehuda said: This is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce, and levirate betrothal after levirate betrothal,</b> it is <b>as we said</b> and these cases were explained in the <i>baraita</i>, but with regard to <b>one <i>yavam</i> and one <i>yevama</i>, how is their</b> complex bond <b>released?</b> He then proceeds to delineate: If <b>he performed levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> and gave her a bill of divorce, she requires <i>ḥalitza</i> from him.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate betrothal and engaged in intercourse, this is</b> done <b>in accordance with its mitzva.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that</b> this mishna <b>supports</b> the statement of <b>Rav Huna. As Rav Huna said: The mitzva of a <i>yevama</i> is</b> properly performed when the <i>yavam</i> <b>betroths</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>and</b> only <b>afterward engages in intercourse.</b> This statement indicates that the levirate betrothal is a necessary component of the mitzva, and the mishna seems to imply the same. The Gemara refutes this claim: This is not necessarily the case, as you can read the mishna as stating that <b>this also is in accordance with its mitzva.</b> If he performed levirate betrothal and then engaged in intercourse, this too is a proper manner to proceed, but we do not have to interpret the mishna as indicating that this is the only way to fulfill the mitzva.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious?</b> If one can fulfill the mitzva without performing levirate betrothal, why would one think that levirate betrothal is detrimental? The Gemara answers: It was indeed necessary for the mishna to teach us this, for it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since the Master said</b> above (29b): <b>One who performs levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> causes the levirate bond to dissipate from himself, and a</b> standard <b>bond of betrothal and marriage takes effect on him,</b> you might <b>say</b> that he <b>no</b> longer <b>performs a mitzva</b> when he carries out levirate marriage, as the levirate bond is no longer in place. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that we consider the levirate betrothal and the subsequent intercourse as part of the same process, which constitutes a mitzva.
The Gemara continues: With regard to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself, Rav Huna said: The mitzva of levirate marriage</b> is properly performed when the <i>yavam</i> <b>betroths</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>and afterward engages in intercourse, and if he engaged in intercourse and</b> later <b>performed levirate betrothal, he has acquired</b> the <i>yevama</i>. The Gemara is puzzled: <b>If he engaged in intercourse and</b> then <b>performed levirate betrothal it is obvious</b> that he has acquired her, <b>as he has</b> already <b>acquired her by intercourse.</b> The levirate betrothal does not affect the issue one way or another. <b>Rather, say</b> as follows: <b>If he engaged in intercourse without</b> prior <b>levirate betrothal,</b> even in that case <b>he has acquired</b> her.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that a <i>yavam</i> who has intercourse without levirate betrothal <b>is flogged?</b> The Gemara answers: The lashes are not because he transgressed by not performing levirate betrothal, but rather they are <b>lashes for rebelliousness</b> given for transgressing a <b>rabbinic</b> law, namely for acting in an immodest manner.
The Gemara cites other instances where the Sages administered lashes for immodest behavior. <b>As Rav</b> would <b>flog one who betroths</b> a woman <b>by intercourse,</b> despite the fact that betrothal is effective by this method, because he acted in a promiscuous manner. <b>And</b> he would likewise <b>flog one who betroths</b> a woman <b>in the marketplace,</b> rather than at home, as this too is loose behavior, <b>and</b> he would also administer lashes <b>to one who betroths</b> a woman <b>without</b> a prior <b>marriage agreement</b> [<b><i>shiddukhei</i></b>], as this too is an act of permissiveness.
<b>And</b> he would further lash <b>one who nullifies a bill of divorce</b> he had earlier sent by declaring in the presence of witnesses that the bill of divorce is nullified. This action is effective, but by doing so he transgresses the rabbinic ordinance of the Sages that bans such an action as it might lead his wife to unlawfully wed another. <b>And</b> he would also flog <b>one who delivers a declaration</b> preemptively invalidating <b>a bill of divorce,</b> by informing three people before giving a bill of divorce that he is not doing so of his own free will and he wants to cancel it ahead of time. Here too he will mislead his wife, who will assume it is a valid bill of divorce.
<b>And</b> he would lash <b>one who behaves irreverently</b> toward <b>a messenger of the Sages,</b> even if the messenger is not a scholar, as he thereby shows disrespect to the Sages themselves. <b>And</b> he would administer lashes to <b>one who remained under an excommunication of the Sages</b> for <b>thirty days and did not go to the court and petition for</b> the removal of <b>his excommunication after</b> correcting the sin that led to the excommunication in the first place. This behavior demonstrates that he does not care about the excommunication, and is therefore deserving of lashes.
<b>And</b> he would also lash <b>a son-in-law who lives in his father-in-law’s house,</b> as this is likely to lead to temptation between the younger couple and older couple who share the same house. The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>one who lives</b> in his father-in-law’s house, <b>yes,</b> he would lash him, but with regard to <b>one who</b> only <b>passed</b> through his father-in-law’s house at regular intervals, <b>no,</b> he would not lash him? <b>But</b> an incident occurred involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who passed by the entrance to his father-in-law’s house and Rav Sheshet lashed him.</b> The Gemara explains: There was a special set of circumstances in that case, as <b>that</b> man <b>was suspected with regard to his mother-in-law,</b> and therefore he was lashed merely for passing near her house, as he thereby gave credence to the rumors.
The Sages <b>of Neharde’a</b> would <b>say: In all</b> these cases <b>Rav would not flog, apart from</b> the case of one who <b>betrothed by intercourse and without</b> a prior <b>marriage agreement. And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> he would flog a man who betrothed by intercourse <b>even</b> if he did so <b>with</b> a prior <b>marriage agreement, due to the immorality</b> involved, as he must invite witnesses to observe the act.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How</b> is <b>levirate betrothal</b> performed? <b>He gives her money or the equivalent</b> value of <b>money</b> and declares: You are hereby betrothed to me. The Gemara asks: <b>And with a document, how</b> does he betroth her? The Gemara is puzzled by this question: <b>With a document, how</b> does he betroth her? It is <b>as we have said</b> by the <i>halakhot</i> of a regular document of betrothal: If <b>he wrote to her on paper or on earthenware, even though it is not worth a <i>peruta</i>,</b> the words: <b>You are hereby betrothed to me,</b> it is effective. As a document is not effective as a means of betrothal due to its monetary value but rather due to the words it contains, there is no requirement that it be of a minimum value. However, because the <i>halakhot</i> of betrothal by a document were already taught, the Gemara is puzzled as to the nature of this question. <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>the document of a marriage contract for levirate marriage, how</b> is it written? Abaye understands that the question did not refer to the document of betrothal but rather to the marriage contract of a levirate marriage.
The Gemara explains that <b>he writes to her: I, so-and-so, son of so-and-so, have accepted so-and-so, my <i>yevama</i> upon me, to feed and maintain her in a fitting manner, provided that her marriage contract will</b> still <b>be</b> payable <b>from the property of her first husband</b> and not from the property of the <i>yavam</i>. The Gemara adds: <b>But if the first</b> husband <b>does not have</b> property, <b>the Sages instituted for her</b> that she should receive her marriage contract <b>from the second</b> husband, i.e., the <i>yavam</i>, for the same reason that they instituted the marriage contract in the first place: <b>So that she will not be demeaned in his eyes such that</b> he will easily <b>divorce her.</b> If he will suffer no financial penalty, he is likely to divorce over the smallest argument.
§ <b>Abaye inquired of Rabba:</b> If a <i>yavam</i> <b>gave</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>a bill of divorce, and said</b> the following formula: <b>You are hereby divorced from me but you are not permitted to any</b> other <b>man, what is</b> the status of such a bill of divorce? <b>Is the bill of divorce of a <i>yevama</i></b> a bill of divorce <b>based on rabbinic</b> law and therefore subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of a regular bill of divorce; and consequently, <b>a bill of divorce that is effective for a married woman is</b> also <b>effective for a <i>yevama</i>,</b> and <b>a bill of divorce that is not effective for a married woman is not effective for a <i>yevama</i>?</b> Since this type of a divorce is invalid in the case of a married woman, it is similarly ineffective in the case of a <i>yevama</i>. <b>Or perhaps</b> the Sages were concerned that <b>perhaps</b> people <b>will come to confuse</b> this bill of divorce <b>with</b> an unqualified <b>bill of divorce</b> given by a <i>yavam</i> and they therefore decreed that it should affect the levirate bond, preventing the <i>yavam</i> from marrying the <i>yevama</i>.
Rabba <b>said to him: We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> they will come to <b>confuse</b> this bill of divorce <b>with a</b> regular <b>bill of divorce,</b> and it therefore disqualifies a <i>yevama</i>. <b>Rabba bar Ḥanan strongly objects to this: However, if that is so,</b> that we are stringent with the bill of divorce of a <i>yevama</i> out of concern that people might confuse the two types of bills of divorce, if <b>he gives her a mere</b> piece of <b>paper,</b> which does not mention divorce, <b>so too will it disqualify her? He said to him: There</b> it is different, as a mere piece of paper has no effect on any other woman, for <b>it does not disqualify</b> her <b>for</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> If a husband gives his wife a piece of paper that contains nothing about divorce, even if he says: This is a bill of divorce, his action is of no consequence, not even to forbid her to a priest. <b>Here,</b> however, a bill of divorce of this kind at least <b>disqualifies</b> a woman from marrying <b>into the priesthood.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “They shall not take a woman that is a harlot, or profaned; <b>and a woman divorced from her husband they shall not take,</b> as he is holy to his God” (Leviticus 21:7). This verse lists the women whom a priest is prohibited from marrying. From this verse it can be inferred: <b>Even</b> if <b>she was only divorced from her husband</b> who said when giving her a bill of divorce: You are divorced from me, but did not permit her to other men, even such a woman <b>they may not take</b> in marriage. Although a bill of divorce of this kind does not permit the woman to others, it does suffice to prohibit her from marrying a priest. <b>And this is</b> what is referred to as <b>the trace of a bill of divorce, which disqualifies</b> a woman from marrying <b>into the priesthood.</b> Since this bill of divorce is valid to a certain extent, it also disqualifies a <i>yevama</i>.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said: They said</b> that <b>if one said to a scribe</b> [<b><i>lavlar</i></b>]: <b>Write a bill of divorce for my betrothed</b> now, <b>such that when I marry her I will divorce her</b> with the bill of divorce, if he indeed gave her this bill of divorce after their marriage <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> Why? <b>Because it is</b> already <b>in his power to divorce her</b> while she is betrothed to him, and therefore the bill of divorce written during their betrothal is valid.

Daf 52b

<b>But</b> if he wrote a bill of divorce <b>for</b> a <b>regular woman</b> who has no connection to him, even if he later married her, it is <b>not a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This is <b>because</b> at the time of the writing of the bill of divorce, <b>it is not in his power to divorce her,</b> and therefore the bill of divorce is of no consequence. All this is evident, but in light of the above <i>halakhot</i> <b>Rami bar Ḥama inquires:</b> If he wrote a bill of divorce <b>for his <i>yevama</i></b> and did not give it to her immediately, but only after they were married, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it a valid bill of divorce or not? The Gemara clarifies the options: On the one hand, <b>since she is tied to him</b> she is <b>considered like his betrothed; or perhaps, since he has not</b> yet <b>performed levirate betrothal with her,</b> she is <b>not</b> even considered the equivalent of his betrothed, and the bill of divorce is not effective? The Gemara does not have a resolution for this and states that the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Ḥananya inquires:</b> If <b>he wrote a bill of divorce for his levirate bond,</b> by specifying in the bill of divorce that he is thereby severing the levirate bond between them, <b>but not for his levirate betrothal,</b> or if he wrote a bill of divorce <b>for his levirate betrothal and</b> stated that it is <b>not for his levirate bond, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the <b>levirate betrothal superimposed upon the levirate bond,</b> so that they are considered a single, continuous link, <b>and he is like one who divorces half a woman, and one who divorces half a woman has done nothing; or perhaps this stands on its own and that stands on its own,</b> and he can therefore cancel either the levirate bond or the levirate betrothal separately.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why do you not <b>resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from</b> a teaching of <b>Rava? For Rava said:</b> If a <i>yavam</i> <b>gave a bill of divorce for his levirate betrothal, her rival wife is permitted.</b> The levirate betrothal he had previously performed is thereby canceled, which leaves the bond intact, and the rival wife of this <i>yevama</i> remains available for levirate marriage. This indicates that levirate betrothal and the levirate bond are not connected. The Gemara answers: <b>To Rava it is obvious,</b> but <b>to Rav Ḥananya it is a dilemma. What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>? Since no other proof is forthcoming, and Rav <b>Ḥananya</b> does not accept the teaching of Rava, the question remains undecided. The Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ It was taught in the mishna: If the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> then <b>performed levirate betrothal,</b> nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i> and this levirate betrothal is not valid. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: This is the statement of Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that <b>betrothal does not take effect on</b> those who are forbidden as they are <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition.</b> Once he has performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, the woman is forbidden to him due to the prohibition derived from the verse “So shall it be done to the man who does not build his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9), and betrothal is ineffective. <b>But the Rabbis say something is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> Although the woman who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> is forbidden to him, if he does betroth her, his betrothal is effective, as with any regular prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>And can you establish</b> that the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva? But doesn’t the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>teach:</b> If he <b>gave a bill of divorce and performed levirate betrothal, she requires a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalitza</i>. Now if</b> this is in accordance with <b>Rabbi Akiva’s</b> opinion, <b>once he gave her a bill of divorce, is levirate betrothal effective for her?</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that if one gives a bill of divorce to his <i>yevama</i>, she is forbidden to him forever</b> and he no longer has the option of marrying her? As it <b>is stated</b> with regard to a woman who was divorced and married another man who subsequently died or divorced her: <b>“Her former husband, who sent her away, may not</b> take her again to be his wife” (Deuteronomy 24:4). Rabbi Akiva emphasizes the words “who sent her away,” implying that he may not remarry her <b>after sending</b> her <b>away.</b> This indicates that there is an instance where a husband may not remarry his wife even if she has not married another, merely because he has given her a bill of divorce. This applies to the case of a <i>yevama</i> where the bill of divorce she receives renders her permanently prohibited to him. According to Rabbi Akiva, once she is rendered prohibited to him, no further action performed by the <i>yavam</i> is effective, so why does the levirate betrothal performed require a bill of divorce?
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> This is not difficult because <b>the bill of divorce for levirate marriage</b> was established by the Sages and only has the force of <b>rabbinic</b> law, <b>and the</b> aforementioned <b>verse</b> is not a Torah prohibition, but rather <b>a mere support.</b> Therefore there is no Torah prohibition against marrying a <i>yevama</i> who received a bill of divorce, and the levirate betrothal performed afterward is effective according to Rabbi Akiva as well.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> of betrothal after <i>ḥalitza</i>, the Gemara notes: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> as <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: These matters were only stated in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Akiva, who considers a <i>yevama</i> who underwent <i>ḥalitza</i> to be</b> prohibited <b>like a forbidden relation.</b> Therefore, any further betrothal is not effective with her, as is the case with forbidden relations. <b>But the Rabbis say something is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>. And I say: When</b> is betrothal effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>? It is effective <b>when he betrothed for the purpose of marriage,</b> like the regular betrothal of any ordinary woman. <b>But</b> if <b>he betrothed her</b> after <i>ḥalitza</i> and specified that he is doing so <b>for the purpose of levirate marriage,</b> in that case <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i> and then betroths her, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: If he betrothed her for the purpose of</b> regular <b>marriage she requires a bill of divorce from him;</b> if he betrothed her <b>for the purpose of levirate marriage she does not require a bill of divorce from him. And the Rabbis say: Whether he betrothed her for the purpose of</b> regular <b>marriage, or whether he betrothed her for the purpose of levirate marriage, she requires a bill of divorce from him,</b> as this betrothal is effective.
<b>Rav Yosef said: What is the reason for Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s distinction between one who betroths his <i>ḥalutza</i> for the purpose of levirate marriage and one who does so for the purpose of regular marriage? It is because the Sages <b>considered him like</b> one who <b>hoes the property of a convert</b> who died without leaving heirs. The property of such a convert is ownerless, and whoever takes possession of it acquires its title. As one of the methods of taking possession of land is hoeing, if one hoed the property of this convert with the intention of acquiring it, it belongs to him. However, if he hoed the convert’s property <b>while</b> mistakenly <b>thinking</b> that the land <b>was his own,</b> even though he performed an act of acquisition, since he lacked the requisite intention <b>he has not acquired</b> the land. Here too, since the <i>yavam</i> intended to betroth her for the purpose of levirate marriage, and the levirate bond no longer exists, his action is not effective.
<b>Abaye said to him: Are</b> the two situations <b>comparable?
