There,</b> in the case of hoeing, <b>he does not intend to acquire</b> the land as he works, as he thinks that it is already his, whereas <b>here he does intend to acquire</b> the woman. <b>This</b> case <b>is similar only to the one who hoes the property of this</b> deceased <b>convert while thinking it is that of a different convert.</b> The <i>halakha</i> in that case is <b>that he acquires</b> the land, despite his imprecise knowledge of what he is acquiring. Here too the betrothal should take effect regardless of his error.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis cannot be explained in the above manner. Instead, he suggests: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where he said to</b> his <i>ḥalutza</i>: <b>Be betrothed to me with levirate betrothal. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>levirate betrothal is superimposed upon</b> the <b>levirate bond,</b> and is therefore only possible when the bond exists, <b>and</b> since <b><i>ḥalitza</i> comes</b> and <b>releases the levirate bond,</b> levirate betrothal is not effective for her. <b>And the Rabbis hold: This,</b> the levirate bond, <b>stands on its own, and that,</b> levirate betrothal, <b>stands on its own.</b> Although the bond has been canceled, the formula of: Be betrothed to me with levirate betrothal, is effective. <b>At the outset,</b> before <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>if he had said to her: Be betrothed to me with levirate betrothal, would</b> this <b>not be</b> an <b>effective</b> betrothal despite the lack of connection between the levirate betrothal and the levirate bond? <b>Now too</b> it should be <b>effective,</b> even though she performed <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Rava said: If he said to her:</b> Be betrothed to me <b>with levirate betrothal, everyone agrees that it is effective,</b> and she is acquired. <b>And with what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where he said to her: Be betrothed to me with the levirate bond,</b> and the dispute is as follows: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b>

Daf 53a

that <b>the levirate bond is substantial,</b> and this betrothal is based on the levirate bond. <b>And</b> in this case, the <b><i>ḥalitza</i> comes</b> and <b>releases the levirate bond.</b> Therefore this type of betrothal does not acquire the <i>ḥalutza</i>. <b>But the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>the levirate bond is not substantial,</b> that is, the bond itself does not create a connection between the <i>yavam</i> and <i>yevama</i>, and that in general, levirate betrothal acquires a <i>yevama</i> as a form of betrothal unrelated to the levirate bond. <b>And</b> consequently, <b>at the outset, if he had said to her: Be betrothed to me by the levirate bond, would</b> this <b>not be effective? Now too,</b> after <i>ḥalitza</i>, even without the bond, it should likewise be <b>effective.</b>
<b>Rav Sherevya</b> suggested a different point of dispute and <b>said:</b> In a case when the woman performed <b>valid <i>ḥalitza</i>, if he</b> later <b>said to her: Be betrothed to me by the levirate bond, everyone agrees that it is not effective,</b> as there is no longer any bond. <b>And here,</b> they <b>disagree</b> with regard to one who performed <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> exempts</b> her from the levirate bond and disqualifies her from betrothal as a <i>yevama</i>. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> does not</b> fully <b>exempt</b> her, and some element of the levirate bond remains intact and she can therefore be betrothed with the levirate bond.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Everyone</b> agrees that <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> does not exempt</b> her and does not entirely nullify the bond. <b>And here</b> they <b>disagree</b> as to whether <b>a condition is</b> effective <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> When the <i>yavam</i> states he is performing <i>ḥalitza</i> on the condition that the <i>yevama</i> give him one hundred dinars, for example, is this condition effective and therefore the <i>ḥalitza</i> is nullified if the condition is not fulfilled? One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>a condition is</b> effective <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> If the <i>yevama</i> fails to comply with the condition, the <i>ḥalitza</i> is ineffective and she can still be betrothed with the levirate bond. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>a condition is not</b> effective <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> and therefore the <i>ḥalitza</i> is always effective, and the subsequent levirate betrothal is ineffective.
<b>Ravina said: Everyone agrees</b> that <b>a condition is</b> effective <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>, and here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to a compound condition.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>we require a compound condition.</b> The man must explicitly stipulate that the <i>ḥalitza</i> should be effective if the condition is upheld, and that it should not be effective if she does not fulfill the condition. If he did not state both the positive and negative sides of the condition it does not take effect, and the <i>ḥalitza</i> is effective and the levirate bond is canceled. Consequently, betrothal by the levirate bond is ineffective. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds that we do not require a compound condition.</b> Therefore, the condition applies and cancels the <i>ḥalitza</i>, which leaves the levirate bond intact.
§ The mishna teaches: If the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> then either <b>performed levirate betrothal, or gave a bill of divorce, or engaged in intercourse,</b> nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>likewise teach</b> that <b>nothing is</b> effective <b>after intercourse,</b> for he also mentioned the case of one who engaged in intercourse and then proceeded to perform other actions such as levirate betrothal, divorce and <i>ḥalitza</i>. Indeed, <b>Abaye and Rava both say</b> that the mishna should <b>teach: Nothing is</b> effective <b>after intercourse,</b> as this clause is fit to be inserted into the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>And the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna; why did he not state this? The Gemara explains: <b>The permission for a <i>yevama</i> to</b> marry a member of the <b>public is preferable to him.</b> He preferred to teach cases in which the <i>yevama</i> is permitted to marry any man from the general public as opposed to a situation where she is married to the <i>yavam</i>.
The mishna teaches that all the <i>halakhot</i> with regard to levirate betrothal after levirate betrothal and the like apply <b>both</b> in cases of <b>one <i>yevama</i></b> to one <i>yavam</i>, <b>as well as</b> in cases of <b>two <i>yevamot</i></b> to one <i>yavam</i>. The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Azzai. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ben Azzai says: Levirate betrothal is</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal in</b> the case of <b>two <i>yevamin</i> and one <i>yevama</i>, but levirate betrothal is not</b> effective <b>after levirate betrothal in</b> the case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> and one <i>yavam</i>.</b> The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, in contrast, does not differentiate between the cases.
The mishna further teaches: <b>How so?</b> If he performed <b>levirate betrothal with this</b> one and performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with that one, the first woman requires a bill of divorce to cancel the levirate betrothal. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this teaching <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel. As Shmuel said:</b> If a <i>yavam</i> <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the woman <b>who received levirate betrothal,</b> then the <b>rival wife is not exempt</b> as this <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid. The fact that the Gemara does not state that the <i>ḥalitza</i> be performed with the woman who received levirate betrothal indicates that this <i>ḥalitza</i> is not a valid <i>ḥalitza</i> and would not be sufficient to exempt the rival wife.
<b>And</b> this would constitute <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of <b>Rav Yosef’s</b> opinion, for he holds that it is preferable to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the woman who received levirate betrothal and thereby exempt the second woman. As the first woman requires a bill of divorce and therefore is necessarily disqualified from marrying into the priesthood, it is preferable to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her as well and consequently leave the second woman eligible to marry a priest. The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>Does</b> the mishna <b>teach: He should perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> which would imply that the <i>yavam</i> should do so <i>ab initio</i>? It <b>teaches</b> that <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> implying that the ruling in the mishna is <b>after the fact.</b> Therefore, there is no indication in the mishna that the <i>yavam</i> should perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the second woman, and it is possible that if he were to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the first woman he would thereby exempt the second one. It is simply that the particular case discussed by the mishna here concerns a man who performed levirate betrothal with this woman and <i>ḥalitza</i> with that one.
It is further taught in the mishna: If he gave <b>a bill of divorce to this one and a bill of divorce to that one,</b> they require <i>ḥalitza</i> from him. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>it supports</b> the statement of <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna. As Rabba bar Rav Huna said:</b> In cases of <b>invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>is required to repeat</b> the <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>with all of the brothers,</b> as that single invalid <i>ḥalitza</i> is insufficient. Similarly, in this case of invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>, it would be necessary to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with all of the <i>yevamot</i>. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>require</b> in this context? It means that such women <b>require in general.</b> The plural form does not refer to all the <i>yevamot</i> mentioned in the mishna, but rather it means that all <i>yevamot</i> in similar situations require <i>ḥalitza</i>.
It was taught in the mishna: If he gave <b>a bill of divorce to this one and performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with that one,</b> nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that this supports</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> as it indicates that the <i>yavam</i> should perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the rival wife rather than the woman who received a bill of divorce. <b>And</b> it would likewise be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who prefers performing <i>ḥalitza</i> with the disqualified woman. The Gemara again rejects this proof: <b>Does it teach: He should perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> a ruling <i>ab initio</i>? <b>It teaches: He performed <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> which is only <b>after the fact,</b> meaning he acted in that manner in this particular case.
The mishna taught that if <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one woman <b>and</b> then <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with another one, <b>or he performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and then proceeded to perform levirate betrothal, nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>also teach: Nothing is</b> effective <b>after intercourse,</b> as this is indicated in the mishna as well. The Gemara answers: Indeed, <b>Abaye and Rava both say</b> that it should <b>teach: Nothing is</b> effective <b>after intercourse.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna did not state this because <b>the permission for a <i>yevama</i> to</b> marry a member of the <b>public is preferable to him,</b> and he therefore specified a case that involves <i>ḥalitza</i>.
§ It was taught in the mishna: Nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>both</b> in cases of <b>one <i>yavam</i> to two <i>yevamot</i>,</b> as well as cases of two <i>yevamin</i> to one <i>yevama</i>. The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> that once a <i>yavam</i> has performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i>, <b>the entire household,</b> the woman who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> as well as her rival wives, <b>is liable due to a prohibition</b> derived from the verse “So shall it be done to the man who does not build his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9), but the women are not liable to <i>karet</i> due to the prohibition with regard to a brother’s wife. In light of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling, <b>it was necessary to teach us that betrothal does not take effect on</b> the rival wife of the woman who performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, despite the fact that she is only <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva.
<b>However, according to Reish Lakish, who said</b> that the <b>entire household,</b> apart from the woman who received <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>, was it necessary to teach us that betrothal does not take effect on</b> forbidden relations for which one <b>is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>?</b> According to Reish Lakish, after the <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, the mitzva of levirate marriage is canceled and the <i>karet</i> prohibition against marrying a brother’s wife is once again in force. As all agree that betrothal does not take effect on those liable to receive <i>karet</i>, it is unnecessary for the mishna to teach this ruling.
The Gemara answers: <b>Reish Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: And according to your reasoning,</b> that the mishna would not be teaching us an apparently obvious <i>halakha</i>, consider the <b>latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches</b> that if a <i>yavam</i> <b>engaged in intercourse and</b> another <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate betrothal</b> with the same woman, the levirate betrothal is not effective. Now <b>was it necessary to teach us that betrothal is not effective for a married woman?</b> Once a <i>yavam</i> has engaged in relations with a <i>yevama</i> she is his full-fledged wife, and certainly no other betrothal is effective.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that not every clause in the mishna teaches a novel <i>halakha</i>, and the reasoning of the <i>tanna</i> is as follows: <b>Since he teaches the release of</b> the bond between <b>one <i>yavam</i> and one <i>yevama</i>, he also teaches</b> the case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> and one <i>yavam</i>, and since he teaches</b> the case of <b>two <i>yevamot</i> and one <i>yavam</i>, he also teaches</b> the case of <b>two <i>yevamin</i> and one <i>yevama</i>.</b> The <i>tanna</i> therefore listed all possible cases even though we do not learn a novel <i>halakha</i> from each and every one.

Daf 53b

§ It was taught in the mishna: If <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> then proceeded to either <b>perform levirate betrothal, or give</b> a bill of divorce, or engage in intercourse with a second woman, nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, it was necessary</b> to teach that in the case of one who <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and then performed levirate betrothal</b> the levirate betrothal is not effective. For <b>it might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>we should issue a decree</b> with regard to <b>levirate betrothal that</b> takes place <b>after <i>ḥalitza</i> due to levirate betrothal that</b> takes place <b>before <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> and rule that all levirate betrothal is effective. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us that we do not issue a decree</b> in this case. <b>However,</b> the case of one who <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and gave a bill of divorce, why do I</b> need this case? What novelty is there in the teaching that a bill of divorce after <i>ḥalitza</i> is not effective?
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> that each new case must teach something new, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>he engaged in intercourse and</b> then proceeded to <b>perform levirate betrothal, or give a bill of divorce, or perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with a second woman, nothing is effective. In this case the same question can be asked: <b>Granted, it was necessary</b> to teach the case of one who <b>engaged in intercourse and gave a bill of divorce.</b> This is because <b>it might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>we should issue a decree</b> with regard to <b>a bill of divorce that</b> is given <b>after intercourse, due to a bill of divorce that</b> is given <b>before intercourse,</b> and decree that this bill of divorce alone is insufficient and she requires <i>ḥalitza</i> as well. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us that we do not issue</b> such <b>a decree. But</b> the case of a <i>yavam</i> who <b>engaged in intercourse and performed levirate betrothal, why do I</b> need to state it? Once he has engaged in intercourse with her she is his wife in all regards; what difference does levirate betrothal make?
<b>Rather,</b> one must say that <b>since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the case of one who <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> then <b>performed levirate betrothal, he also taught</b> the case of one who <b>engaged in intercourse and</b> then <b>performed levirate betrothal,</b> due to the similarity between them. <b>And since he wished to teach</b> the case of one who <b>engaged in intercourse and</b> then <b>gave a bill of divorce, he also taught</b> the case of one who <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and</b> then <b>gave a bill of divorce.</b> We should therefore not infer anything from these superfluous cases, as they are merely stated for stylistic reasons.
§ The mishna taught: With regard to intercourse, <b>when it is</b> at the beginning nothing is effective after it, but if it was in the middle or at the end, something is effective after it. The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Yosei ben Yoḥanan, a man of Jerusalem, says in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> With regard to <b>both intercourse and <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> if one of them were performed <b>at the beginning, nothing is effective after it,</b> but if they were done <b>in the middle or at the end,</b> i.e., they were preceded by some other action, <b>something is</b> effective <b>after it.</b> According to the mishna, however, nothing is effective after <i>ḥalitza</i> regardless of when it was performed.
<b>And</b> therefore it can be concluded that there are <b>three disputes with regard to</b> this <b>matter,</b> i.e., three opinions on this issue. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds:</b> In the case of <b>intercourse</b> that is preceded by a disqualifying action, <b>where there is</b> a reason <b>to issue a decree,</b> lest one violate a prohibition by engaging in intercourse after <i>ḥalitza</i> or intercourse was performed, <b>we issue a decree</b> establishing that invalid intercourse should not be as effective as valid intercourse. With regard to <b><i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> however, <b>where there is no</b> reason <b>to issue a decree</b> as there is no concern of a prohibition even if an action is performed after <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>we do not issue a decree.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Neḥemya holds</b> that with regard to <b>intercourse there is also no</b> reason <b>to issue a decree. And as</b> for what <b>you said</b> in justification of your ruling, <b>that we should issue a decree</b> in a case of <b>intercourse after a bill of divorce due to intercourse after <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> there is no cause for such a concern. <b>Since <i>ḥalitza</i></b> is effective <b>by Torah</b> law, people <b>know</b> that it is fully effective and cannot be followed by anything, and they will not confuse it with laws instituted by the Sages. <b>And as</b> for what <b>you said that we should issue a decree</b> with regard to <b>intercourse after levirate betrothal due to intercourse after intercourse, since</b> the acquisition of <b>intercourse</b> is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>this</b> matter <b>is known</b> by people, and they will not err in this regard. <b>And Abba Yosei ben Ḥanan holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who issue a decree with regard to intercourse,</b> but he adds <b>and issues a decree</b> with regard to <b><i>ḥalitza</i> due to intercourse.</b> He therefore does not differentiate between <i>ḥalitza</i> and intercourse at all.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who had intercourse with his <i>yevama</i>, whether unwittingly,</b> i.e., he thought he was having intercourse with someone else, <b>or intentionally,</b> i.e., he knew she was his <i>yevama</i> and nevertheless had intercourse with her without intent to perform levirate marriage; <b>whether</b> due to <b>coercion or willingly; even if he</b> was <b>unwitting and her</b> participation was <b>intentional, his</b> participation was <b>intentional and she</b> was <b>unwitting, he was coerced and she was not coerced,</b> or <b>she was coerced and he was not coerced; both one who</b> merely <b>engages in the initial stage of intercourse and one who completes</b> the act of intercourse <b>has</b> thereby <b>acquired</b> his <i>yevama</i>. <b>And</b> similarly, the Torah <b>did not distinguish between</b> an act of <b>intercourse</b> in an atypical manner, i.e., anal intercourse, <b>and intercourse</b> in a typical manner.
<b>And so too,</b> with regard to a man <b>who had intercourse with any one of those with whom relations are forbidden [<i>arayot</i>]</b> by <b>the Torah or</b> with those who are <b>unfit for him</b> even though they are not in the category of <i>arayot</i>, <b>for example, a widow with a High Priest; a divorcée and a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>] with a common priest; a <i>mamzeret</i>,</b> i.e., a woman born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship, <b>or a Gibeonite woman with an Israelite; the daughter of an Israelite with a <i>mamzer</i> or a Gibeonite; he has disqualified her</b> from marrying into the priesthood through this act no matter how it was performed, <b>and</b> the Torah <b>did not distinguish between</b> the act of <b>intercourse</b> in an atypical manner, i.e., anal intercourse, <b>and intercourse</b> in a typical manner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the significance of the word <b>even</b> in the statement that begins with: Even if he was unwitting and her participation was intentional? Since the mishna has already said that there is no halakhic difference whether the act of intercourse was performed intentionally, what is added by that statement?
The Gemara answers: The mishna is stated in the style of: <b>Needless to say.</b> It is <b>needless to say</b> that if <b>he</b> was <b>unwitting and she intended</b> to fulfill the <b>mitzva,</b> or <b>alternatively, he</b> acted <b>intentionally</b> without intent to fulfill the mitzva <b>and she intended</b> to fulfill the <b>mitzva,</b> he has acquired her. <b>However, even if he</b> was <b>unwitting and she</b> acted <b>intentionally, where both of them did not intend</b> to act <b>for the sake of the mitzva, he nevertheless acquires</b> her. Similarly, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: Even</b> if <b>both of them</b> acted <b>unwittingly, intentionally,</b> or <b>were coerced,</b> he acquires the <i>yevama</i> through the act of intercourse.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances the mishna</b> is referring to when it mentions a man who <b>was coerced? If we say</b> that it is <b>when gentiles coerced him</b> by threatening to kill him if he did not have intercourse with her <b>and</b> he therefore <b>had intercourse with her, didn’t Rava say</b> that <b>there is no</b> such thing as <b>coercion</b> of a man to have intercourse with a woman <b>with whom relations are forbidden, because there is no erection</b> of the male organ <b>without intent?</b> Consequently, even if he acted due to the threat, his action is considered intentional.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be referring to <b>one who was sleeping</b> and became erect, and his <i>yevama</i> drew him onto herself. However, <b>didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that

Daf 54a

<b>a sleeping</b> man <b>has not acquired his <i>yevama</i>,</b> as he did not intend to perform the act of intercourse at all? <b>Rather,</b> the mishna was referring <b>to one who was inserted</b> into his <i>yevama</i> by accident. But <b>didn’t Rabba say:</b> One who <b>fell from a roof and was inserted</b> into a woman due to the force of his fall <b>is liable</b> to pay <b>four</b> of the five <b>types of indemnity</b> that must be paid by one who damaged another: Injury, pain, medical costs, and loss of livelihood. However, he is not liable to pay for the shame he caused her, as he did not intend to perform the act, <b>and if</b> she is <b>his <i>yevama</i>, he has not acquired</b> her in this manner.
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where he intended</b> to have intercourse with <b>his wife</b> and became erect, <b>and his <i>yevama</i></b> forcefully <b>grabbed hold of him and he had intercourse with her.</b> The Gemara further asks: If so, <b>what are the circumstances</b> of the case when <b>both of them were coerced</b> that was mentioned by <b>the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya?</b> The Gemara answers: It is a case <b>where he intended</b> to have intercourse with <b>his wife, and gentiles grabbed hold of him and pressed</b> him and his <i>yevama</i> <b>against each other, and he</b> thereby <b>had intercourse with her.</b>
§ The Gemara inquires as to the source of these <i>halakhot</i>: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> with regard to the verse <b>“Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), that this indicates that the act of intercourse in this circumstance is <b>a mitzva,</b> i.e., it is preferable to the alternative, which is <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>Alternatively,</b> the verse <b>“Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her,”</b> indicates that it does not matter how he had intercourse with her, <b>whether unwittingly or intentionally, whether</b> due to <b>coercion or willingly.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you derive</b> from this phrase that the act of intercourse in this case is a <b>mitzva?</b> How can the same phrase also indicate that it does not matter what the intentions of the two parties were during the act of intercourse? The Gemara answers: The fact that it is <b>a mitzva is derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And if the man does not wish</b> to take his <i>yevama</i>” (Deuteronomy 25:7), which indicates that if he <b>wishes, he performs levirate marriage,</b> which is preferable to <i>ḥalitza</i>. Therefore, <b>when</b> the <b>verse</b> cited above <b>came,</b> it indicated that levirate marriage has occurred <b>whether</b> the parties acted <b>unwittingly or intentionally, whether</b> due to <b>coercion or willingly.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that the phrase: <b>“Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> indicates that levirate marriage has been performed if they engage in <b>typical</b> sexual intercourse. The next phrase, <b>“and take her,”</b> includes even <b>atypical,</b> i.e., anal, sexual intercourse. The concluding phrase of the verse, <b>“and consummate the levirate marriage,”</b> indicates that <b>sexual intercourse completes her</b> acquisition, <b>but money and a</b> marriage <b>document do not complete her</b> acquisition to him as his fully betrothed wife, in contrast to the regular <i>halakhot</i> of marriage. By emphasizing <b>“and consummate the levirate marriage with her,”</b> the verse teaches that he acquires her even if he acted <b>against her will. Alternatively: “Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> indicates that levirate marriage has occurred <b>whether</b> the parties acted <b>unwittingly</b> or intentionally, whether due to coercion or willingly.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you derive</b> from this phrase that levirate marriage has been performed if they engage in <b>typical</b> sexual intercourse? How can it also indicate that it does not matter what the intentions of the two parties were during the act of intercourse? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> a different verse: <b>“To establish a name for his brother”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:7), which indicates that intercourse must occur <b>in the place where he establishes a name,</b> i.e., where it can lead to childbirth. Therefore, <b>when</b> the <b>verse</b> cited above <b>came,</b> it indicated that levirate marriage has occurred <b>whether</b> the parties acted <b>unwittingly or intentionally, whether</b> due to <b>coercion or willingly.</b>
§ The Gemara addresses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> cited in the previous discussion. <b>Rav Yehuda said: A sleeping</b> man <b>has not acquired his <i>yevama</i>, as the verse states: “Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), which indicates that he does not acquire her <b>unless he intends</b> to act <b>for the sake of sexual intercourse.</b> Since a sleeping man does not intend to engage in sexual intercourse, he does not acquire his <i>yevama</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that one acquires his <i>yevama</i> through sexual intercourse regardless of <b>whether he</b> was <b>awake or asleep?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> the <i>baraita</i> in the following emended form: <b>Whether she</b> was <b>awake or asleep.</b> The woman’s awareness is not a necessary component in order to perform levirate marriage.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> that one acquires his <i>yevama</i> through sexual intercourse regardless of <b>whether he was awake or he was asleep</b> and regardless of <b>whether she was awake or she was asleep?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here</b> when the <i>baraita</i> says that a sleeping man acquires his <i>yevama</i>? It is referring to a man <b>who is dozing.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>dozing? Rav Ashi said:</b> One is <b>asleep but not asleep, awake but not awake, when,</b> if <b>they call him, he</b> will <b>answer, but he is unable to provide a reasonable</b> answer. <b>And when they</b> later <b>inform him</b> of what happened, <b>he remembers</b> it.
The Gemara returns to the statement of Rabba cited earlier in order to discuss <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> that Rabba addressed. <b>Rabba said:</b> One who <b>fell from a roof and was inserted</b> into a woman due to the force of his fall <b>is liable</b> to pay <b>four</b> of the five <b>types of indemnity</b> that must be paid by one who damaged another, <b>and if</b> she is <b>his <i>yevama</i> he has not acquired</b> her in this manner. He is liable to pay for <b>injury, pain, loss of livelihood,</b> and <b>medical costs. However, he is not liable</b> to pay for the <b>shame</b> he caused her, <b>as the Master said: One is not liable</b> to pay <b>for shame unless he intends</b> to humiliate his victim. Consequently, one who fell from a roof accidentally is not liable to pay for the shame he caused the woman.
<b>Rava said:</b> If <b>he intended to press</b> his sexual organ <b>into a wall, and he</b> accidentally <b>pressed</b> it <b>into his <i>yevama</i>, he has not acquired</b> her, as he did not intend to engage in an act of sexual intercourse. However, if he intended <b>to press</b> his sexual organ <b>into an animal, and he pressed</b> it <b>into his <i>yevama</i>, he has acquired</b> her, <b>as he</b> at least <b>intended</b> to act <b>for the purpose of sexual intercourse in general,</b> i.e., for some form of sexual intercourse.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>both one who</b> merely <b>begins the act of intercourse</b> and one who completes it has acquired the <i>yevama</i> through this act. <b>Ulla said: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> is considered an act of sexual intercourse <b>by Torah law? As it is stated: “And if a man shall lie with a woman having her sickness and shall uncover her nakedness, he has made naked [<i>he’era</i>] her fountain”</b> (Leviticus 20:18). The verse is referring to the first stage of intercourse, and <b>from here</b> it is derived that <b>the initial stage of intercourse [<i>ha’ara’a</i>]</b> is considered sexual intercourse <b>by Torah law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> a source for this <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> the subject of the verse cited above. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse with regard to <b>the rest of those with whom relations are forbidden? And if you say we should derive it from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a menstruating woman, what</b> comparison can be made <b>to a menstruating woman,</b> concerning whom the <i>halakha</i> is more stringent than others with whom relations are forbidden, <b>in that she causes one who has intercourse with her to become ritually impure?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in other cases <b>comes from</b> a verse about <b>a brother’s wife, as it is written: “And if a man shall take his brother’s wife, it is impurity [<i>nidda</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 20:21). The word <i>nidda</i> generally refers to a menstruating woman, and so the Gemara asks: <b>Is his brother’s wife always menstruating? Rather,</b> it means that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to her is <b>like</b> that of <b>a menstruating woman: Just as</b> one is liable to receive punishment for violating the prohibition against engaging in sexual intercourse with <b>a menstruating woman through the initial stage of intercourse, so too,</b> one is liable to receive punishment for violating the prohibition against engaging in sexual intercourse with <b>a brother’s wife through the initial stage of intercourse.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> comparison can be made between <b>a brother’s wife</b> and other women with whom relations are forbidden? The prohibition with regard to a brother’s <b>wife is</b> more stringent in that <b>it is within his power to increase</b> the number of women forbidden by this prohibition, <b>as, if he wishes, he can go on betrothing a thousand</b> women, all of whom would be forbidden to his brother. Consequently, the prohibition with regard to a brother’s wife cannot serve as a model for other prohibitions.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in other cases <b>comes from</b> a verse with regard to <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, as it is written: “And you shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother’s sister nor of your father’s sister; for he has made naked [<i>he’era</i>] his kin”</b> (Leviticus 20:19). The Gemara asks: <b>It is</b> possible <b>to refute</b> this source as follows: <b>What</b> comparison can be made between other women with whom relations are forbidden and <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, which are</b> unique in that they are prohibited due to <b>a prohibition that comes on its own?</b> The prohibition with regard to a father’s sister and a mother’s sister does not stem from marriage, but from the biological fact that she is his father’s or mother’s sister. It is therefore dissimilar to prohibitions that result from marriage.
The Gemara states: The principle that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse <b>does not come from</b> any <b>one</b> of the sources cited above. <b>Let it come</b> by deriving the <i>halakha</i> in any <b>one</b> other case <b>from</b> the common denominator of <b>two</b> of the sources mentioned above. The Gemara asks: <b>From which</b> two sources could this principle <b>come</b> to be derived? If you say it can <b>come</b> to be derived <b>from</b> the combination of the source with regard to <b>a brother’s wife and</b> the source with regard to <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, what</b> comparison may be drawn from these cases, <b>which are</b> unique in that they are <b>prohibited because</b> they are <b>kin?</b>
<b>Rather, let it come from</b> the prohibition proscribing <b>a menstruating woman and</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister,</b> as a menstruating woman is not prohibited as a family relative. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>What</b> comparison may be drawn from these cases, <b>which are</b> each a <b>prohibition that comes of its own</b> accord, as neither one is created through marriage? <b>Rather, let it come from</b> the prohibition proscribing <b>a menstruating woman and</b> the prohibition proscribing <b>a brother’s wife. As, what</b> can you say to <b>refute</b> this teaching? These two cases do not share any unique features that might be cause for stringency.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, strongly objects to this: What</b> comparison may be drawn based upon the precedent of <b>a menstruating woman and a brother’s wife, which are</b> stringent in that <b>they cannot be permitted</b> to others for the duration of <b>the existence of the</b> factor <b>that renders them prohibited?</b> A menstruating woman is forbidden as long as she experiences a flow of menstrual blood, while a brother’s wife is forbidden for the duration of the brother’s lifetime. Can <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to a married woman, who can become permitted during the lifetime of the one who renders her prohibited,</b> i.e., if her husband divorces her?
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Is that to say</b> that <b>it is</b> only during <b>the existence of the</b> factor <b>that renders them prohibited that a menstruating woman and a brother’s wife cannot be permitted</b> to others, <b>but afterward,</b> when the prohibiting factor has been resolved, <b>they can be permitted?</b> In the case of <b>a menstruating woman,</b>

Daf 54b

<b>the matter depends upon days,</b> not blood. Although the flow of blood causes her to become impure, she remains impure for a full seven days regardless of whether she continues to experience menstrual bleeding for the duration of that time period. Similarly, in the case of <b>a brother’s wife, the Merciful One makes</b> her forbidden status <b>dependent upon children,</b> as, if she has children she remains forbidden to her husband’s brother even after her husband dies.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara <b>refutes</b> the derivation in the following manner: <b>What</b> comparison can be drawn from <b>a menstruating woman and a brother’s wife, which</b> are unique in <b>that</b> what <b>renders them prohibited does not render them permitted?</b> Each becomes permitted due to an external factor, i.e., the passing of seven days or the death of her childless husband. <b>Can you say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of these cases apply <b>to a married woman,</b> whose prohibited status is different <b>in that the one who renders her prohibited</b> to the rest of the world, i.e., her husband, has the capacity to <b>render her permitted</b> through divorce?
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara offers another source for the <i>halakha</i> that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse. <b>Rabbi Yona said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: The verse states</b> at the end of the chapter on forbidden relations: <b>“For whoever shall do any of these abominations, the souls that do them shall be cut off”</b> (Leviticus 18:29). <b>All those with whom relations are forbidden are compared</b> to each other in this verse, and therefore also <b>to a menstruating woman,</b> who is mentioned in that chapter. Consequently, <b>just as</b> one is liable to receive punishment for having sexual intercourse with <b>a menstruating woman</b> from the time of <b>the initial stage of intercourse, so too,</b> one violates <b>all</b> prohibitions against engaging in forbidden relations from the time of <b>the initial stage of intercourse.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>But</b> if that is the source of this <i>halakha</i>, <b>why do I need</b> the term <b><i>nidda</i> that is written with regard to a brother’s wife?</b> The Gemara answers that it is needed <b>for that which Rav Huna</b> taught, <b>as Rav Huna said: From where in the Torah</b> is there <b>a hint to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>yevama</i>?</b> The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>From where? Isn’t it written</b> explicitly in the verse <b>“Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5)? <b>Rather,</b> Rav Huna meant to say: <b>From where</b> is there <b>a hint that a <i>yevama</i> is forbidden</b> to her brother-in-law <b>in her husband’s lifetime,</b> even after she is divorced from her husband?
The Gemara remains puzzled: No proof is needed for this <i>halakha</i> either, as <b>this is</b> based upon <b>logical reasoning: From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One says</b> the woman <b>is permitted</b> to her brother-in-law <b>after her husband’s death it may be inferred that in her husband’s lifetime she is forbidden</b> to him.
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>Perhaps after her husband’s death</b> it is <b>a mitzva</b> for her brother-in-law to marry her, whereas <b>during her husband’s lifetime</b> their marriage is <b>optional. Alternatively,</b> perhaps <b>after her husband’s death, yes,</b> she is permitted to him, while <b>during her husband’s lifetime, no,</b> they are not permitted to marry, but there is no punishment of <i>karet</i> if they do. This is because the source of the prohibition is the mitzva for them to marry after the husband’s death, <b>and a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> has the status of <b>a positive mitzva,</b> but nothing more.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And if a man shall take his brother’s wife, it is impurity [<i>nidda</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 20:21). <b>Is his brother’s wife</b> necessarily <b>a menstruating woman [<i>nidda</i>]? Rather,</b> she is <b>like a menstruating woman</b> in the following manner: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a menstruating woman, although she has a permitted</b> stage <b>afterward, at the time</b> that she is <b>forbidden,</b> one who has intercourse with her is liable <b>to</b> receive the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a brother’s wife, although she has a permitted</b> stage <b>afterward, during her husband’s lifetime</b> marriage to her brother-in-law is punishable <b>by <i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the source of the <i>halakha</i> that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse is as stated above, <b>why do I need</b> this <i>halakha</i> to be indicated by the word <i>he’era</i> (Leviticus 20:19) in the case of <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister?</b>
The Gemara answers that it is needed <b>for the dilemma that Ravina raised before Rava:</b> With regard to <b>one who performs the initial stage of intercourse with</b> another <b>male, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it considered to be a forbidden act of homosexual intercourse? The Gemara is puzzled by this dilemma: <b>With regard to a male, it is written</b> explicitly: “You shall not lie with a man <b>as with a woman”</b> (Leviticus 18:22), which indicates that anything considered an act of sexual intercourse with a woman is also considered an act of sexual intercourse with a man.
<b>Rather,</b> the word <i>he’era</i> in the case of a father’s sister and a mother’s sister is needed to resolve the following dilemma: With regard to <b>one</b> who <b>performs the initial stage of intercourse with an animal, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rava <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>If</b> the word <i>he’era</i> <b>does not</b> refer <b>to the matter of the initial stage of intercourse</b> in the context <b>where it is written,</b> i.e., the prohibition with regard to <b>a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, as</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from a comparison based upon</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yona, refer it to the matter of the initial stage of intercourse</b> with <b>an animal.</b> The superfluous expression written in the case of a father’s sister and a mother’s sister teaches that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse even with an animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>Since</b> intercourse with <b>an animal is</b> a prohibition for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b>capital punishment from the court, what is the reason</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> that applies to <b>it is written with regard to</b> the prohibitions proscribing a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>? Let</b> the word <i>he’era</i> <b>be written with regard to</b> prohibitions for which one is liable to receive <b>capital punishment from the court, and let us derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a prohibition punishable by <b>capital punishment from the court,</b> i.e., the case of bestiality, <b>from</b> another prohibition punishable by <b>capital punishment from the court.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Since the entire verse</b> of a father’s sister and a mother’s sister <b>comes for</b> the purpose of <b>an exposition,</b> as the Gemara is about to explain, <b>this matter,</b> i.e., that the initial stage of intercourse is considered intercourse, <b>is also written for</b> the purpose of <b>an exposition,</b> i.e., to indicate that this principle holds true in a different context, i.e., that of bestiality.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <b>exposition</b> that the rest of the verse introduces? <b>As it is taught in a</b> <i>baraita</i>, the verse <b>“You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s sister”</b> (Leviticus 18:12) indicates that the prohibition applies <b>whether</b> she is your father’s sister <b>from</b> his <b>father, or from</b> his <b>mother. Do you say</b> that she is forbidden <b>whether</b> she is your father’s sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother, or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> a sister <b>from</b> his <b>father</b> who is forbidden, <b>but not from</b> his <b>mother?</b>
<b>It</b> may be inferred <b>logically</b> from the fact that the Torah <b>rendered him liable here and rendered him liable with his sister: Just as</b> with regard to <b>his sister</b> he is liable to receive punishment <b>whether</b> she is his sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother, so too here,</b> he is liable <b>whether</b> she is his father’s sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way</b> and compare a father’s sister and a mother’s sister to a different <i>halakha</i>: The Torah <b>rendered him liable here and rendered him liable with his aunt,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s brother: <b>Just as</b> concerning <b>his aunt,</b> he is liable to receive punishment only with regard to the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s paternal brother, <b>and not</b> for the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>mother,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s maternal brother, <b>so too here,</b> he is liable only with regard to a father’s sister or a mother’s sister <b>from</b> their <b>father,</b> i.e., a paternal sister, <b>and not from</b> their <b>mother,</b> a maternal sister.
The Gemara analyzes these two possibilities: <b>Let us see to which</b> case <b>it is</b> more <b>similar,</b> i.e., which is a better comparison. <b>We</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a prohibition that comes on its own,</b> i.e., a father’s sister and a mother’s sister, <b>from a prohibition that</b> also <b>comes on its own,</b> i.e., a sister, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his aunt cannot</b> be used to <b>prove</b> otherwise, <b>as</b> it is <b>not a prohibition that comes on its own,</b> but through marriage.
The Gemara counters this argument: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way</b> and claim that <b>we</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the relatives of</b> his <b>father,</b> i.e., his father’s sister, <b>from the</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the relatives of</b> his <b>father,</b> i.e., his father’s brother’s wife, <b>and</b> the case of <b>his sister cannot</b> be used to <b>prove</b> otherwise, <b>as</b> she is <b>his own relative.</b> Consequently, there is no conclusive proof based on reasoning alone.
Therefore <b>the verse states: “You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s sister,”</b> which teaches that this prohibition applies <b>whether</b> she is your father’s sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother.</b> Similarly, the verse <b>“You shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother’s sister”</b> indicates that the prohibition applies <b>whether</b> she is your mother’s sister <b>from</b> her <b>father or from</b> her <b>mother.</b> These prohibitions are stated twice (Leviticus 18:12–13 and 20:19), and the superfluous verse indicates that the prohibition applies even to the maternal sister of one’s father or mother.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the Torah <b>to write</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a father’s sister,</b> and <b>why do I</b> need the Torah <b>to write</b> it again <b>with regard to a mother’s sister? Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> Both verses <b>are necessary. If the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> one’s <b>father’s sister,</b> one might say that it is limited to that case, <b>as she has</b> common <b>lineage</b> with her nephew, since lineage goes through one’s father. <b>However,</b> with regard to one’s <b>mother’s sister</b> you might <b>say</b> that she is <b>not</b> prohibited, as she is not considered to share common lineage with him.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> one’s <b>mother’s sister,</b> one might say that it is limited to that case, <b>as she is certainly</b> his relative, since one’s biological relationship with his mother is absolutely certain. <b>However,</b> with regard to one’s <b>father’s sister,</b> one might <b>say no,</b> that she is not forbidden, as paternity can never be established beyond doubt. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> for this <i>halakha</i> to be stated in both cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>his aunt, where it is obvious to the <i>tanna</i></b> that the prohibition includes only the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father and not from</b> his <b>mother, from where does he</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy between the terms <b>“his uncle”</b> and <b>“his uncle.” It is written here: “He has uncovered his uncle’s nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 20:20), <b>and it is written there,</b> with regard to the redemption of a Jew who has been sold to a gentile: <b>“Either his uncle or his uncle’s son shall redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:49). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of redemption, it must be a relative <b>from the</b> side of his <b>father and not from the</b> side of his <b>mother, so too here,</b> with regard to forbidden relations, the prohibition applies to the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s paternal brother, <b>and not from</b> his <b>mother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And there,</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of redemption, <b>from where do we</b> derive that a maternal relative is not included? <b>The verse states:</b> “Or any that is near of kin to him <b>of his family shall redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:49), and it is an established principle that only <b>the family of</b> one’s <b>father is called family,</b> while <b>the family of</b> one’s <b>mother is not called family,</b> as lineage is determined based upon one’s father.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>they said to him: Your wife is dead, and he</b> then <b>married her sister from her father.</b> He was subsequently informed that his second wife <b>died, and he married her sister from her mother,</b> i.e., his second wife’s maternal sister. He was then informed that his third wife <b>died, and he married her sister from her father,</b> i.e., his third wife’s paternal sister. He was then informed that his fourth wife <b>died, and he married her sister from her mother,</b> i.e., his fourth wife’s maternal sister. It later became apparent that all these rumors were unfounded and all the women were still alive. Consequently, since one cannot marry his wife’s sister during his wife’s lifetime, some of the marriages are void.
The <i>halakha</i> in this case is that it is <b>permitted</b> for him to marry his <b>first, third, and fifth</b> wives, as they are not related to each other. Consequently, these marriages are valid, <b>and</b> these women <b>exempt their rival wives</b> from levirate marriage if they all became subject to levirate marriage and one of them performed levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>. However, it is <b>prohibited</b> for him to marry his <b>second and fourth</b> wives, as they are both sisters of one of his previous wives, and their marriages are therefore void. Consequently, <b>sexual intercourse</b> between <b>one of them</b> and his brother, if he has died childless, <b>does not exempt her rival wife,</b> i.e., the real wives of the deceased, from levirate marriage.
<b>And if</b> the first wife indeed died, <b>and he had intercourse with the second</b> woman <b>after the death of the first</b> one, it is <b>permitted</b> for him to marry <b>the second and fourth</b> women, who are not related to each other, <b>and they exempt their rival wives</b> from levirate marriage if they perform levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>and</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for him to marry <b>the third and fifth</b> women, as they are sisters of his previous wives, who are still alive, and consequently these marriages are void.

Daf 55a

<b>Apparently,</b> this mishna indicates that <b>his wife’s sister, whether from the father,</b> i.e., a paternal sister, <b>or from the mother,</b> i.e., a maternal sister, <b>is forbidden. From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> that the prohibition applies even to his wife’s maternal sister? The Gemara responds: <b>It is derived from</b> the prohibition proscribing <b>his sister. Just as his sister</b> is forbidden <b>whether</b> she is his sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother, so too here,</b> a wife’s sister is forbidden <b>whether from the father or from the mother.</b>
The Gemara challenges the validity of this source: <b>And let it be derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his aunt: Just as</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>his aunt</b> applies only to the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father but not from</b> his <b>mother,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s paternal brother but not the wife of his father’s maternal brother, <b>so too here,</b> the prohibition with regard to his wife’s sister should apply only to her sister <b>from</b> her <b>father but not</b> to her sister <b>from</b> her <b>mother.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is reasonable</b> that <b>he should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case <b>from</b> the case of <b>his sister, as</b> the <i>tanna</i> thereby derives the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one’s own relatives from</b> another case of <b>his own relatives,</b> whereas his aunt is forbidden as his father’s relative.
The Gemara counters: <b>On the contrary, he should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this instance <b>from</b> the case of <b>his aunt, as</b> he thereby derives the <i>halakha</i> in <b>a matter</b> prohibited <b>through betrothal from</b> another <b>matter</b> prohibited <b>through betrothal.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a wife’s sister <b>is derived from</b> that of <b>a brother’s wife, as</b> they are both <b>something</b> forbidden <b>by means of betrothal and</b> they are <b>his own relatives.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a brother’s wife itself, from where do we</b> derive that the prohibition applies to the wife of both a paternal and a maternal brother? <b>As it is taught in a</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>“You shall not uncover the nakedness of your brother’s wife”</b> (Leviticus 18:16), which indicates: <b>Whether from the father or from the mother.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>Do you say</b> the prohibition applies <b>whether</b> she is the wife of one’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother,</b> i.e., whether she is the wife of one’s paternal brother or maternal brother? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> the wife of one’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father and not from</b> his <b>mother? It</b> may be inferred <b>logically</b> from the fact that the Torah <b>rendered him liable here and rendered him liable with</b> regard to <b>his sister: Just as</b> with regard to <b>his sister</b> he is liable to receive punishment <b>whether</b> she is his sister <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother, so too here,</b> he is liable to receive punishment <b>whether</b> she is the wife of his brother <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way</b> and compare this case to the case of an aunt. The Torah <b>rendered him liable here and rendered him liable with</b> regard to <b>his aunt,</b> i.e., the wife of his father’s brother: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>his aunt,</b> he is liable to receive punishment only for the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>father and not</b> for the wife of his father’s brother <b>from</b> his <b>mother, so too here,</b> he is liable to receive punishment only for the wife of his brother <b>from</b> his <b>father and not from</b> his <b>mother.</b>
The Gemara analyzes these two possibilities: <b>Let us see to which</b> case <b>it is</b> more <b>similar. We</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his own relatives,</b> i.e., his brother’s wife, <b>from</b> another case of <b>his own relatives,</b> i.e., his sister, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his aunt cannot</b> be used to <b>prove</b> otherwise, <b>as</b> she is his <b>father’s relative. Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way: We</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a <b>matter</b> prohibited <b>through betrothal,</b> i.e., a brother’s wife, <b>from</b> another <b>matter</b> prohibited <b>through betrothal,</b> i.e., his father’s brother’s wife, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his sister cannot</b> be used to <b>prove</b> otherwise, <b>as</b> it is <b>a prohibition that comes on its own.</b>
Since it is impossible to prove which <i>halakha</i> should serve as the model for the case of a brother’s wife, <b>the verse states</b> a second time in the same verse: <b>“It is your brother’s nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 18:16), in order to emphasize that she is forbidden <b>whether</b> she is the wife of his brother <b>from</b> his <b>father or from</b> his <b>mother.</b>
The Gemara challenges this interpretation of the extra phrase in the verse: <b>Say</b> that both <b>this</b> first part of the verse <b>and that</b> latter part refer <b>to the wife of a brother from the father,</b> i.e., the wife of one’s paternal brother. As for the repetition, <b>one</b> part of the verse renders prohibited a woman <b>who has children,</b> who is prohibited from marrying her husband’s brother <b>during her husband’s lifetime</b> even after they are divorced, <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> renders prohibited a woman <b>who does not have children,</b> who is also prohibited from marrying her husband’s brother <b>during her husband’s lifetime,</b> even after she is divorced. The Gemara responds: The prohibition proscribing a woman who <b>does not have children</b> for the duration of <b>her husband’s lifetime is derived from</b> the statement of <b>Rav Huna</b> (54b), and it requires no further source.
The Gemara presents another challenge: <b>Say</b> that both <b>this</b> first part of the verse <b>and that</b> latter part refer <b>to the wife of a brother from the father,</b> i.e., the wife of one’s paternal brother. As for the repetition, <b>one</b> part of the verse renders a woman <b>who has children</b> prohibited from marrying her husband’s brother for the duration of <b>her husband’s lifetime,</b> even after she is divorced, <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> renders prohibited a woman <b>who has children</b> and indicates that it is prohibited for her to marry her husband’s brother even <b>after her husband’s death.</b>
The Gemara responds: The <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited for a woman <b>who has children</b> to marry her husband’s brother even <b>after her husband’s death does not require a verse. From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One says that</b> one <b>who has no children is permitted</b> to marry the brother after her husband’s death, it can be inferred <b>that</b> if <b>she has children,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to marry her husband’s brother.
The Gemara raises another challenge: <b>But perhaps</b> if <b>she does not have children</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to marry <b>everyone</b> else <b>and permitted</b> for her to marry her <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> as specified by the Torah. However, if <b>she does have children</b> it <b>is permitted</b> for her to marry <b>everyone and</b> it <b>is permitted</b> for her to marry her <b><i>yavam</i></b> as well. <b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps <b>if she does not have children</b> it is <b>a mitzva</b> for her husband’s brother to marry her, and if <b>she does have children</b> it is <b>optional.</b> Consequently, the extra phrase in the verse should be necessary in order to indicate that the prohibition against marriage applies in all of these cases.
<b>Alternatively,</b> if <b>she does not have children, yes,</b> she is permitted to her husband’s brother, and if <b>she does have children, no,</b> she is not permitted to him, but the punishment of <i>karet</i> does not apply to this prohibition. This is because the source of the prohibition is the mitzva for them to marry after the husband’s death, <b>and a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> has the status of <b>a positive mitzva,</b> but nothing more. Consequently, the extra phrase in the verse should be necessary in order to indicate that the punishment of <i>karet</i> is still applicable.
The Gemara responds: The Torah <b>wrote a different verse</b> to teach that the prohibition against marrying one’s brother’s wife is in full force, including the punishment of <i>karet</i>, in these cases: <b>“He has uncovered his brother’s nakedness;</b> they shall be childless” (Leviticus 20:21). Therefore, the extra phrase mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> can indicate that the prohibition against marrying one’s brother’s wife applies both to the wife of a paternal brother and to the wife of a maternal brother.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the wife of a brother from</b> one’s <b>mother</b> should be just <b>like</b> that of <b>the wife of a brother from</b> his <b>father: Just as the wife of a brother from</b> one’s <b>father is permitted,</b> i.e., one can marry her, <b>after her husband’s death, so too, the wife of a brother from</b> his <b>mother should be permitted after her husband’s death.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The verse states: “She</b> is your brother’s nakedness,” thereby emphasizing that <b>she shall</b> remain after her husband’s death <b>as she is</b> during his life.
§ The Gemara above stated that all of the instances of forbidden intercourse are compared to one another. Therefore, since there is already a verse that states: “For whoever shall do any of these abominations, the souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people” (Leviticus 18:29), the Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need</b> the phrase <b>written with regard to one’s sister</b> that states that intercourse is punishable by <b><i>karet</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers that it is necessary <b>for that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan said that if he performed all of them,</b> i.e., he violated every prohibition against engaging in forbidden intercourse <b>in a single lapse of awareness, he is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for each and every one.</b> One might have thought that there is one prohibition against engaging in forbidden intercourse, and many different ways to violate the prohibition. Therefore, if one violated the prohibition in different ways during one lapse of awareness, one is liable to bring only one sin-offering. This verse therefore indicates that each act of intercourse with a relative with whom intercourse is forbidden is a violation of an independent prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Yitzḥak, who said</b> that <b>all</b> forbidden relations for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> were included</b> in the verse: “The souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people,” <b>why was</b> the punishment of <b><i>karet</i> with regard to one’s sister singled out?</b> In order <b>to sentence him to <i>karet</i> and not to flogging.</b> Although he has violated a prohibition, which generally carries a punishment of flogging, he is not flogged due to the fact that he is liable to receive the more severe punishment of <i>karet</i>. Since he has used the verse to teach this <i>halakha</i>, <b>from where do we</b> know <b>to divide</b> the prohibitions against engaging in forbidden intercourse and consider each an independent prohibition?
The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the verse <b>“And</b> you shall not approach <b>a woman</b> to uncover her nakedness <b>as long as she is impure by her uncleanness”</b> (Leviticus 18:19), which serves <b>to render</b> him <b>liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for each and every woman.</b>
The Gemara poses another question: <b>Why do I need</b> the phrase that <b>the Merciful One writes with regard to one’s aunt,</b> which states: <b>They shall be childless?</b> The death of one’s children is included in the punishment of <i>karet</i>, and it has already been established that all of the forbidden intercourse is punishable by <i>karet</i>. The Gemara answers that it is necessary <b>for that</b> which <b>Rabba</b> said, <b>as Rabba raised a contradiction: It is written</b> with regard to one who had intercourse with his brother’s wife: <b>“They shall be childless”</b> (Leviticus 20:22), <b>and it</b> also <b>states</b> with regard to one who had intercourse with his aunt: <b>“They shall die childless”</b> (Leviticus 20:21). <b>How so?</b> If <b>he</b> already <b>has children, he will</b> eventually <b>bury them;</b> if <b>he does not have children, he will go childless.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And it is necessary to state: They shall be childless, and it is</b> also <b>necessary to state: They shall die childless. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>They shall be childless, I would have said</b> that only those children he had <b>before his sin</b> will die, <b>but</b> those born to him <b>from</b> the time of <b>his sin and on, no,</b> they will not die. <b>The Torah</b> therefore <b>states: They shall die childless,</b> indicating that even if he has children afterward they will die and he will remain childless. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>They shall die childless, I would have said</b> that this is referring to children born <b>from</b> the time of <b>his sin and on, but</b> those born <b>from the beginning,</b> before he sinned, <b>no,</b> they will not die. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> to mention both expressions.
§ The Gemara above (54a–54b) derived that the initial stage of intercourse is considered an act of sexual intercourse with regard to prohibitions that are punishable by capital punishment or <i>karet</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> is considered an act of sexual intercourse <b>with regard to those liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for</b> violating ordinary Torah <b>prohibitions?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact that <b>the Merciful One reveals with regard to a designated maidservant</b> that the prohibition has been violated only through an act of <b>cohabitation with seed,</b> i.e., a complete act of sexual intercourse, in the verse “And whoever lies with a woman in cohabitation with seed, and she is a bondmaid designated to a man” (Leviticus 19:20), <b>by inference, those liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for</b> violating ordinary <b>prohibitions</b> are liable even <b>through the initial stage of intercourse.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One reveals</b> that <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> is considered sexual intercourse <b>with regard to</b> forbidden relationships for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> then, <b>by inference, those liable for</b> violating ordinary <b>prohibitions</b> are liable only <b>through the completion of</b> the act of <b>sexual intercourse</b> and not merely for the initial stage of intercourse. <b>Rav Ashi said: If so, let the verse remain silent</b> in the case of a <b>designated maidservant,</b> and it would be assumed that one is liable to receive punishment only for completing the act of sexual intercourse. The fact that the Torah specified that in this case one is liable to receive punishment only for completing the act of sexual intercourse indicates that with regard to other ordinary prohibitions one is liable even for the initial stage of intercourse.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> is considered an act of sexual intercourse <b>with regard to those liable</b> to receive punishment <b>for</b> violating <b>prohibitions</b> specific to <b>the priesthood?</b> Since these prohibitions are unique in that they apply only to priests, their parameters cannot be derived from prohibitions that apply to the entire population. The Gemara answers: It <b>is derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the words <b>taking</b> and <b>taking.</b> This verb appears in prohibitions punishable by <i>karet</i>, e.g., “And if a man shall take his sister” (Leviticus 20:17), and in prohibitions of the priesthood, where it states: “They shall not take a woman that is a harlot” (Leviticus 21:7).
The Gemara asks further: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the initial stage of intercourse is considered an act of sexual intercourse with regard to <b>those liable</b> to receive punishment for violating <b>a positive mitzva,</b> e.g., one who has intercourse with an Egyptian or Edomite convert? The verse states: “The children that are born to them of the third generation may enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:9). It is therefore a positive mitzva that only the grandchildren of these converts may have intercourse with a Jew.

Daf 55b

<b>It is derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the terms <b>entering</b> and <b>entering.</b> The verse states in the context of a prohibition: “A <i>mamzer</i> shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:3), and in the context of a prohibition derived from a positive mitzva: “The children that are born to them of the third generation may enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:9). Consequently, these types of prohibitions are equated.
The Gemara poses another question: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the initial stage of intercourse is considered sexual intercourse with regard to the prohibition against a <b><i>yevama</i></b> having intercourse with a man from <b>the general public?</b> The Gemara answers that there is no need for an independent source in this case: <b>If</b> you are asking <b>according to the one who said</b> that this is an ordinary <b>prohibition,</b> it is <b>a prohibition</b> like any other. <b>If</b> you are asking <b>according to the one who said</b> that this is <b>a positive mitzva,</b> it is <b>a positive mitzva</b> like any other.
<b>Rather,</b> the question is as follows: <b>From where do we</b> derive that a <b><i>yevama</i></b> is acquired by her <b><i>yavam</i></b> via the initial stage of intercourse? The Gemara answers: <b>It is derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the <b>words entering</b> and <b>entering.</b> This verb is used with regard to ordinary Torah prohibitions, as mentioned above, and also with regard to levirate marriage, in the verse “Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her” (Deuteronomy 25:5).
The Gemara asks further: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a woman</b> is betrothed <b>to her husband</b> through the initial stage of intercourse? The Gemara answers: <b>It is derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the words <b>taking</b> and <b>taking.</b> With regard to betrothal, the verse states: “When a man takes a wife and marries her” (Deuteronomy 24:1). This verb is also used with regard to forbidden intercourse, as in the verse: “And if a man shall take his sister” (Leviticus 20:17).
§ <b>Rava said:</b> Now that it has been established that the initial stage of intercourse is considered an act of sexual intercourse, <b>why do I</b> need the expression <b>“cohabitation with seed”</b> (Leviticus 19:20) <b>that the Merciful One writes with regard to a designated maidservant;</b> the expression <b>“cohabitation with seed”</b> (Leviticus 18:20) written <b>with regard to a married woman;</b> and the expression <b>“cohabitation with seed”</b> (Numbers 5:13) written with regard to <b>a <i>sota</i>?</b>
The Gemara explains that the expression is necessary with regard to <b>a designated maidservant as we said</b> above (55a), because it indicates that one is liable to receive punishment only for a complete act of intercourse with a designated maidservant but not for the initial stage of intercourse. With regard to <b>a married woman,</b> the word seed <b>excludes one who has intercourse</b> with a <b>dead</b> organ, i.e., one that is not erect, as this cannot lead to childbirth.
The Gemara questions this resolution: <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to the one who said</b> that one who <b>has intercourse</b> while his organ is <b>dead</b> with <b>those with whom relations are forbidden, is exempt,</b> as this is not considered an act of intercourse. <b>However, according to the one who said</b> that <b>he is liable, what is there to say? Rather,</b> according to this opinion, the verse <b>excludes one who has intercourse with a dead</b> woman. <b>As</b> it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since after death</b> she <b>is also called</b> her husband’s <b>kin, say that</b> one who had intercourse with her <b>should be liable</b> to receive punishment for committing adultery <b>with a married woman.</b> It therefore <b>teaches us</b> that intercourse with a dead woman is not considered intercourse at all.
The Gemara addresses the third case: <b>Why do I need</b> the expression cohabitation with seed in the context of <b>a <i>sota</i>?</b> It is needed <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that the expression <b>a cohabitation with seed excludes something else.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <b>something else? Rav Sheshet said: It excludes</b> a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>was jealous with regard to her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself and have <b>atypical,</b> i.e., anal, sexual intercourse with another man. <b>Rava</b> objected to this explanation and <b>said to him: It is written: “The cohabitations of a woman”</b> (Leviticus 18:22), indicating that there are two types of intercourse with a woman, and the same <i>halakha</i> applies to both.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> It <b>excludes</b> a situation <b>where</b> the husband <b>was jealous with regard to her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself with another man and engage in intimate contact <b>by way of</b> other <b>limbs.</b> The verse indicates that the wife does not become prohibited to her husband if she secludes herself with the man after this warning. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> Does <b>the Merciful One prohibit</b> a woman to her husband due merely to <b>licentious</b> behavior without sexual intercourse? Since this behavior would not render a woman prohibited to her husband, it is obvious that a warning that explicitly mentions this behavior is insufficient to cause the woman to become a <i>sota</i> if she then secludes herself with the man.
<b>Rather, Abaye said: It excludes</b> a case <b>where</b> he <b>was jealous with regard to her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself with another man and <b>kiss,</b> i.e., have external contact of the sexual organs. The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to the one who said</b> that the definition of <b>the initial stage of intercourse is the insertion of the corona;</b> therefore, mere external contact is not considered sexual intercourse. <b>However, according to the one who said</b> that the definition of the initial stage of intercourse is a <b>kiss, what is there to say?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the expression: Something else, in the <i>baraita</i>, is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>was jealous with regard to her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself with another man and engage in intimate contact <b>by way of</b> other <b>limbs. And it is necessary</b> to state that the woman does not become prohibited to her husband as a <i>sota</i> in this case, as <b>it might enter your mind to say that the Merciful One made</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>dependent on the husband’s objection,</b> as it is his decision to warn his wife, <b>and</b> since <b>he objects</b> to contact of this nature, she becomes a <i>sota</i> if she secludes herself after this warning. The Torah therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not considered a warning.
§ The Gemara returns to the precise definition of the initial stage of intercourse. <b>Shmuel said:</b> The definition of <b>the initial stage of intercourse is a kiss,</b> i.e., external contact of the sexual organs. Shmuel explains: This is <b>comparable to a person who places his finger on his mouth;</b> it is <b>impossible that he not press the flesh</b> of his lips. Similarly, when there is contact of the sexual organs, there will certainly be at least a small amount of penetration, and this is considered an act of sexual intercourse.
<b>When Rabba bar bar Ḥana came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: <b>The completion of intercourse</b> stated <b>with regard to a designated maidservant is the insertion of the corona,</b> and no more. <b>Rav Sheshet raised an objection</b> based upon the following <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>cohabitation with seed</b> indicates that <b>one is liable</b> to receive punishment <b>only for a complete</b> act of <b>sexual intercourse. What, does</b> this <b>not</b> refer to the <b>complete</b> insertion of the <b>member?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is possible that it is referring to the <b>complete</b> insertion of the <b>corona.</b>
