<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: The definition of <b>the initial stage of intercourse is the insertion of the corona. They said to him: But Rabba bar bar Ḥana did not say so,</b> as he taught that Rabbi Yoḥanan said that the insertion of the corona constitutes a complete act of sexual intercourse and is not considered merely the initial stage of intercourse. <b>He said to them: Either he lied or I am lying.</b> There is clearly a contradiction, and one of us cited Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion incorrectly.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: The definition of <b>the initial stage of intercourse is the insertion of the corona.</b> The Gemara comments: He <b>certainly disagrees with Rabba bar bar Ḥana,</b> who cited Rabbi Yoḥanan as stating that insertion of the corona constitutes a complete act of sexual intercourse. <b>Shall we say that he</b> also <b>disagrees with Shmuel,</b> who defined the initial stage of intercourse as external contact of the sexual organs?
The Gemara responds: <b>No;</b> it is possible that there is no dispute between them, and Ravin said that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>calls</b> the entire process <b>from a kiss until the insertion of the corona the initial stage of intercourse,</b> while anything beyond that point is a complete act of sexual intercourse.
<b>When Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda came</b> from Eretz Yisrael he reported that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The definition of <b>the initial stage of intercourse is the insertion of the corona,</b> whereas <b>a complete</b> act of <b>sexual intercourse is literally a complete</b> act of <b>sexual intercourse,</b> i.e., insertion of the male organ beyond the corona.

Daf 56a

<b>From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> insertion of anything less than the corona <b>is only</b> considered <b>a kiss, for which he is exempt. And</b> this statement <b>disagrees with</b> that of <b>Shmuel,</b> who maintains that one is liable to receive punishment for external contact of the sexual organs.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <b>both one who</b> merely <b>engages in the initial stage of intercourse and one who completes</b> the act of intercourse <b>have</b> thereby <b>acquired</b> the <i>yevama</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does it mean that he has <b>acquired</b> his <i>yevama</i>? <b>Rav said:</b> He has <b>acquired</b> her <b>for everything.</b> In other words, she is considered his wife in all regards. Therefore, if he is a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And Shmuel said he has only acquired her with regard to the matters stated in the chapter</b> of levirate marriage, i.e., <b>to inherit his brother’s property and to exempt her from levirate marriage</b> if he then dies and leaves behind children from another wife.
The Gemara adds: If she was a <i>yevama</i> <b>from marriage, everyone agrees</b> that she may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> after the initial stage of intercourse, <b>as she was</b> already <b>partaking at the outset,</b> when she was married to the deceased brother. Therefore, even a minimal act of intercourse is enough to allow her to continue to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>When they disagree</b> it <b>is</b> with regard to a <i>yevama</i> <b>from betrothal. Rav said:</b> She <b>may partake, as the Merciful One includes unwitting intercourse</b> and the other forms of intercourse listed in the mishna, and considers them <b>like intentional</b> intercourse.
<b>And Shmuel said: When the Merciful One includes</b> these forms of intercourse, He does so only <b>to establish</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>in place of</b> the <b>husband,</b> but <b>to strengthen</b> him more <b>than</b> the <b>husband, no.</b> Since she was merely betrothed to the deceased brother, she was not permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>, and therefore she may not partake of <i>teruma</i> at this point either.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Shmuel follows his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning,</b> as <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In <b>any</b> case <b>where the</b> woman’s marriage to her original <b>husband entitles</b> her <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, intercourse with the <b><i>yavam</i></b> in any of the manners described in the mishna also <b>entitles</b> her <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and any</b> case <b>where</b> her relationship with her original <b>husband does not entitle</b> her <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, i.e., if she had been betrothed but not married, intercourse with the <b><i>yavam</i></b> in the manners described in the mishna also <b>does not entitle</b> her <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a</b> mentally <b>competent daughter of an Israelite who was betrothed to a competent priest, and he did not have a chance to marry her before he became a deaf-mute</b> and was no longer mentally competent, <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as marriage to a deaf-mute does not enable a woman to partake of <i>teruma</i>. If the deaf-mute husband subsequently <b>died and</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>happened before a deaf-mute <i>yavam</i></b> for levirate marriage, <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And in this</b> regard <b>the strength of the <i>yavam</i> is greater than the strength of the husband.</b>
<b>Granted, according Rav,</b> this <b>works out well,</b> as intercourse with the deaf-mute <i>yavam</i>, which is comparable to the unwitting intercourse mentioned in the mishna because the deaf-mute is not mentally competent, effects the levirate marriage and allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i> despite the fact that she could not do so during the lifetime of her first husband. <b>However, according to Shmuel,</b> this is <b>difficult,</b> as he maintains that a <i>yavam</i> cannot have more rights than the deceased husband due to intercourse undertaken without intent to perform levirate marriage.
The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> Amend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say as follows:</b> If <b>he did not have a chance to marry her before he became a deaf-mute, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If <b>he married her and afterward became a deaf-mute, she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. If he then <b>died, and</b> she <b>happened before a deaf-mute <i>yavam</i></b> for levirate marriage, <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>In this</b> regard the strength of the <i>yavam</i> is greater than the strength of the husband? It means to say <b>that if</b> the original <b>husband</b> was a <b>deaf-mute from the outset,</b> i.e., before consummating the marriage, <b>she would not</b> have been allowed to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>whereas if the <i>yavam</i></b> was a <b>deaf-mute from the outset</b> she may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> once they perform levirate marriage, because she had been fully married to the deceased brother.
<b>And some say</b> a different version of the dispute between Rav and Shmuel: If she was a <i>yevama</i> <b>from betrothal,</b> i.e., her marriage with the deceased brother had never been completed, and she and the brother-in-law engaged in an inferior form of intercourse as described in the mishna, <b>everyone agrees</b> that she may <b>not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as she did not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in her husband’s lifetime.</b>
<b>When they disagree,</b> it is with regard to a <i>yevama</i> <b>from marriage. Rav says: She</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>as she was</b> permitted to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>initially,</b> while married to the deceased brother. <b>And Shmuel says</b> she <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, because <b>when the Merciful One includes unwitting intercourse</b> and considers it <b>like intentional</b> intercourse, it was only with regard to <b>the matters stated in the chapter</b> of levirate marriage, <b>but for every</b> other <b>issue, no.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel</b> himself <b>said:</b> In <b>any</b> case <b>where the</b> woman’s marriage to her original <b>husband entitles</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, intercourse with the <b><i>yavam</i></b> in one of the manners listed in the mishna also <b>entitles</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>? The Gemara answers: Emend the wording and <b>say</b> as follows: With regard to <b>any</b> act of <b>intercourse through which the husband entitles</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>a <i>yavam</i></b> also <b>entitles</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>; <b>and</b> with regard to <b>any</b> act of <b>intercourse through which the husband does not entitle</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>a <i>yavam</i></b> also <b>does not entitle</b> her to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Just as betrothal cannot be performed via an unwitting act of intercourse, this act does not entitle a <i>yevama</i> to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a</b> mentally <b>competent daughter of an Israelite who was betrothed to a competent priest, and he did not have a chance to marry her before he became a deaf-mute</b> and was no longer mentally competent, <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. If the deaf-mute husband subsequently <b>died, and</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>happened before a deaf-mute <i>yavam</i></b> for levirate marriage, <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And in this</b> regard <b>the strength of the <i>yavam</i> is greater than the strength of the husband. Granted, according to Rav, he</b> can <b>answer as</b> Shmuel <b>answered initially,</b> i.e., according to the first version of the dispute between Rav and Shmuel. <b>However, according to Shmuel,</b> it is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is <b>difficult.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> In the case of <b>a</b> mentally <b>competent daughter of an Israelite who was betrothed to a</b> mentally <b>competent priest, and he did not have a chance to marry her before he became a deaf-mute</b> and was no longer mentally competent, <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>If a son was born to her</b> from this priest, <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> on account of her son. If <b>the son died, Rabbi Natan says she may</b> continue to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and the Rabbis say she may not</b> continue to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Natan? Rabba said: Since she has</b> already <b>partaken of</b> <i>teruma</i> in a permitted manner, she may continue. <b>Abaye said to him: However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> in the case of the <b>daughter of an Israelite who was married to a priest, and he died</b> childless, she <b>should</b> be allowed to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as she has</b> already <b>partaken of</b> it in the past. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>since he has passed away, his</b> priestly <b>sanctity has left her,</b> and she is considered a regular Israelite in all regards. <b>Here too, since</b> the son <b>has passed away, his</b> priestly <b>sanctity has left her,</b> and therefore she should not be entitled to partake of <i>teruma</i>. Rabba’s explanation should consequently be rejected.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: Rabbi Natan holds</b> that <b>the marriage of a deaf-mute</b> who was competent when he betrothed his wife <b>entitles her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, and we do not</b> issue a <b>decree</b> against the wife partaking of <i>teruma</i> through <b>marriage</b> to <b>a deaf-mute due to</b> the case of <b>betrothal</b> to <b>a deaf-mute.</b> Although the betrothal of a deaf-mute does not take effect, his consummation of a marriage does take effect and entitles his wife to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Abaye said to him: If so, why do I</b> need the <i>baraita</i> to specify that <b>a son was born to her?</b> She should be entitled to eat <i>teruma</i> even if she did not have a son. Rav Yosef responded: That case is mentioned <b>due to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that she is entitled to partake of <i>teruma</i> only if she has a child.
Abaye asks further: <b>And let Rabbi Natan disagree with them in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> as well. Rav Yosef responds: Rabbi Natan <b>left the Rabbis until they finished their statement, and then disagreed with them</b> with regard to their entire statement. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let</b> the <i>baraita</i> first <b>teach</b> that if <b>the son died</b> she <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, and subsequently state: <b>Rabbi Natan said</b> she <b>may eat.</b> Why is Rabbi Natan’s opinion mentioned before the Rabbis finished stating their opinion? The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this <b>is difficult</b> according to Rav Yosef.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>And so too, one who had intercourse with any one of those with whom relations are forbidden</b> by <b>the Torah</b> in any form is liable to receive punishment. <b>Rav Amram said: This matter was said</b> to us by <b>Rav Sheshet,</b>

Daf 56b

<b>and he illuminated our eyes from the mishna,</b> i.e., he demonstrated that the mishna serves as the basis for his opinion: With regard to <b>the wife of an Israelite who was raped, although she is permitted to her husband, she is disqualified for the priesthood.</b> Therefore, if her husband dies, she may not marry a priest. <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of our mishna also <b>taught: And so too,</b> in the case of <b>one who had intercourse with any one of those with whom relations are forbidden [<i>arayot</i>]</b> by <b>the Torah or</b> with those who are <b>unfit</b> to marry <b>him</b> even though they are not in the category of <i>arayot</i>, the woman is disqualified from marrying a priest.
<b>What is the meaning of</b> the phrase: <b>And so too? What, is it not</b> that <b>it is no different</b> whether they have intercourse <b>unwittingly or intentionally, and it is no different</b> whether they have intercourse <b>due to coercion or willingly? And it is taught</b> that <b>he has rendered her disqualified</b> from marrying a priest.
The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>No, what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>And so too?</b> It is referring <b>to the initial stage of intercourse,</b> as this too invalidates her. The Gemara asks: <b>The initial stage of intercourse of whom? If we say</b> it is referring to <b>those with whom relations are prohibited</b> and carry a punishment of <i>karet</i> or death <b>[<i>arayot</i>], is this to say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to those with whom relations are prohibited is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> as implied by the phrase: And so too? <b>On the contrary, we derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>yevama</i> from</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to those with whom relations are prohibited, as the main</b> source that indicates that <b>the initial stage of intercourse</b> is considered intercourse <b>is stated in</b> the context of <b>those with whom relations are prohibited</b> and not in the context of a <i>yevama</i>.
<b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>And so too?</b> It is referring <b>to atypical,</b> i.e., anal, <b>sexual intercourse with those with whom relations are prohibited [<i>arayot</i>].</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>On the contrary, the main</b> source that atypical intercourse is considered intercourse, which is based upon the verse <b>“The cohabitations of a woman”</b> (Leviticus 18:22) <b>is written with regard to those with whom relations are prohibited [<i>arayot</i>].</b>
<b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>And so too?</b> It is referring <b>to atypical</b> intercourse <b>by those liable for</b> violating an ordinary <b>prohibition</b> not punishable by <i>karet</i>, with regard to whom the expression: The cohabitations of a woman, does not appear. In any event, Rav Sheshet’s proof from the mishna is not conclusive.
§ <b>Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>the wife of a priest who was raped, her husband is flogged</b> if he later has intercourse with <b>her, due to</b> the fact that it is prohibited for a priest to have intercourse with a <b><i>zona</i>.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Due to</b> the prohibition proscribing a <b><i>zona</i>, yes; due to ritual impurity, no?</b> The Torah refers to a married woman who has had intercourse with another man as ritually impure, and she is forbidden to her husband. The Gemara emends Rava’s statement: <b>Say</b> that he is <b>also</b> flogged <b>due to</b> the prohibition with regard to a <b><i>zona</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised an objection</b> based upon a verse with regard to a <i>sota</i>: <b>“And neither was she taken”</b> (Numbers 5:13) indicates that <b>she is forbidden</b> to her husband because she willingly committed adultery, <b>but</b> if <b>she was</b> forcibly <b>taken,</b> i.e., raped, <b>she is permitted</b> to her husband. The term “And…she” indicates that although these principles apply in this case, <b>you have another</b> case of a woman <b>who</b> is <b>prohibited even though she was</b> forcibly <b>taken. And which is this? This is the wife of a priest.</b>
<b>And a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva,</b> e.g., the prohibition proscribing a priest’s wife to her husband if she has been raped, which is derived from the fact that the Torah indicates that the wife of an Israelite remains permitted, has the status of <b>a positive mitzva,</b> not a prohibition. Consequently, one should not be flogged for this offense, as one is flogged only for violating a prohibition.
<b>Rabba said</b> in response: <b>All</b> married women who engaged in extramarital intercourse <b>were included</b> in the category of <b><i>zona</i>. When the verse specified with regard to the wife of an Israelite: “And neither was she taken,”</b> as it is only in that case that she is <b>forbidden,</b> it thereby indicates that if in fact <b>she was</b> forcibly <b>taken,</b> she is <b>permitted. By inference,</b> unlike the wife of an Israelite, <b>the wife of a priest remains as she was.</b> Since the Torah does not limit the category of <i>zona</i> with regard to the wife of a priest, she is considered a <i>zona</i> even if she was raped.
<b>And some say</b> a different version of this discussion. <b>Rabba said:</b> With regard to <b>the wife of a priest who was raped, her husband is flogged for</b> having intercourse with <b>her due to</b> her <b>ritual impurity.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Due to ritual impurity, yes; due to</b> the prohibition proscribing a <b><i>zona</i>, no? Apparently, in</b> a case of <b>rape,</b> the victim <b>is not called a <i>zona</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised an objection</b> from the verse: <b>“And neither was she taken”</b> indicates that <b>she is forbidden</b> to her husband because she willingly committed adultery, <b>but</b> if <b>she was</b> forcibly <b>taken, she is permitted</b> to her husband. The term: “And…she,” indicates that although these principles apply in this case, <b>you have another</b> case of a woman <b>who</b> is <b>forbidden even though she was</b> forcibly <b>taken. And which is this? This is the wife of a priest. And a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> has the status of <b>a positive mitzva,</b> not a prohibition. Consequently, one should not be flogged for this offense, as one is flogged only for violating a prohibition.
<b>Rava said: All were included</b> in the verse “Her former husband, who sent her away, may not take her again to be his wife <b>after she was made ritually impure”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:4). <b>When the verse specified with regard to the wife of an Israelite: “And neither was she taken,”</b> as it is only in that case that she is <b>forbidden,</b> it thereby indicates that if <b>she was</b> forcibly <b>taken</b> she is <b>permitted. By inference, the wife of a priest remains as she was,</b> and she is forbidden.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A widow to a High Priest, a divorcée, or a <i>ḥalutza</i> to a common priest,</b> even if they had only engaged in <b>betrothal</b> and had not yet had intercourse, <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> Since they are forbidden to the men who betrothed them, the betrothal itself disqualifies them from the privileges of priesthood even if they are the daughters of priests. <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon declare them fit</b> to partake of <i>teruma</i>. Since the prohibition is violated through the act of intercourse and not betrothal, the women are disqualified only once they have intercourse.
In a case where these women <b>were widowed or divorced,</b> if it was <b>from marriage, they are disqualified</b> from the priesthood and may not partake of <i>teruma</i>. This is because a woman prohibited from marrying a priest who has intercourse with a priest becomes a <i>ḥalala</i>, and is thereby disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>. However, if they were widowed or divorced <b>from</b> their state of <b>betrothal,</b> they are once again <b>fit</b> to partake of <i>teruma</i> according to all opinions.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It is taught in a</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir said:</b> This is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as optional betrothal,</b> e.g., in the case of an Israelite who betroths the daughter of a priest, <b>does not entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as her betrothal to a non-priest disqualifies her from partaking of her father’s <i>teruma</i>, <b>is it not all the more so</b> true in a case of <b>betrothal</b> that constitutes <b>a transgression,</b> as in the cases in the mishna?
<b>They said to him: No, if you say</b> that this is true with regard to an Israelite, <b>whose</b> status <b>cannot entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in another case,</b> as one betrothed to an Israelite may never partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the case with regard to <b>betrothal</b> to a priest that constitutes <b>a transgression, where his</b> status <b>does entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in a different case,</b> as marriage to a priest entitles a woman to partake of <i>teruma</i> in a case where it is permitted for them to marry?
<b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya said:</b> In the case of <b>a priest with crushed testicles</b> or with other wounds to his genitals <b>who betrothed the daughter of an Israelite,</b> which is prohibited by the verse “He that is crushed or maimed shall not enter into the congregation of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:2), <b>we have arrived at the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Meir</b> on the one hand <b>and Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon</b> on the other.
<b>According to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that a woman who is <b>reserved for intercourse that is invalid,</b> i.e., prohibited, <b>by Torah law may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>this one may also not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as it is prohibited by Torah law for her to have intercourse with a man with crushed testicles. <b>According to Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, who say</b> that a woman who is <b>reserved for intercourse that is invalid by Torah</b> law <b>may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> until she actually engages in the prohibited act of intercourse,

Daf 57a

<b>this one may also partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> until that time. The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>From where</b> do we know that this is correct? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon stated</b> their opinion <b>there only</b> with regard to a priest <b>whose</b> status <b>can entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in another case, but here,</b> in the case of a priest with crushed testicles, <b>whose</b> status <b>cannot entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in another case,</b> as it is forbidden for him to marry a woman who was born Jewish, <b>no,</b> they did not state their opinion.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>here too, his</b> status <b>can</b> at least <b>entitle</b> his wife <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> if he marries <b>the daughter of converts, wasn’t it</b> already <b>raised as a dilemma</b> by <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan before Rabbi Oshaya</b> whether the daughter of converts who married a priest with crushed testicles may partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and he was unable to resolve it</b> for <b>him?</b> Therefore, there is a difference between a priest with crushed testicles and other priests who betroth women who are disqualified by their intercourse.
<b>It was stated</b> that <b>Abaye said:</b> Women betrothed to a priest with crushed testicles may eat <i>teruma</i> <b>since his</b> status <b>entitles</b> his wife <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in</b> a case where <b>he has not known her.</b> If a priest was properly married and then his testicles became crushed, as long as he has not known his wife, i.e., engaged in intercourse with her, after that point in time, she may continue partaking of <i>teruma</i> as his wife.
<b>Rava said</b> she may continue to partake of <i>teruma</i> for a different reason: She may eat <i>teruma</i> <b>since</b> the status of this priest <b>entitles his Canaanite slaves and maidservants to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Because he has the power to enable others to partake of <i>teruma</i>, the case of a woman betrothed to a priest with crushed testicles is comparable to the cases in the mishna, and Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon would permit the woman to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara clarifies the two opinions. <b>Abaye did not say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> because he claims that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> related to <b>the acquisition of marriage from the acquisition of marriage, and we do not derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> related to <b>the acquisition of marriage from the acquisition of slaves.</b>
<b>And Rava did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye,</b> as he maintains that <b>it is different there, as she had already partaken of</b> <i>teruma</i> before her husband’s testicles were crushed and therefore she may continue to partake of it. <b>And Abaye</b> would respond that <b>we do not say</b> that the case is different because <b>she had already partaken of</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>as, if you do not say so,</b> the <b>daughter of an Israelite who</b> was <b>married to a priest who died</b> childless <b>should</b> be allowed to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as she had already partaken of</b> <i>teruma</i> while her husband was alive. <b>And Rava</b> replies that there is no comparison between the two cases: <b>There, his acquisition lapses</b> upon his death; <b>here, his acquisition does not lapse,</b> as she is still his wife.
§ The Gemara earlier mentioned a question that Rabbi Yoḥanan posed to Rabbi Oshaya, and it now turns its attention to that matter <b>itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma before Rabbi Oshaya:</b> With regard to <b>a priest</b> with <b>crushed testicles</b> or with other wounds to his genitals <b>who married the daughter of converts, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning whether <b>his</b> status <b>entitles her to partake of <i>teruma</i>?</b> Rabbi Oshaya <b>was silent and said nothing to him. Eventually another great man came and raised a different dilemma before</b> Rabbi Oshaya, <b>and he resolved his</b> question. <b>And who was</b> this great man? <b>Reish Lakish. Rabbi Yehuda Nesia said to Rabbi Oshaya: Is Rabbi Yoḥanan not a great man?</b> Why didn’t you address his dilemma? Rabbi Oshaya <b>said to him:</b> I did not respond <b>because he raised a dilemma before me that has no resolution.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>According to whom</b> did he raise his dilemma? <b>If</b> it was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> then, <b>whether</b> the priest with crushed testicles <b>retains his</b> priestly <b>sanctity or whether he does not retain his</b> priestly <b>sanctity</b> and may marry women forbidden to priests, she <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. The reasoning is as follows: <b>If he retains his</b> priestly <b>sanctity she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as the Master said:</b> The status of the <b>daughter of a male convert</b> is <b>like</b> that of the <b>daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i>.</b> They are both prohibited from marrying a priest, and therefore even if they marry a priest, it is prohibited for them to eat <i>teruma</i>.
Even <b>if he does not retain his</b> priestly <b>sanctity she may not eat, as we say</b> that according to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>the congregation of converts is called</b> the <b>congregation</b> of the Lord. Therefore, when the Torah renders it prohibited for a man with crushed testicles to marry into the congregation of the Lord (see Deuteronomy 23:2), it renders it prohibited for him to marry converts.
<b>And if</b> he raised his dilemma <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> then, <b>whether he retains his</b> priestly <b>sanctity</b> or <b>whether he does not retain his</b> priestly <b>sanctity, she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. If <b>he retains his sanctity</b> she <b>may partake, as</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said: Even</b> if a <b>convert married a convert, his daughter is fit for</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood. If he does not retain his sanctity</b> she <b>may partake, as</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said:</b> The <b>congregation of converts is not called</b> the <b>congregation</b> of the Lord, and therefore even those forbidden from entering the congregation may marry converts. Consequently, it is certainly permitted for the priest with crushed testicles to marry the daughter of converts.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan raised his dilemma <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 1:5) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: A woman</b> who is <b>the daughter of converts may not marry into the priesthood unless her mother was Jewish</b> from birth.
<b>And his dilemma was as follows:</b> Is the reason she may marry a priest if her mother was Jewish from birth that <b>fitness</b> to marry a priest <b>has been added to her,</b> but she is not considered a member of the congregation of the Lord and may therefore marry a man with crushed testicles? If so, since she may marry a priest, <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> once she does so. <b>Or perhaps sanctity has been added to her</b> and she is considered a member of the congregation of the Lord. Consequently, she may not marry a man with crushed testicles, and if she does, <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> even if he is a priest.
The Gemara suggests an answer to this dilemma. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: When Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥinnana came from the south, he came and brought</b> this <b><i>baraita</i> in hand: From where</b> is it derived that <b>a priest with crushed testicles</b> or with other wounds to his genitals <b>who married the daughter of converts entitles her to partake of <i>teruma</i>? As it is stated: “But if a priest buys any soul, the purchase of his money,</b> he <b>may eat of it”</b> (Leviticus 22:11). In this context, a wife is also considered his monetary acquisition, and therefore she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara analyzes this source: <b>According to whom</b> is this <i>baraita</i> stated? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say</b> that <b>whether</b> this priest <b>retains his sanctity</b> or <b>whether he does not retain his sanctity,</b> she <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>? <b>And if</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, why do I</b> need a special <b>verse</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Didn’t he say</b> that <b>whether</b> he <b>retains his sanctity</b> or <b>whether he does not retain his sanctity, she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>? <b>Rather, is it not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov? And</b> you can <b>learn from this</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>fitness was added to her, and</b> therefore <b>she</b> may <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that it is so.
§ The Gemara cites a dispute with regard to an issue related to the previous discussion. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the following question. <b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 57b

<b>There is</b> significance <b>to</b> a priest entering <b>a wedding canopy</b> with women who are <b>unfit</b> to marry a priest. If a priest’s daughter who is unfit to marry a priest enters the wedding canopy with a priest, she becomes disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i> from her father’s household. This is the case even if the priest did not betroth her and they did not engage in sexual intercourse. <b>And Shmuel said: There is no</b> significance <b>to</b> a priest entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with women who are <b>unfit</b> to marry a priest. Only sexual intercourse disqualifies her from the privileges of priesthood.
<b>Shmuel said: And Abba,</b> i.e., Rav, whose first name was Abba, <b>concedes to me, with regard to a girl less than three years and one day old,</b> that she is not disqualified by merely entering the wedding canopy. <b>Since there is no</b> legal significance to an act of <b>intercourse</b> with <b>her, there is no</b> legal significance to entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with <b>her.</b>
<b>Rava said: We, too, learn</b> in the following <i>baraita</i> that there is no legal significance to an act of intercourse with a girl less than three years old: <b>A girl three years and one day old can be betrothed via sexual intercourse; and if</b> she was a <i>yevama</i> and her <b><i>yavam</i> had intercourse with her, he has acquired her; and</b> a man who has intercourse with her while she is married to someone else <b>is liable on her account because</b> of the prohibition of intercourse with <b>a married woman; and</b> if she experiences a menstrual discharge <b>she renders ritually impure a man who has intercourse with her, so that he renders impure the object upon which he lies like the upper one.</b>
If <b>she is married to a priest she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If <b>one of those</b> who render women <b>unfit</b> for marrying a priest <b>had intercourse with her, he has disqualified her</b> from being able to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
Rava infers from this <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is a girl three years and one day old who is disqualified via intercourse,</b> and consequently <b>she is</b> also <b>disqualified via the wedding canopy.</b> However, a girl who is <b>less than three years and one day old, who is not disqualified via intercourse, is also not disqualified via the wedding canopy.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that it is so.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> With regard to the question of whether <b>there is</b> legal significance <b>to</b> a priest entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with women who are <b>unfit</b> to marry a priest, <b>we have arrived at the dispute</b> cited in the mishna between <b>Rabbi Meir</b> on the one hand <b>and Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon</b> on the other.

Daf 58a

<b>According to Rabbi Meir, who says that betrothal</b> to a priest <b>disqualifies</b> a woman who is unfit to marry him from partaking of <i>teruma</i> even if she is the daughter of a priest, entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with a priest <b>also disqualifies</b> her. Conversely, <b>according to Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, who say</b> that <b>betrothal does not disqualify</b> her, entering the <b>wedding canopy also does not disqualify</b> her.
The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>And from where</b> do we know that these <i>tanna’im</i> would apply their opinions with regard to betrothal to entering the wedding canopy? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Meir only stated</b> his opinion <b>there, with regard to betrothal, which acquires her. However,</b> in the case of <b>a wedding canopy, which does not acquire her, no,</b> she is not disqualified.
<b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon stated</b> their opinion <b>only there, with regard to betrothal, as it is not close to</b> an act of <b>sexual intercourse. However,</b> with regard to entering the <b>wedding canopy, which is close to</b> an act of <b>sexual intercourse,</b> as it is the place where the bride and groom are secluded together and symbolizes the woman’s entrance into her husband’s home, it is possible <b>that it also disqualifies</b> her from partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rather, if it can be said</b> that this issue was already discussed by earlier Sages, it was <b>in the dispute</b> between <b>these</b> other <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they married one another,</b> i.e., either a woman who is <b>fit or</b> a woman who is <b>unfit</b> married a priest, <b>or they entered the wedding canopy and did not</b> yet <b>have intercourse</b> with him, <b>they</b> are entitled to <b>eat of his</b> food <b>and</b> to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Gemara interrupts its presentation of the <i>baraita</i> to examine its wording. The fact that the <i>baraita</i> mentions a case where <b>they entered</b> the wedding canopy but did not yet have intercourse proves <b>by inference that</b> the earlier case, where <b>they married,</b> is referring to <b>actual marriage.</b> However, this is difficult because if they were actually married and had engaged in intercourse, the woman who was unfit to marry a priest is certainly disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i> due to the prohibited act of intercourse.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a single case: <b>Where</b> they were married, and <b>they entered the canopy, and had not had intercourse? And it is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>they</b> are entitled to <b>partake of his</b> food <b>and</b> to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> This indicates that entrance into the wedding canopy does not disqualify a woman who is unfit to marry a priest from eating <i>teruma</i>, although the act of intercourse does.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Conversely, <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: Any</b> woman <b>whose</b> act of <b>intercourse entitles her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, her wedding canopy</b> also <b>entitles her to partake of <i>teruma</i>; and any</b> woman <b>whose</b> act of <b>intercourse does not entitle her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, her wedding canopy</b> also <b>does not entitle her to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> Consequently, it appears that the <i>tanna’im</i> cited in this <i>baraita</i> disagree over the very question of whether the entry of a priest and a woman unfit to marry him into the wedding canopy has legal significance.
The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>From where</b> do we know that this is correct? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that in the case of the <b>betrothal</b> of a woman unfit for a priest <b>she may not partake of</b> <i>teruma</i>?
The Gemara expresses surprise: According to this suggestion, <b>this</b> expression in the <i>baraita</i> is difficult: <b>Any</b> woman <b>whose</b> act of <b>intercourse does not entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>her wedding canopy</b> also <b>does not entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>It should have</b> said: <b>Any</b> woman <b>whose</b> act of <b>intercourse does not entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>her</b> betrothal <b>money</b> also <b>does not entitle her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as it was the betrothal that disqualified her. The Gemara counters this argument: <b>Perhaps</b> it can be suggested that <b>since</b> the <b>first <i>tanna</i> said</b> his ruling with regard to <b>a wedding canopy,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>also said</b> his ruling with regard to <b>a wedding canopy,</b> even though he holds that she was already disqualified from the time of her betrothal.
§ <b>Rav Amram said: This matter was said</b> to us by <b>Rav Sheshet, and he illuminated our eyes from the mishna,</b> i.e., he demonstrated that the mishna serves as the basis for his opinion. Rav Sheshet’s statement was as follows: <b>There is</b> significance <b>to</b> a priest entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with women who are <b>unfit</b> to marry a priest. <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna also <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <i>sota</i> (<i>Sota</i> 18a–b): When a <i>sota</i> is brought to the Temple to drink the bitter waters, she affirms the oath imposed on her by a priest that she has not committed adultery. The mishna explains that when she says <b>amen,</b> it is as though she herself states <b>that: I did not go astray</b> while <b>betrothed, or married,</b> or as <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i>, or</b> as a fully <b>married</b> woman.
The Gemara inquires: <b>This</b> case of <b>a betrothed</b> woman, <b>what are the circumstances? If we say that he was jealous of her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself with a particular man <b>when she was betrothed, and he</b> also <b>causes her to drink</b> the waters <b>when she is betrothed,</b> is <b>a betrothed</b> woman <b>fit to drink</b> the waters of a <i>sota</i>? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Sota</i> 23b): <b>A betrothed</b> woman <b>and a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> do not drink,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>sota</i> waters applies only to married women; <b>and they do not collect their marriage contract</b> if they secluded themselves after being warned, as they have acted in a licentious fashion?
<b>Rather,</b> the case in the first mishna cited above is <b>that he was jealous of her</b> and warned her not to seclude herself with a particular man <b>when she was betrothed, and she secluded herself</b> with that man, <b>and</b> her husband <b>causes her to drink when she is</b> already <b>married.</b> However, in that case <b>do the waters examine her? Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And the man shall be clear from iniquity,</b> and that woman shall bear her iniquity” (Numbers 5:31), that <b>when the man is clear of iniquity the waters examine his wife,</b> but if <b>the man is not clear of iniquity the waters do not examine his wife?</b> By secluding herself with the other man when she was betrothed, the woman rendered herself forbidden to her husband. If he then married her, he cannot be described as clear of iniquity, and therefore the <i>sota</i> waters are ineffective.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>that he was jealous of her when she was betrothed, and she secluded herself</b> with the other man anyway, <b>and she had entered the wedding canopy but did not</b> yet <b>have intercourse</b> with her husband when he brought her to the priest. Consequently, she is made to drink the <i>sota</i> waters as a married woman, and her husband has not committed a transgression, as he has not had intercourse with her. <b>Learn from this</b> that <b>there is</b> significance <b>to</b> a priest entering the <b>wedding canopy</b> with women who are <b>unfit</b> to marry a priest, as demonstrated by the fact that the <i>sota</i> waters will examine her in these circumstances.
<b>Rava said: Do you hold that this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> sufficiently <b>accurate</b> to rely upon? <b>But when Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina came from the South, he came with</b> this <b><i>baraita</i> in hand:</b> The verse states with regard to the oath of the <i>sota</i>: “And some man has lain with you <b>besides your husband”</b> (Numbers 5:20), which indicates that it applies only <b>when the cohabitation of the husband preceded that of the adulterer, but not when the cohabitation of the adulterer preceded that of the husband.</b> Consequently, in the case under discussion, drinking the <i>sota</i> waters would not be effective.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said: You find it in</b> a case <b>such as</b> where <b>her betrothed had intercourse with her</b> licentiously when she was a betrothed woman <b>in her father’s house.</b> Since the act of intercourse was committed licentiously rather than for the purpose of consummating the marriage, the woman is still considered betrothed. Subsequently, her betrothed warned her not to seclude herself with a particular man, and she disobeyed. Then, they entered the wedding canopy together, despite the fact that they are forbidden to one another. Once they entered the wedding canopy, the woman can be made to drink the bitter waters. This proves that there is significance to entering the wedding canopy with a woman that is unfit for one to marry.
The Gemara asks: If so, in <b>the corresponding</b> case <b>with regard to a widow waiting for</b> her <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> in <b>which</b> the <b><i>yavam</i> had</b> licentious <b>intercourse with her in her father-in-law’s house,</b>

Daf 58b

<b>do you call her a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i>?</b> Once they have engaged in intercourse, <b>she is his proper wife, as Rav said</b> that one who has intercourse with his <i>yevama</i>, even without intending to thereby perform levirate marriage, <b>has acquired her for all</b> matters. The Gemara responds: This is in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said</b> that he <b>has acquired her only with regard to the matters stated in the chapter</b> of levirate marriage, but not with regard to other matters, and therefore she is not considered his wife with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>sota</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>The only reason</b> this proof was presented is to support the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> who is the one who holds that there is legal significance to a priest entering the wedding canopy with a woman who is unfit to marry him. <b>Didn’t Rav say he has acquired her for all</b> matters? The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here? For example,</b> a case where the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate betrothal with her</b> and afterward had intercourse with her for the sake of promiscuity. <b>And this is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who say: Levirate betrothal acquires</b> a <i>yevama</i> in <b>a full-fledged</b> manner and removes the levirate bond. Therefore, when they have intercourse, they do not become fully married.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> the case of the <i>yevama</i> who was betrothed <b>is</b> the same as the case of <b>a betrothed</b> woman. What is the difference between the two cases? The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> are the examples in the mishna of <b>a married</b> woman <b>and a fully married</b> woman <b>not a single matter? Rather,</b> the mishna must be referring to two very similar cases, with the following difference: <b>A married</b> woman means <b>his own</b> wife <b>and</b> a fully <b>married</b> woman is referring <b>to that of his fellow,</b> i.e., his brother’s wife who became his wife through levirate marriage. <b>Here too,</b> the case of <b>a betrothed</b> woman is referring to <b>his own</b> wife <b>and</b> the case of <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i></b> is <b>that of his fellow,</b> i.e., his <i>yevama</i>, who is now betrothed to him.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Rava’s question can be resolved in a manner unrelated to the question about a priest entering the wedding canopy with a woman unfit for him. The <i>baraita</i> he cited <b>is</b> in accordance with <b>this <i>tanna</i>,</b> who does not require the man to be clear of iniquity, <b>as it is taught in a</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One cannot be jealous over a betrothed</b> woman and warn her not to seclude herself with a particular man in order <b>to cause her to drink</b> the <i>sota</i> waters <b>when she is betrothed, but one can be jealous over her to cause her to drink</b> the <i>sota</i> waters <b>when she is married,</b> even if she secluded herself with the man when she was still betrothed.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The question never arises at all, as the oath is formulated <b>by means of extension.</b> The woman cannot be forced to drink the <i>sota</i> waters for events that took place while she was betrothed. However, if she is obligated to drink due to events that took place when she was married, the oath may be extended to include any possible acts of infidelity when she was betrothed.
§ <b>Rav Ḥanina sent in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: One who performs levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> and he has a brother, even if he is a priest and she is</b> the daughter of <b>a priest, he has disqualified her from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> By Torah law, the other brother may still have intercourse with her and thereby perform levirate marriage, but by rabbinic law only the brother who betrothed her may perform levirate marriage. Due to the fact that she is considered to be waiting for levirate marriage even vis-à-vis the brother who is rabbinically prohibited from marrying her, she is classified as a woman who is waiting for an invalid act of intercourse. Consequently, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until the consummation of the levirate marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>According to whom</b> did Rabbi Yoḥanan make this statement? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, say that Rabbi Meir said</b> that a woman who is <b>reserved for an invalid</b> act of <b>intercourse may not eat</b> <i>teruma</i> when the act of intercourse is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law. However, if the act of intercourse is prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>did</b> Rabbi Meir actually <b>say</b> that the woman is disqualified from eating <i>teruma</i>? <b>Rather,</b> if we say it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, now</b> that they hold that even a woman who is <b>reserved for intercourse prohibited by Torah</b> law <b>may partake of</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>is it necessary</b> to state that she may partake of <i>teruma</i> if she is reserved for intercourse prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law<b>?</b>
<b>Rather, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> an accurate version of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: If a <i>yavam</i> who <b>performed levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i></b> has a brother, <b>all agree</b> that the <i>yevama</i> <b>may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. If <b>he has a brother</b> who is <b>a <i>ḥalal</i>,</b> e.g., his mother was a divorcée and therefore unfit to marry his father, who was a priest, <b>all agree</b> that the <i>yevama</i> <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as she is considered reserved for an invalid act of intercourse. <b>They disagreed only</b> in a case when <b>he gave her a bill of divorce. Rabbi Yoḥanan said she may partake of</b> <i>teruma</i>, as she is considered to have returned to her father’s house, while <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that <b>she may not partake of</b> <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara analyzes the two opinions: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said she may eat</b> <i>teruma</i> because <b>even according to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> in the mishna that <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>this applies only</b> when she is <b>waiting for intercourse</b> that is <b>invalid by Torah</b> law, <b>but</b> if the intercourse is prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>she may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. In this case, since they have not yet performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, the levirate bond still applies by Torah law, but they are prohibited by rabbinic law from consummating the levirate marriage.
<b>And Reish Lakish said: She may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>because even according to Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, who say</b> in the mishna that <b>she may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>this applies only</b> to a case of betrothal, <b>as</b> a priest <b>can entitle</b> a woman <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in another case</b> via betrothal. <b>But here,</b> where he gave her a bill of divorce, <b>since he cannot entitle</b> a woman <b>to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in</b> any <b>other case</b> by giving her a bill of divorce, <b>no.</b>
<b>And lest you say here too,</b> in the case of a bill of divorce, <b>he can entitle her to partake of</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>when she returns</b> to her father’s house, this case is different for the following reason: A woman <b>who returns</b> to her father’s house <b>has been severed from</b> her husband <b>and she is close to her</b> father’s <b>house [<i>bei nasha</i>],</b> and therefore she may once again partake of <i>teruma</i> on her father’s account. <b>However, this</b> <i>yevama</i> who has received a bill of divorce <b>is</b> still <b>bound to</b> her <i>yavam</i> until they perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and she is therefore disqualified from eating <i>teruma</i>.
§ It was taught in the mishna that in the case of women who married priests despite the fact that they were unfit to do so, if <b>they were widowed or divorced</b> from that marriage, they are disqualified from eating <i>teruma</i>, but if they were widowed or divorced while they were only betrothed, they are fit to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef raised a dilemma before Shmuel:</b> In the case of <b>a High Priest who betrothed a minor and she matured under him,</b> i.e., while betrothed to him,

Daf 59a

<b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara clarifies the dilemma: <b>Do we follow</b> the time of <b>marriage,</b> at which point she was unfit for him according to most <i>tanna’im</i>, who hold that a High Priest may not marry a grown woman, as she is no longer called “a wife in her virginity” (Leviticus 21:13)? <b>Or do we follow</b> the time of <b>betrothal,</b> at which point she was of suitable age?
Shmuel <b>said to him: You learned it</b> in the mishna: If <b>they were widowed or divorced from marriage, they are disqualified</b> from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, but if they were widowed or divorced <b>from betrothal, they are fit</b> to partake of <i>teruma</i>. This indicates that disqualifications from the privileges of priesthood are determined based upon marriage rather than betrothal.
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef <b>said to</b> Shmuel: With regard to <b>causing her</b> to become <b>a <i>ḥalala</i> I did not raise a dilemma, as</b> it is clear <b>that it is intercourse that causes her</b> to become <b>a <i>ḥalala</i>. When I raised a dilemma,</b> it was with regard to the verse pertaining to a High Priest: <b>“And he shall take a wife in her virginity”</b> (Leviticus 21:13). <b>What</b> does “take” mean in this verse? <b>Do we require</b> that only <b>the taking of betrothal</b> must occur when she is in her virginity, i.e., when she is a minor or a young woman, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>we require</b> even <b>the taking of marriage</b> to be performed when she is a minor or young woman?
Shmuel <b>said to him: This, too, you learned</b> in a mishna (61a): If <b>he betrothed a widow and was</b> subsequently <b>appointed to be High Priest, he may marry</b> her, despite the fact that a High Priest is prohibited from marrying a widow. This indicates that her permissibility to him is determined according to the time of the betrothal rather than the time of marriage. The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>There it is different, as it is written: “He shall take for a wife”</b> (Leviticus 21:14). The superfluous expression “for a wife” indicates that he is permitted to marry the widow in this case.
The Gemara objects: <b>Here, too,</b> with regard to a woman who matured after betrothal, <b>it is written:</b> “And he shall take <b>a wife</b> in her virginity,” and this should indicate that he may marry the grown woman in this case. The Gemara answers that the term “wife” allows for the inclusion of <b>one</b> case <b>but not two.</b> Consequently, since a High Priest may marry a widow he had betrothed before he was appointed High Priest, it cannot also be derived that he may marry a grown woman that he had betrothed before she matured.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to include the case of a widow and exclude that of a grown woman? The Gemara answers: In <b>this</b> case, of the grown woman, <b>her body has changed,</b> and therefore she is forbidden to him even though she was betrothed before she matured. In <b>that</b> case, of the widow, <b>her body has not changed.</b> It is the priest’s personal status that has changed, and therefore she remains permitted.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A High Priest may not marry a widow, whether</b> she is <b>a widow from betrothal or a widow from marriage. And he may not marry a grown woman.</b> He may marry only a minor or a young woman. <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon declare a grown woman fit</b> to marry a High Priest. <b>And he may not marry a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states with regard to a High Priest: <b>“A widow…he shall not take”</b> (Leviticus 21:14), which prohibits him from marrying any widow, <b>whether</b> she is <b>a widow from betrothal or a widow from marriage.</b> The Gemara is surprised by this statement: This is <b>obvious,</b> as the verse is referring to a widow without further specification. The Gemara answers: It is necessary; <b>lest you say that one should derive</b> a verbal analogy between the words <b>“widow”</b> and <b>“widow,”</b> based upon the usage of that term in a verse with regard to <b>Tamar,</b> Judah’s daughter-in-law (Genesis 38:11), as follows: <b>Just as there,</b> Tamar was a widow <b>from marriage, so too here</b> the verse is referring only to a widow <b>from marriage.</b> The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that <b>it is indeed so,</b> that the suggested verbal analogy is correct. The Gemara answers: It is <b>similar to</b> the case of <b>a divorcée: Just as a divorcée</b> is forbidden to a priest <b>whether</b> she was divorced <b>from marriage or from betrothal, so too a widow</b> is forbidden to a High Priest <b>whether</b> she is a widow <b>from marriage or from betrothal.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>And</b> a High Priest <b>may not marry a grown woman. The Sages taught</b> that the verse: <b>“And he shall take a wife in her virginity”</b> (Leviticus 21:13) <b>excludes a grown woman, whose hymen has worn away,</b> i.e., it is no longer as complete as that of a minor or a young woman; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon declare a grown woman fit</b> to marry a High Priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that were the verse referring simply to <b>a virgin</b> it would have <b>indicated</b> that <b>even</b> a woman with <b>partial</b> signs of <b>virginity,</b> i.e., a grown woman, is permitted. Since the verse states <b>“her virginity,”</b> it means that she is fit to marry a High Priest only <b>if all of</b> the signs of <b>her virginity are</b> intact, which excludes a grown woman. The full expression <b>“in her virginity”</b> indicates that if she has experienced sexual intercourse in <b>a typical</b> manner, which takes place in the area of her virginity, i.e., her hymen, <b>yes,</b> she is disqualified from marrying a High Priest; but if she has experienced sexual intercourse in <b>an atypical</b> manner i.e., anal intercourse, <b>no,</b> she is not disqualified.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon hold</b> that were the verse referring simply to <b>a virgin,</b> it would have <b>indicated</b> that only <b>a complete virgin</b> is fit to marry a High Priest, but not a grown woman. When it states <b>“her virginity,”</b> it indicates that <b>even</b> a woman with <b>partial</b> signs of <b>virginity,</b> i.e., a grown woman, is fit to marry the High Priest. The full expression <b>“in her virginity”</b> indicates that she is not fit to marry a High Priest <b>unless all of her virginity is intact,</b> i.e., she has not engaged in intercourse of any kind, <b>whether typical</b> sexual intercourse <b>or atypical</b> sexual intercourse.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If <b>she had atypical sexual intercourse, she is disqualified from</b> the High <b>Priesthood,</b> i.e., from marrying the High Priest. <b>Rava raised an objection</b> based upon a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to rape: <b>“And she shall be his wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:19), and the Sages explained that this is referring only <b>to a woman suitable for him, excluding a widow for a High Priest</b> and <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i> for a common priest.</b> In these cases, the rapist is not permitted to marry his victim.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> that the High Priest raped her by engaging <b>in typical</b> intercourse, <b>why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> <b>specifically</b> state that she is forbidden to him <b>because</b> she is <b>a widow? Let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the fact <b>that she is</b> now <b>a non-virgin. Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> that he had <b>atypical</b> intercourse with her, <b>and due to</b> the fact that she is <b>a widow, yes,</b> that is the reason she is forbidden, but <b>due to</b> the fact that she is <b>a non-virgin, no,</b> that is not the reason she is forbidden? This indicates that a woman who had intercourse in an atypical manner is not considered a non-virgin and is not disqualified from marrying a High Priest.

Daf 59b

The Gemara refutes this proof: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that a woman who engaged in atypical intercourse is permitted to a High Priest, <b>and when Rav said</b> his statement, it was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who holds that such a woman is disqualified from marrying a High Priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> Rav’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, why</b> did he <b>specifically</b> state that she is forbidden to him <b>because</b> she is <b>a non-virgin? Let him derive</b> it <b>from</b> the fact <b>that she is a <i>zona</i>, as Rabbi Elazar said:</b> Even in the case of <b>an unmarried man who had intercourse with an unmarried woman not for the purpose of marriage, he has</b> thereby <b>caused her to become a <i>zona</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> When Rav said that a woman who had anal intercourse is disqualified from marrying a High Priest, he was referring <b>to</b> a woman <b>who had intercourse with an animal, as there</b> she <b>is</b> disqualified <b>because</b> she is <b>a non-virgin,</b> but she <b>is not</b> disqualified <b>because</b> of the prohibition of <b>a <i>zona</i>.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: Whichever way you</b> look at it, there is a difficulty with this answer: <b>If she is</b> considered <b>a non-virgin, she is</b> also <b>a <i>zona</i>, and if she is not a <i>zona</i> she is</b> also <b>not a non-virgin. And lest you say</b> that it is <b>analogous to</b> a case of <b>a woman who lost her virginity via penetration by a foreign object atypically,</b> i.e., anally, whose hymen was therefore not damaged and she is not forbidden as a <i>zona</i>, yet she is no longer considered a virgin, that is not correct: <b>If so,</b> if such a woman is considered a non-virgin and forbidden to a High Priest, <b>you</b> would <b>have no woman who is fit for the</b> High <b>Priesthood, who has not lost her virginity via penetration by a foreign object</b> atypically, i.e., <b>by a pebble</b> used to clean herself in the lavatory.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Zeira said</b> that Rav was referring <b>to one who refused</b> her husband after having only atypical intercourse with him. Although the act of intercourse was not licentious, as she was married at the time, she is nevertheless disqualified from marrying into the priesthood because she is not a virgin.
§ <b>Rabbi Shimi bar Ḥiyya said:</b> A woman who <b>had intercourse with an animal</b> is like one whose hymen was torn accidentally. Consequently, she is not a <i>zona</i> and is <b>fit for the priesthood. This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>had intercourse with one who is not a man,</b> i.e., an animal, <b>although</b> she is liable to <b>stoning</b> if she did so intentionally and in the presence of witnesses who forewarned her of her punishment, she is nevertheless <b>fit for the priesthood.</b>
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> involving <b>a certain girl [<i>riva</i>] in</b> the village of <b>Hitlu who was sweeping the house, and a village [<i>kufri</i>] dog</b> used for hunting <b>sodomized her from behind. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted her to the priesthood,</b> as she was not considered a <i>zona</i>. <b>Shmuel said: And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi permitted her even <b>to a High Priest,</b> as she was still considered a virgin. The Gemara is puzzled by this comment: <b>Was there a High Priest in the days of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>Rather,</b> Shmuel meant that <b>she is fit for a High Priest.</b>
<b>Rava of Pirkin said to Rav Ashi: From where is this matter</b> derived <b>that the Sages stated</b> that <b>there is no harlotry with regard to an animal?</b> Rav Ashi responded that it is <b>as it is written: “You shall not bring the hire of a harlot or the price of a dog</b> into the House of the Lord your God for any vow; for both of them are an abomination to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19). This verse prohibits one from sacrificing an animal as an offering if that animal was ever used to pay a harlot for her services, or if it was ever used as payment in the purchase of a dog.
<b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 30a): <b>The hire of a dog,</b> i.e., a kosher animal that a man or woman gave as payment to the owner of a dog in order to have sexual intercourse with it, <b>and</b> similarly <b>the price of a prostitute,</b> a kosher animal used to purchase a prostitute as a maidservant, <b>are permitted</b> to be sacrificed as offerings. This is <b>because it is stated</b> that <b>both of them,</b> the specific items listed in the verse, are abominations. Consequently, only <b>two</b> items are prohibited, i.e., the payment given to a prostitute for her services, and the payment used in the purchase of a dog, <b>and not four,</b> as the reverse cases are excluded from this <i>halakha</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> A High Priest <b>may not marry</b> a woman that <b>he himself raped and</b> a woman that <b>he himself seduced,</b> as he is commanded to marry a virgin. <b>And if he married</b> her, <b>he is married.</b> With regard to a woman who was <b>raped by another</b> man <b>and</b> a woman <b>seduced by another</b> man, <b>he may not marry</b> her. <b>And if he married</b> her, <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says</b> that <b>the child</b> born from this union <b>is a <i>ḥalal</i>, and the Rabbis say</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>. It states that <b>if he married</b> the woman that he himself raped or seduced, <b>he is married. Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: And he must divorce</b> her <b>with a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> consider <b>that which</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: If he married</b> her, <b>he is married.</b> Since it is obvious that the marriage is technically valid, it must be saying that they are permitted to remain married. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> No, it means <b>to say</b>

Daf 60a

<b>that he does not pay the fine of a seduced</b> woman. One who seduced a woman and does not wish to marry her must pay a fine (see Exodus 22:14–15). Since in this case he did marry her, he is not liable to pay the fine even though he is required to divorce her.
The Gemara relates that when <b>Rav Geviha went from Bei Ketil he stated</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Ashi,</b> who <b>said to him: Isn’t it Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan who both say:</b> A High Priest <b>may not marry a grown woman and a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally, but if he married</b> one of them <b>he is married?</b>
<b>Apparently,</b> the reason for this <i>halakha</i> is that since <b>she will eventually be a grown woman under him,</b> i.e., while married to him, and <b>she will eventually be a woman whose hymen was torn under him,</b> as she will not remain a virgin, they are permitted to remain married after the fact. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a High Priest who married a woman he raped or seduced, since <b>she will eventually be a non-virgin under him,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be understood as stating that they may remain married. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>difficult</b> for Rav Huna.
§ The <i>baraita</i> cited above taught: With regard to a woman who was <b>raped by another</b> man <b>and</b> a woman <b>seduced by another</b> man, the High Priest <b>may not marry</b> her. <b>And if he married</b> her, <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says</b> that <b>the child</b> born from this union <b>is a <i>ḥalal</i>, and the Rabbis say</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed. Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. And, so too, Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b>
<b>Some say</b> a different version of this statement. <b>Rav Huna said that Rav said: What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov? He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> that an unmarried man who has intercourse with an unmarried woman has thereby caused her to become a <i>zona</i>. Consequently, since the other man had intercourse with this woman outside of the context of marriage, she is a <i>zona</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does</b> he really <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Elazar? <b>Don’t we maintain</b> that <b>the teaching of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov</b> measures <b>a <i>kav</i> but is clean,</b> i.e., not many of his rulings have been recorded, but those that have been recorded are considered authoritative, and the <i>halakha</i> is always in accordance with his opinion? <b>However, with regard to this</b> ruling of Rabbi Elazar, <b>Rav Amram said that Rav said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with Rabbi Elazar.</b> The Gemara comments: This is indeed <b>difficult.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> This is not the reason for the dispute. Rather, they <b>disagree with regard to whether there is a <i>ḥalal</i> from</b> a relationship for which the man and woman are <b>liable for</b> transgressing <b>a positive mitzva.</b> The marriage of a High Priest to a non-virgin is a violation of the mitzva that a High Priest marry a virgin, but it is not expressed in the Torah as a prohibition against a High Priest marrying a non-virgin. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov holds</b> that <b>there is a <i>ḥalal</i> from</b> a relationship for which the man and woman are <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a positive mitzva, and the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>there is no <i>ḥalal</i> from</b> a relationship for which the man and woman are <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a positive mitzva.</b>
<b>What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov? As it is written: “A widow, or one divorced, or a <i>ḥalala</i>, or a <i>zona</i>, these shall he not take; but a virgin</b> of his own people shall he take for a wife” (Leviticus 21:14), <b>and it states</b> subsequently: <b>“And he shall not profane his seed among his people”</b> (Leviticus 21:15). Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov maintains that this profanation is referring <b>to all of them,</b> i.e., he profanes his seed by marrying any woman unfit for him, including a non-virgin.
<b>And</b> what do <b>the Sages</b> hold? The word <b>“these” concluded</b> discussion of <b>that matter.</b> Consequently, only the prohibitions listed before the phrase “these shall he not take” result in the offspring being a <i>ḥalal</i>. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said:</b> The word <b>“these”</b> comes <b>to exclude a menstruating woman.</b> If a priest has relations with a menstruating woman, the offspring is not a <i>ḥalal</i>, as this is not a prohibition specific to priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which is taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>From</b> the prohibitions preceding the phrase <b>“these</b> shall he not take” <b>you cause</b> your offspring to be <b>a <i>ḥalal</i>, but you do not cause</b> your offspring to be <b>a <i>ḥalal</i></b> by having a child <b>with a menstruating woman. In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? <b>It is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, let</b> the verse <b>write</b> the word <b>these at the end,</b> after stating that a High Priest must marry a virgin, in order to make it clear that if he marries a non-virgin their child is a <i>ḥalal</i>. The Gemara responds: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to a priest’s <b>betrothed sister, Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda say: He</b> must <b>become impure for her</b> upon her death. <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: He</b> may <b>not become impure for her.</b> With regard to his sister who has been <b>raped or seduced, all agree</b> that <b>he may not become impure for her</b> upon her death. With regard to his sister <b>whose hymen was torn accidentally, he may not become impure for her;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon would say</b> the following principle: If his sister was <b>fit for a High Priest, he</b> must <b>become impure for her,</b> but if she was <b>not fit for a High Priest, he may not become impure for her.</b>
<b>And</b> if his sister was <b>a grown woman, he</b> must <b>become impure for her according to everyone.</b> Even those who hold that a High Priest may not marry a grown woman because her hymen is no longer whole agree that with regard to a priest becoming impure, she is considered a virgin and he must therefore become impure for her upon her death.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda? They expound</b> the verse <b>as follows:</b> “And for his virgin sister, who is near to him, who has had no man, for her must he defile himself” (Leviticus 21:3). <b>“And for his virgin sister” excludes</b> one who has been <b>raped or seduced,</b> as they are not virgins.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I should exclude even a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally</b> via a foreign object. <b>The verse</b> therefore <b>states: “Who has had no man,”</b> to include only <b>one whose becoming</b> a non-virgin was caused <b>by a man,</b> i.e., through intercourse. <b>This</b> case of a woman <b>whose becoming</b> a non-virgin <b>was not</b> caused <b>by a man</b> but rather by an object is thereby <b>excluded</b> from the category of a non-virgin, and her brother does become impure for her. <b>“Who is near”;</b> this is <b>to include a betrothed</b> sister. <b>“To him”;</b> this is <b>to include a grown woman.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need a verse</b> to include a grown woman? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Meir say</b> that the word <b>“virgin” indicates even</b> a woman who is <b>partly a virgin,</b> i.e., a grown woman, whose hymen is partially intact? Consequently, when the verse states that the priest becomes impure for his virgin sister, a grown woman is included. The Gemara answers: The derivation from the verse is <b>necessary,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>we should derive</b> a verbal analogy from the word <b>“virgin”</b> in this context and the word <b>“virgin” from there,</b> the context of a High Priest: In the analogy, <b>just as there</b> the virgin referred to is <b>a young woman and not a grown woman, so too here</b> she must be <b>a young woman.</b> The verse therefore <b>teaches us</b> that a priest becomes impure for his sister even if she is a grown woman.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon, what is their reason? They expound as follows: “And for his virgin sister” excludes</b> a woman who was <b>raped or seduced and a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally,</b> who is also not considered a virgin. <b>“Who has had no</b> man” <b>excludes a betrothed</b> sister, although she is not yet fully married. <b>“Who is near”;</b> this is <b>to include a betrothed</b> woman <b>who was</b> then <b>divorced,</b> as she is once again near to her brother. <b>“To him”;</b> this is <b>to include a grown woman.</b> The Gemara asks: Can the term <b>“who is near”</b> come <b>to include a betrothed</b> woman <b>who was divorced?</b>

Daf 60b

<b>Didn’t Rabbi Shimon say:</b> If she was <b>fit for a High Priest,</b> her brother must <b>become impure for her,</b> and if she was <b>not fit for a High Priest,</b> her brother <b>may not become impure for her?</b> A divorced woman is not fit for a High Priest even if she had been only betrothed before her divorce. The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as the Merciful One includes</b> her by the term: Who is <b>near,</b> which includes any sister who is close to him, even if she is unfit for a High Priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally</b> should <b>also</b> be <b>included.</b> The Gemara responds that the term: Who is <b>near,</b> which is written in the singular, includes only <b>one</b> additional case <b>and not two.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> to render forbidden a woman whose hymen was accidentally torn and permit a divorcée who had previously been only betrothed, and not the opposite? The Gemara answers: In <b>this</b> case of the woman whose hymen was torn, <b>an action has been performed</b> on her body, whereas in <b>that</b> case of the divorcée, <b>no action has been performed</b> on her body.
The <i>baraita</i> cites Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon as holding that a priest may not become impure for his sister who was betrothed and then divorced, and it cites only Rabbi Shimon as holding that he may not become impure for his sister who was a grown woman. Based on this, the Gemara asks: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yosei left his partner,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>it may be inferred that with regard to a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that a priest does become impure. <b>From where</b> does <b>he</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains that he derives it <b>from</b> the phrase: “Who <b>has had no man,”</b> as a woman whose hymen was torn accidentally has not been with a man.
The Gemara asks: <b>Haven’t you</b> already <b>derived</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a betrothed woman from that phrase?
