<b>In any event,</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that a priest whose foreskin was <b>drawn forward and</b> one who was <b>born circumcised may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. This would seem to be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna</b> that a priest whose foreskin was drawn forward may not eat <i>teruma</i> at least by rabbinic law. The Gemara concludes: This is in fact <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of his opinion.
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: A priest who is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> may not partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> but <b>his wives [<i>nashav</i>] and slaves may partake</b> of it. The Gemara is puzzled by this teaching: <b>From where does a <i>tumtum</i> have wives?</b> If he does not have a visible male organ, how can he marry a woman? <b>If we say that he</b> merely <b>betrothed</b> a woman, <b>as it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a <i>tumtum</i> betrothed</b> a woman <b>his betrothal is</b> considered <b>a</b> valid <b>betrothal,</b> as he might be a male, and similarly if he <b>was betrothed</b> by a man, <b>his betrothal is</b> deemed <b>a</b> valid <b>betrothal</b> as he might be a female, there is a difficulty.
One could <b>say that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>said</b> that the betrothal of a <i>tumtum</i> is valid only <b>as a stringency,</b> i.e., out of concern that he might be a male, and therefore the woman cannot leave without a proper bill of divorce. But <b>should we say</b> that his betrothal is valid also <b>as a leniency,</b> to allow his wife to eat <i>teruma</i>? There is an <b>uncertainty</b> here that perhaps <b>he is a woman, and</b> one <b>woman cannot betroth</b> another <b>woman.</b>
<b>Abaye said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> is referring to a <i>tumtum</i> whose male organ is hidden, but he is speaking of a situation <b>where his testicles are visible externally.</b> Since it is evident that he is a male, he can betroth a woman even though he cannot have relations with her.
<b>Rava said</b> a different answer: <b>What is</b> meant here by the word <i>nashav</i>, which was translated earlier as his wives, but which can also be understood as <b>his women?</b> It refers here to the priest’s <b>mother,</b> who, after her husband the priest has passed away, may continue to eat <i>teruma</i> by virtue of her son. The Gemara questions this interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>His mother?</b> It <b>is obvious</b> that she may eat <i>teruma</i> on his account, as he is her offspring by a priest. The Gemara explains: This statement is nevertheless necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that only if the priest <b>is capable of having children</b> does he <b>enable</b> his mother <b>to eat</b> <i>teruma</i>, but if he <b>is incapable of having children</b> he <b>does not enable</b> his mother <b>to eat</b> <i>teruma</i>, and therefore a <i>tumtum</i>, who cannot have children, should not enable his mother to eat <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, as a woman may eat <i>teruma</i> by virtue of the child she bore a priest, even if that child is incapable of having children.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof in support of Abaye’s opinion from that which is taught in the latter part of the <i>baraita</i>: A priest who is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> may not partake of <i>teruma</i> or sacrificial food.</b> There is a difficulty here, as the <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tumtum</i> may not partake of <i>teruma</i> was already taught in the first part of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Granted, according to Abaye,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> in the <b>first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> the <i>halakha</i> governing a <i>tumtum</i> who is <b>definitely uncircumcised,</b> i.e., one whose testicles are visible externally, so that he is definitely male but cannot undergo circumcision because his member itself is hidden. <b>And</b> then <b>he teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> the <i>halakha</i> governing a <i>tumtum</i> about whom there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether he is <b>uncircumcised,</b> i.e., one whose genitalia are completely hidden, so that he might not even be a male.
<b>But according to Rava, why do I</b> need the repetition of the <i>halakha</i> governing a <b><i>tumtum</i></b> in <b>the latter clause?</b> The <i>tanna</i> already stated this <i>halakha</i> in the first part of the <i>baraita</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>What is</b> this <b><i>tumtum</i></b> referred to in the latter clause? It is a man who is definitely <b>uncircumcised.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Now,</b> if a <i>tumtum</i>, about whom there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether he is <b>uncircumcised, may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, as stated in the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, can it be supposed that a man who is <b>definitely uncircumcised</b> may eat <i>teruma</i>, so that it was necessary for the <i>baraita</i> to teach in the latter clause that he may not do so? The Gemara answers: <b>He is saying: What is the reason.</b> The <i>baraita</i> should be understood as follows: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>a <i>tumtum</i> may not partake of <i>teruma</i>?</b> It is <b>because</b> there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether he is <b>uncircumcised, and an uncircumcised</b> priest <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i> or sacrificial food.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this amoraic dispute as to whether or not one who had been circumcised but his residual foreskin was drawn forward is considered uncircumcised by Torah law is <b>parallel to</b> the following dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it is taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Shabbat</i> 16:7): One whose foreskin was <b>drawn forward, and</b> similarly, <b>one who was born circumcised, and a convert who converted when he was</b> already <b>circumcised, and a child whose</b> appropriate <b>time</b> for circumcision already <b>passed</b> and he was still uncircumcised, <b>and all others</b> who require <b>circumcision,</b> which, as the Gemara parenthetically adds, comes <b>to include one who has two foreskins,</b> both of which must be removed, <b>may be circumcised only during the day. Rabbi Elazar bar Shimon says:</b> If the circumcision is performed <b>at its</b> appropriate <b>time,</b> i.e., on the eighth day,

Daf 72b

<b>they may be circumcised only during the day.</b> However, if the circumcision is performed <b>not at its</b> appropriate <b>time, they may be circumcised</b> either <b>during the day or at night. What, is it not</b> the case that <b>they disagree about the following: One Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that the obligation to circumcise one whose foreskin was <b>drawn forward</b> is <b>by Torah law,</b> and therefore he must be circumcised during the day despite the fact that the procedure is not performed at the proper time, <b>and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar bar Shimon, <b>holds</b> that the circumcision of one whose foreskin was <b>drawn forward</b> is <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> the disagreement in that way? With regard to <b>a child whose</b> appropriate <b>time</b> for circumcision <b>has</b> already <b>passed, is there anyone who says that</b> the obligation to circumcise him is only <b>by rabbinic law?</b> Even after the eighth day, there is certainly a Torah obligation to circumcise him, and yet the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree about this case as well.
<b>Rather, everyone</b> agrees that the obligation to circumcise one whose foreskin was <b>drawn forward</b> is <b>by rabbinic law, and</b> that the obligation to circumcise <b>a child whose</b> appropriate <b>time</b> for circumcision <b>has</b> already <b>passed</b> is <b>by Torah law. And here they disagree with regard to the following: One Sage holds</b> that <b>we expound</b> the phrase <b>“and on the day”</b> in the verse “And on the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised” (Leviticus 12:3). The superfluous word “and” indicates that even if the child was not circumcised on the eighth day, the procedure must still be performed during the day. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar bar Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not expound</b> the phrase <b>“and on the day,”</b> and therefore a circumcision must be performed during the day only when it takes place on the eighth day, but afterward it may be performed even at night.
<b>As in</b> the case <b>where Rabbi Yoḥanan was sitting and he expounded: <i>Notar</i>,</b> the flesh of an offering that is left over beyond its allotted time, requires burning. If it is burnt <b>at its</b> appropriate <b>time,</b> i.e., on the same day that it became <i>notar</i>, it <b>may be burned only during the day.</b> If it is burnt <b>not at its</b> appropriate <b>time,</b> it <b>may be burned either during the day or at night.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Elazar raises an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a child who <b>is circumcised on</b> the <b>eighth</b> day <b>may be circumcised only during the day. From where</b> do I derive <b>to include</b> in this <i>halakha</i> a child who is circumcised <b>on the ninth, tenth, eleventh,</b> or <b>twelfth</b> day? <b>From where</b> is it derived that he, too, may be circumcised only during the day? Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And on the day,”</b> which teaches that the obligation to circumcise during the day extends beyond the eighth day itself.
<b>And even</b> the Sage <b>who does not expound</b> the letter <b><i>vav</i>,</b> meaning “and,” as superfluous, <b>expounds</b> the letters <b><i>vav</i> and <i>heh</i></b> when they come together and understands them as alluding to cases not explicitly mentioned in the biblical text. Regarding <i>notar</i> the verse states: “And that which remains [<i>vehanotar</i>] of the flesh of the offering on the third day shall be burnt with fire” (Leviticus 7:17), where the letters <i>vav</i> and <i>heh</i> teach that the obligation to burn <i>notar</i> during the day extends beyond the third day itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>was silent,</b> as he had no response.
<b>After</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>left, Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who was impressed with Rabbi Elazar’s exposition, <b>said to Reish Lakish: I saw that</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>son of Pedat, was sitting and expounding</b> the Torah <b>as Moses</b> had received it directly <b>from the mouth of the Almighty. Reish Lakish said to him:</b> Was this exposition <b>his own? It is a <i>baraita</i>.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan inquired: <b>Where is this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught?</b> Reish Lakish replied: It is <b>in <i>Torat Kohanim</i>,</b> otherwise known as <i>Sifra</i>, a work of halakhic midrash on the book of Leviticus. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>went out</b> and <b>learned</b> the entire <i>Torat Kohanim</i> <b>in three days, and reached</b> a full <b>understanding of it in three months.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> If <b>an uncircumcised</b> priest <b>sprinkled</b> the purification waters containing the ashes of a red heifer in order to purify someone who had contracted ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, <b>his sprinkling is valid, just as it is</b> in the case of a priest <b>who immersed himself that day</b> but does not become completely purified until nightfall. <b>As, although</b> such an individual <b>is prohibited from</b> eating <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> he is <b>fit for</b> all the rites connected to the red <b>heifer.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If <b>one who immersed himself that day</b> is fit for all the rites connected to the red heifer, that is because <b>he is</b> at least <b>permitted to</b> eat <b>tithes,</b> and so he is treated more leniently than one who is uncircumcised, for whom it is prohibited to partake of second tithe. The Gemara answers: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>we are speaking about eating? We spoke</b> in reference <b>to touching,</b> and the proof was as follows: <b>If one who immersed himself that day</b> and <b>who is forbidden to touch <i>teruma</i>,</b> as he invalidates <i>teruma</i> by touch, is nevertheless <b>permitted</b> to participate <b>in</b> all the rites connected to the red <b>heifer;</b> then with regard to one who is <b>uncircumcised, who is permitted to touch</b> <i>teruma</i> according to all opinions, <b>is it not right that</b> he should be <b>permitted</b> to participate <b>in</b> the rites connected to <b>the</b> red <b>heifer?</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>That</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>an uncircumcised</b> priest <b>sprinkled</b> the purification waters, <b>his sprinkling is valid. And an incident occurred</b> in which such an individual sprinkled the purification waters <b>and the Sages validated his sprinkling.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Para</i> 5:5): If <b>a <i>tumtum</i> sanctified</b> the purification waters by placing a small amount of ashes from the red heifer into springwater that had been placed into a container for that purpose, <b>his sanctification is invalid because</b> there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether he is <b>uncircumcised, and an uncircumcised</b> man <b>is disqualified from sanctifying</b> the purification waters. <b>But</b> if <b>a hermaphrodite sanctified</b> the purification waters, <b>his sanctification is valid. Rabbi Yehuda</b> disagrees and <b>says: Even</b> if <b>a hermaphrodite sanctified</b> the purification waters, <b>his sanctification is invalid, because</b> there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether a hermaphrodite is <b>a woman, and a woman is disqualified from sanctifying</b> the purification waters. <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that one who is definitely <b>uncircumcised, and</b> even one about whom there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether he is <b>uncircumcised, is disqualified from sanctifying</b> the purification waters.
<b>Rav Yosef said: This <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i>, who disqualifies one who is uncircumcised from sanctifying the purification waters, <b>is a <i>tanna</i> from the school of Rabbi Akiva, who includes the uncircumcised</b> in the same <i>halakha</i> <b>as</b> that which governs <b>the ritually impure. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that the words “any man” in the verse <b>“Any man</b> from the seed of Aaron who is a leper or a <i>zav</i> shall not eat of the holy things until he be pure” (Leviticus 22:4), come <b>to include</b> one who is <b>uncircumcised,</b> and it is prohibited for him as well to partake of consecrated food. And so too, with regard to other matters as well, e.g., sanctifying the purification waters, one who is uncircumcised has the same status as one who is ritually impure.
<b>Rava said: I was sitting</b> at the time <b>before Rav Yosef, and I had</b> the following <b>difficulty:</b> If so, according to Rav Yosef’s opinion that the uncircumcised and the ritually impure have the same status, should one <b>not</b> be able <b>to find a <i>tanna</i> who teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the uncircumcised and</b> that of <b>the ritually impure</b> together, <b>and we should say</b> that this is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva?</b> There should be some source that reflects this view.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>not</b> such a source? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who is <b>uncircumcised and</b> one who is <b>ritually impure are exempt from</b> making an <b>appearance</b> in the Temple on each of the three pilgrim Festivals. The Gemara refutes this argument: This is no proof, as <b>there</b> it can be argued that one who is uncircumcised is exempt from appearing in the Temple <b>because he is repulsive,</b> and it is unbefitting that one who is uncircumcised appear in the Temple courtyard, but this does not mean that with regard to other matters as well he is treated like one who is ritually impure.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda <b>follow their</b> usual line of <b>reasoning</b> with regard to a hermaphrodite. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All are fit to sanctify</b> the purification waters <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor. Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit</b> for the task, <b>but deems a woman and a hermaphrodite unfit.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reasoning of the Rabbis? As it is written: “And they shall take for the impure of the ashes of the burning of the sin-offering,</b> and he shall place on it running water in a vessel” (Numbers 19:17). The juxtaposition of the placement of the water to the gathering of the ashes indicates that they are governed by the same <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, <b>those who are unfit for gathering</b> the ashes <b>are</b> likewise <b>unfit for sanctification,</b> whereas <b>those who are fit for gathering</b> the ashes <b>are</b> likewise <b>fit for sanctification.</b> Since a woman is fit to gather the ashes of the red heifer, she may also sanctify its waters.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you: If so,</b> then <b>let the verse state: And he shall take. What</b> is the significance of the shift to the plural form: <b>“And they shall take”?</b> It teaches <b>that even those who are unfit there are fit here.</b> As the <i>halakhot</i> of the two cases are not identical, Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit to perform the sanctification.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda <b>a woman</b> should <b>also</b> be fit to sanctify the purification waters. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda reads the verse precisely. It says: <b>“And he shall place</b> on it,” <b>and not: And she shall place</b> on it. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? <b>If</b> the verse <b>was written: And he shall take…and he shall place, I would say</b> that <b>one</b> individual must <b>take</b> the ashes <b>and</b> the same <b>one</b> must also <b>place</b> the water on them. <b>The Merciful One</b> therefore <b>writes: “And they shall take,”</b> indicating that the ritual is valid even when performed by two different individuals.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written: And they shall take…and they shall place, I would say that two</b> people must <b>take</b> the ashes <b>and two</b> must <b>place</b> the water on them, but if these rites are performed by fewer than two people they are invalid. <b>The Torah</b> therefore <b>states: “And they shall take…and he shall place,”</b> to teach <b>that even</b> if <b>two</b> people <b>take</b> the ashes <b>and one</b> person <b>places</b> the water on them, the ritual is valid. Since the verse had to be formulated precisely in this manner in order to teach that <i>halakha</i>, the words “and he shall place” cannot be understood as coming to exclude a woman.

Daf 73a

It is further stated: <b>“And the pure person shall sprinkle upon the impure”</b> (Numbers 19:19). The verse states <b>“pure”;</b> this indicates <b>by inference that he is</b> in some way <b>ritually impure.</b> In other words, the verse speaks of one who is pure only in relation to one who is impure. Were this not the case, there would have been no need at all to mention his purity, as it would have been understood that since the red heifer is called a sin-offering, with regard to which purity is paramount, the one performing the ritual must be pure. Of necessity, then, this “pure” individual is not completely pure in all regards. This <b>teaches that one who immersed himself that day is fit to</b> perform the rites connected to the red <b>heifer.</b>
The Gemara returns to the previous discussion. <b>They raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> In the case of <b>an uncircumcised</b> man, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> his eating second <b>tithe?</b> Can one claim that <b>just as</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing the <b>Paschal lamb is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing second <b>tithe with regard to acute mourning,</b> in that an acute mourner, who may not eat second tithe, is likewise prohibited from partaking of the Paschal lamb, so <b>too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning second <b>tithe is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>Paschal lamb with regard to lack of circumcision,</b> in that an uncircumcised man, who may not partake of the Paschal lamb, is likewise prohibited from eating second tithe?
<b>Or perhaps</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing the <b>stringent</b> case of the Paschal lamb <b>is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing the <b>lenient</b> case of second tithe, but the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>lenient</b> case of second tithe <b>is not derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>stringent</b> case of the Paschal lamb, and therefore it is prohibited for an uncircumcised man to partake of the Paschal lamb, but he may eat second tithe.
Rav Sheshet <b>said to them: You</b> already <b>learned</b> the answer to this question in a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 1:9): The following <i>halakhot</i> apply to both <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> the <b>first fruits</b> of the new harvest, which must be given to the priests: If a priest ate of them while in a state of ritual impurity, <b>he is liable</b> to the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven; <b>and</b> if a non-priest ate of them unintentionally, he must restore the value of the produce he ate, adding <b>one-fifth</b> of its value as a fine; <b>and they are</b> both <b>forbidden to non-priests.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>And they are</b> considered in all regards <b>the</b> private <b>property of the priest</b> to whom they were given; <b>and they are nullified,</b> i.e., rendered permitted for consumption by non-priests, <b>in</b> a mixture of <b>one hundred and one,</b> when there are at least one hundred parts of permitted food for each part of <i>teruma</i> or first fruits; <b>and they</b> both <b>require washing of the hands</b> before they may be eaten; <b>and</b> if a priest is ritually impure, he may not eat of <i>teruma</i> or first fruits, even after immersion, until after <b>sunset</b> on the day of his immersion. All of <b>these</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to <i>teruma</i> and first fruits, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to second <b>tithe.</b>
Rav Sheshet resumes his argument: <b>And if it is so</b> that one who is uncircumcised may eat second tithe, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> also <b>teach: It is prohibited for an uncircumcised man</b> to eat of <i>teruma</i> and first fruits, <b>which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to second <b>tithe.</b>
The Gemara rejects this argument: This is no proof, as the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>taught</b> only some of the differences between <i>teruma</i> and first fruits on the one hand and second tithe on the other, <b>and he omitted</b> others. The Gemara asks: The mishna is sometimes not exhaustive, but it never omits only one case. <b>What</b> other difference <b>did he omit that</b> you say that <b>he</b> also <b>omitted this</b> difference?
The Gemara answers: <b>He omitted</b> the following, <b>as he teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>There are</b> <i>halakhot</i> that apply to second <b>tithe and first fruits, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b><i>teruma</i>. As</b> second <b>tithe and first fruits require</b> that they be <b>brought to</b> a particular <b>place,</b> Jerusalem, where they must be eaten, whereas <i>teruma</i> may be consumed in all places; <b>and they</b> both <b>require a declaration,</b> as a declaration must be made on the last day of Passover in the fourth and seventh years of the Sabbatical cycle, stating that one’s agricultural obligations with regard to tithes have been fulfilled properly, and so too a declaration must be made when first fruits are brought to the Temple; <b>and they are forbidden to an acute mourner; and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> an acute mourner to partake of first fruits. <b>And they</b> both <b>require eradication</b> before Passover in the fourth and seventh years of the Sabbatical cycle if one failed to bring them beforehand; <b>and Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> first fruits from the obligation of eradication.
<b>And yet</b> second tithe and first fruits differ from <i>teruma</i> in that <b>it is prohibited to burn</b> the former and benefit from the burning, even when the produce is <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity</b> and therefore unfit to be eaten, e.g., one may not burn impure oil for light;

Daf 73b

<b>and one who eats them when they themselves,</b> the second tithe and first fruits, <b>are ritually impure is flogged,</b> even though he himself is ritually pure, <b>which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b><i>teruma</i>;</b> and these differences the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach. Apparently,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>taught</b> certain differences between the cases <b>and omitted</b> others. Therefore, the omission of the <i>halakha</i> governing an uncircumcised man does not prove that it is permitted for him to eat second tithe.
§ Having cited the mishna, the Gemara proceeds to discuss it. It was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that second tithe and first fruits <b>are forbidden to an acute mourner; and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> an acute mourner to partake of first fruits. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do</b> the Rabbis derive that first fruits are forbidden to one who is in acute mourning? <b>As it is written: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, or of your wine, or of your oil…nor the offering of your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:17), <b>and the Master said: “The offering [<i>teruma</i>] of your hand,” these are</b> the <b>first fruits. And first fruits are juxtaposed</b> in this verse <b>to</b> second <b>tithe: Just as</b> the second <b>tithe is forbidden to an acute mourner, so too, first fruits</b> are <b>forbidden to an acute mourner.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> counters that since <b>the Merciful One calls</b> first fruits <b>“<i>teruma</i>,”</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing them is similar to that which governs <i>teruma</i>: <b>Just as <i>teruma</i> is permitted to an acute mourner, so too, first fruits</b> are <b>permitted to an acute mourner.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> both second tithe and first fruits <b>require eradication</b> before Passover in the fourth and seventh years of the Sabbatical cycle; <b>and Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> first fruits from the obligation of eradication. <b>One Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>juxtaposes</b> first fruits to second tithe: Just as second tithe is subject to eradication, so too are first fruits. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>does not juxtapose</b> the two <i>halakhot</i> and derive one from the other.
It was stated above that <b>it is prohibited to burn</b> second tithe and first fruits even when they are <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity, and</b> that <b>one who eats them when they themselves,</b> the second tithe and first fruits, <b>are ritually impure is flogged,</b> even though he himself is ritually pure. <b>From where do we</b> derive these <i>halakhot</i>? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The verse with regard to the confession of tithes states: <b>“I did not consume of it while impure”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:14), a general statement that means <b>whether I,</b> the one who ate it, was <b>ritually impure, and</b> the tithe <b>was ritually pure,</b> or <b>whether I was ritually pure and</b> the tithe <b>was ritually impure.</b> Regardless, the tithe may not be consumed through burning or eating in a state of impurity.
The <i>tanna</i> adds: <b>And where one is</b> actually <b>warned against eating</b> second tithe in a state of impurity, this <b>I do not know.</b> Although it is obvious from the verse that this is prohibited, the source for the prohibition is unclear. The Gemara is puzzled by this last statement: The prohibition against eating second tithe when one is in a state of <b>ritual impurity of the body</b> is <b>explicitly written,</b> as it is stated with regard to the ritual impurity imparted by a creeping animal: <b>“The soul that touches it shall be impure until the evening, and he shall not eat from the holy things unless he has washed his flesh in water”</b> (Leviticus 22:6). This is referring to second tithe, as will be explained later (74b).
The Gemara explains: Rather, <b>this is</b> the <b>dilemma he is raising: From where</b> is it derived that one may not eat it when the tithe <b>itself</b> is in a state of <b>ritual impurity? The verse states: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:17), <b>and later it states</b> with regard to offerings that have been disqualified: <b>“You shall eat it within your gates, the impure and the pure alike, as the gazelle and as the hart”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:22). <b>And</b> a Sage <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Even a ritually impure and a ritually pure</b> person <b>may eat</b> together <b>on one table</b> and <b>out of one bowl without concern. And the Merciful One states: That which I said to you there,</b> with regard to disqualified offerings: <b>“You shall eat it within your gates,”</b> means regardless of whether it is the individual or the meat that is impure; but <b>here,</b> with regard to second tithe, <b>you may not eat</b> it in that state. From here it is derived that one may not eat second tithe when the tithe itself is ritually impure.
It was stated above that one is prohibited from burning second tithe and first fruits even when they are ritually impure, <b>which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> does not apply to <i>teruma</i>? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: As the verse</b> with regard to the declaration of tithes <b>states: “I did not consume of it while impure”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:14), and the words “of it” teach that <b>of it,</b> i.e., tithe, <b>you may not burn</b> when it is impure, <b>but you may burn</b> and derive benefit from <b>the oil of <i>teruma</i> that has become ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But say</b> perhaps as follows: <b>Of it you may not burn, but you may burn</b> and derive benefit from <b>consecrated oil that became ritually impure.</b> The Gemara refutes this suggestion: That possibility is unacceptable. Is it <b>not an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? <b>If</b> with regard to <b>the tithe, which is lenient, the Torah said: “I did not burn of it while impure,”</b> then with regard to <b>consecrated</b> oil, <b>which is</b> more <b>stringent,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> prohibited to burn them while ritually impure?
The Gemara retorts: <b>If so,</b> then with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> as well,</b> say that <b>it is an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as <i>teruma</i> is certainly more sacred than tithes. If it is prohibited to benefit from second tithe while it is burning, all the more so would it be prohibited to benefit from <i>teruma</i> while it is burning. The Gemara answers: <b>Isn’t it written “of it”?</b> From there it is derived that there is an item excluded from the prohibition against burning in a state of ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to conclude that “of it” comes to exclude <i>teruma</i>? Perhaps it comes to exclude consecrated items. The Gemara replies: <b>It is reasonable</b> that <b>I do not exclude consecrated items</b> from the prohibition against benefiting from their burning, as with regard to consecrated items there are many stringent elements. Their Hebrew acronym is <b><i>peh</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>ayin</i>, <i>kaf</i>, <i>samekh</i>,</b> which is a mnemonic for the following stringencies that apply to consecrated items and not to <i>teruma</i>:
<b><i>Piggul</i>:</b> If, during one of the rites involved in the sacrifice of an offering, i.e., slaughter, receiving the blood, bringing it to the altar, or sprinkling it on the altar, the priest or the one bringing the offering entertains the thought of eating the offering at a time that is unfit for eating, the offering is thereby invalidated. <b><i>Notar</i>:</b> Meat of an offering that remained beyond its allotted time may not be eaten and must be burned. <b>Offering [<i>korban</i>]:</b> It is an offering to God. <b>Misuse</b> of consecrated objects <b>[<i>me’ila</i>]:</b> One who unwittingly derives benefit from consecrated items is required to bring a guilt-offering for misuse of consecrated objects. <b><i>Karet</i>:</b> The punishment of one who eats consecrated items while ritually impure is <i>karet</i>. <b>Forbidden to an acute mourner [<i>asur le’onen</i>]:</b> An acute mourner is prohibited from eating consecrated items. None of these <i>halakhot</i> apply to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, consecrated items are more stringent than <i>teruma</i>, and accordingly they are not excluded from the prohibition against deriving benefit while ritually impure.
The Gemara rejects this argument. <b>On the contrary, it is <i>teruma</i> that I would not exclude</b> from the prohibition, <b>as</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> there are many stringent elements, represented by the acronym <b><i>mem</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>zayin</i>,</b> which is a mnemonic for the following: <b>Death [<i>mita</i>]:</b> One who is prohibited from eating <i>teruma</i> but ate it intentionally is liable to the punishment of death at the hand of Heaven. <b>One-fifth [<i>ḥomesh</i>]:</b> A non-priest, to whom <i>teruma</i> is forbidden, who unwittingly ate <i>teruma</i> is obligated to pay its value to the priest plus one-fifth of the sum. <b>And</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>does not have</b> the possibility of <b>redemption [<i>pidyon</i>]:</b> Once it is sanctified, <i>teruma</i> may not be redeemed and rendered non-sacred. <b>And it is forbidden to non-priests [<i>zarim</i>].</b> These stringencies do not apply to consecrated items.
The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> stringencies that apply to consecrated items <b>are</b> more <b>numerous</b> than those that apply to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, it is appropriate to be more stringent with consecrated items and exclude impure <i>teruma</i> from the prohibition against deriving benefit from it while it is burned. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different reason, without counting the number of stringencies: Consecrated items are more stringent because one who eats them while ritually impure is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which <b>is more severe</b> than death at the hand of Heaven, the punishment in the case of <i>teruma</i>.
It was further stated above that <b>one who eats</b> second tithe and first fruits <b>when they themselves,</b> the second tithe and first fruits, <b>are ritually impure is flogged, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara infers from this that <b>it is lashes that he does not receive</b> when he eats <i>teruma</i> that is ritually impure; <b>however,</b> the transgression of <b>a prohibition is</b> involved. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is prohibited? <b>The verse</b> referring to offerings that have been disqualified <b>states: “You shall eat it within your gates”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:22). The word “it” indicates that it is only <b>this,</b> disqualified offerings, that may be eaten in a state of impurity, <b>but not another</b> type of consecrated food. This is a prohibition that is derived by inference from a positive mitzva, i.e., it is not stated in the Torah in the form of a prohibition. <b>And</b> there is a principle that <b>a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> is classified as <b>a positive mitzva,</b> for which no lashes are administered.
The Gemara demonstrated earlier that no proof can be adduced from the mishna cited by Rav Sheshet, as the <i>tanna</i> of that mishna taught only some of the differences between second tithe and <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rav Ashi said: From the first part</b> of the mishna <b>as well, you</b> can <b>conclude that he taught</b> certain differences <b>and omitted</b> others, <b>from</b> the fact that <b>he does not teach</b> the following additional difference:

Daf 74a

<i>Teruma</i> and first fruits <b>apply in all the years of the seven-year</b> Sabbatical cycle, including the third and the sixth years, <b>and they do not have</b> the possibility of <b>redemption,</b> as once they are sanctified they may not be redeemed and rendered non-sacred. <b>This is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>second tithe,</b> which applies only in the first, second, fourth, and fifth years of the cycle and which can be redeemed. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from here</b> that the <i>tanna</i> did not list all of the differences between second tithe and <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara resumes its discussion of whether or not an uncircumcised man is prohibited from eating second tithe. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof with regard to this question from the following <i>baraita</i>: If <b>shreds</b> of flesh <b>that invalidate the circumcision</b> remain after the foreskin was removed, <b>one may not eat <i>teruma</i>, nor the Paschal lamb, nor sacrificial food, nor tithe. What, is it not</b> referring to <b>tithe of produce,</b> and so the dilemma is resolved? The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>No,</b> the tithe mentioned in this <i>baraita</i> is <b>animal tithe.</b> The <i>baraita</i> teaches that the meat of the animal tithe was forbidden to one who is uncircumcised.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Animal tithe is</b> the same as <b>sacrificial food,</b> as it too is an offering the meat of which is eaten by the animal’s owner; why would the <i>tanna</i> single it out? The Gemara counters: <b>And according to your reasoning</b> that the <i>baraita</i> would not have singled out specific offerings, <b>didn’t we learn</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that an uncircumcised man may not eat the <b>Paschal lamb, and</b> yet <b>it</b> also <b>teaches</b> that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>sacrificial food?</b>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Granted,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to mention both <b>the Paschal lamb and sacrificial food. As, if</b> the <i>baraita</i> had <b>taught</b> only the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>the Paschal lamb,</b> one might have said that an uncircumcised man may not eat the Paschal lamb <b>because</b> the disqualification resulting from <b>lack of circumcision</b> is <b>written</b> explicitly <b>with regard to the Paschal lamb, but</b> with regard to other <b>sacrificial food,</b> concerning which the Bible says nothing about circumcision, one might <b>say</b> that there is <b>no</b> such prohibition. <b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>baraita</i> had <b>taught</b> only the <i>halakha</i> with respect to <b>sacrificial food, I would say: What</b> is meant here by <b>sacrificial food?</b> This is referring specifically to <b>the Paschal lamb,</b> concerning which the prohibition with regard to an uncircumcised man is stated explicitly, but other sacrificial food is permitted to him. <b>But why do I</b> need <b>animal tithe</b> to be mentioned at all? It is no different than any other sacrificial food. In that case, the tithe mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> is referring to second tithe.
The Gemara suggests a different refutation of this proof: <b>Rather,</b> the tithe mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>first tithe,</b> the one-tenth of the produce that is given to the Levites, <b>and</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that <b>first tithe is forbidden to common</b> Israelites. Since first tithe is forbidden to an ordinary Israelite, it may similarly be forbidden to an uncircumcised man. However, there is no proof from here that second tithe is forbidden to one who is uncircumcised, as second tithe is permitted even to ordinary Israelites.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof <b>from</b> that which <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav of Difti taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>An uncircumcised</b> man <b>is prohibited</b> from eating <b>of two</b> different <b>tithes. What, is it not</b> that <b>one</b> is the <b>tithe of produce and one</b> is <b>animal tithe?</b> The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>Here, too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>first tithe, and</b> the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from yet another <i>baraita</i>: <b>It is prohibited for an acute mourner</b> to eat second <b>tithe, but</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him to eat <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> to participate in the preparation of the red <b>heifer. It is prohibited for one who immersed himself that day</b> but does not become completely purified until nightfall to eat <b><i>teruma</i>, but</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him to participate in the preparation of the red <b>heifer and</b> to eat second <b>tithe. It is prohibited for</b> one who <b>lacks atonement,</b> e.g., a <i>zav</i> or leper who immersed at the conclusion of his period of impurity but has not yet brought an offering for his atonement, to participate in the preparation of the red <b>heifer, but</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him to eat <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> second <b>tithe. And if it is so</b> that an uncircumcised man may eat second tithe, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> also <b>teach: It is prohibited for an uncircumcised</b> man to eat <b><i>teruma</i>, but</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him to participate in the preparation of the red <b>heifer and</b> to eat second <b>tithe.</b> The fact that the <i>baraita</i> omits this ruling proves that an uncircumcised man is in fact prohibited from eating second tithe.
The Gemara rejects this argument: No proof can be adduced from here, as <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> was <b>taught</b> by a <i>tanna</i> <b>from the school of Rabbi Akiva, who includes an uncircumcised</b> man in the same <i>halakha</i> <b>as</b> that which governs one who is <b>ritually impure. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The words “any man” in the verse <b>“Any man</b> from the seed of Aaron who is a leper or a <i>zav</i> shall not eat of the holy things until he be pure” (Leviticus 22:4) come <b>to include</b> one who is <b>uncircumcised;</b> he, too, is prohibited from partaking of consecrated food or participating in the preparation of the red heifer.
With regard to the issue itself, the Gemara inquires: <b>And who</b> is the <b><i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Akiva? It is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who disagrees with <b>Rabbi Yosef the Babylonian. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The burning</b> of the red heifer <b>by an acute mourner or by</b> one who <b>lacks atonement is valid. Rabbi Yosef the Babylonian says:</b> If the burning is performed by <b>an acute mourner,</b> it is <b>valid;</b> but if it is performed by one who <b>lacks atonement,</b> it is <b>invalid.</b> The anonymous first <i>tanna</i> clearly disagrees with Rabbi Akiva, as the previous <i>baraita</i>, which was attributed to Rabbi Akiva, states that one who lacks atonement is prohibited from participating in the preparation of the red heifer. It may be presumed that this <i>tanna</i> disagrees with Rabbi Akiva with respect to one who is uncircumcised as well.
The Gemara further comments on this issue. <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak, too, maintains</b> that <b>an uncircumcised</b> man is <b>prohibited from</b> eating second <b>tithe, as Rabbi Yitzḥak said: From where</b> is it derived that <b>an uncircumcised</b> man <b>is prohibited from</b> eating second <b>tithe? It is stated:</b> “And I did not consume <b>of it</b> while impure” (Deuteronomy 26:14) <b>with regard to</b> second <b>tithe, and it is stated:</b> “Do not eat <b>of it</b> raw” (Exodus 12:9) <b>with regard to the Paschal lamb. Just as</b> in the case of <b>the Paschal lamb,</b> with regard to which <b>“of it” is stated, an uncircumcised</b> man <b>is prohibited from</b> eating <b>it, so too,</b> in the case of second <b>tithe,</b> with regard to which <b>“of it” is stated, an uncircumcised</b> man <b>is prohibited from</b> eating <b>it.</b>
With regard to this verbal analogy, the Gemara comments: It must be that this phrase “of it” <b>is available,</b> i.e., it is superfluous in its own context and therefore available for the purpose of establishing a verbal analogy. <b>As, if it is not available,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted</b> logically, as it is possible to say: <b>What</b> is unique <b>to the Paschal lamb?</b> It is <b>that one is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> it being <b><i>piggul</i> or <i>notar</i>, or</b> due to him being <b>ritually impure.</b> It could therefore be argued that it is owing to the Paschal lamb’s special sanctity and severity that an uncircumcised man may not partake of it. But from where is it derived that an uncircumcised man may not eat second tithe? The Gemara concludes: This is <b>not so,</b> as the phrase “of it” <b>is</b> indeed <b>available</b> for establishing the verbal analogy.
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> of the phrases “of it” is not needed in its own context and <b>is</b> therefore <b>available</b> for establishing a verbal analogy? <b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: “Of it” is written three</b> times <b>with</b> regard to <b>the Paschal lamb:</b> “Do not eat of it raw… And you shall not leave any of it until morning, and that which remains of it until the morning you shall burn with fire” (Exodus 12:9–10). The three instances of “of it” are expounded as follows: <b>One for itself,</b> to teach that the prohibition relates to the Paschal lamb; <b>and one for the verbal analogy; and one for</b> another purpose.
<b>According to the one who says</b> that <b>the verse comes to provide you with a positive</b> mitzva to burn that which is left over <b>after</b> it has taught <b>the prohibition</b> against leaving it over until the morning, to teach that one is not flogged for violating the prohibition, because any prohibition that can be rectified by the performance of a positive mitzva does not carry a punishment of lashes; <b>since “that which remains [<i>notar</i>]” is written, “of it” is also written. And according to the one who says</b> that the verse comes <b>to provide him with the second morning for burning,</b> i.e., to teach that the leftover meat of the Paschal lamb is not burned on the following morning, which is a Festival, but rather on the following morning, the first of the intermediate days of the Festival; <b>since “until morning” is written, “of it” is also written.</b>
Similarly, <b>“of it” is written three</b> times <b>with</b> regard to second <b>tithe:</b> “I did not eat of it in my mourning, and I did not consume of it while impure, and I did not give of it for the dead” (Deuteronomy 26:14). The three instances of “of it” are expounded as follows: <b>One for itself; and one for</b> that which <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said, that the verse comes to permit a priest to burn impure <i>teruma</i> oil and derive benefit from its light; <b>and one for</b> the following teaching of <b>Reish Lakish.</b>
<b>As Reish Lakish said</b> that <b>Rabbi Samya said: From where</b> is it derived that if the <b>second tithe became ritually impure, it is permitted for one to anoint</b> one’s body <b>with it? As it is stated: “Nor did I give of it for the dead.”</b> It is <b>for the dead that I did not give</b> of it, <b>but for the living</b> in a manner <b>similar</b> to the way it is given for <b>the dead, I gave</b> of it. Now, <b>what usage</b> of tithe <b>is the same for the living and the dead? You must say it is anointing.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra strongly objects to this: But say</b> that the verse is referring not to anointing but to <b>purchasing a coffin and shrouds for</b> one who is deceased with money received in exchange for the second tithe; this is prohibited, but buying clothing and the like for one who is living is permitted. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: “Of it”</b> indicates benefit derived <b>from</b> the tithe <b>itself</b> and not from the money acquired in exchange for the tithe. <b>Rav Ashi said</b> a different answer: <b>“I did not give”</b> must be <b>similar to “I did not eat”; just as there,</b> eating is <b>from</b> the tithe <b>itself, so too here,</b> giving is <b>from</b> the tithe <b>itself.</b> In any event, the three instances of “of it” written with regard to second tithe are required for different expositions.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> yet there is <b>still</b> a difficulty, as the verbal analogy <b>is available</b> only <b>from one side,</b> since only the verse with regard to the Paschal lamb is superfluous in its own context. Granted, <b>this</b> works out <b>well according to the one who says</b> that <b>one can derive from</b> a verbal analogy that is available only from one side <b>and one cannot refute it</b> logically, even if there are valid counterarguments. <b>But according to the one who said</b> that <b>one can derive from</b> such an analogy and <b>one can</b> also <b>refute it</b> logically, if there are grounds to distinguish between the two cases, <b>what can be said?</b> As explained above, the analogy between the Paschal lamb and second tithe can be refuted.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>of Rabbi Abbahu</b> with regard to the burning of impure <i>teruma</i> oil <b>is derived from what Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh</b> said. <b>As Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My <i>terumot</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:8)? From the amplification of the plural “My <i>terumot</i>,” it is derived that <b>the verse is speaking of two <i>terumot</i>, one <i>teruma</i> that is ritually pure and one <i>teruma</i> that is ritually impure. And the Merciful One states:</b> “I have given <b>you,”</b> i.e., <b>it shall be yours,</b> and you may derive benefit from it. Since there is a stringent prohibition against eating impure <i>teruma</i>, the benefit that is permitted is <b>to burn it beneath your cooked dish.</b> As the allowance to benefit from the burning of impure <i>teruma</i> is derived from here, the phrase “of it” is available on both sides.
§ It is taught in the mishna that <b>all</b> those <b>who are ritually impure</b> with any type of ritual impurity may not eat <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: The verse states: “Any man from the seed of Aaron who is a leper or a <i>zav</i></b> shall not eat of the holy things until he be pure” (Leviticus 22:4). Now, <b>what matter is the same</b>

Daf 74b

<b>for</b> all the <b>seed of Aaron,</b> both sons and daughters? <b>You must say it is <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But say</b> that perhaps the verse is referring to <b>the breast and thigh</b> of a peace-offering, which also may be eaten by all the seed of Aaron, both male and female? The Gemara answers: The breast and thigh are not permitted to males and females in equal manner, as they <b>are not</b> permitted <b>to</b> the daughter of a priest <b>who returns</b> to the home of her father. If the daughter of a priest marries a non-priest, it is prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i> or sacrificial food. If she is widowed or divorced and has no living descendants by her non-priest husband, it is once again permitted for her to eat <i>teruma</i>, but she may not partake of the breast and thigh of the offerings.
The Gemara asks: If so, the same may be said about <b><i>teruma</i> as well,</b> as it is <b>not</b> permitted <b>to a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> a woman who is disqualified from marrying a priest, even though she is the daughter of a priest. The Gemara answers: <b>A <i>ḥalala</i> is not</b> considered <b>the seed of Aaron.</b>
The Gemara challenges the <i>halakha</i> recorded in the <i>baraita</i> that one who lacks atonement may eat <i>teruma</i>. <b>And from where</b> do you know <b>that this</b> verse: “Any man from the seed of Aaron who is a leper or a <i>zav</i> shall not eat of the holy things <b>until he be pure,”</b> means that he may not eat of the holy things <b>until sunset? Say</b> that perhaps it means that he may not eat of them <b>until he brings</b> his <b>atonement</b> offering and is entirely pure.
The Gemara answers: <b>This cannot enter your mind, as</b> a <i>tanna</i> of <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that <b>the verse is speaking of a <i>zav</i> who</b> experienced only <b>two sightings</b> of an emission, <b>and of a quarantined leper,</b> i.e., a suspected leper who has not yet been declared conclusively ritually impure by a priest. Both of these individuals are ritually impure, but they need not bring an offering as part of the purification process. When understood in this way, the leper and <i>zav</i> are <b>similar to</b> one who touches any object that is <b>impure</b> with ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> mentioned later in the verse: <b>Just as</b> one who touches anything that is <b>impure</b> with ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse does not require an atonement</b> offering for his impurity, <b>these too,</b> the <i>zav</i> and leper referred to in this verse, <b>do not require an atonement</b> offering; rather, they achieve complete purification at sunset.
The Gemara raises a question: <b>But say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> sunset alone suffices to permit the eating of <i>teruma</i> <b>applies only</b> to one <b>who does not require</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering but merely has to wait until sunset to achieve complete purification. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>one who does require</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering, perhaps he may not eat <i>teruma</i> <b>until he brings</b> his <b>atonement</b> offering.
<b>And furthermore,</b> the Gemara raises a question with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:3): When the period of ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i> or a leper has been completed and he <b>immersed</b> during the day <b>and emerged, he may</b> immediately <b>partake of</b> second <b>tithe;</b> once <b>the sun has set for him,</b> he may <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>;</b> once he has <b>brought his atonement</b> offering, he may <b>eat sacrificial food. From where do we</b> derive these different <i>halakhot</i>?
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Three verses are written</b> with regard to purity for eating sacred food. <b>It is written: “And he shall not eat of the holy things, unless he has bathed his flesh in water”</b> (Leviticus 22:6); <b>but</b> if <b>he has bathed,</b> i.e., immersed, he is immediately <b>pure</b> and may partake of sacred food. <b>And it is written: “And when the sun has set, he shall be pure, and afterward he may eat from the holy things”</b> (Leviticus 22:7), which indicates that he must wait until sunset. <b>And it is</b> further <b>written: “And the priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 12:8), which indicates that following childbirth a woman is not completely pure until she has brought her offering. <b>How so?</b> How can the apparent discrepancy between these three verses be resolved? <b>Here,</b> in the first verse, it is referring <b>to</b> second <b>tithe; there,</b> in the second verse, it is referring <b>to <i>teruma</i>;</b> and <b>here,</b> in the third verse, it is referring <b>to sacrificial food.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But I can reverse</b> this construct and apply the more stringent condition to tithe. The Gemara answers: <b>It is reasonable</b> to say that <b><i>teruma</i> is</b> subject to the <b>more stringent</b> condition, <b>as it is</b> already subject to many stringent elements represented by the acronym <b><i>mem</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>zayin</i>,</b> which is a mnemonic for the following: One who is prohibited from eating <i>teruma</i> but ate it intentionally is liable to the punishment of death [<i>mita</i>] at the hand of Heaven; a non-priest who unwittingly ate <i>teruma</i> is obligated to pay its value to the priest plus one-fifth [<i>ḥomesh</i>] of the sum; <i>teruma</i> does not have the possibility of redemption [<i>pidyon</i>]; and it is prohibited to non-priests [<i>zarim</i>]. These stringencies do not apply to second tithe.
The Gemara counters: <b>On the contrary,</b> second <b>tithe</b> should be governed by the <b>more stringent</b> condition, <b>as it has</b> the stringencies represented by the acronym <b><i>heh</i>, <i>dalet</i>, <i>samekh</i>, <i>tet</i>, <i>beit</i>,</b> which is a mnemonic for the following: Second tithe must be brought [<i>hava’a</i>] to Jerusalem; it requires that a declaration [<i>viddui</i>] be made on the last day of Passover in the fourth and seventh year of the Sabbatical cycle, stating that one’s agricultural obligations with regard to tithes have been properly fulfilled; it is prohibited [<i>asur</i>] to be eaten by one in acute mourning; it may not be burned in a state of impurity [<i>tuma</i>]; and it must be removed [<i>biur</i>] from one’s house before Passover in the fourth and seventh years of the Sabbatical cycle, if one failed to do so beforehand.
The Gemara responds: <b>Even so,</b> the punishment of <b>death is a greater</b> stringency, and therefore it is appropriate that <i>teruma</i> should be subject to the additional stringency of waiting until sunset.
<b>Rava said:</b> Even <b>without</b> the rationale that the punishment of <b>death is a greater</b> stringency, <b>you still could not say</b> that the first verse that speaks only of immersion is referring to <i>teruma</i>. As <b>the verse states</b> in the continuation: “The <b>soul</b> that touches it” (Leviticus 22:6). Now, <b>what matter is the same for every soul? You must say it is tithe,</b> as <i>teruma</i> may be eaten only by priests.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the mishna: <b>But still,</b> say that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> sunset alone is enough for the eating of <i>teruma</i> <b>applies only</b> to one <b>who does not require</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering but merely has to wait until sunset when he is completely purified. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>one who does require</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering, such as a confirmed leper, perhaps he may not eat <i>teruma</i> <b>until he brings</b> his <b>atonement</b> offering.
<b>Abaye said: Two verses are written with regard to a woman after childbirth: It is written:</b> “She shall touch no hallowed thing, nor come into the Sanctuary, <b>until the days of her purification are completed”</b> (Leviticus 12:4), which suggests that <b>once her days are completed</b> and the sun has set on the last day, <b>she is</b> completely <b>pure</b> and requires nothing more. <b>And</b> elsewhere <b>it is written: “And the priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 12:8), which indicates that following childbirth a woman is not completely pure until she has brought her offerings. <b>How so? Here,</b> in the first verse, it is referring <b>to <i>teruma</i>; there,</b> in the second verse, it is referring <b>to sacrificial food.</b> A woman following childbirth falls into the category of one who lacks atonement, but nevertheless the verse teaches that if she has immersed, she may eat <i>teruma</i> after sunset. The same is true of a confirmed leper and all others who lack atonement.
The Gemara asks: <b>But I can reverse</b> this construct and apply the more stringent condition to <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>It is reasonable</b> to say that <b>sacrificial food is</b> subject to the <b>more stringent</b> condition, as it is already subject to many stringent elements represented by the acronym, <b><i>peh</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>ayin</i>, <i>kaf</i>, <i>samekh</i>,</b> which is a mnemonic for the following stringencies that apply to sacrificial food and not to <i>teruma</i>: An offering is disqualified by improper intention during one of the rites involved in its sacrifice with regard to the time it will be eaten [<i>piggul</i>]; meat of an offering that remained beyond its allotted time [<i>notar</i>] may not be eaten and must be burned; it is an offering [<i>korban</i>] to God; one who unwittingly derives benefit from sacrificial food is required to bring a guilt-offering for misuse of consecrated items [<i>me’ila</i>]; the punishment of one who eats sacrificial food while ritually impure is excision [<i>karet</i>]; sacrificial food is prohibited [<i>asur</i>] to an acute mourner.
The Gemara challenges this argument: <b>On the contrary, <i>teruma</i></b> should be subject to the <b>more stringent</b> condition, <b>as,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>, there are many stringent elements represented by the acronym <b><i>mem</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>zayin</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> stringencies that apply to sacrificial food <b>are</b> more <b>numerous</b> than those that apply to <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rava said:</b> Even <b>without</b> the rationale that <b>those</b> stringencies that apply to sacrificial food <b>are</b> more <b>numerous, you still could not say</b> that the verse that renders a woman pure at sunset refers to sacrificial food, as <b>the verse states: “And the priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be pure,”</b> which indicates <b>by inference that she</b> remains <b>ritually impure</b> to some degree until she has sacrificed her offerings. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that she may eat <b>sacrificial food</b> immediately after sunset, you should <b>apply here</b> what is stated in a different verse: <b>“And the flesh that touches anything impure shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 7:19), which indicates that one who is impure with any type of ritual impurity is prohibited from eating sacrificial food. <b>Rather, learn from this</b> that the verse is referring to <b><i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, strongly objects to this</b> argument: <b>And how can you say</b> that a <i>halakha</i> governing <b><i>teruma</i> is written here,</b> in the verse: “Until the days of her purification are completed” (Leviticus 12:4)? <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The section dealing with a woman following childbirth opens with the verse: <b>“Speak to the children of Israel,</b> saying: If a woman delivers and bears a male, then she shall be unclean seven days; as in the days of the impurity of her menstrual affliction shall she be unclean” (Leviticus 12:2). From this verse <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>the children of Israel</b> are included in this <i>halakha</i>; <b>from where</b> do I derive that <b>a convert and an emancipated maidservant</b> are also included? Therefore, <b>the verse states: “A woman,”</b> which includes other women. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the verse is speaking <b>of <i>teruma</i>, are a convert and a maidservant eligible to eat <i>teruma</i>?</b> It is prohibited for them to marry priests, so there can be no possibility of their eating <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rava said: And</b> is the verse <b>not</b> referring to <i>teruma</i> as well?

Daf 75a

<b>But isn’t it written</b> in that same section dealing with a woman after childbirth: <b>“She shall touch no hallowed thing,</b> nor come into the Sanctuary, until the days of her purification are completed” (Leviticus 12:4), which comes <b>to include <i>teruma</i>? Rather, the Torah considers several</b> distinct <b>matters</b> separately, and not all the verses refer to <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need <b>three verses with regard to <i>teruma</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> all <b>necessary, as, had</b> <i>teruma</i> been derived solely from the verse: “He shall not eat of the holy things <b>until he be pure”</b> (Leviticus 22:4), <b>I would not have known by what</b> means ritual purity is achieved, whether by immersion alone or in some other way. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “And when the sun has set he shall be pure,</b> and afterward he may eat from the holy things” (Leviticus 22:7), to teach that he must also wait for sunset.
<b>And had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“And when the sun has set,”</b> I might have said that <b>this applies</b> only <b>to</b> one <b>who does not require</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering, <b>but</b> as for one <b>who requires</b> an <b>atonement</b> offering, one might <b>say</b> that he may not eat <i>teruma</i> <b>until he brings</b> his <b>atonement</b> offering. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes:</b> “She shall touch no hallowed thing, nor come into the Sanctuary, <b>until the days of her purification are completed”</b> (Leviticus 12:4), which indicates that she may eat <i>teruma</i> as soon as her days of purification are completed, and she need not wait until after she has brought her atonement offering.
<b>And had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“Until</b> the days of her purification <b>are completed,” I would say</b> that upon the completion of the purification period she is immediately purified <b>even without immersion.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Until he be pure.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to that <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael and says</b> that <b>the verse</b> “Any man from the seed of Aaron who is a leper or a <i>zav</i> shall not eat of the holy things until he be pure” (Leviticus 22:4) <b>is speaking of a <i>zav</i> who</b> already experienced <b>three sightings</b> of an emission, <b>and of a confirmed leper,</b> both of whom must bring an offering as part of their purification process; <b>and,</b> this being the case, <b>that</b> phrase <b>“until he be pure”</b> must mean <b>until he brings</b> his <b>atonement</b> offering; then <b>why do I</b> need <b>two verses with regard to sacrificial food,</b> this verse and the verse with regard to a woman after childbirth: “And the priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be pure” (Leviticus 12:8), to teach us that sacrificial food may not be eaten until after the atonement offering has been brought?
The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> both <b>necessary, as had the Merciful One written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a woman after childbirth,</b> one might have said that it applies only to her <b>because her</b> period of ritual <b>impurity is</b> so <b>long,</b> as she may not return to eating <i>teruma</i> or sacrificial food for either forty days, in the case of a male child, or eighty days, in the case of a female. <b>But with regard to a <i>zav</i>, say</b> that this is <b>not</b> the case. <b>And had the Merciful One written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a <i>zav</i>,</b> one might have said that it applies only to him, <b>as no exemption is</b> ever <b>made from its general prohibition</b> and he is always impure. <b>But</b> as for <b>a woman after childbirth,</b> who is permitted to her husband for thirty-three or sixty-six days of that period, <b>say</b> that this is <b>not</b> the case. Both verses <b>are</b> therefore <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara asks: As for the verse stated with regard to a vessel that contracted ritual impurity through contact with a creeping animal: <b>“It must be put into water, and it shall be impure until the evening;</b> then shall it be pure” (Leviticus 11:32), <b>why do I</b> need it? <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It is necessary in order to teach about <b>touching.</b> An impure vessel, even after it has been immersed, still imparts ritual impurity to the <i>teruma</i> that it touches until nightfall. The same applies to an impure individual who has already undergone immersion; not only is it prohibited for him to eat <i>teruma</i>, but also he renders it impure if he touches it.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Had the verse stated only: “It must be put into water, <b>and it shall be impure</b> until the evening,” one <b>might</b> have thought that it remains ritually impure until the evening <b>in all</b> regards. <b>Therefore, the verse states: “Then shall it be pure,”</b> indicating that it is pure following immersion, even before sunset. And <b>had</b> it stated only: <b>“Then shall it be pure,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that it is pure following immersion <b>in all</b> regards. <b>Therefore, the verse states: “And it shall be impure</b> until the evening.” <b>How so;</b> how can the apparent contradiction between the two parts of the verse be resolved? <b>Here,</b> the verse is referring <b>to</b> second <b>tithe,</b> for which immersion alone suffices; and <b>there</b> it is referring <b>to <i>teruma</i>,</b> for which sunset is required.
The Gemara asks: <b>But I can reverse</b> this construct and say that the greater stringency should be applied to second tithe. The Gemara answers: <b>It is reasonable</b> to say that <i>teruma</i> is subject to the greater stringency; <b>just as the eating of <i>teruma</i> is</b> subject to <b>greater stringency than the eating of</b> second <b>tithe, so too, the touching of <i>teruma</i></b> should be subject to <b>greater stringency than the touching of</b> second <b>tithe.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that the prohibition with regard to the <b>touching of <i>teruma</i> is derived from here: “She shall touch no hallowed thing,</b> nor come into the Sanctuary, until the days of her purification are completed” (Leviticus 12:4); this is <b>a warning with respect to one who eats</b> <i>teruma</i> after having immersed but before sunset. <b>Or,</b> perhaps, <b>it is nothing other than</b> a warning <b>with respect to one who touches</b> <i>teruma</i> before sunset, as is implied by the plain reading of the verse?
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “She shall touch no hallowed thing, nor come into the Sanctuary,</b> until the days of her purification are completed” (Leviticus 12:4), thereby <b>juxtaposing consecrated</b> food <b>to the Sanctuary. Just as</b> the prohibition against entering <b>the Sanctuary is a matter that involves the taking of life,</b> as one who enters the Sanctuary while impure is liable to receive <i>karet</i>, <b>so too,</b> the prohibition against touching <b>consecrated</b> food must be <b>a matter that involves the taking of life,</b> e.g., eating <i>teruma</i> in a state of ritual impurity; <b>but</b> the prohibition against <b>touching</b> <i>teruma</i> in a state of impurity <b>does not involve the taking of life,</b> as there is no punishment of <i>karet</i> for mere touching.
<b>And</b> as for the fact <b>that</b> the verse <b>expressed</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in terms of touching, this is what</b> it <b>is saying:</b> The <i>halakha</i> governing <b>touching is like</b> that of <b>eating,</b> as they are both prohibited to an impure person, even after immersion, until sunset. But the verse is actually speaking of the prohibition against eating <i>teruma</i> in a state of impurity.
§ It is taught in the mishna that the wife of a priest with <b>crushed testicles</b> or a severed penis may eat <i>teruma</i> on his account, provided that they have not engaged in sexual relations since his injury. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught</b> with regard to a woman <b>awaiting intercourse that would disqualify</b> her from marrying into the priesthood <b>by Torah</b> law, as in this case, where the woman would become disqualified from marrying into the priesthood if she had relations with her injured husband, that such a woman <b>may eat</b> <i>teruma</i>? <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> <b>is subject to dispute, and it is</b> taught in the mishna in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon,</b> who similarly stated that a widow betrothed to a High Priest may eat <i>teruma</i> on his account, provided that he has not engaged in sexual relations with her.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The mishna can be understood <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> that <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that a widow betrothed to a High Priest may not eat <i>teruma</i> on his account, as <b>it is different here, as she</b> had <b>already eaten</b> <i>teruma</i> on her husband’s account before his injury. Since she has done nothing to disqualify herself, she retains her presumptive status as one for whom it is permitted to eat <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> counter this argument? He maintains that <b>we do not say that</b> since <b>she</b> had already <b>eaten</b> <i>teruma</i> on her husband’s account she continues to do so, <b>as, if you do not say</b> that <b>this</b> argument must be rejected, then it <b>should</b> be permitted for <b>an Israelite woman who married a priest and her husband died</b> without children to continue <b>eating</b> <i>teruma</i> on his account, <b>as she</b> had <b>already eaten</b> <i>teruma</i> because of him during his lifetime. However, such a conclusion is clearly incorrect. This <i>halakha</i> indicates that the fact that she had already eaten <i>teruma</i> is irrelevant.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> holds that the two cases are not comparable, as <b>there,</b> where the husband died, <b>his acquisition</b> of his wife <b>has lapsed,</b> i.e., they are no longer married, and therefore she cannot continue to eat <i>teruma</i> on his account, whereas <b>here,</b> where his genitals were injured, <b>his acquisition has not lapsed.</b> While sexual relations between them are forbidden, their marriage remains intact.
§ It is taught in the mishna: <b>Who is</b> deemed <b>a man with crushed</b> testicles? <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Who is</b> deemed <b>a man with crushed testicles?</b> It is <b>anyone whose testicles have been wounded, even</b> if only <b>one of them.</b> Furthermore, a man is considered to have crushed testicles not only if they have been wounded, but <b>even</b> if they have been <b>punctured, or</b> have <b>decayed</b> as the result of an injury, <b>or are</b> partly <b>deficient</b> for some other reason. <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, said: I heard from the Sages in the vineyard in Yavne</b> that <b>anyone who has only one testicle is nothing other</b> than <b>a eunuch by natural causes, and he is fit.</b>
The Gemara is puzzled by the wording of this last teaching: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that he is <b>a eunuch by natural causes,</b> i.e., from birth? That designation refers to one who was born without testicles, whereas the reference here is to one who lost a testicle as the result of an injury. <b>Rather,</b> say that <b>he resembles a eunuch by natural causes, and he is fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: As for one whose testicles <b>were punctured, is he incapable of having children,</b> so that he should have the status of one whose testicles were crushed? <b>Wasn’t</b> there an incident where <b>a certain man was climbing up a palm tree,</b>

Daf 75b

<b>and a thorn [<i>silva</i>]</b> from the tree <b>punctured him in the testicles, and</b> semen <b>resembling a thread of pus issued from him,</b> as the thorn had perforated his testicle, <b>and</b> yet <b>he</b> later <b>had children.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Didn’t Shmuel send</b> this case <b>before Rav, who said to him: Go</b> out and <b>inquire about his children where they come from,</b> as he doubted that this man could father children, and therefore his wife must have committed adultery.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: A man wounded with crushed</b> testicles <b>at the hand of Heaven,</b> e.g., from birth or as the result of an illness, <b>is fit</b> to marry a woman who was born Jewish. <b>Rava said: This is</b> the reason <b>that we read</b> in the Torah: <b>“A man wounded</b> with crushed testicles,” <b>and we do not read: The man wounded</b> with crushed testicles. In the Hebrew text, the latter phrase: The man wounded, can be understood to include one whose testicles have always been crushed, whereas “a man wounded” indicates that he was wounded, i.e., his disability is the result of injury.
A similar idea <b>was taught in a <i>baraita</i>. It is stated: “A man wounded [<i>petzua</i>]</b> with crushed testicles [<i>dakka</i>] or a severed [<i>kerut</i>] penis <b>shall not enter</b> into the congregation of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:2), <b>and it is stated</b> in the very next verse: <b>“A <i>mamzer</i> shall not enter</b> into the congregation of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:3). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to a <i>mamzer</i>, his blemish was created <b>at the hands of man,</b> i.e., by his parents who sinned, <b>so too, here,</b> with regard to one with crushed testicles, the verse must be speaking about one whose mutilation was <b>at the hands of man.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> The verse dealing with injured genitals speaks of three types of injury: Wounded [<i>petzua</i>], crushed [<i>dakka</i>], and severed [<i>kerut</i>]. <b>Wounded</b> applies <b>to all of them; crushed</b> applies <b>to all of them;</b> and <b>severed</b> applies <b>to all of them,</b> as will immediately be explained. <b>Wounded</b> applies <b>to all of them, whether the member was wounded, or the testicles were wounded, or the spermatic cords were wounded.</b> Similarly, <b>crushed</b> applies <b>to all of them, whether the member was crushed, or the testicles were crushed, or the spermatic cords were crushed.</b> And <b>severed</b> also applies <b>to all of them, whether the member was severed, or the testicles were severed, or the spermatic cords were severed.</b>
§ <b>One of the Sages said to Rava: From where</b> is it derived <b>that this</b> phrase <b>“<i>petzua dakka</i>,”</b> literally meaning wounded by crushing, is referring to a man who suffered an injury <b>in that place,</b> i.e., his genitals? <b>Say</b> that perhaps it is referring to one who was injured <b>on his head.</b> Rava <b>said to him: From</b> the fact that the verse <b>does not mention</b> the number of <b>generations</b> of his descendants that may not enter into the congregation, as do the verses with regard to a <i>mamzer</i> or an Ammonite or Moabite, <b>learn from this</b> that it is referring to a man who suffered an injury <b>in that place.</b> The blemish is evidently one that prevents him from having children, and therefore he has no generations of descendants.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Torah <b>does not mention</b> the number of <b>generations</b> of his descendants that may not enter into the congregation is due to a halakhic reason rather than a biological one, i.e. <b>that</b> only <b>he is prohibited</b> from entering into the congregation, whereas <b>his son and his son’s son are fit</b> to do so?
The Gemara explains that the identity of a <i>petzua dakka</i> is derived in a different way: The case of a <i>petzua dakka</i> is <b>similar to</b> that of <b>one whose penis has been severed,</b> mentioned immediately afterward: <b>Just as one whose penis has been severed</b> suffered an injury <b>in that place, so too, this</b> man was injured <b>in that place.</b>
