According to Rabbi Yehuda, a <i>tumtum</i> is regarded as definitely sexually impotent, and therefore his <i>ḥalitza</i> is of no consequence. Therefore, if the <i>tumtum</i> went ahead and performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, he has not disqualified the other brothers from performing levirate marriage. According to Rabbi Yosei, however, he is only doubtfully sexually impotent, and therefore he has disqualified the other brothers from performing levirate marriage. <b>And</b> there is also a difference between them as to whether the <i>tumtum</i> must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> where there are no</b> other <b>brothers</b> besides him. According to Rabbi Yehuda he need not do so, whereas according to Rabbi Yosei he must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> owing to his uncertain status.
§ <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba, brother of Rabbi Yehuda bar Zavdi, said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>a hermaphrodite, one is liable to</b> receive the punishment of <b>stoning on his account</b> for intercourse <b>at two places,</b> whether one penetrated him anally, in the manner of homosexual intercourse, or through his female organ. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against this from the following teaching. <b>Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> If one had intercourse with <b>a hermaphrodite,</b> he <b>is liable to</b> be punished with <b>stoning on his account as if</b> he had relations <b>with a male. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is if he had relations with him <b>through his male</b> organ, i.e., in the manner of homosexual intercourse, <b>but</b> if he engaged in intercourse with him <b>through his female</b> organ, he is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara answers that Rav <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Simai says:</b> With regard to <b>a hermaphrodite, one is liable to</b> be punished with <b>stoning on his account</b> for intercourse <b>at two places.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Simai? Rava said:</b> The Sage <b>bar Hamedurei explained</b> the matter <b>to me,</b> based on an allusion to this <i>halakha</i> found in the Bible. The verse states: <b>“And you shall not lie with a male as with a woman [<i>mishkevei isha</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 18:22). The phrase <i>mishkevei isha</i>, referring to lying with a woman, appears in the plural. Now, <b>what male has two</b> manners of <b>lying? You must say</b> that <b>this</b> is referring to <b>a hermaphrodite,</b> and the plural form <i>mishkevei</i>, meaning: Lyings, indicates that there is liability for both manners of intercourse with him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Simai counter this argument? The Gemara explains: <b>Although he has two</b> manners of <b>lying, it is</b> nevertheless <b>written: “With a male,”</b> indicating that one is liable to be stoned on a hermaphrodite’s account only if he had relations with him in the manner of a male.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who explain this entire verse as referring to a hermaphrodite, <b>from where do they</b> derive that a man is prohibited from engaging in relations with <b>an ordinary male?</b> The Gemara answers: They derive it <b>from</b> the words <b>“a woman.”</b> The Gemara asks further: And <b>from where do</b> the Rabbis derive that one is liable to be punished for engaging in intercourse with <b>a woman</b> who is forbidden to him even if he engaged in relations <b>in an unnatural manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse? The Gemara responds: They derive it <b>from</b> the inclusive “and” in <b>“and…with a woman.”</b>
§ <b>Rav Shezvi said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Not in all</b> regards did <b>Rabbi Eliezer say</b> that <b>a hermaphrodite is a proper male. As, if you say so,</b> that a hermaphrodite is a proper male in every aspect, then <b>with regard to consecrated</b> animals an animal that is a hermaphrodite <b>should become sacred</b> if one consecrated it.
<b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that it does not become sacred? As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a bird <b>used for sexual relations</b> with a human being, <b>and one set aside</b> for idolatrous purposes, <b>and one</b> that itself was <b>worshipped</b> as an idol, <b>and one</b> given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute (see Deuteronomy 23:19), <b>and one</b> that was <b>the price of a dog</b> received in exchange for the sale of a dog (see Deuteronomy 23:19), <b>and</b> similarly, a bird that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite,</b> if one killed any of these birds by pinching their necks in the manner of an offering rather than by ritual slaughter, the birds <b>render</b> him and the <b>garments</b> he is wearing <b>ritually impure,</b> when the birds are eaten and come into contact <b>with</b> his <b>throat.</b> The reason is that pinching is valid only for sacrificial birds; any other bird that is killed by pinching is deemed an unslaughtered carcass. Since none of these birds are fit to be sacrificed, pinching their necks renders them unslaughtered carcasses, and the unslaughtered carcass of a clean bird imparts ritual impurity when it is eaten and reaches the individual’s throat.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If one pinched the neck of a bird that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite, it does not render</b> him and the <b>garments</b> he is wearing <b>ritually impure</b> when it is eaten and comes into contact <b>with</b> his <b>throat,</b> as the sanctity of an offering does in fact apply to it. <b>As Rabbi Eliezer would say: Wherever it is</b> explicitly <b>stated</b> in the Torah <b>“male” and “female,” you</b> are to <b>remove a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from among them,</b> as their gender status is in doubt. This is true of animal offerings, with regard to which the Torah uses the terms male and female. In the case of <b>a bird-</b>offering, however, <b>since male and female are not stated with regard to it,</b> but instead the Torah simply mentions turtledoves and young pigeons, <b>you</b> are <b>not</b> to <b>remove a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from among them,</b> as they are fit for the altar. It is evident then that Rabbi Eliezer maintains that a hermaphrodite is not considered a proper male with respect to offerings.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We too learned</b> this explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that states: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b>

Daf 84a

<b>Forbidden crossbred livestock, an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months</b> [<b><i>tereifa</i></b>], an animal <b>delivered through the abdominal wall,</b> and an animal that is <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite do not become sacred and do not render</b> another animal <b>sacred</b> in their place.
<b>And Shmuel said: They do not become sacred by way of substitution,</b> i.e., if one had an animal that had been designated as an offering, and he wished to substitute one of these animals for it, the substituted animal does not become sacred. <b>And they</b> themselves <b>do not render</b> another animal <b>sacred when it is made a substitute</b> for them. If one designated one of these animals as an offering and he wished to substitute another animal for it, it does not become sacred. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from this</b> that Rabbi Eliezer does not consider a hermaphrodite to be a proper male.
It is taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If one had intercourse with <b>a hermaphrodite,</b> one <b>is liable to</b> be punished with <b>stoning on his account as if</b> one had relations with <b>a male. It is taught</b> on this matter in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: When I went to learn Torah from Rabbi Elazar ben Shamua, his students joined</b> together <b>against me like the roosters of Beit Bukya,</b> highly aggressive animals that do not allow other creatures to remain among them, <b>and they did not let me learn</b> there. Therefore, I managed to learn <b>only one thing in our mishna,</b> which is that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If one had intercourse with <b>a hermaphrodite,</b> one <b>is liable to</b> be punished with <b>stoning on his account as if</b> one had relations with <b>a male.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>There are</b> women <b>who are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their <i>yevamin</i>,</b> while others <b>are permitted to their <i>yevamin</i> and forbidden to their husbands.</b> Certain women <b>are permitted</b> both <b>to these and to those, and</b> others <b>are forbidden to</b> both <b>these and to those.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>And these are</b> cases of women who are <b>permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their <i>yevamin</i>:</b> In the case of <b>a common priest who married a widow, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is</b> the <b>High Priest,</b> the widow, who was permitted to her husband, is forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>, as it is prohibited for the High Priest to marry a widow. The same is true in the case of <b>a priest disqualified due to flawed lineage</b> [<b><i>ḥalal</i></b>], e.g., the son of a priest and a divorcée, <b>who married</b> a woman <b>fit</b> to marry a priest, <b>and he has a brother</b> who <b>is</b> a priest <b>fit</b> for service. That woman was permitted to marry the <i>ḥalal</i> but is forbidden to his brother. Having engaged in intercourse with the <i>ḥalal</i>, she is rendered a <i>ḥalala</i>, a woman disqualified from marrying a priest.
Another example is the case of <b>an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage <b>who married an Israelite woman</b> of similar lineage, <b>and he has a brother</b> who is <b>a son born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzer</i>];</b> or <b>a <i>mamzer</i> who married a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>], and he has a brother</b> who <b>is an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage. A <i>mamzer</i> is permitted to marry a <i>mamzeret</i>, but neither is permitted to a Jew of unflawed lineage. In each of these cases, these women <b>are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their <i>yevamin</i>.</b>
<b>And these</b> are cases of women who <b>are permitted to their <i>yevamin</i> and forbidden to their husbands:</b> For example, there is the case of <b>a High Priest who betrothed a widow, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is a common priest,</b> whom she is permitted to marry. This is true only if the High Priest merely betrothed her. However, if he consummated the marriage, he rendered her a <i>ḥalala</i> forbidden to all priests, including her <i>yavam</i>. The additional cases are a priest <b>fit</b> for service <b>who married a <i>ḥalala</i> and he has a brother</b> who <b>is a <i>ḥalal</i>; an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage <b>who married a <i>mamzeret</i>, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>;</b> and <b>a <i>mamzer</i> who married an Israelite woman</b> of unflawed lineage, <b>and he has a brother</b> who <b>is,</b> similarly, <b>an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage. All of these women <b>are permitted to their <i>yevamin</i> and forbidden to their husbands.</b>
<b>And these</b> are cases where women <b>are forbidden</b> both <b>to these and to those: A High Priest who married a widow, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is a High Priest or a common priest;</b> a priest <b>fit</b> for service <b>who married a <i>ḥalala</i>, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is</b> a priest <b>fit</b> for service; <b>an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage <b>who married a <i>mamzeret</i>, and he has a brother</b> who <b>is</b> similarly an ordinary <b>Israelite,</b> or <b>a <i>mamzer</i> who married an Israelite woman</b> of unflawed lineage, <b>and he has a brother</b> who <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> All of these women <b>are forbidden</b> both <b>to these and to those. And all other women are permitted to their husbands and to their <i>yevamin</i>.</b>
With regard to <b>secondary relatives,</b> who are forbidden <b>by rabbinic law,</b> if the woman is <b>a secondary relative to the husband but not a secondary relative to the <i>yavam</i>,</b> she <b>is forbidden to the husband and permitted to the <i>yavam</i>.</b> Conversely, if she is <b>a secondary relative to the <i>yavam</i> but not a secondary relative to the husband,</b> she <b>is forbidden to the <i>yavam</i> and permitted to the husband.</b> If she is <b>a secondary relative</b> both <b>to this</b> man <b>and to that</b> man, she <b>is forbidden to this</b> one <b>and to that</b> one.
Furthermore, if a man marries a woman forbidden to him as a secondary relative, <b>she does not have</b> the right to receive payment for her <b>marriage contract</b> if divorced or widowed, <b>nor</b> is she entitled to payment from her husband for the <b>produce</b> of her property that he used, <b>nor</b> is she entitled to provisions for her <b>sustenance</b> from his estate, <b>nor</b> does she get back her <b>worn clothes</b> or other objects she brought with her to her marriage. <b>And</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed, and</b> the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> her.
In contrast, <b>a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest, a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>]</b> married <b>to a common priest, a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman</b> married <b>to an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage, and <b>an Israelite woman</b> of unflawed lineage married <b>to a Gibeonite or to a <i>mamzer</i></b> all <b>have</b> the right to receive payment for their <b>marriage contract,</b> although it was prohibited for them to marry.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> As an example of a woman who is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>, the mishna cites the case of a widow married to a common priest whose brother was a High Priest. The Gemara asks: <b>Why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> a case where the priest <b>married</b> the widow? <b>Let him teach</b> that he <b>betrothed</b> her, as even if she is widowed after betrothal she requires levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>And if you would say:</b> The <b>reason</b> that the <i>tanna</i> cited the case where they <b>were married</b> is that in this case <b>there is a positive mitzva</b> that the High Priest marry a virgin <b>and</b> also <b>a prohibition</b> to marry a widow, and therefore she is forbidden to him. <b>However,</b> if <b>he betrothed</b> her, the <b>positive mitzva</b> of levirate marriage <b>comes and overrides</b> the <b>prohibition</b> against marrying a widow. To counter this argument, the <i>tanna</i> states: <b>But</b> that cannot be the case, as <b>the entire chapter</b> discusses cases involving the <b>positive mitzva</b> of levirate marriage <b>and prohibitions,</b> and in all those cases, the <b>positive mitzva does not come and override the prohibition,</b> even in the absence of an additional positive mitzva.
The Gemara answers: The mishna could have cited a case where the priest betrothed the widow. Instead, the mishna cites a case where the priest married a widow, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna the case of <b>a High Priest who married a widow</b> who has a brother who is a common priest. That case is <b>specifically</b> if he <b>married</b> her, <b>because he</b> thereby <b>rendered her a <i>ḥalala</i>. However,</b> if he only <b>betrothed</b> her, <b>she is permitted</b> to his brother who is a common priest, as it is permitted for him to marry a widow. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>also taught</b> in the <b>first clause</b> the case where the priest <b>married</b> her.
The Gemara asks: <b>But rather than teaching</b> a case where she was married in the first clause <b>due to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>let him teach</b> a case where she was betrothed in the first clause <b>due to the middle clause,</b> which speaks of <b>a High Priest who betrothed a widow, and he has a brother</b> who is <b>a common priest.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> the reason the <i>tanna</i> taught the case where the priest married the widow is <b>due to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that is its <b>neighbor [<i>bat bukta</i>],</b> i.e., due to the fact <b>that</b> in the adjacent case <b>he wants to teach</b> the case of <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married</b> a woman <b>fit</b> to marry a priest. There, the <b>reason</b> that the woman is forbidden to his brother is specifically that the <i>ḥalal</i> <b>married</b> her, <b>as he rendered her a <i>ḥalala</i></b> by consummating the marriage. <b>However,</b> if the <i>ḥalal</i> merely <b>betrothed her, she is permitted to him. Due to that</b> reason, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the case where the priest <b>married</b> the widow.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> the case of a common priest who married <b>a widow? Let him teach</b> that the priest married <b>a virgin.</b> Since in any case she becomes a widow upon his death, what difference is there whether she was previously a widow?

Daf 84b

<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>this <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that it is her status at the time of <b>the first marriage</b> that determines her status when <b>she happens</b> before the <i>yavam</i> for levirate marriage, and not her status at the time of her husband’s death, and therefore if she had been a virgin when she married she would have been permitted to enter into levirate marriage with a High Priest, that cannot be so, as the mishna cites the case of <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married</b> a woman <b>fit</b> to marry a priest, in which case the woman is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>. <b>And</b> in that case, <b>we do not say</b> that <b>the first marriage</b> determines her status when <b>she happens</b> before him for levirate marriage, as the woman was fit to marry the brother when she married the <i>ḥalal</i> and was rendered a <i>ḥalala</i> only as a result of her marriage.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> fact, that the mishna cited a case where the priest married a widow, is <b>certainly due to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, i.e., <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause: A High Priest who married a widow, and he has a brother</b> who is the <b>High Priest or a common priest.</b> In the case where the <i>yavam</i> is a common priest, the widow is forbidden to him <b>specifically</b> if the High Priest married <b>a widow,</b> as by consummating the marriage he rendered her a <i>ḥalala</i>. <b>However,</b> had she been <b>a virgin</b> when the High Priest married her, he would not render her a <i>ḥalala</i>, and when the High Priest dies <b>she</b> would be <b>fit for</b> his brother. It is <b>due to that</b> reason that the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the case of <b>a widow</b> in the first clause as well.
§ <b>Rav Pappa objects to</b> the mishna: <b>If it is so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael he reported that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that in the case of <b>a second-generation Egyptian who married a first-generation Egyptian woman, her son is considered a</b> second-generation Egyptian, as the child’s status in this matter is determined according to the mother, then <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>also teach</b> the following case:
With regard to <b>a second-generation Egyptian who married two Egyptian women, one</b> of whom was <b>a first-generation</b> Egyptian convert <b>and one</b> of whom was from the <b>second</b> generation, <b>and he had sons</b> from both <b>the first and second</b> women, <b>if</b> these two sons <b>married in their</b> proper <b>way,</b> meaning that the third-generation Egyptian married an ordinary Jewish woman, and the second-generation convert married another second-generation Egyptian, then it is also true of these women that <b>they are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their <i>yevamin</i>.</b> The second-generation Egyptian is forbidden to his Jewish <i>yevama</i>, while the third-generation Egyptian is an ordinary Jew and therefore prohibited to marry his <i>yevama</i>, who is a second-generation Egyptian woman.
<b>And if they married</b> in the <b>reverse</b> manner, i.e., the third-generation convert married a second-generation Egyptian woman, and the second-generation man married an ordinary Jewish woman, <b>they are permitted to their <i>yevamin</i> and forbidden to their husbands.</b> Similarly, <b>they are permitted</b> both <b>to these and to those</b> if these sons married <b>converts,</b> for an Egyptian convert is permitted to marry a convert of a different nationality. And there is also a case in which <b>they are forbidden to these and to those,</b> namely if they married <b>sexually underdeveloped women [<i>ayloniot</i>].</b> If an Egyptian married an <i>aylonit</i>, she is forbidden to him as a Jewish woman, and she is forbidden to his brother, a third-generation Egyptian convert who is permitted to marry a Jewish woman, because levirate marriage is prohibited with an <i>aylonit</i>. The fact that the mishna omits these cases appears to indicate that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara answers: There is no proof from here with regard to the <i>halakha</i>, as the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna did not mention all possible examples. Rather, <b>he taught</b> certain cases <b>and omitted</b> others. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> else <b>did he omit that he omitted this?</b> The <i>tanna</i> would not have omitted only one example. The Gemara answers: <b>He omitted</b> the case of a <b>man with crushed testicles</b> or with other wounds to his genitals. If the husband is such a man, the wife is forbidden to her husband and permitted to her <i>yavam</i>. If the <i>yavam</i> is such a man, the opposite is true.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> this mishna is determined to have taught certain cases and omitted others <b>due to</b> the omission of the case <b>of a man with crushed testicles</b> or other wounds to his genitals, this <b>is not an omission, as</b> in this mishna the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> a principle that applies to all forbidden relationships for which one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition.</b> This category includes such a case, and therefore it was not omitted.
The Gemara answers: <b>Is that to say</b> that with regard to those relationships for which one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition, he does not teach</b> a principle <b>and again teach</b> them in detail? But this is not the case. <b>He teaches</b> the case of <b>a common priest who married a widow</b> and he had a brother who was a high priest, <b>and</b> the case of <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married</b> a woman <b>fit</b> to marry a priest and he had a brother who was a priest fit for service, both of whom are forbidden as they are liable for violating a prohibition. Therefore, since the <i>tanna</i> did not specifically teach the case of the man with crushed testicles, this constitutes an omission.
The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> clause of the mishna is not merely a specification of the previous general <i>halakha</i>, as <b>it was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention these cases individually in order <b>to teach us</b> another <i>halakha</i> <b>that Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>not prohibited</b> for daughters of priests who are <b>fit</b> to marry priests to <b>marry men</b> who are <b>disqualified</b> from the priesthood, although this marriage disqualifies them from subsequently marrying a priest.
The Gemara challenges that answer: <b>But</b> the mishna also <b>teaches</b> these cases: <b>A <i>ḥalal</i> who married</b> a woman <b>fit</b> to marry a priest; <b>and an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage <b>who married an Israelite woman</b> of unflawed lineage, <b>and he has a brother</b> who is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> These are specifications that do not teach additional <i>halakhot</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>This too is not</b> a case of the <i>tanna</i> <b>going back and teaching</b> additional examples of the same <i>halakha</i> without adding anything, <b>as he teaches us</b> something new through each of these two examples. The first example is referring to <b>a prohibition that is not equally applicable to all,</b> such as one concerning priests, and the second example is referring to <b>a prohibition that is equally applicable to all,</b> such as one involving a <i>mamzer</i>.
The Gemara further challenges the answer: <b>But</b> the mishna also <b>teaches</b> the case of <b>an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage <b>who married a <i>mamzeret</i> and who has a brother</b> who <b>is an Israelite</b> of similar lineage, <b>and</b> the example of <b>a <i>mamzer</i> who married a <i>mamzeret</i> and he has a brother</b> who <b>is an Israelite</b> of unflawed lineage. Consequently, the <i>tanna</i> does in fact teach the same <i>halakha</i> several times with regard to a prohibition that is equally applicable to all. <b>Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>he taught and omitted</b> certain cases and did not list all possible examples? The Gemara concludes: <b>Indeed, conclude from it</b> that this is the case, and therefore there is no proof from here that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan.
§ The Gemara returns to a statement cited incidentally above, in order to discuss <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>not prohibited</b> for daughters of priests who are <b>fit</b> to marry priests to <b>marry</b> men who are <b>disqualified</b> from the priesthood, although this marriage would disqualify them from subsequently marrying a priest, and they may do so even <i>ab initio</i>. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that</b> the following statement of the mishna <b>supports his</b> opinion: <b>A <i>ḥalal</i> who married</b> a woman who is <b>fit,</b> and he has a brother who is a priest fit for service, this woman is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to <b>a priestess,</b> i.e., a priest’s daughter, <b>who is appropriate to</b> marry <b>him? And what is</b> the meaning of: <b>Fit?</b> This means that <b>she is fit for the priesthood,</b> and yet the mishna says she is permitted to her husband, the <i>ḥalal</i>.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> it is possible that the mishna is speaking of <b>an Israelite woman. And what is</b> the meaning of: <b>Fit?</b> It means that <b>she is fit to</b> enter <b>the congregation</b> of the Jewish people, through marriage. According to this explanation, there is no proof from the mishna about daughters of priests.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> consider the phrase: A <i>ḥalal</i> who married a woman fit to marry a priest, and <b>he has a brother</b> who <b>is</b> also <b>fit.</b> Consistency demands that here <b>too</b> it means that the brother <b>is fit to</b> enter <b>the congregation.</b> Can it not therefore be deduced <b>by inference that he,</b> the deceased <i>ḥalal</i>, was <b>unfit to</b> enter <b>the congregation?</b> But such an inference would be an error, as a <i>ḥalal</i> is disqualified only from the priesthood. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a <b>priest, and from the fact that he</b> must <b>be a priest, she</b> too must be <b>a priestess?</b> The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case, of the <i>ḥalal</i>, is <b>as it is,</b> i.e., he is fit for the priesthood. <b>And that</b> case, of the woman, is <b>as it is,</b> i.e., she is fit to enter the congregation.
<b>Ravin bar Naḥman raised an objection</b> against Rav’s ruling from the following <i>baraita</i>: The verse states about priests: <b>“They may not take</b> a woman who is a harlot [<i>zona</i>], or profaned [<i>ḥalala</i>]” (Leviticus 21:7). The same verse says: <b>“They</b> also <b>may not take</b> a woman divorced from her husband.” This repetition of “they may not take” <b>teaches</b> us <b>that the woman is</b> also <b>prohibited by means of</b> the prohibition addressed to <b>the man.</b> Therefore, we can conclude that there is a prohibition for a daughter of a priest to marry a <i>ḥalal</i>.
<b>Rava said:</b> Ravin bar Naḥman’s objection is not valid. All that the <i>baraita</i> teaches is that <b>anywhere that a prohibition</b> of sexual intercourse applies to <b>him,</b> i.e., to a man, the same <b>prohibition</b> applies to <b>her,</b> his female partner. <b>And anywhere that a prohibition does not</b> apply to <b>him, the prohibition does not</b> apply to <b>her</b> either. It does not, however, indicate that since it is prohibited for a priest to marry a <i>ḥalala</i> it is also prohibited for the daughter of a priest to marry a <i>ḥalal</i>.
The Gemara asks with regard to the <i>baraita</i> itself: <b>And is this</b> matter <b>derived from here? It is derived from</b> a different statement that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Rav said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and the school of Rabbi Yishmael similarly taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“When a man or woman</b> shall <b>commit any sin</b> that <b>people</b> commit” (Numbers 5:6). <b>The verse</b> here <b>equates a woman to a man with regard to all punishments of the Torah.</b> Consequently, the <i>halakhot</i> of forbidden marriages apply equally to women and to men. Why then do we need to learn the same thing from the repetition of “they may not take”?
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it was derived only <b>from that</b> verse, <b>I would say</b> that this principle is true of <b>a prohibition that is equally</b> applicable <b>to all, but</b> with regard to <b>a prohibition that is not equally</b> applicable <b>to all,</b> such as the prohibitions pertaining to priests, this is <b>not</b> the case. Since these prohibitions only apply to priests, we might have thought that they do not extend to women. The verse therefore teaches that the prohibition applies to women in the same manner as men.

Daf 85a

The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> there is the prohibition for priests to contract <b>ritual impurity</b> from a corpse, <b>which is a prohibition that is not equally</b> applicable <b>to all,</b> as only priests are bound by this prohibition, <b>and the reason</b> that this command applies only to male priests is <b>that the Merciful One writes:</b> “Speak to the priests <b>the sons of Aaron,</b> and say to them: None shall defile himself” (Leviticus 21:1), from which it is inferred: <b>The sons of Aaron and not the daughters of Aaron. Therefore,</b> were it <b>not</b> for <b>this</b> specific derivation, <b>I would say</b> that <b>women</b> from priestly families <b>are</b> also <b>obligated</b> to avoid becoming ritually impure. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not due to</b> the principle that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said, that women are equated to men with regard to all punishments in the Torah, including those that are not equally applicable to all?
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> that initial assumption, that the daughters of priests might be obligated to avoid ritual impurity, is not due to the <i>halakha</i> that Rav Yehuda said that Rav said, but rather it is something that <b>we learn</b> through tradition <b>from</b> the words <b>“they may not take.”</b> This phrase teaches that women are included in the marital prohibitions of the priesthood, and we might therefore have thought that they are included in all <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to priests.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this answer: With regard to that verse about <b>taking,</b> it <b>was necessary for him</b> to mention this explicitly, for <b>it might enter your mind to say: We should learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b>impurity</b> and conclude that just as only male descendants of Aaron are prohibited from contracting <b>ritual impurity,</b> the restrictions of marriage also apply only to men. The verse therefore <b>teaches us,</b> with the words “they may not take,” that this is not the case.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, arrived at</b> the town of <b>Hintzevu, to the place</b> of <b>Rav Idi bar Avin.</b> The townspeople <b>asked them:</b> Is it <b>prohibited</b> for daughters of priests who are <b>fit</b> to marry priests to <b>marry</b> men <b>disqualified</b> from the priesthood <b>or not?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to them: You learned it</b> in a mishna (<i>Kiddushin</i> 69a): People of <b>ten</b> types of <b>lineages ascended from Babylonia: Priests, Levites, and Israelites, <i>ḥalalim</i>, converts, and freed</b> slaves, <b>and <i>mamzerim</i>, Gibeonites, children of unknown paternity [<i>shetukim</i>], and foundlings.</b> With regard to <b>Priests, Levites,</b> and <b>Israelites,</b> they <b>are permitted to marry</b> into <b>one another’s</b> families; <b>Levites, Israelites, <i>ḥalalim</i>, converts,</b> and <b>freed</b> slaves <b>are permitted to marry</b> into <b>one another’s</b> families; <b>converts, freed</b> slaves, <b>and <i>mamzerim</i>, Gibeonites, <i>shetukim</i>, and foundlings are permitted to marry</b> into <b>one another’s</b> families; <b>whereas</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> that <b>priestesses,</b> i.e., daughters of priests, are permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>a <i>ḥalal</i>.</b> This must mean they are forbidden to them.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to him:</b> There is no proof from here, for <b>he teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>anywhere that these</b> men <b>may marry those</b> women, <b>and</b> there is also a parallel case where <b>these</b> women <b>may marry those</b> men. With regard to the case of <b>a priest,</b> however, <b>since if he wants to marry a <i>ḥalala</i> this is prohibited</b> to him, the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> this <i>halakha</i>. Consequently, there is no proof from this mishna that daughters of priests who are fit to marry priests are warned against marrying men disqualified from the priesthood. <b>They came before Rav Idi bar Avin</b> and told him about the question and their debate about the matter. <b>He said to them: Children, this</b> is what <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> Daughters of priests who are <b>fit</b> to marry priests <b>are not warned against marrying</b> men <b>disqualified</b> from the priesthood.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relatives,</b> whose status is established <b>by rabbinic law,</b> are sometimes forbidden to the husband and sometimes to the <i>yavam</i>. <b>The residents of</b> the town of <b>Biri inquired of Rav Sheshet:</b> Is a woman who is <b>a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative of the husband but not a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative of the <i>yavam</i></b> entitled to <b>a marriage contract from the <i>yavam</i> or not?</b> The Gemara clarifies the sides of the dilemma: Perhaps, <b>since the Master said</b> that in a levirate marriage, the payment of <b>her marriage contract is</b> due <b>from the property of her first husband,</b> and this woman, who was a secondary relative of her first husband, does not receive a marriage contract from him, <b>she</b> consequently <b>does not have</b> the right to one from the <i>yavam</i> either.
<b>Or perhaps, since</b> there is a principle in levirate marriage <b>that if she does not have</b> a marriage contract <b>from</b> the <b>first</b> husband, e.g., he died without leaving behind any property, <b>the Sages instituted</b> a marriage contract <b>for her from</b> the <b>second</b> one, we should say that <b>she has</b> a marriage contract from the <i>yavam</i>?
<b>Rav Sheshet said to them: You learned it</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Payment of <b>her marriage contract is</b> due <b>from the property of her first husband, and if she was a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative of the husband, she does not have</b> one <b>even from the <i>yavam</i>.</b> This <i>baraita</i> clearly answers the question.
The Gemara asks: Can it be concluded <b>by inference</b> from the <i>baraita</i> <b>that there is</b> a case of a woman in a levirate marriage <b>who</b> does <b>have</b> a marriage contract <b>from the <i>yavam</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and this is</b> what <b>it is teaching:</b> Payment of <b>her marriage contract is</b> due <b>from the property of her first husband, and if she does not have</b> anything <b>from the first husband</b> because he died without property, <b>they instituted</b> a marriage contract <b>for her from the second</b> one. <b>And if she was a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative of the husband, she does not have</b> one <b>even from the <i>yavam</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar inquired of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> Do women in cases like <b>a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest</b> and <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> married <b>to a common priest have</b> rights to payment for their <b>sustenance</b> from their husbands, <b>or do they not have</b> a right to <b>sustenance?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the case under discussion? <b>If we say that</b> she <b>is dwelling under his</b> roof, he <b>stands in</b> a position where he is obligated to <b>arise and divorce</b> her. In such a situation, does <b>she have</b> a right to <b>sustenance?</b> It is obvious that she does not. The Gemara clarifies: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to ask this question with regard to a case <b>where he went overseas</b> and therefore is not present to divorce her, <b>and</b> in the meantime <b>she borrowed</b> money for her sustenance <b>and ate. What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in that case?
Is it correct to say that <b>sustenance is a stipulation in the marriage contract,</b> and <b>since she has a marriage contract she</b> also <b>has</b> a right to <b>sustenance,</b> and therefore the husband must pay her debt? <b>Or perhaps</b> there is a difference between the cases: Concerning <b>a marriage contract, which</b> gives her motivation to <b>take</b> the money <b>and leave</b> him, <b>she has</b> rights to it, as the Sages wanted to motivate her to seek divorce and end the prohibited marriage. However, with regard to <b>sustenance,</b> we are worried that if he provides for her sustenance, <b>perhaps she might tarry with him,</b> as she would have no reason to rush the divorce, and consequently <b>she</b> does <b>not have</b> rights to it. <b>He said to him: She does not have</b> a right to sustenance.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>she does have</b> a right to sustenance? The Gemara answers: <b>When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught,</b> it is referring to sustenance she receives <b>after</b> his <b>death.</b> At that point, she is no longer in violation of a prohibition, while the obligation to sustain her remains intact.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the discussion, which is that <b>he said to him:</b> It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>she has</b> a right to sustenance. He replied: He <b>stands in</b> a position where he is obligated to <b>arise and divorce</b> her. He should not be required to provide for her sustenance. He again asked: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>she has</b> a right to sustenance? He responded: <b>When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught</b> it is referring to the period <b>after</b> his <b>death.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: A widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest,</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> married <b>to a common priest has</b> the right to receive payment for her <b>marriage contract;</b> and for the <b>produce of</b> her property that her husband used; and <b>sustenance;</b> and she gets back her <b>worn clothes</b> and other objects she brought to the marriage; <b>and she is disqualified</b> as a <i>ḥalala</i> from marrying a priest; <b>and her offspring is disqualified</b> from the priesthood as a <i>ḥalal</i>; <b>and</b> the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> her. A woman who is <b>a secondary relative</b> prohibited <b>by rabbinic law has neither a marriage contract; nor</b> payment for the <b>produce</b> of her property; <b>nor sustenance; nor</b> does she get back her <b>worn clothes; and she is fit</b> to marry a priest <b>and her offspring is fit</b> for the priesthood; <b>and</b> the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> her.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: For what</b> reason did they <b>say</b> that <b>a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest has a marriage contract? Because he is disqualified</b> from the priesthood by his marriage to her, as a priest who marries a woman forbidden to him is barred from the Temple service until he divorces her and agrees not to remarry her, <b>and she is</b> rendered a <i>ḥalala</i> and <b>disqualified</b> from the priesthood by intercourse with him, <b>and any place where he is disqualified and she is disqualified,</b>

Daf 85b

<b>they penalized him</b> through the <b>marriage contract.</b> In other words, the Sages did not exempt him from payment of the marriage contract in that case. Since he is disqualified from the priesthood until he divorces her, the marriage will not last, and they did not force her to forfeit her marriage contract. <b>And for what</b> reason did <b>they say</b> that women forbidden as <b>secondary relatives by rabbinic law do not have a marriage contract? Because he is fit</b> for the priesthood <b>and she is</b> similarly <b>fit,</b> the couple therefore sees no need to divorce, <b>and any place where he is fit and she is fit they penalized her</b> by exempting him from payment of the <b>marriage contract,</b> in order to speed up the divorce.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> a different reason: <b>These</b> cases, a widow married to a High Priest and a divorcée married to a common priest, are prohibited by <b>Torah law, and Torah law does not require strengthening</b> by means of additional enactments. <b>But those</b> secondary relatives are forbidden by <b>rabbinic law, and rabbinic law</b> does <b>require strengthening. Alternatively,</b> the Gemara presents a second explanation: In <b>this</b> case, when they are both disqualified, it is <b>he who encourages her</b> to live with him despite the deleterious effect the prohibition will have on her and her offspring. Therefore, they penalized him by making him pay the marriage contract. <b>But</b> in <b>that</b> case, when they both remain fit for the priesthood despite the prohibited nature of their marriage, it is <b>she</b> who <b>encourages him,</b> and they consequently penalized her.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who teaches the alternative</b> explanation; whose opinion does it follow? <b>Some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar teaches it and is saying: What is the reason?</b> In other words, the latter part of the <i>baraita</i> provides the rationale for the previous statement: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>they said</b> that if <b>he is disqualified</b> from the priesthood <b>and she is</b> similarly <b>disqualified, they penalized him</b> through the <b>marriage contract?</b> It is <b>because</b> in such a case <b>he</b> primarily <b>encourages her</b> to violate the prohibition, as the main disqualification concerns her, so they penalize him for enticing her to sin. <b>And</b> for <b>what reason did they say</b> that when <b>he is fit and she is fit they penalized her</b> through the <b>marriage contract?</b> It is <b>because</b> in such a case <b>she encourages him,</b> since she is not disqualified and therefore may care less about the sin. The Sages therefore penalized her.
Conversely, <b>some say</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi is the one who <b>teaches it, and</b> the case of <b>a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> poses <b>a difficulty</b> to his opinion, as it seems to contradict his principle that rabbinic law requires strengthening: <b>A <i>ḥalutza</i></b> is forbidden to a priest <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and</b> yet <b>she does have a marriage contract.</b> In response, <b>he then said</b> an additional explanation: <b>Since he disqualifies her</b> from the priesthood <b>by rabbinic law,</b> in <b>this</b> case it is <b>he who encourages her, and</b> in <b>that</b> case of secondary relatives, when neither of them is disqualified, <b>she encourages him.</b>
The Gemara asks: Practically speaking, <b>what</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the explanations of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar? Rav Ḥisda said: The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns the cases of <b>a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman</b> married <b>to a Jew</b> of unflawed lineage.
According to <b>the one who says</b> that the reason the marriage contract is not revoked from a widow who is married to the High Priest is because this relationship is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, which doesn’t require strengthening, <b>this too is by Torah</b> law, and therefore she receives her marriage contract. But according to <b>the one who says</b> it is <b>because he encourages her,</b> in this case <b>she encourages him,</b> as the woman is disqualified regardless, and she wants to marry a Jew because there is a way for her descendants to be fit to enter the congregation: If her <i>mamzer</i> son marries a maidservant and has children, they will be slaves who can then be freed and enter the congregation.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> in a mishna (<i>Kiddushin</i> 69a) that if a <i>mamzer</i> marries a maidservant and they have a child, their son is both <b>a slave and a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> since she has no hope of her descendants being fit to enter into the congregation, <b>she does not encourage him at all. Rather, Rav Yosef said: The</b> practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to one who <b>remarries his divorcée after she has married</b> another man. According to <b>the one who says</b> that it depends on whether the prohibition is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>this too is</b> prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> it is <b>because he encourages her,</b> in this case <b>she encourages him,</b> as she and her children are unaffected by this marriage.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But according to Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that offspring <b>from</b> forbidden intercourse for which one <b>is liable</b> for violating <b>a prohibition is a <i>mamzer</i>, she does not encourage him at all,</b> because according to this opinion her children would be adversely affected by the marriage. <b>Rather, Rav Pappa said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them</b> involves <b>a non-virgin</b> married <b>to a High Priest.</b> According to <b>the one who says</b> that it depends on whether the prohibition is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>this too is</b> prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> it <b>is because he encourages her,</b> in this case <b>she encourages him,</b> as the marriage merely violates a positive mitzva, which does not disqualify her children.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, who said</b> that offspring conceived through intercourse with a priest <b>for which one is liable for</b> violating <b>a positive mitzva is a <i>ḥalal</i>, she does not encourage him at all. Rather, Rav Ashi said: The</b> practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to the case of one who <b>remarries his</b> wife when there is <b>an uncertainty</b> if she is <b>an adulteress.</b> If a married woman was in seclusion with another man after her husband had become suspicious and had warned her concerning that man, and the husband did not subsequently bring her to be examined by the bitter waters as a <i>sota</i>, but rather continued to live with her, he has acted contrary to Torah law, as she is forbidden to him.
In this case, according to <b>the one who says</b> that it depends on whether the prohibition is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>this too is</b> prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> it is <b>because he encourages her,</b> in this case <b>she encourages him,</b> as her children are not disqualified by such a relationship. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash, who said</b> that <b>even if her husband went to cause her to drink</b> the bitter waters <b>and had intercourse with her on the way, he has</b> thereby <b>rendered her a <i>zona</i></b> and disqualified her from the priesthood, <b>she does not encourage him at all. Rather, Mar bar Rav Ashi said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to the case of a <b>definite adulteress.</b> In such a case, all agree that their children are not <i>mamzerim</i>, despite the prohibition against their cohabitation. Consequently, she encourages him to sin.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <b>an Israelite woman betrothed to a priest</b> or <b>pregnant from a priest,</b> and he died; and <b>a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i>,</b> who is <b>a priest; and similarly,</b> the <b>daughter of a priest</b> who is betrothed, pregnant from, or is a widow waiting <b>for</b> her <i>yavam</i>, who is <b>an Israelite, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If there is <b>an Israelite woman betrothed to a Levite or pregnant from a Levite;</b> and <b>a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i>, who is a Levite; and similarly</b> the <b>daughter of a Levite</b> who is betrothed, pregnant from, or a widow waiting <b>for</b> her <i>yavam</i>, who is <b>an Israelite, she may not partake of tithes.</b>
If there is a <b>daughter of a Levite betrothed to a priest</b> or <b>pregnant from a priest;</b> and <b>a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i>, who is a priest; and similarly a daughter of a priest</b> who is betrothed <b>to</b> or pregnant from a Levite, or is a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i>, who is <b>a Levite, she may partake of neither <i>teruma</i> nor tithes.</b> This follows the <i>halakha</i> that betrothal, pregnancy, and waiting for a <i>yavam</i> disqualify the daughter of a priest from eating <i>teruma</i>, but they do not enable an Israelite woman to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that an Israelite woman betrothed to a Levite may not partake of tithes. The Gemara is puzzled by this ruling: <b>And let her</b> even <b>be</b> a complete <b>foreigner</b> who is not a Levite; <b>may a foreigner not partake of tithes?</b> In contradistinction to <i>teruma</i>, no special sanctity pertains to tithes; they are merely the possession of the Levite. What difference does it make, then, whether she is a Levite or not? <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that the <b>first tithe is forbidden to foreigners,</b> i.e., non-Levites, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 86a

<b><i>Teruma</i> is for a priest and</b> the <b>first tithe is for a Levite;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya permits it,</b> i.e., the first tithe, <b>to a priest,</b> as he too is from the tribe of Levi. The Gemara is puzzled by this last statement: It says: <b>Permits it.</b> Does this prove <b>by inference that there is one</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>that prohibits</b> a priest from partaking of tithes? But a priest is also a Levite and cannot be considered a foreigner. <b>Rather, say</b> that Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya meant that <b>one may give it even to a priest.</b> The tithe does not have to be handed to a Levite; one may choose to give it to a priest instead.
The Gemara inquires: <b>What is the reason</b> for <b>Rabbi Meir’s</b> opinion? <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rabba, said in the name of tradition</b> that the verse states: <b>“For the tithe of the children of Israel that they set apart as a <i>teruma</i> to the Lord,</b> I have given to the Levites for an inheritance” (Numbers 18:24). From the fact that this verse calls the tithe “<i>teruma</i>,” we learn: <b>Just as <i>teruma</i> is forbidden to foreigners, so too</b> is the <b>first tithe forbidden to foreigners,</b> i.e., non-Levites. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, is it true that <b>just as</b> with <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> a foreigner who eats it <b>is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>and</b> to pay the additional <b>fifth for it, so too,</b> with regard to <b>tithes,</b> a foreigner who eats it should be <b>liable for it</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>and</b> to pay the additional <b>fifth?</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “They will die through it if they profane it”</b> (Leviticus 22:9), and a different verse states: <b>“Then he shall add the fifth part thereof unto it”</b> (Leviticus 22:14). A close reading of these verses shows that the Torah is emphasizing that the death penalty comes <b>through it,</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>and not through tithes,</b> and that a fifth must be added <b>to it, but not to tithes.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Meir, how do they account for the comparison in the above verse? The Gemara answers: They would say it teaches that <b>just as</b> the requirement to separate <b><i>teruma</i> produces</b> the status of forbidden <b>untithed produce, so too</b> the requirement to separate the <b>first tithe also produces</b> the status of forbidden <b>untithed produce.</b>
<b>And</b> this is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought a person <b>should be liable only for untithed produce from which no</b> <i>terumot</i> or tithes <b>have been separated at all,</b> but if the <b>great <i>teruma</i> has been separated from it and the first tithe has not been separated from it;</b> or if the <b>first tithe</b> has been separated from it <b>and</b> the <b>second tithe has not; or even</b> if the <b>poor man’s tithe,</b> which is merely given to the poor and has no sanctity, has not been separated, <b>from where</b> is it derived that such produce also has the status of untithed produce?
<b>The verse states: “You may not eat within your gates</b> the tithe of your grain” (Deuteronomy 12:17), <b>and below,</b> with regard to the poor man’s tithe, <b>it states: “That they may eat within your gates and be satisfied”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:12). <b>Just as “your gates” stated below</b> is referring to <b>the poor man’s tithe, so too “your gates” stated here</b> is referring to <b>the poor man’s tithe, and the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah <b>“you may not</b> eat,” implying that it may be eaten only after separation.
<b>And if</b> we had learned it only <b>from there, I would say</b> that it merely teaches <b>a prohibition</b> against partaking of untithed produce of this type, <b>but</b> the <b>death</b> penalty is <b>not</b> warranted. The comparison to <i>teruma</i> consequently <b>teaches us</b> that eating this type of untithed produce is also punishable by death at the hand of Heaven.
<b>A different version</b> of this discussion presents it in the form of a question: Isn’t it the case that the <i>halakha</i> that failure to separate the <b>first tithe creates</b> the status of <b>untithed produce is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> taught? If so, there is no need for the exposition of the verse referring to tithes as <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the proof was <b>from that</b> source alone, <b>I would say</b> that it is only prohibited <b>by a prohibition but</b> the <b>death</b> penalty is <b>not</b> warranted. He therefore <b>teaches us</b> that all the stringencies of untithed produce are in force.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> manner <b>did you establish</b> the mishna? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> But if so, <b>say the latter clause:</b> The <b>daughter of a Levite betrothed to a priest and</b> the <b>daughter of a priest</b> betrothed <b>to a Levite may eat neither <i>teruma</i> nor tithe. Here, what foreignness is there</b> that prohibits her from partaking of the tithe? Even according to the opinion that prohibits the first tithe to foreigners, this woman is a Levite on both sides. <b>Rav Sheshet said: What is</b> the meaning of: <b>She may not eat, that</b> the mishna <b>teaches?</b> It means that <b>she may not give permission</b> to others <b>to separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> from the tithe. As long as she is merely betrothed to a Levite, she may not appoint a messenger to set aside the <i>teruma</i> from the tithe on behalf of the Levite, as she is not yet his wife.
The Gemara asks: Is it to be concluded <b>by inference that a married</b> woman <b>may give permission</b> to separate <i>teruma</i> from the tithe? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, and isn’t it taught: “And you may eat it in any place, you and your households”</b> (Numbers 18:31)? This <b>teaches that an Israelite woman married</b> to a Levite <b>may give permission</b> to another <b>to separate</b> <i>teruma</i> from the Levite’s tithe.
The <i>baraita</i> continues to discuss this <i>halakha</i>: Do <b>you say</b> she may give <b>permission to separate</b> <i>teruma</i> from the tithe, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> referring <b>to eating? Say</b> in response: If an Israelite woman married to a priest <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> which is <b>stringent,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> true for <b>tithe,</b> which is <b>lenient?</b> Consequently, there is no need to teach us this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rather,</b> the verse <b>teaches that an Israelite woman married</b> to a Levite <b>may give permission</b> to another <b>to separate</b> <i>teruma</i> from the tithe.
<b>Mar, son of Rabbana, said:</b> The mishna is not teaching that the daughter of a Levite who was betrothed to a priest may not partake of tithe, but rather it is coming <b>to say that we do not distribute tithe to her in the granary.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that the reason for the decree against distributing <i>teruma</i> to a woman in the granary is <b>due to</b> the prohibition (<i>Yevamot</i> 100a) against a woman <b>being alone</b> with a strange man in the granary, which is a secluded place, as this concern applies equally to the case here. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that the Sages prohibited this practice <b>due to</b> concern that the woman might be <b>a divorcée,</b> who is no longer entitled to <i>teruma</i>, this concern should not apply to the <b>daughter of a Levite. Does she not partake of tithe</b> on her own account, even after she is divorced?
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>And according to your reasoning</b> that rejects the explanation of Mar, son of Rabbana, with regard to the daughter of a Levite, <b>does a divorcée</b> who is the <b>daughter of a priest not partake of <i>teruma</i>?</b> Why should the daughter of a priest married to a priest not receive <i>teruma</i> in a granary? <b>Rather,</b> this is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that was enacted primarily <b>due to</b> a priest’s <b>divorcée</b> who is the <b>daughter of a non-priest,</b> as she may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i> after her divorce. They also applied this decree to the daughter of a priest divorced from a priest. For this reason, they also decreed against a Levite woman receiving a portion in the granary.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, why specifically</b> one who was <b>betrothed; the same would hold true even</b> for <b>a married</b> woman <b>as well.</b> The Gemara answers: There is no difference between them in this regard, but <b>since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna: <b>Betrothed, he also taught</b> in <b>the latter clause: Betrothed,</b> although the <i>halakha</i> in the latter clause does not apply exclusively to a betrothed woman.
§ <b>The Sages taught: <i>Teruma</i> is</b> given <b>to a priest, and</b> the <b>first tithe is</b> given only <b>to a Levite;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b>

Daf 86b

The first tithe is given <b>to a priest.</b> The Gemara is puzzled: <b>To a priest and not to a Levite?</b> But the Torah expressly states that the first tithe is for Levites. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> he means it can be given <b>also to a priest.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> for <b>Rabbi Akiva’s</b> opinion? <b>As it is written: “You shall speak to the Levites, and you shall say to them”</b> (Numbers 18:26). Clearly, <b>the verse speaks of Levites,</b> not priests. <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Eliezer, maintains <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: In twenty-four places</b> in the Bible the <b>priests are called Levites. And this is one of those</b> verses: <b>“And the priests the Levites, the sons of Zadok”</b> (Ezekiel 44:15).
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> replies: <b>Here you cannot say</b> the verse is referring to priests, <b>as it is written: “And you may eat it in any place”</b> (Numbers 18:31), from which we learn that the tithe is given to <b>one who can eat it in any place.</b> This <b>excludes a priest, who cannot eat it in a cemetery,</b> as he is prohibited from entering such a place. Consequently, the verse cannot be referring to priests. <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Eliezer, how does he respond to this claim? He explains the verse as follows: He may eat it <b>anywhere that he wishes,</b> that is, in any city, <b>as it does not require</b> the <b>wall</b> of Jerusalem, like the second tithe. <b>And</b> we further learn from here that <b>if he eats it in</b> a state of <b>bodily impurity he is not flogged.</b> Consequently, we can say that tithe may be eaten by priests in any place.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain garden from which Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya,</b> a priest, <b>would take</b> the <b>first tithe,</b> in accordance with his opinion that priests are also entitled to this tithe. <b>Rabbi Akiva went,</b> closed up the garden, and <b>changed its entrance</b> so that it would be facing <b>toward the cemetery,</b> to prevent Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya from entering the garden. Rabbi Elazar <b>said</b> in the form of a lighthearted exaggeration: <b>Akiva,</b> a former shepherd, comes <b>with his satchel, but I have to live;</b> from where will I receive my livelihood if I cannot claim the first tithe? Rabbi Elazar was actually a very wealthy man and did not need the produce from this garden. However, his point was that Rabbi Akiva acted in order to stop him from receiving something that he felt was rightfully his.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the following question: <b>For what reason did</b> the Sages <b>penalize</b> the <b>Levites with regard to</b> their <b>tithe,</b> by declaring that it may be given to priests as well? <b>Rabbi Yonatan and the Elders</b> who were with him <b>disagree</b> with regard to <b>this</b> matter. <b>One said</b> it was because <b>they did not ascend,</b> i.e., immigrate to the land of Israel, <b>in the days of Ezra. And one said</b> that it was not a penalty at all, but they gave the first tithe to the priests <b>so that they</b> could <b>rely on it during their days of impurity.</b> Because it is prohibited for priests to consume <i>teruma</i> while in a state of impurity, they would have had nothing to eat if they were dependent exclusively on <i>teruma</i>. It is permitted, however, to eat the tithe while impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> it was because <b>they did not ascend,</b> we can understand that <b>due to that</b> reason <b>they penalized</b> the Levites by forcing them to share their tithe with the priests. <b>But according to the one who says</b> it was done <b>so that the priests</b> could <b>rely on it during their days of impurity,</b> should we <b>penalize the Levites for</b> the benefit of <b>priests? Rather, everyone agrees</b> that it was <b>a penalty</b> for the fact <b>that they did not ascend in the days of Ezra, and here they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage holds</b> that the <b>penalty</b> is that the tithe must be given <b>to the poor, and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>priests are</b> classified as <b>poor in the days of their impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the <b>penalty</b> imposed on the Levites is that the tithe must be given <b>to the poor, due to that</b> reason <b>Rabbi Akiva changed</b> the garden <b>entrance</b> so that it would be facing <b>toward the cemetery,</b> as Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya was a wealthy man. <b>But according to the one who says</b> the tithe was given <b>to the priests, why did he change</b> the <b>entrance</b> so that it would be <b>toward the cemetery?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This is what he said to him,</b> i.e., this is what he meant: <b>If you come</b> to receive the tithe <b>by virtue of</b> the <b>penalty</b> imposed on the Levites, <b>you may have</b> it, <b>but if you come by the</b> standard <i>halakha</i> <b>of distribution,</b> demanding your share with the Levites, <b>you may not have</b> the tithe. If the owner of the garden chooses to give it to you, you may accept it, but you may not take it yourself.
The Gemara asks with regard to the penalty imposed on Levites: <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> the Levites <b>did not ascend in the days of Ezra? As it is written: “And I gathered them together to the river that runs to Ahava; and we encamped there</b> for <b>three days; and I viewed the people, and the priests, and found there none of the sons of Levi”</b> (Ezra 8:15). With regard to this, <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Initially they would establish officers</b> over the people <b>only from</b> among <b>the Levites, as it states: “And the officers, the Levites, before you”</b> (II Chronicles 19:11), but <b>now they establish officers only from</b> among the <b>Israelites, as it is stated: And the officers of the many at your heads.</b> This indicates that officers were appointed from: The many, meaning the largest group, ordinary Israelites.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>An Israelite woman married to a priest may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If the priest <b>died and she had a child from him, she may</b> continue to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If she subsequently <b>married a Levite,</b> she may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i> but <b>she may partake of</b> the first <b>tithe</b> on his account. If he, too, <b>died and she</b> had <b>a child from him, she may</b> continue to <b>partake of tithe</b> on account of the child. If she then <b>married an Israelite, she may partake of neither <i>teruma</i> nor tithe.</b> If her Israelite husband <b>died and she</b> had <b>a child from him, she</b> still <b>may partake of neither <i>teruma</i> nor tithe.</b>
If <b>her child from the Israelite</b> also <b>died,</b> while her son from the Levite remained alive, <b>she may partake of tithe</b> on account of the Levite’s child. If <b>her child from the Levite died,</b> leaving her with a son from the priest, <b>she may</b> once again <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If <b>her child from the priest died</b> as well, <b>she may no</b> longer <b>partake of either <i>teruma</i> or tithe.</b>

Daf 87a

The <b>daughter of a priest married to an Israelite may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If the Israelite <b>died and she</b> has <b>a son from him, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i></b> as long as that son is alive. If she subsequently <b>married a Levite she may partake of tithe.</b> If he <b>died, and she</b> had <b>a son from him, she may</b> still <b>partake of tithe.</b> If she subsequently <b>married a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> If the priest <b>died and she</b> had <b>a son from him, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
If <b>her son from the priest</b> also <b>died, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> but she may partake of tithe, as she has a son from a Levite. If <b>her son from the Levite died, she may no</b> longer <b>partake of tithe.</b> If <b>her son from the Israelite died, she returns to her father’s house</b> and may once again partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And with regard to this</b> woman, it <b>is stated: “And she is returned unto her father’s house, as in her youth; she may eat of her father’s bread”</b> (Leviticus 22:13).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna: If <b>her son from the Levite died she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: This <i>halakha</i> with regard to a woman previously married to a priest, who had a child from the priest and was then married to a Levite and separated from him, <b>that she once again may partake due to her son</b> from the priest, <b>from where do we</b> derive it? <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It states: “But if a priest’s daughter be a widow, or divorced, and have no child, and is returned unto her father’s house, as in her youth” (Leviticus 22:13). The verse could have stated: If a priest’s <b>daughter.</b> Instead, it states: <b>“But</b> if a priest’s <b>daughter,”</b> with an extra word, represented by the single Hebrew letter <i>vav</i>, to include this case.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>which</b> Sage is this exposition? Is it only <b>in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who expounds</b> the additional letter <i>vav</i>, representing the word “and,” as an inclusive term? The Gemara refutes this suggestion: It can be understood <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> it is in accordance with <b>the Rabbis,</b> who do not usually derive <i>halakhot</i> from an additional <i>vav</i>, as in this case the <b>entire</b> phrase: <b>“But</b> if a priest’s <b>daughter,” is superfluous,</b> as the previous verse had already specified that we are dealing with “the daughter of a priest.” Therefore, everyone agrees that in this context the additional letter in the text comes to include the additional case.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to the daughter of a priest, <b>when she returns</b> to her father’s house after having been married to a non-priest and then separated from her husband, <b>she returns to</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i> but she does not return to</b> partake of <b>the breast and</b> right <b>hind leg</b> of peace-offerings. <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Ravina bar Sheila said: What is the verse</b> that teaches us this <i>halakha</i>? <b>“She may not eat of that which is set apart from the sacred things”</b> (Leviticus 22:12). This verse indicates: <b>From that which is separated from the sacred things,</b> i.e., offerings, and given to a priest, <b>she may not eat. Rav Naḥman</b> said that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> comes from a different source: We infer from the words “she may eat <b>of</b> her father’s <b>bread”</b> (Leviticus 22:13), that she may <b>not</b> eat <b>all bread;</b> this comes to <b>exclude the breast and</b> right <b>hind leg.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama objects to this:</b> But we can <b>say</b> that the verse comes to <b>exclude nullification of vows.</b> The Torah would consequently be teaching us that even after she “is returned unto her father’s house, as in her youth” (Leviticus 22:13), she does not return to her youth in all ways, as her father may not nullify her vows. <b>Rava said:</b> The connection between her and her father’s house with regard to vows has <b>already been severed,</b> as taught by <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: “But the vow of a widow, or of a divorcée…shall stand against her”</b> (Numbers 30:10). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this? <b>She was removed from the category</b> of one who is under the authority of her <b>father</b> when she married, <b>and she has</b> likewise <b>been removed from the category</b> of one who is under the authority of her <b>husband,</b> as she is no longer married to him.
<b>Rather,</b> the verse is referring to a case <b>where the father transferred</b> his daughter <b>to the husband’s agents</b> for the purpose of marriage, and she consequently left her father’s house. <b>Or,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where the father’s agents transferred</b> her <b>to the husband’s agents and she was widowed or divorced on the way,</b> before she arrived at her husband’s house. <b>How shall I consider her?</b> Is she in the <b>house of this one, her father, or</b> is she in the <b>house of that one, her husband? Rather,</b> this comes <b>to tell you: Since she has</b> entirely <b>left her father’s jurisdiction</b> when she was transferred to the husband’s agents, even if for just <b>one moment,</b> her father <b>is no longer able to nullify</b> her vows. We learn from here that a father cannot annul his daughter’s vows after she has been married, and there is no need for an additional verse to teach this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Safra said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that she does not return to her father’s house with regard to the breast and the right hind leg is derived from the verse: <b>“From her father’s bread she may eat,”</b> which indicates that she partakes of the <b>“bread”</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>but not</b> of the <b>meat</b> of the breast and hind leg. <b>Rav Pappa said</b> a different interpretation: <b>“From her father’s bread she may eat”</b> is referring to <b>bread owned by her father,</b> such as <i>teruma</i>, which is the property of the priest, which <b>excludes the breast and</b> right <b>hind leg, as</b> the priests <b>receive</b> their portion <b>from the table of</b> the <b>Most High.</b> Unlike <i>teruma</i>, the breast and right hind leg do not belong to the priests. Rather, after the offering is sacrificed to God, they eat these portions but are not considered to own them.
<b>And Rava said:</b> It states: <b>“And the breast of waving and the hind leg of heaving you shall eat…you, and your sons and your daughters with you”</b> (Leviticus 10:14). This indicates that daughters of priests may eat <b>at a time when</b> they are <b>“with you,”</b> but once they have left the priest’s domain, e.g., by marrying an ordinary Israelite, they may no longer partake of these gifts even if they subsequently return to his household.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> It was <b>taught:</b> With regard to the daughter of a priest, <b>when she returns to her father’s house,</b> after marrying and separating from her husband without a child, <b>she returns for</b> the purposes of eating <b><i>teruma</i>, but she does not return for</b> the purposes of eating <b>the breast and</b> right <b>hind leg.</b> By contrast, if an Israelite woman ate <b>on account of her son</b> from a priest, if she later married an Israelite and he died, <b>she returns</b> to partake <b>even of the breast and</b> right <b>hind leg.</b>
<b>Rav Mordekhai went</b> and <b>stated</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Ashi,</b> who <b>said</b> to him: <b>From where does</b> he <b>include</b> the case of a woman who partakes of <i>teruma</i> on account of her son? <b>From</b> the verse <b>“but</b> if a priest’s <b>daughter”</b> (Leviticus 22:13). <b>Is</b> the Israelite woman <b>preferable to her,</b> the daughter of a priest herself, who does not return to eating the breast and hind leg? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the Torah <b>writes exclusions,</b> as we learned above, which teach us that she does not return in all regards, whereas <b>here it does not write exclusions.</b> Consequently, although the <i>halakha</i> of a woman who has a son from a priest is itself derived from the case of the daughter of a priest returning to her father’s house, she has more abilities than the latter.
§ The Gemara returns to the mishna. The mishna taught: The <b>daughter of a priest married to an Israelite</b> may not partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>The Sages taught: “And she is returned unto her father’s house”</b> (Leviticus 22:13); this <b>excludes a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i>,</b> for she cannot go back to her father’s house as long as she is still waiting for the <i>yavam</i> to perform levirate marriage. <b>“As in her youth”;</b> this <b>excludes a pregnant woman,</b> as her pregnancy has changed her, and she is no longer as she was in her youth.
<b>But</b> could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference,</b> without the need for a special exposition of a verse? <b>If in a place,</b> i.e., a case, <b>where</b> the Torah <b>did not make</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a child from the first</b> husband <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a child from the second</b> husband <b>to exempt her from levirate marriage;</b> this is the case of a woman who married a man, had a son with him, was widowed, remarried, and her second husband died childless. She requires levirate marriage despite the fact that she has a child, as the first husband’s child is irrelevant with regard to her need for levirate marriage for the second husband. Despite this limitation, the Torah <b>made</b> the status of <b>a fetus like</b> that of a child who was <b>born,</b> as a pregnant woman does not perform levirate marriage.
If this is so, then in <b>a place where</b> the Torah <b>did make</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a child from the first</b> husband <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a child from the second</b> husband <b>to disqualify her from <i>teruma</i>;</b> this is the case of a daughter of a priest who married an Israelite, had a son with him, was widowed, and afterward married another Israelite, who died childless. She may not partake of <i>teruma</i> on account of her son from the first husband. <b>Is it not,</b> therefore, <b>right that we should make a fetus like</b> a child who was <b>born</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>, that would prevent her from returning to partake of <i>teruma</i> if she is pregnant? If this reasoning is correct, there is no need for the biblical exposition.
However, this proof can be refuted: <b>No, what I</b> should say is that the Torah <b>made a fetus like</b> a child who was <b>born with regard to levirate marriage, because</b> with regard to levirate marriage the Torah <b>made the dead like the living:</b> If the woman had a child at the time of her husband’s death she is entirely exempt from levirate marriage, even if her son subsequently died. The deceased child is like a living one in the sense that he continues to exempt his mother from the requirement of levirate marriage. <b>Shall we</b> then <b>make a fetus like</b> a child who was <b>born with regard to <i>teruma</i>, where</b> the Torah <b>did not make the dead like the living?</b> In the case of <i>teruma</i>, as long as the daughter of a priest has a living son from her Israelite husband, she is disqualified from <i>teruma</i>, but if he dies she may partake of <i>teruma</i> again, as we do not consider him like a living son. Consequently, we cannot learn the <i>halakha</i> of <i>teruma</i> from levirate marriage with regard to the status of a fetus. Therefore, <b>the verse states “as in her youth”</b> to <b>exclude a pregnant woman.</b>
