The Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary to write</b> this verse that teaches the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a pregnant woman, and it was necessary</b> also <b>to write “and she have no child”</b> (Leviticus 22:13) <b>because had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“And she have no child,”</b> I would have said that <b>at the outset</b> she was only <b>one body</b> when she ate <i>teruma</i>, <b>and now,</b> upon her return, there are <b>two bodies,</b> and that is why she is no longer “as in her youth.” <b>But a pregnant woman, who at the outset</b> was <b>one body and now</b> is still <b>one body,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>she may partake of</b> <i>teruma</i> until the birth of her son. Consequently, it is <b>necessary</b> for a verse to teach the <i>halakha</i>. <b>And</b> vice-versa, <b>had the Merciful One written</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a pregnant woman,</b> I might have said that this is true only of a pregnant woman <b>because at the outset</b> her <b>body</b>

Daf 87b

was <b>empty, and now</b> her <b>body</b> is <b>full</b> with the child, and therefore she is no longer “as in her youth.” <b>But</b> in a situation where <b>“she has no child,” when at the outset</b> her <b>body</b> was <b>empty and now</b> her <b>body</b> is also <b>empty,</b> as she has given birth, you might <b>say</b> that she should <b>not</b> be disqualified. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to write both verses.
Parenthetically, the Gemara lists terms signifying the following discussions, to serve as <b>a mnemonic</b> device: <b>Said to him, we should not make, by death, we should make and not make, by a child, <i>yavam</i> and <i>teruma</i>, levirate marriage and <i>teruma</i>.</b> This list of terms, taken from the introductions or key phrases in each of the ensuing discussions, is the <b>mnemonic.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda from De’iskarta said to Rava,</b> in continuation of the discussion of the <i>baraita</i>: Should <b>we not make the</b> <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>dead</b> children <b>like the</b> <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>living</b> children <b>with regard to levirate marriage by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, and say: <b>And if in a place where</b> the Torah <b>made</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a child from the first</b> husband <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a child from the second</b> husband, <b>to disqualify her from <i>teruma</i>,</b> for as long as she has a child who is not a priest she is prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, the Torah nevertheless <b>did not make dead</b> children <b>like living</b> ones; therefore, in a <b>place where</b> the Torah <b>did not make a child from the first</b> husband <b>like a child from the second to exempt her from levirate marriage, is it not right that we should not make the dead like the living?</b> Why, then, is a <i>yevama</i> exempt from levirate marriage if her late husband’s only child dies?
<b>The verse states: “Her ways are the ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace”</b> (Proverbs 3:17). In other words, since the ways of Torah are those of pleasantness, the Torah would not obligate a woman who has married in the meantime to subsequently perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, as this might demean her in her husband’s eyes.
The Gemara inquires: <b>And let us make</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>dead</b> children <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>living</b> ones <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, from an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if in a place where</b> the Torah <b>did not make a child from the first</b> husband <b>like a child from the second to exempt her from levirate marriage,</b> it nevertheless <b>made the living like the dead,</b> as a woman whose husband died and left a child is exempt from levirate marriage even if that child subsequently dies; then, in <b>a place where</b> the Torah <b>made a child from the first like a child from the second to disqualify her from <i>teruma</i>, is it not right that we should make the living like the dead?</b> The Gemara responds: Therefore, <b>the verse states “and she have no child,</b> she is returned unto her father’s house, as in her youth” (Leviticus 22:13), <b>and</b> here <b>she does not</b> currently <b>have</b> children.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>And let us make</b> her <b>child from the first</b> husband <b>like</b> her <b>child from the second</b> one <b>with regard to levirate marriage,</b> again <b>from an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if in a place where</b> the Torah <b>did not make the living like the dead with regard to <i>teruma</i>,</b> it still <b>made a child from the first</b> husband <b>like a child from the second,</b> then in <b>a place where it made the living like the dead, with regard to levirate marriage, is it not right that we should make a child from the first</b> husband <b>like a child from the second,</b> and thereby exempt her from levirate marriage? The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states</b> about levirate marriage: <b>“And he has no child”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), <b>and</b> in fact <b>he had none</b> at the time of his death.
The Gemara offers another possibility: <b>And should we make a child from the first</b> husband <b>not like a child from the second</b> one <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, from an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If in a place where</b> the Torah <b>made the living like the dead to exempt her from levirate marriage,</b> it still <b>did not make a child from the first</b> husband <b>like a child from the second,</b> then in <b>a place where</b> the Torah <b>did not make the living like the dead, with regard to <i>teruma</i>, is it not right that we should not make</b> the <b>child from the first</b> husband <b>like</b> the <b>child from the second?</b> The Gemara responds: Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And <b>she have no</b> child,” <b>but</b> in fact this woman <b>has</b> children.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman whose husband went overseas, and</b> witnesses <b>came and</b> they <b>said to her: Your husband is dead, and she married</b> another man on the basis of this testimony, <b>and afterward her husband came</b> back from out of the country, <b>she must leave</b> both <b>this</b> man <b>and that</b> one, as they are both forbidden to her. <b>And she requires a bill of divorce from this</b> one <b>and that</b> one.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>she has</b> a claim to <b>neither</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract, nor</b> the <b>profits</b> of her property used by either of them, <b>nor sustenance, nor</b> the <b>worn clothes</b> she brought to the marriage. She has rights to these claims <b>neither against this</b> man <b>nor against that</b> one, i.e., she cannot collect these payments from either her first or second husband. <b>And if she took</b> any of these items <b>from this</b> man <b>or from that</b> one, she must <b>return</b> them to him.
<b>And the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i> from this</b> one <b>and from that</b> one. Her child from the second husband is a definite <i>mamzer</i>, as she was never divorced from her first husband, and the Sages decreed that if she returned to her first husband, a child born later from him is also a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>And neither this</b> man <b>nor that</b> man <b>may become impure for her</b> upon her death, if they are priests. <b>And neither this</b> one <b>nor that one is entitled</b> to the rights that stem from the marriage bond: <b>Neither to her found</b> articles, <b>nor to her earnings, nor to the nullification of her vows.</b>
If she <b>was</b> a regular <b>Israelite woman, she is disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood,</b> as her intercourse with the second husband is considered an act of illicit sexual relations, <b>and</b> the <b>daughter of a Levite</b> is disqualified <b>from</b> partaking of the first <b>tithe, and</b> the <b>daughter of a priest</b> is disqualified <b>from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>. And neither</b> the <b>heirs of this</b> man nor the <b>heirs of that</b> one <b>inherit her marriage contract,</b> as she is not considered married to either of them. This clause will be explained in the Gemara. <b>And if they</b> both <b>died</b> childless, <b>the brothers of this</b> one <b>and the brothers of this</b> one must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and they do not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees with the first <i>tanna</i> and <b>says</b> that she does receive payment of her marriage contract, and the obligation of <b>her marriage contract is upon the property of her first husband. Rabbi Elazar says: The first</b> husband <b>is entitled to her found</b> articles, <b>to her earnings, and to the nullification of her vows.</b> Since her second marriage was an error, the first husband does not forfeit his rights. <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> an even more far-reaching ruling: <b>Her sexual relations or her <i>ḥalitza</i> with the brothers of the first</b> husband <b>exempts her rival wife,</b> as it is considered a proper levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>, and certainly she does not require <i>ḥalitza</i> from the brother of the second husband. <b>And</b> if she returns to her first husband, <b>the child from him is not a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
All these <i>halakhot</i> refer to a situation when she married with the permission of the court, after hearing that her husband had died. <b>But if she married without</b> the <b>consent</b> of the court, basing herself entirely on the testimony she heard, and her husband returned, it is <b>permitted</b> for her <b>to return to</b> her first husband. The mishna adds another difference between these two scenarios: If <b>she married by</b> permission of <b>the court, she must leave</b> both of them <b>and she is exempt from</b> bringing <b>the offering,</b> i.e., the sin-offering for her unwitting adultery, as she had the authorization of the court and is therefore considered to have acted under duress.
If, however, <b>she did not marry by</b> permission of <b>the court, she must leave</b> her second husband <b>and is liable to</b> bring <b>an offering</b> for mistakenly having relations with a man forbidden to her. In this regard, the <b>power of the court is greater, as she is exempt from</b> bringing <b>an offering.</b> If the <b>court instructed her to marry</b> on the basis of inaccurate testimony, <b>and she went and ruined</b> herself by engaging in licentious relations outside matrimony, <b>she is liable to</b> bring <b>an offering, as they permitted her only to marry,</b> and not to engage in licentious relations.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If <b>she married without</b> the <b>consent</b> of the court she is <b>permitted to return to him,</b> this indicates that she did so <b>not by</b> the <b>consent</b> of the <b>court, but</b> rather <b>by witnesses,</b> i.e., as there are two witnesses, she does not require special permission from the court. With this in mind, <b>it may be inferred that the first clause</b> of the mishna, which speaks of one who acted <b>with the consent of</b> the <b>court,</b> is referring to a situation <b>when</b> there was <b>one witness. Apparently, one witness is deemed credible</b> when he testifies about a husband’s death, i.e., the court will permit a wife to marry on the basis of the testimony of a lone witness.
<b>And we also learned</b> in a mishna (122a): <b>They established</b> that <b>they would</b> allow a woman to <b>marry</b> if her husband was reported dead by one <b>witness,</b> based solely on what he learned <b>from the mouth of</b> another <b>witness,</b> i.e., hearsay testimony, <b>and</b> also the testimony of <b>a woman</b> who heard <b>from</b> another <b>woman, and</b> even the testimony of <b>a woman</b> who heard <b>from a slave or from a maidservant. Apparently, one witness is deemed credible</b> in this regard, as whenever hearsay testimony is accepted, the testimony of one witness is also valid.
<b>And we also learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Karetot</i> 11b) that if <b>one witness says</b> to someone: <b>You ate forbidden fat, and</b> the accused <b>says: I did not eat</b> it, the accused is <b>exempt</b> from bringing an offering. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> he is exempt <b>is that</b> the individual in question <b>said: I did not eat</b> it, which indicates that if <b>he</b> had been <b>silent</b> and failed to deny the accusation, the lone witness is <b>deemed credible. Apparently, one witness is deemed credible by Torah</b> law with regard to certain issues.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states: <b>“Or if his sin be known to him”</b> (Leviticus 4:23, 28). This indicates that he himself must be aware of his sin, <b>and not if it was made known to him by others.</b> In other words, one is not obligated to bring an offering due to the testimony of others, even if they testify that he had transgressed. I <b>might</b> have thought <b>he should be exempt even though he does not contradict</b> the witness’s claim. Therefore, <b>the verse states: If his sin be known to him,</b> which indicates that <b>in any case,</b> however he comes by this knowledge, he is liable.
The Gemara clarifies this <i>halakha</i>. <b>What are the circumstances? If we say that two</b> witnesses <b>came</b> and informed him <b>and</b> he <b>does not contradict them, why do I</b> need a <b>verse</b> to teach this ruling? After all, the testimony of two witnesses is always accepted. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>one</b> witness, <b>and</b> yet <b>if he does not contradict</b> the sole witness, that witness is <b>deemed credible?</b> One can <b>learn from this</b> that <b>one witness is deemed credible</b> with regard to prohibitions. The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>And from where</b> do you infer <b>that</b> the reason is <b>due to</b> the fact that the one witness <b>is deemed credible? Perhaps</b> the accused must bring an offering <b>because</b> he remains <b>silent, as</b> there is a principle that <b>silence is considered like an admission.</b>
And you should <b>know</b> that this is the reason, <b>as the latter clause</b> of <b>that</b> same <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>said</b> to him: <b>You ate forbidden fat, and he says: I did not eat</b> it, he is <b>exempt,</b> and <b>Rabbi Meir obligates</b> him to bring an offering. <b>Rabbi Meir said</b> that this is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If two</b> witnesses <b>can bring him to</b> the <b>severe</b> penalty of <b>death</b> by testifying that he had committed a transgression for which one is liable to receive the death penalty, should they <b>not bring him to</b> the <b>more lenient</b> obligation of <b>an offering?</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> There is a difference between the two cases, as with regard to an offering, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>if he would choose to say: I was an intentional</b> sinner? One who sins intentionally is not liable to bring an offering. Since the accused in the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> can negate the testimony that would have rendered him liable to bring an offering, he can likewise deny the act itself, whereas if witnesses testify that he performed an action that incurs the death penalty, his denial has no bearing on the case. The Gemara clarifies: In <b>the first clause</b>

Daf 88a

of the mishna, <b>what is the reason that</b> when he remains silent, <b>the Rabbis obligate</b> him to bring to an offering based on the testimony of one witness? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>because</b> the witness <b>is deemed credible, but</b> there is the case of <b>an ordinary pair</b> of witnesses, <b>where even though he contradicts their</b> claim <b>they are deemed credible, and</b> yet <b>the Rabbis exempt</b> him from bringing an offering. If so, they would certainly not obligate him to bring an offering due to the testimony of a lone witness. <b>Rather, is it not because he</b> remained <b>silent, and silence is considered like an admission?</b> If this is the reason why he brings an offering, there is no proof from here that the testimony of one witness is accepted.
<b>Rather,</b> this <b>is</b> evidently based on <b>logical reasoning: Just as it is in</b> the case of <b>a piece</b> of meat about which it is <b>uncertain</b> if it is <b>forbidden fat</b> and <b>uncertain</b> if it is <b>of</b> permitted <b>fat,</b> and there is no way of clarifying which it is, <b>and one witness comes and says: It is clear to me that it is</b> permitted <b>fat,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that he is deemed credible.</b> Here too, the testimony of a single witness can resolve the uncertainty.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is it comparable? There, the presumption of a prohibition has not</b> been established, as there is no proof that the piece was ever forbidden, and one can therefore rely on the witness who permits it, whereas <b>here, the presumption of</b> the <b>prohibition</b> with regard <b>to a married woman is</b> established, <b>and</b> there is a principle that <b>nothing involving</b> those <b>with whom relations are forbidden</b> can be determined by <b>fewer than two</b> witnesses.
In fact, <b>this is comparable only to</b> a case involving <b>a piece</b> of meat <b>that</b> is <b>definitely</b> forbidden <b>fat, and one witness comes and says: It is clear to me that it is</b> permitted <b>fat,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that he is not deemed credible.</b> The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>Is it comparable? There,</b> when it is established as forbidden fat, <b>even</b> if <b>one hundred</b> witnesses <b>come they are not deemed credible. Here, since if two</b> witnesses <b>come</b> and say the husband is dead <b>they</b> would be <b>deemed credible, let us also deem one</b> witness <b>credible.</b> This is <b>just as it is in</b> the case of <b>untithed produce,</b> i.e., produce from which neither <i>teruma</i> nor tithe has been separated, <b>consecrated</b> property, <b>and <i>konamot</i>,</b> an alternative term for offerings [<i>korbanot</i>] used in vows creating prohibitions. Such vows are called by the generic term: <i>Konamot</i>.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>this</b> case of <b>untithed produce, what are the circumstances? If</b> it <b>is his,</b> and he testifies that <i>terumot</i> and tithes have been separated from it, he should be deemed credible <b>because it is within his power to prepare</b> the produce for consumption by separating tithes whenever he wishes. <b>Rather,</b> you must say that he testifies with regard to untithed produce <b>of another,</b> but if so, <b>what does</b> the anonymous Sage who cited this example <b>hold</b> in this case?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>If</b> he <b>holds</b> that <b>one who separates</b> tithes <b>from his</b> produce <b>for</b> that <b>of another does not require the owner’s knowledge,</b> and he can prepare his friend’s produce for consumption whenever he chooses, in this case too his testimony is deemed credible <b>because it is within his power to prepare it. And if he holds</b> that <b>the owner’s knowledge is required</b> before someone else can separate the gifts, and this is referring to a situation where the witness comes <b>and says: I know with regard to it that it is prepared,</b> in that case, <b>it itself,</b> this very <i>halakha</i>, <b>from where do we</b> derive it? Why is the case of untithed produce more obvious than the testimony with regard to a missing husband?
Similarly, with regard to <b>consecrated</b> property <b>too,</b> if it is merely <b>sanctity</b> that inheres in its <b>value,</b> i.e., it is not an actual offering but an item that has been dedicated to the Temple upkeep, then the reason why the testimony of one witness who says it is not consecrated is accepted is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>it is within his power to redeem it.</b> And <b>if</b> this is referring to <b>inherent sanctity,</b> the matter still remains to be clarified: <b>If</b> it is <b>his</b> offering, then the reason is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>it is within his power to request</b> from a Sage <b>that</b> the vow be dissolved, like any other vow. <b>Rather,</b> you must say that it is referring to the offering <b>of another, and he said: I know with regard to it that its owner requested</b> from a Sage <b>that</b> his vow be dissolved. However, here too, in this case <b>itself, from where do we</b> derive that he is deemed credible?
In the case of <b><i>konamot</i> too, if</b> he <b>holds</b> that <b>there is misuse</b> of consecrated objects <b>with regard to <i>konamot</i>,</b> i.e., he holds that articles sanctified by a <i>konam</i> have the status of consecrated property, <b>and</b> that the <b>sanctity</b> that inheres in its <b>value applies to them,</b> then his claim is accepted <b>because it is within his power to redeem it. And if</b> he <b>maintains</b> that <b>there is no misuse</b> of consecrated objects <b>in</b> the case of <b><i>konamot</i>, and it is an ordinary prohibition that rides on its shoulders,</b> i.e., it is forbidden due to its similarity to consecrated property despite the fact that is not fully sacred, even in this case the above argument applies: <b>If</b> the property in question <b>is his,</b> it is permitted <b>because it is within his power to request</b> from a Sage <b>that</b> his vow be dissolved.
<b>Rather,</b> you will say that the <i>konam</i> must belong <b>to another, and he said: I know with regard to it that its owner requested</b> from a Sage <b>that</b> his vow be dissolved. However, with regard to this <i>halakha</i> <b>itself,</b> that one witness is deemed credible in this case, <b>from where do we</b> derive it? Consequently, after the Gemara has refuted these attempts to explain why one witness should be deemed credible, the question remains: Why is the testimony of a single witness accepted in the case of a missing husband?
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: Due to the stringency that you were stringent with her,</b> the woman who married on the basis of a single witness, <b>at the end,</b> i.e., if it turns out that the testimony was incorrect and the husband is still alive, the <i>halakha</i> is very severe with her and she loses out in all regards, <b>you are lenient with her at the beginning,</b> by accepting the testimony of a single witness to enable the woman to marry. The Gemara suggests: If so, let us <b>not be stringent</b> at the end <b>and not be lenient</b> at the beginning.
The Gemara answers: <b>Due to</b> the case of <b>a deserted wife, the Sages were lenient with her.</b> Since it is not always easy to find two witnesses to attest to a husband’s death, the Sages realized that if the testimony of one witness were not accepted, the woman would be likely to remain a deserted wife, unable to remarry. However, to prevent this leniency from causing mistakes and licentiousness, they were very stringent with her in a case where the testimony is found to be erroneous, to ensure that she is very careful not to accept untrustworthy accounts.
§ The mishna teaches that if she was informed that her husband was dead and she married another man, and her husband later returned, <b>she must leave this one and this one. Rav said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only if she married by</b> virtue of the testimony of <b>one witness, but</b> if <b>she married on the basis of</b> the testimony of <b>two witnesses, she does not</b> have to <b>leave</b> him. <b>They laughed at him in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>The man,</b> the first husband, <b>has come and stands</b> before us, <b>and</b> yet <b>you say she does not</b> have to <b>leave</b> her second husband. The Gemara explains: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a situation <b>when we do not know</b> the man who comes before us claiming to be the first husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>If we do not know him,</b> even if she married <b>by one witness, why</b> should she <b>leave?</b> The testimony of the witness who says the husband is dead should be accepted. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for a case <b>when two</b> others <b>came and said: We were with him from when he left until now, and it is you who do not recognize him,</b> as his appearance has changed over the course of time. This is <b>as it is written: “And Joseph recognized his brothers but they did not recognize him”</b> (Genesis 42:8), <b>and Rav Ḥisda said</b> that this verse <b>teaches that</b> Joseph <b>left</b> his brothers <b>without a full beard, and he came with a full beard,</b> which is why they failed to recognize him. This shows that one’s appearance can change so much over time that even his own family members are unable to identify him.
The Gemara asks: Even in this case, <b>ultimately they are two</b> against <b>two.</b> Initially, two witnesses testified that the man was dead, and now another pair arrives saying he is alive. Why should the testimony of the witnesses who say he is dead be accepted, allowing her to remain with the second husband, while other witnesses claim he is still alive?

Daf 88b

<b>And</b> as this is an uncertain case, <b>one who has intercourse with her stands</b> obligated to bring <b>an uncertain guilt-</b>offering. Since before she remarried some witnesses say she is a married woman while others claim she is now a widow, her relations with her second husband involve a possible prohibition that entails <i>karet</i>, and whoever mistakenly performs an action of this kind is liable to bring an uncertain guilt-offering. If so, this second husband must certainly divorce her. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> that woman <b>married one of her witnesses,</b> who testified that her husband had died. Since the witness himself has no doubt as to the truth, he is not liable to bring an uncertain guilt-offering.
The Gemara asks: Even so, <b>she herself stands</b> obligated to bring <b>a uncertain guilt-</b>offering, as she has no personal knowledge of the matter and relied on the witness. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where she says: It is clear to me.</b> For whatever reason, she is certain that this is not her husband and that he is dead, and therefore she too is not liable to bring an uncertain guilt-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this? That is, if Rav is referring only to this particular case, he has not taught anything new, as <b>even Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei, stated</b> his opinion <b>only</b> with regard to a case <b>where witnesses came and afterward</b> she <b>married, but</b> in the case where she <b>married and afterward witnesses came, he did not state</b> his <i>halakha</i> with regard to this case.
To what ruling is the Gemara referring? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say</b> that the husband is <b>dead and two say</b> he is <b>not dead,</b> or if <b>two say</b> that this woman <b>was divorced and two say</b> she <b>was not divorced, this</b> woman <b>may not marry; and if she married</b> regardless, she need <b>not leave</b> her new husband, as there is no uncontroverted testimony that she is forbidden to him. <b>Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei, said:</b> She must <b>leave</b> him. <b>Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> further <b>said: When</b> do <b>I say</b> she must <b>leave</b> him? <b>When the witnesses</b> who contradicted the first pair by claiming she is still married <b>came and afterward she married,</b> despite their testimony. <b>However,</b> if <b>she married and afterward</b> the second pair of <b>witnesses came, this</b> woman need <b>not leave</b> her second husband.
The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav spoke too,</b> he was referring to a case <b>when</b> the second pair of <b>witnesses came</b> and testified that this is her husband, <b>and afterward she married.</b> Rav claims that even in that case she need not leave her second husband. His ruling serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> in favor of that of the first <i>tanna</i>. <b>And some say</b> that Rav’s teaching should be understood as follows: <b>The reason is that she married and afterward witnesses came; however,</b> if <b>witnesses came and afterward she married,</b> she must <b>leave</b> him. <b>According to whose</b> opinion is this ruling of Rav? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> a priest <b>does not want</b> to observe the strictures against disqualified women, that the court <b>forces him [<i>dafno</i>]</b> by flogging him, and it sanctifies him despite his wishes? <b>The verse states,</b> at the end of the chapter that deals with the prohibitions of the priesthood: <b>“And you shall sanctify him</b>…he shall be sacred for you” (Leviticus 21:8), which indicates that this is performed even <b>against his will.</b>
Rava analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What are the circumstances?</b> Assuming that this is referring to a priest who married a woman whose status as a divorced woman or a <i>zona</i> is uncertain, <b>if we say that she did not marry one of her witnesses and did not say: It is clear to me,</b> that the opposing witnesses were speaking the truth, <b>need this be said</b> that the court <b>forces him?</b> Since both of them are clearly in violation of a transgression, it is obvious that they must be separated. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>when she married one of her witnesses and she says: It is clear to me, and</b> even so the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching</b> that the court <b>forces him? Apparently,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>they remove her from him,</b> which contradicts Rav’s opinion that one who married based on the testimony of two witnesses need not leave her second husband.
The Gemara answers: <b>A prohibition</b> with regard <b>to the priesthood is different,</b> as uncertainties with regard to priests are treated stringently, as though they were definite. <b>And if you wish, say: What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: The court <b>forces him?</b> It means that it <b>forces him by witnesses.</b> In other words, only if another pair of witnesses comes and clarifies the matter does the court prevent the marriage <i>ab initio</i>. However, if she has already married she need not leave her husband. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is referring to a situation <b>when witnesses came and afterward she married, and</b> this <i>baraita</i>, which claims that the court forces him to divorce her in that case, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: She need <b>not leave</b> him, <b>that Rav said?</b> It means that she need <b>not leave her</b> state of <b>being permitted</b> to her <b>first</b> husband. Since she married according to <i>halakha</i>, on the basis of witness testimony, she is considered to have acted under duress. Like any other woman not married to a priest who was unfaithful against her will, she may return to her first husband upon his return.
The Gemara asks: If that is what he meant, <b>Rav</b> already <b>said it once. As we learned</b> in the mishna: If she <b>married without</b> the <b>consent</b> of the court, but rather by witnesses’ testimony, it is <b>permitted</b> for <b>her to return to him. And Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: That is</b> the <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> Evidently, Rav already ruled that she does not forfeit her original permitted status. The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> ruling <b>was stated by inference from the other.</b> In other words, Rav did not state both <i>halakhot</i> explicitly, but only one of them, from which his other statement was inferred.
<b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> that she must leave her second husband <b>only if she does not contradict</b> the witness who claims her first husband is alive. <b>However,</b> if <b>she contradicts him,</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her second husband. The Gemara inquires: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here? <b>If we say</b> we are dealing <b>with two</b> witnesses who testified that her husband is still alive, even <b>if she contradicts him, what of it?</b> The testimony of the two witnesses is fully accepted. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring <b>to one</b> witness, from which it may be inferred that <b>the reason</b> that she need not leave her second husband <b>is that she contradicts him,</b> which indicates that <b>if she</b> remains <b>silent</b> and does not contradict his testimony, she must <b>leave</b> him.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Ulla say</b> that <b>wherever</b> you find <b>that the Torah relies on one witness, this is</b> a full testimony equal to that of <b>two</b> witnesses, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness <b>has no</b> bearing <b>in a place where</b> it is contradicted by <b>two</b> witnesses? If so, there is no difference between one witness and two witnesses in this case. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case where the pair who said he was alive were <b>disqualified</b> from giving <b>testimony, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: Wherever</b> you find that <b>the Torah relies on one witness, follow the majority of opinions.</b> If the testimony is valid, the account of two witnesses is the same as one hundred, as no greater credence is granted to the larger number. However, when the testimony is invalid the majority opinion is accepted. <b>And</b> in these cases <b>they established</b> the testimony of <b>two women against one man like</b> the testimony of <b>two men against one man,</b> whose claim is not considered equivalent to two. In this case, if the wife also contradicts their account she joins the single witness, and therefore the testimony of the disqualified witnesses is not accepted.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>anywhere that one valid witness came initially</b> and testified that the husband was dead, <b>even one hundred women</b> claiming that he is alive <b>are considered like one</b> witness, and their contrary account is not accepted. And <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> In a case <b>where a woman came</b> and testified <b>initially.</b>
<b>And</b> you must accordingly <b>amend</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Neḥemya</b> so that it reads <b>as follows: Rabbi Neḥemya says: Wherever</b> you find that <b>the Torah relies on one witness, follow the majority of opinions, and they established two women against one woman like two men against one man. However,</b> in a case involving <b>two women against one man</b> who is a valid witness, this <b>is like half against half,</b> i.e., they are equal. With regard to Shmuel’s statement, if the wife herself remains silent, the testimony of the first woman that the husband is dead has been negated, as her account was contradicted by two women. But if the claim of the wife is joined to that of the first woman she need not leave her second husband.
§ The mishna teaches that if she remarried as the result of an error, then when her first husband returns <b>she requires a bill of divorce from this one and from that one.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, from the first</b> husband <b>she requires a bill of divorce,</b> as she is his actual wife. <b>But from the second, why</b> does she need a bill of divorce? Surely their relationship <b>is merely licentious.</b> Since her first husband was alive at the time, her marriage to the second is entirely invalid, as one cannot betroth a married woman. A woman does not require a bill of divorce for engaging in sexual relations.
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> those who are unaware of the entire story <b>say</b> that <b>this</b> first husband <b>divorced</b> her <b>and</b> afterward <b>this</b> second man <b>married</b> her. <b>And</b> if she subsequently leaves him without a bill of divorce, they will claim that we <b>find a married woman leaving</b> her husband <b>without a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna (92a), <b>that teaches</b> that if <b>they said to her: Your husband is dead, and she became betrothed</b> to another, <b>and afterward her husband came,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for her <b>to return to</b> her first husband. <b>There too, let us say</b> that people might think that <b>this one divorced</b> her <b>and that one betrothed</b> her, <b>and</b> we <b>find a married woman leaving</b> her husband, i.e., her second husband, <b>without a bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> even if she was merely betrothed she <b>requires a bill of divorce</b> from the second man before she can return to her first husband. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> people will say that we <b>find this one remarrying his divorcée after she was betrothed</b> to another. The Gemara answers: In this regard the <i>tanna</i> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Keifar, who stated</b> a principle with regard to a divorcée who formed a relationship with another man, that if she came <b>from marriage</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to return to her first husband, but if she came <b>from betrothal</b> it is <b>permitted.</b> Consequently, even if people do claim as above, there is no cause for concern.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the mishna (92a) <b>teaches: Even though</b>

Daf 89a

the <b>last one gave her a bill of divorce, he has not disqualified her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood,</b> as she is not considered a divorcée at all, this proves <b>by inference that she does not require a bill of divorce</b> from him. The reason is <b>that if she requires a bill of divorce,</b> even if it is only due to uncertainty, <b>why</b> has he <b>not disqualified her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood?</b> A bill of divorce of any validity would bar her from marrying a priest. <b>Rather,</b> a bill of divorce given by a man to a woman who is not his wife is clearly of no account, and the reason for the ruling in <b>the latter clause,</b> with regard to betrothal, is that people will <b>say</b> there was no need for a bill of divorce because <b>it was a mistaken betrothal.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, in <b>the first clause too,</b> they will <b>say it was a mistaken marriage.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages penalized her</b> by requiring her to receive a bill of divorce, lest people say she divorced this man and went back and married the first one. The Gemara counters: If so, in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>let us also penalize her.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The first clause</b> involves a situation <b>where she violated a prohibition</b> through her intercourse, and therefore the Sages <b>penalized her.</b> Conversely, in <b>the latter clause, when she did not violate a prohibition,</b> as she simply became betrothed, <b>the Sages did not penalize her.</b>
§ The mishna taught that this woman <b>does not have,</b> i.e., she is not entitled to, the payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages instituted a marriage contract</b> in general, <b>for</b> an ordinary woman? <b>So that she will not be demeaned in his eyes such that</b> he will easily <b>divorce her.</b> The necessity to find money for her marriage contract will prevent a hasty decision to divorce her. However, in the case of <b>this</b> woman, on the contrary, the Sages actually prefer that <b>she will be demeaned in his eyes such that</b> he will easily <b>divorce her,</b> as the marriage was forbidden and she may not remain with him. Consequently, they eliminated her marriage contract to encourage him to divorce her.
§ The mishna further states that <b>she does not have</b> claim to <b>profits, or sustenance, or worn clothes.</b> Why not? Because the <b>stipulations in the marriage contract,</b> i.e., all the rights of a wife stemming from the stipulations that are part of a marriage contract, <b>are considered like</b> the <b>marriage contract</b> itself. Since she has no marriage contract, she does not have the stipulations in a marriage contract either.
§ The mishna also teaches that if <b>she took</b> any of the above <b>from this</b> man <b>or from that</b> one she must return anything she took. The Gemara comments: This <b>is obvious.</b> Since she is not entitled to these articles, of course she must give them back. The Gemara explains: It is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since she has</b> already <b>taken hold</b> of them <b>we do not remove</b> them <b>from her</b> possession, as this is merely a penalty and she obtained nothing that did not legally belong to her. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the court requires her to return even these items.
§ The mishna taught that <b>the child</b> of either of the men is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> To clarify this issue, the Gemara cites a different discussion. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Terumot</i> 2:2): <b>One may not separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from ritually impure</b> produce in order <b>to</b> exempt <b>ritually pure</b> food, <b>and if he separated</b> <i>teruma</i> from impure food <b>unwittingly, his <i>teruma</i> is</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> If he acted <b>intentionally, he has done nothing,</b> that is, his action is of no effect. The Sages debated: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the expression: <b>He has done nothing? Rav Ḥisda said: He has done nothing at all,</b> meaning <b>that even that <i>griva</i></b> of produce he set aside as <i>teruma</i> <b>returns to</b> its former <b>untithed</b> state, as his entire act is completely disregarded.
<b>Rav Natan, son of Rabbi Oshaya, said: He has done nothing</b> with regard to <b>preparing the remaining</b> produce from which he separated <i>teruma</i>, <b>but</b> the fruit he separated <b>is</b> itself <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Although the portion he set aside is sanctified as <i>teruma</i>, this does not exempt him from separating more <i>teruma</i> from ritually pure produce. The Gemara clarifies the two opinions: <b>Rav Ḥisda did not say</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Natan, son of Rabbi Oshaya, as, if you say it is <i>teruma</i>, on occasion</b> he <b>will be negligent and not separate</b> anything more, assuming that if the portion he set aside has the status of <i>teruma</i> he must certainly have done everything required.
The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 3:1): With regard to <b>one who separates</b> <i>teruma</i> from <b>a serpent melon [<i>kishut</i>] and it was discovered</b> to be <b>bitter,</b> or from <b>a watermelon and it was discovered</b> to be <b>spoiled,</b> it is <b><i>teruma</i>, and</b> yet he must <b>go back and separate</b> <i>teruma</i> from another serpent melon or watermelon. No concern is expressed in this mishna that one might neglect to set aside <i>teruma</i> a second time. The Gemara answers: <b>Are you raising a contradiction</b> between the case of <b>an unwitting</b> sinner and that <b>of an intentional</b> sinner? There is a difference between them, as one who was <b>unwitting did not commit a transgression</b> and consequently does not deserve to be penalized, whereas one who was <b>an intentional</b> sinner <b>did commit a transgression.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between this ruling involving <b>an unwitting</b> sinner and another <i>halakha</i> <b>of an unwitting</b> sinner: <b>Here, it is taught</b> that if the one who separated ritually impure produce instead of ritually pure produce was <b>unwitting, his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>,</b> which indicates that he does not have to separate <i>teruma</i> again. However, <b>there,</b> with regard to rotten fruit, <b>it is taught</b> that it is <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> yet he must <b>separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>again.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> his was <b>an unwitting</b> act that is <b>close to an intentional</b> one, <b>as he should have tasted it</b> first to ensure that he was separating quality fruit. His failure to do so renders him virtually a willful sinner, and therefore the Sages penalized him by obligating him to set aside <i>teruma</i> again. In the case of impure <i>teruma</i>, in contrast, he may not have been able to investigate the matter when he separated the portion.
<b>And</b> the Gemara also <b>raises a contradiction</b> between one case involving <b>an intentional</b> sinner and another case <b>of an intentional</b> sinner. <b>Here, it</b> is <b>taught</b> that in the case of <b>an intentional</b> sinner who separates <i>teruma</i>, <b>he has done nothing. There, we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 5:10), that with regard to <b>one who separates</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> produce growing in a vessel <b>that is not perforated, for</b> produce that grew in <b>a perforated</b> vessel, which is considered connected to the ground, it is <b><i>teruma</i>, but he must go back and separate</b> <i>teruma</i> a second time. This ruling is based on the principle that anything that grew in a pot without a hole does not require separation of <i>teruma</i> by Torah law. In this case, the fact that he must again set aside <i>teruma</i> does not mean that the portion he separated is not consecrated at all.
The Gemara answers: <b>In</b> a case involving <b>two vessels he will listen.</b> Since the difference between the two vessels is clear to the eye, if the owner is told he must separate <i>teruma</i> again, it can be assumed that he will comply. In contrast, <b>in</b> the case of <b>one vessel he will not listen,</b> as ritually impure and pure produce look the same to him. Consequently, if he is informed that he must set aside <i>teruma</i> a second time despite the fact that the produce he already set aside has the status of <i>teruma</i>, he will take no notice.
The Gemara asks another question: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Natan, son of Rabbi Oshaya, who said</b> that <b>he has done nothing</b> with regard to <b>preparing the remaining</b> produce <b>but it is</b> nevertheless <b><i>teruma</i>,</b>

Daf 89b

in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 5:10): If one separates <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> that which grew in <b>a perforated</b> pot <b>for that which is</b> from <b>a non-perforated</b> pot, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>, but it may not be eaten until he removes</b> on behalf <b>of</b> that portion itself <b><i>teruma</i> and tithe from another place?</b> In other words, the portion he separated as <i>teruma</i> is not entirely consecrated, as it too is considered untithed produce in the sense that <i>teruma</i> must be separated for it. In contrast, one who sets aside impure <i>teruma</i> does not have to separate <i>teruma</i> from that portion itself.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here,</b> with regard to ritually impure <i>teruma</i>, <b>it is different, as by Torah</b> law <b>it is</b> in fact <b>full-fledged <i>teruma</i>,</b> but the Sages penalized him by making him separate <i>teruma</i> again. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elai, as Rabbi Elai said: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to one who separates <i>teruma</i> from poor-</b>quality produce <b>for superior</b>-quality produce <b>that his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>? As it is written</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>: <b>“And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, seeing that you have set apart from it its best”</b> (Numbers 18:32). This verse states that if one separated <i>teruma</i> from inferior-quality produce he has committed a sin, which shows that his action is effective, as Rabbi Elai proceeds to explain.
Rabbi Elai elaborates: <b>And if</b> this inferior portion is <b>not sanctified</b> as <i>teruma</i> at all, <b>why</b> is there <b>a bearing of sin?</b> If the produce does not have the status of <i>teruma</i> he has not done anything, which means that his action cannot be considered a transgression. <b>From here</b> we learn <b>with regard to one who separated from the bad for the good that his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i></b> after the fact. Similarly, the <i>teruma</i> of one who separates ritually impure food for pure food is valid <i>teruma</i> by Torah law.
After clarifying the opinions themselves, the Gemara analyzes the case in greater detail. <b>Rabba said to Rav Ḥisda: According to your</b> opinion, <b>that you said he has done nothing at all,</b> meaning <b>that even that <i>se’a</i></b> he set aside <b>returns to</b> its former <b>untithed</b> state, <b>what is the reason</b> for this? It is a rabbinic <b>decree,</b> as <b>perhaps he will be negligent and will not separate</b> <i>teruma</i> a second time. However, <b>is there anything that by Torah</b> law <b>is <i>teruma</i>,</b> as stated by Rabbi Elai, <b>and</b> yet <b>due to</b> the concern: <b>Perhaps he will be negligent, the Sages removed</b> its status as sacred and gave <b>to</b> it the status of <b>non-sacred</b> food? <b>And can the court stipulate</b> and enact a decree <b>to uproot something</b> that applies <b>by Torah</b> law?
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rabba: <b>And you, do you not hold</b> that the Sages have the power to do so? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>the child is a <i>mamzer</i> from this one and from that one? Granted,</b> the child <b>from the second</b> man is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> as he was born to a married woman from a man who was not her husband. <b>However,</b> with regard to the child <b>from the first</b> husband, <b>why</b> is he a <i>mamzer</i>? After all, <b>she is his wife, and</b> by Torah law their son <b>is a full-fledged Jew. And</b> the Sages’ declaration that he is a <i>mamzer</i> cannot be seen as a mere stringency, as <b>they</b> thereby <b>permit him to a <i>mamzeret</i>.</b> This shows that a rabbinical decree can uproot a Torah prohibition.
Rabba <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda that <b>Shmuel said as follows:</b> It is <b>forbidden</b> for the child of the first husband <b>to</b> marry <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>. And similarly, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he</b> said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the child is <b>forbidden to a <i>mamzeret</i>. And</b> if so, <b>why does</b> the mishna <b>call him a <i>mamzer</i>?</b> This is <b>to</b> teach us that the Sages are stringent and render it <b>prohibited</b> for <b>him to</b> marry a regular <b>Jewish woman.</b> With regard to the issue at hand, as he may not marry a <i>mamzeret</i>, the Sages did not in fact uproot a mitzva that applies by Torah law.
<b>Rav Ḥisda sent</b> a proof <b>to Rabba, in the hand</b> of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Huna: And can the court not stipulate to uproot something prohibited by Torah</b> law? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From when does a man inherit</b> from <b>his minor wife,</b> who was married off by her mother or brother, as enacted by the Sages, a marriage that is not valid by Torah law? <b>Beit Shammai say: From when she stands at her</b> fully developed <b>height,</b> i.e., when she grows up and reaches the age of maturity. <b>And Beit Hillel say: From when she enters the wedding canopy. Rabbi Eliezer says: From when she has sexual relations.</b> As soon as she is considered his wife, all the <i>halakhot</i> of a wife apply to her. <b>And he inherits</b> from <b>her and becomes impure for her</b> if she dies, even if he is a priest, <b>and she eats <i>teruma</i> on his account</b> if he is a priest.
The Gemara first clarifies various details of this <i>baraita</i>. <b>Beit Shammai say: From when she stands at her height.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise at this statement: Is this the case <b>even though she has not</b> yet <b>entered the wedding canopy?</b> Betrothal alone, without the marriage canopy, is not enough to enable a man to inherit from an adult woman, let alone a minor. The Gemara answers: You must <b>say</b> that Beit Shammai meant <b>from when she stands at her</b> fully developed <b>height and enters the wedding canopy. And Beit Shammai said to Beit Hillel as follows: That which you said,</b> that he inherits her <b>from when she enters the wedding canopy,</b> is not enough. Rather, <b>if she stands at her</b> fully developed <b>height,</b> the <b>wedding canopy is effective for</b> bringing about <b>her</b> marriage, <b>and if not,</b> the <b>wedding canopy is not effective for</b> bringing about <b>her</b> marriage.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: From when she has sexual relations.</b> The Gemara again expresses surprise: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Eliezer say</b> that <b>the actions of a minor girl are nothing,</b> which indicates that marriage and intercourse with her are not considered an act of acquisition. Rather, we must <b>say</b> that he meant <b>from when she matures and has sexual relations.</b>
The Gemara returns to the issue at hand, whether the court can stipulate to uproot something prohibited by Torah law. <b>In any event</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching</b> that <b>he inherits</b> from <b>her. But here</b> is a case <b>where by Torah</b> law <b>her father,</b> i.e., his relatives, as he is dead, <b>inherits</b> from <b>her,</b> as a minor orphan cannot marry by Torah law, <b>and</b> yet <b>by rabbinic</b> law the <b>husband inherits</b> from <b>her.</b> This shows that the Sages can uproot a Torah mitzva. The Gemara answers: This is no proof, as in monetary matters <b>property declared ownerless by the court is ownerless,</b> and therefore the court can allocate her inheritance as they see fit.
<b>As Rabbi Yitzḥak said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that property declared ownerless by the court is ownerless? As it is stated: “And whoever does not come within three days, according to the council of the princes and the Elders, all his property should be forfeited, and himself separated from the congregation of the captivity”</b> (Ezra 10:8). This verse indicates that the court can confiscate anyone’s possessions.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that the proof that the court can declare property ownerless is <b>from here: “These are the inheritances that Elazar the priest, and Joshua, son of Nun, and the heads of the fathers’ houses of the tribes of the children of Israel distributed for inheritance”</b> (Joshua 19:51). <b>What do heads have to do with fathers?</b> The expression “the heads of the fathers’ houses of the tribes” is unusual and vague. <b>Rather,</b> this comes <b>to tell you: Just as fathers bequeath to their sons anything they want</b> to, <b>so too,</b> the <b>heads,</b> i.e., the leaders and judges of the people, <b>bequeath to the people anything they want</b> to. This shows that the leaders can take property from one individual and give it to another.
It was stated that the husband of a minor <b>becomes impure for her,</b> even if he is a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>But here</b> is a case <b>where by Torah</b> law <b>her father,</b> not the man she married, is obligated to <b>become impure for her,</b> as the latter is not his wife by Torah law, <b>and</b> yet <b>by rabbinic</b> law her <b>husband defiles himself for her.</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>because she is</b> considered like <b>a corpse with no one to bury it [<i>met mitzva</i>],</b> for which even a priest must become impure. Once she is married, her relatives from her father’s family no longer care for her welfare, which means her husband is the only one who is entrusted with her burial.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is she</b> in fact <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which</b> corpse <b>is a <i>met mitzva</i>? Any</b> corpse <b>that does not have</b> anyone <b>to bury it.</b> If it was in a place where if <b>one calls and others</b> would <b>answer him, this is not a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b> In contrast, this girl does have relatives who can bury her, if necessary. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too, since</b> the members of her father’s family <b>do not inherit</b> from <b>her,</b> she would <b>call and they</b> would <b>not answer her,</b> as they have no desire to go to any trouble for her. Since her husband inherits from her, it is his duty to tend to her burial, and he must therefore become impure for her, as she has the status of a <i>met mitzva</i>.

Daf 90a

It was further taught: <b>And she eats <i>teruma</i> on his account.</b> The Gemara explains: This is referring to <b><i>teruma</i></b> that applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law, not by Torah law. The Gemara attempts to offer a proof for this claim. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If a non-priest <b>ate ritually impure <i>teruma</i></b> of a priest, he must <b>pay</b> him with <b>ritually pure, non-sacred</b> produce. In a case where he <b>paid</b> with <b>impure, non-sacred</b> food, <b>Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir</b> that if he did so <b>unwittingly, his payment is</b> considered <b>payment,</b> but if he acted <b>intentionally, his payment is not payment</b> at all. <b>And the Rabbis say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> one <b>his payment is</b> a valid <b>payment,</b> and the food has the sanctity of <i>teruma</i>, although it is ritually impure, <b>and</b> he must also <b>go back and pay</b> him again with <b>pure, non-sacred</b> food.
<b>And we discussed</b> this <i>baraita</i> with regard to the following question: Why is it that according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, when the non-priest pays the priest with ritually impure, ordinary food <b>intentionally, his payment</b> is <b>not</b> considered <b>payment?</b> On the contrary, the non-priest <b>should be blessed, as he ate something of his that is not fit for him</b> even <b>during</b> the priest’s <b>days of impurity,</b> as impure <i>teruma</i> must be burned, <b>and he pays</b> him with impure, ordinary food, which is <b>something that is fit for him during his days of impurity.</b> Admittedly, once he gives it to him, the produce becomes impure <i>teruma</i>, but at the time of his payment the food was available to be eaten.
<b>And Rava said, and some say</b> this statement <b>unattributed</b> to any particular Sage: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and this is</b> what it is <b>teaching:</b> If he <b>ate ritually impure <i>teruma</i>, he pays</b> with <b>anything,</b> even impure, non-sacred produce. If he <b>ate pure <i>teruma</i> he pays</b> with <b>pure, non-sacred</b> food, and if he <b>paid</b> with <b>impure, non-sacred</b> produce, the Sages disagreed about this case: <b>Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> If done <b>unwittingly, his payment is payment;</b> if <b>intentionally, his payment is not payment. And the Rabbis say: Whether unwittingly or intentionally, his payment is payment, and</b> he must <b>go back and pay</b> with <b>pure, non-sacred</b> produce.
The Gemara returns to the issue at hand, whether the court can stipulate to uproot something prohibited by Torah law. <b>And here</b> it is a case <b>where by Torah</b> law the produce he gave him <b>is proper payment,</b> and is fully owned by the priest, to the extent <b>that if a priest betroths a woman with them,</b> the <b>betrothal with her is valid. And</b> yet <b>the Sages said,</b> i.e., it is a rabbinic law, according to Sumakhos in the name of Rabbi Meir, that <b>his payment is not payment. And</b> this means that <b>we permit a married woman to all</b> men, as she is betrothed by Torah law but in practice she is treated as an unmarried woman. Evidently, a rabbinical prohibition overrides a betrothal that is effective by Torah law.
The Gemara answers: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>His payment is not payment, that Rabbi Meir said?</b> It means <b>that he is required to go back and pay</b> with <b>ritually pure, non-sacred</b> produce. However, the food he initially gave is also consecrated. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> the opinion of <b>Sumakhos is</b> the same as that of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> is whether <b>they decreed</b> against <b>an unwitting</b> sinner <b>due to an intentional</b> sinner. According to Sumakhos, if he unwittingly paid with impure, non-sacred produce his payment is valid and the Sages did not penalize him with a second payment, whereas the Rabbis maintain that even if his sin was accidental he must repay the priest, as the Sages issue the decree in a case of a mistaken transgression due to the case of one who sinned intentionally.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof. With regard to <b>blood that became ritually impure, and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it</b> on the altar, the following distinction applies: If he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the offering <b>is accepted.</b> If he sprinkled the blood <b>intentionally,</b> the offering <b>is not accepted.</b>
<b>And here</b> it is a case <b>where by Torah</b> law the blood <b>effects acceptance, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>For what does the</b> High Priest’s <b>frontplate effect acceptance? For blood, for meat, and for fat that became impure, whether unwittingly or intentionally, whether by unavoidable accident or willingly, whether</b> in the case <b>of an individual</b> offering <b>or</b> an offering <b>of the community. And the Sages said</b> that if a priest sprinkled impure blood intentionally the frontplate <b>does not effect acceptance,</b> and its owner must bring another offering. The Gemara infers: Since he is not obligated to bring this extra offering by Torah law, in essence he <b>subsequently brings in a non-sacred</b> animal <b>to</b> the Temple <b>courtyard.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said</b> that there is no proof from here, as <b>what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>Does not effect acceptance, that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>said?</b> It means that it does not effect acceptance <b>in</b> the sense that it <b>permits</b> the meat of the offering <b>to be eaten. However, the owners</b> themselves <b>attain atonement through it,</b> and they do not have to bring another offering.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Ultimately,</b> the Torah mitzva of <b>eating</b> the <b>meat</b> of this offering <b>is uprooted, and it is written: “And they shall eat those things with which atonement was made”</b> (Exodus 29:33). This verse <b>teaches that the priests eat</b> the offering <b>and</b> the <b>owner</b> thereby <b>gains atonement. He said to him:</b> The case of <b>sit and refrain from action [<i>shev ve’al ta’aseh</i>] is different.</b> In other words, the Sages can uproot a Torah mitzva by instructing one to sit and <b>refrain from action,</b> i.e., to remain passive and do nothing. They cannot, however, uproot a mitzva by telling him to perform an action.

Daf 90b

Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rabba: <b>I wanted to raise a difficulty against you</b> from the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an uncircumcised man.</b> The Sages decreed that one who converts on the eve of Passover may not partake of the Paschal lamb, due to his ritual impurity. According to Beit Hillel, one who separates from the foreskin by being circumcised is ritually impure like one who separates from the grave (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 92a). This is the <i>halakha</i> despite the fact that by Torah law he is obligated to bring the offering. Rav Ḥisda continued: And I also thought of asking from the case of <b>sprinkling</b> the waters of a purification offering for one who became ritually impure through contact with a corpse, as the Sages rendered it prohibited for one who is impure to receive the sprinkling on the eve of Passover that occurred on Shabbat, although this prevents him from partaking of the Paschal lamb.
<b>And</b> I was likewise going to raise a question from the case of a circumcision <b>knife,</b> which the Sages decreed may not be carried on Shabbat, despite the fact that this entails the neglect of a Torah mitzva. <b>And</b> I also wanted to raise a question from the case of a linen <b>cloak, on</b> which the Sages did not allow one to place <b>ritual fringes</b> made of wool. This is a decree that was issued lest he do the same with a garment worn only at night, which is exempt from fringes, and therefore this would be a mixture of wool and linen that is forbidden, although this means that he is unable to fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes.
<b>And</b> likewise I wanted to mention a difficulty from the case of <b>the lambs sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i>.</b> When the festival of <i>Shavuot</i> occurs on Shabbat, the Sages rendered it prohibited to sprinkle the blood of its sacrificial lambs if the offerings had not been slaughtered with the proper intention, despite the fact that the sprinkling itself is not prohibited by Torah law. <b>And</b> similarly, there is a difficulty with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of the <b><i>shofar</i>,</b> which is sounded on Rosh HaShana, and yet the Sages rendered it prohibited for it to be blown on Shabbat, lest one carry it four cubits in the public domain.
<b>And</b> finally I wished to raise a difficulty from the case of <b>a <i>lulav</i>,</b> which may not be carried on the first day of <i>Sukkot</i> that occurred on Shabbat, for the same reason the Sages rendered it prohibited to sound the <i>shofar</i> on Rosh HaShana that occurs on Shabbat. However, <b>now that you have resolved for us</b> that an action defined as a case of: <b>Sit and refrain from action, is not</b> considered <b>uprooting, all these are also</b> cases of <b>sit and refrain from action.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof. The verse states with regard to a true prophet: <b>“To him you shall listen”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:15). From here it is derived that <b>even</b> if the prophet <b>says to you: Transgress one of the mitzvot of the Torah, for example,</b> as in the case of <b>Elijah at Mount Carmel,</b> who brought an offering to God on that mountain during a period when it was forbidden on pain of <i>karet</i> to sacrifice offerings outside the Temple, with regard to <b>everything</b> that he permits <b>for</b> the requirement of the <b>hour,</b> you must <b>listen to him.</b> This indicates that a Torah mitzva can indeed be uprooted in an active manner.
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as it is written: “To him you shall listen,”</b> which means that it is a positive mitzva to obey a prophet, and a positive mitzva overrides a prohibition. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him derive from</b> this case a principle that the Sages have the same power as a prophet. The Gemara answers: <b>Safeguarding a matter is different.</b> Since Elijah acted with the aim of preventing the Jewish people from worshipping idols, it was temporarily permitted for him to override a mitzva, in order to strengthen Torah observance with regard to a particular matter in which the people are lax.
The Gemara suggests another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> The Sages rendered it prohibited for a man who has sent a bill of divorce to his wife to cancel it in the presence of a court without her knowledge after he has given the bill of divorce to his messenger but before she gets the document. The prohibition was instituted to prevent a situation where the messenger, who is unaware of the cancellation, gives her the bill of divorce and she marries another man under the mistaken impression that she is divorced. If he proceeded to <b>nullify it</b> regardless, it is <b>nullified;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He cannot nullify or add to its condition</b> in a case where the bill of divorce included a stipulation. For <b>if so,</b> i.e., if he has the ability to cancel the bill of divorce, <b>what good is the power of the court</b> in their decree that one may not do so?
The Gemara explains the proof from this source: <b>And here</b> it is a case <b>where by Torah</b> law, the <b>bill of divorce is nullified, and</b> yet <b>due to</b> the reason of: <b>What</b> good <b>is the power of the court,</b> his nullification is ineffective, which means that <b>we permit a married woman to all</b> men. The Gemara answers: The <i>halakhot</i> of marriage afford no proof, as with regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman, he <b>betroths on the authorization of the Sages, and</b> in this case <b>the Sages nullified the betrothal,</b> which they can do because their consent was required for the betrothal to be effective in the first place.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> This <b>works out well</b> in a case <b>when he betrothed with money,</b> as it can be explained that the Sages declared the money ownerless, thereby negating the betrothal. However, if <b>he betrothed by</b> means of <b>sexual relations, what can be said?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages equated his relations</b> with this woman with <b>licentious sexual intercourse.</b> Since in this situation as well the acquisition of betrothal is effective only by authorization of the Sages, they have the power to declare it invalid.
The Gemara cites yet another relevant source. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Ya’akov said: I have heard that</b> the reason why <b>the court may administer lashes and punish not by Torah</b> law, i.e., in response to actions for which one is not liable to receive punishment by Torah law, is <b>not</b> so as <b>to transgress matters of Torah, but to establish a safeguard for the Torah. And</b> an example of this is <b>an incident involving a certain person who rode on a horse on Shabbat in the days of the Greeks,</b> an act that is prohibited by rabbinic law, <b>and they brought him to the court and they stoned him</b> as a desecrator of Shabbat. They did so <b>not because he was deserving of this,</b> as riding a horse is not punishable by stoning by Torah law, <b>but because the hour required it,</b> as at that time Jews were negligent with regard to Shabbat observance.
<b>And again, an incident</b> occurred <b>involving a certain person who cohabited with his</b> own <b>wife under a fig tree</b> in plain view, <b>and they brought him to the court and flogged him, not because this</b> punishment was <b>fitting for him,</b> as it is not prohibited by the Torah for one to engage in relations with his wife wherever he chooses, <b>but because the hour required it,</b> to discourage others from engaging in licentious behavior. This shows that the court can uproot a Torah mitzva even by means of a positive action such as stoning. The Gemara answers: <b>Safeguarding a matter is different.</b> As stated above, the court may uproot a Torah mitzva so as to strengthen Torah observance in general, as was the case with the prophet Elijah.
§ The mishna taught: <b>Neither this one,</b> her first husband, <b>nor that one,</b> her second, <b>may become impure for her,</b> if they were priests. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains <b>that it is written: “But to his relative, who is close to him,</b> for her he may defile himself” (Leviticus 21:2), <b>and the Master said: “His relative” is his wife.</b>
<b>And it is</b> further <b>written: “He shall not defile himself, a husband among his people, to profane himself”</b> (Leviticus 21:4). It may be inferred from this apparent contradiction between the verses that <b>there is a husband who becomes impure</b> for his wife, <b>and there is a husband who does not become impure. How so? He becomes impure for his fit wife, but he does not become impure for his disqualified wife.</b> Since in the case of the mishna, the woman in question is disqualified with regard to both men, neither of them may become impure for her.
§ The mishna further taught: <b>Neither this one nor that one is entitled to her found</b> articles. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages said</b> that the <b>found</b> object <b>of a wife</b> belongs <b>to her husband? So that he should not harbor enmity</b> toward her, due to her refusal to give him the item she found. <b>Here,</b> however, <b>let him harbor much enmity</b> toward her, as the Sages want him to divorce her.
§ <b>And</b> the mishna also taught that neither man is entitled <b>to her earnings.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages said</b> that a wife’s <b>earnings</b> belong to her husband? <b>Because she eats</b> his <b>food.</b> In this case <b>here, since she does not have</b> rights to his <b>food, her earnings are not his</b> either.
§ <b>And</b> the mishna further taught that they <b>may not nullify her vows.</b> The Gemara similarly explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Merciful One states</b> that <b>a husband may nullify</b> his wife’s vows? <b>So that</b> she should <b>not</b> have to fulfill a vow that will cause her <b>to become repulsive</b> to him, such as refraining from washing or from applying cosmetics. <b>Here,</b> let <b>her be highly repulsive,</b> as the Sages want their relationship to end.
§ The mishna taught that if she <b>was an Israelite woman, she is disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b>

Daf 91a

The Gemara asks: It <b>is obvious</b> that she is disqualified, as she is a <i>zona</i>, a woman who has had sexual relations with a man forbidden to her by the Torah and with whom she cannot establish a marital bond. The Gemara answers: Since it <b>was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention the disqualification of <b>a daughter of a Levite from</b> partaking of <b>the tithe,</b> he added that an Israelite woman is likewise disqualified from marrying into the priesthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And a daughter of a Levite, is</b> she <b>disqualified from</b> partaking of <b>the tithe by licentiousness? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a Levite woman who was captured,</b> who may have had intercourse with one of her captors, <b>or</b> even in a case <b>where</b> a Levite woman definitely <b>engaged in licentious sexual relations, we</b> nevertheless <b>give her</b> first <b>tithe and she may eat</b> it? This indicates that an act of fornication does not disqualify a woman from partaking of the tithe. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> The disqualification is <b>a penalty</b> imposed by the Sages on this particular woman for not taking sufficient care, as she married without witness testimony as to her first husband’s death.
§ The mishna further taught that the <b>daughter of a priest</b> in this situation is disqualified <b>from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: This statement does not refer to <i>teruma</i> by Torah law, as it is obvious that she is prohibited to eat this produce. Rather, she is barred <b>even from <i>teruma</i></b> that applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law.
§ <b>And</b> the mishna also taught: <b>Neither</b> the <b>heirs of this</b> one nor the <b>heirs of that</b> one <b>inherit her marriage contract.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>A marriage contract, what is its purpose;</b> why mention the inheritance of a marriage contract after the mishna has just said that she is not entitled to the payment of a marriage contract at all? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is referring to <b>the marriage contract</b> payment <b>of the male sons.</b> One of the conditions of a marriage contract is that any male children born to this woman who inherit from their father will receive the sum of her marriage contract in addition to their share of the inheritance with their other paternal brothers.
The Gemara asks: This <b>is obvious.</b> Since she does not have a claim for the payment of her marriage contract, she is not entitled to the other conditions of a marriage contract either. The Gemara answers: It is necessary. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>with regard to</b> the woman <b>herself, who committed a prohibition, the Sages penalized her,</b> but <b>with regard to her offspring the Sages did not penalize them,</b> as they did nothing wrong, the <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the entire marriage contract is canceled, along with all its conditions.
§ The mishna further taught that <b>the brothers of this</b> one <b>and the brothers of that</b> one all <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and they do not consummate levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>The brother of the first one performs <i>ḥalitza</i> by Torah</b> law, as that woman is legally the wife of the first husband and therefore requires <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>But he does not consummate levirate marriage by rabbinic</b> law, as the Sages penalized her and prohibited her from returning to the first husband. Conversely, <b>the brother of the second one performs <i>ḥalitza</i> by rabbinic</b> law, so that people do not say that a childless woman can leave her <i>yavam</i> without <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>But he does not consummate levirate marriage, neither by Torah</b> law <b>nor by rabbinic</b> law, as her marriage to the second man was an error.
§ The mishna taught: <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that the obligation of <b>her marriage contract is upon the property of her</b> first <b>husband. Rav Huna said: The last</b> Sages in the mishna, Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, <b>concede to the first</b> ones, and merely add to their statement. However, <b>the first</b> ones <b>do not concede to the last</b> Sages. In other words, the second set of Sages extend the rulings of the first Sages beyond the cases to which they specifically referred.
The Gemara clarifies this statement: <b>Rabbi Shimon concedes to Rabbi Elazar.</b> How so? <b>For if</b> with regard to <b>sexual relations, which is the main prohibition,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>did not penalize</b> her, as he claims that the intercourse of the <i>yavam</i>, her first husband’s brother, acquires her and exempts her rival wife, <b>all the more so</b> her first husband should be entitled to <b>her found</b> objects <b>and her earnings, which</b> are merely <b>money. And</b> yet <b>Rabbi Elazar does not concede to Rabbi Shimon,</b> as he claims that in the case of <b>her found</b> objects <b>and her earnings, which</b> are only <b>money,</b> the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>sexual intercourse, which is a prohibition,</b> they did <b>penalize</b> her.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Elazar <b>both concede to Rabbi Yosei</b> with regard to a marriage contract.
