If in the case of <b>these</b> matters discussed above, <b>which</b> are relevant <b>when she is living under</b> her husband’s authority and is treated as a married woman, the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her, but allowed him to retain her found articles and earnings as though she were a full-fledged wife, <b>all the more so</b> they did not make her forfeit the <b>marriage contract, which</b> is designed <b>for</b> her <b>to take and</b> then <b>leave</b> the marriage. <b>And</b> by contrast, <b>Rabbi Yosei does not concede to them.</b> He maintains that in the case of <b>a marriage contract, which</b> is <b>for</b> her <b>to take and leave,</b> the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>these</b> other conditions, which take effect <b>when she is</b> still <b>living under his</b> authority, they did <b>penalize</b> her.
In contrast to Rav Huna, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The first</b> Sages <b>concede to the last ones,</b> but <b>the last ones do not concede to the first</b> Sages. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, the statements of the first Sages are more inclusive, whereas the second Sages restrict and limit the previous rulings. How so? <b>Rabbi Yosei concedes to Rabbi Elazar,</b> as he reasons as follows: If with regard to <b>a marriage contract, which</b> is given <b>from him to her,</b> the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her, as Rabbi Yosei maintains that since she did not sin willfully she is entitled to her marriage contract, <b>all the more so</b> they did not enforce a penalty with regard to <b>her found</b> objects <b>and her earnings, which</b> are <b>from her to him.</b> The Sages certainly did not cause him to forfeit something he has the right to claim from her.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar does not agree with</b> Rabbi Yosei with regard to a marriage contract. He claims that <b>it is</b> concerning <b>her found</b> objects <b>and her earnings, which</b> are <b>from her to him,</b> that the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her. <b>However,</b> as pertains to the <b>marriage contract, which</b> is <b>from him to her,</b> the Sages did <b>penalize</b> her, as a punishment.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Elazar <b>both concede to Rabbi Shimon,</b> for the following reason: <b>And if</b> with regard to <b>these,</b> i.e., her found objects and earnings or her marriage contract, <b>which</b> are given <b>in his lifetime,</b> the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her, then with regard to the <b>sexual relations</b> of the <i>yavam</i>, <b>which</b> occur <b>after the death</b> of the husband, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that they should not penalize her, and she should remain permitted? <b>And Rabbi Shimon does not concede to them,</b> as <b>it</b> is only in the case of <b>sexual relations, which</b> occur <b>after</b> his <b>death,</b> that the Sages did <b>not penalize</b> her. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>these</b> other matters, which apply <b>during</b> the husband’s <b>lifetime,</b> the Sages did <b>penalize</b> her by depriving her of them.
§ The mishna taught that if <b>she married without</b> the <b>consent</b> of the court she is permitted to return to her first husband. <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: This is the <i>halakha</i>. Rav Naḥman said to him: Why do you steal</b> in, i.e., why do you state your opinion in a sneaky manner? <b>If you maintain in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> then you should explicitly <b>say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as your <i>halakha</i> follows</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>And lest you say: If I</b> were to <b>say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> that would erroneously <b>indicate</b> that I agree with him <b>even with regard to the first</b> case, that of a married woman who married another on the basis of one witness. If so, you should <b>say</b> the following: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to the last</b> case. The Gemara comments: Indeed, the question of why Rav Huna did not state his ruling in this manner is <b>difficult.</b>
§ <b>Rav Sheshet said: I say</b> that <b>when Rav dozed and was falling asleep he said this <i>halakha</i>.</b> In other words, Rav did not examine the matter carefully, as this ruling is unnecessary. Rav Sheshet explains: <b>From the fact</b> that Rav declared a ruling of <b><i>halakha</i>,</b> it may be inferred <b>that</b> others <b>disagree</b> with this opinion. However, there is actually no dispute here, as <b>what could she have done?</b> It is as though <b>he raped her.</b> Since she received the testimony of witnesses that her husband was dead, she had no reason to refrain from remarrying. Her actions cannot be considered willing, as why should she refrain from marrying after receiving the testimony of witnesses that her husband was dead? Her lack of knowledge in this matter renders this case analogous to a rape. And as is well known, a woman who was raped is permitted to return to her husband.
<b>And it was further taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Any of those with whom relations are forbidden by Torah</b> law <b>do not require a bill of divorce</b> to dissolve a union, <b>except for a married woman who remarried by</b> permission of <b>the court.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>It is</b> only a woman who married <b>by</b> permission of <b>the court who requires a bill of divorce,</b> but if she married <b>based on</b> testimony of <b>witnesses she does not require a bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara further inquires: <b>Who is</b> the author of this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> in his opinion <b>does</b> a woman who married <b>by</b> permission of <b>the court require a bill of divorce</b> from the second man? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> If <b>the court acted</b> merely in accordance <b>with their</b> own <b>instruction</b> when they permitted a woman to remarry and her husband later arrived, it is as though this remarriage were <b>a willful</b> act of <b>a man with a woman,</b> and she is penalized like an intentional adulteress. Conversely, if she married <b>based on</b> testimony of <b>witnesses,</b> it is considered <b>like an unwitting</b> act of <b>a man with a woman.</b> Either way, <b>neither</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>nor</b> in <b>that</b> one, i.e., whether the marriage was in accordance with a decision of the court or based on witness testimony, does she <b>require a bill of divorce,</b> as a woman who committed adultery, whether unwittingly or intentionally, does not require a bill of divorce from the adulterer.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> the case that this <i>baraita</i>, which states that a woman who engaged in forbidden relations, including one who married based on witnesses, does not require a bill of divorce, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b> But if so, there was no need to issue a ruling to this effect, as everyone agrees that the <i>halakha</i> follows the majority opinion.
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> and you should <b>answer</b> the difficulty <b>as follows: Rabbi Shimon says</b> that if <b>the court acted</b> in accordance <b>with their</b> own <b>instruction,</b> it is <b>as though</b> there was <b>the intention of a man with a woman,</b> i.e., as though the man had relations with the woman for the purpose of marriage, <b>and</b> therefore <b>she requires a bill of divorce</b> from him. Conversely, if she married <b>based on</b> testimony of <b>witnesses</b> they considered it <b>as though</b> there was <b>no intention of a man with a woman,</b> as he had relations with her without the intention of marriage, <b>and</b> in that case <b>she does not require a bill of divorce.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that there is no difficulty here at all, as Rabbi Shimon’s statement should be explained differently. In fact, Rabbi Shimon <b>taught</b> his ruling <b>with regard to</b> the <b>prohibition</b> involved, not the issue of a bill of divorce, <b>and this is what he said:</b> If <b>the court acted</b> in accordance <b>with their</b> own <b>instruction,</b> it is <b>as though</b> this was <b>a willful</b> act <b>of a man with a woman, and she is</b> therefore <b>forbidden to her husband</b> like a woman who intentionally engaged in relations with another man. However, if she married <b>based on</b> testimony of <b>witnesses,</b> they considered it <b>as though</b> it was <b>an unwitting</b> act <b>of a man with a woman, and she is not forbidden to her husband.</b>

Daf 91b

<b>Ravina said</b> that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught with regard to an offering,</b> and it should be explained as follows: If <b>the court acted</b> in accordance <b>with their</b> own <b>instruction,</b> it is <b>as though</b> this was <b>a willful</b> act <b>of a man with a woman, and she</b> therefore <b>does not bring an offering,</b> as an individual who followed the ruling of the court is exempt from bringing an offering (see <i>Horayot</i> 2a–b). If she married <b>based on</b> testimony of <b>witnesses,</b> it is considered <b>as though</b> this was <b>an unwitting</b> act <b>of a man with a woman, and</b> therefore <b>she brings an offering.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> and refute Rav Sheshet’s difficulty in the following manner: <b>This first</b> <i>baraita</i>, which exempts forbidden women from a bill of divorce, <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who prohibit a woman in this situation to her husband, even if she had married another based on witnesses. And you should <b>answer</b> the difficulty by reading the relevant clause of the <i>baraita</i> <b>as follows: Apart from a married woman</b> who married on the basis of witness testimony, <b>and</b> this includes one <b>who married by</b> permission of <b>the court,</b> as she too requires a bill of divorce.
§ <b>Ulla raised an objection</b> against Rav Sheshet’s reasoning: <b>Do we say</b> this justification: <b>What could she have done?</b> Is a woman considered to have acted under duress when she had no way to avoid sin? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 79b): If a man <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce and dated it according <b>to a kingdom that is not suitable [<i>hogenet</i>],</b> i.e., one that does not reign over their place of residence; or according <b>to the kingdom of Media</b> or according <b>to the kingdom of Greece,</b> which are no longer in existence; or if he dated it according <b>to the building of the Temple</b> or according <b>to the destruction of the Temple;</b> and similarly if the bill of divorce <b>was</b> given <b>in the east and he wrote</b> in it a place <b>in the west,</b> or <b>in the west and he wrote</b> a place <b>in the east,</b> this bill of divorce is invalid.
Consequently, if she married another man <b>she must leave this one and that one,</b> both the one who gave her the bill of divorce and the new husband. <b>And all these matters</b> mentioned in the mishna here, the penalties imposed on a married woman who remarried unlawfully, apply <b>to her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But why? Let us say: What could she have done.</b> She acted under duress, as she married again only because she thought the bill of divorce was valid. The Gemara answers: This woman did not act under duress, as <b>she should have had the bill of divorce read</b> by a scholar, who would have told her that it was invalid.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof. With regard to <b>one who married his <i>yevama</i>, and the rival wife</b> of the <i>yevama</i> <b>went and married</b> someone else, <b>and this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>was</b> later <b>discovered</b> to be <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman,</b> which means that she was never eligible for levirate marriage and therefore her act of intercourse did not exempt her rival wife from levirate marriage, the rival wife must <b>leave this one and that one,</b> i.e., her husband must give her a bill of divorce and she may not marry the <i>yavam</i>, <b>and all these matters</b> apply <b>to her. But why?</b> Again, <b>let us say: What could she have done.</b> The Gemara answers: This is no proof, as <b>she should have waited</b> until it was clearly established that the other wife was not a sexually underdeveloped woman.
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>all those with whom relations are forbidden, with regard to</b> whom the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>they exempt their rival wives,</b> if these <b>rival wives went and married, and</b> one of <b>these</b> forbidden women was <b>discovered</b> to be <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman,</b> which means that the obligation of levirate marriage did not apply to her at all, and it was the rival wives who should have performed levirate marriage, the rival wife must <b>leave</b> both <b>this and that, and all these matters</b> apply <b>to her. But why? Let us say: What could she have done.</b> The Gemara answers as before: <b>She should have waited.</b>
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear: A scribe wrote a bill of divorce for the man and a receipt for the woman,</b> so that the man should give the bill of divorce to his wife and she should give him the receipt upon his delivery of the marriage contract. <b>And</b> the scribe <b>erred and gave</b> the <b>bill of divorce to the woman and</b> the <b>receipt to the man,</b> leaving them with the mistaken impression that he had the bill of divorce and she the receipt, <b>and they gave</b> each other the documents, <b>this one to that one and that one to this one.</b>
<b>And after a while</b> it became clear <b>that the bill of divorce is in the man’s possession and the receipt in the woman’s possession,</b> and no act of divorce had been performed at all. If the woman had married someone else in the meantime she must <b>leave</b> both <b>this one and that one, and all these matters</b> apply <b>to her. But why? Let us say: What could she have done.</b> The Gemara answers: Here too, <b>she should have had the bill of divorce read</b> by an expert.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If a man <b>changed his name, or</b> his wife’s <b>name,</b> or <b>the name of his city, or the name of her city,</b> and she remarried, she must <b>leave</b> both <b>this one and that one, and all these matters</b> apply <b>to her. But why? Let us say: What could she have done.</b> The Gemara answers: Once again, <b>she should have had the bill of divorce read</b> by a scholar.
<b>Ravina said: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> A man <b>married</b> a woman <b>on</b> the basis that she was divorced. However, she had actually received <b>a bare bill of divorce,</b> i.e., missing a signature. This is referring to a special type of bill of divorce, one that was folded and sewn up. It requires as many witnesses as the number of lines it contains. If a bill of divorce of this kind does not have enough witnesses, it is invalid. In the case of the <i>baraita</i>, if this woman married another man after receiving this bill of divorce, she must <b>leave</b> both <b>this one and this one,</b> and all these penalties apply to her. Again, the question is: What could she have done? The Gemara answers, as before: <b>She should have had the bill of divorce read</b> by someone who could have told her it was invalid.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Pappa thought to take action</b> and permit a woman to return to her husband based on the rationale: <b>What could she have done.</b> In a case where she had no means of clarifying the matter, he ruled that she should be considered to have acted under duress. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rav Pappa: But isn’t it taught</b> repeatedly <b>in all these <i>mishnayot</i></b> that this argument is not accepted?
Rav Pappa <b>said to</b> Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: <b>And</b> did <b>we not resolve</b> these <i>mishnayot</i>, by explaining that in those particular cases she did have the option of clarifying the matter? <b>He said to him: And shall we stand and rely on answers?</b> Admittedly, we found some way of resolving these questions, but the accumulation of difficulties indicates that the rationale: What could she have done, is unacceptable. <b>And</b> indeed, Rav Pappa <b>ceased</b> to follow his original intention and did not issue a lenient ruling.
§ The Gemara discusses the case of the mishna from another perspective. <b>Rav Ashi said: And we are not concerned about a rumor.</b> In other words, if there was an unsubstantiated rumor that the husband was alive, the court takes no notice of it. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> kind of <b>rumor</b> does he mean? <b>If we say</b> that this is referring to <b>a rumor that</b> spread <b>after</b> the <b>marriage</b> of this woman to another man, <b>Rav Ashi has</b> already <b>said this once, as Rav Ashi said:</b>

Daf 92a

<b>We are not concerned about any rumor after marriage.</b> If a rumor spread about a woman after her marriage that she was forbidden to her husband, the court takes no notice of these reports. The Gemara answers: There is a novel aspect to this teaching: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since she came to the court and they permitted</b> her, the very fact that her case had to be discussed indicates that her status is not fully established, and consequently one might think that it should be <b>considered like a rumor before marriage, and she should</b> therefore <b>be forbidden,</b> Rav Ashi therefore <b>teaches us</b> that even in this case, once she is married the court takes no notice of unsubstantiated rumors.
§ The mishna further taught that if <b>she married by</b> permission of <b>the court she must leave</b> him, but she is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. On this issue, <b>Ze’eiri said: The mishna is not</b> accepted, and this is derived <b>from what was taught</b> in <b>the study hall, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in <b>the study hall:</b> If <b>the court ruled that the sun had set</b> at the conclusion of Shabbat, which means it is permitted to perform labor, <b>and later</b> the sun <b>shone, this is not a ruling</b> for which the court is to blame, <b>but an error.</b> Consequently, the court does not have to bring an offering for the unwitting communal sin. Rather, each individual is liable to bring a separate offering. Here too, although the woman married with the consent of the court, they did not issue a mistaken ruling of <i>halakha</i> but simply erred with regard to the facts. She is therefore an unwitting sinner and is liable to bring an offering. 
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that the court’s permission <b>is</b> considered <b>a ruling</b> that renders them liable to bring an offering for an unwitting communal sin.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> You can <b>know that</b> her permission to marry <b>is a ruling,</b> as <b>in the entire Torah one witness is not deemed credible, and</b> yet <b>here he is deemed credible. What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because it is</b> considered <b>a ruling,</b> i.e., she does not rely on the witness but on the decision of the court? By contrast, <b>Rava said</b> that we can <b>know that</b> her permission to marry <b>is an error.</b> His reasoning is <b>that had the court ruled with regard to forbidden fat or with regard to blood that</b> it is <b>permitted, and they went back and saw a reason to prohibit</b> it, <b>if</b> they subsequently <b>retract and say that</b> it is <b>permitted we take no notice of them.</b> If they did not find a conclusive proof but merely offered a new argument, this claim does not cancel the earlier ruling that the substance is forbidden.
<b>Whereas</b> in the case of marriage, <b>when one witness comes</b> the court <b>permits</b> her, and when <b>two</b> witnesses subsequently <b>come</b> and testify that her husband is alive, <b>they render</b> her <b>forbidden. When one</b> other <b>witness again comes</b> forward, claiming that the husband is dead, <b>they permit</b> her. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because it is</b> considered <b>an error</b> of the court, as they did not issue their rulings based on their own reasoning but in reliance on the facts they had garnered from the witnesses? It is therefore considered a factual error, not a mistaken ruling.
The Gemara adds: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer also maintains that</b> the ruling of the court <b>is an error, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If a woman married by permission of the court and it later turned out that her husband was alive, <b>let the law pierce the mountain,</b> i.e., the matter must be fully investigated. If it turns out that the ruling of the court is incorrect, it is nullified <b>and she brings a choice sin-offering. Granted, if you say that it is an error,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>she must bring an offering. However, if you say it is a ruling, why does she bring an offering?</b> It is the court that should be liable to bring an offering for its incorrect ruling.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps Rabbi Eliezer maintains</b> that <b>an individual who acted by ruling of the court</b> is also <b>liable</b> to bring an offering, and this is why he obligates her to bring an offering, despite the fact that she went ahead with the consent of the court. The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>If so, what</b> need is there for the special mention of the rationale: <b>Let the law pierce the mountain?</b> He should simply have said that she is liable to bring an offering. Rather, Rabbi Eliezer evidently maintains that in general an individual does not have to bring an offering for a sin he committed based on the ruling of a court. Here, however, she must bring a sin-offering because there was an error with regard to the facts.
§ The mishna taught that if <b>the court instructed her to marry,</b> and she went and ruined herself, she is liable to bring an offering. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Ruined herself? Rabbi Eliezer says: She engaged in licentious sexual relations</b> with a man, i.e., intercourse not for the purpose of marriage. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It means that she married in a prohibited manner, e.g., <b>a widow to a High Priest,</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who</b> had <b>performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>] to a common priest.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: According to <b>the one who says</b> that <b>she engaged in licentious sexual relations,</b> she is <b>all the more so</b> liable to bring an offering if she is <b>a widow</b> who had sexual relations <b>with a High Priest,</b> as she performed an act prohibited by Torah law. Conversely, according to <b>the one who says</b> that the mishna is speaking of <b>a widow</b> who engaged in relations <b>with a High Priest,</b> it is only in that case that she must bring an offering; <b>however,</b> if <b>she engaged in licentious sexual relations</b> she is <b>not</b> liable to bring an offering. <b>What is the reason? As she can say:</b> It is <b>you who deemed me unattached,</b> and although my behavior was unseemly, I may live with whomever I choose as a single woman.
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If <b>the court ruled that she may marry, and she went and ruined</b> herself, <b>for example a widow</b> who engaged in intercourse <b>with a High Priest,</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> who engaged in intercourse <b>with a common priest, she is liable to</b> bring <b>an offering for each and every sexual act,</b> as each is a separate transgression. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> that she brings <b>one offering for all</b> of them, as she performed them all in a single lapse of awareness. <b>And the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Elazar that if</b> a married woman <b>married</b> in error, e.g., <b>to five people, that she is liable to</b> bring <b>an offering for each and every one</b> of them, <b>since</b> they are <b>separate bodies.</b> She is obligated to bring an offering for each separate man with whom she engaged in sexual relations.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman whose husband and child went overseas, and</b> witnesses <b>came and said to her: Your husband died and afterward your child died,</b> she does not require levirate marriage, as she had a child when her husband died. <b>And</b> for this reason she <b>married</b> another man. <b>And</b> if <b>afterward they said to her</b> that <b>the matters were reversed,</b> i.e., the child died before the husband, which means that she did require levirate marriage, she is therefore a <i>yevama</i> who married a stranger without <i>ḥalitza</i> and <b>she must</b> consequently <b>leave</b> her second husband. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the first child,</b> the one born before they heard about the reversal, <b>and the last one,</b> born after they realized who actually died first, each of these children is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
Conversely, if <b>they said to her: Your child died and afterward your husband died, and she</b> therefore <b>entered into levirate marriage, and afterward they said to her</b> that <b>the matters were reversed,</b> which means she married her husband’s brother when there was no obligation of levirate marriage, <b>she must leave</b> her husband, <b>and the first child and the last one</b> are each <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> If <b>they said to her: Your husband died, and she married, and afterward they said to her</b> that <b>he was alive</b> at the time of her marriage <b>and he</b> later <b>died, she must leave</b> the second husband. <b>And the first child,</b> born when her original husband was still alive, is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>, and the last one,</b> born after his death, <b>is not a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
If <b>they said to her: Your husband died, and she became betrothed</b> to another man, <b>and afterward her husband came, she is permitted to return to him,</b> as betrothal alone does not render her forbidden to her husband. Furthermore, <b>although</b> the <b>last</b> man, i.e., her betrothed, <b>gave her a bill of divorce,</b> he has <b>not</b> thereby <b>disqualified her</b> from marrying into the priesthood. She was never his wife, for the betrothal was invalid, and a bill of divorce given to the wife of another man does not disqualify her. <b>This was taught by Rabbi Elazar ben Matya:</b> The verse states with regard to priests: <b>“Neither</b> shall they take <b>a woman divorced from her husband”</b> (Leviticus 21:7), which indicates: <b>And not</b> one who was divorced <b>from a man who is not her husband,</b> e.g., the second man in this case.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks a question with regard to the first section of the mishna: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>first</b> child <b>and what is</b> the meaning of <b>last</b> child in this context? <b>If we say</b> that the <b>first</b> means the one born <b>before</b> her <b>hearing</b> that the report was erroneous, <b>and</b> the <b>last</b> means the one born <b>after</b> she <b>heard, let him teach</b> simply: <b>The offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> as there is no difference between the two cases.
The Gemara explains that <b>because</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wanted to teach</b> in the <b>latter clause:</b> If <b>they said to her your husband died, and she married, and afterward they said to her</b> that <b>he was alive and he</b> later <b>died, the first</b> child is <b>a <i>mamzer</i> and the last one is not a <i>mamzer</i>, he also taught</b> in the <b>first clause:</b> The <b>first and</b> the <b>last</b> are each a <b><i>mamzer</i>,</b> despite the fact that in this case it makes no difference whether the child was born before or after she heard.
§ <b>The Sages taught: This</b> mishna is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva, who would say</b> that <b>betrothal does not take effect for</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating regular <b>prohibitions,</b> and therefore the child of a <i>yevama</i> who transgressed a prohibition by marrying someone else is a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>However, the Rabbis say</b> that <b>there is no <i>mamzer</i> from a <i>yevama</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the Rabbis <b>say,</b> as a principle: <b>There is no <i>mamzer</i> from</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating regular <b>prohibitions.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This <i>tanna</i></b> called the Rabbis <b>is</b> in fact another <b><i>tanna</i></b> citing the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who claims <b>that</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said</b> that a child born <b>from</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions</b> proscribing sexual relations with <b>close</b> relatives <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> but one born <b>from</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating <b>regular prohibitions,</b> i.e., a prohibition that does not involve a family relationship, such as the prohibition that “the wife of the dead man shall not be married outside of the family to one not of his kin” (Deuteronomy 25:5), <b>is not a <i>mamzer</i>. Rav Yehuda said</b>

Daf 92b

that <b>Rav said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that betrothal</b> by another man <b>does not take effect with a <i>yevama</i>? As it is stated: “The wife of the dead man shall not be married outside of the family to one not of his kin”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), which indicates: <b>She shall not have</b> the possibility of <b>becoming</b> married <b>to one not of his kin,</b> i.e., his betrothal is of no account.
<b>And Shmuel said: In our poverty</b> of knowledge, as we do not fully understand the verse, <b>she requires a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Shmuel was uncertain with regard to this</b> verse: <b>“The wife of the dead man shall not be married</b> outside,” <b>whether it comes for a prohibition,</b> i.e., the woman is prohibited from marrying another man but the betrothal of that other man is effective, or <b>whether</b> it <b>comes</b> to teach <b>that betrothal</b> by any other man <b>does not take effect with her.</b>
<b>Rav Mari bar Raḥel said to Rav Ashi</b> that <b>Ameimar said as follows: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Shmuel. Rav Ashi said: Now that Ameimar said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> who maintains that one who betroths a <i>yevama</i> before she has performed <i>ḥalitza</i> must give her a bill of divorce, <b>if her <i>yavam</i> was a priest, he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her,</b> as she is forbidden to him after the man who betrothed her gave her a bill of divorce, <b>and she is</b> thereby <b>permitted to</b> the man to whom she was betrothed.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this ruling: But in that case, she thereby <b>gains</b> from her prohibited betrothal, as she may subsequently marry the man who betrothed her illegally. <b>If so, we find a sinner benefiting</b> from his transgression. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara emends the teaching: <b>If her <i>yavam</i> was</b> a regular <b>Israelite,</b> this <b>second</b> man who betrothed her <b>must give her a bill of divorce, and she is permitted to</b> the <i>yavam</i>, as a non-priest may marry a divorcée.
§ <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>a <i>yevama</i>, betrothal does not</b> apply <b>to her,</b> but <b>marriage does</b> apply <b>to her.</b> The Gemara expresses puzzlement: <b>If betrothal does not</b> apply <b>to her, marriage also</b> should <b>not</b> apply <b>to her.</b> How can marriage take effect if the earlier and less binding stage of betrothal is of no consequence? Rather, emend the above statement and <b>say: Neither betrothal nor marriage</b> apply <b>to her.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different explanation. <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>Marriage does</b> apply <b>to her?</b> It is referring <b>to</b> a case of <b>licentious sexual relations.</b> In other words, although Rav maintains that betrothal is ineffective for her, if she entered the wedding canopy with another man and had relations with him, her status changes and she is forbidden to the <i>yavam</i>. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna, as Rav Hamnuna said</b> that <b>a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i> who committed an act of licentious sexual relations is forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say: Actually,</b> it is <b>as we said initially,</b> that <b>betrothal does not</b> apply <b>to her</b> but <b>marriage does</b> apply <b>to her.</b> However, this does not mean that marriage is actually effective. Rather, the <i>halakha</i> is that he must give her a bill of divorce, <b>as</b> people might <b>confuse</b> this case <b>with</b> that of <b>a woman whose husband went overseas.</b> The Sages decreed that he must give her a bill of divorce so that people would not say that a woman who remarried after hearing that her husband had died likewise does not require a bill of divorce.
§ <b>Rabbi Yannai said: In the group</b> of Sages who discussed this matter, <b>they counted and concluded</b> that <b>betrothal</b> by another man <b>does not take effect with a <i>yevama</i>. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: My teacher, is this not</b> taught in <b>a mishna</b> that states that betrothal is of no account for such a woman? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 16b): With regard to <b>one who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me after I convert; after you convert; after I am freed</b> from slavery; <b>after you are freed; after your husband dies; after your sister dies;</b> or <b>after your <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with you, she is not betrothed.</b> The reason for the above ruling is that he is considered to be attempting to acquire an entity that is not yet in existence, as the betrothal cannot take effect at that point in time. This indicates that betrothal is entirely ineffective for a <i>yevama</i> until she performs <i>ḥalitza</i>. Rabbi Yannai <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Had I not lifted the earthenware shard for you, would you have discovered the pearl</b> [<b><i>marganita</i></b>] <b>beneath it?</b> It was only after I informed you of the <i>halakha</i> that you were able to cite a proof for it from a mishna.
Sometime later, <b>Reish Lakish said</b> to Rav Yoḥanan: <b>If</b> it were <b>not</b> for the fact <b>that a great man,</b> Rabbi Yannai, <b>praised you, I would say</b> that this is no proof, as it is possible that <b>the mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that <b>betrothal does not take effect for</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating regular <b>prohibitions,</b> and therefore it is not effective with a <i>yevama</i>. However, according to the opinion of the Rabbis, betrothal is effective for this woman, as is the case with all regular prohibitions.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, when he said to her: After your <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> for you, let the betrothal take effect with her, as we have heard that Rabbi Akiva said</b> that <b>a man can transfer an entity that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world.</b> In other words, Rabbi Akiva is of the opinion that an acquisition can take effect for something not yet in existence. If so, even if the betrothal cannot take effect now, it should be valid after she has performed <i>ḥalitza</i>. The proof that this is indeed Rabbi Akiva’s opinion is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 59a):

Daf 93a

If a wife said: <b><i>Konam</i>,</b> i.e., this is forbidden like consecrated property, in reference to anything <b>that I will prepare for your mouth,</b> that is, the payment for any work I perform shall be forbidden to you, <b>he is not required to nullify</b> the vow, as it is automatically void, since she was under a prior obligation to give him her earnings as part of their marriage agreement.
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He should <b>nullify</b> the vow, <b>lest she exceed more than is fitting for him.</b> A husband is entitled only to a certain sum from his wife’s earnings (see <i>Ketubot</i> 64b). If she earns only the sum of money to which he is entitled, the vow certainly does not go into effect. However, she might earn more, in which case the vow would apply with regard to the additional amount. To avoid this scenario, it is preferable for the husband to nullify the vow. This shows that according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva a vow applies even with regard to an entity that has not yet come into the world. In this case, the entity is the earnings for work she has yet to perform.
The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>But wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> This mishna is not referring to a woman who renders the earnings for work she has yet to perform forbidden, but <b>to</b> a wife <b>who says: Let my hands be consecrated to their Maker.</b> In other words, she declares that it is as though her hands were sanctified, which means that anything produced by them is forbidden. <b>Since</b> these <b>hands</b> are <b>in the world,</b> she has not attempted to acquire something that does not exist. Therefore, there is no proof from here with regard to Rabbi Akiva’s opinion on that issue.
§ The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this opinion, that Rabbi Akiva maintains that one cannot acquire an entity that has not yet come into the world, <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Rav Huna</b> agrees <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and Rav</b> agrees <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai, and Rabbi Yannai with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Ḥiyya with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Meir with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said: A person can transfer</b> to another <b>an entity that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world.</b> This shows that Rabbi Akiva indeed maintains that one can acquire something that does not yet exist.
The Gemara specifies the particular contexts in which the aforementioned opinions, all of which concur, were issued: <b>Rav Huna, what is</b> the source for his ruling? <b>As it was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who sells the fruit of a palm tree to another</b> before the fruit has grown, <b>Rav Huna said: Until</b> the fruit <b>has come into the world, he can retract</b> the sale, as it has yet to take effect. However, <b>after</b> the fruit <b>has come into the world, he can no</b> longer <b>retract,</b> despite the fact the fruit had not yet sprouted when he made the acquisition.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said: Even after they have come into the world he can retract,</b> as the acquisition was defective from the outset. He maintains that one cannot transfer ownership of an entity that does not yet exist. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> Even so, <b>I concede that if</b> the buyer <b>seizes</b> the fruit <b>and consumes</b> it, the court <b>does not remove them from him,</b> because despite the faulty acquisition he was promised a sale of fruit.
The Gemara cites the proof that <b>Rav</b> also accepts the ruling that one can acquire an entity that does not yet exist, <b>as Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>one who says to another: This field that I am</b> about to <b>buy, when I buy it, it is acquired by you from now,</b> the addressee <b>has acquired</b> the field, despite the fact that it did not belong to the speaker at the time of his statement.
<b>Rabbi Yannai</b> also agrees <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, as</b> demonstrated by the following episode: <b>Rabbi Yannai had a sharecropper</b> working his land <b>who would bring him a basket [<i>kanta</i>] of fruit every Shabbat eve. One day he was late and did not come.</b> Rabbi Yannai <b>took tithe from the fruit in his house for</b> the fruit he expected to receive. He did this in case the fruit arrived near the beginning of Shabbat, as one may not tithe on Shabbat. However, Rabbi Yannai was uncertain whether it is indeed possible to separate tithes for an entity that has not yet reached one’s possession. He therefore <b>came before Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> to inquire whether his separation of tithes was effective.
Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to him: You acted well, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, with regard to a verse that discusses tithes: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God…<b>in order that you should learn to fear the Lord your God all the days”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:23). With regard to the emphasis of “all,” <b>these are <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals. With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>If we say</b> it was stated in regard to the issue <b>of tithing and eating</b> on Shabbat, this <i>halakha</i> is redundant. <b>Was a verse necessary to permit</b> the prohibition against <b>moving</b> objects, which applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law? Since the prohibition against moving objects is from the Sages, the Torah is certainly not referring to this <i>halakha</i>.

Daf 93b

<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>a case like this,</b> of one who tithed an entity that was not yet in the world, in honor of Shabbat? Rabbi Yannai <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya: <b>But they read before me in a dream</b> these two words: <b>Bruised reed. What, is it not</b> the case that <b>they said to me as follows: “Behold you trust upon the staff of this bruised reed”</b> (II Kings 18:21)? In other words, you rely on an unsubstantiated idea.
Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: <b>No;</b> The dream referred to a different verse, one that deals with the Messiah, as <b>they said to you as follows: “A bruised reed he shall not break and the dimly burning wick he shall not quench;</b> according to truth he shall bring forth justice” (Isaiah 42:3). In other words, Rabbi Yannai acted correctly, in accordance with the ways of truth. This exchange shows that both Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Yannai agree that an entity not in the world can be acquired.
With regard to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, his opinion is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“You shall not deliver a slave to his master”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:16). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The verse is speaking of one who buys a slave on the condition to free him.</b> This owner may not keep his acquisition as a slave. The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where one wrote to</b> a slave in the document of acquisition: <b>When I acquire you</b> as a slave, <b>you are acquired by yourself from now.</b> In this case, the buyer transfers ownership of an entity not yet in the world, as the slave did not yet belong to him.
<b>Rabbi Meir,</b> his opinion is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 16b): <b>One who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me after I convert; after you convert; after I am freed; after you are freed; after your husband dies; after your sister dies; after your <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with you, she is not betrothed. Rabbi Meir says she is betrothed,</b> as the acquisition of a betrothal applies even to an entity not yet in the world, in this case, a woman available for betrothal.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> his opinion is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Moreover, Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said</b> that <b>even if one said:</b> The <b>detached fruit of this garden bed shall be <i>teruma</i> for</b> the currently <b>attached fruit of</b> this <b>garden bed</b> when its fruit will be detached, <b>or</b> if he said: The <b>attached fruit of</b> this <b>garden bed</b> shall be <i>teruma</i> <b>for</b> the currently <b>detached fruit of this garden bed when</b> the fruit <b>reach a third</b> of their growth, i.e., a third of their ripeness, <b>and are detached, and</b> if <b>they</b> actually <b>reached a third and were detached,</b> then <b>his words are upheld</b> and the <i>teruma</i> takes effect, despite the fact that the stipulation was issued before the attached fruit had ripened and before the obligation of <i>teruma</i> applied to the detached fruit. This <i>halakha</i> shows that one can acquire an entity not yet in the world; in this case he acquires the fruit by applying the sanctity of <i>teruma</i> to it.
<b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> his opinion is <b>as we learned</b> in the aforementioned mishna, that if a wife says: <b><i>Konam</i> that I will prepare for your mouth,</b> the husband <b>is not required to nullify</b> the vow. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He should <b>nullify</b> the vow, <b>lest she exceed more than is fitting for him,</b> as he maintains that the vow applies even to entities not yet in the world.
§ <b>They raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> In a case of <b>one witness</b> who testifies that a woman’s husband is dead, <b>with regard to a <i>yevama</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Can the court rely on this witness? The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: Is <b>the reason</b> that the testimony of <b>one witness</b> in the case of a missing husband is accepted <b>because</b> one <b>does not lie about something that will be discovered, and here, too,</b> he will <b>not lie,</b> in case the husband later arrives? <b>Or, perhaps the reason for</b> the eligibility of <b>one witness is because</b> the woman herself <b>is exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. <b>But here, since</b> she <b>sometimes loves</b> the <i>yavam</i>, as she already knew him beforehand, <b>she is not exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again.
<b>Rav Sheshet said to him: You learned</b> the answer to this question in the mishna: If <b>they said to her: Your child died and afterward your husband died, and she entered into levirate marriage, and afterward they said to her</b> that <b>the matters were reversed, she must leave</b> her husband, <b>and the first child and the last one</b> are each <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Rav Sheshet analyzes this case: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> they are <b>two and two,</b> i.e., two witnesses came first and said one account, followed by two other witnesses who claimed the reverse, <b>what did you see</b> to make <b>you rely on these</b> second witnesses when you can equally <b>rely on</b> the first pair? The first witnesses do not lose their credibility merely due to the testimony of the second pair, so why should she have to leave the <i>yavam</i>?
<b>And furthermore,</b> why should the child be a definite <b><i>mamzer</i>?</b> At worst <b>he is</b> an individual whose status as <b>a <i>mamzer</i></b> is <b>uncertain,</b> as there are two conflicting sets of testimonies. <b>And if you would say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>was not precise</b> in his failure to distinguish between a definite <i>mamzer</i> and one of uncertain status, <b>but from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>The first is a <i>mamzer</i> and the last is not a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> one can <b>learn from here</b> that the mishna <b>was taught specifically</b> in this manner, i.e., the <i>mamzer</i> the <i>tanna</i> referred to is a definite <i>mamzer</i>.
<b>Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from</b> here that only <b>one</b> witness testified at first, <b>and the reason</b> for the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that two</b> people <b>came and contradicted him,</b> as the testimony of two witnesses certainly overrules that of a single witness? It may be inferred from this that if it were <b>not so,</b> the lone witness is <b>deemed credible.</b> This shows that the court will accept the testimony of one witness even to allow a woman to enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara provides an alternative version of the discussion. <b>And some</b> Sages maintain another version that <b>says: Let the dilemma not be raised, as even</b> a wife herself <b>is also deemed credible</b> when she says her husband is dead, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (114b): With regard to <b>a woman who said: My husband is dead, she may marry.</b> Likewise, if she claimed: <b>My husband is dead, she should enter into levirate marriage.</b> If so, one witness is certainly deemed credible when he says her husband has died. The case <b>where you</b> could <b>raise the dilemma</b> is with regard <b>to permitting a <i>yevama</i> to all</b> other men, if a witness claims that the <i>yavam</i> is dead.
In this case as well, the Gemara clarifies the sides of this dilemma: <b>What is the reason that one witness</b> is deemed credible? Is it <b>because</b> one <b>does not lie about something that will be discovered,</b> and therefore <b>here too he</b> would <b>not lie? Or, perhaps the reason for</b> accepting the testimony of <b>one witness</b> is <b>because</b> the wife <b>is exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again, <b>but this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>is not exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. Why not? <b>Because</b> she

Daf 94a

<b>hates</b> the <i>yavam</i>, and she would therefore take advantage of any testimony to rid herself of him. <b>Rav Sheshet said to them</b> that <b>you learned it</b> in the mishna. If <b>they said to her: Your husband died and afterward your child died, and she married</b> another man, <b>and afterward they said to her</b> that <b>the matters were reversed, she must leave</b> the other man, <b>and the first child and the last one</b> are each <b>a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
Again, Rav Sheshet analyzes the case: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that they are <b>two and two,</b> i.e., the account of two witnesses was contradicted by two other witnesses, <b>what did you see</b> to make <b>you rely on these</b> second witnesses when you can equally <b>rely on those?</b> Why should she have to leave this man? <b>And furthermore,</b> why should the child be <b>a <i>mamzer</i>?</b> At worst <b>he is</b> an individual whose status as <b>a <i>mamzer</i></b> is <b>uncertain,</b> as there is no proof that the second witnesses are more reliable. <b>And if you would say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna was <b>not precise</b> in his language, <b>but from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>The first is a <i>mamzer</i> and the last is not a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> one can <b>learn from here</b> that the mishna <b>was taught specifically</b> in this manner.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> the case that this is referring to <b>one</b> witness, <b>and the reason</b> is <b>that two</b> others <b>came and contradicted him.</b> It may be inferred from this that if it was <b>not so,</b> the sole witness is <b>deemed credible.</b> The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna is speaking of a case when <b>two</b> witnesses came first, followed by another <b>two</b> witnesses, <b>and</b> the ruling is <b>as Rav Aḥa bar Manyumi said,</b> with regard to a different issue, that it is referring <b>to witnesses of</b> false, <b>conspiring testimony.</b> In other words, the second set of witnesses did not offer an alternative account of the same incident. Rather, they claimed that the first witnesses lied, as they were with them, elsewhere, during the time that they supposedly witnessed the husband’s death. In this case, the first witnesses are entirely disqualified, as the account of the second pair is accepted. 
<b>Here too,</b> we are dealing <b>with witnesses of</b> false, <b>conspiring testimony.</b> Consequently, the question of whether the court believes one witness who testifies that a <i>yavam</i> is dead cannot be resolved from the mishna.
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Aḥa</b> who <b>said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a different source (<i>Yevamot</i> 118b): <b>A woman is not deemed credible</b> if she <b>says: My <i>yavam</i> is dead, so that I may marry,</b> i.e., to permit herself to marry another man. <b>And</b> she is <b>not</b> deemed credible if she says: <b>My sister is dead, so that I may enter her house,</b> i.e., to marry her husband. The Gemara infers: It is <b>she herself who is not deemed credible.</b> It may be inferred from this that if <b>one witness</b> issues this report, he is <b>deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara refutes this argument. <b>And according to your reasoning, say the latter clause</b> of that same mishna: <b>A man is not deemed credible</b> if he <b>says: My brother is dead, so that I may enter into levirate marriage with his wife. And</b> he is <b>not</b> deemed credible when he says: <b>My wife is dead, so that I may marry her sister.</b> Following the above reasoning, it is <b>he himself</b> who <b>is not deemed credible,</b> which indicates that <b>one witness is deemed credible.</b> Yet this cannot be correct: <b>Granted, with regard to a woman, due to</b> the concern that she be left <b>a deserted wife, the Sages were lenient in her</b> case, by allowing her to rely on a single witness. <b>However, with regard to a man, what can be said?</b> There is no concern that he will be left deserted, as a man can marry more than one woman, so he certainly cannot marry a woman on the basis of such flimsy testimony.
<b>Rather,</b> the case of one witness cannot be decided from the mishna, as <b>when is</b> this <i>halakha</i> that a woman is not deemed credible when she says that her <i>yavam</i> is dead <b>necessary</b> to be stated? It <b>is necessary for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Akiva said</b> that the offspring born of intercourse <b>for which</b> one <b>is liable</b> for violating <b>a prohibition is a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> which indicates that even the offspring of a <i>yevama</i> who unlawfully wed another man is a <i>mamzer</i>, one might <b>say</b> that <b>she is concerned for the ruin of her offspring and is</b> consequently <b>exacting</b> in her investigation and would marry only if she received clear, unambiguous testimony. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us that</b> she <b>is concerned for her own ruin,</b> e.g., if there is uncertainty as to whether her husband died, which would force her to leave both him and her second husband, but <b>she is not</b> as <b>concerned for the ruin of her offspring,</b> and in this case she is likelier to marry unlawfully.
§ <b>Rava said: One witness is deemed credible</b> in the case <b>of a <i>yevama</i> by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If <b>for a prohibition involving <i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., adultery of a married woman, <b>you permitted</b> the testimony of one witness, then <b>for a</b> regular <b>prohibition,</b> that of a <i>yevama</i> to another man, is it <b>not all the more so? One of the Sages said to Rava: She herself,</b> a woman who testifies with regard to herself, <b>can prove</b> otherwise: <b>For a prohibition involving <i>karet</i> you permitted</b> her, i.e., if she testifies that her husband is dead she may marry another man and there is no concern that she might still be a married woman, and yet <b>for</b> a regular <b>prohibition you did not permit</b> her, as she is not deemed credible when she claims that her <i>yavam</i> is dead.
<b>But rather, she</b> herself, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>she is not deemed credible? Since sometimes</b> the woman may <b>hate him, she is not exacting</b> in her examination of the matter <b>and marries.</b> With regard to <b>one witness,</b> the same concern <b>also</b> applies: <b>Since sometimes</b> the woman may <b>hate him, she is not exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. The court believes one witness only because they assume that she herself is careful to examine the matter. The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is therefore groundless, and the question remains unresolved.
§ The mishna states that <b>this was an exposition taught by Rabbi Elazar ben Matya:</b> The verse states with regard to priests: “Neither shall they take a woman divorced from her husband” (Leviticus 21:7). This teaches that a woman is not disqualified from marrying into the priesthood by a bill of divorce she receives from a man other than her husband. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Rabbi Elazar should have taught</b> this verse as <b>a pearl but</b> in fact <b>he taught it as an earthenware shard.</b> In other words, he could have arrived at a more significant conclusion.
The Gemara asks: <b>What pearl</b> does he mean? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “Neither shall they take <b>a woman divorced from her husband,” even</b> if she <b>was divorced only from her husband.</b> Even if the woman was separated from her husband and was not permitted to marry anyone else, e.g., if her husband wrote in the bill of divorce: This is your bill of divorce but you are not permitted to any other man, this document is certainly not considered a full-fledged bill of divorce, and yet she is <b>disqualified from the priesthood.</b> If her husband later passes away, she has the status of a divorcée, not a widow, which means that she is prohibited from marrying a priest. <b>And this is the trace of a bill of divorce, which</b> is not an actual bill of divorce and yet <b>disqualifies from the priesthood.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one whose wife went overseas</b> and people <b>came and told him: Your wife is dead, and he married her sister, and afterward his wife came</b> back from overseas, the original wife <b>is permitted to return</b>

Daf 94b

<b>to him,</b> as his erroneous marriage to her sister is considered licentious sexual relations, and one who has intercourse with his wife’s relatives has not rendered his first wife forbidden to himself. <b>And he is permitted to the relatives of the second</b> woman, e.g., her daughter, <b>and</b> this <b>second</b> woman <b>is permitted to his relatives,</b> e.g., his son, as the marriage was entirely invalid. <b>And if the first</b> woman <b>died</b> he is <b>permitted to the second</b> woman, despite the fact that he has already engaged in forbidden relations with her.
If <b>they said to him</b> that <b>his wife is dead, and he married her sister, and afterward they said to him</b> that <b>she was alive</b> when he married the sister <b>and</b> only later <b>died,</b> in this case <b>the first child,</b> born to the sister while his wife was still alive, is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> as he was born from the union of a man and his sister-in-law, <b>and the last one is not a <i>mamzer</i>. Rabbi Yosei says: Whoever disqualifies others</b> also <b>disqualifies himself, and whoever does not disqualify others does not disqualify himself</b> either. Rabbi Yosei’s obscure statement will be explained by the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case of a man who married his wife’s sister after he was informed that his wife was dead, the Gemara comments: <b>And even if his wife and his brother-in-law</b> both <b>went overseas</b> and he was told that they had died, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that this marriage</b> he performed <b>is effective</b> only to the extent <b>that his brother-in-law’s wife is forbidden to his brother-in-law.</b> The reason for this prohibition is that he performed a marriage ceremony with a married woman by mistake, and one who erroneously weds a married woman has thereby rendered her forbidden to her husband. The Gemara adds: <b>Even so,</b> it is only <b>his brother-in-law’s wife</b> who <b>is forbidden</b> to her husband, whereas <b>his</b> own <b>wife</b> remains <b>permitted</b> to him.
It might have been thought that his own marriage, which caused this to be an act of forbidden sexual relations, would also be adversely affected. <b>But</b> the Gemara adds that <b>we do not say: Since his brother-in-law’s wife is forbidden to his brother-in-law, his wife is</b> likewise <b>forbidden to him.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The reason is <b>that if</b> the mishna follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> his wife <b>is</b> now considered, with regard to him, the <b>sister of his divorcée.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>None of those with whom relations are forbidden by Torah law require a bill of divorce from him,</b> even if he married them in a proper manner, <b>apart from a married woman who married</b> by mistake <b>by</b> permission of <b>the court. And Rabbi Akiva adds: Also a brother’s wife and a wife’s sister.</b> Since it is possible that these two women could become permitted to him, by levirate marriage in the case of a brother’s wife, or a wife’s sister after his wife’s death, they too require a bill of divorce. <b>And</b> with regard to the issue at hand, <b>since Rabbi Akiva said</b> that a wife’s sister <b>requires a bill of divorce,</b> this factor <b>by itself</b> indicates that his wife is <b>forbidden to him, as</b> his wife <b>is</b> considered <b>the sister of his divorcée.</b>
The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>And wasn’t it stated with regard to</b> this case that <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>this brother’s wife,</b> mentioned by Rabbi Akiva, <b>what are the circumstances? For example, if his brother betrothed a woman and</b> then <b>went overseas, and</b> the man who was here <b>heard that his brother was dead, and he arose and married his</b> brother’s <b>wife</b> as a <i>yevama</i>. The reason for Rabbi Akiva’s ruling is <b>that</b> uninformed <b>people will say: This first one had a condition in the betrothal</b> with his wife, and his betrothal was canceled because the condition was left unfulfilled, <b>and this</b> other <b>one married well,</b> in compliance with the <i>halakha</i>, as she was not his brother’s wife. It is for this reason that Rabbi Akiva requires him to give her a bill of divorce.
<b>And</b> in <b>this</b> case of <b>a wife’s sister as well, what are the circumstances? For example, if he betrothed a woman and she went overseas, and he heard she died</b> and <b>arose and married her sister. As people will say: This first one, he had a condition in her betrothal,</b> and as the condition was not fulfilled the betrothal is annulled, <b>and this</b> other <b>one married well. However,</b> with regard to the case of the mishna, which involves an actual previous <b>marriage, can it be said</b> that <b>he had a condition in the marriage?</b> There is a presumption that no man marries a woman conditionally. Once he marries her, it is assumed that he waived all prior conditions, and therefore even Rabbi Akiva agrees that a bill of divorce is not required in this case.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: If</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, let him also teach</b> the case of <b>his mother-in-law,</b> as she is another forbidden woman who nevertheless requires a bill of divorce, <b>as we have heard him, Rabbi Akiva, say:</b> One who has relations with his <b>mother-in-law after</b> his wife’s <b>death is not</b> liable to being executed by <b>burning,</b> because the prohibition lapses upon his wife’s death.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states, with regard to one who takes a woman and her daughter: <b>“They shall be burned in fire, he and they [<i>et’hen</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 20:14). Now this cannot literally mean that both women are burned, as the first woman he took did not sin at all. The Sages therefore explained that the word <i>et’hen</i> <b>means he and one of them [<i>mehen</i>].</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: He and both of them.</b> Since it is hard to understand how they could both deserve punishment, the <i>amora’im</i> suggested various interpretations of Rabbi Akiva’s opinion.
<b>Granted,</b> this makes sense <b>according to</b> the explanation of this dispute suggested by <b>Abaye, who said</b> that the <b>interpretation of the meaning</b> of the verse <b>is</b> the difference <b>between them.</b> In other words, Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva did not argue over the <i>halakha</i> itself, but merely over the manner in which the <i>halakha</i> is derived from the Torah. <b>That</b> is, <b>Rabbi Yishmael holds</b> that <b>it states: One</b> woman, and the plain meaning of the verse is: He and one of them. <b>And Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>it states: Two,</b> e.g., if he took two women who were both forbidden to him, such as his mother-in-law and her mother, they are both liable to be executed by burning. If this is the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael, it is <b>fine,</b> as there is no proof from here that the prohibition of a mother-in-law lapses upon his wife’s death.
<b>However,</b> there is a difficulty <b>according to</b> the explanation of <b>Rava, who said</b> that <b>the</b> practical difference <b>between</b> Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva’s opinion concerns <b>one’s mother-in-law after</b> his wife’s <b>death.</b> Rabbi Yishmael maintains that even after the death of one’s wife he is liable for marrying his mother-in-law. Rabbi Akiva maintains that one is liable only if both women are alive, as the verse mentions two women, but if the first one has already died his relations with the second woman are no longer punishable by Torah law. If so, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, according to Rabbi Akiva, <b>also teach</b> that one must give a bill of divorce to his <b>mother-in-law</b> whom he married by mistake, as she too will be permitted to him after his wife’s death.
Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>Granted</b> that <b>the verse excluded her from</b> the punishment of <b>burning, did the verse</b> also <b>exclude her from a prohibition?</b> Even Rabbi Akiva agrees that the Torah prohibits a man from marrying his mother-in-law after his wife’s death. Consequently, he cannot marry her in a permitted manner, despite the fact that according to Rava’s explanation Rabbi Akiva maintains that they are not executed by burning.
§ The Gemara asks another question, from a different perspective: <b>And let</b> his wife <b>be forbidden by</b> his <b>sexual relations</b> with <b>her sister, just as it is in</b> the case of <b>a woman whose husband went overseas,</b> who is forbidden to her husband if she had relations with another man by mistake. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not comparable.</b> With regard to <b>his wife, who is forbidden</b> to him <b>by Torah</b> law if she committed adultery <b>intentionally, the Sages decreed concerning her</b> that she is forbidden to him even if she did so <b>unwittingly.</b>

Daf 95a

However, with regard to <b>a wife’s sister,</b> where even if the sister sins <b>intentionally</b> the wife <b>is not forbidden</b> to him <b>by Torah</b> law, if he did so <b>unwittingly the Sages did not decree with regard to him. And from where do we</b> derive <b>that she is not forbidden? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in the verse: “A man, when his wife goes aside…and a man lies <b>with her”</b> (Numbers 5:12–13), the emphasis of “her” teaches: It is <b>her intercourse</b> with another man that <b>renders her forbidden</b> to her husband, <b>but the intercourse of her sister does not render her forbidden.</b>
<b>As,</b> were it not for this verse, one <b>might</b> have thought: Could this <b>not</b> be derived through <b>an</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: And if in</b> a case <b>where he has relations subject to a light prohibition, the one causing</b> her to be rendered <b>prohibited is forbidden,</b> then <b>in</b> a situation <b>where he has intercourse subject to a severe prohibition, is it not right that the one causing</b> her to be rendered <b>prohibited</b> should be <b>forbidden?</b> This <i>a fortiori</i> inference will be explained later in the Gemara.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to one who has relations with his mother-in-law, that he renders his wife disqualified</b> from remaining married to him. <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>did they disagree? With regard to one who has relations with his wife’s sister, as Beit Shammai say</b> that <b>he renders</b> his wife <b>disqualified, and Beit Hillel say he does not render</b> her <b>disqualified. Rabbi Yosei said:</b> Not so, as <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to one who has relations with his wife’s sister, that he does not render his wife disqualified</b> from remaining married to him. <b>With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to one who has relations with his mother-in-law, as Beit Shammai say he renders</b> his wife <b>disqualified and Beit Hillel say he does not render</b> her <b>disqualified.</b>
Rabbi Yosei explains why Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to the case of one who has relations with his wife’s sister. This is <b>because at first,</b> before the marriage, <b>he is permitted to all the women in the world and she is permitted to all the men in the world.</b> After <b>he</b> has <b>betrothed</b> her as his wife, <b>he renders her forbidden</b> to all men, <b>and she renders him forbidden</b> to her relatives. Consequently, the <b>prohibition by which</b> he <b>renders her forbidden</b> is <b>greater than</b> the <b>prohibition by which</b> she <b>renders him forbidden, as he renders her forbidden to all</b> the <b>men in the world and she renders him forbidden</b> by their betrothal <b>only to her relatives.</b>
Rabbi Yosei’s explanation continues. Could this <i>halakha</i> of a wife’s sister <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: And if he prohibited her</b> through their betrothal <b>to all men in the world,</b> and yet she was <b>unwitting with one forbidden to her,</b> i.e., she had relations with another man by mistake, <b>she is not forbidden to</b> he who is <b>permitted to her,</b> her husband; <b>she, who prohibited him only to her relatives,</b> if <b>he was unwitting with one forbidden to him,</b> her sister, <b>is it not right that we should not render him forbidden to</b> her, she who is <b>permitted to him,</b> namely his wife?
<b>And this is the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> and the reason for the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an unwitting</b> sinner, i.e., that if he had unwitting relations with one of his wife’s relations the wife is not thereby rendered forbidden to him. <b>With regard to</b> one whose act was <b>intentional, from where</b> is the <i>halakha</i> derived? <b>The verse states: “Her,”</b> meaning that it is <b>her intercourse</b> with another man that <b>renders her forbidden</b> to her husband, <b>but the intercourse of her</b> husband with <b>her sister does not render her forbidden</b> to him.
<b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that one who has intercourse with his mother-in-law is forbidden to his wife? <b>As it is written: “They shall be burned in fire, he and they”</b> (Leviticus 20:14). This verse is puzzling: <b>And shall the entire house be</b> punished by <b>burning?</b> Why should both women be punished when only one of them transgressed? <b>If it does not</b> refer to <b>the matter</b> of <b>burning, refer it to</b> the matter of <b>a prohibition,</b> that they are both forbidden to him. This teaches that he is forbidden not only to the woman with whom he sinned, but also to his wife.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> individual <b>performed a transgression</b> by having relations <b>with his mother-in-law. Rav Yehuda had him brought</b> for judgment and ordered that he <b>be flogged. He said to him: If</b> it were <b>not</b> for the fact that <b>Shmuel said the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, I would render</b> your wife <b>forbidden to you permanently.</b>
§ At the start of the <i>baraita</i> the <i>tanna</i> stated an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that is not entirely clear: If in a place where he has relations subject to a light prohibition, the one causing her to be rendered prohibited is forbidden. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <b>light prohibition? Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is referring to one who <b>remarries his divorcée after she married</b> another man.
The Gemara explains that according to this interpretation the <i>a fortiori</i> inference should be understood as follows: If <b>this one,</b> the second husband, <b>has relations with her, he has rendered her forbidden to that one,</b> the first husband. And if the second man divorced her and then <b>the other one,</b> the first husband, <b>had relations with her, he has</b> likewise <b>rendered her forbidden to this one.</b> This demonstrates that even with regard to a light prohibition the man who renders her forbidden is also forbidden by this intercourse.
The Gemara refutes this interpretation: <b>What</b> about the fact <b>that one who remarries his divorcée after she married</b> another man cannot be considered to have violated a light prohibition, as the prohibition is stringent in several regards: <b>As the body is defiled</b> by this intercourse, for the Torah states “after she has been defiled” (Deuteronomy 24:4); <b>and her prohibition</b> applies <b>to the majority</b> of the Jewish people, not to select groups; <b>and her prohibition</b> is <b>an irrevocable prohibition,</b> as she is no longer permitted to her first husband after having relations with her second husband. This last stringency is not true of his wife’s sister, who is permitted to him after the death of his wife.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects this explanation in favor of the following one that <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to relations with a <b><i>yevama</i>,</b> which is called a light prohibition, as the man who has relations with her is forbidden to her. The Gemara clarifies: With regard to this <b><i>yevama</i>, with whom</b> did she engage in intercourse? <b>If we say</b> that she had relations <b>with another</b> man, not her <i>yavam</i>, this would mean that the ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna. As Rav Hamnuna said: A widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> who engaged in licentious sexual relations</b> with another man is <b>forbidden to her <i>yavam</i>.</b> The argument would be as follows: Although the <i>yavam</i> renders the <i>yevama</i> forbidden to every other man, if she has relations with another she becomes forbidden to him as well.
However, this argument can also be challenged: <b>What</b> about the fact <b>that</b> in the case of <b>a <i>yevama</i></b> who engages in this forbidden relationship, <b>the body is defiled and her prohibition</b> applies equally <b>to the majority</b> of the people. Therefore, one cannot derive the prohibitions of one’s wife’s relatives from this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to a case of <b>a <i>yevama</i> to the brothers,</b> as follows: If <b>this</b> brother <b>performed levirate betrothal [<i>ma’amar</i>] with her he has rendered her forbidden to that one,</b> the other brothers, as she is effectively betrothed to him. If one of the <b>other</b> brothers, who had not performed levirate betrothal with her, subsequently <b>has relations with her, he has rendered her forbidden to this one</b> who had performed levirate betrothal with her. The Gemara asks: If that is the meaning of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>why specifically</b> state <b>that</b> the <b>second had relations with her? Even</b> if <b>he performed levirate betrothal with her too,</b> he thereby renders her forbidden to the first brother, which proves that it is not the act of intercourse itself that causes the prohibition.
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as it can be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, who said: There is no levirate betrothal after a levirate betrothal,</b> i.e., if one brother performed levirate betrothal with the <i>yevama</i>, no other levirate betrothal is of any effect. <b>However,</b> this explanation can still be refuted, as her prohibition to the <i>yavam</i> is not due to the act of intercourse, as <b>even</b> if the other brother <b>gave her a bill of divorce,</b> or <b>even</b> if <b>he performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with her,</b> he has likewise rendered her forbidden to the first brother, who performed levirate betrothal.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The light prohibition is that of <b>a <i>sota</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: This <b><i>sota</i>, to whom</b> is she forbidden? <b>If we say</b> that she is forbidden <b>to the husband,</b> the explanation would be as follows: If her <b>husband has relations with her,</b> despite the fact that she is forbidden to him after she disobeyed his warning not to seclude herself with a certain man, he <b>has rendered her forbidden to the fornicator,</b> as she is barred from marrying him even if her husband divorces her. However, <b>why</b> is this true <b>specifically</b> in a case in which he <b>had relations with her? Even</b> if her husband only <b>gave her a bill of divorce</b> and did not have relations with her after her seclusion, <b>or even</b> if <b>he said: I</b> will not force her <b>to drink</b> the waters of a <i>sota</i>, she is likewise forbidden to the other man.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a <i>sota</i></b> who had relations <b>with the fornicator,</b> thereby rendering herself permanently forbidden to her husband, as she was a married woman at the time. Yet this too is puzzling: <b>Is this a light prohibition? It is a severe prohibition, as this is</b> the prohibition proscribing <b>a married woman,</b> one of the most serious of all prohibitions.

Daf 95b

<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the light prohibition is actually that of <b>a married woman. And similarly, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a married woman. And</b> for <b>what</b> reason does the <i>tanna</i> <b>call</b> this <b>a light prohibition?</b> The reason is that it differs from and is more lenient than other prohibitions in <b>that</b> her husband, <b>who renders her forbidden, does not render her forbidden for his whole lifetime,</b> as he can negate the prohibition by giving her a bill of divorce. <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Ḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Elazar:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a married woman.</b>
