If <b>the</b> sons of certain, <b>unflawed</b> lineage were the ones who <b>died,</b> then <b>the mixed</b> sons <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> the widows of <b>the elder woman’s sons but not levirate marriage, as it is uncertain</b> whether she is <b>his brother’s wife or his father’s brother’s wife. With</b> the widows of <b>the</b> certain <b>sons of the daughter-in-law, one</b> of the mixed sons <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> in case she is his brother’s wife. <b>And</b> the other <b>one performs levirate marriage,</b> as even if she is his brother’s son’s wife, she is permitted to him.
In the case of <b>a priestess whose offspring was mixed with her maidservant’s offspring, they may partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as both a priest and the slave of a priest partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And they receive one share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in the granary.</b>

Daf 99b

<b>And they may not become ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse,</b> as each of them might be a priest. <b>And they may not marry women, whether unflawed</b> women, who may not marry a slave, <b>or</b> women <b>unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood, as with regard to each of them it is uncertain whether he is a priest or a slave. If <b>the mixed</b> sons <b>matured and freed each other, they may marry women fit</b> to marry <b>into the priesthood,</b> as a freed slave may marry such women. However, neither may marry a woman unfit for the priesthood, in case he is a priest.
<b>And they may not become ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse,</b> since they are uncertain priests. <b>However, if they became impure, they do not receive the forty</b> lashes, as each of them might not be priest. <b>And they may not partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as one of them is not a priest. <b>However, if they ate</b> <i>teruma</i> unwittingly <b>they do not pay</b> the <b>principal and the</b> additional <b>fifth,</b> as each of them might be a priest. <b>And they do not receive a share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in the granary,</b> as neither can prove that he is a priest. <b>However, they may sell the <i>teruma</i></b> that they remove from their own produce, <b>and</b> although they may not eat it, <b>the money is theirs.</b> Since it cannot be proven with regard to either of them that he is not a priest, <i>teruma</i> cannot be appropriated from them.
<b>And they do not receive a share of the consecrated</b> offerings <b>of the Temple,</b> as each of them might not be a priest. <b>And one may not give them consecrated</b> offerings to sacrifice for the same reason. <b>However,</b> the hides of <b>their own</b> offerings <b>may not be appropriated from their possession,</b> as it cannot be proven with regard to either of them that he is not a priest.
<b>And they are exempt from</b> giving a priest <b>the foreleg, and from</b> giving him <b>the jaw, and from</b> giving him <b>the maw</b> of their non-consecrated kosher animals. <b>And</b> with regard to either of them, the <b>firstling of his</b> kosher animal <b>should graze until it becomes unfit</b> to be sacrificed, i.e., until it gets a blemish. It is against his interest to sacrifice the animal before it gets a blemish, thereby letting it be eaten by the priests. Once it gets a blemish, it cannot be appropriated from him. Since he is possibly a priest, he may claim that the animal is the property of a priest. The animal then becomes his private property, and he may eat it if he wishes. <b>And</b> in general, <b>we place upon him</b> both <b>the stringencies of priests and the stringencies of Israelites.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It is stated in the mishna that if <b>the</b> sons of certain, <b>unflawed</b> lineage were the <b>ones who died,</b> the mixed sons perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with the widows of the elder woman’s sons, but not levirate marriage. The Gemara asks: Does this indicate that <b>because these</b> sons <b>were mixed up they are</b> rendered <b>unfit?</b> The fact that their lineage is unclear should not render them unfit. <b>Rava Pappa said: Say</b> that the correct wording is: <b>And if the certain</b> sons were the ones who <b>died.</b>
It is stated in the mishna that <b>with</b> the widows of <b>the</b> certain <b>sons of the daughter-in-law, one</b> of the mixed sons <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and the other one performs levirate marriage. The Gemara comments that <b><i>ḥalitza</i> is specifically performed</b> first, <b>and afterward levirate marriage. However, levirate marriage is not</b> performed <b>first, because</b> if she is not his own <i>yevama</i> but rather his brother’s daughter-in-law, doing so <b>breaches</b> the prohibition against <b>a <i>yevama</i></b> engaging in intercourse <b>with</b> a member of <b>the public.</b>
§ It is stated in the mishna that in the case of <b>a priestess</b> whose offspring <b>was mixed</b> with her maidservant’s offspring, they receive one share of <i>teruma</i> in the granary. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that they receive <b>one share</b> and no more? Rather, <b>say</b> that they receive <b>a share as one,</b> i.e., they receive a share at the granary only if they come together.
The Gemara comments: According to this modification, <b>we</b> have <b>learned</b> in the mishna a ruling that is <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> that <b>one may distribute <i>teruma</i> to a slave only if his master is with him, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may distribute <i>teruma</i> to the slave</b> of a priest who is possibly a priest himself <b>only if his master is with him;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <i>teruma</i> is distributed to him alone, even without the accompaniment of his master, as <b>he can say: If I am a priest, give me</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>due to my</b> own priesthood, <b>and if I am the slave of a priest, give me due to my master.</b>
The Gemara explains the background behind this dispute: <b>In Rabbi Yehuda’s place, they would elevate</b> a person <b>to</b> the presumptive status of priesthood for the purpose of <b>lineage on</b> the basis of his having received <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> If they saw a person receive <i>teruma</i>, they would assume that he is a priest and testify to that effect. Therefore, <i>teruma</i> was not distributed to someone who might be a slave, unless he was accompanied by his master, lest the slave be assumed to be a priest himself. Conversely, <b>in Rabbi Yosei’s place they would not elevate</b> a person <b>to</b> the presumptive status of priestly <b>lineage</b> on the basis of his having received <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Therefore, he was allowed to receive <i>teruma</i> independently.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok said: In</b> all <b>my days I never</b> had the opportunity to <b>testify</b> in court, <b>besides one testimony, and they promoted a slave to</b> the presumptive status of <b>priesthood on</b> the basis of <b>my word.</b> Although they presumably examined the matter carefully, an error occurred.
The Gemara asks: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that <b>they</b> actually <b>promoted</b> him? <b>Now</b> consider: If, even <b>through the animals of the righteous, the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not bring</b> about <b>a stumbling block,</b> then through <b>the righteous themselves, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> so that He does not bring about stumbling blocks?
<b>Rather, say</b> that this is what Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok meant: <b>They sought to promote a slave to</b> the presumptive status of <b>priesthood on</b> the basis of <b>my word.</b> How did this happen? Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok <b>saw</b> a man receiving <i>teruma</i> <b>in Rabbi Yosei’s locale and went and testified in Rabbi Yehuda’s locale</b> about what he saw, not realizing that this testimony would be sufficient grounds to assume that the man is a priest. Since <i>teruma</i> is distributed there only to priests, the slave was almost promoted to the presumptive status of priesthood erroneously.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> There are <b>ten</b> types of priests <b>to whom one may not distribute <i>teruma</i> in the granary, and they are: A deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, a person whose sexual organs are concealed [<i>tumtum</i>], and a hermaphrodite, and a slave, and a woman, and an uncircumcised man, and a ritually impure man, and</b> one who <b>marries a woman</b> who is <b>unfit for him,</b> i.e., who is unfit to marry a priest. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them, one may send</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>to them, to their homes, with the exception of a ritually impure man and</b> one who <b>marries a woman</b> who is <b>unfit for him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> <i>teruma</i> may not be distributed to <b>a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> as <b>they are not competent,</b> and it is unbecoming to give them <i>teruma</i> in public. It is <b>also</b> inappropriate to distribute <i>teruma</i> to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite,</b>

Daf 100a

as <b>they are</b> each an unusual <b>creature of</b> their <b>own</b> kind. With regard to <b>a slave</b> it is <b>also</b> clear, since if he is given <b><i>teruma</i>, perhaps</b> the court <b>will come to elevate</b> him <b>to</b> the presumptive status of priestly <b>lineage.</b> <i>Teruma</i> may not be distributed to <b>an uncircumcised man and a ritually impure man, because</b> these situations <b>are repulsive</b> and it is unseemly to give them <i>teruma</i> in public. One may not distribute <i>teruma</i> to <b>one who marries a woman unfit for him, due to a penalty</b> that expropriates his priestly rights as long as he persists in his transgression. <b>But</b> for <b>what reason</b> is <i>teruma</i> <b>not</b> distributed to <b>a woman?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, disagree</b> on this issue. <b>One said</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the case of an Israelite woman who was married to a priest and got divorced, thereby losing her permission to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <i>Teruma</i> is not distributed to women in public at all, lest this <b>divorcée</b> continue to receive <i>teruma</i>. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the concern that the owner and the woman might <b>be alone together</b> in the granary.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them?</b> The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> is in the case of <b>a granary that is close to town but is not frequented by people.</b> Because it is close to town, the owner of the granary would know if she was divorced. However, since there are not many people there, the concern about their being alone together remains. <b>Alternatively,</b> there is a practical difference in the case of a granary <b>that is distant but is frequented by people.</b> There, there is concern that the owner of the granary might not know if she was divorced, but the concern that they might be alone together does not exist.
It is stated in the <i>baraita</i> under discussion: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them, one may send</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>to them, to their homes, with the exception of a ritually impure man and</b> one <b>who marries a woman unfit for him.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>However, to an uncircumcised man one may send</b> it. <b>What is the reason?</b> How does he differ from an impure man?
The Gemara answers: One may send him <i>teruma</i>. It is <b>because of circumstances beyond his control,</b> i.e., the death of his brothers from their circumcision, that he was not circumcised. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t an impure man also</b> in his state due to <b>circumstances beyond his control?</b> Why is <i>teruma</i> not sent to him? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> man is uncircumcised because of <b>circumstances entirely beyond his control,</b> as circumcision is considered life-threatening for him, <b>whereas that</b> impure man <b>is not under circumstances entirely beyond his control,</b> as one can protect himself from ritual impurity.
§ <b>The Sages taught: One may not distribute <i>teruma</i> to a slave or a woman</b> if they are <b>in the granary. And in a place where</b> people do <b>distribute</b> it to them, <b>the woman is given first and released immediately.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <b>saying?</b> If one may not distribute <i>teruma</i> to them, how can there be a place where it is distributed?
The Gemara explains that this statement is not referring to <i>teruma</i>. <b>This is what it is saying: In a case where the poor man’s tithe is distributed</b> to the poor from the owner’s house, <b>the woman is given</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>first. What is the reason?</b> She is given the tithe first <b>because</b> it is <b>demeaning</b> for a woman to have to wait in the company of men for a lengthy period of time.
<b>Rava said: Initially, when a man and a woman would come for judgment before me,</b> each for a different case, <b>I would resolve the man’s quarrel first. I would say that</b> since <b>he is obligated in</b> many positive <b>mitzvot</b> I should not waste his time by causing him to wait. However, <b>since I heard this</b> <i>baraita</i>, <b>I resolve the woman’s quarrel first. What is the reason?</b> I resolve her quarrel first <b>because</b> it is <b>demeaning</b> for her to be waiting in the company of men.
§ It is stated in the mishna: If <b>the mixed</b> sons <b>matured</b> and <b>freed</b> each other, they may marry women fit for the priesthood. The use of the past tense indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies after the fact. <b>If one</b> of the sons <b>desires</b> to free the other, he may, but <b>if he does not desire</b> to do so, he is <b>not</b> obligated. <b>And why</b> not? <b>Neither</b> of them <b>can marry a maidservant</b> in case he is a priest, <b>nor can</b> either of them marry <b>a free woman,</b> as he might be a slave. They are therefore unable to fulfill the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply in their current state and should be obligated to free each other. <b>Rava said: Say</b> that the mishna means that <b>we coerce them and they free each other.</b>
It is stated in the mishna that <b>we place upon them</b> both <b>the stringencies of priests and the stringencies of Israelites.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this stated, beyond those cited specifically in the mishna? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is stated with regard <b>to their meal-offering: The handful is taken from it like the meal-offering of an Israelite,</b> unlike that of a priest, which is burned in its entirety. <b>However,</b> the offering <b>does not get eaten, like the meal-offering of priests. How so?</b> How is the practice performed so that both stringencies are kept? <b>The handful is sacrificed</b> and burned <b>by itself, and the remainder</b> of the offering <b>is offered by itself.</b>
The Gemara asks: How can it be performed in this manner? There is a principle that should <b>apply here,</b> that <b>whatever is partly</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> on the altar <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>“you may not make…as an offering”</b> (Leviticus 2:11). This principle states that if part of an item, e.g., the blood of an animal offering or the handful of a meal-offering, is burned on the altar, then burning any of its other parts, which are not designated for burning, is prohibited. How, then, can the remainder of the meal-offering be sacrificed?
<b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, said that</b> the remainder <b>is brought up</b> to the altar only <b>for the purpose of wood,</b> i.e., as fuel for the altar, not as an offering. In this manner, it is permitted. This answer is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> “But they shall not come up <b>for a sweet savor</b> on the altar” (Leviticus 2:12). This verse indicates that <b>you may not bring up</b> leaven and honey as a “sweet savor,” i.e., an offering. <b>However, you may bring up</b> leaven, and honey, and other materials <b>for the purpose of wood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to Rabbi Elazar. However, according to the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Elazar and hold that it may not be burned for the purpose of fuel, <b>what can be said?</b> What is to be done with the remainder? The Gemara answers <b>that</b> the offering <b>is treated in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: The handful is sacrificed by itself, and the remainder is scattered over the place of the ashes. And even the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, only with regard to a sinner’s meal-offering that belongs to priests, as it is fit to be sacrificed</b> in its entirety. <b>However, here,</b> in the case of an uncertain priest, <b>even the Rabbis agree</b> that the remainder is scattered over the ashes, as it cannot be offered in case he is a non-priest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a woman <b>who did not wait three months after</b> separating from <b>her husband, and remarried and gave birth</b> to a son, <b>and it is not known if he was born after nine</b> months of pregnancy <b>to the former</b> husband or <b>if he was born after seven</b> months <b>to the latter</b> husband, if <b>she had sons</b> of certain patrilineage <b>from the first</b> husband <b>and sons</b> of certain patrilineage <b>from the second</b> one, and the son of uncertain patrilineage married and died childless, then the brothers from both husbands <b>must perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with his wife, as they might be his paternal brothers. <b>But they may not perform levirate marriage</b> with her, in case he is only their maternal half brother, and his wife is forbidden to them. <b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>him and their</b> wives, if one of them dies childless, <b>he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and not levirate marriage.</b>

Daf 100b

If <b>he had</b> half <b>brothers from the first</b> husband <b>and</b> half <b>brothers from the second, not from the same mother</b> but from the same father, <b>he performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or levirate marriage</b> with their widows. If he is indeed their paternal half brother, then the widows are his <i>yevamot</i>; if not, he may marry them like any other man. <b>And</b> similarly, with regard to <b>them</b> and his wife, <b>one</b> half brother from one father <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and one</b> from the other father <b>performs levirate marriage.</b>
If <b>one</b> of his two uncertain fathers <b>was an Israelite and one</b> was <b>a priest, he may marry</b> only <b>a woman fit to</b> marry <b>a priest,</b> due to the possibility that he is a priest. <b>And he may not become ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse</b> because he might be a priest. <b>But if he became impure, he does not receive the forty</b> lashes, as he might be a non-priest. Likewise, <b>he does not partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> in case he is a non-priest. <b>However, if he ate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>he does not pay</b> the <b>principal and the</b> additional <b>fifth,</b> as he might be a priest. <b>And he does not receive</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>at the granary. However, he may sell the <i>teruma</i></b> of his own produce <b>and the money is his.</b> It cannot be taken away from him due to the uncertainty with regard to his status.
<b>And he does not receive a share of the sacred of the consecrated</b> offerings, <b>and one may not give him the consecrated</b> offerings to sacrifice. <b>However,</b> the hides of <b>his own</b> offerings <b>may not be appropriated from his possession. And he is exempt from</b> giving a priest <b>the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw</b> of his non-consecrated animals. <b>And the firstling of his</b> animal <b>should graze until it becomes unfit</b> to be sacrificed because it gets a blemish. <b>And</b> in general, <b>we place upon him the stringencies of priests and the stringencies of Israelites.</b>
If <b>both</b> uncertain fathers <b>were priests,</b> then if they die <b>he is in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning over</b> each of <b>them,</b> in case the deceased is his father. <b>And</b> if he dies, <b>they are</b> both <b>in a</b> state of <b>acute mourning over him,</b> as one of them is his father. <b>He may not become ritually impure to</b> bury <b>them,</b> as each one may not be his relative, <b>and they may not become ritually impure to</b> bury <b>him</b> for the same reason. <b>He does not inherit</b> from <b>them,</b> as the heirs of both husbands can reject his claims. <b>However, they inherit</b> from <b>him</b> if he has no sons and split his inheritance equally.
<b>And he is exempt</b> from capital punishment <b>for striking and for cursing</b> both <b>this</b> father <b>and that one.</b> Although one who strikes or curses his father or mother is liable to receive the death penalty, he cannot be held liable, as it is unknown which of the men is his father. <b>He must ascend</b> to the Temple service <b>with the priestly watch of this</b> father <b>and of that one,</b> as he belongs to one of these watches and is obligated to serve with them. <b>However, he does not receive a share</b> of the portion of the offerings that gets eaten, as the members of each watch can claim that he is a member of the other watch. <b>If both</b> uncertain fathers <b>were in one priestly watch, he receives one share,</b> as he certainly belongs to that watch.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna stated that if the son has paternal half brothers from each of his two uncertain fathers and he dies childless, a half brother from one father performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and the other performs levirate marriage. The Gemara comments that <b><i>ḥalitza</i> is specifically performed</b> first <b>and</b> only <b>afterward levirate marriage. However, levirate marriage is not</b> performed <b>first, as</b> that <b>would breach</b> the prohibition against <b>a <i>yevama</i></b> engaging in intercourse <b>with</b> a member of <b>the public</b> in the event that she is not his <i>yevama</i> but rather the <i>yevama</i> of the other half brother.
<b>Shmuel said</b> that if <b>ten priests were standing</b> in one place, <b>and one of them,</b> who is unidentified, <b>left</b> the group <b>and engaged in intercourse</b> with a woman, and she gave birth, <b>the child is a silenced one,</b> i.e., a child whose father’s identity is not known. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase <b>silenced one [<i>shetuki</i>]</b> in this regard? <b>If we say that he is silenced from</b> any claim to <b>his father’s property,</b> this <b>is obvious; do we know who his father is? Rather,</b> it means <b>that he is silenced from the status of priesthood,</b> as well. Although his father certainly is a priest, he is not given this status.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers that the <b>verse states: “And it shall be to him and to his seed after him,</b> the covenant of an everlasting priesthood” (Numbers 25:13). It is derived from “and to his seed after him” that <b>we require</b> a priest’s <b>descendants</b> to be <b>attributed to his lineage, and</b> here that is not the case, as <b>there is no</b> certain father.
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to this: However, if that is so, since</b> the same phrase <b>is written with regard to Abraham: “To be a God to you and to your seed after you”</b> (Genesis 17:7), <b>what is the Merciful One warning him there?</b> Can it possibly mean that one who cannot identify his parents is not obligated to serve God as a Jew? The Gemara answers that <b>this is what He said to him: You may not marry a gentile woman or a maidservant, so that</b> the status of <b>your offspring will not follow her</b> status, as the child of a Jewish man and a gentile woman or maidservant receives the status of his mother.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> A <i>baraita</i> (37a) teaches that if a priest performed levirate marriage with his brother’s wife within three months of his brother’s death, and she gave birth to a son who is either her deceased husband’s son or her brother-in-law’s son, this <b>first</b> son born after the levirate marriage <b>is fit</b> even <b>to be a High Priest. But don’t we require his descendants</b> to be <b>attributed to his lineage, and that is not so</b> in this case, as the father’s identity is unknown? The Gemara answers: The requirement that <b>his descendants</b> be <b>attributed to his lineage is rabbinic</b> law, <b>and the verse is a mere support,</b> not the actual source. <b>And when the Sages decreed</b> that one whose father’s identity is unknown is not a priest, they did so only <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>licentious</b> intercourse. <b>With regard to</b> a case of <b>marriage,</b> as is the case in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>the Sages did not</b> apply the <b>decree.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to</b> a case of <b>licentious</b> intercourse, <b>did the Sages</b> in fact issue <b>a decree? Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna about a woman <b>who did not wait three months after</b> separating from <b>her husband and remarried and gave birth</b> to a son?
<b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>After</b> separating from <b>her husband? If we say</b> it means <b>after her husband’s death, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If they die, <b>he is in a</b> state of <b>acute mourning over</b> each of <b>them, and</b> if he dies, <b>they are</b> both <b>in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning over him. Granted,</b> if they die, <b>he is in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning over them. You find</b> this case <b>with regard to</b> his uncertain father from his mother’s <b>marriage to the second man.</b> If the second husband dies, the child must mourn for him, <b>and</b> he is also in a state of acute mourning following <b>the gathering of the bones of the first</b> husband, who died before he was born. When the bones of a person who was buried are dug up for proper burial in his ancestor’s plot, his relatives mourn for him a second time. <b>But</b> with regard to the statement that if he dies <b>they are in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning for him, how can you find these</b> circumstances? <b>The first</b> husband <b>is</b> already <b>dead.</b>
<b>And</b> assume the mishna’s statement is <b>rather with regard to a divorcée. And</b> accordingly <b>what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>After</b> separating from <b>her husband?</b> It means: <b>After</b> she received <b>a bill of divorce</b> from <b>her husband.</b> If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>He may not become impure to</b> bury <b>them, and they may not become impure to</b> bury <b>him. Granted, they may not become impure to</b> bury <b>him, as</b> the ruling is <b>stringent, as</b> with regard to <b>each one</b> of them <b>perhaps he is not his son. However, why may he not become impure to</b> bury <b>them?</b>
<b>Granted, for the second one he should not become impure,</b> as he might not be his son. <b>However, for the first he should</b> be allowed to <b>become impure whichever way you</b> view it: <b>If he is his son, it is appropriate for him to become impure to</b> bury <b>him,</b> as even a priest must become ritually impure to bury his father. <b>And if he is the son of the latter one, it is appropriate for him to become impure to</b> bury <b>him, as he,</b> the son, <b>is a <i>ḥalal</i>.</b> If his mother is a divorcée, his father, the latter husband, is prohibited as a priest to marry her, and a child born from this relationship is a <i>ḥalal</i>, who is unfit for the priesthood. There would then be no prohibition against his becoming ritually impure.
<b>Rather, is</b> the mishna’s statement <b>not with regard to</b> the <b>licentious</b> intercourse of an unmarried woman? <b>And what is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>After</b> she separated from <b>her husband [<i>ba’ala</i>]?</b> Is it not: <b>After</b> separating from <b>the man with whom she engaged in intercourse [<i>bo’ala</i>],</b> meaning that she engaged in intercourse with a man less than three months before marrying another man, and therefore she does not know the identity of the father? <b>And it is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna that the son <b>ascends</b> to the Temple service <b>with the priestly watch of this one and of that one,</b> which implies that he is considered a priest, although the identity of his father is uncertain due to the licentious intercourse of his mother. <b>And</b> this appears to be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b>
<b>Rav Shemaya said:</b> The mishna’s statement <b>pertains to a girl who refused</b> her husband. A minor girl who was orphaned from her father may be married off by her brothers. However, she may subsequently refuse her husband before reaching majority. This nullifies the marriage entirely, so she is not considered a divorcée, for whom it is prohibited to marry a priest. In the case of the mishna, she did not wait three months after her refusal before marrying again, so she does not know who the father of her child is.
The Gemara asks: <b>Can a girl who refuses</b> her husband <b>give birth? Didn’t Rav Beivai teach before Rav Naḥman</b> that <b>women</b> in <b>three</b> situations <b>may engage in intercourse with</b> a contraceptive <b>resorbent,</b> despite the fact that this practice is generally prohibited: <b>A minor girl, a pregnant woman, and a nursing woman? A minor girl</b> may do so <b>lest she become pregnant and die,</b> as the fetus might endanger her life. <b>A pregnant woman</b> may do so <b>lest</b> she get pregnant a second time and <b>her</b> previous <b>fetus becomes a sandal,</b> i.e., it is squashed by the pressure of the second fetus. <b>A nursing woman</b> may do so <b>lest she wean her child</b> prematurely, as pregnancy will cause her milk to dry up, <b>and he will die</b> of hunger. <b>And who is</b> considered <b>a minor girl</b> in this context? A girl <b>from</b> the <b>age</b> of <b>eleven years and one day until</b> the <b>age</b> of <b>twelve years and one day.</b> If she is <b>younger than this or older than this, she should go ahead and engage in intercourse in her usual manner.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Both <b>this one and that one,</b> i.e., women in any cases, <b>should go ahead and engage in intercourse in their usual manner, and Heaven will have mercy</b> and prevent them from getting pregnant, <b>as it is stated: “The Lord preserves the simple”</b> (Psalms 116:6). Evidently, a girl who is a minor and therefore young enough to refuse her husband cannot become pregnant without endangering her health.
The Gemara answers: <b>You find</b> a solution <b>in</b> the case of <b>a mistaken betrothal.</b> For example, if the first husband betrothed her conditionally and the condition was unfulfilled, the marriage is nullified. This woman may marry a priest. If she did so within three months, the identity of her child’s father is uncertain, which fits the statement in the mishna. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Shmuel said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> The verse states with regard to a <i>sota</i>: <b>“Neither was she [<i>hi</i>] coerced in the act”</b> (Numbers 5:13). It may be inferred that she is <b>forbidden</b> to her husband only if she was not coerced by the adulterer; if <b>she was coerced she is permitted</b> to him.
<b>And</b> the superfluous word “she” indicates that <b>you have another woman who, although she</b> engaged in intercourse willingly and <b>was not coerced, is</b> nevertheless <b>permitted</b> to her husband, as the intercourse is not considered adultery. <b>And who is this? This</b> is referring to a woman <b>whose betrothal was a mistaken betrothal, as even if her child is riding on her shoulders, she may refuse</b> her husband <b>and go off</b> on <b>her</b> way. She is considered an unmarried woman, and she is therefore permitted to return to her husband, even if she engaged in intercourse with another man. The mishna may therefore be explained in a way that does not contradict Shmuel.

Daf 101a

§ It is stated in the mishna that if <b>both</b> uncertain fathers <b>were priests,</b> the son is exempt from punishment for striking and for cursing them. <b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>he struck this</b> uncertain father, <b>and then struck that one,</b> or if <b>he cursed this one and then cursed that one,</b> or if <b>he cursed both of them simultaneously</b> or <b>struck both of them simultaneously,</b> in all these cases <b>he is liable</b> to receive capital punishment, as one of them is certainly his father. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Although if he struck or cursed both of them <b>simultaneously he is liable,</b> if he struck or cursed them <b>one after the other, he is exempt.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He is exempt</b> even if he struck or cursed them <b>simultaneously?</b> The Gemara answers: These are the opinions of <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> and they each expressed their opinion <b>in accordance with</b> that <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of the one who exempts</b> the son from punishment? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: Blessing is stated below</b> (Leviticus 20:9), with regard to cursing parents, <b>and blessing is stated above</b> (Exodus 22:27), with regard to cursing God. The Sages used the word blessing as a euphemism for cursing, as it was their custom to avoid uncouth language. <b>Just as</b> the statement <b>above,</b> in Exodus, is referring to a curse <b>that does not involve partnership,</b> as God is One, <b>so too</b> the statement <b>below,</b> in Leviticus, is referring exclusively to a curse of a parent <b>that does not involve partnership,</b> i.e., when there is no doubt with regard to his identity. <b>And striking is juxtaposed with cursing.</b> Just as one is not liable for cursing when it is unclear who his father is, the same applies to striking.
§ It is stated in the mishna: <b>And he ascends</b> to the Temple service <b>with the priestly watch</b> of both uncertain fathers. However, he does not receive a share of the offerings of either watch. The Gemara asks: <b>Since he does not receive a share, why does he ascend?</b> The Gemara is puzzled by this question: <b>Why does he ascend? Doesn’t he</b> naturally <b>say: I wish to perform a mitzva</b> by serving as a priest? The Gemara explains: <b>However,</b> note that the mishna <b>does not state:</b> If <b>he ascended, but rather: He ascends,</b> in the present tense. Apparently he is obligated to ascend, even <b>against his will.</b> 
Why is he under obligation to serve in the Temple? <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ḥanina said</b> that <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is obligated <b>due to</b> the potential <b>family flaw,</b> i.e., harm to the family name. If he does not serve with these watches, people will infer that both families are unfit for the priesthood, which is not the case.
It is stated in the mishna: <b>And if both</b> uncertain fathers <b>were in one priestly watch,</b> he receives one share. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about the case in which the uncertain fathers belonged to <b>two priestly watches,</b> with regard to which the mishna states <b>that</b> the son <b>does not</b> receive a share, and the case in which they belonged to the same watch? Just <b>as</b> in the case where they belonged to two watches, <b>he goes to this watch</b> to receive a share <b>and they reject him,</b> claiming that he belongs to the other watch, <b>and he goes to that watch and they reject him</b> in the same manner, <b>so too,</b> where they belonged to <b>one watch, he goes to this patrilineal family</b> to receive a share on their day, <b>and they reject him,</b> and the other patrilineal family rejects him too, as his true patrilineal family is unknown.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: If they were both in one priestly watch and one patrilineal family, he receives one share,</b> as he cannot be rejected.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The mitzva of <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the ritual through which the <i>yavam</i> frees the <i>yevama</i> of her levirate bonds, <b>must be</b> performed before <b>three judges, and</b> the ritual does not require the judges to be experts fit to adjudicate other matters, as <b>even if all three are laymen,</b> it is acceptable. <b>If she performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> while he was wearing <b>a shoe</b> made of soft leather that covers the whole foot, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid,</b> but if she performed <i>ḥalitza</i> while he was wearing <b>a soft shoe [<i>anpileya</i>]</b> made of cloth, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid,</b> as it is not considered a real shoe. If <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed while he was wearing <b>a sandal,</b> i.e., footwear made of hard leather, <b>that has a heel,</b> it is <b>valid; but</b> if performed with a sandal <b>without a heel, it is invalid</b> <i>ḥalitza</i>.
If the leg of the <i>yavam</i> was amputated anywhere <b>from the knee down</b> and she performed <i>ḥalitza</i> as he wore a shoe on the stump of his leg, <b>it is valid <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> If, however, the leg was amputated anywhere <b>from the knee and above,</b> and she performed <i>ḥalitza</i> as he wore a shoe on the stump of his leg, <b>it is invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>. If she performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> while the man was wearing <b>a sandal that did not belong to him, or a sandal made of wood, or on the left</b> shoe, <b>which was</b> being worn <b>on his right</b> foot, <b>it is valid <i>ḥalitza</i>. If she performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> as the man was wearing a shoe that was too <b>large</b> for him but <b>which he can</b> still <b>walk in, or</b> a shoe that was too <b>small</b> but <b>that covered most of his foot, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Now that</b> the mishna says that <b>even three laymen</b> are qualified for <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>why do I</b> need it to mention <b>judges?</b> It would be sufficient to say that the mitzva requires three people. The Gemara answers: <b>This teaches us that we require three</b> people <b>who can</b> at least <b>dictate</b> the verses read during the <i>ḥalitza</i> ritual to the participants <b>like judges,</b> as they are not complete laymen in that they are literate. The Gemara comments: <b>We</b> already <b>learned this</b> <i>halakha</i> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>as the Sages taught: The mitzva of <i>ḥalitza</i> is</b> performed <b>before three</b> individuals <b>who know</b> how <b>to dictate</b> the verses <b>like judges. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> <i>Ḥalitza</i> must be performed <b>before five</b> individuals acting as judges.
The Gemara discusses the dispute as to how many individuals must conduct the <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>What is the reason of the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who requires three? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning <i>ḥalitza</i>: “His <i>yevama</i> shall ascend to the gate to the <b>Elders”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:7). Since the minimum number of the plural term “Elders” is <b>two, and</b> since, in order to prevent a paralyzing disagreement between an even number of judges, <b>a court may not</b> be composed of an <b>even</b> number of judges, <b>one more is added to them. Therefore, there are three</b> judges. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> interprets the verse otherwise, for one verse states: “And the <b>Elders of</b> his city shall call him” (Deuteronomy 25:8), indicating a minimum of <b>two</b> judges, and it says in the following verse <b>“Elders”</b> another time, indicating an additional <b>two</b> people, <b>and</b> since <b>a court may not</b> be composed of an <b>even</b> number of judges, <b>one more is added to them. Therefore, there are five</b> judges.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does the first <i>tanna</i> do with this</b> second appearance of the word <b>“Elders”?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>He requires it for</b> allowing the <b>inclusion</b> of <b>even three laymen</b> as presiding judges for <i>ḥalitza</i>. The word “Elders” would seem to limit <i>ḥalitza</i> to recognized judges, but since it is mentioned twice, it becomes an instance of the hermeneutic principle that one restrictive expression appearing after another restrictive expression comes to include some additional <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, repeating the restrictive term “Elders” twice actually comes to include laymen rather than exclude them.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Yehuda derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <i>ḥalitza</i> can be done in the presence of <b>laymen?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> what is written: <b>“Before the eyes of</b> the Elders” (Deuteronomy 25:9), <b>for the Master said: “Before the eyes of” excludes blind individuals</b> from being the judges conducting the <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>And since it was necessary</b> to say <b>“before the eyes of” to exclude blind individuals</b> from being judges for <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>learn from here</b> that <b>even laymen</b> are qualified to be judges for <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>For if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>we require</b> expert judges who are fit to sit on the high court of the <b>Sanhedrin,</b> then <b>why do I</b> need <b>to exclude blind individuals? For that</b> matter can be <b>derived from</b> a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rav Yosef taught, as Rav Yosef taught: Just as a court must be clean in righteousness,</b> as they are careful to judge others justly, and are free of guilt and suspicion, <b>likewise a court must be clean of any</b> physical <b>blemish,</b> with judges who are physically complete.

Daf 101b

This is <b>as it is stated: “You are entirely beautiful, my love, and there is no blemish in you”</b> (Song of Songs 4:7). If the Elders conducting <i>ḥalitza</i> needed to be expert judges, there would be no reason to explicitly exclude the blind, as they are unfit to be judges in a regular court. Evidently it is permitted for laymen to be judges for <i>ḥalitza</i>, and only blind individuals are excluded. The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>what does he do with</b> the verse <b>“before the eyes of”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes for</b> that which <b>Rava</b> taught, <b>as Rava said: The judges must see the spittle that exits from the mouth of the <i>yevama</i></b> as part of the ceremony of <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>as it is written:</b> “His <i>yevama</i> shall approach him, <b>before the eyes of the Elders,</b> and remove his shoe from on his foot <b>and spit</b> before him and respond and say: So shall it be done to the man who does not build his brother’s house” (Deuteronomy 25:9).
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yehuda, should <b>also require</b> “before the eyes” <b>to</b> teach <b>Rava’s</b> statement. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> this <b>is so,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda understands “before the eyes” as requiring the judges to see the spittle. <b>But</b> then <b>from where does he derive</b> the eligibility of <b>laymen?</b> He <b>derives</b> it <b>from</b> the phrase: <b>“In Israel,”</b> in the verse “And his name shall be called in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:10), which indicates that <b>any Israelite,</b> even one who is not an expert judge, may preside over <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>what does he do with this</b> phrase: <b>“In Israel”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for that which was taught by Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda: “In Israel”</b> means <b>in a court of Israelites</b> from birth, <b>and not in a court of converts.</b> The mitzva of <i>ḥalitza</i> must be conducted by judges who can trace their lineage to other Jews from birth, and not converts.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yehuda, from where does he derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>“In Israel” is written another</b> time as well (Deuteronomy 25:7, 10), and that is the source of this principle. <b>And the other,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, what does he do with this additional “In Israel”? The Gemara explains: <b>He requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Once we were sitting</b> in study <b>before Rabbi Tarfon, and a <i>yevama</i> came to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, and he said to us:</b> After the <i>ḥalitza</i> is completed, <b>you should all respond: “He who had his shoe removed.”</b> He understands the verse “His name shall be called in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:10) to mean that all those who witness the <i>ḥalitza</i> must respond: “He who had his shoe removed” (Deuteronomy 25:10).
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, from where did he derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> it <b>from</b> the phrase <b>“Shall be called,”</b> that those who attend the <i>ḥalitza</i> must respond aloud.
The Gemara returns to the dispute concerning the number of judges: <b>However, if that is so,</b> that the plural term “Elders” indicates the need for additional judges, there are other plural terms written in the verse that should also indicate the need for additional judges. As the verse states: <b>“And they shall call”;</b> this is referring to <b>two</b> people. <b>“And they shall speak”</b> indicates <b>two</b> more. Therefore, <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda’s</b> interpretation <b>there</b> should be <b>nine judges here, and according to the Rabbis there</b> should be <b>seven</b> here.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for him</b> to derive <b>the</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“They shall call him”</b> means the judges themselves <b>and not their agents. “They shall speak to him” teaches that they give him counsel appropriate for him</b> concerning whether he should perform levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>. For example, <b>if he was</b> a young <b>boy and she was elderly,</b> or if <b>he was elderly and she was</b> a young <b>girl, they would tell him</b> not to enter into levirate marriage because: <b>What</b> are <b>you</b> doing <b>with</b> a young <b>girl</b> if you are an old man? <b>What</b> are <b>you</b> doing <b>with an elderly woman</b> if you are a young boy? <b>Go be with someone like yourself,</b> closer to your own age, <b>and do not bring a quarrel into your household,</b> as the age difference will be a cause for disputes and strife later.
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> takes place <b>before three</b> men, <b>since the <i>tanna</i> taught us</b> this opinion as <b>an unattributed</b> mishna in the beginning of the chapter, <b>in accordance with</b> this opinion, indicating that this is the <i>halakha</i>. After he heard him say this, <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: If that is so,</b> then <b>declarations of refusal,</b> written on behalf of a girl who as a minor was married to a man by her brother or mother after the death of her father, and is given the right to refuse the marriage upon reaching majority, <b>also</b> should be performed before three men. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (25b): <b>Declarations of refusal and <i>ḥalitza</i></b> are performed <b>before three</b> judges.
<b>And if you would say that indeed</b> three men are required, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>refusal, Beit Shammai say</b> that a declaration of refusal may be performed only by <b>a court of experts, and Beit Hillel say:</b> It may be performed <b>in a court</b> of experts, <b>or not in a court</b> of experts. <b>Both concede</b> that whether the judges are experts or not, <b>three</b> men <b>are required.</b> On the other hand, <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, validate</b> declarations of refusal even <b>before two</b> men. <b>And Rav Yosef bar Minyumi said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: The <i>halakha</i> follows that pair.</b> Evidently, Rav Naḥman is willing to rule differently from the unattributed mishna that rules that three judges are necessary for <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with respect to declarations of refusal, there is only <b>one unattributed</b> mishna (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 2a) that states that refusals are performed before three judges, and <b>here,</b> there are <b>two unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i> that state that <i>ḥalitza</i> is performed before three judges, both here and also in that same mishna in tractate <i>Sanhedrin</i>. The Gemara challenges the previous claim: <b>There too,</b> with regard to refusals, <b>there are two unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (25b): <b>If she made a declaration of refusal or performed <i>ḥalitza</i> before</b> a judge, this judge <b>may marry her</b> if he wishes to, as there is no suspicion of ulterior motives, <b>because he is a member of a court.</b> This mishna implies that declarations of refusal may take place only before a court.
The Gemara concedes: <b>Rather, there,</b> with regard to refusals, there are only <b>two unattributed</b> statements found in the mishna, <b>and here,</b> with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>, there are <b>three unattributed</b> statements found in the mishna. That convinces us to rule in accordance with those three sources requiring three for <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Since this is</b> supported by an <b>unattributed</b> mishna <b>and that is</b> supported by <b>an unattributed</b> mishna, <b>what difference does it make to me</b> if there is <b>one unattributed</b> mishna? <b>What difference does it make to me</b> if there are <b>two unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>? <b>What difference does it make to me</b> if there are <b>three unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>? <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This ruling was made <b>because the unattributed</b> mishna, which states that <i>ḥalitza</i> requires three men, is recorded unequivocally <b>in a place</b> where it is adjacent to a different <b>dispute</b> involving Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 2a): <b>Ordination of Elders and</b> the ceremony of <b>the heifer whose neck is broken</b> are performed <b>before three</b> judges; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Yehuda says: Before five. <i>Ḥalitza</i> and declarations of refusal</b> are performed <b>before three.</b> The Gemara explains the rationale to rule on the basis of this mishna that <i>ḥalitza</i> should in fact be performed before three: <b>And</b> since <b>Rabbi Yehuda did not dispute</b> this second statement concerning <i>ḥalitza</i> even though he disputed the first <i>halakha</i> in the mishna, <b>learn from here: Rabbi Yehuda retracted</b> his opinion concerning <i>ḥalitza</i> and no longer required that it be performed before five men. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from here</b> that he retracted his opinion, and three judges are sufficient for conducting <i>ḥalitza</i>.
§ The Gemara begins a discussion concerning the halakhic details of <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>Rava said: The judges need to establish a location</b> ahead of time where the <i>ḥalitza</i> will be performed, <b>as it is written: “His <i>yevama</i> shall ascend to the gate to the Elders”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:7), indicating that there is an established place, “the gate,” for the court to convene for <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, conducted a case</b> of <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>before five</b> judges. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with</b> whose opinion were they ruling? If you say they ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, but</b> it was proven above that <b>Rabbi Yehuda retracted</b> his initial opinion and requires only three judges. The Gemara answers: They did this only <b>to publicize the matter</b> and not because this number of judges is required.
It is told further: <b>Rav Ashi once happened</b> to come <b>to Rav Kahana’s house.</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>Will the master come up with us to complete the quorum of five</b> men in order to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>? <b>Rav Kahana said</b> further: <b>When I stood before Rav Yehuda, he said to me: Go up to the bundle [<i>zirza</i>]</b> of reeds to join the five men who will oversee the performance of <i>ḥalitza</i>, as a bundle of reeds had been set aside to be the established location where the court will convene to conduct cases of <i>ḥalitza</i>. Those in attendance <b>said to</b> Rav Yehuda: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>five</b> if three are sufficient? <b>He said to them: In order to publicize the matter,</b> and not because it is a halakhic obligation.
It is told: <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda was standing before Rav Yehuda.</b> Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: Go up to the bundle of reeds to complete the</b> quorum of <b>five in order to publicize the matter</b> of this <i>ḥalitza</i>. Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda <b>said to him: We learned</b> that the phrase <b>“In Israel”</b> in the verse: “And his name shall be called in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:10) indicates that <i>ḥalitza</i> must be performed <b>before a court of Israelites</b> from birth, <b>and not before a court</b> composed o<b>f converts, but I am a convert,</b> as Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda had converted along with his father.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> to him: <b>I would exact payment based on the word of</b> someone <b>such as Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda,</b> as he has shown that he is upright and honest by revealing this unknown fact about himself. The Gemara questions: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that <b>one can</b> actually <b>exact</b> payment based on the word of one man, no matter how honest he seems to be? Doesn’t <b>the Merciful One state</b> in the Torah: <b>“By the mouth of two witnesses</b> or by the mouth of three witnesses, shall a matter be established” (Deuteronomy 19:15), indicating that one can exact payment based only on the evidence of at least two witnesses? <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that Rav Yehuda’s intention was to say: <b>I would declare a bill</b> of indebtedness <b>invalid based on his word,</b> accepting his claim that the debt had been collected.
Parenthetical to mentioning the status of a convert with regard to a court of <i>ḥalitza</i>, the Gemara relates: <b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 102a

<b>By Torah law a convert may judge his fellow</b> convert, <b>as it is stated: “You shall set a king over you, whom the Lord your God shall choose; one from among your brothers you shall set king over you”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:15). The Gemara deduces from the terminology of the phrase <b>“over you,”</b> i.e., when presiding over Jews by birth either as a king, a judge, or any other official, that from here it <b>is where we require</b> that the official must be: <b>“From among your brothers,”</b> meaning a Jew by birth. <b>However, a convert may judge his fellow convert,</b> as the requirement of “one from among your brothers” doesn’t apply when presiding over fellow converts.
<b>And if the</b> convert’s <b>mother was from Israel, he may even</b> preside as a judge in a court to <b>adjudicate</b> legal matters involving a native-born <b>Jew. But with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> he may not act as a judge <b>unless both his father and his mother were from Israel</b> from birth, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>“And his name shall be called in Israel:</b> The house of he who had his shoe removed” (Deuteronomy 25:10), implying that he must be born as a member of the Jewish people from both of his parents.
§ <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rav said: If Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>should come and say: One may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a soft leather <b>shoe,</b> the Rabbis <b>would listen to him.</b> But if he says: <b>One may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a hard leather <b>sandal, they would not listen to him, for the people already have</b> established <b>the practice of</b> performing <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>using a sandal.</b>
<b>And Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said: <b>If Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>should come and say: One may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a soft leather <b>shoe, they would listen to him.</b> But if he says: <b>One may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a hard leather <b>sandal, they would not listen to him, for the people already have</b> established <b>the practice of</b> performing <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>using a sandal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical <b>difference between</b> these two opinions? Seemingly, they both say the same thing. The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> is with respect to performing <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather <b>shoe <i>ab initio</i>.</b> According to Rabba’s opinion, one may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> this way <i>ab initio</i>, as Rabba said that only if Elijah comes and permits it would he be heeded, implying that until Elijah does so one may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> this way. According to Rav Yosef’s opinion, one may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather shoe until Elijah comes and teaches us otherwise.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who says</b> that one may <b>even</b> perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather shoe <b><i>ab initio</i>, didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (101a): <b>If she performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> a soft leather <b>shoe, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid,</b> and the past tense wording indicates <b>after the fact, yes, but it is not</b> valid <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The same is</b> true that one may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather shoe <b>even <i>ab initio</i>, but since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wished to teach in the latter clause</b> of that mishna: If <b>an <i>anpileya</i>,</b> a soft shoe made of cloth, was used for <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is disqualified even after the fact, he also taught the first clause</b> of the mishna using wording that indicates validity <b>after the fact,</b> even though it is in fact permitted even <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> performing <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather <b>shoe <i>ab initio</i> is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Yosei said: One time I went to</b> the city of <b>Netzivin</b> in Babylonia, and <b>I found</b> there <b>a certain Elder. I said to him: Do you know Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira,</b> who was from Netzivin? <b>He said to me: Yes, and he is</b> a <b>frequent</b> visitor <b>at my table.</b> I asked the Elder: <b>Have you ever seen if he</b> conducted <b>the <i>ḥalitza</i> of a <i>yevama</i>?</b>
<b>He said to me: I saw that he</b> conducted <b><i>ḥalitza</i> many times.</b> I asked him: <b>Using a</b> soft leather <b>shoe or a</b> hard leather <b>sandal? He said to me: Does anyone</b> allow <b>performing <i>ḥalitza</i> with a</b> soft leather <b>shoe? But the Torah said: “His shoe [<i>na’alo</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:9) <b>and not: His shoe [<i>minalo</i>]. I said to him: If so, what did Rabbi Meir see that</b> made <b>him say</b> that if <b>a woman performed <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a soft leather <b>shoe her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid?</b>
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov says in the name</b> of Rabbi Meir: <b>One may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using</b> a soft leather <b>shoe <i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>And for the one who said one may not</b> perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with a soft leather <b>shoe <i>ab initio</i>, what is the reason</b> for this?
<b>If we say</b> that a soft leather shoe is disqualified <b>because the upper side of the</b> soft leather <b>shoe [<i>panta</i>] is on</b> his foot directly, <b>and the straps</b> [<b><i>arketa</i></b>] tied around the upper portion of the shoe <b>are</b> like a second shoe <b>on top</b> of the shoe that is directly <b>on top</b> of his foot, <b>and the Torah says:</b> “Remove the shoe <b>from on</b> his foot,” indicating that the entire shoe must be “on his foot” <b>but not from on</b> something else <b>that is on</b> his foot, <b>if so,</b> then <b>even after the fact as well,</b> it should <b>not</b> be fit for use. If a soft leather shoe is unfit for <i>ḥalitza</i> by Torah law, it should be prohibited under all circumstances.
Rather, it is <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the concern that one might use a <b>torn</b> soft leather <b>shoe,</b> which may nevertheless be worn if torn due to its softness but is prohibited as it does not cover his foot. No similar concern exists with regard to a torn sandal, as due to its hard exterior it would never be worn if torn, and therefore there is no concern that it will be used for <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Alternatively,</b> it is a rabbinic decree <b>due to</b> concern that one might perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with <b>a half shoe,</b> as the <i>ḥalitza</i> shoe must cover most of the foot, yet there are some who wear soft leather shoes that cover only half of the foot. Therefore, there is a prohibition against using a soft leather shoe for <i>ḥalitza ab initio</i> for fear that a half shoe might also accidentally be used. No similar fear exists with a hard leather sandal as a half sandal is never worn.
<b>Rav said: If I had not seen my beloved</b> uncle, Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>conduct a <i>ḥalitza</i> using a sandal with laces, I would not have conducted <i>ḥalitza</i> with anything other than a sandal of Arabs, which is more tight fitting</b> and snug. The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>this</b> sandal <b>of ours,</b> i.e., the customary sandal of that day, <b>although it does have a ring [<i>ḥumrata</i>]</b> on top to ensure that it will not fall off the foot easily, <b>we tie a strap to it</b> during <i>ḥalitza</i> in order to make it tighter, <b>so that her <i>ḥalitza</i> will be</b> of the <b>highest standard.</b> The strap is tied on so that the sandal will not come off by itself, to ensure that the <i>yevama</i> will have to untie the strap in order to remove the sandal.
§ The Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the following three <i>halakhot</i> that Rav Yehuda taught in the name of Rav: <b><i>Hatarat</i>,</b> meaning release of; <b><i>yevama</i>; <i>sandal</i>.</b> This mnemonic serves as a reminder that the release of a <i>yevama</i> is done through removing a sandal. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: The release of a <i>yevama</i></b> to enable her marriage <b>to</b> a member of <b>the public occurs when most of the heel is removed</b> from the shoe. Even though the shoe has not been entirely removed, or even removed from most of the <i>yavam’s</i> foot; it is still permitted for her to remarry.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>If the straps of</b> a soft leather shoe <b>or</b> a hard leather <b>sandal were untied,</b> but not through the actions of the <i>yevama</i>, <b>or if</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>removed most of his foot</b> from the shoe himself before the <i>yevama</i> completed the removal, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is disqualified.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> her <i>ḥalitza</i> is disqualified <b>is</b> specifically <b>that he removed</b> most of his foot and she only completed the removal, <b>but had she removed</b> most of the foot from the shoe, then <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i></b> would be <b>valid.</b> The Gemara continues: If so, <b>yes,</b> only when the <i>yevama</i> removes <b>most of the foot</b> is the <i>ḥalitza</i> valid, but if she removed only <b>most of the heel,</b> it would <b>not</b> be sufficient.
The Gemara rejects this question: <b>No, most of the foot is</b> the same as <b>most of the heel,</b> and therefore the inference should be that even if she removed most of the heel from the shoe the <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid. <b>And why do they call it: Most of the foot? Because the whole weight of the leg puts pressure on</b> the heel.
The Gemara comments: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>supports Rabbi Yannai, as Rabbi Yannai said: Whether he unties</b> the shoe <b>and she removes it,</b> or <b>whether she unties it and he removes it, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is disqualified unless she both unties it and takes it off.</b> And on the same topic, <b>Rabbi Yannai asked: If she</b> did not remove the sandal, but instead <b>ripped it</b> off him, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>If she burned it</b> using coals, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara presents the real issue in question: Is <b>exposure of the foot</b> the essential act of <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>that we require,</b> through any act of removing that which covers the foot, <b>which exists</b> here? <b>Or perhaps it is removal</b> of the shoe from over the foot <b>that we require, which is lacking</b> here? No answer was found to this question, so the Gemara concludes: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabbi Neḥemya asked Rabba</b> the following question: If the man was wearing <b>two shoes, one on top of the other, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the case? <b>If we say</b> that <b>she removed the outer shoe and the inner shoe remains in place,</b> but <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“From on</b> his foot” <b>and not: From on that which is on</b> his foot. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this question wasn’t asked in a case where the inner shoe remained on his foot. Rather, <b>it is necessary</b> in a case <b>where she tore the outer shoe and took off the inner shoe, and the outer one still remains</b> on his foot although it is torn. The question centers around the previous one with regard to the nature of <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> for valid <i>ḥalitza</i>? Is it <b>removal</b> of the shoe that <b>we require, which we have</b> brought about in this example? <b>Or perhaps</b> it is <b>exposing the foot</b> that <b>we require, which is lacking</b> here, as the foot is still covered by the torn outer shoe.

Daf 102b

The Gemara asks: <b>Is there really a case like this</b> where people wear one shoe on top of another? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, for the Sages saw Rav Yehuda, who went out</b> once <b>to the market wearing five pairs of</b> shoes, which were similar to <b>slippers,</b> one on top of another.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> another <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rav said:</b> An underage <b><i>yevama</i> who grew up among</b> her husband’s <b>brothers</b> before any <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed <b>is permitted to marry one of the brothers</b> through levirate marriage, <b>and we are not concerned</b> about the possibility <b>that</b> during the time she was in the company of her <i>yevamin</i> <b>she removed a sandal from one of them,</b> and thereby she would have already performed <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara infers from this statement: <b>The reason</b> it is permitted to perform levirate marriage now <b>is</b> specifically <b>that we did not see</b> her remove one of their shoes, <b>but if</b> in fact <b>we did see</b> her do so, <b>we are concerned</b> and treat her as a <i>yevama</i> who already performed <i>ḥalitza</i> and is thereby forbidden to all the brothers.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Whether he intended</b> to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>and she did not intend</b> to, <b>or whether she intended</b> to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>and he did not intend to, the <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid, unless they both intended it as one</b> to perform a proper act of <i>ḥalitza</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> Rav <b>said: Even if we</b> did <b>see</b> that she removed a shoe from one of them, <b>we are not concerned that perhaps they intended to</b> perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> the inference from Rav’s statement should be made in the opposite manner: <b>The reason</b> it is permitted for her to perform levirate marriage now <b>is</b> specifically <b>that we did not see</b> her remove a shoe from one of the brothers. <b>But if we did see, we would be concerned</b> and would treat her as a <i>yevama</i> who already performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, despite our knowledge that she did not intend to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>that intention is required, this applies</b> only as far as validating the act of <i>ḥalitza</i> in order <b>to permit her to marry a stranger. But</b> performing an act of <i>ḥalitza</i> even without intention is sufficient to <b>disqualify her for the brothers,</b> rendering prohibited an act of levirate marriage afterward.
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> also <b>said</b> that <b>Rav said: One may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> using a sandal</b> that was <b>sewn</b> together <b>with</b> threads made of <b>flax, as it is stated: “And I made you shoes of <i>taḥash</i> skin”</b> (Ezekiel 16:10), which is the skin of an animal, implying that a shoe is something made entirely of leather. The Gemara challenges: If the source is “<i>taḥash</i>,” <b>let us say:</b> A shoe made of <b><i>taḥash</i> skin, yes,</b> it is valid; but if made of <b>anything else, no.</b> The Gemara rejects this: Because <b>“shoe”</b> and <b>“shoe”</b> are written in the Torah multiple times, this <b>amplifies</b> and includes all types of shoes crafted from leather skins as valid for performing <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the inclusion of the words <b>“shoe”</b> and <b>“shoe” amplifies,</b> then should one include as valid for performing <i>ḥalitza</i> shoes crafted from <b>even any</b> other <b>materials as well,</b> including those not produced from leather at all? The Gemara answers: <b>If so, what purpose does “<i>taḥash</i>” serve,</b> as nothing is learned from it? Rather, from the word <i>taḥash</i> it is derived that the shoe must be crafted entirely of leather, but all types of leather are included because the word “shoe” is repeated in the Torah numerous times.
<b>Rabbi Elazar asked Rav:</b> What is the status of the following type of sandal used for performing <i>ḥalitza</i>? In a case where <b>it,</b> the shoe itself, <b>is made of leather, and</b> the sections that hold <b>its straps [<i>tereisiyyot</i>]</b> are made <b>of hair,</b> as they were woven together with goat’s hair, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to him: Do we not refer to</b> such a sandal <b>as: “And I made you shoes of <i>taḥash</i>”?</b> Since it is crafted from material that comes from an animal it is valid. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> i.e., that anything derived from an animal is valid, then even if it is fashioned <b>entirely of hair it should also be</b> valid. The Gemara answers: <b>That would be called a slipper,</b> not a shoe.
<b>Rav Kahana said to Shmuel: From where is it known that this</b> phrase: <b>“And she shall remove [<i>ḥaltza</i>] his shoe from on his foot”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:9), <b>means to remove? As it is written:</b> “Then the priest shall command, <b>and they shall take out [<i>ḥiltzu</i>] the stones in which the plague is”</b> (Leviticus 14:40), indicating that the word <i>ḥaltza</i> means that they shall remove the stones from their place.
The Gemara asks whether the word <i>ḥaltza</i> can be interpreted differently based upon its apparent meaning in other contexts: <b>But</b> could you <b>say it is</b> a term for <b>strengthening, as it is written: “Arm [<i>heḥaletzu</i>] men from among you for the army”</b> (Numbers 31:3), meaning that men among you will be strengthened and take up arms to prepare for battle? The Gemara answers: <b>There too,</b> the meaning of the word is referring to taking something from its place, as it means <b>removing</b> people <b>from their houses</b> in order <b>to go</b> out <b>to war.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it written: “He delivers [<i>yeḥaletz</i>] the afflicted by His affliction [<i>be’onyo</i>]”</b> (Job 36:15)? This indicates that the afflicted one becomes stronger due to his affliction, as, if the intention was to deliver him from his affliction, it should have said: From His affliction, rather than “by His affliction.” The Gemara answers that the verse should be interpreted as follows: <i>Be’onyo</i>, in other words, <b>as reward for his</b> suffering from <b>affliction, He shall deliver him from the judgment of Gehenna,</b> as is understood from the term <i>be’onyo</i>, through the reward due to his affliction.
The Gemara challenges further: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that it is written: “The angel of the Lord encamps around those who fear Him and delivers them [<i>vayeḥaltzem</i>]”</b> (Psalms 34:8), doesn’t <i>vayeḥaltzem</i> rather mean: He shall strengthen them? The Gemara answers: The verse means: <b>As a reward for those that fear Him, He shall deliver them from the judgment of Gehenna.</b> Therefore, the Gemara interprets <i>vayeḥaltzem</i> as “delivers them,” not as: Strengthens them.
The Gemara challenges further: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that which is written:</b> “And the Lord will guide you, and satisfy your soul in drought, <b>and make your bones strong [<i>yaḥalitz</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 58:11), <b>and Rabbi Elazar said</b> regarding that verse: <b>This is the greatest of blessings, and Rava said</b> it means: <b>Strengthening of bones.</b> This seems to indicate that the root of the word <i>ḥalitza</i> is referring to strengthening. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it has this connotation, and it has this connotation,</b> i.e., the root <i>ḥ-l-tz</i> sometimes connotes removal and sometimes connotes strengthening. <b>But here,</b> only one meaning is possible, as, <b>if it enters your mind</b> that <i>ḥalitza</i> here <b>connotes strengthening, then let the Merciful One write</b> in the Torah: <b>She shall strengthen [<i>ḥaletza</i>] his shoe on his foot [<i>beraglo</i>],</b> indicating that she should tighten the shoe on his foot, rather than stating: “From on his foot [<i>me’al raglo</i>],” which indicates that she is removing something from his foot.
The Gemara responds: <b>If the Merciful One had written</b> in the Torah: <b>On his foot [<i>beraglo</i>], I would have said</b> she must strengthen and tighten the shoe <b>on his foot, yes, but on his calf, no;</b> and if his foot were amputated she may no longer perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah: <b>“From on his foot [<i>me’al raglo</i>],”</b> to teach that she may strengthen the shoe <b>even on his calf,</b> which is part of the leg, or <i>regel</i>, above the foot. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> and <i>ḥalitza</i> really means strengthening, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> in the Torah: She shall strengthen his shoe <b>on the upper part of his foot [<i>beme’al raglo</i>],</b> indicating that the shoe can also be tightened on the area of the calf. <b>What</b> then <b>is</b> the meaning of <b>“from on his foot [<i>me’al raglo</i>],”</b> which is written in the verse? <b>Learn from here</b> that in this context the word <i>ḥalitza</i> clearly <b>indicates removal,</b> meaning that the mitzva of <i>ḥalitza</i> is for the <i>yevama</i> to remove the shoe of the <i>yavam</i> and not to tighten it on his foot.
Parenthetical to this discussion, the Gemara relates: <b>A certain heretic said to Rabban Gamliel:</b> You, the children of Israel, are <b>a nation whose Master removed [<i>ḥalatz</i>] Himself from them,</b> for God has left you in much the same way in which a <i>yavam</i> would perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with his <i>yevama</i>, <b>as it is written: “With their flocks and with their herds they shall go to seek the Lord, but they shall not find Him. He has removed [<i>ḥalatz</i>] Himself from them [<i>meihem</i>]”</b> (Hoshea 5:6). The heretic tried to use this verse as scriptural support that God has performed <i>ḥalitza</i> with the Jewish people.
<b>He,</b> Rabban Gamliel, <b>said to him: Imbecile, does it say: He performed <i>ḥalitza</i> to them [<i>lahem</i>]?</b> Rather, <b>it says “<i>ḥalatz</i> from them [<i>meihem</i>],”</b> meaning it is as if they, the Jewish people, performed <i>ḥalitza</i> on Him. <b>But if a <i>yevama</i> had her shoe removed by her <i>yevamin</i>, does this have any significance?</b> Here too, the meaning of the verse is that the nation of Israel abandoned God by removing themselves from Him, and this abandonment has no significance.
The Gemara analyzes the phrase used in the mishna that discusses the types of shoes that can be used for <i>ḥalitza</i>. It was taught in the mishna that if he was wearing <b>a soft shoe [<i>anpileya</i>]</b> made of cloth for <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>That is to say that an <i>anpileya</i> is not</b> considered <b>a shoe.</b>
<b>And we also learned</b> similarly in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 3:2): <b>The one who collects the funds</b> of shekels donated to the Temple from the chamber and puts them into baskets in order to be used <b>may not enter</b> to collect the funds <b>wearing a garment [<i>pargod</i>] that is cuffed [<i>ḥafut</i>], nor wearing an <i>anpileya</i>, and needless to say</b> that he may not enter wearing <b>a shoe or a sandal, because one may not enter</b> the Temple <b>courtyard wearing a shoe or a sandal.</b> It is prohibited for the one collecting funds from the chamber to enter the chamber wearing a garment or footwear in which money could be hidden, lest people come to suspect that he hid in them funds collected from the chamber. In any case, the wording of the mishna indicates that an <i>anpileya</i> is not considered a type of shoe, since it is permitted to enter the Temple wearing an <i>anpileya</i> when there is no reason for suspicion, unlike a shoe or sandal, which can never be worn in the Temple.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> concerning what footwear is permitted on Yom Kippur, which seems to indicate otherwise: The halakha is <b>the same for a</b> soft leather <b>shoe, and a</b> hard leather <b>sandal, and an <i>anpileya</i>, as one may not walk in them from one house to another, nor from one bed to another</b> on Yom Kippur, due to the prohibition against wearing shoes, indicating that at least as far as Yom Kippur is concerned, an <i>anpileya</i> is considered a shoe.
<b>Abaye said:</b> There, with regard to Yom Kippur, it is referring to an <i>anpileya</i> <b>that has cushioning, and</b> this is forbidden <b>due to the pleasure</b> that one derives from cushioned footwear on a day when people are commanded to afflict themselves. <b>Rava said to him: But</b> is footwear <b>that is not considered</b> to be <b>shoes forbidden on Yom Kippur due to</b> the <b>pleasure</b> one derives from wearing them? <b>But Rabba bar Rav Huna would wrap a scarf on his feet and go out</b> on Yom Kippur so his feet would not be injured, implying that there is no prohibition against wearing something comfortable on one’s foot, as long as it is not defined as a shoe. <b>Rather, Rava said: This</b> is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> when they said that an <i>anpileya</i> has the status of a shoe, it is referring to <b>an <i>anpileya</i></b> made <b>of leather.
