The Gemara cites a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear from what</b> the Rabbis <b>said</b> in response <b>to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: <b>The man who divorces</b> his wife <b>is not similar to the woman who is divorced, as the woman is divorced</b> whether <b>she is willing or unwilling, and the man divorces</b> his wife only <b>willingly. Learn from here</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri <b>raised</b> his <b>dilemma</b> with regard to a deaf-mute <b>man,</b> not a woman, as the reply of the Rabbis is referring to the man, not the woman. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that the Rabbis said to him: This</b> woman, <b>too, has a similar</b> status, one can <b>learn from here</b> that he <b>raised</b> his <b>dilemma</b> with regard to a deaf-mute <b>woman.</b>
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri spoke to</b> the Rabbis <b>in accordance with their statement,</b> i.e., he formulated his statement so as best to argue with their opinion, as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, <b>just as</b> a deaf-mute <b>man cannot divorce</b> his wife, <b>so too</b> a deaf-mute <b>woman cannot be divorced. However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>what is the difference</b> between the case of a deaf-mute <b>woman and</b> the case of a deaf-mute <b>man? They said to him: The man who divorces</b> his wife <b>is not similar to the woman who is divorced.</b>
The mishna taught: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> ben Gudgada <b>testified</b> that in the case of a deaf-mute minor whose father married her off, which is a marriage that is valid by Torah law, she may nevertheless be divorced once she matures. <b>Rava said: From the testimony of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgada</b> one may learn that if a husband <b>said to witnesses: See this bill of divorce that I am giving</b> my wife, <b>and</b> yet <b>he said to her: Take this promissory note, she is divorced,</b> despite the fact when he gave his wife the bill of divorce she did not know what it was.
This <i>halakha</i> is derived from Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgada’s statement in the following manner: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgada say</b> that <b>we do not require her consent,</b> as there is no need for the woman to understand that she is receiving a bill of divorce? <b>Here, too, we do not require her consent,</b> and even if she believes that she is receiving a bill of debt, she is divorced. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that there is no need for the woman’s consent? What is the novel element in Rava’s statement?
The Gemara answers that Rava’s statement is necessary, <b>lest you say: From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the husband <b>said to her: Take this promissory note, he has</b> thereby <b>nullified the bill of divorce.</b> Rava therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, for <b>if it is</b> so, that he nullified the bill of divorce, <b>he would have said</b> so <b>to the witnesses. And from</b> the fact <b>that he did not say</b> this <b>to the witnesses, he</b> evidently <b>did not nullify</b> the bill of divorce <b>at all. And</b> the reason <b>that</b> the husband <b>said this,</b> i.e., that she should take this bill of debt, <b>it was due to shame that he said this to her,</b> as he meant to divorce her all along, but he did not want her to know at the time what he was doing.
The Gemara relates a story: <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Bisna lost the keys to the study hall,</b> and therefore they could not come <b>into</b> the study hall from <b>the public domain on Shabbat.</b> It was impossible to open the synagogue, as they could not bring the key because it is prohibited to carry in the public domain. <b>He came before Rabbi Pedat</b> to ask what to do. Rabbi Pedat <b>said to him: Go</b>

Daf 114a

<b>and lead boys and girls and let them walk there</b> where the keys were lost, <b>and if they find the keys they will bring them</b> to you of their own accord, without you saying anything to them. The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Pedat <b>maintains</b> that with regard to <b>a minor</b> who <b>eats</b> meat from <b>unslaughtered animals</b> or violates other prohibitions, <b>the court is not commanded to prevent him</b> from doing so. The Gemara comments: <b>Let us say that</b> the following source <b>supports his</b> opinion: <b>A person may not tell a child</b> on Shabbat: <b>Bring me a key, or: Bring me</b> my <b>seal</b> from the public domain. <b>However, he may allow</b> the child to <b>detach</b> plants and <b>allow him</b> to <b>throw</b> in the public domain. This shows that one need not be strict with a child who transgresses a prohibition, but one may not tell a child to transgress a prohibition.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Abaye said</b> that this is no proof, as it is possible that <b>detaching</b> plants is referring <b>to an unperforated flowerpot,</b> as the prohibition against detaching plants from a vessel of this kind applies by rabbinic law. Similar, when it states: <b>Throw,</b> this can be referring to throwing <b>in a <i>karmelit</i></b> rather than the public domain. A <i>karmelit</i> is an intermediate domain between public and private domains, which has the status of a public domain <b>by rabbinic</b> law. However, perhaps one is obligated to stop the child if he is transgressing a Torah prohibition.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the following statement (<i>Shabbat</i> 121a): If <b>a gentile comes to extinguish</b> a Jew’s fire on Shabbat, <b>one may not say to him: Extinguish, or: Do not extinguish, because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is not</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew. However, if a Jewish <b>child comes to extinguish</b> a fire on Shabbat, <b>they do say to him: Do not extinguish,</b> despite the fact that he is not yet obligated in mitzva observance, <b>because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew. This shows that one must prevent a minor from violating a Torah prohibition.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is referring <b>to</b> a minor <b>who is acting with his father’s consent.</b> Even if the father did not tell him explicitly what to do, the child is aware of his father’s wishes, and acts on his behalf. The Gemara asks: The <b>same</b> reasoning can be applied <b>with regard to a gentile, that he acts with the Jew’s consent,</b> and yet in this case <b>is it permitted</b> for him to perform labor on behalf of a Jew? The Gemara answers: <b>A gentile acts in accordance with his</b> own wishes. As an adult he is responsible for his own decisions and is not considered to be following the instructions of others.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear: The son of a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> one who is devoted to the meticulous observance of mitzvot, especially the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity, <i>teruma</i>, and tithes, <b>is accustomed to going to his mother’s father,</b> who is <b>an ignoramus</b> and therefore is not known to be as careful to separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes. In this case, the son need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned lest</b> his grandfather <b>feed him</b> food <b>items that are not tithed.</b> If the father <b>found fruit in</b> the child’s <b>hand,</b> and he does not know where the fruit is from, <b>he is not bound</b> to separate tithes from the fruit. This indicates that one need not prevent a minor from eating forbidden food. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The Sages <b>were lenient with regard to doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>].</b> Since the prohibition against eating this produce applies only due to doubt, and most ignoramuses do separate tithes, the Sages were lenient in uncertain cases of this kind.
The Gemara infers: <b>Rather,</b> the <b>reason</b> that the Sages were lenient is <b>that</b> it is <b><i>demai</i>,</b> from which it may be inferred that <b>if it was definitely</b> untithed, the father would be <b>required to tithe</b> the fruit. <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> himself <b>say that</b> one need stop a minor only <b>when he is acting with his father’s consent? Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan is uncertain</b> with regard to this <i>halakha</i>, and therefore <b>in this case he refutes</b> it, and <b>in that case he refutes it.</b> In other words, he reached no definite conclusion about this matter, and therefore he treats each case on its own merits.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>the son of a <i>ḥaver</i> priest who is accustomed to going to his mother’s father, a priest</b> who is also <b>an ignoramus, one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned lest</b> his grandfather <b>feed him ritually impure <i>teruma</i>.</b> If the father <b>found fruit in</b> the child’s <b>hand, he is not bound</b> to take it from him. This shows that even when the concern involves ritually impure <i>teruma</i>, which is a Torah prohibition, one is not required to ensure that a minor does not sin. The Gemara rejects this: This is no proof, as this is referring <b>to <i>teruma</i></b> that is separated <b>by rabbinic</b> law, not a doubt concerning a Torah prohibition.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear: A child may regularly suckle from a gentile woman; and</b> a child may suckle from <b>a non-kosher animal. And</b> in both cases <b>one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned that he</b> might be considered one who <b>suckles from a detestable creature. But one may not feed</b> a child unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses, or animals with wounds that will cause the animals to die within twelve months [<i>tereifot</i>],</b> or <b>repugnant creatures, or creeping animals.</b> A child <b>may suckle from all these,</b> including the non-kosher creatures, <b>even on Shabbat, but</b> in the case <b>of an adult,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for him to suckle on Shabbat even from a kosher animal. <b>Abba Shaul says: We were accustomed to suckle from a kosher animal on a Festival,</b> rather than milk it by hand, in the usual way.
<b>In any event,</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned that he</b> might be considered one who <b>suckles from a detestable creature,</b> which indicates that a child may be left to eat forbidden food. The Gemara rejects this: <b>There,</b> permission is granted <b>due to a danger,</b> because a child must eat. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> it should <b>also</b> be permitted for <b>an adult,</b> as saving a human life supersedes these prohibitions.
The Gemara answers: <b>An adult requires consultation,</b> i.e., doctors or other experts must examine him and establish that he is dangerously ill. The Gemara retorts: <b>A minor should also require consultation</b> as to whether he is in danger. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> There is no need for a special consultation, as in an <b>unspecified</b> case <b>a child is in danger with regard to milk.</b> It can be assumed that a child needs milk, and if he does not get it, he will be in danger.
The Gemara analyzes the last opinion in the above <i>baraita</i>. <b>Abba Shaul says: We were accustomed to suckle from a kosher animal on a Festival.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>What are the circumstances? If there is</b> imminent <b>danger</b> to a person, <b>even on Shabbat</b> it should <b>also</b> be permitted. <b>And if there is no danger, even on a Festival</b> it should be <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where there is suffering,</b> i.e., they suffer from thirst but no danger is involved.
The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> Abba Shaul <b>holds</b> that sucking directly from an animal <b>is</b> considered the prohibited labor of <b>extracting</b> performed <b>in an unusual manner.</b> It is prohibited to remove food from a source that is not fit for consumption. However, in this case he does not do so in the usual way of milking, but by sucking, and therefore it is prohibited by rabbinic law. Consequently, on <b>Shabbat, when</b> it is <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b>stoning, the Sages issued a decree</b> in this case, even if the milking is done in an unusual manner. Conversely, with regard to <b>a Festival, when</b> labor is a <b>negative prohibition</b> that is not punishable by stoning, <b>the Sages did not issue a decree</b> in a situation that involves suffering. In any case, this source offers no proof with respect to how to treat a child who transgresses.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> The verse states, with regard to creeping animals and other non-kosher animals: <b>“You shall not eat them [<i>tokhlum</i>] for they are a detestable thing”</b> (Leviticus 11:42). The Sages interpret this verse as though it said <b><i>ta’akhilum</i>, do not feed them</b> to others. The verse comes <b>to warn adults concerning minors,</b> i.e., not only is it prohibited for adults to eat these items themselves, they may also not feed them to minors. <b>What, is it not</b> the case <b>that</b> this means adults must <b>say to</b> children: <b>Do not eat,</b> and prevent them from transgressing? The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No,</b> it means <b>that</b> an adult <b>may not feed</b> the minor non-kosher food directly <b>by</b> direct <b>action,</b> but this does not prove that one must stop a child from eating non-kosher food of his own accord.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the verse states: <b>“No soul of you shall eat blood”</b> (Leviticus 17:12). This serves <b>to warn adults concerning minors. What, is it not</b> the case <b>that</b> this means adults must <b>say to</b> children: <b>Do not eat blood?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> here, too, it means <b>that</b> an adult may not feed minors <b>by</b> direct <b>action.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the verse states: <b>“Speak</b> to the priests, the sons of Aaron, <b>and say</b> to them: None shall become impure for the dead among his people” (Leviticus 21:1). This reiteration of “speak” and “and say” comes <b>to warn adults concerning minors. What, is it not</b> the case <b>that</b> this means adults must <b>say to</b> children: <b>Do not become impure?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is possible to interpret <b>that</b> an adult should <b>not render</b> children <b>impure by</b> direct <b>action.</b>
The Gemara adds: And all these three cases <b>are necessary,</b> despite the fact that they apparently teach the same <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that adults may not feed minors forbidden food. <b>As,</b> had the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>repugnant creatures,</b>

Daf 114b

we would have said that the <i>halakha</i> is stringent in this case <b>because they are prohibited by any amount,</b> i.e., a creeping animal or insect is prohibited on pain of lashes even if it is very small, provided that it is a whole creature (<i>Tosafot</i>). <b>However,</b> with regard to eating <b>blood, which</b> is not a Torah prohibition <b>unless there is</b> at least the volume of <b>a quarter</b><i>-log</i>, one might <b>say</b> that there is <b>no</b> prohibition against directly feeding minors, as this prohibition is more lenient. <b>And</b> had the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>blood,</b> we would have said that they were stringent with regard to blood <b>because there is</b> the punishment of <b><i>karet</i></b> for eating blood. <b>However, for creeping animals,</b> whose consumption does not entail <i>karet</i>, one might <b>say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply.
<b>And</b> had the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only <b>these two</b> cases, we would have said it is <b>because their prohibitions apply equally to all</b> Jews. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>ritual impurity,</b> which is a mitzva for priests alone, one might <b>say</b> that there is <b>no</b> prohibition against directly rendering minors ritually impure. <b>And</b> had the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>ritual impurity,</b> we would have said that the case of <b>priests is different</b> and more stringent, <b>because</b> the Torah <b>includes</b> extra mitzvot <b>for them. However,</b> with regard to <b>these</b> prohibitions of creeping animals and blood, one might <b>say</b> that there is <b>no</b> prohibition against directly feeding minors. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> to state all these cases.
§ The Gemara cites another relevant source with regard to a minor who eats the meat of unslaughtered animals. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If <b>two brothers, one</b> of whom is <b>a deaf-mute and</b> the other <b>one</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> were <b>married to two</b> halakhically <b>competent sisters, and the deaf-mute married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>died, what should the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>do?</b> His brother’s wife is <b>released</b> without levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>due to</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a wife’s sister.</b>
If <b>the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>died, what should the deaf-mute</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>do? He divorces his wife with a bill of divorce,</b> which is as valid as their original marriage. <b>And his brother’s wife is forbidden</b> to him <b>forever.</b> He must divorce his wife, as the levirate bond applies by Torah law, whereas his marriage is valid by rabbinic law. However, in practice he is unable to consummate levirate marriage with the <i>yevama</i> or perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her.
The Gemara inquires: <b>Why</b> should <b>he divorce his wife with a bill of divorce? Let her</b> continue to <b>live with him,</b> as a deaf-mute <b>is</b> in the same category <b>as a minor who eats</b> the meat of <b>unslaughtered animals,</b> for he is not legally competent. Consequently, even if he were to engage in sexual relations with her, this would not be considered a transgression. The Gemara answers: If the matter concerned the deaf-mute alone, this would be the case. However, here he must divorce her <b>due to the prohibition</b> that applies to <b>her,</b> as his wife is legally competent, and just as she is forbidden to him, he is also forbidden to her.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If <b>two</b> halakhically <b>competent brothers</b> were <b>married to two sisters, one</b> of whom is <b>a deaf-mute and</b> the other <b>one</b> halakhically <b>competent, and the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the deaf-mute</b> sister <b>died, what should the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>do?</b> The deaf-mute is <b>released due to</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a wife’s sister.</b> If <b>the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>died, what should the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the deaf-mute</b> sister <b>do? He divorces his wife with a bill of divorce,</b> as the halakhically competent sister came before him for levirate marriage, and the legal status of her levirate bond is higher than that of his marriage to his wife, a deaf-mute. <b>And he</b> releases <b>his brother’s wife,</b> who is not a deaf-mute, <b>by means of <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as they are both competent and can therefore perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara again asks: <b>But why</b> should <b>he divorce his wife with a bill of divorce? Let her</b> continue to <b>live with him,</b> as a deaf-mute <b>is</b> in the same category <b>as a minor who eats</b> the meat of <b>unslaughtered animals.</b> The Gemara answers as above: He must divorce her <b>due to the prohibition</b> that applies to <b>him.</b>
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If <b>two brothers, one</b> of whom is <b>a deaf-mute and</b> the other <b>one</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> were <b>married to two sisters, one</b> of whom is <b>a deaf-mute and</b> the other <b>one</b> halakhically <b>competent, and the deaf-mute</b> brother <b>married to the deaf-mute</b> sister <b>died, what should the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>do?</b> The deaf-mute woman is <b>released due to</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a wife’s sister.</b> If <b>the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> brother <b>married to the</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> sister <b>died, what should the deaf-mute</b> brother <b>married to the deaf-mute</b> sister <b>do? He divorces his wife with a bill of divorce, and his brother’s wife is forbidden</b> to him <b>forever.</b>
Rava elaborates: <b>But here</b> is a case <b>where there is no prohibition</b> that applies to <b>her and there is no prohibition</b> that applies to <b>him,</b> as they are both deaf-mutes who are not prohibited to each other, <b>and</b> yet it <b>is taught</b> that <b>he divorces his wife with a bill of divorce. Rav Shemaya said:</b> This is a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the danger of <b>permitting a <i>yevama</i> to</b> a member of the <b>public.</b> Since people might think that the deaf-mute sister is his full-fledged wife, they are likely to conclude that it is permitted for this <i>yevama</i> to marry someone other than the <i>yavam</i>, like any other sister of the wife of the <i>yavam</i>. However, in actual fact she is not the sister of the wife of her <i>yavam</i>, as the deaf-mutes are not married by Torah law, and she may not marry any other man because she is a <i>yevama</i> whose <i>yavam</i> cannot marry her or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. For this reason, the Sages decreed that this deaf-mute husband must divorce his wife. In sum, this source too does not provide conclusive proof with regard to the question of a minor who eats meat from unslaughtered animals.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman who went, she and her husband, overseas,</b> if there was <b>peace between him and her,</b> i.e., the couple were not fighting at the time, <b>and</b> there was also <b>peace in the world,</b> i.e., there was no war at that time, <b>and</b> the woman <b>came</b> back by herself <b>and said: My husband died, she may marry</b> on the basis of her own testimony. Likewise, if she said: <b>My husband died,</b> and they did not have children, but her husband had a brother, <b>she may enter into levirate marriage.</b>
If there was <b>peace between him and her</b> when they left <b>but</b> there was <b>war in the world,</b> or if there was <b>a quarrel between him and her and peace in the world, and she came and said: My husband died, she is not deemed credible,</b> as she may be mistaken or lying. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: She is never deemed credible</b> when she testifies that her husband died, <b>unless she came crying and her clothing was torn,</b> in which case it is apparent that she is speaking the truth. <b>They said to him:</b> This is an incorrect distinction. Rather, <b>both this</b> woman who cries <b>and this</b> woman who does not cry <b>may marry</b> on the basis of their own testimony.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>taught</b> the clause: <b>Peace between him and her, because</b> later <b>he wanted to teach</b> the clause: <b>A quarrel between him and her.</b> Likewise, <b>he taught: Peace in the world, because he wanted to teach</b> afterward: <b>War in the world.</b> In other words, the fact that there was peace between them or peace in the world is of importance only because the opposite is the case in other situations dealt with in the mishna. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> emphasized the lack of disruptions in the first case cited by the mishna.
<b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> that one does not rely on her testimony <b>when</b> there is <b>war?</b> It is <b>because she says</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case: Can it <b>enter one’s mind</b> that <b>among all these</b> people <b>who were killed,</b> her husband alone <b>is saved? If you say: Since there was peace between him and her, she guards herself</b> and waits <b>until she</b> actually <b>sees</b> that he died; even so, <b>at times</b> it might happen <b>that</b> his enemies <b>strike him with an arrow or spear and she thinks</b> that <b>he is certainly dead</b> due to the wound, <b>and</b> yet this is no proof that he is dead, as <b>there are</b> instances <b>when</b> someone <b>prepares medicine [<i>samterei</i>]</b> for the wounded person <b>and he survives,</b> despite his apparently fatal wound.
<b>Rava thought to say</b> that <b>famine is not like war, as</b> in the case of a famine <b>she will not say</b> and infer based on what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case. <b>Rava then</b> retracted and <b>said: Famine is like war.</b> Why did he change his mind? This happened <b>because a certain woman came before Rava,</b> and <b>said to him: My husband died in a famine.</b> Seeking to cross-examine her, Rava <b>said to her:</b> Did <b>you do well to save yourself,</b> by running away and leaving him? Did it <b>enter your mind that with that small amount of sifted flour that you left him he could have survived? She said to him: The Master also knows that in a case like this he could not survive.</b> Rava understood from her comment that she did not actually see her husband die, but merely saw that he was weak from hunger, and yet she testified with certainty that he died.
<b>Rava then</b> retracted again and <b>said: Famine is worse than war</b> in this respect. <b>As</b> in <b>wartime,</b> it is only <b>if she said: My husband died in the war, that she is not deemed credible.</b> This indicates that if in a time of war she says: <b>He died upon his bed,</b> or in some other unrelated manner, <b>she is deemed credible,</b> as she would not err in this case, <b>whereas with regard to a famine she</b> is deemed credible only <b>if she says: He died and I buried him.</b> In other words, during a famine it must be clear that she is testifying about his actual death, and is not basing her claim on an assumption.
Similarly, <b>a rockslide is like war, as she will say</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case, and she might not meticulously examine the facts to see if he was possibly saved. Furthermore, <b>an outbreak of snakes and scorpions is like war, as she will say</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case.
In a case of <b>pestilence</b> or a similar plague, <b>some say it is like war, and some say it is not like war.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Some say it is like war, as she will say</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case, because she assumes that if most everyone died in the plague her husband could not have survived. Conversely, <b>some say it is not like war, because we rely on that which people say</b> in the common expression: For <b>seven years there was pestilence and not a person left,</b> i.e., died, <b>before his time.</b> In other words, with regard to natural disasters of this kind it is known sometimes that one can avoid harm, and therefore if a woman testifies that her husband died she certainly witnessed his death.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the scholars: If <b>she maintains</b> that there is <b>a war in the world,</b> i.e., if the court was not aware of a war in that place, but the wife comes and claims that there was a war, and she went on to say that her husband died in this war, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case? <b>Do we say: Why should she lie?</b> In other words, if she was lying she would have issued a more advantageous claim. Since she herself informed the court that there was a war, which undermines her claim that her husband died, there is no legitimate reason to suspect her of lying.

Daf 115a

<b>Because if she wanted</b> to lie <b>she</b> would have <b>said:</b> There was <b>peace in the world,</b> and the court would have accepted her testimony. <b>Or perhaps</b> it can be argued: <b>Since she has maintained</b> that there was a war and this claim of hers has already been accepted, with regard to her report concerning her husband, <b>she will say</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case, <b>and</b> the argument of: <b>Why would I lie, does not come and undermine the</b> established <b>presumption</b> that there was a war.
The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> in an attempt to resolve this dilemma. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> It was taught that if a woman comes and says: <b>They set our house</b> on fire and the house became filled with <b>smoke,</b> or: <b>They set our cave</b> on fire to <b>smoke</b> us out, and she adds: My husband <b>died and I was saved, she is not deemed credible.</b> In this case, she herself related the entire story, and even so her version of events is not accepted. The Gemara answers that this is no proof. <b>There,</b> in the case of the fire, <b>it is different, as one says to her: Just as a miracle occurred for you</b> and you were saved, <b>likewise a miracle</b> might have <b>occurred for</b> your husband and he too survived.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from another <i>baraita</i>. If a woman comes and says: A group of <b>gentiles attacked us,</b> or: A group <b>of bandits attacked us,</b> and she adds: My husband <b>died and I was saved, she is deemed credible.</b> This indicates that her testimony is accepted due to the argument of: Why should she lie? The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>There,</b> in that <i>baraita</i>, her testimony is accepted because it stands to reason that she is speaking the truth, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Idi. As Rav Idi said:</b> With regard to <b>a woman, her weapons are upon her.</b> In other words, a woman is generally not killed by thieves, because the very fact of her being a woman protects her. They would most likely rape her and not kill her. Consequently, it is reasonable to assume that she is speaking the truth.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who</b> got married. <b>At the end of his wedding a fire broke out in the bridal chamber,</b> where the bride and groom were standing, during the ceremony. <b>His wife</b> screamed and <b>said to them: Look at my husband, look at my husband! They went and saw</b> an unrecognizable <b>burnt man fallen down, and a palm</b> of a hand <b>lying</b> there.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin thought to say: This is</b> the same as the case of: <b>They set our house</b> on fire and the house became filled with <b>smoke,</b> or: <b>They set our cave</b> on fire to <b>smoke</b> us out, i.e., we cannot rely on her claim that her husband died. <b>Rava said: Is</b> this case <b>comparable</b> to those? <b>There she did not say: Look at my husband, look at my husband. And furthermore,</b> there is another difference: Here, there is <b>a burnt man who has fallen down and a palm that is lying</b> there. In other words, her statement is substantiated by facts.
<b>And</b> why didn’t <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin</b> accept her testimony? In his opinion, <b>a burnt man who has fallen down</b> is not conclusive proof, as one might still <b>say:</b> Perhaps <b>another person came to the rescue and the fire burned him. And</b> as for <b>the palm lying</b> there, perhaps <b>the fire burned him and caused a deformity</b> through which he lost his hand, <b>and due to his embarrassment he went and ran away to</b> somewhere else <b>in the world,</b> but he is still alive. Consequently, Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin did not want to rely upon the testimony of the wife.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before them:</b> In the case of <b>one witness</b> who testifies to the death of someone <b>during a war, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>The reason that one witness is deemed credible</b> when he provides testimony concerning the death of a husband is <b>because</b> the husband being alive <b>is a matter that is likely to be revealed,</b> and one would <b>not lie</b> in a case of this kind. <b>Here, too,</b> one witness would <b>not lie. Or perhaps the reason that one witness</b> is trusted <b>is because</b> his account is supported by the fact that <b>she herself is exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. <b>And here, since sometimes</b> she <b>hates him,</b> and war is a situation that requires especially careful investigation and it is tempting for her to rely on the witness, <b>she is not exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again, and therefore the testimony of one witness is not accepted.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma. <b>Rabbi Akiva said: When I descended to Neharde’a</b> in Babylonia <b>to intercalate the year, I found</b> there the Sage <b>Neḥemya of Beit D’li, and he said to me: I heard that</b> the Sages <b>do not</b> allow <b>a woman to marry in Eretz Yisrael based on</b> the testimony of <b>one witness, apart from Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava,</b> as the other Sages are reluctant to rely on his opinion. <b>And I said [<i>namti</i>] to him: This is so. He said to me: Say to them in my name:</b> Do <b>you know that this country is riddled with troops? This is</b> the tradition that <b>I received from Rabban Gamliel the Elder, that</b> the Sages do allow <b>a woman to marry based on one witness.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i> in relation to the issue at hand. <b>What</b> is the significance of his comment that this <b>country is riddled with troops? Isn’t</b> he saying: <b>Even though this country is riddled</b> with troops, <b>this is</b> the tradition that <b>I received, that</b> the Sages do allow <b>a woman to marry based on one witness,</b> notwithstanding the war. <b>Apparently, one witness is deemed credible</b> in the case of a missing husband during a time of war.
<b>Rava said: If this is</b> how you interpret the matter, in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this <b>country different</b> from any other? In other words, why did Neḥemya of Beit D’li mention a particular place? <b>He should have</b> said: <b>Any place where there are troops. Rather, Rava said: This is what he said: You know that this country is riddled with troops, and I cannot leave the members of my household and come before the Sages,</b> due to the danger. Therefore, I cannot testify in person that <b>this is</b> the tradition that <b>I received from Rabban Gamliel</b> the Elder, <b>that</b> the Sages allow <b>a woman to marry based on one witness.</b> According to this interpretation, his statement has no bearing on the matter at hand.
The Gemara continues. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> that relates <b>an incident involving two Torah scholars who were coming with Abba Yosei ben Simai by boat, and</b> that boat <b>sank. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi allowed <b>their wives to marry based on</b> the testimony given by <b>women</b> that these men were dead. <b>But</b> consider: <b>Water,</b> i.e., the sea, <b>is like war</b> with respect to this <i>halakha</i>, as there is room in both cases for conjecture and error. <b>And women, even one hundred</b> of them, <b>are considered as one witness</b> with regard to their testimony about a husband’s death. <b>And</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught:</b> He allowed them <b>to marry,</b> which indicates that one may rely on one witness even during a war.
The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way? Apparently, the women testified only that the boat sank, <b>and this is</b> a case of <b>an endless body of water,</b> as the boat sank at sea in a spot from which it is impossible to see the shore. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that if a man was on a boat that sank in <b>an endless body of water his wife is prohibited</b> to marry, as there is no proof that he actually drowned and didn’t emerge from the water on a different shore. <b>Rather,</b> one must say: <b>What are the circumstances? That</b> those women <b>said: Those</b> drowned men <b>were brought up before us</b>

Daf 115b

<b>and we saw them immediately</b> when they came out of the water, <b>and</b> the women <b>stated distinguishing marks</b> that identified these people. <b>As,</b> in this case <b>we do not rely upon</b> the women, <b>but</b> upon <b>the distinguishing marks.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who deposited sesame plants with his friend.</b> Sometime later <b>he said to him: Give me the sesame plants.</b> The friend <b>said to him: You</b> already <b>took them.</b> The owner replied: <b>But they were</b> of <b>such-and-such</b> an amount, <b>and placed in a barrel;</b> go and check that barrel and you will see that I am right. The bailee <b>said to him: You took your</b> sesame plants, <b>and these</b> in the barrel at my house <b>are other ones.</b>
The case came before the Sages for a ruling. <b>Rav Ḥisda thought to say: This</b> situation <b>is</b> the same as the situation involving the <b>two Torah scholars</b> who drowned, when they used distinguishing marks to identify them. <b>And we do not say</b> in that case: <b>Those</b> men <b>went</b> elsewhere <b>in the world, and these</b> men who floated up <b>are different people.</b> Here too one may rely upon the distinguishing marks of the sesame plants given by the owner, and there is no reason to think that these sesame plants are different ones.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Is it comparable? There they said distinguishing marks</b> that identified the victims. <b>Here,</b> in the case of <b>sesame plants, what distinguishing marks might they have,</b> by which they could be identified? <b>And</b> as for <b>that which he said: They were</b> of <b>such-and-such</b> an amount, one can <b>say it happened by chance</b> that this second time it <b>was</b> the same <b>amount,</b> and there is no proof that these are the same sesame plants.
With regard to the same issue, <b>Mar Kashisha, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: And are we concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the one guarding the plants <b>moved them</b> from their place? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 4:11): If one <b>found a vessel on which</b> the letter <b><i>kuf</i> was written,</b> all objects inside the vessel are designated for a <b><i>korban</i>,</b> an offering; if the letter <b><i>mem</i></b> was written on it, it is <b><i>ma’aser</i>,</b> tithes; if it was the letter <b><i>dalet</i>,</b> it is <b><i>dimua</i>,</b> a mixture of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce; if <b><i>tet</i>,</b> it signifies <b><i>tevel</i>,</b> untithed produce; and finally, if it is a <b><i>tav</i>,</b> it indicates <b><i>teruma</i>. As during a time of danger,</b> i.e., religious persecution against Jews, <b>they would write,</b> for example, <b><i>tav</i> instead of <i>teruma</i>.</b> In this case, no concern is expressed that someone might have moved the <i>teruma</i> from that vessel to somewhere else.
In response to this claim, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And aren’t we concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> someone <b>moved</b> the <i>teruma</i> from their place? <b>Say the latter clause</b> of that same mishna <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even if</b> one <b>found a barrel on which</b> the full word <b><i>teruma</i> was written, these</b> contents <b>are non-sacred. As I say: Last year it was full of <i>teruma</i>, and</b> someone <b>removed</b> the contents and replaced them with non-sacred produce. This proves that the possibility that someone moved the original contents is taken into consideration.
<b>Rather,</b> say as follows: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> someone <b>moved</b> the contents of a container from their place, <b>and here,</b> with regard to the marked vessels, <b>they disagree about this</b> issue: <b>The Sage</b> who claims that one may rely on the inscription <b>holds</b> that <b>if it is so, that he moved</b> the <i>teruma</i>, <b>he would have erased</b> the inscription. <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yosei, responds that one can <b>say he forgot</b> to do so. <b>Alternatively, he left the label to preserve [<i>panaḥya</i>]</b> the contents, so that people would mistakenly think that it contained <i>teruma</i> and would refrain from taking the produce.
§ The Gemara relates a story that deals with the permission of a woman to remarry. <b>Yitzḥak the Exilarch, son of the sister of Rav Beivai, was walking from Cortva to Spain and died</b> along the way. <b>They sent</b> this message <b>from</b> Spain: <b>Yitzḥak the Exilarch, son of the sister of Rav Beivai, was walking from Cortva to Spain and died.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Are we concerned about</b> the possibility of <b>two</b> men named <b>Yitzḥak or not?</b> Perhaps there is someone else with the same name, and therefore the mention of his name is not a sufficiently distinguishing mark. <b>Abaye said: We are concerned</b> about this possibility. <b>Rava said: We are not concerned.</b>
<b>Abaye said: From where do I say</b> my reasoning that there might be another man with the same name? <b>As a certain bill of divorce was found in</b> the city of <b>Neharde’a, and</b> this passage was <b>written</b> on it: <b>On the colonial [<i>kelonya</i>] side of the city, I, Androlinai of Neharde’a, excused, sent away,</b> and divorced <b>my wife so-and-so.</b> Androlinai’s wife requested permission to remarry based on this bill of divorce, but they did not know if he was the man who gave the divorce or if it was given by another man of the same name. <b>And the father of Shmuel sent this</b> question <b>before Rabbi Yehuda Nesia</b> in Eretz Yisrael. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <b>sent</b> a message <b>to him: All of Neharde’a must be examined,</b> to see whether there is another man by that name. This shows that one must be concerned that there might be two people with the same name.
<b>And Rava said:</b> This story provides no proof. <b>If it is so,</b> that there were grounds to suspect that someone else of the same name wrote the bill of divorce, Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <b>should have</b> said: <b>The entire world must be examined,</b> in case there is someone else with the same name somewhere. Since he did not say this, evidently there was no legitimate reason for this suspicion at all. Why, then, did Rabbi Yehuda Nesia send instructions to examine all of Neharde’a? <b>Rather,</b> Rava added, <b>it was due to respect for the father of Shmuel that he sent this</b> message. He did not want to write explicitly that Shmuel’s father had inquired unnecessarily, and therefore he wrote his reply in a manner which indicated his partial agreement with the concern.
<b>Rava said: From where do I say</b> my reasoning that we are not concerned about two people with identical names? <b>As there were two</b> promissory <b>notes produced in Meḥoza, and</b> these names of the creditors were <b>written on them: Ḥavai bar Nanai and Nanai bar Ḥavai, and Rava bar Avuh collected dinars</b> for them <b>with these</b> promissory notes, without concerning himself with the possibility that they might be referring to other people. <b>And</b> the names <b>Ḥavai bar Nanai and Nanai bar Ḥavai are very common in Meḥoza,</b> i.e., there are certainly other people with these names, and yet he was not worried about this matter. The Gemara asks: <b>And Abaye,</b> how does he answer this proof?

Daf 116a

<b>With regard to what</b> should we <b>be concerned</b> in the case of the promissory note? <b>If</b> we are concerned <b>about</b> the possibility of <b>falling,</b> i.e., that the promissory note might have dropped from this person’s hand and the other one found it, the former is certainly <b>careful with it</b> so as not to lose it, as he knows there is someone else in the city with the same name. <b>If</b> we are concerned <b>about</b> the possibility that it was given as <b>a deposit</b> for safekeeping, i.e., that the actual owner might have given it to the one in possession of it, <b>since his name is the same as the name</b> of the bailee, the owner <b>would not deposit</b> his contract <b>with him</b> without some insurance.
<b>If you say</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the actual owner <b>passed,</b> i.e., transferred the promissory note <b>to this</b> person whose name is the same as his own, i.e., he gave or sold it to him so he may collect it for himself, in that case the one in possession is entitled to collect the money, as <b>letters</b> of credit <b>are acquired through passing.</b> There is no need for an additional act of acquisition here, which means that the promissory note belongs to the one in possession of it, despite the fact that it was not originally written for him. Consequently, no proof can be brought from this case with regard to whether or not one should be concerned about two people with identical names.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain bill of divorce that was found in</b> the city of <b>Sura and the following was written in it: In the city of Sura, I, Anan bar Ḥiyya</b> of <b>Neharde’a, excused and sent away</b> and divorced <b>my wife, so-and-so. And the Sages examined</b> the area <b>from Sura to Neharde’a,</b> throughout almost all of Babylonia, <b>and there was no other Anan bar Ḥiyya</b> than the one they knew, <b>apart from an Anan bar Ḥiyya of Ḥagra who was in Neharde’a. And</b> yet <b>witnesses came and said that on that day, when that bill of divorce was written: Anan bar Ḥiyya of Ḥagra was with us</b> in Neharde’a, not in Sura.
<b>Abaye said: Even according to my</b> opinion, by <b>which I say</b> that generally <b>we are concerned</b> about the possibility of someone else with the same name, <b>here we are not concerned.</b> The reason is <b>that the witnesses say</b> the other Anan bar Ḥiyya <b>was in Neharde’a; what,</b> then, <b>is he doing in Sura?</b> Consequently, there is no concern that the bill of divorce was written by the Anan bar Ḥiyya of Ḥagra.
<b>Rava said: Even according to my</b> opinion, in which I say <b>that we are not concerned</b> in general, <b>here,</b> when it is established that there definitely is another man by the same name, <b>we are concerned.</b> As for the apparently contradictory testimony, <b>perhaps he went by a flying camel,</b> an extremely fast means of transportation, and was able to travel from Neharde’a to Sura in one day. <b>Alternatively,</b> he might have arrived <b>by</b> a miraculous <b>shortcut. Alternatively,</b> he might have <b>given verbal instructions</b> beforehand for them to write the bill of divorce in a place where he was not physically located.
This last answer is <b>as Rav said to the</b> court <b>scribes, and likewise Rav Huna said to the scribes: When you are in</b> a place called <b>Shili, write</b> that the contract was written <b>in Shili, even when the instructions are given</b> to you <b>in</b> a different place called <b>Hini. And</b> likewise, <b>when you are in Hini, write</b> that it was written <b>in Hini, even when the instructions are given</b> to you <b>in Shili.</b>
The Gemara returns to the original question: <b>What was</b> the conclusion that was reached <b>about this</b> case involving <b>sesame plants?</b> Do they belong to the one who deposited them, or is the claim of the bailee accepted, that he returned them and placed other sesame plants in the same barrel? <b>Rav Yeimar said: We are not concerned</b> that they are different plants, and <b>Ravina said: We are concerned.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>we are concerned</b> about the possibility that the bailee replaced them with others, and we do not rely on the distinguishing marks provided by the claimant in this case.
§ The mishna taught: If there was <b>a quarrel between him and her,</b> her testimony that her husband died is not accepted. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of a <b>quarrel between him and her? Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This is a case <b>where</b> people heard <b>her say to her husband: Divorce me.</b> The Gemara asks: Is this proof? <b>All</b> women <b>likewise say this</b> when they are angry; this does not prove that there was an unresolved quarrel left between them. <b>Rather,</b> a quarrel is <b>when she says to her husband: You divorced me,</b> i.e., she claims that she was actually divorced.
The Gemara asks: If she said to her husband that he divorced her, <b>let us believe her</b> claim, <b>in</b> accordance with the statement <b>of Rav Hamnuna. As Rav Hamnuna said: A woman who said to her husband: You divorced me, is deemed credible.</b> Why? There is <b>a presumption</b> that <b>a woman would not dare</b> to lie <b>in the presence of her husband</b> about a matter which he knows to be untrue. If so, why isn’t her claim that she was divorced accepted? This would mean that there is no need for any testimony concerning his death, as the ties between them have already been severed.
The Gemara answers: In fact, a couple is considered to be quarreling <b>when she says: You divorced me in the presence of</b> two witnesses, <b>so-and-so and so-and-so; and</b> the court <b>asked those</b> men <b>and they said: This matter never happened.</b> In this case it is obvious that there was a terrible quarrel between them, but her claim that she was divorced is not accepted. Consequently, her later claim that her husband is dead is not accepted.
§ The Gemara analyzes the ruling of the mishna itself. <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>in</b> the case of <b>a quarrel</b> between them the court does not accept her testimony? <b>Rav Ḥanina said: Because she lies,</b> i.e., due to their quarrel she is likely to testify falsely that her husband died. <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: Because she says</b> what <b>she imagines</b> to be the case. When there is peace between them, she examines the matter thoroughly to discover whether he actually died, but if there is a quarrel between them she is not so exacting, as she is pleased to be rid of him. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> these two explanations?

Daf 116b

The practical difference <b>between them is</b> in a case <b>where he initiated the quarrel.</b> In this situation there is no concern that she might knowingly lie, as she loves him. However, due to the quarrel between them she might not be meticulous in her investigations.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there was <b>one witness</b> who testified that the husband died, <b>in</b> a case that involved <b>a quarrel</b> between them, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains the different sides of this dilemma: <b>What is the reason that one witness is deemed credible?</b> Is it <b>because</b> it <b>is a matter that is likely to be revealed,</b> and one does <b>not lie</b> in a case of this kind? <b>Here too,</b> one witness would <b>not lie. Or perhaps the reason that one witness is deemed credible is because she</b> herself <b>is exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. <b>And here, since there is a quarrel</b> between them, <b>she is not exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again, despite the testimony of the witness. The Gemara comments: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that a wife <b>is never</b> deemed credible when she testifies that her husband died, unless she came crying and her clothing was torn, while the Rabbis say she may remarry in any case. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yehuda: According to your statement, a crafty woman</b> who knows how to deceive will come with torn clothes crying, and it <b>will</b> be permitted for her to <b>marry.</b> However, <b>a foolish woman</b> who does not know how to deceive <b>will not</b> be permitted to <b>marry.</b> Is this a fair outcome? <b>Rather, both this</b> woman <b>and that</b> woman <b>may marry.</b>
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> woman <b>who came to the court of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The people sitting there <b>said to her: Lament your husband, tear your clothing, unbind your hair,</b> so that you have the appearance of a mourner, and the court will believe you. The Gemara asks: Did <b>they instruct her to lie?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They thought, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that it is permitted for her to marry in any case. However, they were concerned that Rabbi Yehuda would rule that she may not remarry if she did not display her grief, in accordance with his opinion. Therefore, <b>they said</b> that <b>she should do this, so that</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>would</b> also <b>permit her</b> to marry, and she would avoid any complications.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Hillel say: We heard</b> that one may accept the testimony of a woman concerning the death of her husband <b>only when she comes from the grain harvest, and</b> when she testified <b>in the same country</b> where he died, <b>and</b> in circumstances <b>similar to the incident that occurred,</b> in which a lenient ruling was issued, as will be explained.
<b>Beit Shammai said to</b> Beit Hillel: The <b>same</b> <i>halakha</i> applies to a wife <b>who comes from the grain harvest, and one who comes from the olive</b> harvest, <b>and</b> also <b>one who comes from the grape harvest, and</b> even <b>one who comes from one country to</b> another <b>country.</b> Although the incident in question took place during the grain harvest, <b>the Sages spoke of the grain harvest only</b> because it was the <b>present</b> occurrence, i.e., that is what happened in practice, but this is no proof that she is deemed credible only when she arrived specifically from the grain harvest. The mishna comments: <b>Beit Hillel retracted</b> their opinion, and decided <b>to teach in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai</b> on this issue.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Beit Shammai said to Beit Hillel: According to your statement</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies solely in circumstances similar to the incident that occurred, if so, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it applies in <b>the wheat harvest. From where</b> do I derive that the same applies in <b>the barley harvest? And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it applies to <b>one who reaps</b> grain. <b>From where</b> do I derive that this <i>halakha</i> includes <b>someone who harvests</b> grapes, <b>or harvests</b> olives, <b>or harvests</b> dates, <b>or harvests</b> figs?
<b>Rather, that incident which occurred during the grain harvest, and the same is true of all these</b> other circumstances. <b>Here too,</b> concerning a woman who comes from another country, and other, similar cases, <b>the incident that occurred</b> took place <b>in that country, but the same is true of all these</b> other cases.
<b>And Beit Hillel,</b> how did they respond to this argument? <b>In that same country, where people are</b> commonly <b>found</b> moving from place to place, <b>she is scared</b> to lie, lest her account be contradicted. However, <b>between one country and another country, where people are not</b> commonly <b>found</b> moving back and forth, <b>she is not scared,</b> and therefore she might be lying when she says he died. <b>And Beit Shammai</b> reason: <b>Here too caravans are found,</b> and if he was alive the truth would eventually be revealed.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> was this <b>incident that occurred? As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: It was at the end [<i>shilfei</i>] of the wheat harvest, and ten people went to harvest wheat. A snake bit one of them and he died, and his wife came and told the court</b> that her husband died. <b>And they sent</b> messengers, who <b>discovered</b> that it happened <b>in accordance with her statement. At that time they said: The woman who says: My husband died, may marry</b> on the basis of this testimony. Furthermore, if she says: <b>My husband died</b> without children, and he has a brother, <b>she enters into levirate marriage.</b> This is the case to which Beit Hillel referred.
§ The Gemara analyzes this dispute. <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akiva and the Rabbis,</b> who argued in this case, <b>disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may not carry the waters of purification,</b> i.e., the water containing the ashes of the red heifer for the ritual purification of one who became impure through contact with a corpse, <b>and the ashes of purification,</b> of the red heifer, <b>and transport them on the Jordan</b> River. <b>And</b> one may not transfer them across the river <b>in a boat.</b>
<b>And one may not stand on one side</b> of the river <b>and throw</b> the ashes <b>to the other side, nor float them upon the water</b> as he crosses, <b>nor ride with them</b> across the river, <b>neither on the back of an animal nor on the back of another</b> person, as this is similar to a boat that passes over the water, <b>unless the legs</b> of the rider <b>were touching the ground. However, one may transport them</b> across the water <b>over a bridge.</b> This prohibition applies to <b>both the Jordan</b> River <b>and</b> all <b>other rivers. Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akiva says: They said</b> this prohibition <b>only</b> with regard to <b>the Jordan, and</b> transporting <b>in a boat, and in</b> circumstances similar <b>to</b> the <b>incident that occurred,</b> when ritual impurity was found in a boat on the Jordan River.
<b>Let us say</b> that <b>the Rabbis say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> that when a decree is enacted due to a specific case that occurred, this <i>halakha</i> applies to all similar circumstances. <b>And Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akiva says in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> that the decree applies only in the exact circumstances as the precedent case.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion. <b>The Rabbis</b> could <b>say to you: We stated</b> our ruling <b>even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> as there is a difference between the two cases. <b>Beit Hillel state</b> their opinion, that she is not deemed credible when she comes from one country to another, <b>only</b> in that case <b>there, because she is scared. In a nearby place she is scared</b> to give false testimony, as her lie can easily be discovered, whereas <b>in a distant place she is not scared.</b> However, <b>here,</b> concerning the ashes of the red heifer, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if it is <b>the Jordan</b> River, and <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if it is one of the many <b>other rivers?</b>
Meanwhile, <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akiva</b> could have <b>said to you: I stated</b> my ruling <b>even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> as <b>Beit Shammai state</b> their opinion <b>only there, because she</b> herself <b>is exacting</b> in her investigation before she <b>marries</b> again. Since this is the decisive consideration, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if <b>the place is near,</b> and <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if <b>the place is far? Here,</b> however, the Sages issued their decree <b>due to</b> a specific <b>incident that occurred. And</b> therefore <b>the Sages issued</b> their <b>decree with regard to the Jordan</b> River <b>and in a boat,</b> the circumstances in <b>which</b> the <b>incident occurred.</b> Conversely, <b>the Sages did not issue</b> the <b>decree with regard to other rivers, where the incident did not occur.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is <b>this incident that occurred,</b> involving the ashes of the red heifer? <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a person who was transporting waters of purification and ashes of purification on the Jordan</b> River, <b>and in a boat, and an olive-bulk of a corpse was found stuck to the bottom of the boat,</b> which rendered the waters and ashes ritually impure. <b>At that time they said: A person may not carry waters of purification and ashes of purification and transport them on the Jordan</b> River, <b>and in a boat.</b> Later Sages dispute whether this decree applies to similar cases, or only to the exact circumstances of this specific incident.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> A woman who testifies that her husband died <b>may marry, and take</b> the money guaranteed in <b>her marriage contract. Beit Hillel say: She may marry, but she may not take her marriage contract,</b> as qualified witnesses are required for monetary matters. <b>Beit Shammai said to them:</b> If <b>you have permitted</b> a <b>woman</b> potentially <b>forbidden to him, which is</b> a relatively <b>stringent</b> prohibition, based merely upon her own testimony, <b>will we not permit a monetary matter,</b> which is more <b>lenient,</b> as the money can be returned and this sin does not entail such a severe punishment? <b>Beit Hillel said to them:</b> This is no proof, as <b>we find</b>

Daf 117a

<b>that the brothers do not come into</b> the <b>inheritance</b> from the deceased brother <b>based on her</b> testimony. Evidently, although this testimony is accepted with regard to forbidden sexual relationships, it is not effective for monetary matters.
<b>Beit Shammai said to them: But we can learn this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from the scroll of the marriage contract, as</b> every husband <b>writes for her that: If you marry another</b> man, <b>take what is written for you</b> in this contract. This shows that her right to receive the money of her marriage contract is dependent upon her eligibility to remarry. In this case, as she is deemed credible when she says her husband died and she may marry again, she is likewise entitled to the money of the marriage contract. <b>And Beit Hillel</b> again <b>retracted</b> their opinion, and decided <b>to teach in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> If the woman <b>entered into levirate marriage</b> based upon her own testimony, <b>her <i>yavam</i> comes into</b> the <b>inheritance</b> of the property of his dead brother <b>based on her</b> testimony. He adds: If Beit Shammai <b>taught</b> their <i>halakha</i> that she is entitled to her money, <b>by interpreting homiletically</b> the language of a <b>marriage contract, will we not teach by interpreting homiletically the Torah</b> itself?
Rav Ḥisda explains: <b>The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“He shall succeed in the name of his</b> dead <b>brother”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:6), which is interpreted by the Sages as referring to the right of inheritance of the brother who consummates the levirate marriage. <b>And</b> this man <b>did succeed</b> with respect to the marital relationship, as he consummated the levirate marriage based on the testimony of his <i>yevama</i> that her husband died. Consequently, he takes the place of his brother with respect to his inheritance as well.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> A woman <b>came to the court and said: My husband died; permit me to marry.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that after investigating the matter, <b>they permit her to marry, and</b> also <b>give her her marriage contract.</b> However, if she came and said: <b>Give me my marriage contract, they do not even permit her to marry. What is the reason?</b> Since <b>she came with</b> the money of the <b>marriage contract in mind,</b> she is suspected of lying, and her testimony is rejected.
However, the following <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the scholars. If she came and said: <b>Permit me to marry and give me my marriage contract, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Since she mentioned</b> the money from <b>her marriage contract,</b> this shows that <b>she came with the marriage contract in mind. Or perhaps every matter a person has</b> in his favor <b>he</b> will <b>say to the court,</b> even if it is not of particular importance. <b>And if you say</b> that the ruling in this case is in accordance with the principle: <b>Every matter a person has</b> in his favor <b>he</b> will <b>say to the court,</b> then in a case where she said: <b>Give me my marriage contract and permit me to marry, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>Here she certainly came with the marriage contract in mind,</b> as she mentioned it first. <b>Or perhaps</b> she said it in this manner <b>since she does not know what will set her free.</b> In other words, she might have thought that taking the money guaranteed by her marriage contract is part of the process that enables her to remarry, but this does not prove that she is focused on the money. The Gemara states that the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All are deemed credible</b> when they come <b>to give testimony with regard to</b> the death of a woman’s husband, <b>apart from her mother-in-law, the daughter of her mother-in-law, her rival wife, the wife of her <i>yavam</i>, and her husband’s daughter,</b> her stepdaughter. The reason is that these women are likely to hate her and will lie to her detriment.
The mishna explains: In the case of a divorce all people, including these women, may bring her bill of divorce and testify that it was written appropriately. <b>What,</b> then, <b>is the difference between a bill of divorce and death?</b> The mishna answers: The difference is <b>that</b> in the case of a bill of divorce <b>the writing proves</b> the accuracy of the testimony, i.e., her testimony is supported by the text of the document itself, whereas with regard to the death of her husband there is no proof apart from the statement of the woman herself.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the scholars: With regard to <b>the daughter of her father-in-law,</b> who is not the daughter of her mother-in-law, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May she testify to the death of the woman’s husband, or is she also under suspicion? The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>The reason that the daughter of her mother-in-law</b> is suspected of lying is <b>because she has a mother who hates</b> her daughter-in-law, and therefore the daughter <b>also hates her. But here, there is no mother who hates her,</b> as she is not the mother-in-law’s daughter, and therefore she should be deemed credible.
<b>Or perhaps the reason that the daughter of her mother-in-law</b> hates her is <b>that she says: She eats the food [<i>girsena</i>] that</b> my <b>mother</b> prepares. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of the daughter of her father-in-law, <b>she also says: She eats the food of my father’s house.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>All are deemed credible</b> when they come <b>to testify with regard to her except for five women. And if it is so,</b> that the daughter of her father-in-law is also disqualified, <b>there are</b> actually <b>six</b> women. The Gemara rejects this: This is no proof, as <b>perhaps the reason that the daughter of her mother-in-law</b> is disqualified from testifying is <b>that she says: She eats the food of my father’s house,</b> and if so, the <i>halakha</i> <b>is no different</b> with regard to <b>her mother-in-law’s daughter and no different</b> with regard to <b>her father-in-law’s daughter.</b> Since the two women are disqualified for the same reason the Sages did not list these as two separate cases.
The Gemara raises a contradiction from another source. <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Apart from seven women</b> who are not trustworthy. Apparently that <i>tanna</i> added the daughter of her father-in-law as a separate category. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> ruling <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda adds also a father’s wife,</b> who hates her stepdaughter, <b>and a daughter-in-law,</b> who hates her mother-in-law.
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>A father’s wife is included in</b> the category of <b>the husband’s daughter,</b> while <b>a daughter-in-law</b> is <b>included in</b> the category of <b>her mother-in-law.</b> In other words, just as a mother-in-law is suspicious of her daughter-in-law, a daughter-in-law is equally suspicious of her mother-in-law, and they need not be listed separately.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who counts them separately, can answer: <b>Granted</b> that <b>her mother-in-law hates</b> the <b>daughter-in-law, as she says: She eats the food I</b> prepare; <b>but a daughter-in-law, what is the reason</b> that <b>she hates her mother-in-law?</b> Similarly, <b>granted the husband’s daughter, that she hates</b> her <b>father’s wife, as she says:</b> This woman <b>eats the food that</b> my <b>mother</b> prepared. <b>However, the father’s wife, what is the reason</b> that <b>she hates her husband’s daughter?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what is</b> the reason that Rabbi Yehuda <b>adds</b> these <b>two? Rather,</b> his logic is: In the case of <b>a daughter-in-law, what is the reason</b> that <b>she hates her mother-in-law? Because she reveals to her son everything</b> his wife <b>does.</b> And likewise <b>a father’s wife also hates the husband’s daughter, because she reveals to her father everything she does.</b> In each case the reason for this hatred is different from the reason for the hatred of the other woman, the mother-in-law or the husband’s daughter, and therefore they belong in a separate category.
<b>And the Rabbis,</b> who say that the reasons for the hatred are the same and therefore count only five disqualified women, how do they respond to this argument? They cite the verse: <b>“As in water face answers to face, so the heart of man to man”</b> (Proverbs 27:19). That is, if one person hates another, the feeling soon becomes mutual. Here too, there is no need for a separate reason in order that the hatred be reciprocated. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> why doesn’t he rely on this verse? Rabbi Yehuda would retort: <b>That</b> verse <b>was written about matters of Torah.</b> In other words, it means that the more one studies Torah, the more Torah he understands.
§ <b>Rav Aḥa bar Avya says: They raise a dilemma in the West,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael. With regard to <b>her mother-in-law who comes afterward, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? This refers to the mother of the husband’s brother, but not her husband’s mother, i.e., the wife’s future mother-in-law if the wife enters into levirate marriage. Can this woman testify with regard to the future wife of her son? The Gemara clarifies: <b>Does it enter her mind that</b> if this woman’s <b>husband died,</b> the widow <b>will happen before the <i>yavam</i>,</b> her son, for levirate marriage, <b>and</b> as the widow, when she then married her son, would eat her food <b>she hates her</b> already, <b>or not?</b>

Daf 117b

<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma. If <b>she said: My husband died and afterward my father-in-law died, she may marry and take</b> her money from the <b>marriage contract, and her mother-in-law is prohibited</b> to remarry; she is not deemed credible to testify for her mother-in-law, as already stated. The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>her mother-in-law is prohibited</b> to remarry? Is it <b>not because we say:</b> Perhaps <b>her husband did not</b> really <b>die,</b> and she is still her mother-in-law, <b>and her father-in-law did not die</b> either, <b>and</b> the reason <b>that she says this</b> statement <b>is that she intends to ruin her mother-in-law?</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>She reasons: Later,</b> when the husbands arrive, <b>she will not come back and trouble me,</b> because if the mother-in-law relies on this testimony and remarries she will no longer be able to return to her original husband, and she will be out of her daughter-in-law’s life. This shows that there is a concern that a daughter-in-law might lie in order to prevent future family relationships from coming into being. Similarly, a woman should be suspected of lying with regard to her future daughter-in-law.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion. <b>Perhaps</b> it <b>is different there, as</b> the daughter-in-law has already <b>felt oppressed by her</b> mother-in-law. In other words, she is suspected of lying because she had previous dealings with that woman, whereas in the case of a future mother-in-law, with whom she had no previous dealings, there is no such concern. Consequently, the dilemma cannot be resolved from this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <b>witness says:</b> The man <b>died, and</b> the wife <b>married</b> based on this testimony, <b>and one</b> other witness <b>came and said:</b> He did <b>not die, she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her new husband due to this testimony. However, if one <b>witness</b> comes and <b>says:</b> The husband <b>died, and two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> He did <b>not die,</b> then <b>even though she married</b> based on the first witness <b>she must leave</b> her new husband. If <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say: He died, and</b> one <b>witness says:</b> He did <b>not die,</b> the testimony of the two witnesses is accepted, and <b>even though she did not</b> yet <b>marry, she may marry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> in the case of one witness contradicted by another witness <b>is that she</b> already <b>married;</b> however, if <b>she did not</b> yet <b>marry</b> and a second witness comes in the meantime and contradicts the statement of the first one, <b>she may not marry.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Ulla say: Wherever</b> you find that <b>the Torah relies on one witness,</b> his testimony is considered complete proof, as though <b>there are two</b> witnesses present <b>here?</b> If so, the witness who comes and testifies to the opposite is only one witness, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness <b>has no</b> standing <b>in a place where</b> it is contradicted by <b>two</b> witnesses. Why, then, may she not remarry, even <i>ab initio</i>?
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>said:</b> If <b>one witness says: He died, and they permitted her to marry</b> based on his testimony, <b>and one</b> other witness later <b>came and said: He did not die, she does not leave her initial, permitted</b> state, i.e., the permission she was granted to remarry is still in force, and she may marry <i>ab initio</i>.
§ The mishna taught that if one <b>witness says: He died,</b> and two come and say: He did not die, she must leave her new husband. The Gemara asks: This <b>is obvious, as the statement of one</b> witness <b>has no</b> standing <b>in a place where</b> it is contradicted by <b>two</b> witnesses. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>of</b> people <b>disqualified</b> from giving <b>testimony.</b> In other words, the mishna is referring to two people who are generally disqualified from serving as witnesses. In the case of a missing husband, however, their testimony is accepted in contradiction of the first, qualified, witness. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: Wherever</b> you find that <b>the Torah relies on one witness, follow the majority of opinions,</b> even if they are disqualified. <b>And</b> the Sages <b>established</b> the testimony of <b>two women against one man</b> in this case <b>like</b> the testimony of <b>two men against one man,</b> i.e., the testimony of the two witnesses negates the earlier testimony of a single witness. The mishna is teaching that even if the first witness was qualified to give testimony, his account is negated by the statements of the two disqualified witnesses who contradicted him.
<b>And if you wish, say: Anywhere that a qualified witness came initially</b> and testified that he died, <b>even</b> if <b>one hundred women</b> came and contradicted his account, they <b>are considered like one witness,</b> and cannot negate his testimony. <b>However,</b> here it is speaking of a case <b>where a woman came initially</b> and they relied on her testimony to release the wife, and afterward two other women came and contradicted her.
The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> you can <b>explain</b> the ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya as follows: Rabbi Neḥemya says: Wherever</b> you find that <b>the Torah relies on one witness,</b> e.g., in testimony concerning a woman’s missing husband, <b>follow the majority of opinions, and they established two women against one woman like two men against one man. However,</b> in a case involving <b>two women against one man,</b> the latter of whom is a qualified witness, this <b>is like half against half,</b> i.e., they are equal. The testimony of two women has no advantage over that of one male witness, who is considered like two witnesses in testimony concerning a missing husband.
§ The mishna taught: If <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say: He died,</b> and one witness says: He did not die, even if she did not yet marry, she may marry. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us?</b> If you say it is referring <b>to</b> people <b>disqualified</b> from giving <b>testimony, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, who follows the majority of opinions,</b> then <b>this</b> case <b>is</b> identical to <b>that</b> previous case.
The Gemara answers. This case is also necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>when we follow the majority of opinions,</b> this is only when it leads <b>to a stringency, but</b> when this principle would lead <b>to a leniency,</b> to permit her to marry based on the majority of opinions, we do <b>not</b> follow the majority opinion. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that there is no difference in this regard, as the majority of opinions is accepted whether this leads to a lenient or a stringent outcome.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If two women who were married to the same man come forward, and <b>one</b> of them <b>says</b> that the husband <b>died, and</b> the other <b>one says he did not die, the one who says he died may marry</b> on the basis of her own testimony, <b>and she takes</b> the money of <b>her marriage contract. And the one who said he did not die may not marry, and does not take</b> the money of <b>her marriage contract.</b>
If <b>one</b> wife <b>says: He died</b> in a normal manner, <b>and</b> the other <b>one says: He was killed, Rabbi Meir says: Since they contradict one another, these</b> women <b>may not marry. Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon say: Since they both agree that he is not alive they may marry,</b> despite the fact that they dispute the circumstances of his demise. If <b>a witness says: He died, and a witness says: He did not die,</b>

Daf 118a

or one <b>woman says: He died, and</b> another <b>woman says: He did not die, this</b> woman <b>may not marry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught that if one rival wife says their husband died, while the second maintains that he did not die, the one who says he did not die may not remarry. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason is that</b> the second rival wife <b>said</b> explicitly: <b>He did not die,</b> from which it may be inferred that if <b>she was silent</b> and said nothing, <b>she</b> is permitted to <b>marry</b> based on the testimony of the first.
