However, this conclusion is problematic, as there is a principle that <b>one rival wife may not testify on</b> behalf of <b>another,</b> and if so, how can she rely on the testimony of her rival wife?
The Gemara answers that this inference is incorrect, as <b>it was necessary for</b> the mishna to state: <b>He did not die,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this</b> man did in fact <b>die, and</b> with regard to <b>that</b> which <b>she says: He did not die, she intends to ruin her rival wife. And</b> as for herself <b>she says: Let her die with the Philistines.</b> This is a paraphrase of the verse: “Let me die with the Philistines” (Judges 16:30), which is a shorthand expression for one’s desire to hurt his enemies even if he suffers the same fate himself. In this case it means that she is prepared to testify falsely that their husband did not die, so as to ruin her rival wife. Therefore the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, and she is not permitted to marry based on the testimony of her rival wife.
§ The mishna taught that if <b>one</b> wife <b>says: He died,</b> and one says: He was killed, Rabbi Meir says that as they contradict one another, they may not remarry. The Gemara asks: <b>And let Rabbi Meir</b> also <b>disagree in the first clause,</b> when one witness says the husband died and the other claims he did not die. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This is <b>taught as</b> a tannaitic <b>dispute.</b> In other words, Rabbi Meir also disagreed with the first clause, <b>and</b> the unattributed opinion in the mishna <b>is</b> that of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the first clause is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as in this</b> case <b>even Rabbi Meir concedes that any</b> claim of: <b>He did not die, with regard to testimony</b> enabling <b>a woman</b> to remarry, <b>is not</b> considered <b>contradictory.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If one <b>witness says: He died, and</b> one <b>witness says: He did not die,</b> or if one <b>woman says: He died, and</b> another <b>woman says: He did not die, she may not marry. Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, the unattributed</b> statement in this mishna <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that when a rebuttal contradicts the original testimony, one cannot rely upon the testimony that the husband died. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> this is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara answers: Yes, this is <b>difficult.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a woman who went, she and her husband, overseas, and she comes and says: My husband died, she may marry, and she takes her marriage contract</b> based on her own testimony. <b>And it</b> remains <b>prohibited for her rival wife</b> to remarry, as a woman cannot testify on behalf of her rival wife. If the rival wife <b>was an Israelite woman</b> married <b>to a priest, she may</b> continue to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as she is not permitted to remarry, and therefore the presumption that the husband is still alive is maintained in relation to her. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Tarfon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: This is not</b> the <b>way to spare</b> someone <b>from transgression.</b> According to the opinion of Rabbi Tarfon, there is a concern that she might be eating <i>teruma</i> unlawfully. There is no remedy for this situation <b>unless it is prohibited</b> for the rival wife <b>to marry,</b> as she cannot rely on the testimony of her rival wife, <b>and it is</b> also <b>prohibited</b> for her <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> lest the other woman was speaking the truth. In other words, the <i>halakha</i> is stringent on both counts.
The mishna discusses a similar case. If a woman <b>said: My husband died and afterward my father-in-law died, she may marry and take her marriage contract, and it is prohibited</b> for <b>her mother-in-law</b> to remarry, as a woman may not testify on behalf of her mother-in-law. If the mother-in-law <b>was the daughter of an Israelite married to a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Tarfon. Rabbi Akiva says: This is not</b> the <b>way to spare</b> her <b>from transgression;</b> there is no remedy <b>unless it is prohibited</b> for the mother-in-law <b>to marry and</b> also <b>prohibited</b> for her <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states the dispute between Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva with regard to two apparently identical cases. The Gemara explains: And it is <b>necessary</b> to state both of these examples. <b>As, had</b> the mishna <b>stated</b> the dispute only in <b>this first</b> case, I would have said: It is <b>in this</b> case that <b>Rabbi Tarfon said</b> the wife is suspected of lying, <b>because the suffering is physical,</b> i.e., she is jealous of her rival wife, with whom she shares her husband. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>her mother-in-law, where the suffering is merely verbal</b> and not physical, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Akiva,</b> i.e., that she is not considered a liar, and therefore it should be prohibited for her mother-in-law to partake in <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And</b> vice-versa: <b>Had</b> the mishna <b>stated</b> the dispute only <b>in this</b> second case, I would have said: It is <b>in this</b> case that <b>Rabbi Akiva said</b> that the mother-in-law must refrain from eating <i>teruma</i> in case the daughter-in-law is not lying, <b>but in this</b> other case of the rival wife, you might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Tarfon</b> that she may eat <i>teruma</i>, as a rival wife is certainly not telling the truth. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state the dispute in both two cases.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Tarfon.</b> The testimony of a woman who is suspected of harboring ill will toward another is entirely rejected with regard to that other person, and no credence is given to her account at all. <b>Abaye said:</b> Likewise, <b>we, too, learn</b> in a mishna (118b): If a woman came and said: <b>A son was born to me overseas,</b> and <b>my son died and afterward my husband</b> died, <b>she is deemed credible</b> in all regards, and she enters into levirate marriage. If she said: <b>My husband</b> died <b>and afterward my son</b> died, which means she is exempt from levirate marriage, <b>she is not deemed credible.</b>
That mishna adds: <b>But</b> in any case, the court is <b>concerned about her statement, and she must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b> In other words, the court takes into consideration the possibility that she is speaking the truth, and if her son did die after her husband it is prohibited for her to enter into levirate marriage. Abaye infers from the language of the mishna on 118b: <b>It is</b> with regard <b>to her own statement that</b> the court is <b>concerned.</b> This indicates that the court is <b>not concerned</b> at all <b>about the statement of</b> her <b>rival wife</b> who testified with regard to her. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from here</b> that this is the case.

Daf 118b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In relation to the dispute between Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva in the previous mishna, in which Rabbi Akiva states that one must avoid a possible transgression, the mishna cites two similar cases involving other topics. With regard to one who <b>betrothed one of five women, and he does not know which</b> of them <b>he betrothed,</b> and <b>each one</b> of them <b>says: He betrothed me,</b> if he does not want to marry any of them <b>he gives a bill of divorce to each and every one</b> of them so none will have the status of a woman with regard to whom there is uncertainty whether she is divorced. <b>And he leaves the marriage contract among them and departs.</b> The marriage contract remains in dispute between the women until they clarify which of them is entitled to the money. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Tarfon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: This is not</b> the <b>way to spare</b> someone <b>from transgression,</b> as perhaps the woman he actually betrothed will not receive the money to which she is entitled. There is no remedy <b>unless he gives a bill of divorce and a marriage contract</b> payment <b>to each and every one.</b> And likewise, in the case of one who <b>stole</b> money <b>from one of five</b> people <b>and does not know from which</b> of them <b>he stole,</b> and <b>each one says: He stole from me, he leaves the stolen</b> money <b>among them and departs,</b> and they will decide among themselves how to distribute the money; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Tarfon. Rabbi Akiva says: This is not</b> the <b>way to spare</b> him <b>from transgression;</b> there is no remedy <b>unless he pays each and every one of them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers: It <b>is taught</b> in the mishna that <b>he betrothed</b> one of five women, whereas <b>it is not taught</b> that <b>he had sexual intercourse</b> with one of five women, as a different ruling applies in this case. Similarly, with regard to the second case, it <b>is taught</b> that <b>he stole</b> from one of five people, and <b>it is not taught</b> that <b>he purchased</b> an item from one of five people. If so, <b>whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna?</b> It is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i> and</b> it is also <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva did not dispute</b> the case <b>of</b> a man <b>who betrothed one of five women and he does not know which</b> of them <b>he betrothed,</b> as everyone agrees in this case <b>that he leaves</b> the money of <b>the marriage contract among them and departs. With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to</b> the case of one <b>who had sexual intercourse</b> with one of them for the purpose of betrothal. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: He leaves the money among them and departs,</b> while <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He does not fulfill his obligation <b>unless he pays each and every one of them.</b> Since he married in an inappropriate manner, the Sages penalized him by compelling him to pay all the women.
Likewise, <b>Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva did not dispute</b> the case <b>of</b> one <b>who purchased an item from</b> one of <b>five people and he does not know from which of them he purchased it.</b> Everyone agrees in this case <b>that he leaves the price of the purchase among them and departs. They disagree only with regard to</b> one <b>who stole from five people, as Rabbi Tarfon says: He leaves the stolen</b> money <b>among them and departs, and Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He does not fulfill his obligation <b>unless he pays the stolen</b> money <b>to each and every one</b> of them. In this case, as he committed a transgression, he must ensure that the stolen money is restored to its proper owner.
The Gemara states: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said</b> that Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva <b>do not disagree with regard to</b> the cases of one who <b>betrothed and</b> one who <b>purchased,</b> one may learn <b>by inference that the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> with whom he disagrees, <b>holds</b> that <b>they do disagree</b> about the cases of betrothed and purchased, whereas with regard to one who had sexual intercourse and one who stole an item Rabbi Tarfon agrees with Rabbi Akiva. With this in mind, <b>who is</b> the author of the mishna?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>If</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, let it teach</b> the cases of <b>betrothed and</b> also <b>purchased,</b> but not that of one who stole or one who had intercourse, as the first <i>tanna</i> maintains that Rabbi Tarfon agrees with Rabbi Akiva in those cases. <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, let it teach</b> the cases of one who <b>had sexual relations and</b> that of one who <b>stole.</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds that Rabbi Tarfon and Rabbi Akiva disagree in the case of one who had sexual relations, not in the case of a man who betrothed one of five women. Likewise, he maintains that they disagree in the case of one who stole from five people, not one who purchased an item from five people.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, and what is</b> the meaning of the term: <b>Betrothed?</b> It means that <b>he betrothed</b> one of the women <b>by</b> means of <b>sexual intercourse.</b> And the mishna <b>taught</b> the term <b>betrothed to convey to you the far-reaching</b> nature of the stringent opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>As, although</b> this man <b>performed</b> an act that violated <b>a prohibition</b> that applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> i.e., he did not have licentious sexual relations with her but rather engaged in intercourse for the purpose of betrothal, which is in violation of a rabbinic prohibition that one may not betroth a woman by sexual intercourse <i>ab initio</i>, even so Rabbi Akiva <b>penalizes</b> him. And the mishna <b>taught</b> the case of one who <b>stole</b> so as <b>to convey to you the far-reaching</b> nature of the lenient opinion <b>of Rabbi Tarfon, as although he performed</b> an act that violated <b>a prohibition</b> that applies <b>by Torah law,</b> nevertheless <b>he does not penalize</b> him even in this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a woman who went, she and her husband, overseas, and her son</b> was <b>with them, and</b> later <b>she came</b> back <b>and said: My husband died and afterward my son died, she is deemed credible.</b> It is permitted for her to remarry, and she is exempt from levirate marriage. The reason is that she had children when she left, and therefore she retains her presumptive status of one who is exempt from levirate marriage. However, if she said: <b>My son died and afterward my husband died, she is not deemed credible,</b> i.e., she may not enter into levirate marriage. <b>And</b> yet <b>we are concerned</b> and give some credence <b>to her statement,</b> in case she was actually widowed by a childless husband, and therefore <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> to exempt her from the levirate bond with her <i>yavam</i>, <b>and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
If she went with her childless husband and returned alone and testified: <b>A son was born to me overseas, and she</b> further <b>said: My son died and afterward my husband died, she is deemed credible</b> and may even enter into levirate marriage, as she was presumed to be childless when she left and consequently she retains that presumptive status. However, if she said: <b>My husband died and afterward my son died, she is not deemed credible</b> for the purpose of exempting her from levirate marriage, <b>but</b> the court is <b>concerned about her statement. And</b> therefore <b>she must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
If she said: <b>A <i>yavam</i> was born for me overseas,</b> i.e., when the family left the country her husband did not have a brother, and she claims that in the meantime a brother was born to her husband, and <b>she</b> also <b>said: My husband died and afterward my <i>yavam</i> died,</b> or: <b>My <i>yavam</i></b> died <b>and afterward my husband</b> died, in either case <b>she is deemed credible.</b> This is because when she left she was not presumed to require levirate marriage, and the suggestion that her husband now has a brother is based solely on her testimony.
However, if <b>she went, she and her husband and her <i>yavam</i>, overseas, and</b> upon her return she <b>said: My husband died and afterward my <i>yavam</i></b> died, or: <b>My <i>yavam</i></b> died <b>and afterward my husband</b> died, <b>she is not deemed credible, as a woman is not deemed credible</b> if she <b>says: My <i>yavam</i> died,</b> in order <b>that she may marry</b> another man. <b>And</b> she is <b>not</b> deemed credible if she says that <b>her sister died,</b> in order <b>that she may enter the house</b> of her sister’s husband. <b>And a man is not deemed credible</b> if he <b>says: My brother died, so that he may enter into levirate marriage with his</b> brother’s <b>wife, and</b> he is <b>not</b> deemed credible when he says that <b>his wife died,</b> in order <b>that</b> he <b>may marry</b> his wife’s <b>sister.</b> The Sages accepted impaired testimony of this kind only when there was a concern about creating a situation of a deserted wife.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> In the case of a man <b>who confers possession</b> of <b>a bill of divorce to his wife,</b> i.e., he appoints an agent to take the bill of divorce to his wife, <b>when</b> she has a potential <b><i>yavam</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if her husband dies before she is divorced? One might say that <b>since she hates</b> her <i>yavam</i>, receiving the bill of divorce is <b>for her benefit,</b> as this act renders her prohibited to him, <b>and</b> it is a principle that <b>one may act in a person’s interest in his absence.</b> If so, as soon as the husband gives the bill of divorce to the agent she is divorced. <b>Or perhaps, since she sometimes loves</b> her <i>yavam</i>, <b>this</b> bill of divorce <b>is to her disadvantage, and one may not act against a person’s interest in his absence.</b> Consequently, she is not divorced until the bill of divorce reaches her possession.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava that <b>we learned</b> an answer to this dilemma in the mishna: <b>And we are concerned about her statement, and she</b> must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b> The mishna states that the court gives her statement some credence in either case, both when her testimony would exempt her from levirate marriage and when it would allow her to marry her <i>yavam</i>. This indicates that levirate marriage is considered neither in her interest nor a disadvantage for her. Rather, its classification is uncertain.
§ <b>Ravina said to Rava:</b> With regard to one <b>who confers possession</b> of <b>a bill of divorce to his wife</b> through an agent in a situation <b>when there was a quarrel</b> between them, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains both sides of the question: <b>Since she has a quarrel with him,</b> the bill of divorce might be considered <b>for her benefit. Or perhaps,</b> her <b>physical comfort is preferable to her,</b> as she prefers to remain married despite the quarrel between her and her husband. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as Reish Lakish said:</b> There is a popular idiom among women: <b>It is better to sit as two [<i>tan du</i>] than to sit</b> lonely as a <b>widow,</b> i.e., a woman prefers the companionship of any husband over being alone.
<b>Abaye said</b> a similar popular expression: One <b>whose husband is</b> small <b>as an ant, she places her seat among the noblewomen,</b> as she considers herself important merely by virtue of being married. <b>Rav Pappa said</b> a different maxim: One <b>whose husband is a wool comber [<i>naftza</i>],</b> a lowly occupation, <b>she calls him to sit</b> with her <b>at the entrance to the house,</b> to display herself as a married woman.
Similarly, <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> One <b>whose husband sells cabbage heads [<i>kulsa</i>] does not require lentils for her pot.</b> She is so happy she is married that she does not mind even if he does not provide her with food. The Gemara comments: A Sage <b>taught: And all of these</b> women who appear so satisfied with their marriage, they all <b>commit adultery and attribute</b> the children <b>to their husbands.</b> This is another reason why they are so keen to be married. This shows that even when there are quarrels between a couple, the wife still prefers the status of a married woman, and therefore the bill of divorce is not considered in her interest.

Daf 119a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a woman whose husband and rival</b> wife <b>traveled to a country overseas, and</b> witnesses <b>came and told her: Your husband died, she shall not marry</b> any other man, in case she requires levirate marriage with her brother-in-law, i.e., <i>yavam</i>, in which case she is prohibited from marrying anyone else. <b>And she</b> also <b>shall not enter into levirate marriage until she knows whether she,</b> i.e., <b>her rival wife, is pregnant.</b> If her rival wife bears a child to her late husband, she does not have a levirate bond with her brother-in-law, and she is therefore prohibited from marrying him.
<b>If she had a mother-in-law</b> overseas, but her late husband had no brothers, <b>she need not be concerned</b> that a brother to her husband may have been born. But if her mother-in-law <b>departed</b> from her town <b>pregnant,</b> this widow <b>should be concerned</b> that perhaps her late husband now has a brother, with whom she is obligated in levirate marriage. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> Even in such a case <b>she need not be concerned</b> and may marry whomever she wishes.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> implied by the extra word: She, in the expression in the first clause of the mishna: Whether <b>she,</b> i.e., <b>her rival wife, is</b> pregnant? The Gemara answers that it <b>teaches us this: We are concerned</b> about a possible pregnancy of <b>this rival wife</b> who went overseas with her husband, <b>but we are not concerned about</b> the possibility that he married <b>another rival wife</b> overseas and sired a child by her.
It was taught in the mishna: <b>She shall not marry</b> any other man <b>and shall not enter into levirate marriage</b> until she knows whether her rival wife is pregnant. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> she may <b>not enter into levirate marriage, because perhaps</b> her rival wife <b>is pregnant, and</b> if so, this widow <b>would encounter the Torah</b> prohibition proscribing <b>a brother’s wife.</b> If a child is born to her late husband, levirate marriage is not required and she is prohibited from marrying her brother-in-law. <b>But why</b> should she <b>not marry</b> another man? <b>Follow the majority of women, and</b> as <b>most women become pregnant and give birth,</b> it is probable that her rival wife did have a child.
<b>Shall we say</b> that the mishna follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who is concerned about the minority?</b> There is a minority of women who do not give birth, and Rabbi Meir takes this minority into consideration and requires the widow to wait and clarify whether or not she is required to enter into levirate marriage.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the mishna follows the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. When the Rabbis follow the majority, it is an evident majority,</b> which is extant and can be examined. <b>For example,</b> in a situation where a piece of meat is found in front of <b>nine stores</b> selling kosher meat and one store selling non-kosher meat, if it is not known from which store the meat came, it may be assumed that it came from one of the stores that sells kosher meat. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>the Sanhedrin</b> reaches its decisions by a majority vote of its members. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a non-evident majority,</b> which is based solely upon general statistical information, such as the assertion that most women become pregnant and give birth, even <b>the Rabbis do not follow the majority.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the case of <b>a minor boy or minor girl,</b> as pertains to levirate marriage, <b>is</b> dependent upon <b>a non-evident majority, and</b> nevertheless <b>the Rabbis follow the majority</b> in their ruling, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A minor boy or minor girl may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not enter into levirate marriage;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Meir: You have aptly stated that they may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> since <b>“man”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:7), i.e., an adult male, <b>is written in the section</b> of the Torah pertaining to <i>ḥalitza</i>. Though an adult female is not mentioned explicitly, <b>we employ</b> an analogy based on <b>juxtaposition</b> of <b>the woman to the man</b> and require that the female involved in <i>ḥalitza</i> be an adult as well. <b>But what is the reason that they may not enter into levirate marriage,</b> about which the Torah’s phraseology does not specifically indicate adults?
<b>He said to them:</b> I am concerned about <b>the minor boy, lest he be confirmed as a sexually underdeveloped man</b> when he grows up, and I am concerned about <b>the minor girl, lest she be confirmed as an <i>aylonit</i>,</b> a sexually underdeveloped woman, when she grows up. Then levirate marriage would not apply, and <b>they would end up encountering a forbidden relative</b> if they consummated the levirate marriage. <b>And the Rabbis hold: Follow the majority of minor boys, and most minor boys are not sexually underdeveloped</b> when they grow up. Likewise, <b>follow the majority of minor girls, and most minor girls are not</b> in the category of <b><i>aylonit</i></b> when they grow up. This indicates that the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Meir even with regard to a non-evident majority. <b>Rather, it is clear that the mishna is</b> following <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who is concerned about the minority.
The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> manner <b>did you establish</b> the mishna? You established it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> However, <b>say the latter clause: If she had a mother-in-law</b> overseas, <b>she need not be concerned</b> that her mother-in-law may have given birth to another son. <b>Why</b> should she not be concerned about this? <b>Follow the majority of women, and most women become pregnant and give birth.</b> The <b>minority</b> become pregnant and <b>miscarry. And</b> among <b>all women who give birth, half</b> of the children are <b>male and half</b> are <b>female.</b> Therefore, we can <b>join the minority who miscarry to the half</b> who give birth to <b>females, and then the male children</b> born <b>would be</b> only <b>the minority.</b> Nevertheless, if the mishna actually follows Rabbi Meir, who is concerned about minority circumstances, <b>let him be concerned</b> that a <i>yavam</i> might have been born, necessitating a levirate marriage.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps, since</b> the widow <b>is</b> legally <b>presumed</b> to be permitted <b>to</b> marry a man from the general <b>public,</b> since her husband had no known brothers, Rabbi Meir <b>is not concerned</b> about the minority. The Gemara challenges: If so, in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, where the widow <b>is</b> legally <b>presumed to</b> require <b>levirate marriage,</b> as her husband had no children, <b>she should</b> be permitted to <b>enter into levirate marriage</b> without concern that her rival wife might have given birth.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> In <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which</b> relates to <b>a prohibition</b> proscribing a brother’s wife when levirate marriage does not apply, which bears the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>, they were concerned</b> about the minority possibility because of the severity of the prohibition. But in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which</b> relates to <b>an ordinary prohibition,</b> that of a woman whose husband died childless marrying without performing <i>ḥalitza</i>, the prohibition is not so severe. Therefore, <b>they were not concerned</b> about the minority and relied upon the presumption.
<b>Rava said</b> in opposition to this contention: <b>Now since this</b> prohibition <b>is by Torah</b> law <b>and that</b> prohibition <b>is by Torah</b> law, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if it is <b>a prohibition</b> bearing the punishment of <b><i>karet</i></b> and <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if it is <b>an ordinary prohibition?</b> If both prohibitions are by Torah law there is no justification for distinguishing between a severe prohibition and a minor one! <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that we must reject this contention, and say:

Daf 119b

In <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>the</b> legal <b>presumption</b> is that this widow <b>is</b> obligated <b>to</b> enter into <b>levirate marriage, but</b> in <b>a majority</b> of cases she will actually be permitted <b>to</b> marry a man from the general <b>public,</b> because it is statistically probable that her rival wife had a child. <b>A</b> legal <b>presumption is not</b> as <b>significant as a majority,</b> meaning that the majority carries more weight than the presumption, and she should be permitted to marry immediately. <b>But bring the minority who miscarry</b> into consideration, and <b>join</b> this <b>to the</b> legal <b>presumption, and it becomes</b> similar to an even balance of <b>half and half.</b> Those who miscarry detract from the strength of the majority, causing it to be equal in legal significance to the legal presumption. Therefore, the ruling is that <b>she shall not marry</b> any man who is not her <i>yavam</i> <b>and she shall not enter into levirate marriage</b> either.
However, in <b>the latter clause, the</b> legal <b>presumption is</b> that the widow is permitted <b>to</b> marry a man from the general <b>public,</b> since her late husband had no brothers initially. <b>And</b> in <b>a majority</b> of cases her mother-in-law will not have had another son, and therefore the widow will actually be permitted <b>to</b> marry a man from the general <b>public.</b> Consequently, the possibility that her husband has a brother, necessitating levirate marriage, <b>is</b> not taken into account because it is <b>a minority of a minority,</b> i.e., it is a minority and it contradicts the legal presumption, <b>and</b> even <b>Rabbi Meir is not concerned about a minority of a minority.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna that in the case of a woman whose husband and rival wife went overseas and then her husband died, <b>she shall not marry and shall not enter into levirate marriage</b> until she knows whether her rival wife is pregnant. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> must she wait <b>indefinitely?</b> She should be permitted to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> on account of the uncertainty and then marry another man.
<b>Ze’eiri said:</b> In order <b>for herself [<i>le’atzma</i>]</b> to be permitted to marry, she must wait <b>three months</b> after performing <i>ḥalitza</i>, since every woman must wait three months after her husband’s death before she marries again. Additionally, due to the concern <b>for</b> the possibility that <b>her fellow</b> wife may be pregnant, she must wait <b>nine</b> months, after which time that wife would have given birth had she been pregnant, <b>and</b> then <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i> whichever way you</b> look at it. If her rival wife gave birth in the meantime, she is permitted to marry anyone she wishes, and the <i>ḥalitza</i> is superfluous; if her rival wife did not give birth, necessitating levirate marriage, she is exempted by the <i>ḥalitza</i>. However, she may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> earlier because <i>ḥalitza</i> performed while any wife of the deceased husband is pregnant is ineffective.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: For</b> those concerns relating to <b>herself</b> she must wait <b>three</b> months, as explained, but <b>for</b> concerns related to <b>her fellow</b> wife’s possible pregnancy she must wait <b>indefinitely,</b> until it is verified whether or not that wife gave birth. The Gemara challenges Rabbi Ḥanina’s opinion: <b>But let her perform <i>ḥalitza</i> whichever way you</b> look at it, since, whatever happened, after nine months she may certainly perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>Abaye bar Avin and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Avin both say</b> in explanation of Rabbi Ḥanina’s opinion: <b>It is</b> a rabbinic <b>decree lest there be viable offspring</b> of that other wife. If so, her <i>ḥalitza</i> is superfluous, since she was exempt from both levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i>; <b>and</b> then <b>it transpires</b> that <b>you necessitate an announcement</b> on <b>her</b> behalf stating that she is permitted <b>to the priesthood,</b> as a woman who has undergone <i>ḥalitza</i> is forbidden to a priest, but in this case it has become clear retroactively that she did not undergo <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And so let an announcement be necessary for her</b> if a viable offspring is found. The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps there will be</b> people <b>who were</b> present <b>at the <i>ḥalitza</i></b> ceremony <b>but were not</b> present <b>at the announcement</b> that she is permitted to marry a priest, <b>and</b> if this woman marries a priest <b>they will</b> mistakenly <b>say: They are permitting a <i>ḥalutza</i> to</b> marry <b>a priest.</b>
The Gemara deliberates further about this: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 118b): If a woman says: <b>A son was born to me in a country overseas, and she</b> also <b>said: My son died, and then my husband died, she is deemed credible.</b> However, if she said: <b>My husband died and then my son died, she is not deemed credible</b> about the sequence of events, <b>but</b> even so <b>one</b> must <b>be concerned about her statement</b> that her husband died childless. Consequently, <b>she</b> must <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, but she may not enter into levirate marriage.</b>
The Gemara says: Just as there is concern about an announcement for the priesthood, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps witnesses</b> will eventually <b>come and testify</b> that the sequence of events was <b>as she said,</b> rendering her <i>ḥalitza</i> superfluous. <b>And</b> then <b>it transpires</b> that <b>you necessitate an announcement</b> on <b>her</b> behalf stating that she is permitted <b>to the priesthood,</b> and nevertheless the mishna instructs her to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> There it is referring only <b>to a divorced woman,</b> who was divorced from a previous husband, so that she is already prohibited from marrying a priest in any case. <b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where she said: He and I were hiding</b> alone with our son <b>in a cave.</b> Consequently, there is no concern that witnesses will come and testify about the sequence of the events.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there are <b>two sisters-in-law</b> married to two childless brothers who testify about their marital status, and <b>this one says: My husband died, and that one says: My husband died,</b> although each one of them is deemed credible with regard to her own status as a widow, <b>this one is prohibited</b> from marrying <b>due to</b> the possibility that <b>the husband of that</b> other sister may be alive, obligating her in levirate marriage, <b>and that one is prohibited</b> from marrying <b>due to the husband of this</b> sister, according to the same rationale. Although each is accorded credibility as to her own husband’s death, the <i>halakha</i> is that sisters-in-law are among the five types of women not accorded credibility with regard to each other’s permissibility to marry because of possible conflicts of interest.
If <b>this one has witnesses</b> to her husband’s death, <b>and that one does not have witnesses,</b> then <b>the one who has witnesses is prohibited</b> from marrying, as there are no witnesses to the death of her <i>yavam</i> to exempt her from levirate marriage; <b>but the one who has no witnesses is permitted</b> to marry based on her own testimony that her husband died combined with the witnesses’ testimony exempting her from levirate marriage. If <b>this one has children and that one has no children,</b> then <b>the one with children is permitted</b> to marry, as she herself is deemed credible with regard to her husband’s death, and her children exempt her from levirate marriage. <b>But the one without children is prohibited</b> from marrying, as the death of her <i>yavam</i> has not been corroborated independently of her sister-in-law’s testimony.
If there were two additional <i>yevamin</i> with whom these two widows <b>entered into levirate marriage, and</b> then <b>the <i>yevamin</i> died</b> childless, the women <b>are prohibited from marrying,</b> since the concern about an additional living <i>yavam</i> still remains. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Since</b> these women <b>were permitted to</b> marry <b>the</b> living <b>brothers-in-law,</b> as the testimony of each was deemed credible with regard to her own status, <b>they are permitted,</b> from then on, <b>to</b> marry <b>any man</b> because their statements, taken together, indicate that neither one is obligated to enter into levirate marriage.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It was <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>this one has witnesses</b> that her husband died <b>and</b> also has <b>children, and the other has neither witnesses nor children, they are both permitted</b> to marry. This is because the woman who has children is exempt from levirate marriage, and the woman who has no children may rely upon the witnesses’ testimony that her <i>yavam</i> died.
It was taught in the mishna: If <b>they</b> both <b>entered into levirate marriage and</b> then <b>the <i>yevamin</i></b> they married <b>died, they are prohibited from marrying. Rabbi Elazar says: Since they were permitted to</b> marry <b>the <i>yevamin</i>, they are permitted to any man.</b>
<b>Rava raised a dilemma: What is Rabbi Elazar’s reasoning?</b> Is it <b>because he holds</b> in general that one <b>rival wife may testify for another</b> rival wife about her husband’s death, and he similarly holds that all of the five types of women who are presumed to have a conflict of interest with each other may testify for one another nonetheless? <b>Or perhaps</b> it is <b>because she would not cause herself injury.</b> Although she would be suspected of lying and saying that her husband died in order to harm her rival wife, if she herself enters into levirate marriage it can be assumed that she was telling the truth, because if she does so while her husband is actually alive, she would be committing incest with her brother-in-law. Consequently, her rival wife is also permitted to marry on the basis of her testimony.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the practical difference</b> between the two reasons?

Daf 120a

The Gemara responds that Rabbi Elazar’s reasoning could make a practical difference with regard <b>to</b> allowing <b>the rival wife to marry before</b> the woman <b>herself,</b> i.e., the woman who testified that her husband died, remarries. <b>If you say that</b> according to Rabbi Elazar, <b>one rival wife may testify for another,</b> then <b>although</b> the woman who testified that her husband died <b>has not married, we</b> allow her <b>rival wife to marry.</b> Since the woman’s report is deemed credible with regard to herself, it is also deemed credible with regard to her rival wife. However, <b>if you say</b> that Rabbi Elazar’s reasoning is <b>due to</b> the presumption that <b>she would not cause herself injury,</b> then <b>if she has</b> actually <b>married we may</b> allow <b>her rival wife to marry,</b> but <b>if she has not married, we may not</b> allow <b>her</b> rival wife <b>to marry,</b> in case she lied in order to cause harm to her rival wife.
<b>What</b> is the basis of Rabbi Elazar’s ruling? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution based upon the wording of the <i>baraita</i> itself: <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Since they were permitted to</b> marry <b>the brothers-in-law, they are</b> now <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>any man. Granted, if you say that</b> his reason is because <b>she would not cause herself injury, this is</b> the reason <b>that if she has</b> actually <b>married,</b> as in this case, where each woman entered into levirate marriage, <b>we may</b> allow <b>her</b> rival wife <b>to marry.</b>
<b>But if you say</b> the reason is <b>because one rival wife may testify for another,</b> then <b>although she</b> herself <b>has not married,</b> it should <b>still</b> be permitted for her rival wife to marry, and it would be unnecessary for Rabbi Elazar to state his opinion in a case where the women had already entered into levirate marriage. <b>Rather, conclude from this that Rabbi Elazar’s reason is because she has</b> already <b>married, and she would not cause herself injury</b> by marrying if her original husband had not died.
The Gemara rejects that and suggests that <b>Rabbi Elazar stated</b> his opinion <b>to</b> the Rabbis <b>in accordance with their</b> own <b>statement,</b> as follows: <b>According to my own</b> opinion, <b>one rival wife may testify for another, and although she,</b> herself, <b>has not married,</b> nevertheless <b>we may</b> allow <b>her</b> rival wife <b>to marry. But</b> even <b>according to your own</b> opinion, <b>admit, in any event, that where she has</b> actually <b>married we may</b> allow <b>her</b> rival wife <b>to marry because she would not cause injury to herself. But the Rabbis,</b> rejecting this, say that <b>she acts upon</b> the premise: <b>“Let me die with the Philistines”</b> (Judges 16:30), i.e., a woman may even harm herself by remarrying while her original husband is still alive, in order to harm her rival wife by causing her to remarry as well.
The Gemara suggests another solution. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a woman who went with her husband to a country overseas, and who</b> later <b>came and said: My husband died, she is</b> permitted <b>to marry and collect</b> the widow’s compensation from <b>her marriage contract, but her rival wife is prohibited</b> from doing so. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Since she is permitted</b> to marry, <b>her rival wife is also permitted.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Elazar holds that the rival wife is permitted to marry because the wife who testified that her husband has died is permitted to do so, even if the latter has not actually remarried yet. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Say</b> that Rabbi Elazar means: <b>Since she was permitted and has married.</b>
The Gemara asks: If Rabbi Elazar’s reason is that she would not cause herself injury, how can her rival wife be permitted to marry? <b>Let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps she,</b> i.e., the woman who claimed that the husband was dead, <b>came with a bill of divorce</b> and is therefore permitted to remarry though the husband is alive. <b>And</b> the fact <b>that she says this,</b> i.e., that her husband is dead, <b>is intended</b> only <b>to injure her rival wife,</b> who will remarry, thinking that the husband is dead, and will suffer the severe consequences of adultery.
The Gemara then validates this concern. <b>If she</b> actually <b>married an Israelite,</b> which is permitted for a divorced woman, then <b>indeed</b> one must consider the possibility that she is actually divorced and not widowed, and the rival wife is not permitted to marry. However, <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case where <b>she married a priest,</b> who is prohibited from marrying a divorced woman, and therefore she must actually be a widow, as she would not damage herself by entering into a forbidden marriage.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may testify</b> that a man died <b>only</b> if he can testify <b>about</b> seeing <b>the countenance [<i>partzuf</i> ] of</b> the <b>face with the nose,</b> as this allows one to identify the individual with certainty. <b>Although there are distinguishing marks [<i>simanim</i>] on his body and his personal belongings,</b> which appear to indicate his identity, one may not rely on these as identification. Furthermore, <b>one may not testify</b> that a person died <b>until his soul</b> actually <b>departs. And even if one saw him cut open</b> and severely wounded, <b>or crucified, or</b> with a wild <b>animal eating</b> parts <b>of him,</b> he may not testify that he died. Additionally, <b>one may testify</b> to someone’s death <b>only</b> when the body was witnessed <b>up to three days</b> following death and not after that, since the appearance may change due to decomposition.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava says:</b> One cannot establish general guidelines for this matter because <b>not every person, nor every place, nor every hour is identical.</b> Decomposition is not uniform. It occurs at different rates in different situations.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the witnesses saw his <b>forehead but not the countenance of the face,</b> or if they saw <b>the countenance of the face but not</b> his <b>forehead, they may not testify</b> that it is he, <b>until</b> they see <b>both of them with the nose. Abaye said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Kahana</b> who said: <b>What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that one may testify that a man died only if one sees his face? The verse is: <b>“The show of their face does witness against them”</b> (Isaiah 3:9), which indicates that one clearly recognizes another only upon seeing his face.
The Gemara relates that <b>Abba bar Marta, who is</b> also known as <b>Abba bar Minyumi, had been loaned money by</b> members of <b>the Exilarch’s house.</b> Since he did not want to be seen by these violent people, <b>he brought wax [<i>kira</i>], stuck</b> it <b>to</b> a strip of <b>worn-out fabric,</b> and <b>stuck</b> all of that <b>to his forehead</b> in order to alter his appearance. <b>He passed before them and they did not recognize him [<i>beshakru</i>].</b> This shows how much a person’s face changes when the appearance of his forehead is altered.
§ We learned in the mishna that, <b>although there are distinguishing marks</b> on a dead person’s body and clothing, one may not rely on these as identification. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that distinguishing marks are not</b> recognized as valid identification <b>by Torah law,</b> and while a rabbinic ordinance allows one to rely upon them to remedy certain situations, for testimony about a person’s death, the Sages require the stringencies of Torah law?
<b>But</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction,</b> based upon the following <i>baraita</i>: If an agent charged with delivering a bill of divorce to a woman lost it, and then <b>he found it tied to a purse, or a money bag [<i>arnekei</i>], or a ring, or if it was found among his personal belongings, even after a long time, it is valid,</b> i.e., one may rely upon the distinguishing marks on these objects to positively identify the document, and the agent may then deliver it to the woman. This indicates that distinguishing marks are sufficient to identify an object even by Torah law.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. That</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai,</b> while <b>this</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis; as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not testify</b> about a person’s identity <b>based upon</b> the position of <b>a mole</b> on his body. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai says: One may testify</b> based on a mole. <b>What, is it not about this</b> issue <b>that they disagree:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai, <b>holds that distinguishing marks are</b> recognized as valid identification <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the anonymous first <i>tanna</i>, representing the majority of the Rabbis, <b>holds that distinguishing marks are</b> recognized as a means of identification only <b>by rabbinic</b> law and are therefore insufficient to permit a Torah prohibition?
<b>Rava said:</b> It is possible <b>that everyone</b> agrees that <b>distinguishing marks are</b> recognized as valid identification <b>by Torah</b> law, and <b>here they are disagreeing about</b> whether such <b>a mole is commonly found on his peer,</b> i.e., anyone very similar to him, which would undermine its usefulness as a means of identification. One <b>Sage,</b> the anonymous first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that such <b>a mole is commonly found on his peer</b> and therefore is not sufficient for identification. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is not commonly found on his peer</b> and is therefore an unambiguous distinguishing mark sufficient for identification.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> otherwise: <b>Here they are disagreeing about</b> whether <b>a mole is likely to change</b> in appearance and size <b>after death.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the anonymous first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds that it is likely to change after death.</b> It is insufficient for identification because it may have looked different when the person was alive. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai, <b>holds that it is not likely to change after death</b> and is reliable for identification. This marks the end of one version of the discussion about this issue.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rava said: Everyone</b> agrees that <b>distinguishing marks</b> are relied upon <b>by rabbinic</b> law. However, this is referring to ordinary distinguishing marks. Marks that are exceptionally unusual may be relied upon even according to Torah law. <b>And here,</b> in the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai, it is <b>about</b> whether <b>a mole</b>

Daf 120b

<b>is an unambiguous distinguishing mark</b> that <b>they disagree.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Mahavai, <b>holds</b> that a mole <b>is an unambiguous distinguishing mark</b> and may be relied upon by Torah law. Consequently, if a man’s corpse was identified in this manner, his wife may remarry. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the anonymous first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that a mole <b>is not an unambiguous distinguishing mark.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>According to the</b> first <b>version, that Rava said</b> that <b>distinguishing marks are</b> recognized as valid identification <b>by Torah</b> law, there is a question: <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in the mishna: <b>Although there are distinguishing marks on his body and his personal belongings,</b> one may not rely on these as identification, implying that distinguishing marks are not valid identification by Torah law?
The Gemara answers: The mishna’s intent is that ordinary distinguishing marks on <b>one’s body,</b> which constitute only weak evidence to a person’s identity, e.g., <b>that he was tall or short,</b> are not valid identification. Additionally, one cannot rely upon distinguishing marks on his <b>personal belongings, as we are concerned about borrowing,</b> i.e., perhaps the deceased had borrowed the clothes he was wearing from someone else. The Gemara asks: <b>But if we are concerned about borrowing,</b> then, with regard to returning lost property, <b>how can we return a donkey based</b> solely <b>upon distinguishing marks on the saddle?</b> Why don’t we consider the possibility that the saddle was borrowed?
The Gemara answers: <b>People do not</b> normally <b>borrow a saddle because it bruises the donkey,</b> as the saddle must fit exactly to the donkey’s measurements. The Gemara raises further objections based upon the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier: <b>If he found</b> the lost bill of divorce <b>tied to a purse, or a money bag, or a ring,</b> he may rely upon the distinguishing marks on those items and deliver the bill of divorce to the woman. But <b>how can we return it</b> and not be concerned that these belongings may have been lent to someone else whose bill of divorce is tied to them?
The Gemara answers: The case of the <b>ring</b> is referring to a signet ring, which one does not lend, <b>because he is concerned about forgery,</b> i.e., that the borrower might use it to forge his consent on documents without his knowledge. With regard to <b>a purse or a money bag, people consider it a bad omen</b> to lend them out <b>and do not lend</b> them to others. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that the reason not to permit a woman to remarry and not to accept that her husband is dead based upon the distinguishing marks found on <b>his personal belongings</b> is that the distinguishing marks referred to are only general ones, e.g., he wore <b>white or red</b> clothing, but they are not unambiguous distinguishing marks.
§ We learned in the mishna: <b>And even if one saw him cut open [<i>meguyyad</i>]</b> and severely wounded, one may not testify that he died. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> a person who is <b>cut open is</b> fit <b>to live</b> for much time afterward? The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from what was taught in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 1:6): A dead <b>person renders</b> other people and objects <b>impure only when his soul</b> actually <b>departs, even if he is cut open</b> and severely wounded, <b>and even if he is</b> clearly <b>dying.</b> From this we may deduce that <b>he does not</b> yet <b>render</b> others <b>ritually impure,</b> as he still has some life in him, <b>but he is not</b> fit <b>to live</b> for much time afterward.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The contradiction raised is <b>not difficult: This</b> mishna here <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> while <b>that</b> mishna from tractate <i>Oholot</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may testify about</b> the death of a person who is <b>cut open, but one may not testify about a crucified person. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Even concerning</b> a person who is <b>cut open, one may not testify</b> that he is dead <b>because</b> his wound <b>can be scorched,</b> and this cauterization of the wound may stop the flow of blood <b>and</b> allow him to <b>survive.</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But can you establish</b> the mishna to be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar? Isn’t it taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> (121a): <b>An incident</b> occurred <b>in Asya in which they lowered a certain</b> man <b>into the sea</b> on a rope, <b>and</b> when they pulled the rope back to land <b>only his leg came up in their hands.</b> They were not certain whether he was alive or dead. <b>The Sages said:</b> If his leg was cut <b>from the knee and above,</b> his wife <b>may marry,</b> as he would not survive such a wound; if his leg was cut only <b>from the knee and below, she may not marry.</b> This indicates that someone cut open in the first manner is assumed to be dead. If this follows Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar’s opinion, why doesn’t it say that there is a concern that he might be alive even if the leg was cut from the knee and above?
The Gemara answers: <b>Water is different, as it aggravates the wound.</b> Since he was in the water, it can be assumed that such a wound will certainly lead to death.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥanna say: I myself saw an Arab who took his sword [<i>safseira</i>] and cut open his camel, and</b> the camel died so quickly that it <b>could not</b> even <b>cease its braying</b> before it died? This indicates that a living being that is cut open has no chance of surviving. <b>Abaye said: That</b> camel <b>was emaciated</b> and weak, causing it to die immediately, but a normal camel would not have died so quickly.
<b>Rava said</b> a different resolution to the apparent contradiction between the mishna here and the mishna in tractate <i>Oholot</i>: The mishna here is referring to a case where the man was cut open <b>with a white-hot knife, and everyone agrees</b> that one may not testify to the death of a person wounded in such a manner, as the wound would close due to the heat.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>Or</b> even if one saw that a wild <b>animal was eating</b> parts of him, one may not testify that he died. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> where the animal was eating <b>from a place</b> on his body <b>that does not</b> cause <b>his soul to depart,</b> i.e., does not inevitably lead to death, such as his hand or foot. <b>But</b> if the animal was eating <b>from a place</b> on his body <b>that does</b> cause <b>his soul to depart, one may testify</b> to his death.
<b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: If</b> someone <b>cut</b> a man’s <b>two</b> passageways, the trachea and the esophagus, <b>or most of</b> the way through the <b>two</b> passageways, <b>and</b> the maimed person <b>fled, one may testify</b> to his death.
The Gemara challenges that conclusion: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Shmuel said: If</b> someone <b>cut</b> a man’s <b>two</b> passageways, <b>or most of</b> the way through the <b>two</b> passageways, <b>and</b> the maimed person <b>gestured and</b> thereby <b>communicated: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, then these</b> onlookers <b>should write</b> it <b>and deliver</b> it to her. Since only a living person may give a bill of divorce, this indicates that the maimed man is considered alive. The Gemara answers: <b>He is</b> still <b>alive</b> at the moment, <b>but he will eventually die</b> from the wound. Consequently, he may appoint an agent to deliver a bill of divorce to his wife, but after a while one may testify that he is dead.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that such a wound is definitely fatal, one who unintentionally wounds another in this manner <b>should be exiled on his account,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of one who unintentionally kills another. <b>Why is</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> one unintentionally <b>cut</b> the <b>two</b> passageways of another person, <b>or most of</b> the thickness of <b>the two, he is not exiled?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>But it was stated with regard to</b> that <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rav Hoshaya said: We are concerned that perhaps the wind aggravated his</b> condition and actually caused his death, in which case the perpetrator is not culpable for the death and should not be exiled. <b>Alternatively, perhaps he,</b> the maimed person,

Daf 121a

<b>hastened his</b> own <b>death.</b> For instance, if the maimed man convulsed intensely, injuring himself, the perpetrator is not culpable for the death and should not be exiled. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between these</b> two considerations, that the wind or the victim himself hastened his death?
The Gemara explains: There is a practical difference between them in a case <b>where one cut</b> someone <b>in a house of marble</b> that was closed on every side, in which there was no wind, <b>and</b> the victim <b>convulsed. Alternatively,</b> there is a difference in a case <b>where one cut</b> the victim <b>outside,</b> where there is wind, <b>and</b> the victim <b>did not convulse</b> at all.
§ It was taught in the mishna that one may testify to someone’s death only when he saw the corpse within three days of the individual’s death. However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> ben Bava <b>says: Not every</b> person, nor every place, nor every hour is identical. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Did Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava disagree</b> with the Rabbis with the intent <b>to</b> rule more <b>leniently</b> and hold that sometimes one may testify to the identity of one who died even if he did not see the body within three days of his death? <b>Or, did he disagree</b> with the intent <b>to</b> rule more <b>stringently</b> and hold that sometimes one may not testify even if he saw the body within three days of the individual’s death?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution: <b>A certain man drowned in</b> a place called <b>Carmi, and they drew him out</b> of the water <b>near Bei Hedya after three days, and Rav Dimi from Neharde’a allowed his wife to marry. And furthermore, a certain man drowned in the Tigris</b> River, <b>and they drew him out</b> of the river <b>onto the Bridge of Shabistana, and Rava allowed his wife to marry based upon his friends’ testimony,</b> although the body was seen only <b>five days after</b> death.
<b>Granted, if you say</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava <b>disagreed</b> with the intent <b>to</b> rule more <b>leniently, these</b> Sages <b>who acted</b> here, allowing these women to marry, acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava. But if you say he disagreed</b> with the intent <b>to</b> rule more <b>stringently, in accordance with whose</b> opinion did these Sages <b>act?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Water is different, since it contracts</b> the body, preventing it from bloating and changing shape.
The Gemara wonders about this: <b>But didn’t you say</b> (120b) that <b>water aggravates a wound</b> by causing additional swelling? The Gemara answers: <b>This applies when there is a wound, but when there is no wound, the water contracts</b> the body and thereby prevents the shape of the face from changing. The Gemara comments: <b>And this applies</b> only in a case <b>where they drew him out</b> of the water and <b>viewed him at that time. But</b> if the viewing <b>was delayed</b> for some time after the body was drawn from the water, it certainly <b>will have become</b> very <b>bloated,</b> making it impossible to positively identify.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a man <b>fell into the water</b> and did not come out, <b>whether</b> the body of water <b>has</b> a visible <b>end or does not have</b> a visible <b>end, his wife is prohibited</b> from remarrying. There is no absolute proof that the man died, as it is possible that he emerged from the water some distance away. <b>Rabbi Meir said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a certain</b> person <b>who fell into the Great Cistern and emerged</b> only <b>after three days.</b> This is evidence that sometimes one may survive a fall into water, even when everyone assumes he is dead.
<b>Rabbi Yosei said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a blind man who descended to immerse</b> for ritual purity <b>in a cave, and his guide descended after him,</b> and they disappeared there, <b>and they remained there long enough for their souls to have departed, and</b> the Sages <b>permitted their wives to marry</b> because they had disappeared into the water and not emerged. <b>And</b> there was <b>another incident in Asya in which they lowered a certain</b> man <b>into the sea</b> on a rope, <b>and</b> when they pulled the rope back to land <b>only his leg came up in their hands,</b> and they were not certain whether he was alive or dead. <b>The Sages said:</b> If his leg was cut <b>from the knee and above,</b> his wife <b>may marry,</b> as he did not survive such a wound; if his leg was cut only <b>from the knee and below, she may not marry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> If a man <b>fell into the water, whether</b> the body of water <b>has</b> a visible <b>end or does not have</b> a visible <b>end, his wife is prohibited</b> from marrying; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> If he fell into a body of water <b>with</b> a visible <b>end, his wife is permitted</b> to marry, <b>but</b> if he fell into a body of water <b>with no end, his wife is prohibited</b> from marrying.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> defining a body of <b>water with</b> a visible <b>end? Abaye said: Any</b> body of water <b>where one stands</b> in one place <b>and can see</b> the shore <b>in</b> all <b>four directions</b> is considered water with a visible end, since anyone emerging from the water would be seen. However, if the body of water is so large that it is impossible to see its shore on all sides, the individual may have emerged at a place where he could not be seen by others standing at the place where he fell in.
There was <b>a certain man who drowned in the lake in</b> a place called <b>Samkei. Rav Sheila allowed his wife to marry</b> based on the testimony of witnesses who saw that he entered the water and did not emerge. <b>Rav said to Shmuel: Come, let us excommunicate him</b> for having issued this ruling. Shmuel <b>said to him: Let us first send him</b> a message and clarify whether he had a sufficient reason to issue this ruling.
<b>They sent him</b> the following question: When a man disappears in <b>an endless body of water, is his wife a forbidden or a permitted</b> woman, i.e., may she remarry? <b>He sent</b> back <b>to them: His wife is forbidden.</b> They asked him further: <b>Is the lake of Samkei a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end or an endless body of water? He sent</b> a response <b>to them: It is an endless body of water,</b> since one cannot see the water’s edge on every side. They then asked him: If so, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>the Master,</b> i.e., Rav Sheila, <b>acted this way,</b> allowing the wife to remarry?
He answered them: <b>I erred</b> in my reasoning. <b>I thought: Since the waters are gathered and stagnant</b> and not flowing like a river, <b>they are considered as a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end. But that is not so. Since there are waves</b> in this body of water, <b>say that the waves carried him</b> away from our sight, allowing him to emerge without being seen.
In light of this response, <b>Shmuel recited</b> this verse <b>about Rav: “No mischief shall befall the righteous”</b> (Proverbs 12:21). Since the righteous Rav waited and did not excommunicate Rav Sheila, he was prevented from causing him injustice. Rav Sheila had been mistaken and had not intentionally violated the decree of the Sages prohibiting a woman from remarrying on the basis of her husband having disappeared into an endless body of water. <b>Rav recited</b> this verse <b>about Shmuel: “But salvation</b> lies <b>in much counsel”</b> (Proverbs 11:14), since it was Shmuel’s advice that caused Rav to wait.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving two people</b> who <b>were fishing with nets on the Jordan</b> River, <b>and one of them entered a cave containing a</b> pond of <b>fish</b> next to the shore. Meanwhile, <b>the sun set and</b> the one who had entered the cave <b>could not see the cave’s opening</b> and did not exit, so his friend thought he had drowned. <b>His friend waited long enough for his soul to have departed and came and notified</b> the man’s <b>household</b> that he had drowned. <b>The following day the sun rose, and</b> the man in the cave <b>recognized the opening of the cave</b> and exited through it. <b>And he came and found profuse eulogizing in his house. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said</b> about this: <b>How great are the words of the Sages, who said:</b> If a man fell into <b>a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end, his wife is permitted</b> to marry, but in a case of water <b>with no end, his wife is prohibited</b> from marrying.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> even in the case of <b>a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end, let us also be concerned about a cave containing a</b> pond of <b>fish.</b> Even if the individual did not emerge for a long period of time, it is possible that he entered a cave and is still alive. The Gemara answers: <b>A cave containing a</b> pond of <b>fish is not common in a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: That which the Sages said,</b> that if a man fell into <b>an endless body of water, his wife is prohibited</b> from remarrying, <b>applies</b> only <b>to an ordinary person</b> who is not well known and could slip away secretly and live in anonymity, hiding the fact that he survived. <b>But</b> it does <b>not</b> apply to <b>a Torah scholar,</b> because <b>if he would emerge</b> from the water, <b>publicity would be</b> generated and the news of his survival would spread. The Gemara rejects this: <b>That is not so. It is no different</b> for <b>an ordinary man and it is no different</b> for <b>a Torah scholar. After the fact,</b> i.e., if she remarried, <b>yes,</b> she may remain with her new husband, but she may <b>not</b> remarry <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Gamliel said: Once I was traveling on a boat, and</b> from a distance <b>I saw a boat that shattered</b> and sank. <b>And I was grieved over</b> the apparent death of <b>the Torah scholar who was on board. And who was it? Rabbi Akiva. But when I disembarked onto dry land, he came, and sat, and deliberated before me about <i>halakha</i>. I said to him: My son, who brought you up</b> from the water? <b>He said to me: A plank from the boat came to me, and I bent my head before each and every wave that came toward me.</b> The waves did not wash me off of the board, and I reached the shore.
<b>From here the Sages stated: If wicked people come upon a person, he should bend his head before them.</b> That is, he should temporarily restrain himself and not fight them, and he will therefore be saved. After this parenthetical statement, the Gemara returns to Rabban Gamliel’s story. <b>I said at that moment: How great are the words of the Sages, who said:</b> If a man fell into <b>a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end,</b> his wife <b>is permitted</b> to remarry. But in a case of <b>an endless body of water,</b> his wife <b>is prohibited</b> from remarrying.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Akiva said: Once I was traveling on a boat, and I saw a certain boat sinking at sea, and I was grieved over</b> the apparent death of <b>the Torah scholar who was on board. And who was it? Rabbi Meir. But when I disembarked at the province of Cappadocia, he came, and sat, and deliberated before me about <i>halakha</i>. I said to him: My son, who brought you up</b> from the water? <b>He said to me:</b> One <b>wave carried me to another, and that other</b> wave <b>to another, until</b> I reached the shore, and a wave <b>cast me up onto dry land. I said at that moment: How great are the words of the Sages, who said:</b> If a man fell into <b>a body of water with</b> a visible <b>end, his wife is permitted</b> to remarry. But in a case of <b>an endless body of water, his wife is prohibited</b> from remarrying.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If an individual <b>fell into a lion’s den, one may not testify about him</b> that he died, since the lions might not have killed him. If he fell <b>into a pit filled with snakes and scorpions, one may testify</b> about his death, since it is certain that they killed him. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: Even</b> if he fell <b>into a pit filled with snakes and scorpions, one may not testify about him</b> that he died, because <b>we are concerned</b>

Daf 121b

that <b>perhaps he is a charmer [<i>ḥabbar</i>]</b> of snakes and scorpions who knows magic or some stratagem to keep them from harming him. <b>And the first <i>tanna</i></b> holds that we need not be concerned about this possibility, <b>as, due to the pressure</b> of his body falling on top of them, <b>they will harm him,</b> even if he could control them under other circumstances.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If one <b>fell into a blazing furnace, one may testify about him</b> that he has died. If he fell <b>into</b> a boiling <b>cauldron filled</b> with <b>wine or oil, one may</b> also <b>testify about him</b> that he has died. <b>In the name of Rabbi Aḥa, they said:</b> If he fell into a cauldron <b>of oil, one may testify about him</b> that he has died, <b>because this ignites</b> the fire even more. Through the force of his fall, oil will splash into the fire and increase the heat of the cauldron. However, if he fell into a cauldron <b>of wine, one may not testify about him</b> that he has died, <b>because</b> when wine splashes into the fire <b>it extinguishes</b> the fire. <b>They said to him: At first it</b> partially <b>extinguishes</b> the fire <b>but eventually it ignites</b> it even more, and therefore it can be assumed that he has died.
§ The mishna stated that <b>Rabbi Meir said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a certain</b> individual <b>who fell into the Great Cistern</b> and emerged after three days. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They said to Rabbi Meir: One does not mention miraculous acts</b> to teach general <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> about that story defines it as an example of <b>miraculous acts? If we say</b> the fact <b>that he did not eat or drink</b> for three days and still survived is miraculous, <b>but isn’t it written: “Fast for me, and neither eat nor drink</b> three days, night or day” (Esther 4:16), demonstrating that one may survive this experience naturally?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the miraculous element is <b>that he did not sleep</b> during those three days, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If one says: I hereby take on <b>an oath that I will not sleep for three days,</b> the court <b>flogs him</b> for taking an oath in vain, <b>and he may sleep immediately</b> because it is impossible to remain awake for three consecutive days.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Meir, what is the reason</b> this was not a miraculous incident? The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Kahana said: There were</b> several levels of <b>arches</b> built <b>on top of</b> other <b>arches</b> within the Great Cistern, and he supported himself on the arches and slept. <b>And the Rabbis</b> said that <b>they were</b> made <b>of marble</b> and it was impossible to hold onto them and sleep. <b>And Rabbi Meir</b> assumed that <b>it is inconceivable that he didn’t grasp</b> some part of an arch for a short time <b>and sleep a little,</b> and therefore this incident does not qualify as a miracle.
<b>The Sages taught: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving the daughter of Neḥunya the well digger, who fell into the Great Cistern, and they came and notified Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa</b> and asked that he pray for her. After <b>the first hour, he said to them:</b> She is at <b>peace</b> and unharmed. After <b>the second</b> hour, <b>he said to them:</b> She is at <b>peace.</b> After <b>the third</b> hour <b>he said to them: She has ascended</b> from the cistern.
When she came to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa, <b>he said to her: My daughter, who pulled you up</b> from the cistern? <b>She said to him: A male sheep,</b> i.e., a ram, <b>happened by</b> and sensed <b>me</b> in that cistern, <b>and</b> there was <b>an old man leading him</b> who pulled me out. <b>They said</b> to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa: <b>Are you a prophet</b> with knowledge of what is happening far away? <b>He said to them,</b> using a figure of speech from the Bible: <b>“I am not a prophet, nor the son of a prophet am I”</b> (Amos 7:14). <b>Rather,</b> I reasoned as follows: Could it be that concerning <b>the endeavor that the righteous</b> Neḥunya <b>is engaged</b> in, i.e., digging for the benefit of the public, <b>his offspring would stumble upon</b> its fruits and thereby be killed? I therefore knew that God would certainly save her.
<b>Rabbi Abba said: Even so, the son</b> of Neḥunya the well digger <b>died of thirst,</b> and the merit of his father, who attended to the water supply, did not protect him, <b>as is stated: “And around Him it storms [<i>nisara</i>] mightily”</b> (Psalms 50:3), <b>which teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is exacting with His surroundings,</b> i.e., the righteous who are close to Him, <b>up to a hairsbreadth [<i>sa’ara</i>],</b> so that even slight deviations can elicit severe punishment. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> This idea is derived <b>from here: “A God dreaded in the great council of the holy ones, and feared by all that are about Him”</b> (Psalms 89:8). This indicates that God is most feared by those that are nearest to Him, i.e., the righteous, because He is more exacting of them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Even</b> if one <b>heard from the women,</b> who were <b>saying: So-and-so died, this is sufficient</b> in order to testify to his death. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even if one heard from the children,</b> who were <b>saying: We are going to eulogize and bury so-and-so,</b> that is also sufficient. Furthermore, one may rely upon someone mentioning that a man died, regardless of <b>whether</b> the speaker <b>intends</b> to testify and thereby allow the man’s wife to remarry <b>or whether he does not intend</b> to offer formal testimony.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava says: With regard to a Jew</b> who offers this information, it may be relied upon <b>even if he intends</b> for his statement to be considered formal testimony. However, <b>with regard to a gentile, if he intended</b> to testify, <b>his testimony is not</b> considered valid <b>testimony.</b> His statement is relied upon only when he does not intend to state it as formal testimony.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to relying on what children said, that they are going to eulogize and bury so-and-so, the Gemara asks: <b>Perhaps they will not go;</b> perhaps they only assumed that the individual would die, but in the end he didn’t. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> It is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the children <b>say: We are coming from eulogizing and burying so-and-so.</b>
The Gemara asks: Since they are children, <b>perhaps it was merely a grasshopper</b> with which they played <b>that died, and they brought it out</b> as if to its funeral, calling it <b>by</b> the <b>name of</b> the individual suspected to be dead, and their statement should not be considered valid proof of his death. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a situation <b>where the children say: Such and such rabbis were there; such and such eulogizers were there,</b> so that it is clear that they were referring to an event that truly occurred.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <b>With regard to a gentile, if he intended</b> to testify, his testimony is not considered valid testimony. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where he intended to permit</b> the woman to remarry through his testimony, <b>but</b> if <b>he</b> merely <b>intended to testify</b> about the man’s death, <b>his testimony is</b> considered <b>testimony.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How do we know</b> the intention of the gentile? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> If <b>he came to the court and said: So-and-so died, allow his wife to marry, this is</b> an instance of <b>intending to permit</b> her to remarry. If he said simply: <b>He died, this is</b> an instance of merely <b>intending to testify.</b>
This <b>was also stated</b> by other <i>amora’im</i>. <b>Reish Lakish said: They taught</b> this <b>only when one intended to permit</b> the woman to remarry, <b>but if he</b> merely <b>intended to testify</b> about the man’s death, <b>his testimony is</b> considered valid <b>testimony. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: Didn’t such an incident occur involving</b> Rabbi <b>Oshaya the Distinguished, who permitted</b> women to marry based upon the testimony of gentiles while he was <b>with eighty-five Elders?
